text: Course: ACTG 210 — Introduction to Financial Accounting Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Concepts and standards underlying the preparation and analysis of external reports; alternative effects and role of accounting in the business environment and capital markets. Course Information: Previously listed as ACTG 110. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 211 — Introduction to Managerial Accounting Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Management planning and control; cost concepts and measurement; cost accounting systems; analysis of cost and volume-profit relationships; standard costs and variances; and budget preparation. Prerequisites: ACTG 210. Accounting majors need a grade of C or better in ACTG 210. Course Information: Previously listed as ACTG 111. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 315 — Intermediate Financial Accounting I Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and standards related to asset valuation, revenue recognition, gain and loss recognition, and their impact on income measurement and financial position. Prerequisites: Average grade of B or higher in ACTG 210 and ACTG 211. Course Information: For satisfactory progress in the Accounting major, students must receive a C or better in ACTG 315 and may be repeated only once. Transfer credit may be accepted from an AACSB accredited institution on a case-by-case basis.

Course: ACTG 316 — Intermediate Financial Accounting II Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in accounting and financial reporting including: cash flow statements, income taxes, long-term debt and leases, investments, derivative securities, and contingencies and employee retirement benefits and stockholders' equity. Prerequisites: Grade of C in ACTG 315.

Course: ACTG 326 — Cost Accounting Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Design of cost accounting systems; alternate costing methods; costing for decision making; budgeting and performance evaluation. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACTG 210 and grade of C or better in ACTG 211. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 355 — Business Law I: Commercial Transactions Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Commercial transactions including: contracts, sales of goods, negotiable instruments, and secured transactions. Prerequisites: A passing grade in ACTG 211 or the equivalent.

Course: ACTG 392 — Data Analytics for Accountants Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students with experience in accounting data analytics thinking, key terminology, and hands on experience with analytics tools and techniques. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACTG 210 and Grade of C or better in ACTG 211 and IDS 270. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 394 — Special Topics in Accounting - Undergraduate Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Investigates selected contemporary accounting topics using readings in both academic and professional journals as well as cases for analysis. Prerequisites: A passing grade in both ACTG 316 and ACTG 326.

Course: ACTG 396 — Independent Study in Accounting - Undergraduate Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent study in approved topics; written report prepared under the guidance of a faculty member is required. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACTG 316 ; and Grade of C or better in ACTG 326 ; and declaration of a major and submission of form of approval to the department head one week before the beginning of the semester.

Course: ACTG 417 — Advanced Financial Accounting Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Financial accounting theory for business combinations, consolidated financial statements, international transactions and investments, and partnership accounting. Prerequisites: Grade of D or better in ACTG 316. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ACTG 435 — Auditing Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the audit function; ethical and legal environment; audit standards; objectives and procedures; materiality and audit risk; sampling; auditing in a computer environment; reporting. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACTG 315. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 436 — Advanced Audit Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Builds on the skills obtained in the introduction to auditing course and will focus on strengthening students’ understanding of fundamental aspects of an audit of financial statements and internal controls over financial reporting. Prerequisites: ACTG 435. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 444 — Federal Income Tax for Financial Planning Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 Description: Concepts and provisions of federal income taxation applicable to individual taxpayers, partnerships, individuals and trusts as it relates to certified financial planning careers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACTG 210. Course Information: Credit is not given for ACTG 444 if the student has credit in ACTG 445. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Federal Income Tax for Financial Planning
metadata.subject: Accounting (ACTG)

text: Course: ACTG 445 — Federal Income Tax I Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Concepts and provisions of federal income taxation as applicable to individual taxpayers, partnerships, individuals and trusts. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACTG 315. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for ACTG 445 if the student has credit for ACTG 508. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 446 — Federal Income Tax II Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Concepts and provisions of federal income taxation on corporations and partnerships; special problems in reorganization, liquidations, and personal holding companies. Prerequisites: A passing grade in ACTG 445 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 447 — Tax Research Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides students with experience in conducting tax research for hypothetical fact patterns similar to those their future clients will face. Prerequisites: ACTG 445 ; and credit or concurrent registration in ACTG 446. Credit or concurrent registration in ACTG 446 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ACTG 446 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Prereq Codes (parsed): ACTG 446 Coreq Codes (parsed): ACTG 446

Course: ACTG 456 — Business Law II: Business Organizations Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Business organizaions, including: agency, general partnerships, limited partnerships, corporations, limited liability companies, securities regulations, bankruptcy, suretyship, bailments, real property, wills and trusts, accounting liability. Prerequisites: A passing grade in ACTG 355 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ACTG 457 — Foundations for Sustainable Business Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to sustainable business foundations: setting sustainability goals and key performance indicators, governance, stakeholder engagement and communication, strategic operations, technology integration, financial accountability, and reporting. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as IDS 457 and MGMT 457.

Course: ACTG 465 — Governmental and Non-Profit Accounting Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Financial transaction analysis and recording system; budget preparation and control; concepts and principles underlying the financial reports of governmental and non-profit organizations. Prerequisites: A passing grade in ACTG 316. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ACTG 470 — Ethical Environment of Business Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An examination of the decision making process on both the individual and organizational levels. The effect of moral, legal, and economic factors on the decision making process. Prerequisites: A passing grade in ACTG 211. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ACTG 474 — Accounting Information Systems Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Skills and concepts that enable the documentation, design and use of accounting information systems, understanding transaction cycles, sound internal controls, accounting software and the electronic business environment. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACTG 210 and Grade of C or better in ACTG 211 ; and IDS 200. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 475 — Database Accounting Systems Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Concepts and principles of designing database systems to perform accounting functions, applications of microcomputer accounting software packages systems design tools, and computerized transaction cycles. Prerequisites: A passing grade in both ACTG 211 and IDS 200. Course Information: Same as IDS 475. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 476 — Enterprise Accounting Systems Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Uses ERP software and analytics to teach transaction processing, internal controls, dashboard design, analytical tools and visual presentation of accounting data used to manage large organizations. Prerequisites: ACTG 475 or equivalent database experience. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Good Excel skills are very helpful; IDS 331 would be an excellent background course.

Course: ACTG 484 — International Accounting Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Financial accounting for international operations, multinational managerial accounting and control, comparative international accounting, international reporting issues and international taxation. Prerequisites: Grade of D or better in ACTG 316. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ACTG 485 — Valuation and Analysis Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Financial analysis and valuation of firms. Corporate strategies, financial reporting issues and market perceptions. Prerequisites: ACTG 315 and FIN 300 for undergraduate students. One accounting and one finance class or consent of the instructor for graduate students. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ACTG 492 — Accounting Data Analytics Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Accounting professionals look at huge financial and transactional data available from multitude of corporate and external sources. Businesses can use information and analytics tools to improve their performance metrics and generate valuable insights. Prerequisites: ACTG 315 and ACTG 326 and ACTG 474 ; or ACTG 500. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in ACTG 435 and Grade of C or better in ACTG 476.

Course: ACTG 493 — Accounting Cases, Research and Analysis Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines US GAAP, alternatives, SEC filings and company financial statements, through cases and research projects using various research methodologies. Satisfies research requirements for CPA candidacy. Prerequisites: A passing grade in ACTG 316. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ACTG 494 — Special Topics in Accounting Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 1-4 Description: Topics rotate in various areas of accounting, including but not restricted to financial, managerial, governmental and nonprofit accounting, law and business ethics. Explores current issues and proposed alternatives. Prerequisites: Two courses in accounting or finance beyond ACTG 211 and FIN 300 or the equivalent.

Course: ACTG 495 — Competitive Strategy Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 4 Description: Multidisciplinary analysis of organization strategy and policy, using case method and/or business simulation. Assignments involve extensive library research and oral and written reports. Prerequisites: Senior standing in the College of Business Administration and completion of all other core courses; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for ACTG 495 if the student has credit in IDS 495 or MGMT 495 or FIN 495.

Course: ACTG 499 — Research Experience Subject: Accounting (ACTG) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the supervision of a faculty member. The faculty member and student will determine the research project. Each student must submit a report and each student must participate at a research event on campus. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: AH 100 — Introduction to Art and Art History Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Forms, meanings, and purposes of art. Discussion of techniques, styles and content as well as historical and social contexts, in various media and cultures. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Art and Art History
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 101 — The Naked and the Nude: Studies in Visual Literacy Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Diverse social and psychological aspects of nakedness, nudity and related forms of bodily vulnerability studied through a wide-ranging history of art. Team-taught by the entire Art History faculty. Rigorous training in visual literacy. Museum visit. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: The Naked and the Nude: Studies in Visual Literacy
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 110 — World History of Art and the Built Environment I Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 4 Description: Comprehensive overview of how world art, architecture, and visual culture from prehistory to 1400 CE respond to and shape culture, religion, politics and history. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: World History of Art and the Built Environment I
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 111 — World History of Art and the Built Environment II Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 4 Description: Comprehensive overview of how world art, architecture, and visual culture from 1400 CE through contemporary respond to and shape culture, religion, politics and history. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: World History of Art and the Built Environment II
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 122 — History of Chicago Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the architecture and built environment of Chicago from its founding in the early nineteenth century until today. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: AH 125 — Introduction to the Art and Architecture of Asia Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Using cross-cultural case studies, this course introduces students to some of the major artistic methods, monuments, and themes associated with Asian art and architecture. Course Information: Same as GLAS 125. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Art and Architecture of Asia
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 130 — Photography in History Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Developments in the history of photography including cultural, social, commercial, scientific, political and artistic applications, and its transformation of the related social meanings of art and subjectivity. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Recommended Background: Any art history course; any photography studio course. Past course.

Course: AH 140 — World Architecture, Climate, and Ecology: An Alternative History Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Offers a history of world architecture with emphasis on world societies that are not conventionally studied and therefore marginalized in the western canon from the perspective of climate and ecology. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: World Architecture, Climate, and Ecology: An Alternative History
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 150 — Art and Money Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Surveys topics in the intertwined histories of art and money, asking how works of art from various periods and places might illuminate the often mysterious workings of economic life. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: AH 160 — Trends in International Contemporary Art Since 1960 Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Surveys international trends in art since 1960. Emphasis is on movements, new media, intermedia, criticism and theory. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Trends in International Contemporary Art Since 1960
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 172 — Visual Culture of the Ancient Americas Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction to visual and material cultures of the indigenous peoples of the Western Hemisphere from the end of the last ice age until the arrival of Europeans in the 16th century. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Visual Culture of the Ancient Americas
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 180 — Intro to Museum & Exhibition Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Engages students with museum and exhibition histories, frameworks and experiences through activities, reading and films, field trips and lectures by professionals and faculty in affiliated areas including anthropology, art, and history. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: AH 201 — Reading and Writing Art Criticism Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the writing and reading of art criticism in a variety of media. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 204 — Greek Art and Archaeology Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Contributions of archaeological excavations to the study of ancient Greece, 600 BC to 31 BC. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as CL 204 , and HIST 204. Credit is not given for AH 204 if the student has credit in CL 215. Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: AH 205 — Roman Art and Archaeology Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Contributions of archaeological excavations to the study of ancient Rome and her empire 1000 BC-400 AD. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as CL 205 , and HIST 205. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: AH 206 — Museums and Exhibitions in Motion Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Students will shadow museum staff, and learn about traditional and leading-edge exhibition craft through example and practice. They will look at exhibitions, and examine creative and critical interventions made by artists, activists and scholars. Prerequisites: AH 180.

Course: AH 207 — Topics in Architecture, Art, and Design Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the history of architecture, art and design. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Architecture, Art, and Design
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 208 — Topics in Modern Architecture, Art and Design Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Varying topics in how architecture, art and design have impacted the designed world over the last several centuries. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Modern Architecture, Art and Design
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 209 — Near Eastern Art and Archaeology Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the art, archaeology, and material culture of ancient societies in western Asia (Mesopotamia, Syria, the Levant, Anatolia, and Iran) from the first settled villages of the Neolithic to Alexander the Great (ca 9600-330 BCE). Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as CL 209. Credit is not given for AH 209 if the student has credit in ARST 209 or CL 209. Previously listed as ARST 209. Class Schedule Information: To be properly, registered students should enroll in one Lecture and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Recommended Background: AH 110.

Course: AH 210 — Ancient Egyptian Art and Archaeology Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Ancient Egypt from 6000-1000 BCE. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as BLST 210 and CL 210. Credit is not given for AH 210 if the student has credit in ARST 210 or CL 210 or BLST 210. Previously listed as ARST 210. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Recommended Background: Credit in AH 100 or AH 110.

Course: AH 211 — History of Urbanism Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The history of the city: Its form, meaning, function and representation from classical antiquity to the present. Selected topics in the history of settlement patterns and the planning of cities. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 212 — The Contemporary Built Environment Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Varying topics in the way the urban and rural landscape has been treated over the last several decades. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level.

Course: AH 218 — Pompeii: Everyday Life in a Roman Town Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the Roman town of Pompeii, including its history, society, politics, economy, religion, art, architecture, and entertainments. Course Information: Same as CL 218 and HIST 218. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Pompeii: Everyday Life in a Roman Town
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 219 — Art and Architecture of East Asia Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the historic and contemporary art and architecture of China, Korea and Japan, as well as the architecture and art of Asian Diasporas. Course Information: Same as GLAS 219. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Art and Architecture of East Asia
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 220 — Buddhist Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: A chronologically and thematically organized survey of Buddhist art and architecture in Asia and beyond. Course Information: Same as RELS 220 and GLAS 220. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: AH 221 — Medieval Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The development of early Christian, Byzantine, Romanesque, and Gothic architecture. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor.

Course: AH 222 — Renaissance Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The development of architecture in Renaissance Europe, with emphasis on the Italian Penninsula, from 1400 to 1600. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor.

Course: AH 223 — Baroque Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The development of architecture in Europe from 1600 to 1750. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 224 — North American Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The development of architecture, urbanism, and architectural theory over the last 500 years. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor.

Course: AH 225 — European Architecture, 1750-1900 Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The development of European architecture, urbanism and architectural theory from 1750 to 1900. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor.

Course: AH 228 — History of Landscape Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of developments in the history of gardens, parks, and other designed spaces over the past 1000 years. Course Information: Prerequistie(s): 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor.

Course: AH 230 — History of Photography I: 1820-1920 Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: History of photography from the 1820s to the beginning of the twentieth century. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 231 — History of Photography II: 1900 to Present Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: History of photography from the beginning of the twentieth century to the present. Course Information: Preerequisite(s): 3 hours of Art HIstory at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: History of Photography II: 1900 to Present
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 232 — History of Film I: 1890 to World War II Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: History of film from its beginnings in the 1890s up to World War II. Course Information: Same as ENGL 232 and MOVI 232. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: ENGL 131 or ENGL 132 or ENGL 230. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: History of Film I: 1890 to World War II
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 233 — History of Film II: World War II to the Present Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: History of film from World War II to contemporary movements in world cinema. Course Information: Same as ENGL 233 and MOVI 233. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: ENGL 131 or ENGL 132. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: History of Film II: World War II to the Present
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 234 — New Media Studies Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Developments in non-traditional visual media since 1960. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level.

Course: AH 235 — History of Design I: 1760-1925 Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of industrial and graphic design from the Industrial Revolution to 1925. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as DES 235. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: AH 236 — History of Design II: 1925 to the Present Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of industrial and graphic design from 1925 to the present. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as DES 236. Recommended Background: AH 235 or DES 235.

metadata.class_name: History of Design II: 1925 to the Present
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 242 — Early Christian and Byzantine Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The art, architecture and built environment of the Early Christian and Byzantine world from the third to fifteenth century CE. Religious and secular arts are surveyed in their historical contexts, paying attention to political, social and cultural circumstances. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level recommended but not required. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Early Christian and Byzantine Art and Architecture
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 243 — Medieval Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The art and architecture of the medieval west from 200 CE through the fifteenth century, including urbanism and the built environment. Religious and secular arts are surveyd in their historical context. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 244 — Islamic Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The art and architecture of Islamic civilizations from the seventh century to the modern period. Religious and secular arts are surveyed in their historical contexts. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor or 3 hours of Art History courses at the 100-level. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: AH 245 — Selected Topics in Medieval Architecture and Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the architecture, art and material culture of Europe and the Mediterranean region, from Late Antiguity through the western Middle Ages, Byzantium and/or Islam. Course Information: May be repeated in topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level.

metadata.class_name: Selected Topics in Medieval Architecture and Art
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 246 — European Avant-Garde Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Major movements of the avant-garde, including Cubism, Futurism, Suprematism, Surrealism, and Constructivism. Cross -fertilization of ideas between cultures and media, including literature, film, architecture and visual arts. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as CEES 246. Taught in English.

Course: AH 248 — Russian Visual and Material Culture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Non-textual manifestations of Russian culture such as painting, sculpture, architecture, design and decorative arts in a way that emphasizes how an object's compositional medium relates to its aesthetic and functional purposes. Prerequisites: Completion of ENGL 160 ; or any 100-level RUSS or AH course. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as RUSS 248. Taught in English.

Course: AH 249 — Beauty, Power, Imagination: The Italian Renaissance Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the radical changes brought forth by the Italian Renaissance in the way people thought and acted in the world, and in almost every aspect of life: art, architecture, culture, economics, politics, and society. Course Information: Same as CL 249 and ITAL 249. Taught in English. The program includes optional activities such as field trips to the Art Institute and to the Daley Library Rare Book Collection. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Beauty, Power, Imagination: The Italian Renaissance
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 250 — Italian Renaissance Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Painting, sculpture, and architecture in Italy from the fourteenth through the sixteenth centuries. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 251 — Northern Renaissance Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The art and architecture of the Low Countries, Germany, France, and England during the fiteenth and sixteenth centuries. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 252 — Art of the Baroque and Rococo Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: European painting, sculpture, and architecture of the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Art of the Baroque and Rococo
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 253 — Topics in Art and Architecture of the Renaissance and Baroque Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Varying topics in art and architecture from 14th through 18th-century Europe, with emphasis on historical, cultural and artistic contexts, and the development of particular periods or movements. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Art and Architecture of the Renaissance and Baroque
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 259 — Art in the Age of Enlightenment and Revolution Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of European art from the Rococo and the Neoclassical to the expansion of print culture, through the lens of the eighteenth century's sweeping political, social and cultural transformations. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee. Recommended Background: AH 111. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: Art in the Age of Enlightenment and Revolution
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 260 — European Art from 1750 to 1900 Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Painting and sculpture in Western Europe from Neo-Classicism through early Modernism. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 261 — European and American Art from 1900 to the Present Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The art of Western Europe and the United States from high Modernism and the historic avant-garde movements through post-modernism and the new media arts. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: European and American Art from 1900 to the Present
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 262 — American Art to 1945 Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The visual arts in the United States from the colonial period through 1945. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 263 — Latin American Colonial Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of Latin American art and architecture from European contact to independence. Prerequisites: Three hours of art history at the 100 level, or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as LALS 263.

Course: AH 264 — African American Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Interdisciplinary survey of the artistic production of African American artists from the nineteenth century to the present. Course Information: Same as BLST 264. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: AH 265 — History of Performance Art 1900 - Present Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the ways selected examples of performance art made since 1900 articulate responses to the conditions governing life in the places they were made (including Europe, U.S., Russia, Brazil, and Japan.) Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: AH 160 and AH 260. Creative Arts course.

Course: AH 266 — Topics in the Global Visual Environment Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the globalized visual environment, including urbanism and architecture, art, designed object, and landscapes. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the Global Visual Environment
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 270 — African Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the arts of the major tribal cultures of Sub-Saharan Africa. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as AAST 270.

Course: AH 271 — Native American Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the arts of the indigenous peoples of the United States and Canada. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as NAST 271.

Course: AH 273 — Visual Culture of the Ancient Andes Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the visual expressions, material culture, and built environment of ancient Andean civilization, from the earliest manifestations of societal complexity through the Spanish Conquest, with particular attention to the environmental, ideologi. Course Information: Same as LALS 239. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Visual Culture of the Ancient Andes
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 274 — Visual Culture of Ancient Mesoamerica Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the visual expressions, material culture, and built environment of ancient Mesoamerican civilization, from the earliest manifestations of societal complexity through the Spanish Conquest, with particular attention to the environmental, id. Course Information: Same as LALS 240. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: AH 275 — South Asian Visual Cultures Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Art and architectural traditions of South Asia, contextualizing their uses and meaning within Hindu, Buddhist, Islamic, and contemporary communities of India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: AH 276 — Topics in the Indigenous Art and Architecture of the Americas Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the art, architecture, and visual culture of the native peoples of North, Central and South America and the Caribbean. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: AH 273 or AH 274.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the Indigenous Art and Architecture of the Americas
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 278 — Topics in the Art, Architecture and Visual Culture of Asia Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the art, architecture, and visual cultures of Asia and Asian diasporas. Course Information: Same as GLAS 278. May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the Art, Architecture and Visual Culture of Asia
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 300 — Topics in Architecture, Art and Design Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the history of architecture, art and design, from the ancient world to the present. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AH 110 and AH 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in AH 110 and AH 111 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AH 110 and AH 111 Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: 3 hours in Art History in the general subject area. Prereq Codes (parsed): AH 110, AH 111 Coreq Codes (parsed): AH 110, AH 111

metadata.class_name: Topics in Architecture, Art and Design
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 301 — Theories and Methods in Art History Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: The methodologies and theories of the discipline and their application to selected problems. Prerequisites: Junior standing and major in art history, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AH 200. Required for majors in art history.

metadata.class_name: Theories and Methods in Art History
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 302 — Museum and Exhibition Workshop Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Taught as a practicum, and act as a laboratory for imaginative, justice focused approaches to the work of cultural institutions. It will be organized around the collaborative design and completion of an exhibition and/or program. Prerequisites: AH 180. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.
Course: AH 303 — Writing in Art History Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 1 Description: Research methodology and writing in the field of art history.

Course: AH 304 — Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic World Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the career of Alexander the Great of Macedon and his legacy in Greece, Egypt and the Near East, up until the arrival of the Romans. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as CL 304.

metadata.class_name: Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic World
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 322 — Contemporary Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Worldwide trends in recent architecture, urbanism, architectural theory and criticism. Course Information: AH 110 and AH 111 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: AH 399 — Collaborative Research Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Research experience under the guidance of faculty. Prerequisites: AH 303 and AH 301 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: AH 404 — Topics in Architecture, Art and Design Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in the history of European and North American architecture, art and design. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 200 level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s) if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Architecture, Art and Design
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 407 — The Power of the Image: Roman Sculpture as Propaganda Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Historical and thematic examination of the use of Roman sculpture, by emperors and private individuals of all social classes, as an instrument of personal and political propaganda. Prerequisites: one of the following courses: AH 204 , AH 205 , AH 110 , CL 101 , CL 103 , CL 203 , CL 204 , CL 205 , HIST 203 , HIST 205 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CL 407 and HIST 407. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: The Power of the Image: Roman Sculpture as Propaganda
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 420 — History of Architecture I Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to architecture, urbanism, and architectural theory worldwide from antiquity to 1450. Prerequisites: Graduate standing.

Course: AH 421 — History of Architecture II Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to architecture, urbanism and architectural theory worldwide from 1450 to the present. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and AH 420.

Course: AH 422 — Topics in the Literature of Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Discussion of selected readings in the theory and criticism of architecture. Prerequisites: 3 hours in the history of architecture or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the Literature of Architecture
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 423 — Topics in Modern and Contemporary Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 4 Description: Selected topics in modern and contemporary architecture. Prerequisites: Graduate standing, and four hours in the history of architecture or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Architecture
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 424 — Topics in Architecture and Urban Form in Chicago Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 2-4 Description: Topics on the development of the built environment of the Chicago and metropolitan area, and the effect on its architecture of social, political and economic forces.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Architecture and Urban Form in Chicago
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 430 — Contemporary Photography Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Developments in the history of photography since 1950. Prerequisites: 3 hours in the history of photography or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: AH 431 — Photographic Theory Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Developments in photographic theory from its prehistory in the camera obscura and linear perspective through its heyday in the machine age up to its place in our image world today. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: AH 150 or any photography studio course.

Course: AH 432 — Topics in Film and Video Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected studies in genres, schools, individual artists, critics, and theorists of film and video. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or 3 hours in the history of film or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: AH 435 — Topics in Modern and Contemporary Design Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in modern and contemporary design. Prerequisites: 3 hours in the history of design or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Design
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 441 — Topics in Medieval Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in European art and architecture of the Middle Ages. Prerequisites: 3 hours of medieval art and architecture or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Medieval Art and Architecture
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 449 — Women and Film Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Roles and representations of women in classical Hollywood, European art and independent feminist cinemas. Course Information: Same as ENGL 449 and GWS 449. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as AH 434. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 330 , 344 , 345 , or 347. Junior standing or above.

Course: AH 450 — Topics in Renaissance Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in Early Renaissance, High Renaissance, or Mannerist Art and Architecture. Prerequisites: 3 hours in art history at the 200 level or above, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: AH 455 — Topics in Early Modern Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in early modern art. Prerequisites: consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: A 200-level and/or 300-level AH course or above is recommended.

Course: AH 460 — Topics in Modern and Contemporary Art Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in nineteenth- and twentieth-century modern and contemporary art. Prerequisites: 3 hours of modern art and architecture or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Art
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 463 — Topics in North American Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in North American art and architecture from colonial times to 1945. Prerequisites: 3 hours of North American art and architecture or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in North American Art and Architecture
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 464 — Topics on Art in Chicago Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 2-4 Description: Topics on the survey of art in Chicago, from the nineteenth century to the present, with an emphasis on contemporary Chicago art expressions.

Course: AH 465 — Arts of the Black Atlantic Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Interdisciplinary and discursive explorations of the visual and artistic expressions of artists of African descent in the New World. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: AH 466 — Material Worlds: Topics in Material Culture Studies Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines current theories of material culture, drawn from art history, archaeology and anthropology to reflect on technologies of production and social life of things. Case studies will be drawn from ancient, medieval and modern historical context. Course Information: Same as ANTH 466 and CL 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Material Worlds: Topics in Material Culture Studies
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 468 — History of Mexican Painting: from Teotihuacan to Frida Kahlo Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of the history of Mexican painting from Mesoamerica to modern times. This class will answer a set of thematic questions regarding the exclusory practices of painting within and outside of the hegemonic artistic discourses. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: History of Mexican Painting: from Teotihuacan to Frida Kahlo
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 470 — Topics in Indigenous American Art, Architecture, and Visual Culture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in the art, architecture and visual culture of the indigenous Americas. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: 3 hours of Art History (undergraduates); Graduate standing (graduates).

metadata.class_name: Topics in Indigenous American Art, Architecture, and Visual Culture
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 471 — Topics in Asian Art and Architecture Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in the art and architecture of Asia. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Asian art and/or architecture or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GLAS 471. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Asian Art and Architecture
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 480 — Collecting Art and Building the Art Museum Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The history of art collections and of art museums: public, academic, and private collections of art, and the architectural development of art museums. Formation of the earliest collections of art, and history of American collectors. Prerequisites: AH 110 and AH 111 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Collecting Art and Building the Art Museum
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AH 481 — Museum Practices Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Administration of visual arts organizations, their budgets, staffing, structures, accreditation, and long-range planning. Prerequisites: AH 480 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: AH 482 — Museology Internship Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 6 or 8 Description: Practical supervised experience in institutions serving the visual arts. Placements in museums, community art centers, college, commercial, or non-traditional galleries, and public agencies. Prerequisites: AH 481 or consent of the instructor.

Course: AH 483 — Internship Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Introduction to professional practice offering students the opportunity to couple academic learning with professional experience in an off-campus placement. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only. May be repeated. Field work required.

Course: AH 484 — Careers in the Arts Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Through guest lectures by Chicago-area professionals and field trips to local institutions, this seminar will introduce a range of careers in the arts along with the skills and training required to undertake such jobs. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

Course: AH 485 — Introduction to Historic Preservation Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Preservation planning, historic building restoration, and the political and economic factors affecting the conservation of historic resources. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 200 level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: AH 490 — Honors Thesis Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 3 Description: Individual study on a project selected with the approval of the adviser. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: AH 491 — Study Abroad in Art History Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 0-12 Description: Study abroad within an approved foreign exchange program or department-sponsored program. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: AH 492 — Readings in Art and Architecture History Subject: Art History (AH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individually planned readings on selected topics under the supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Junior standing and 3 hours of Art History above the 100 level and consent of the instructor. Enrollment priority will be given to majors and graduate students in Art History. Course Information: 1 to 3 undergraduate hours. 2 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours for undergraduate students or 12 hours for graduate students. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Readings in Art and Architecture History
metadata.subject: Art History (AH)

text: Course: AHS 100 — Applied Health Sciences Seminar I Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces students to resources at UIC. Emphasizes academic skill building, professional development, major/career exploration, health and wellness, social justice, diversity and inclusion and community engagement. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Course meets for full 16 weeks of the semester.

Course: AHS 101 — Rehabilitation Sciences Student Success Seminar Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 1 Description: This introductory seminar is designed to provide participants the opportunity to explore, practice, and reflect on the overall building blocks for success as a college student in the Rehabilitation Sciences program at UIC. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Priority will be given to students in the BS in Rehabilitation Sciences.

Course: AHS 102 — Introduction to Clinical Research in Rehabilitation Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Designed to introduce the structure, processes, and importance of clinical research in rehabilitation sciences. Emphasis will be placed on reading, analyzing, and conducting basic research and using the university library system. Prerequisites: AHS 101. Priority will be given to students in the BS in Rehabilitation Sciences.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Clinical Research in Rehabilitation Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 111 — Career Planning in the Health Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 1 Description: Provides the skills to develop personal career planning and development for health and other sectors. Promotes self-discovery, explores career choices, and aids the articulation of academic goals and career plans upon completion of this course. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

metadata.class_name: Career Planning in the Health Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 112 — Career Readiness in the Health Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 1 Description: Explores skills needed: to create a self-brand; to navigate a job search; to develop life skills for the world of work. Emphasis on health-related vocations and on personal and professional development throughout the career-span. Course Information: .

metadata.class_name: Career Readiness in the Health Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 200 — Introduction to Integrated Health Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of the biological, behavioral, economical, and socio-cultural determinants of health from the level of the gene to society. Contextualizes health into current behavioral and social theories and paradigms. Course Information: Taught as a blended course with both online content and face to face discussion sessions.

Course: AHS 210 — Introduction to Rehabilitation Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Aspects of rehabilitation social sciences as they relate to the maximization of functional capacity in persons seeking rehabilitation services, and the interaction of persons with the surrounding environment. Prerequisites: AHS 100 or credit or concurrent registration in AHS 101. Priority registration for students in the BS in Rehabilitation major. Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 101 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 101 Prereq Codes (parsed): AHS 101 Coreq Codes (parsed): AHS 101

Course: AHS 294 — Special Topics in the Health Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 1-5 Description: Covers special topics relevant to the health sciences. Course Information: May be repeated.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in the Health Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 299 — Applied Health Scienes Study Abroad Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 0-18 Description: Provides credit for study abroad. Student's proposal must have prior approval of the student's major program or department. Final determination of credit is made on the student's completion of the work. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 36 hours per academic year or for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year.

Course: AHS 304 — Human Sexuality and Health Science Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to sexuality and sexual functioning across the lifespan with particular emphasis on the intersection of sexuality and health. Course Information: Taught as a blended course with both online content and face to face discussion sessions.

Course: AHS 325 — Approaches to Rehabilitation Case Management Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Case management of clients in rehab settings through continuum of care from acute care to home/community. Introduction to collaborative process of assessment, planning, care coordination, evaluation, and advocacy to meet an individual’s and family needs. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 102 and AHS 210 ; or consent of the instructor. Priority will be given to students in the BS in Rehabilitation Sciences, but the course will be open to all UIC students who meet the prerequisite requirement. Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 102 and AHS 210 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 102 and AHS 210 Prereq Codes (parsed): AHS 102, AHS 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): AHS 102, AHS 210

Course: AHS 330 — Physical and Mental Health Issues in Rehabilitation Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to common diagnostic conditions seen in rehabilitation, the physical and mental health impact of each condition, and implications for independent living and community participation. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 210. Priority will be given to students in the BS in Rehabilitation Sciences, but will be open to other students with approval. Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 210 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 210 Prereq Codes (parsed): AHS 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): AHS 210

metadata.class_name: Physical and Mental Health Issues in Rehabilitation
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 365 — Measurement and Assessment in Rehabilitation Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Designed to introduce students to measures and assessments used in rehabilitation sciences. The course will cover examples of measures used in clinical practice as well as in rehabilitation research. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 210 ; and STAT 101 or STAT 130 ; or consent of the instructor. Priority will be given to students in the BS in Rehabilitation Sciences, but open to all UIC students who meet the prerequisites requirements. Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 210 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 210 Prereq Codes (parsed): AHS 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): AHS 210

Course: AHS 375 — Ethics, Law and Professionalism in Health Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the ethical, legal, and professional theories, issues, and decision-making process involved in health sciences and health care environments. Course Information: Priority to senior level students in BS in Rehabilitation Sciences and BS in Liberal Arts and Sciences, majors in Integrated Health Studies, but open to all UIC students.

metadata.class_name: Ethics, Law and Professionalism in Health Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 393 — Synthesis in Health and Rehabilitation Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Students will develop a synthesis project that integrates their practical experiences in healthcare settings, research laboratories, or community centers with content learned in major core courses. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field work required. Course sections will be divided up and tailored to the students in the Bachelor’s Program in Rehabilitation Sciences and students in the Integrated Health Sciences Program. Recommended Background: Past experience volunteering or working in a health care setting and/or being a consumer of health care preferred.

metadata.class_name: Synthesis in Health and Rehabilitation Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 396 — Independent Study in Applied Health Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Selected topics in applied health sciences for individual student study, with faculty approval and supervision. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

metadata.class_name: Independent Study in Applied Health Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 402 — Health Inter-professional Seminar Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 2 Description: Exposure to a variety of healthcare providers in an effort to educate students to better provide patient care and consumer services and to deliver patient-centered care and consumer services as an interdisciplinary team. Course Information: Priority will be given to students in the BS in Rehabilitation Sciences.

Course: AHS 405 — Experiential Learning in Health and Rehabilitation Sciences Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Students pursue practical experiences in community and healthcare settings, applying knowledge gained through coursework, following service models used by the partner organization, and focusing on the needs of the people and communities served. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 325. Open only to juniors and seniors; and consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 325 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in AHS 325 Course Information: Field work required. In preparation for site engagement, all students will complete HIPAA training through UIC and a CPR certification course. Students will complete additional site-specific material review such as the “Recognizing and Reporting Child Abuse: Training for Mandated Reporters” through DCFS as required by partner sites. These items will be done as part of the course curriculum. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Practice and one Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): AHS 325 Coreq Codes (parsed): AHS 325

metadata.class_name: Experiential Learning in Health and Rehabilitation Sciences
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 425 — Rehabilitation Services and Resources for Children with Developmental Disabilities and Families Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to general concepts related to rehabilitation services and settings for children with or at risk for developmental delays/disabilities and their family. Emphasis is placed on understanding evidence-based therapies,supports,and resources. Prerequisites: AHS 210 and AHS 330.

metadata.class_name: Rehabilitation Services and Resources for Children with Developmental Disabilities and Families
metadata.subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS)

text: Course: AHS 495 — Urban Health Multicultural Seminar Subject: Applied Health Sciences (AHS) Credits: 1 Description: Students attend multicultural and urban health-related seminars, participate in faculty-student discussion, academic presentations, and directed reading groups to integrate issues of cultural difference into students' professional development. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. All Academy seminars are pre-approved: other approved events will be announced to students. Any off-campus events must have prior approval. One academic year is allotted for completion of seminar. Students should register the semester they begin attending lectures; grades will be deferred until course is completed.

Course: ANAT 315 — Anatomy I Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 4 Description: Structural and functional anatomy of the human head, neck and orofacial complex. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANAT 316 — Anatomy II Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to the structural and functional systems biology of the human body. Prerequisites: ANAT 315.

Course: ANAT 399 — Undergraduate Laboratory Research Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 1-4 Description: Laboratory research for advanced undergraduates. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

Course: ANAT 403 — Human Neuroanatomy Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 3 Description: Morphological organization of the nervous system. Functional correlations of neural structures. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the instructor. Must be in a degree program. Course Information: Same as NEUS 403. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ANAT 414 — Neuroanatomy for Allied Health Program Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 3 Description: Basic Development and gross features of the central nervous system and systems neuroanatomy; motor, sensory and integrative functional areas. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ANAT 439 — Gross Human Anatomy I Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 3 Description: Gross structure of the adult human thorax, abdomen, pelvis and perineum, emphasizing spatial relationships and functional/clinical relevance. Includes embryology and radiology topics. Prerequisites: Graduate standing in a degree-granting program only and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Limited to six (6) students. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANAT 440 — Gross Human Anatomy II Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 4 Description: Gross structure of the adult human head & neck/deep back and limbs, emphasizing spatial relationships and functional/clinical relevance. Includes embryology and radiology topics. Prerequisites: Graduate standing in a degree-granting program only and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Limited to six (6) students. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANAT 441 — Gross Human Anatomy Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 5 Description: Functional and structural anatomy of the body. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the instructor; or enrollment in the Doctor of Physical Therapy program or M.S. in Biomedical Visualization program. Course Information: For allied health students. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ANAT 442 — Cell Structure and Human Histology Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 5 Description: Structure and function of cells and fundamental tissues. Function and microscopic anatomy of organs. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANAT 443 — Case Studies in Clinical Anatomy Subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology (ANAT) Credits: 3 Description: Clinical approach to human anatomy by examining a series of case studies. An introduction to clinical medicine using problem based learning to integrate anatomical knowledge with clinical signs and patient symptoms. Prerequisites: ANAT 441.

Course: ANTH 100 — The Human Adventure Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of approaches to the study of the origins and the cultural and biological development of humankind. Course Information: No credit given towards the major in Anthropology. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: ANTH 101 — World Cultures: Introduction to Social Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Concepts and methods in the study of world cultures from a comparative anthropological perspective, emphasizing selected non-U.S. societies, cultures, and ethnographic regions. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: World Cultures: Introduction to Social Anthropology
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 102 — Introduction to Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: This course surveys world prehistory and introduces students to the theories and methods archaeologists use to understand the past. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course, and Past course.

Course: ANTH 105 — Human Evolution Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Human evolution and variability; methods of assessing fossil evidence for evolutionary change; principles of biological adaptation. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course, and Past course.

Course: ANTH 200 — Anthropological Theory Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical approaches to the study of culture and society in anthropology. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 or consent of the instructor.

Course: ANTH 201 — Asian Markets, Corporations, and Social Justice Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: A critical analysis of multinational corporations as social institutions and their commodification and representation of Asian and Asian American cultures and economies. Includes topics like KPop, fair trade, sweatshops, and the beauty industry. Prerequisites: GLAS 100 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 201.

metadata.class_name: Asian Markets, Corporations, and Social Justice
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 207 — Asian Cities: Urban Cultures of the Global South Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: The dynamics of urbanization in a number of Asian cities, including Mumbai, Shanghai, Singapore and Dubai, that have emerged as important nodes in the global economy, and that exemplify contemporary urban culture as it manifests cross-culturally. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 207.

metadata.class_name: Asian Cities: Urban Cultures of the Global South
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 208 — Virtual Lives: Science, Technology, and Culture Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: An anthropological perspective on science and technology. The role of science and technology on the social and cultural worlds in which we live. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Class Schedule: To be properly registered, students must be enrolled in one Lecture and one Discussion. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Virtual Lives: Science, Technology, and Culture
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 215 — Anthropology of Religion Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of varieties of religious experience, including magic and witchcraft, with emphasis on non-Western religions and the role of religious institutions in social integration. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as RELS 215.

Course: ANTH 216 — Medicine, Culture, and Society Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Medical anthropology explores illness and health as both embodied and socially constructed. It maintains that illness reflects cultural understandings of the body, social/structural inequalities, and differential distributions of power. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Recommended for pre-health students who plan to work in multi-cultural settings. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: ANTH 217 — Special Topics in Sociocultural Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on new and innovative topical and theoretical approaches in Anthropology or new research topics of interest in socio-cultural anthropology. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term.
