Course: ANTH 218 — Anthropology of Children and Childhood Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Examines childhood, a uniquely human life stage, both across cultures and from a biosocial perspective that includes both physical and social development. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 and ANTH 105 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course.

Course: ANTH 219 — Anthropology of Globalization Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Explores capitalism as a culture, its origins, and the problems of consumer culture in the U.S. and the world. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course.

Course: ANTH 220 — Method and Theory in Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to techniques and methods in archaeology, archaeological reasoning, research design, and methods of analysis. Archaeological methods for the analysis of prehistoric technology, economy, social and political organization. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 or consent of the instructor.

Course: ANTH 223 — Southwestern Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the archaeology of ancient Native American cultures of the North American Southwest, emphasizing processes of culture change from earliest times until European contact, with focus on current debates and relevant methods and theories. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 102 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 102 Course Information: Same as LALS 223. Prereq Codes (parsed): ANTH 102 Coreq Codes (parsed): ANTH 102

Course: ANTH 224 — Archaeology of Mainland Southeast Asia Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the archaeology of mainland Southeast Asia, ranging from the appearance of early peoples to the rise of states such as the Angkorian Khmer Empire. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 or ANTH 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GLAS 224.

Course: ANTH 226 — Archaeology of North America Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the prehistoric cultures of North America from earliest times until the arrival of Europeans. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LALS 257.

Course: ANTH 227 — Ancient Civilizations of Mexico and Central America Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and interpretation of the archaeological evidence on the process of development of native civilization in the Meso-American area from the beginnings of agricultural settlement to the eve of the Spanish conquest. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 ; or sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GEOG 207 and LALS 258.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Civilizations of Mexico and Central America
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 229 — Special Topics in Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Covers special topics in archaeology. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: ANTH 231 — Becoming Human: The Fossil Record Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: The fossil record as it applies to different interpretations of human evolution; principles of evolutionary biology; survey of the biology and behavior of living primates. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ANTH 233 — Forensic Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Addresses the role of anthropologists in criminal cases involving human skeletal remains, including biological variation, personal identification, cause of death, humanitarian efforts, and ethics. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for ANTH 233 if the student has credit for the comparable ANTH 239 topics section Forensic Anthropology. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ANTH 234 — Modern Human Variation and Adaptation Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: A broad overview of genetic variation and biosocial adaptation in contemporary human groups. Prerequisites: ANTH 105. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANTH 237 — The Human Skeleton Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Examination of the human skeleton, emphasizing bone identification and functional anatomy. Course Information: Same as BIOS 237. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: ANTH 238 — Biology of Women Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: An evolutionary perspective on the biology of women from conception to menopause, in light of current research on genetics, hormones, and development. Topics include sexual differentiation, sex differences, and life history. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ANTH 105 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 238. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: ANTH 239 — Special Topics in Biological Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Special topics in Biological Anthropology. Prerequisites: ANTH 105 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: ANTH 242 — Introduction to Arab American Studies Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses key themes in Arab American Studies: immigration and racism; family, gender, and sexuality; socio-economic class; religious affiliation; arts and cultures; and politics and political activism. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. US Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 242.

Course: ANTH 243 — The Archaeology of Buddhism Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: The development, spread, integration, and decline of Buddhism in many parts of Asia. The study of material culture as a way of reconstructing and understanding the religious past. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as RELS 243.

Course: ANTH 244 — Arab and Asian Connections in the U.S. and Globally Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: A comparative study of contemporary Arab and Asian communities in the US and around the globe that examines issues of militarism/war; immigration/displacement; racism; and social justice activism. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. US Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 244.

metadata.class_name: Arab and Asian Connections in the U.S. and Globally
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 245 — Anthropology of the Middle East Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to social science approaches to the histories, politics, cultures, and contemporary issues of the Middle East using theories and methods drawn from cultural anthropology, human geography, history, and related disciplines. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 ; and completion of the English composition requirement; or consent of the instructor.

Course: ANTH 246 — Politics of Immigration Enforcement Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: How immigrants in the United States have been constructed as a “problem” and ways that authorities have consequently sought to govern them. Topics include nativism, illegalization, criminalization, border policing, detention, deportation, and rights. Course Information: Same as LALS 234.

Course: ANTH 248 — Afro Asian Solidarities Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of the radical possibilities of transnational alliances and the long history of cross-racial solidarities between Asia and Africa, Asians and Africans, both globally and in the U.S. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. US Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 248 and GWS 248.

Course: ANTH 255 — Introduction to Middle East and Muslim Feminisms Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to Middle East and Muslim feminisms that draws on the social sciences. Emphasizes intersections of family, religion, nation, colonialism, militarism, gender, and sexuality. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 255 and GWS 255.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Middle East and Muslim Feminisms
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 262 — Constructions of Gender, Race, Health, and Human Rights Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Explores issues at the intersections of gender, race, and sexuality through the lens of health in both U.S. and non-U.S. contexts. Prerequisites: GWS 101 or GWS 102 ; and sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GWS 262.

metadata.class_name: Constructions of Gender, Race, Health, and Human Rights
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 273 — Ethnography of Southeast Asia Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of selected cultures of mainland Southeast Asia, with emphasis on cultural ecology, tribal formation, and nationalism. Course Information: Same as GEOG 273. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: ANTH 274 — Cultures of Global Vietnam Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Vietnamese American histories, culture, politics, and creative arts in comparative, relational, and transnational perspectives. Emphasis on artists, activists, and scholars living in Vietnam and in the diaspora. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100. Course Information: Same as GLAS 274 and HIST 274.

Course: ANTH 276 — Pacific Island Cultures Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Polynesian, Micronesian, and Melanesian island societies; their ecosystems and cultures, emphasizing their unity and diversity.

Course: ANTH 277 — Ethnography of Meso-America Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the contemporary indigenous cultures of Meso-America, studied against their pre-conquest history and in their development since the Spanish Conquest. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as LALS 270.

Course: ANTH 279 — South Asian Cultures and Societies Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the people and cultures of South Asian Cultures; emphasis on social structure, religion, and recent cultural changes. Course Information: Same as GLAS 279. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: ANTH 309 — Writing Culture Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of genres of anthropological reporting with a critical examination of the process by which observations are transformed into written form as well as continued development of composition skills. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 and completion of the English composition requirement (or its equivalent); or consent of the instructor.

Course: ANTH 310 — An Introduction to the Anthropology of the Body Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical and methodological approaches to the body as the interface between nature and culture. It considers how culture is embodied, how the body is encultured, and how cultures of perception vary through time and space.

metadata.class_name: An Introduction to the Anthropology of the Body
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 311 — The Anthropology of Consumption Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: The nature, experience, and cultural politics of consumption from historical and cross cultural perspectives paying particular attention to the emergence of consumption as a crucial domain within the culture of capitalism.

Course: ANTH 312 — Cross-Cultural and Historical Perspectives of Youth Culture Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: The cultural construction of "youth" and "youth culture" through time and around the world. The ways in which age designations are used to naturalize a variety of broader cultural/ideological projects.

metadata.class_name: Cross-Cultural and Historical Perspectives of Youth Culture
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 314 — Anthropology of Food Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: The culture and politics of food in cross-cultural perspective with an emphasis on holism (the political, social, and environmental vectors of food systems), identity, and social movements. Prerequisites: ANTH 101.

Course: ANTH 319 — Environmental Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of the environment in relation to human technology and global connection divided into three general topics: transformation of the environment, commodification of nature, and politics of the environment. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: ANTH 320 — Topics in Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Readings, study and discussion of selected problems in archaeology. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 and successful completion of one archaeology class at the 200 level.

Course: ANTH 324 — Angkor and the Khmer Empire Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: An investigation of the people, culture, technologies and achievements of the medieval southeast Asian Angkorian Khmer through a combination of archaeological, textual and art historical evidence. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 and ANTH 102.

Course: ANTH 328 — Child Migration Across the Americas Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Examines why and how migrant children have played a central role in the past and present migratory dynamics of the Americas. Course Information: Same as LALS 328.

Course: ANTH 332 — Performance Ethnography Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Students engage performance as a subject and method of study as they investigate the methods and ethics of conducting ethnographic research and creating performance in order to explore how people express, negotiate, and create identity and meaning. Course Information: Same as THTR 332. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Recommended Background: Considerable interest in performance and/or ethnography is important; but no formal performance or ethnography training is required.

Course: ANTH 333 — Undocumented Social Movements Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Undocumented coalitions, visibility, and refusal. Poetry, films, artivism, movement journalism, and secondary readings. Visibility, claiming and redefining citizenship, and building power alongside other racialized communities. Course Information: Same as ANTH LALS 333.

Course: ANTH 335 — Topics in Biological Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical and substantive issues in the study of both human and non-human primates as well as hominids, as represented in current journals and topical volumes. Prerequisites: ANTH 105 and one 200-level course in biological anthropology. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ANTH 386 — Elements of Spatial Analysis Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Implications of geographic concerns for data gathering and analysis. Spatial sampling and weighting of areal data. Reconciling record and zone inconsistencies when merging data from several sources. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GEOG 386.

Course: ANTH 390 — Honors Research Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Individual study or research projects for students seeking departmental distinction. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above, approval of the department, a 3.00 University grade point average, and a 3.50 grade point average in anthropology. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Successful completion necessary for "Departmental Distinction" with final paper submitted to three-member honors committee for approval. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and major.

Course: ANTH 394 — Topics in Sociocultural Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Reading, study and discussion of selected problems in sociocultural anthropology. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ANTH 409 — Ancient Maya Writing, Language and Culture Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Recent trends in Maya epigraphy, information gained from Maya hieroglyphs, linguistics, and historical ethnographies are applied to anthropological analyses of past lifeways. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LALS 409. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Maya Writing, Language and Culture
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 411 — Urban Cultural Problems Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: A study of the processes of urbanization and of cultural and social adjustments to the city; illustrated by case studies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 415 — Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health I Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Explores the field of cultural medical anthropology and provides a theoretical foundation allowing for understanding and exploration of anthropology's role in international health. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ANTH 216 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IPHS 415. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health I
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 416 — Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health II Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an evolutionary and biocultural approach to human biology, physiology, health and disease. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ANTH 232; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IPHS 416. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health II
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 418 — Ethnographic and Qualitative Research Methods Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Practical introduction to the techniques of social scientists for research in natural social settings: participant observation/non-participant observation, interviewing, use of documentary sources, etc. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Same as GEOG 418. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 420 — Seminar in Archaeology and Ethnography Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Case studies of investigations in archeology using research monographs and other primary sources. Substantive data and related theoretical problems are examined simultaneously. Prerequisites: Junior standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 15 hours.

Course: ANTH 423 — Andean Prehistory Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An overview of the cultural evolution of the Andean region from the arrival of the first inhabitants to the development of the Inca empire. Prerequisites: ANTH 269; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LALS 423. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 424 — Violence Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey of violence theory and research. Examination of types, causes and consequences of violence historically and in the present. Exploration of acts of resistance to violence. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CLJ 423. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 425 — Field Techniques in Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Exposure to field methods in archaeology through participation in an actual research project. Students are instructed in field excavation techniques. Usually offered in summer session. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 or consent of the instructor. Recommended: Concurrent registration in ANTH 426 or GEOG 426. Course Information: Same as GEOG 425. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Practice.

Course: ANTH 426 — Laboratory Techniques in Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Exposes students to laboratory methods in archaeology through the analysis of excavated materials. Students are instructed in laboratory techniques. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 or consent of the instructor. Recommended: Concurrent registration in ANTH 425 or GEOG 425. Course Information: Same as GEOG 426. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ANTH 428 — Chiefdoms Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Focus on traditional non-state, yet complex, societies known as "chiefdoms." Examine the organization and evolution of such societies through a combination of ethnographic, historical and archaeological data. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 or ANTH 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 429 — Archaeological Methods Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: This course will familiarize students with various methodologies used by archaeologists and geo-archaeologists. Course will concentrate on a different method each time it is taught. Course Information: Same as GEOG 429. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s). Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: ANTH 432 — Mortuary Archaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides a cross-cultural survey of mortuary customs, an overview of general theoretical approaches and a critical analysis in the study of mortuary customs and human remains in archaeological contexts. Prerequisites: Undergraduates only: Grade of C or better in ANTH 237. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Undergraduates only: 200-level courses in archaeology and cultural anthropology.

Course: ANTH 433 — Ancient Diseases Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: A multidisciplinary approach to the study of diseases in the past, integrating biological anthropology, archaeology, history, and biology. Topics include infectious diseases, medical treatments, and reproductive health. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 237 or BIOS 237 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 237 or BIOS 237 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: ANTH 233 or Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 237 or BIOS 237. Prereq Codes (parsed): ANTH 237, BIOS 237 Coreq Codes (parsed): ANTH 237, BIOS 237

Course: ANTH 435 — Global Migrations Across the Americas Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Processes of migrant mobilities and control in the Americas. Structural causes, social groups, and role of global inequality. Case studies in the US and Latin America regarding the securitization of migration and growth patterns in migrant mobility. Course Information: Same as LALS 437. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 436 — The Indian Ocean World: Contact, Commerce, Culture Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The movement of people, goods, religious movements and ideas, throughout the Indian Ocean region from earliest times to the colonial era. Course Information: Same as HIST 436 and GLAS 437. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: The Indian Ocean World: Contact, Commerce, Culture
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 437 — Bioarchaeology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 5 Description: Provides an overview of mortuary theory and the bioarchaeological methods used to study health and disease, diet, activity patterns, kinship and cultural practices in archaeological populations. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ANTH 237 ; and consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANTH 453 — Seminar in Cultural Ecology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Cultural ecology and cultural evolution, emphasizing peasant farming and other subsistence systems. Soil management under shifting and sedentary agriculture. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 or GEOG 151 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GEOG 453. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 455 — Quantitative Methods Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introductory statistics course in statistical methods for anthropological problem-solving. Primary emphasis is on univariate and bivariate statistics, such as means standard deviations, correlation, chi square, t-tests, and simple regressions. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GEOG 455. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ANTH 461 — Museum Collecting: Documentation, Registration, and Curation Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the collection of anthropological objects for museum curation. Ethics of collecting, standards for documentation, legal aspects of collecting, ethnographic interviewing, registration of objects and archives, curation and housing. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Lab-Discusssion.

metadata.class_name: Museum Collecting: Documentation, Registration, and Curation
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 462 — Museum Exhibit Research and Design Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to anthropological museum exhibitions. Issues of representation and cultural politics, museums¿ roles in the communities they serve, developing a story around objects, and the technical aspects of exhibit design.

Course: ANTH 466 — Material Worlds: Topics in Material Culture Studies Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines current theories of material culture, drawn from art history, archaeology and anthropology to reflect on technologies of production and social life of things. Case studies will be drawn from ancient, medieval and modern historical context. Course Information: Same as AH 466 and CL 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Material Worlds: Topics in Material Culture Studies
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 473 — Anthropology of Social Movements Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the causes of social change from the perspective of sociocultural anthropology. An ethnographic approach to political life, how communities describe and enact their experiences as individuals and citizens. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 476 — Rise and Fall of the Inca Empire Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 Description: Using an integration of ethnographic, historical, and archaeological information, this course is designed to provide a thorough introduction to the study of the Incas. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Rise and Fall of the Inca Empire
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 477 — Remote Sensing of the Environment Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Principles and practices of processing and interpretation of remotely sensed imagery including aerial photographs, radar and multispectral satellite images. Hands-on use of image-processing software. Course Information: Same as GEOG 477. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANTH 478 — Paleoindians and Peopling of the Americas: From Alaska to Tierra del Fuego Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Summarizes current knowledge of the first migration of humans to the New World, analyzes its significance, and evaluates the controversies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Paleoindians and Peopling of the Americas: From Alaska to Tierra del Fuego
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 479 — Culture and Colonialism in South Asia Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the emergence of colonial cultures of domination and resistance on the Indian subcontinent from the eighteenth century to 1947. Course Information: Same as GLAS 479 and HIST 479. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Culture and Colonialism in South Asia
metadata.subject: Anthropology (ANTH)

text: Course: ANTH 480 — Sociolinguistics Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Variations in language that correlate with variation in societies and smaller social groups; interactions of languages and societies. Prerequisites: LING 405 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LING 480. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ANTH 481 — Geographic Information Systems I Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Components and performance properties of geographic information systems. Geographic hierarchies and data structures. Problems and solutions in handling large geographic files. Geocoding. Prerequisites: GEOG 100 and one from GEOG 278, GEOG 386, IDS 100; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GEOG 481. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ANTH 482 — Geographic Information Systems II Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Application of raster (or grid) based geographic information systems to the spatial analysis of landscapes. Course Information: Same as GEOG 482. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ANTH 483 — Geographic Information Systems III Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 4 Description: Problems encountered in the analysis and portrayal of geographic data. Topics include taxonomy, regionalization, trend surface analysis, time series, markov probabilities, and computer cartographic procedures for displaying output from analytic procedures. Prerequisites: GEOG 482 or ANTH 482 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GEOG 483.

Course: ANTH 490 — Independent Study Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 1-6 Description: Independent reading under the supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Junior standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours with approval. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major.

Course: ANTH 494 — Special Topics in Anthropology Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Reading, study, and discussion of selected problems for graduate students and majors in anthropology. Prerequisites: Junior standing or approval of the department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ANTH 496 — Internship Subject: Anthropology (ANTH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Professional field experience with an agency or organization in the private or public sector on projects related to the student's area of specialization. Prerequisites: Declared major in anthropology, minor in geography or full graduate standing in anthropology or geography and consent of the faculty advisor, head of the department, or the director of internship programs. Course Information: Same as GEOG 496. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Only 4 hours of credit may be applied toward the Minor in Geography. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: ARAB 101 — Elementary Arabic I Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to and practice in speaking, reading, and writing Arabic and comprehending spoken arabic. Prerequisites: For students who have not studied Arabic or placement as determined by test score or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for ARAB 101 if the student has credit for ARAB 115.

Course: ARAB 102 — Elementary Arabic II Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 4 Description: Continues Arabic 101. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ARAB 101 and appropiriate score on the placement test or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for ARAB 102 if the student has credit for ARAB 115.

Course: ARAB 103 — Intermediate Arabic I Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of practice in speaking, reading, and writing Arabic and comprehending spoken Arabic. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ARAB 102 ; or Grade of C or better in ARAB 115 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Credit is not given for ARAB 103 if student has credit for ARAB 116.

Course: ARAB 104 — Intermediate Arabic II Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of practice in comprehending spoken Arabic and reading Arabic with some work in speaking and writing Arabic. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ARAB 103 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Credit is not given for ARAB 104 if the student has credit for ARAB 116.

Course: ARAB 105 — Modern Arab Culture Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: Intro to modern Arab culture through movies, music, literary and historical texts. The course aims to correct negative stereotypes by exploring different Arab cultures, religion, art, and politics. Course Information: Taught in English. World Cultures course.

Course: ARAB 115 — Intensive Elementary Arabic Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 8 Description: Intensive introduction to modern standard Arabic with emphasis on speaking, reading, and writing. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Equivalent to Arabic 101 and 102 combined. Offered during selected summers only. May be offered as an 8-week or 12-week online course during selected summers only. Students with 101 or 102 credits may not take the course. Credit is not given for ARAB 115 if the student has credit in ARAB 101 or ARAB 102. Recommended Background: For students who have not studied Arabic.

Course: ARAB 201 — Advanced Arabic through Literature Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to both classical and modern Arabic literature in the original language. Arabic rhetoric. Intensive listening, speaking, reading and writing at an intermediate to advanced level. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ARAB 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test or the equivalent AP Test score, or if taking as an elective, the consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in Arabic.

Course: ARAB 202 — Media Arabic Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: Vocabulary and grammar of Modern Standard Arabic as used in media such as newspapers, television and the web. Different uses of Arabic in various media outlets and introductory level media analysis. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ARAB 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test or the equivalent AP Test score, or if taking as an elective, the consent of the instructor.

Course: ARAB 203 — Arabic for Healthcare Professions and Sciences Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: An advanced course for students interested in pursuing a career in healthcare who would like to communicate effectively in Arabic with patients and families. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ARAB 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor; or the equivalent AP Test score.

metadata.class_name: Arabic for Healthcare Professions and Sciences
metadata.subject: Arabic (ARAB)

text: Course: ARAB 222 — Philosophy in the Islamic World Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of philosophy in the Islamic world from 8th century until today. Topics include: logic and psychology to metaphysics, theology, and politics. Special emphasis on cultural interactions between philosophers of different faiths and cultures. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PHIL 222 and RELS 222.

Course: ARAB 230 — Arabic Literature in Translation Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the genres and themes of classical and modern Arabic literature in translation. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement. World Cultures course. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: ARAB 250 — The Heritage of Muslim Iberia Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the history, culture and scientific achievements associated with the Muslim presence in Iberia from 711 CE to the fall of Grenada in 1492 CE, and the interplay of Arab and non-Arab cultures in the Western Mediterranean. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement. Past course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: ARAB 270 — The Reel Arab Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of how Arabs are portrayed in the cinema. Exploration of popular films (both Western and Arab) and their prominent conventions. Focus on gender issues, racial and ethnic representations, and analysis of patriarchal attitudes. Prerequisites: Completion of ENGL 160 ; or any 100- or 200-level film course. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as MOVI 270. Taught in English.

Course: ARAB 299 — Independent Reading Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 1-3 Description: Individually planned readings on selected topcis under faculty supervision. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours. Taught in English.

Course: ARAB 310 — Aristotle and the Arabs Subject: Arabic (ARAB) Credits: 3 Description: Traces the major topics of ancient Greek philosophy, especially those of Aristotle, and their transformation into the philosophy developed in the Arabic classical period. Prerequisites: CL 221 or PHIL 221 or RELS 230. Course Information: Same as CL 310 and PHIL 310.

Course: ARCH 105 — Architectural Studio 1 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 5 Description: Introduction to the visual and graphic principles of architectural design and production, with emphasis on observation, process, and composition, developed under the theme of representation and visual culture. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: 5 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ARCH 106 — Architectural Studio 2 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 5 Description: Introduction to materials and methods of assembly in architectural design and production, with emphasis on design process, problem-solving, and construction, developed under the general theme of representation and visual culture. Prerequisites: ARCH 105 and approval of the department. Course Information: 5 hrs. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ARCH 151 — Architecture at Chicago Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 2 Description: Introduction to the architecture culture of the School of Architecture and in the city. Corequisites: ARCH 105. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required.

Course: ARCH 200 — Architecture and Society Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 4 Description: Provides an understanding of the issues and factors that motivate and influence architectural design and theory, and how architecture is shaped by and shapes cultural concerns and social organization. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: ARCH 205 — Architectural Studio 3 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 5 Description: Principles of building design and representation explored through integrative analysis of program, site, structure, materials, mechanical systems, and composition, developed under the general theme of architectural technology. Prerequisites: ARCH 105 and ARCH 106 ; and approval of the department. Students must have earned an average grade of C or better in ARCH 105 and ARCH 106. Course Information: 5 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students will use city as a research laboratory with field work on project sites. Additional scheduled field trips will be made to significant or historical architectural buildings as part of preliminary design research and analysis. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ARCH 206 — Architectural Studio 4 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 5 Description: Expands basic principles of building design and representation explored through integrative analysis of program, site, structure, materials, mechanical systems, and composition, developed under the general theme of architectural technology. Prerequisites: ARCH 205 and approval of the department. Course Information: 5 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students will use city as a research laboratory with field work on project sites. Additional scheduled field trips will be made to significant or historical architectural buildings as part of preliminary design research and analysis. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ARCH 210 — Architecture as Archetype: Explorations of the City and Its Forms Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to architectural knowledge through its most elementary forms, analyzing their historical manifestations and present expressions. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Architecture as Archetype: Explorations of the City and Its Forms
metadata.subject: Architecture (ARCH)

text: Course: ARCH 251 — Architectural Analysis Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of the form and space of the built environment beginning with experiential and empirical inquiry and expanding to formal, visual, compositional, and perceptual techniques. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department; and BA Architectural Studies students must enroll concurrently in ARCH 105 ; and BS Architecture students must have completed ARCH 106 and also register concurrently in ARCH 205. Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ARCH 252 — Modern Architecture Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the concept of architectural theory as an integral part of making, understanding, and interpreting works of architecture. Prerequisites: BS Arch students: ARCH 205 and ARCH 251. BA Arch students: ARCH 251. Arch Minor Students: ARCH 200. Corequisites: BS Arch students must concurrently enroll in ARCH 206. Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ARCH 359 — Architectural Technology 1 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 4 Description: Examines the architect's role in protecting the health, safety and welfare of the public through responsible and ethical building practices. Prerequisites: Third year standing in the Bachelor of Science in Architecture program or approval of the school. Corequisites: ARCH 365. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 360 — Architectural Technology 2 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to building construction processes, terminology, principles, conventions, standards, applications, restrictions and communcations pertaining to construction materials and assemblies. Prerequisites: ARCH 359 or approval of the school. Corequisites: ARCH 366. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 365 — Architectural Studio 5 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 6 Description: Intermediate exercises in building design and representation explored through integrative analysis of program, site, structure, materials, mechanical systems, and composition, developed under the general theme of city and environment. Prerequisites: ARCH 205 and ARCH 206 ; and approval of the department. Students must have earned an average grade of C or better in ARCH 205 and ARCH 206. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students will use city as a research laboratory with field work on project sites. Additional scheduled field trips will be made to significant or historical architectural buildings as part of preliminary design research and analysis. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 366 — Architectural Studio 6 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 6 Description: Extended intermediate exercises in building design and representation explored through integrative analysis of program, site, structure, materials, mechanical systems, and composition, developed under the general theme of city and environment. Prerequisites: ARCH 365 and approval of the department. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students will use city as a research laboratory with field work on project sites. Additional scheduled field trips will be made to significant or historical architectural buildings as part of preliminary design research and analysis. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 371 — Architectural Theory 1 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: The emergence of the metropolis beginning in the mid-nineteenth century is examined through a survey of the forces that produced it, and the ideologies and practices that have attempted to organize, control, and simulate it. Course Information: BS Arch students must be enrolled in ARCH 359 and ARCH 365. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 372 — Architectural Theory 2 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Discusses a diversity of critical and generative approaches to twentieth-century architecture and theory, with an emphasis on how architects invent and instrumentalize history. Prerequisites: ARCH 371. BS students must concurrently enroll in ARCH 366. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 391 — Architectural Study Abroad Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 0-17 Description: Lectures, seminars, studio, and independent travel/study abroad. Architectural/art history, architectural elective and/or architectural theory and analysis. Prerequisites: A 2.50 cumulative grade point average in architecture and approval of the school. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 34 hours.

Course: ARCH 395 — Cooperative Education Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to architectural practice. Offers students the opportunity to couple academic learning with professional experience in an off-campus placement. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Restricted to students withthird or fourth year standing in the B.A. in Architectural Studies program. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours. Field work required.

Course: ARCH 399 — Architecture Elective I Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Special topics in architectural theory, design, and criticism. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ARCH 414 — Contemporary Practices Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: An upper level "selective" seminar that examines specific approaches to the contemporary practice of architecture; students choose by lottery from among several options that are offered by faculty. Prerequisites: ARCH 252 ; and approval of the department. BS in Architecture students must complete ARCH 371 and 372. Corequisites: BS in Architecture students must concurrently enroll in ARCH 465. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ARCH 440 — Digital Design and Fabrication Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Lectures, 3D software modeling lab time, and lab time for fabricating these files into physical models and prototypes, delivers a survey knowledge of digital fabrication and production in contemporary architectural practice. Prerequisites: ARCH 106 ; and approval of the department.

Course: ARCH 465 — Advanced Topic Studio 1 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 6 Description: Advanced studio that pursues specific design and research agendas of current significance; students choose by lottery from among several options that are offered by faculty. Prerequisites: ARCH 360 and ARCH 365 and ARCH 366 and ARCH 372 ; and junior standing or above; and approval of the department. Students must have earned an average grade of C or better in both ARCH 365 and ARCH 366. Students with a lower grade point average for the 365/366 studio sequence are required to take an eight-week summer studio in which they must earn at least a C in order to advance to the studio sequence for the following year. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students will use city as a research laboratory with field work on project sites. Additional scheduled field trips will be made to significant or historical architectural buildings as part of preliminary design research and analysis. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 466 — Advanced Topic Studio 2 Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 6 Description: Advanced studio that pursues specific design and research agendas of current significance; students choose by lottery from among several options that are offered by faculty. Prerequisites: ARCH 465 ; and approval of the department. Students must have earned an average grade of C or better in ARCH 365 and ARCH 366. Students with a lower grade point average for the 365/366 studio sequence are required to take an eight-week summer studio in which they must earn at least a C in order to advance to the studio sequence for the following year. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students will use city as a research laboratory with field work on project sites. Additional scheduled field trips will be made to significant or historical architectural buildings as part of preliminary design research and analysis. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ARCH 470 — Structures I: Statics Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the analysis of structural elements. Introduction to fundamental structural planning criteria and relevant concepts of tension, compression and bending. Introduction to historical and contemporary structural precedents. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 and Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 131. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 and Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 131 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 and Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 131 Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180, PHYS 131 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180, PHYS 131

Course: ARCH 471 — Structures II: Strength of Materials Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to material properties; strength characteristics of building materials and material assemblies; stress and strain; rigidity and deformation; temperature effects; torsion effects; combined loading of elements and systems. Prerequisites: ARCH 470 and approval of the school.

Course: ARCH 499 — Special Topics Subject: Architecture (ARCH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Special topics in theory, design, technology, or graphic skills and craft (manual or digital). Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 3 time(s).

Course: ART 101 — Signifying Practices: Art and Visual Culture Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to theoretical perspectivs for analyzing experiences of visual and multi-modal phenomena. Strategies for researching and writing about topics related to contemporary aesthetic practices. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Signifying Practices: Art and Visual Culture
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 110 — Introduction to Art Education Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to practical and theoretical perspectives in art education. Students will be introduced to methods of interpretation and meaning making, and learn how art educators work in collaboration with diverse populations. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Students are not required to have a background in art education. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: ART 112 — Introduction to Drawing Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to drawing: orientation to the description and expressive potential of drawing through exposure to a variety of subjects, media, and formal concepts. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 102. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Creative Arts course.

Course: ART 116 — The Science and History of Sound in the Arts Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 3 Description: Investigates physical properties of sound and their application in the arts. Students will explore sound through math, physics, and acoustics fundamental principles. Principles of sound will be tested/evaluated through research/applied projects. Course Information: Same as MUS 116. Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Natural World - No Lab course.

metadata.class_name: The Science and History of Sound in the Arts
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 130 — Introduction to Painting + Color Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Beginning painting: introduction to major directions of contemporary painting; underlying historical precedents; orientation to subjects and formal concepts using relevant materials and process. Course Information: Field Trip required at a nominal fee. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll for one Lecture and one Laboratory. Creative Arts course.

Course: ART 140 — Introduction to Sculpture Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: The study of major directions and underlying historical precedents in contemporary sculpture. Orientation to concepts of 3-dimensionality through use of relevant processes and heuristic approaches to making. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 140. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Creative Arts course.

Course: ART 150 — Introduction to New Media Arts Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: An introduction to the theory and practice of responsive arts. Through hands-on exercises, students learn to design interactive interfaces and responsive environments. Survey lectures focus on current practices and the history of new media. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 100. Extensive computer use required. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Creative Arts course.

Course: ART 151 — Introduction to Creative Coding in New Media Arts Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Under the professional instruction of an expert in coding languages, students will investigate the ways in which social media, data, and code have been instrumental in re-configuring the nature of social relationships in our society. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Students will use coding languages such as Processing, HTML, and JavaScript. Moving through beginning and intermediate levels of coding, students will explore creative new avenues of applying these tools. Students will gain skills to expand upon traditional uses of coding by aligning it with the contemporary art practices of New Media, a field in which technology and contemporary art combine. Class Schedule: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. 420071 Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Creative Coding in New Media Arts
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 160 — Introduction to Digital Photography Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to digital photography: basic familiarity with camera, photographic techniques, Photoshop, low level lighting and high end printing. Includes social, cultural, critical and aesthetic considerations of the medium. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 150. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Fully manual Digital Camera and laptop computer with appropriate Photoshop software is required. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Creative Arts course.

Course: ART 170 — Introduction to Filmmaking Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the practice, history and context of the moving image. Basic experimentation with image/sound capture and editing as related to film, video and audio. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 170. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Creative Arts course.

Course: ART 190 — Introduction to Socially Engaged Art Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduces the concept of socially engaged art, a practice that blurs the line between art and life, emphasizing participation, dialogue, and action. Includes field visits and dialogue with artists. Students design and realize a public art project. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Course Information: 3 hours. Previously listed as AD 190. Field trips required at a nominal fee. No previous art and studio experience is necessary for this class. Field Trips Required: Mess Hall, Dorchester Projects and Rebuild Foundation, Threewalls, Hyde Park Art Center, Experimental Station, and South Side Community Art Center, are all site-specific resources for this course. Students will visit at least two of these sites as part of their analysis and exploration of socially engaged art practices. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Creative Arts course.

Course: ART 201 — Democratic Practices in Art Education Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Explores the evolution of various practices and sites of art education in Chicago, the U.S. and in global contexts. The course examines the role of the arts in education and democratic life. Prerequisites: Art Education majors or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: ART 210 — Understanding Curriculum, Development, and Learning in Art Education Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Contextualizes methods of teaching art within histories of art and education. Design and teach curriculum that emphasizes contemporary art, cultural diversity, adolescent development and community issues. Prerequisites: ART 201. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Curriculum, Development, and Learning in Art Education
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 212 — Topics in Drawing I Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: This course addresses current practices and theories in drawing. The course is an investigation of drawing as a vehicle by which to explore a variety of media. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor; and completion of the art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 203. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 223 — Topics in Justice Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 3 Description: Uses aesthetic and theoretical approaches to examine global or local issues of justice; will have rotating topics. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: ART 230 — Topics in Painting I Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Direct experience and related readings investigate innovations and major directions in contemporary painting. The instructor directs in-depth focus regarding a specific topic or emphasis. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor; and completion of art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 230. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: ART 240 — Topics in Sculpture I Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Specific topics, designed by the instructor, address current practices and theories in sculpture and installation. The course is an investigation of sculptural practices as a vehicle by which to explore a variety of media. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of art foundation program. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 250 — Topics in New Media Arts: Intermediate Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Concentration course in New Media Art. Students create artwork with new media technologies, interactive installations, software and computer animation. Includes social, cultural, critical and aesthetic considerations of new media. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the art foundation program. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Topics in New Media Arts: Intermediate
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 260 — Topics in Digital Photography Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Intermediate digital phography: specific topics designed by instructor, conceptual/contextual image making, familiarity with camera, photographic techniques, Photoshop, basic lights techniques and high end printing. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the first-year art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 267. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 261 — Topics in Analog Photography Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to analog black and white photography: advance familiarity with camera, photographic techniques, printing and basic lighting. The course is an investigation of analog photography. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of instructor; and completion of the first-year art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 268. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 270 — Topics in Film I Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: An introduction to 16mm film production in theory and practice. Assignments, screenings, discussions and readings related to experimental cinema supplement topics such as: cinematography, editing, composition and cameraless film making. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 271. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be registered properly, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 272 — Topics in Video I Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: An intermediate video production course in theory and practice. Assignments, screenings, discussions, and readings related to video art as well as technical skills needed for production and post-production. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of instructor; and completion of the art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 278. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 274 — Topics in Motion Graphics I Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to basic film/video animation techniques including direct animation, stop-motion, cycles, metamorphosis, and special graphic processes and effects. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 274. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 275 — Topics in Screenwriting Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Project-based course is an introduction to screenwriting. Students learn the principles of substance, structure and style and how to write in proper script format. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or abaove; or cnsent of the instructor; and completion of the art foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 275. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours.

Course: ART 280 — Topics in Color Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Course presents a wide range of historical and contemporary color theories and investigates color in terms of color science, reproduction and communication. Provides a conceptual framework for approaching color and working knowledge of its attributes. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the Art Foundation Program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 209. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 290 — Art and Resistance: Socially Engaged Art Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Covers an overview of how artists have engaged in political movements and more contemporary examples including artists involved in the Occupy and Black Lives Matter Movements. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Material covered in class will include DaDa which arose as reaction to World War I, German artist Joseph Beuys and his notion of Social Sculpture and his involvement in the Organization for Direct Democracy and the Green Party, the role art and design played in the Black Panther Party, the Guerilla Girls and their feminist critique of art institutions. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Art and Resistance: Socially Engaged Art
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 310 — Visual and Verbal Literacy in Art Education Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Explores relevance of critical theory, text-based contemporary art, cultural studies, and aesthetics to the school art curriculum. Strategies for incorporating reading and writing into arts education. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ART 210 ; and junior standing or above; and approval of the department. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture one Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Visual and Verbal Literacy in Art Education
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 312 — Topics in Drawing II Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Topics directed by the instructor; may include individual study and related readings in contemporary art; further investigation and extended applications in drawing. Prerequisites: ART 212 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 304. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 323 — Topics in Justice Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 3 Description: Uses aesthetic and theoretical approaches to examine global or local issues of justice; will have rotating topics. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: ART 330 — Topics in Painting II Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: In-depth focus regarding a specific topic/emphasis under the direction of the instructor; direct experience and related readings investigate innovations and major directions in contemporary painting. Prerequisites: ART 230 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 332. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 340 — Topics in Sculpture II Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Specific topics--designed by the instructor--address current practices and theories in sculpture and installation. The course is an investigation of sculptural practice as a vehicle by which to explore a variety of media. Prerequisites: ART 240 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 342. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 350 — Advanced Topics in New Media Arts Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Concentration course in New Media Art. Students create artwork with new media technologies, interactive installations, software and computer animation. Includes social, cultural, critical and aesthetic considerations of new media. Prerequisites: ART 250. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in New Media Arts
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 360 — Topics in Photography Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Direct experience and related readings investigate innovations and major directions in contemporary photography. The instructor directs in-depth focus regarding a specific topic or emphasis. Prerequisites: ART 260 ; and junior standing or above; and consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 360. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 362 — Topics in Photography: Alternative Process and Lighting Studio Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Exploring alternative process in photography and how they can inform the work in contemporary practices as well as the exploration of tools and techniques of a photographic lighting studio. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of Art Foundation Program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 262. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Photography: Alternative Process and Lighting Studio
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 370 — Topics in Film II Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: An advanced 16mm production course that uses screenings, readings, and discussions of experimental film to supplement such practical topics as sync-sound recording, color film, digital editing of 16mm film, and post-production techniques. Course Informaion: Previously listed as AD 371. Prerequisites: ART 270 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 372 — Topics in Video II Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: A topics-based project-oriented course that emphasizes advanced media production in the areas of 16mm film, video, motion graphics, and sound. Prerequisites: ART 272 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 378. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 374 — Topics in Motion Graphics II Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Applications of advanced methods in film/video post-production graphics. Creative projects utilizing sound synchronization, computer motion synthesis, and related techniques. Prerequisites: ART 274 ; and junior standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 374. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 376 — Topics in Audio Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Audio production for film, video and sound artists. Study of basic recording, mixing and dissemination techniques and contemporary/historical overview of how artists engage with audio. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 276. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 380 — Topics Seminar Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Seminar and discussion with focus on specific topics relevant to contemporary art practice, examined in relation to critical readings, research, and writing. Prerequisites: AH 160. Open only to juniors and seniors. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 391. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 381 — Topics in Documentary Media Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Specific topics varying each semester will address current practices and theories in documentary media. The mechanical reproduction applied to recording, documenting, and interpreting real life situations and events. Prerequisites: ART 270 and ART 370 ; or ART 272 and ART 372 ; or ART 260 and ART 261 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 362. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.
