Course: ART 382 — Topics in Art Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Multidisciplinary art making course based on a topic chosen by instructor. Course consists of art production and written assignments, lecture, class critiques and individual meetings. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 390 — Art in Context: Socially Engaged Art Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: The context is half the work, a statement by the A.P.G. points to the knowledge that how a work of art is produced cannot be separated from its meaning. This course focuses on art that finds itself in the world and social and political context. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Art in Context: Socially Engaged Art
metadata.subject: Art (ART)

text: Course: ART 400 — Advanced Critique Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: A sustained critical viewing and discussion of student work in order to consider, measure and reconsider effective strategies in artistic production. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required.

Course: ART 401 — Senior Projects: Critique Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 6 Description: Critique/discussion for advanced art majors. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; and consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 462. Class Schedule Information: To be registered properly, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Conference.

Course: ART 402 — Senior Projects: Thesis Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 6 Description: Exhibition/thesis production and seminar culminating in an exhibition/final thesis show for graduating seniors. Prerequisites: ART 401 ; and senior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 453. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Conference.

Course: ART 410 — Art Education Practicum Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Experience in classroom teaching and curriculum design, connecting practices of contemporary artmaking with practices of contemporary critical pedagogy. Design and teach interdisciplinary curriculum. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better or concurrent registration in ART 210 ; and junior standing or above; and approval of the department. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: ART 423 — Topics in Justice Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Uses aesthetic and theoretical approaches to examine global or local issues of justice; will have rotating topics. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours, 4 graduate hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: ART 454 — 3D Space I: Modeling Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to 3D modeling, texturing, lighting and rendering. Students develop a cross-media skill set that can be used for visualizing sculptural and/or architectural installations, filmic animation and compositing, gaming and object design. Prerequisites: Consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 454. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 455 — 3D Space II: Animation Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of 3D Space I: Modeling. Includes a focus on environment design with advanced texturing, lighting, rendering and particles. Prerequisites: ART 454 ; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 455. May be repeated for maximum of 8 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 456 — Embedded Media: Physical Computing Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: A practical and conceptual exploration into electronic sensors, processors and actuators as applied to interactive media. Prerequisites: AD 205; and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 456. Extensive computer use is required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 457 — Interactive 3D Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: An introduction to real-time ineractive art theory and to the design and production practices used in creating 3D applications for games and the web. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 457. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 458 — Advanced Interactive 3D Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Advanced theory and practice of real-time interactive art and producing 3D applications for games and the web. Conceptualization, planning, and development of interactive 3D and virtual reality environments. Prerequisites: ART 457 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 458. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 460 — Advanced Independent Projects: Photography Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: A practical and conceptual exploration into independent individual projects in contemporary photography. Prerequisites: ART 260 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: ART 470 — Adv Projects: Moving Image Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: A practical and conceptual exploration into possibly long form, longer-term individual or collaborative projects in contemporary film and/or video. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ART 272 ; and junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in ART 272 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ART 272 Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): ART 272 Coreq Codes (parsed): ART 272

Course: ART 480 — Independent Study in Art Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 0-5 Description: Intensive workshops in specific art related topics and techniques directed and announced by the instructor. Prerequisites: Junior or graduate standing; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 2 to 5 graduate hours. May be repeated. Previously listed as AD 406. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ART 484 — Educational Practicum with Seminar I Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades nine through twelve. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ART 210 and Grade of B or better in ART 310 and Grade of B or better in ART 410 ; and senior standing or above; and approval of the department and approval of the Council for Teacher Education. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the School of Art and Art History. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: ART 485 — Educational Practicum with Seminar II Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades nine through twelve. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ART 210 and Grade of B or better in ART 310 and Grade of B or better in ART 410 ; and senior standing or above; and approval of the department and approval of Council for Teacher Education. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of School of Art and Art History. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: ART 490 — Art and the Collective Impulse Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 4 Description: Art is collective and social endeavor. This course traces the legacy of group work and artist collectives with a focus on developing successful models for collaboration and participation. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ART 499 — Art Internship Subject: Art (ART) Credits: 0-4 Description: Introduction to professional practice offering students the opportunity to couple academic learning with professional experience in an off-campus placement. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Only 8 hours of credit may apply toward Art major requirements. Requirements for the organization offering an internship: understanding/agreement that a student intern is an artist in training (not a volunteer, not a freelancer) positions are paid (at or above federal minimum wage) student is seeking professional experience (not a portfolio piece) setting is a studio environment (the student is not the only artist on site) 15 hours per week expected, 20 hours per week maximum.

Course: ASP 021 — Workshop for Students Enrolled in MATH 121 Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 2 Description: A workshop where smaller groups of students work together with the instructor to enhance their problem-solving skills by solving additional problems both similar to, as well as more challenging than, the ones given in MATH 121. Corequisites: MATH 121. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

metadata.class_name: Workshop for Students Enrolled in MATH 121
metadata.subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP)

text: Course: ASP 060 — Resources and Strategies for College Success Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 3 Description: Learn study strategies such as time management, studying for and taking tests, critical reading, and critical thinking. Connect to key campus resources that are designed to help students succeed. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit.

metadata.class_name: Resources and Strategies for College Success
metadata.subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP)

text: Course: ASP 061 — Introduction to Positive Psychology Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 1 Description: Student coaches and mentors will study theory in positive psychology, as it relates to the coaching practice. Topics such as motivation, behavioral change, decision making, and communication will be covered. Prerequisites: Students must be pre-approved to register for the course. Students must be working as a coach or mentor in an approved UIC program. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Field work required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Course will take place on Part-of-Term B (second part) of the Fall semester. No graduation credit.

Course: ASP 080 — Workshop for Students Enrolled in MATH 180 Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 2 Description: A workshop where smaller groups of students work together with the instructor to enhance their problem-solving skills by solving additional problems both similar to, as well as more challenging than, the ones given in MATH 180. Corequisites: MATH 180. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

metadata.class_name: Workshop for Students Enrolled in MATH 180
metadata.subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP)

text: Course: ASP 081 — Workshop for Students Enrolled in MATH 181 Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 2 Description: A workshop where smaller groups of students work together with the instructor to enhance their problem-solving skills by solving additional problems both similar to, as well as more challenging than, the ones given in MATH 181. Corequisites: MATH 181. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit.

metadata.class_name: Workshop for Students Enrolled in MATH 181
metadata.subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP)

text: Course: ASP 084 — Research Poster and Presentation Workshop for LARES Students Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 3 Description: Working with a faculty mentor, students conduct research related to the Latino community and present their findings at a pre-selected conference. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Extensive computer use required. Restricted to students in the Latin American Recruitment and Educational Services Program.

metadata.class_name: Research Poster and Presentation Workshop for LARES Students
metadata.subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP)

text: Course: ASP 085 — Boosting Academic Strategies for Success Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 2 Description: Designed to support students who wish to enhance their academic success in and out the classroom. This intensive support program equips students with critical strategies and tools to maximize their learning experience at UIC. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit.

Course: ASP 090 — Critical Strategies for Reading and Writing Success Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 2 Description: Critical reading and thinking strategies for comprehending, writing about, and learning textbook material representing different academic disciplines. Instruction in writing summaries and syntheses of readings included. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit.

metadata.class_name: Critical Strategies for Reading and Writing Success
metadata.subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP)

text: Course: ASP 092 — Vocabulary Enrichment Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 2 Description: Strategies for increasing the number of words students understand in their reading/ listening and use in their speaking/writing. Techniques for learning unfamiliar technical terms in textbooks. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Meets 8 weeks of the semester.

Course: ASP 095 — Academic and Professional Writing Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 2 Description: Academic and professional writing principles and their application are introduced and practiced. Practice in writing resumes, business and professional correspondence, reports, and theses. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit.

Course: ASP 096 — Independent Study Subject: Academic Skills Program (ASP) Credits: 0-3 Description: For those who wish to supplement regular courses or undertake individual study projects. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit.

Course: BA 070 — Elementary Mathematics for Business Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Rational operations and arithmetic, fundamental operations of algebra, linear equations and polynomials, and graphic with applications to business. Prerequisites: Eligibility determined by performance on the placement test. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit.

Course: BA 090 — Intermediate Algebra for Business Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 5 Description: Linear equations, rational expressions, quadratic equations, graphing, exponentials and logarithms, systems of linear equations with applications to business. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in BA 070 or grade of C or better in MATH 070; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: BA 100 — Introduction to Professional Development Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces first year students to UIC Professional development and presence. Students will use self-assessment tools and improvisational techniques to enhance their professional development and strengths. Prerequisites: Admission to the College of Business Administration. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester. Should be taken in the first year after acceptance into the College of Business Administration. Recommended Background: Incoming first year students.

Course: BA 101 — Business First-Year Seminar Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 1 Description: A first-year seminar for students to understand UIC Business academic majors and related careers. Provides a foundation for student success by outlining degree completion, careers and introducing students to resources.

Course: BA 111 — Business Decision-Making Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the qualitative and quantitative frameworks for critically evaluating business scenarios and decisions. Emphasis on applications to illustrate how information is analyzed and used in business decision-making.

Course: BA 190 — UIC Business Seminar Program Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 0-3 Description: The principle objective of the UIC Business Seminar Program is to build and foster the intellectual society within the UIC Business community while introducing students to relevant business material. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours. Students may only be enrolled in one section per term. No graduation credit.Meets eight weeks of the semester. The program provides UIC Business students with the opportunity to closely interact with faculty in a small-group environment. It encourages students to explore potential areas of interest in a unique and innovative manner.

Course: BA 194 — Special Topics in Business Administration Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 1-3 Description: Exploration of topics in Business Administration not covered in existing offerings or study of selected topics in greater depth. Subject matter will vary by offering. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: BA 200 — Business Communication Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of effective business communication applied to practice in writing and speaking, individual and team work; emphasis on written communication. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 or the equivalent.

Course: BA 220 — Business Professional Development II Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 1 Description: Seminar uses experiential activities to develop each student’s authentic professional presence, verbal and non-verbal skills necessary to excel professionally. Interviewing, networking, dynamic presentations, impromptu speaking and creative team. Prerequisites: BA 100. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: BA 289 — Business Internship Program I Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 0-3 Description: Business internships provide students an opportunity to gain practical work experience in their field of study and to test their career choice. Prerequisites: Full-time status, admission into the College of Business Administration, good academic standing, and consent of the director of the Business Career Center. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

Course: BA 290 — Business Ethics Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: A one semester 3 credit hour required elective of all non-accounting business majors, to aid our students in the formation of the attitude, disposition and habit of thinking, working and living in an ethical environment.

Course: BA 299 — Business Administration Study Abroad Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 0-18 Description: Provides credit for foreign study. Student's proposal for study abroad must have prior approval of CBA Undergraduate Student Services. Final determination of credit is made on the student's completion of the work. Prerequisites: Requires approval of the Study Abroad Office and College of Business Administration Undergraduate Student Services. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 48 hours of credit. May be repeated for a maximum of 36 hours per academic year or for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year. Class Schedule Information: Study Abroad. Foreign travel required.

Course: BA 300 — Advanced Managerial Communications Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced study of business communication, including practice in the writing of case studies and reports. Prerequisites: BA 200.

Course: BA 320 — Civic Engagement Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 1 Description: Each semester, the class will be themed on a city-wide issue (homelessness, hunger, education, etc.). We will partner with a local non-profit, that addresses the chosen theme, to provide a direct service opportunity and guest lecturers for the class. Prerequisites: BA 100 and BA 220 ; and junior standing or above. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: BA 330 — Analysis of Firms, Markets, and Industries for Business Decision Making Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of consumer and resource markets; firm production and costs; industry structure, competition, strategy and government regulation and development of managerial decision making skills. Prerequisites: ECON 120 ; and MATH 165 or MATH 160 or MATH 125. Course Information: Credit is not given for BA 330 if the student has credit in ECON 220. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Analysis of Firms, Markets, and Industries for Business Decision Making
metadata.subject: Business Administration (BA)

text: Course: BA 351 — Legal Environment of Business Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the legal, political and regulatory controls that define and limit business practice opportunities. The interaction of law, politics and ethics are emphasized. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BA 200 and MGMT 350. Credit or concurrent registration in BA 200 and MGMT 350 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BA 200 and MGMT 350 Course Information: Credit is not given for BA 351 if student has credit in ACTG 355. Prereq Codes (parsed): BA 200, MGMT 350 Coreq Codes (parsed): BA 200, MGMT 350

Course: BA 395 — Assessment Experience Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 0 Description: Students will complete a day long program to assess learning outcomes, through a test, simulations, individual case analysis, verbal communication exercises, team presentation and teamwork skills designed to assess program learning results. Prerequisites: Open only to juniors and seniors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: BA 420 — Professional Presence Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Workshop style, experiential course using simulations and adapted theater exercises of graduating difficulty that teach students to refine their professional presence. Course Information: Previously listed as ACTG 420.

Course: BA 489 — Business Internship Program II Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 0-3 Description: Business internships provide both graduate and undergraduate professional and practical work experience in their field of study and career choice. Prerequisites: Full-time status, admission into the College of Business Administration, good academic standing at UIC, and consent of the director of the Business Career Center. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

Course: BA 490 — International Student Exchange Program Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 0-18 Description: The Student Exchange Program enables the reciprocal exchange of students between UIC and colleges or universities in other countries. There are a variety of programs tailored to meet the needs of both graduate and undergraduate students. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and approval of the student's major department, the CBA College Office and the Office of International Affairs. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 36 hours per academic year or for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year. Determination of the number of credits to be granted is part of the proposal approval process. Students from other UIC Colleges and Schools are eligible for the program. For more information, visit the website at http://www.uic.edu/depts/oia/resources-student/studentexchange.html.

Course: BA 494 — Special Topics in Business Administration Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 1-4 Description: Exploration of topics in Business Administration not covered in existing offerings or study of selected topics in greater depth. Subject matter will vary by offering. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: BA 495 — Business Strategy Subject: Business Administration (BA) Credits: 3 Description: Strategic management and business policy formulation and implementation. Students will utilize knowledge from all functional areas of business to formulate business strategy and implementation plans through case analysis (may include simulation). Prerequisites: ACTG 210 and ACTG 211 and BA 200 and ECON 218 and IDS 200 and IDS 270 ; and IDS 355 and FIN 300 and MGMT 340 and MGMT 350 and MKTG 360 ; and senior standing or above. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: BCMG 307 — Fundamentals of Biochemistry Subject: Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics (BCMG) Credits: 3 Description: Includes the chemistry of cellular constituents, enzymology, metabolism, and intracellular control and elements of molecular biology. Prerequisites: General and organic chemistry. Lecture course intended primarily for advanced undergraduate students in associated health sciences.

Course: BCMG 399 — Undergraduate Laboratory Research Subject: Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics (BCMG) Credits: 1-4 Description: Laboratory research for advanced undergraduates. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

Course: BCMG 411 — Introduction to Biological Chemistry Subject: Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics (BCMG) Credits: 4 Description: Includes chemistry of cellular constituents; enzymology; metabolism of sugars, proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids; and regulation of metabolism. Prerequisites: Organic chemistry. Lecture course designed primarily for students in the College of Dentistry. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Lecture.

Course: BHIS 399 — Undergraduate Research Experience in Health Informatics Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 1-3 Description: An introduction of Biomedical and Health Informatics research to undergraduate students under the guidance of a Health Informatics faculty research advisor. Prerequisites: Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors; and consent of the instructor. Minimum GPA 3.0. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Offered on-campus only (not online).

metadata.class_name: Undergraduate Research Experience in Health Informatics
metadata.subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS)

text: Course: BHIS 405 — Medical Sciences and Human Pathophysiology Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction of fundamental concepts in pathophysiology. Specific disorders of major organ systems including etiology, manifestations, diagnostic tests, treatment modalities, pharmacotherapy and complications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in KN 251 and Grade of C or better in KN 252; or Grade of C or better in KN 253 and Grade of C or better in KN 254; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught fully online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet.

Course: BHIS 406 — Medical Terminology for Health Information Management Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 2 Description: An Introduction to medical terminology and pharmacology, necessary to understanding the use of clinical vocabularies and classification systems in health information systems. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught fully online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet. Restricted to students in the Department of Biomedical and Health Information Sciences or consent of the Instructor.

metadata.class_name: Medical Terminology for Health Information Management
metadata.subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS)

text: Course: BHIS 410 — Health Data Structures and Management Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 3 Description: Data structures in clinical information systems, including database design and management, networking and security. Emphasis on "intrapreneurial" skills required to solve organizational information management problems. Prerequisites: BHIS 460 and BHIS 461 and BHIS 480.

Course: BHIS 428 — Consumer Health: Engaging Patients Through Technology Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an opportunity to apply patient engagement frameworks through mixed method assessment of health information accessed using health information technology. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Extensive computer use required. Course is offered over 16 weeks for undergraduate students.

metadata.class_name: Consumer Health: Engaging Patients Through Technology
metadata.subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS)

text: Course: BHIS 433 — Principles of Evidence-Based Health Care Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 2 Description: Qualitative and quantitative assessment of human subject clinical research: locating, evaluating, comparing scientific papers as bases for health care education and practice. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing and approval of the school. Course Information: Same as MHPE 433.

Course: BHIS 437 — Health Care Data Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 3 Description: Review of data types in a health care information system. How data is transformed into information and then again transformed into knowledge through integrated computer systems. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught online only. A UIC netid is required.

Course: BHIS 460 — Introduction to Health Informatics Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to information technology and systems in a healthcare setting. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in HIM 410 or equivalent experience. Students should demonstrate basic computing skills including knowledge of an office productivity suite (MS Office or other), electronic mail, and Internet browsers. Credit or concurrent registration in HIM 410 or equivalent experience Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in HIM 410 or equivalent experience Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet. Recommended Background: IDS 200 or the equivalent. Prereq Codes (parsed): HIM 410 Coreq Codes (parsed): HIM 410

Course: BHIS 461 — Information Systems for Health Information Management Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 2 Description: Advanced topics in information technology and systems in a health care setting; collection, analysis and management of health care data; special issues related to the role of health information administrators. Prerequisites: IDS 200 and credit or concurrent registration in BHIS 460. Credit or concurrent registration in BHIS 460 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BHIS 460 Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): BHIS 460 Coreq Codes (parsed): BHIS 460

metadata.class_name: Information Systems for Health Information Management
metadata.subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS)

text: Course: BHIS 480 — Management and Business Practices Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of management with emphasis on business functions, procedures, and organizational structure as applied to various health care settings including private and institutional practice. Prerequisites: Advanced undergraduate or graduate standing in the Department of Biomedical and Health Information Sciences or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: BHIS 499 — Information Sources in Biomedical & Health Information Sciences Subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS) Credits: 1 Description: Prepares students to locate, interpret and evaluate pertinent research information sources. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above required; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester. Extensive computer use required. Taught fully online. Students must have an active UIC netid with valid password and access to a computer and the internet.

metadata.class_name: Information Sources in Biomedical & Health Information Sciences
metadata.subject: Biomedical and Health Information Sciences (BHIS)

text: Course: BIOS 102 — Biological Sciences First-Year Seminar Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 1 Description: Seminar course designed to introduce first-year students in the Biological Sciences major to departmental resources and opportunities that will promote student success. Prerequisites: Open only to freshmen. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: BIOS 104 — Biology for Non-majors Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Origin and diversity of life; genetics, evolution, ecology and ecosystems; energy flow; photosynthesis; human anatomy and physiology; development of biological ideas; and biology, biotechnology and human society. Course Information: Credit is not given for BIOS 104 if the student has credit in BIOS 100 or BIOS 101 or BIOS 110 or BIOS 120. Animals may be used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: BIOS 110 — Biology of Cells and Organisms Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Introductory biology at the molecular, cellular, and organismal level. Topics include: Scientific skills, biological chemistry, cell structure and function, metabolism, cell division, molecular genetics, diversity, anatomy and physiology. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOS 100. Animals used in instruction. THIS COURSE IS INTENDED FOR SCIENCE MAJORS. BIOS 110 and BIOS 120 may be taken in any order. Credit is not given for BIOS 110 if the student has credit in BIOS 100. Credit is not given for BIOS 104 if the student has credit in BIOS 100, BIOS 101, BIOS 110 or BIOS 120. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory-Discussion. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: BIOS 112 — Program Design I in the Context of Biological Problems Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to programming using Biology as the context for programming in a high-level language; control structures, variables, simple and aggregate data types; problem-solving techniques; biology topics include central dogma and genetics. Course Information: Same as CS 112. Credit is not given for BIOS 112 if the student has credit in CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 111 or CS 113 or MCS 160 or MCS 260. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Program Design I in the Context of Biological Problems
metadata.subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS)

text: Course: BIOS 120 — Biology of Populations and Communities Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Introductory biology at the level of populations and communities. Topics include: Scientific skills, evolution, Mendelian and population genetics, biological diversity, and ecological systems including ecosystem processes and human impacts. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOS 101. Animals used in instruction. This course is intended for science majors. BIOS 110 and BIOS 120 may be taken in any order. Credit is not given for BIOS 120 if the student has credit in BIOS 101. Credit is not given for BIOS 104 if the student has credit in BIOS 100, BIOS 101, BIOS 110 or BIOS 120. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: BIOS 184 — The Basics of Neuroscience Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to the scientific study of the brain and behavior. Overview of neuroscience as an integrative discipline. Course Information: Same as PHIL 184 and PSCH 184. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: BIOS 196 — Biology Colloquium Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 2 Description: Combines in-class seminars with off-campus day and weekend field trips, with the goal of introducing students to different areas of the Biological Sciences, and alternate career options. Prerequisites: Major in biological sciences, biochemistry, or neuroscience. Course Information: May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: BIOS 199 — Introduction to Research Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 1 Description: An introduction to research for students interested in becoming biology majors. Credit is contingent on approval by the research supervisor of a written report that is also submitted to the Biology colloquium faculty adviser. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: 1 hour. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Laboratory.

Course: BIOS 220 — Genetics Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of genetics, gene and chromosome structure, gene expression, inheritance of complex traits, Mendelian and non-Mendelian inheritance, genomes, and genetic engineering. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110 ; and BIOS 101 or BIOS 120. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 222 — Cell Biology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: The physiological processes that govern cell function. Topics include enzyme kinetics, metabolism, membranes, membrane transport, electrical and chemical signaling, intracellular motors, motility, and junctions. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110.

Course: BIOS 230 — Evolution and Ecology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Molecular and ecological basis of evolutionary change through adaptation or natural selection to explain diversity of species, behaviors, populations, communities and ecosystems and how these interactions are affected by the changing environment. Prerequisites: BIOS 101 or BIOS 120.

Course: BIOS 236 — Animal Behavior Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Examine the proximate and ultimate causes of animal behavior; neural and hormonal mechanisms; diversity of behavior and their relationship to an organism's ecology and evolution. Prerequisites: BIOS 101 or BIOS 120.

Course: BIOS 237 — The Human Skeleton Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Examination of the human skeleton, emphasizing bone identification and functional anatomy. Course Information: Same as ANTH 237. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 250 — Microbiology and Application to Health Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to microbial growth and metabolism, disease pathogenicity and control, epidemiology and human infections. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110 ; and Credit in CHEM 115 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 130 or CHEM 230 or CHEM 232. Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 130 or CHEM 230 or CHEM 232 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 130 or CHEM 230 or CHEM 232 Course Information: Credit for BIOS 250 is not given if the student has credit in BIOS 350. Intended for pre-nursing students and should not be taken by those who need BIOS 350. Recommended Background: BIOS 101 or BIOS 120. Prereq Codes (parsed): CHEM 130, CHEM 230, CHEM 232 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHEM 130, CHEM 230, CHEM 232

Course: BIOS 272 — Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Comparative vertebrate anatomy through the analysis of varying morphological features of hard and soft tissues. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110 ; and BIOS 101 or BIOS 120. Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 286 — The Biology of the Brain Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of basic neurobiology. Brain structure, chemistry, development and control of behavior (sensation, movement, emotions, memory, cognition, sex). Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110.

Course: BIOS 294 — Special Topics in Biological Sciences Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 1-5 Description: Selected topics in the Biological Sciences. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: BIOS 296 — Directed Instruction Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 2 Description: Leadership opportunity for upper-division students who wish to assist with the biology colloquium. Prerequisites: BIOS 196 and approval of the department. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discusssion and one Practice. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Students will be required to submit a final report describing their leadership activities and experiences.

Course: BIOS 299 — Honors Biology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 1 Description: An additional hour of related work for students registered in another course in Biological Sciences. Prerequisites: Membership in Honors College, or, for superior students, approval of the department; and registration in a Biological Sciences course (except BIOS 391 or BIOS 399 ) and consent of the instructor. Open only to freshmen, sophomores, and juniors. Honors course. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: BIOS 305 — Plant Evolutionary Ecology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Fundamental aspects of plant structure and function, plant-environment interactions, and how they shape biodiversity, with an emphasis on their evolutionary context. Prerequisites: BIOS 230.

Course: BIOS 310 — Genetics Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 2 Description: Advanced laboratory techniques in gene inheritance, expression and regulation using genetic engineering, molecular biology and bioinformatic and statistical analysis to study Mendelian, microbial, molecular, human and population genetics. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 220. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 220 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 220 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOS 221. Animals used in instruction. Credit is not given for BIOS 310 if student has credit in BIOS 221. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 220 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 220

Course: BIOS 312 — Cell Biology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 2 Description: Laboratory training in advanced cell biology methods used in research and clinical settings. Microscopy, protein extraction and quantification, immunoassays, cell culture, experimental design, data analysis and scientific writing are emphasized. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent credit in BIOS 222. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOS 223. Credit is not given for BIOS 312 if the student has credit in BIOS 223.

Course: BIOS 320 — Developmental Biology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Principles governing growth and differentiation from the molecular to the organismic level. Prerequisites: BIOS 220.

Course: BIOS 321 — Developmental Biology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Laboratory problems in developmental biology. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 320. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 320 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 320 Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 320 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 320

Course: BIOS 323 — Molecular Biology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Modern molecular biology techniques used in the isolation and functional analysis of genes. Bioinformatics, gene cloning, gene fusions and expression assays will be used in the analysis of the gene isolation and analysis. Prerequisites: BIOS 220.

Course: BIOS 325 — Human Embryology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Major events in human development between fertilization and birth. The developmental origins of adult body structure and function, normal anatomical variations, and congenital malformations. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110.

Course: BIOS 326 — Embryology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 1 Description: Examination of histological sections of mammalian embryos. Identification of cells and tissues from their microscopic appearance, reading serial sections. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 325. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 325 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 325 Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 325 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 325

Course: BIOS 331 — General Ecology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Field and laboratory data collection for hypothesis testing; required field trips to representative plant communities. Prerequisites: BIOS 101 or BIOS 120. Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Required field trips on Saturdays. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Practice.

Course: BIOS 333 — Visualizing Biological Data Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Data visualization and graphing principles and techniques in the Biological Sciences, including ethical data communication and data visualizations for both scientific and non-scientific audiences. Prerequisites: BIOS 110 ; and BIOS 220 or BIOS 222 or BIOS 230. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: STAT 100 or STAT 130.

Course: BIOS 336 — Animal Behavior Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Field and laboratory data collection for hypothesis testing in animal behavior. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 236. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 236 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 236 Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 236 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 236

Course: BIOS 340 — Environmental Physiology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: The performance of an organism or group of organisms in the context of their natural environment and their evolutionary background. The organism as an integrated system rather than a collection of cellular or organ processes. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110 ; and BIOS 101 or BIOS 120.

Course: BIOS 343 — Animal Physiological Systems Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: How the human body works including digestive, neuromuscular, sensory, respiratory, excretory, endocrine and cardiovascular systems using examples across animal species and human case studies. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOS 240. Credit is not given for BIOS 343 if student has credit in BIOS 240. Recommended Background: BIOS 222.

Course: BIOS 350 — General Microbiology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the morphology, staining, genetics, physiology, and biochemistry of microbial life with special emphasis on prokaryotic structure, function, diversity, and importance to human beings. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110 ; and Credit for CHEM 115 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 130 or CHEM 230 or CHEM 232. Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 130 or CHEM 230 or CHEM 232 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 130 or CHEM 230 or CHEM 232 Recommended Background: BIOS 101 or BIOS 120. Prereq Codes (parsed): CHEM 130, CHEM 230, CHEM 232 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHEM 130, CHEM 230, CHEM 232

Course: BIOS 351 — Microbiology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 2 Description: Laboratory experience with aseptic and pure culture techniques; staining and microscopy of microorganisms; identification of unknown bacteria; control of microbial growth; antibiotics; medical microbiology. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 250 or BIOS 350. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 250 or BIOS 350 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 250 or BIOS 350 Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 250, BIOS 350 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 250, BIOS 350

Course: BIOS 352 — Introductory Biochemistry Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Structure and function of cellular constituents; enzymology; metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, nucleotides; molecular biology of biosynthesis of proteins and nucleic acids. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110 ; and BIOS 101 or BIOS 120 ; and CHEM 230 or CHEM 232. Course Information: Same as CHEM 352. No credit given for BIOS 352 if student has credit in BIOS 452 or BIOS 454 or CHEM 452 or CHEM 454. No credit toward the degree in biochemistry.

Course: BIOS 355 — Immunology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Innate and adaptive immune responses. Humoral immune responses, cell mediated responses, hypersensitivity, autoimmunity, cancer, and immunodeficiency. Prerequisites: BIOS 222. Recommended Background: BIOS 350 or BIOS 250.

Course: BIOS 360 — Introduction to Paleontology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: The morphology, ecology, and relationships of fossil organisms. Basic principles of paleontology, including evolution, paleoecology and functional morphology. Prerequisites: EAES 101 or EAES 111 ; or BIOS 110 and BIOS 120. Course Information: Same as EAES 360. Field trip required at a nominal fee. One day field trip to collect fossils. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 365 — Human Ecological Systems Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Human-environmental interactions and feedbacks (positive and negative) and the ecological basis for health and sustainability of human-dominated landscapes. Case studies of real-world environmental issues. Prerequisites: BIOS 101 or BIOS 120 or EAES 101 or PSCH 100 or SOC 100 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: BIOS 386 — Seminar on Neurobiology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 2 Description: Reading and discussion of both classic and recent research papers that are important in neurobiology. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or PSCH 262.

Course: BIOS 391 — Independent Study Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 1 Description: Individual study not covered in standard courses under close supervision of a faculty member. Credit is contingent on approval by research supervisor of a written report that is submitted to the department. Prerequisites: Minimum of 2.00 grade point average in biological sciences courses and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. A maximum of 5 hours of BIOS 391 and/or BIOS 399 may be credited toward the department undergraduate major requirements. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: BIOS 399 — Independent Research Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 2 Description: Individual research. Credit is contingent on approval by the research supervisor of a written report that is submitted to the department. Prerequisites: Minimum of 2.00 grade point average in biological sciences courses, approval of the department, and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. A maximum of 5 hours of BIOS 391 and/or BIOS 399 may be credited toward the department undergraduate major requirements. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major. Recommended Background: Junior standing.

Course: BIOS 416 — Natural Products Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Biogenetic approach to secondary metabolites. General principles and selected studies of phenolic compounds, terpenes, alkaloids, and other interesting natural products. Prerequisites: One year of organic chemistry. Course Information: Same as CHEM 456. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: BIOS 420 — Genomics Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical background in genomics with practical experience in obtaining and analyzing large scale Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) datasets using high capacity computational resources. Prerequisites: BIOS 220 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: STAT 101 or STAT 130 or BIOS 112.

Course: BIOS 427 — Ecosystem Ecology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Flow of energy and matter between the environment and biological organisms including bioological interactions that govern the cycling of water, carbon and nutrients at various spatial and temporal scales. Prerequisites: BIOS 230. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: BIOS 430 — Evolution Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Empirical evolutionary data and theory, with an intro to data science, modeling, simulations in R programming language; it covers the history of evolution, population genetics, the species problem, biodiversity, macroevolution. Prerequisites: BIOS 120 and either BIOS 220 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Recommended Background: BIOS 230.

Course: BIOS 431 — Plant and Animal Interactions Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Ecology of plant and animal interactions. In-depth reading and discussion of primary literature on herbivory and plant defense and pollination, seed dispersal and protection mutualisms. Prerequisites: BIOS 230.

Course: BIOS 435 — Plant Evolution Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the history of plant life in a rigorous survey of plant genetics, factors that influence diversity of form and function, the astonishing diversity of plant sexual systems, and conservation. Prerequisites: BIOS 230.

Course: BIOS 437 — Topics in Tropical Ecology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the character of tropical ecosystems. In-depth reading and discussion of one or more current topics. Prerequisites: BIOS 230.

Course: BIOS 443 — Animal Physiological Systems Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Discussion and laboratory exploration of mammalian physiological systems, including immune, endocrine, cardiac, vascular, nervous, pulmonary, renal, and digestive systems. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 343 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 340 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 343 Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 340 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 343 Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 340 Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture, one Laboratory, and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 343, BIOS 340 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 343, BIOS 340

Course: BIOS 446 — Evolution and Human Disease Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Pathogen evolution, transmission of infectious disease, host response to pathogens, drug resistance in pathogens, and cancer progression/treatment are examined in light of natural selection, phylogenetics, coevolution, and population genetics. Prerequisites: BIOS 230. Recommended Background: BIOS 220.

Course: BIOS 450 — Advanced Microbiology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Comprehensive analysis of metabolic, ecological, genomic, and functional diversity among the major groups of microorganisms. Relationship between microbial diversity and biogeochemistry in the environment, human/animal hosts, and engineered systems. Prerequisites: BIOS 350.

Course: BIOS 452 — Biochemistry I Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Chemistry of proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates and lipids. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 230 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 234. Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 234 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 234 Course Information: Same as CHEM 452. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Prereq Codes (parsed): CHEM 234 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHEM 234

Course: BIOS 454 — Biochemistry II Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Continues Biological Sciences 452. Carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, electron transport. Metabolism of amino acids, nucleic acids, proteins. Biosynthesis of macromolecules and regulation of macromolecular synthesis. Prerequisites: BIOS 452 or CHEM 452. Course Information: Same as CHEM 454. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 455 — Introduction to Landscape Ecology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Uses a combination of lectures, discussions, and hands-on activities to introduce the concepts and methods of landscape ecology. We will discuss how landscape ecology can be applied to solving current environmental problems. Prerequisites: BIOS 230 ; or BIOS 331. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: BIOS 458 — Biotechnology and Drug Discovery Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Molecular and gene therapy, using small molecules including antisense, aptamers, and proteins. Structure-based drug design. Structural bioinformatics and drug discovery program. High-throughput screening. Combinatorial chemistry technology. Prerequisites: BIOS 352 or CHEM 352 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 452 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 452 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 452 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 452 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 452 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 452 Course Information: Same as CHEM 458. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 452, CHEM 452 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 452, CHEM 452

Course: BIOS 460 — Molecular Biophysics of the Cell Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to force, time energies at nanometer scales; Boltzmann distribution; hydrodynamic drag; Brownian motions; DNA, RNA protein structure and function; sedimentation; chemical kinetics; general aspects of flexible polymers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 245 or Grade of C or better in PHYS 260 or the equivalent; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same BME 450 and PHYS 450.

Course: BIOS 466 — Principles of Paleontology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and methods of evolutionary paleobiology; includes paleoecology, functional morphology, and major features of organic evolution. Prerequisites: EAES 360 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as EAES 466. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 473 — Soils and the Environment Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Soil science, emphasizing local soils and parent materials, soil classification and mapping, soil physics, soil gases and greenhouse gas emissions, soil chemistry and biogeochemistry, soil-plant interactions, and soil invertebrates. Course Information: Same as EAES 473. Field work required. Recommended Background: Introductory courses in Chemistry and Biology. Coursework in EAES (such as EAES 101 and/or EAES 111 ) is preferred.

Course: BIOS 475 — Neural Engineering I: Introduction to Hybrid Neural Systems Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Modeling and design of functional neural interfaces for in vivo and in vitro applications, electrodes and molecular coatings, neural prostheses and biopotential control of robotics. Prerequisites: BIOE 472 or BME 472. Course Information: Same as BME 475. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Neural Engineering I: Introduction to Hybrid Neural Systems
metadata.subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS)

text: Course: BIOS 480 — Introduction to Modern Biostatistics with R Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: An in-depth intro to research design, data visualization, and modern univariate statistics, from basic linear model to generalized linear models and linear mixed-effects models. Prerequisites: MATH 170 or MATH 180 or STAT 130. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. All work done in the open-source R statistical computing language. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Modern Biostatistics with R
metadata.subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS)

text: Course: BIOS 482 — Molecular and Developmental Neurobiology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: A hands-on laboratory course designed to explore the most recent neurotechniques and how they are being used to advance knowledge of the brain. Model organism use will be restricted to small invertebrates (C. elegans). Prerequisites: BIOS 286 ; or PSCH 262.

Course: BIOS 483 — Neuroanatomy Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Organization of the nervous system, with an emphasis on mammals. Prerequisites: BIOS 272 or BIOS 286 or BIOS 325 or PSCH 262 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PSCH 483 and NEUS 483. Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 484 — Neuroscience I Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Neuroscience as an integrative discipline. Neuroanatomy of vertebrates, neural development, cellular neurobiology, action potential mechanisms, synaptic transmission and neuropharmacology. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or PSCH 262. Course Information: Same as PHIL 484 and PSCH 484.

Course: BIOS 485 — Neuroscience II Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Integrative neuroscience, including sensory and motor systems; learning, memory, and language; pathology of nervous systems; philosophical perspectives, and modeling. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or PSCH 262. Course Information: Same as PHIL 485 and PSCH 485.

Course: BIOS 486 — Animal Behavior and Neuroethology Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 4 Description: Neural and behavioral mechanisms of environmental information processing and interaction throughout the animal kingdom. Laboratory emphasizing a research project with journal style lab report, essay on assigned topic, occasional field trips required. Prerequisites: One course in neuroscience, animal physiology, or animal behavior. Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: BIOS 489 — Cellular Neurobiology Laboratory Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 Description: Recording from and analyzing the activity of nerve cells, neuronal networks, and other electrically excitable tissues. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or the equivalent.

Course: BIOS 490 — Topics Biological Sciences Subject: Biological Sciences (BIOS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In-depth analysis of advanced topics in molecular, cellular, biomedical, ecology and evolution and neuroscience involving reading primary literature, term paper, student presentations and critical discussion. Prerequisites: BIOS 230 ; or BIOS 220 ; or BIOS 222 ; or Graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: BLST 100 — Introduction to Black Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: The Black experience, focusing on African and African American culture, the slave trade, slavery and emancipation in the Americas, 20th and 21st century social relations, and struggles for civil rights. Course Information: Previously listed as AAST 100. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: BLST 101 — Introduction to Black Diaspora Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the historical and contemporary dispersal of people from the African continent around the globe beginning in the 15th century to the present. Course Information: Previously listed as AAST 101. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: BLST 103 — Black Politics and Culture in the United States Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: The shifting relationship between black politics and black cultural forms across various historical periods. Course Information: Same as POLS 112. Previously listed AAST 103. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Black Politics and Culture in the United States
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 104 — Race, Place, and Schooling: Black Americans and Education Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the social, political, cultural, and economic factors shaping Black Americans' educational experiences in the United States histprically and currently. Course Information: Same as EDPS 104. Previously listed as AAST 104. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Race, Place, and Schooling: Black Americans and Education
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 105 — Black Film, 1900 - Present: Images, Individuals and Ideas on Screen Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the history of black people in film – looking both at films by black people in the United States and the diaspora, and at the relationship between black filmmakers, performers, and audiences to national and global film industries. Course Information: Same as COMM 105 and MOVI 105. Previously listed as AAST 105. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Black Film, 1900 - Present: Images, Individuals and Ideas on Screen
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 110 — Introduction to African American Literature, 1760-1910 Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Comprehensive survey, 1760-1910, from earliest folk roots to formal literary tradition. Course Information: Same as ENGL 118. Previously listed as AAST 110. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: BLST 111 — Introduction to African American Literature Since 1910 Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Comprehensive survey of African American literature from 1910 to the present. Course Information: Same as ENGL 119. Previously listed as AAST 111. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to African American Literature Since 1910
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 125 — Black Religious Traditions Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the religious history of black people in the United States and the diaspora. Examination of religious institutions, the role of religion in black social and political movements, mass rebellions, and revolts. Course Information: Same as RELS 125. Previously listed as AAST 125. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: BLST 191 — African and Caribbean Francophone Literature in Translation Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the Francophone literature of Africa and the Caribbean and to its historical and cultural contexts. Course Information: Same as FR 191. Previously listed as AAST 191. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: African and Caribbean Francophone Literature in Translation
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 206 — Black Studies and the Production of Knowledge Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Students will explore the history and implications of research in a wide range of fields and gain an introduction to anti-racist, decolonial, and feminist approaches to knowledge production. Prerequisites: Three credit hours in Black Studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AAST 206.

metadata.class_name: Black Studies and the Production of Knowledge
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 207 — Racism: Global Perspectives Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to global, transnational, and comparative perspectives on racism. Analysis of race and racism not only in the United States, but also in Africa, the Middle East, Latin America, Europe, and other contexts. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as SOC 207. Previously listed as AAST 207.

Course: BLST 210 — Ancient Egyptian Art and Archaeology Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the art, architecture, archaeology and material culture of ancient societies in Egypt from prehistory to the end of the Ptolemaic Dynasty (ca 6000-30 BCE). Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as AH 210 and CL 210. Credit is not given for BLST 210 if the student has credit in ARST 210 or AH 210 or CL 210. Previously listed as AAST 210. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Recommended Background: Credit in AH 100 or AH 110.

Course: BLST 221 — The Atlantic Slave Trade: Violence, Exploitation, Resistance Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Thematic social, cultural and economic history tracing rise and fall of Atlantic slave trade from African supply systems to New world consumption 1550-1880 with focus on slave experiences. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as HIST 221. Previously listed as AAST 221. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: The Atlantic Slave Trade: Violence, Exploitation, Resistance
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 225 — Racial and Ethnic Groups Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Sociological and social-psychological analysis of racial, religious, and other ethnic groups; consideration of historical and current social problems arising from their relationships in society. Prerequisites: SOC 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as LALS 225 and SOC 225. Previously listed as AAST 225.

Course: BLST 229 — Black Diaspora Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Interdisciplinary, in-depth study of the making of the African Diaspora--the forced and voluntary movement of African peoples around the globe. Topics may vary. Prerequisites: BLST 100 ; or BLST 101. Course Information: Same as HIST 229. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Previously listed as AAST 229.

Course: BLST 241 — Precolonial Africa in World History Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: The history of African societies in the period before 1850 through the rise of kingdoms and territorial states, migration of peoples, the spread and impact of Islam, and west African trading networks. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 241. Previously listed as AAST 241. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: BLST 242 — History of Modern Africa Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: The effect of European partition and colonialism; African military and political resistance; economic imperialism; the rise of nationalism; the problems of independence. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 242. Previously listed as AAST 242. Class Schedule Information: to be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: BLST 246 — Black Lives in Historical Context Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Interdisciplinary survey of key episodes in black history and their relationship to contemporary black life such as slavery, abolition and resistance. The course will draw connections between historical and current aspects of black life. Prerequisites: BLST 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as HIST 243. Previously listed as AAST 246.

Course: BLST 247 — African American History to 1877 Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major social, economic, political, and cultural developments in African American history from the rise of the Atlantic Slave Trade to Reconstruction. Prerequisites: One course in Black Studies or History; or consent of the instructor. Past course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as HIST 247. Previously listed as AAST 247.

Course: BLST 248 — African American History since 1877 Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major social, economic, and political developments in African American history since Reconstruction. Topics include Jim Crow, black leadership, migration, civil rights and nationalism. Prerequisites: One course in Black Studies or History; or consent of the instructor. Past course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as HIST 248. Previously listed as AAST 248.

Course: BLST 249 — Black Freedom Movements in the U.S Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of Black resistance and social change movements from the 1900's through the 1970's; the political ideologies and practices of various leaders and organizations that have had an impact on Black American politics. Course Information: Previously listed as AAST 249. Past course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Black Freedom Movements in the U.S
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 250 — Comparative Black Literatures Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Selected works of literature and criticism in the context of the U.S. and the Black diaspora.
