Comparative study of race, culture, and politics in literature. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or completion of the English composition requirement. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as ENGL 260. Previously listed as AAST 250.

Course: BLST 252 — U.S. Racism and Imperialism Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examines histories and narratives of U.S. imperialism and racism. Investigates how U.S. imperial power is inextricably tied to the workings of racial difference and hierarchy. Same as GLAS 252. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100 or Grade of C or better in BLST 100 or Grade of C or better in BLST 101. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: BLST 258 — Race and Urban Life Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the experiences of Blacks in urban areas since the 1900's. Course Information: Same as SOC 258. Previously listed as AAST 258.

Course: BLST 261 — Reading Black Women Writing Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examines inscriptions of race, gender, class, and sexuality as they shape the literary and critical practices of black women writers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in a 100-level Black Studies or African American literature course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ENGL 261 and GWS 261. Previously listed as AAST 261.

Course: BLST 262 — Black Cultural Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Study of approaches, methods, and key debates in the study of black culture in a transnational and diasporic context. Prerequisites: BLST 100. Creative Arts course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as ENGL 262. Previously listed as AAST 262.

Course: BLST 263 — Black Intellectual History Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Key debates and contributions of black thought to national and global politics and culture since the 19th century. Prerequisites: BLST 100. Individual and Society course, and Past course. Course Information: Same as HIST 263. Previously listed as AAST 263.

Course: BLST 264 — African American Art Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Interdisciplinary survey of the artistic production of African American artists from the nineteenth century to the present. Course Information: Same as AH 264. Previously listed as AAST 264. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: BLST 265 — Harlem Renaissance Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: The intellectual, cultural, and artistic expressions among African Americans from 1912 to 1933, with an emphasis on the literary texts and social history. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in BLST 100 ; and Grade of C or better in BLST 110 or Grade of C or better in BLST 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as ENGL 265. Previously listed as AAST 265.

Course: BLST 266 — Topics in African Literature Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examination and analysis of selected works of African literature, history, and criticism. Topics will vary. Course Information: Same as ENGL 266. May be repeated. Previously listed as AAST 266.

Course: BLST 270 — African Art Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the arts of the major tribal cultures of Sub-Saharan Africa. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as AH 270. Previously listed as AAST 270.

Course: BLST 271 — Race and the Politics of Incarceration Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examines how incarceration and criminalization affects black people in contemporary society. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in BLST 100 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SOC 100 or Grade of C or better in CLJ 101. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as CLJ 271 and SOC 271. Previously listed as AAST 271.

metadata.class_name: Race and the Politics of Incarceration
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 272 — Race, Gender, and Sexuality Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Explores how Black feminist and queer intellectual work on race, gender and sexuality has been used to radically reimagine what a just world would look like. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Course Information: Same as GWS 272. Previously listed as AAST 272. Prereq Codes (parsed): ENGL 161 Coreq Codes (parsed): ENGL 161

Course: BLST 274 — The Politics of Blackness in Latin America Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Examines race, culture, and politics in Latin America from historical and contemporary perspectives with a particular emphasis on the latter half of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century. Course Information: Same as LALS 274 and POLS 274. Recommended Background: Three credit hours in BLST or LALS or POLS.

metadata.class_name: The Politics of Blackness in Latin America
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 294 — Topics in Black Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in Black Studies. Specific topics are announced each term. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register for more than one section per term. Previously listed as AAST 294.

Course: BLST 306 — Black Politics in the United States Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Historical analysis of Black electoral politics in the U.S., including traditional political party participation and movement politics. Prerequisites: Three courses in political science, history or sociology; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 311. Previously listed as AAST 306.

metadata.class_name: Black Politics in the United States
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 351 — Topics in Black Art and Literature Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Study of literature and the other arts in the context of the African diaspora. Topics vary. Prerequisites: Introductory course in Black Studies or English; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ENGL 351. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary. Previously listed as AAST 351.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Black Art and Literature
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 356 — Constitutional Law: Women, Gender and Privacy Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: A multidisciplinary examination of U.S. constitutional law and politics in shaping issues of gender, privacy, race, and sexual orientation; including reproduction, labor, sexual harassment, political participation, and women and crime. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in POLS 101 or Grade of C or better in POLS 112 ; or Grade of C or better in BLST 100 or Grade of C or better in BLST 103 ; or Grade of C or better in GWS 101 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 356 and POLS 356. Previously listed as AAST 356.

metadata.class_name: Constitutional Law: Women, Gender and Privacy
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 358 — Constitutional Law: African-American Legal History Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the African-American constitutional experience from the 1600s to the present, focusing on landmark decisions of the United States Supreme Court. Course Information: Same as POLS 358. Previously listed as AAST 358.

Course: BLST 394 — Special Topics in Black Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Selected advanced topics in Black Studies. Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: BLST 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: BLST 398 — Independent Study: Special Topics Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 1-3 Description: Selected topics for individual research. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and departmental approval. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Previously listed as AAST 398.

Course: BLST 401 — Senior Seminar in Black Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 Description: Through weekly readings, discussions, and assignments, students will be guided through a hands-on process of developing a senior project within a small, supportive and dynamic learning community. Prerequisites: BLST 206 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AAST 401.

Course: BLST 406 — Topics in Black Feminist and Queer Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced study of topics related to theories of race, gender and sexuality with a specific focus on black feminist and queer studies. Topics may vary. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and one 100-level course in Black Studies or one 100-level course in Gender and Women’s Studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 406. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Black Feminist and Queer Studies
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 407 — Seminar in Comparative Racialization Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an interdisciplinary and comparative approach to the making and remaking of "race" and the resultant racialized experiences of different groups in the U.S. and globally. Prerequisites: BLST 207 or SOC 207 or BLST 225 or SOC 225 or LALS 225 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as SOC 407. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as AAST 407.

Course: BLST 408 — Global Black Feminisms Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines transnational, Third Wave and Third World Black feminist approaches to global politics from historical and contemporary perspectives with a particular emphasis on the late 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century. Course Information: Same as GWS 408 and LALS 408. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Undergraduate students: at least three credit hours in BLST or GWS or LALS.

Course: BLST 410 — Race, Gender and Representation: Black Bodies in Media and Mass Culture Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the ideological, cultural and economic structures that shape the representation of Black subjects in performance, visual arts, and mass media, paying close attention to gender and sexuality. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as COMM 410 and GWS 410. Recommended Background: Three or more credit hours in Black Studies or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Race, Gender and Representation: Black Bodies in Media and Mass Culture
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 441 — Topics in African History Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of African history, Black Studies, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 441. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated.

Course: BLST 481 — Topics in African American and Diaspora History Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: African American history and/or history of the diaspora for students with significant background in the field. Topics vary. Prerequisites: 3 hours of BLST history course or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 485. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in African American and Diaspora History
metadata.subject: Black Studies (BLST)

text: Course: BLST 490 — Topics in Black Literature Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The study and analysis of selected works of Black literature and culture for students with significant background in the field. Topics vary by semester. Prerequisites: BLST 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ENGL 473. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Previously listed as AAST 490.

Course: BLST 492 — Topics in Social Science Research Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examination of selected specialized topics that vary each semester. Topics are drawn from research in political science, psychology, sociology, and history. Prerequisites: BLST 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one term per semester. Previously listed as AAST 492.

Course: BLST 494 — Advanced Topics in Black Studies Subject: Black Studies (BLST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In-depth study of selected topics in the field of Black Studies. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Any two 200-level Black Studies courses or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: BME 101 — Introduction to Biomedical Engineering Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Principles, practice, and the role of biomedical engineers in science, engineering, and commercialization of medical products. Professional ethics, career paths, introduction to graphical design tools and instrumentation. Course Information: Credit is not given for BME 101 if the student has credit in BIOE 101. Previously listed as BIOE 101.

Course: BME 102 — Biomedical Engineering Freshman Seminar Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 1 Description: Exposure to biomedical engineering research through attendance of graduate student seminars followed by faculty-mediated discussion. Writing seminar summaries, student shadowing, articulating long-term goals, and planning an academic trajectory. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as BIOE 102. Restricted to first year Biomedical Engineering students (freshmen or transfer students).

Course: BME 194 — Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering I Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 1-5 Description: Special topics to be arranged. Course topics aimed at first-year students. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering I
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 205 — Biomedical Engineering Thermodynamics Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to equilibrium and non-equilibrium thermodynamics, with emphasis on non-equilibrium (living) systems. Applications include thermodynamics of living cells and the lung, molecular energy exchange, and energy exchange in exercise. Prerequisites: PHYS 141. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 205. Credit is not given for BME 205 if the student has credit in BIOE 205 or CHE 201 or ME 205.

Course: BME 240 — Modeling Physiological Data and Systems Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Computational tools and techniques for models and statistics used to describe, interpret and analyze physiological data and systems. Time series, image and population data types. Prerequisites: BIOS 110 ; and MATH 180 ; and CS 109. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 240. Credit is not given for BME 240 is students have credit for BIOE 240.

Course: BME 250 — Clinical Problems in Biomedical Engineering Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of three current problems in biomedical engineering. Student teams work with a faculty facilitator toward each solution. Problem identification, strategic planning, brainstorming, information gathering, and reporting. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 101 and Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 102; or Credit or concurrent registration in BME 101 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 102. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 101 and Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 102 Credit or concurrent registration in BME 101 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 102 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 101 and Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 102 Credit or concurrent registration in BME 101 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 102 Course Information: Credit is not given for BME 250 if the student has credit in BIOE 250. Previously listed as BIOE 250. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOE 101, BIOE 102, BME 101, BME 102 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOE 101, BIOE 102, BME 101, BME 102

Course: BME 294 — Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering II Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 1-5 Description: Special topics to be arranged. Course topics aimed at second-year students. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering II
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 310 — Biological Systems Analysis Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Modeling of physiological system dynamics using frequency and Laplace domain methods, as well as their computational implementation in Matlab. Measurement of physiological system dynamics. Prerequisites: MATH 220 and MATH 310; and BIOE 240 or BME 240. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 310. Credit is not given for BME 310 if the student has credit in BIOE 310 or ECE 310 or ME 312.

Course: BME 325 — Biotransport Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Transport phenomena in biomedical engineering and living systems, specifically processes vital to the design of medical devices for artificial clinical intervention. Topics include circulatory system dynamics and modeling of physiological systems. Prerequisites: BIOS 110 and MATH 220 and BME 205 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 310. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 310 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 310 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 325. Credit is not given for BME 325 if students have credit in BIOE 325. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 310 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 310

Course: BME 332 — Bioinstrumentation and Measurements I Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and application of instrumentation used for physiological and medical measurements. Characteristics of physiological variables, signal conditioning devices and transducers. Prerequisites: BIOS 110 and ECE 210 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 310. Credit or concurrent registration in BME 310 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 310 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 430. Prereq Codes (parsed): BME 310 Coreq Codes (parsed): BME 310

Course: BME 333 — Bioinstrumentation and Measurement Laboratory I Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 Description: Practical experience in the use of biomedical instrumentation for physiological measurements. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 332. Credit or concurrent registration in BME 332 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 332 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 431. Prereq Codes (parsed): BME 332 Coreq Codes (parsed): BME 332

Course: BME 339 — Biostatistics I Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Statistical treatment of data and model estimation treated in a framework of biological experiments, and attributes of data generated from such experiments. Experimental design is included. Prerequisites: MATH 210 ; and BME 240. Course Information: Credit is not given for BME 339 if the student has credit in BIOE 339. Previously listed as BIOE 339. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Excel and MATLAB.

Course: BME 391 — Biomedical Engineering Practicum Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge gained in previous engineering courses within a professional, working environment. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 3 hours awarded toward degree requirements.

Course: BME 394 — Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering III Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 1-5 Description: Special topics to be arranged. Course topics aimed at third-year students. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering III
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 396 — Senior Design I Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Design considerations for biomedical devices emphasizing traditional engineering design concepts. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 332 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 333 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 339 ; and BME 250. Credit or concurrent registration in BME 332 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 333 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 339 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 332 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 333 and Credit or concurrent registration in BME 339 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 396. Credit is not given for BME 396 if the student has credit in BIOE 396. Prereq Codes (parsed): BME 332, BME 333, BME 339 Coreq Codes (parsed): BME 332, BME 333, BME 339

Course: BME 397 — Senior Design II Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 Description: Application of principles of engineering and engineering design methodology to the solution of a large scale biomedical engineering design problem. Prerequisites: BME 396 ; and BME 332 and BME 333 and BME 339. Course Information: Credit is not given for BME 397 if the student has credit in BIOE 397. Previously listed as BIOE 397.

Course: BME 398 — Undergraduate Research Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 0-5 Description: Research under the close supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: BME 399 — Professional Development for Biomedical Engineers Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 0 Description: Career options, career planning, and job search skills relevant to bioengineers. Formal and informal networking, on-line resources, resume and portfolio preparation, interview skills. Special issues relevant to international students. Prerequisites: Open only to juniors; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as BIOE 399.

Course: BME 402 — Medical Technology Assessment Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: Assessment of medical technology in the context of commercialization. Objectives, competition, market share, funding, pricing, manufacturing, growth, and intellectual property; many issues unique to biomedical products. Prerequisites: BIOE 250 or BME 250 ; and junior standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 402.

Course: BME 403 — Quality Assurance for Medical Products Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: Requirements for current good manufacturing practices and quality assurance in the design and manufacture of medical devices. Prerequisites: BIOE 250 or BME 250 ; and junior standing or above. Course Information: 2 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 403.

Course: BME 407 — Pattern Recognition I Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The design of automated systems for detection, recognition, classification and diagnosis. Parametric and nonparametric decision-making techniques. Applications in computerized medical and industrial image and waveform analysis. Prerequisites: ECE 341 or BME 339 or IE 342 or STAT 381. Course Information: Same as ECE 407. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: BME 408 — Medical Product Development Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: Bioentrepreneur course. Major stages of medical product development (investigative, feasibility, development, commercialization, maturation and growth), regulatory issues, product performance, failure mode and effect analysis, hazard analysis. Prerequisites: BIOE 250 or BME 250 ; and junior standing or above. Course Information: 2 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 408.

Course: BME 410 — FDA and ISO Requirements for the Development and Manufacturing of Medical Devices Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: FDA Performance Standard for General Medical Devices for manufacturing and development engineers. Product requirement definition, design control, hazard analysis, failure mode and effect analysis, regulatory submission, product tests, ISO 9001. Prerequisites: BIOE 250 or BME 250 ; and junior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 410.

metadata.class_name: FDA and ISO Requirements for the Development and Manufacturing of Medical Devices
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 415 — Biomechanics Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Continuum mechanics of cells, tissues and organs. Statics and force balances; stress, strain and constitutive relations; equilibrium, universal solutions and inflation; finite deformation; nonlinear problems; finite element methods. Prerequisites: BIOE 310 or BME 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for BME 415 if the student has credit in BIOE 415. Previously listed as BIOE 315.

Course: BME 421 — Biomedical Imaging Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to engineering and scientific principles associated with X-ray, magnetic resonance, ultrasound, computed tomographic and nuclear imaging. Prerequisites: MATH 220 and MATH 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 421. Credit is not given for BME 421 if the student has credit in BIOE 421.

Course: BME 422 — Magnetic Resonance Imaging: Theory and Practice Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamental priciples of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) from a signal processing perspective. Focus on image acquisition, formation, and analysis. Prerequisites: BIOE 310 or BME 310 or ECE 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 422.

metadata.class_name: Magnetic Resonance Imaging: Theory and Practice
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 423 — Biomedical Imaging Laboratory Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 Description: Acquisition and processing of biomedical imaging data. Relaxation time-based magnetic resonance imaging, motion sensitive magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography, ultrasound, nuclear medicine imaging and optical imaging. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 421 or BME 421. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 421 or BME 421 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 421 or BME 421 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 423. Extensive computer use required. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOE 421, BME 421 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOE 421, BME 421

Course: BME 432 — Bioinstrumentation and Measurements II Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Principles of bioinstrumentation for the assessment of physiological function and therapeutic intervention. Prerequisites: BME 332. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 432.

Course: BME 433 — Bioinstrumentation and Measurements II Laboratory Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 1 Description: Laboratory experiments using instruments to assess physiological function. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 432. Credit or concurrent registration in BME 432 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 432 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 433. Prereq Codes (parsed): BME 432 Coreq Codes (parsed): BME 432

Course: BME 439 — Biostatistics II Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 4 Description: Statistical treatment of data, model estimation, and inference are treated in a framework of biological experiments and attributes of data generated from such experiments. Prerequisites: BIOE 339 or BME 339. Course Information: Credit is not given for BME 439 if the student has credit for BSTT 400. Previously listed as BIOE 439. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Knowledge of MATLab.

Course: BME 450 — Molecular Biophysics of the Cell Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to force, time energies at nanometer scales; Boltzmann distribution; hydrodynamic drag; Brownian motions; DNA, RNA protein structure and function; sedimentation; chemical kinetics; general aspects of flexible polymers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 245 or Grade of C or better in PHYS 260 or the equivalent; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as BIOS 460 and PHYS 450.

Course: BME 452 — Biocontrol Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Considers the unique characteristics of physiological systems using the framework of linear systems and control theory. Static and dynamic operating characteristics, stability, and the relationship of pathology to control function. Prerequisites: BIOE 310 or BME 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 452.

Course: BME 455 — Introduction to Cell and Tissue Engineering Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Foundation of cell and tissue engineering covering cell technology, construct technology, and cell-substrate interactions. Emphasis in emerging trends and technologies in tissue engineering. Prerequisites: BIOE 460 or BME 460 ; and BIOS 320 or BIOS 343 or BIOS 452. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 455.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Cell and Tissue Engineering
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 456 — Cell & Tissue Laboratory Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 Description: Includes polymer scaffold fabrication, microstamping biomolecules, cellular adhesion and proliferation assays, and immo/fluorescent tagging. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 455 or Credit or concurrent registration in BME 455 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 455 or Credit or concurrent registration in BME 455 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 455 or Credit or concurrent registration in BME 455 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 456. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOE 455, BME 455 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOE 455, BME 455

Course: BME 460 — Materials in Biomedical Engineering Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Analysis and design considerations of problems associated with prostheses and other implanted biomedical devices. Prerequisites: CME 260 ; and BIOS 220 or BIOS 222 or BIOS 286 or BIOS 340 or PSCH 262 or CHEM 232. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 460.

Course: BME 462 — Introduction to Dental Clinical Research and Technology Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Dental implants, biomaterials, biomechanics, tissue engineering, oral surgery, orthodontics, endodontics, nanomedicine, simulators and ADEA certifications, digital dentistry, virtual and augmented reality. Prerequisites: CME 260 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Dental Clinical Research and Technology
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 470 — Biomedical Optics Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Physical principles and instrumentation relevant to the use of light in biomedical research. Several current and developing clinical applications are explored. Prerequisites: PHYS 142. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 470.

Course: BME 471 — Biomedical Optical Imaging Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamentals of light-matter interactions, geometric optics, nonlinear optics, ultra-fast lasers, photodetectors, light microscopy, supper-resolution imaging, photoacoustic tomography, optical coherence tomography, functional optical imaging. Prerequisites: PHYS 142 and BIOS 110. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not give for BME 471 if the student has credit in BIOE 471. Previously listed as BIOE 471.

Course: BME 472 — Models of the Nervous System Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Mathematical models of neural excitation and nerve conduction, stochastic models and simulation of neuronal activity, models of neuron pools and information processing, models of specific neural networks. Prerequisites: BIOE 310 or BME 310 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 484. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 484 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 484 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for BME 472 if students have credit in BIOE 472. Previously listed as BIOE 472. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 484 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 484

Course: BME 475 — Neural Engineering I: Introduction to Hybrid Neural Systems Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Modeling and design of functional neural interfaces for in vivo and in vitro applications, electrodes and molecular coatings, neural prostheses and biopotential control of robotics. Prerequisites: BIOE 472 or BME 472. Course Information: Same as BIOS 475. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 475.

metadata.class_name: Neural Engineering I: Introduction to Hybrid Neural Systems
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 476 — Neural Engineering I Laboratory Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 Description: Hands-on experience with computational and experimental models of engineered neural systems, with emphasis on neuroprostheses and biosensors. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 475 and BIOE 430 and BIOE 431; or Credit or concurrent registration in BME 475 and BME 332 and BME 333. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 475 and BIOE 430 and BIOE 431 Credit or concurrent registration in BME 475 and BME 332 and BME 333 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOE 475 and BIOE 430 and BIOE 431 Credit or concurrent registration in BME 475 and BME 332 and BME 333 Course Information: Previously listed as BIOE 476. Animals used in instruction. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOE 475, BIOE 430, BIOE 431, BME 475, BME 332, BME 333 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOE 475, BIOE 430, BIOE 431, BME 475, BME 332, BME 333

Course: BME 479 — Wearables and Nearables Technology Laboratory Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Practical experience in design and development of wearable and nearable devices. Acquisition and processing of sensors data. Design and development of user-friendly user interface. Prerequisites: BME 240 ; or CS 251 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CS 479. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ECE 210 and CS 109.

Course: BME 480 — Intro to Bioinformatics Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Computational analysis of genomic sequences and other high throughput data. Sequence alignment, dynamic programming, database search, protein motifs, cDNA expression array, and structural bioinformatics. Prerequisites: BME 339 and MATH 310; and BIOS 220 or BIOS 222 or CHEM 232 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for BME 480 if the student has credit in BIOE 480.

Course: BME 481 — Bioinformatics Laboratory Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 2 Description: Teaches students how to use bioinformatics tools, including sequence alignment methods such as Blast, Fasta, and Pfam, as well as structural bioinformatics tools, such as Rasmol and CastP. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 480 or Credit in BIOE 480; and senior standing or above. Credit or concurrent registration in BME 480 or Credit in BIOE 480 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BME 480 or Credit in BIOE 480 Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Previously listed as BIOE 481. Credit is not given for BME 481 if the student has credit in BIOE 481. Prereq Codes (parsed): BME 480, BIOE 480 Coreq Codes (parsed): BME 480, BIOE 480

Course: BME 483 — Molecular Modeling in Bioinformatics Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Basic structural and dynamics tools in protein structure prediction, structure comparison, function prediction, Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulations. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in BIOE 480 or Grade of B or better in BME 480. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 483.

Course: BME 485 — Nanobiosensors Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fabrication and principles of operation for nanostructures used for biological sensing and analysis. Optical and electrical properties, use of biomolecules as active sensing elements. Prerequisites: BIOE 205 or BME 205 ; and BIOS 220 or BIOS 222 or BIOS 286 or BIOS 340 or CHEM 232 or PSCH 262 ; and PHYS 142. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as BIOE 485.

Course: BME 489 — Human Augmentics Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of technologies for augmentation of human capabilities; human limitations; implants and wearable technologies; implants; brain-computer interfaces; exoskeletons; sensors and networks. Includes project work. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CS 489. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: BME 494 — Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering IV Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 1-5 Description: Special topics to be arranged. Course topics aimed at fourth-year undergraduate and graduate students. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Previously listed as BIOE 494.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering IV
metadata.subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME)

text: Course: BME 496 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis I Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 0-8 Description: Applying engineering design methodology to a large scale biomedical engineering design problem. Technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: May be repeated. Credit only given to non-degree students. Extensive computer use required. Previously listed as BIOE 496.

Course: BME 497 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis II Subject: Biomedical Engineering (BME) Credits: 0-8 Description: Applying engineering design methodology to a large scale biomedical engineering design problem. Technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Credit only give to non-degree students. Previously listed as BIOE 497. Extensive computer use required.

Course: BPS 430 — Principles of Toxicology Subject: Biopharmaceutical Sciences (BPS) Credits: 2 Description: Examines the toxic effects of drugs and chemicals on organ systems. Lectures emphasize basic principles, effects on specific organ systems, major classes of toxic chemicals, and specialized topics such as forensic and industrial toxicology. Course Information: Same as PCOL 430. Credit is not given for BPS 430 if student has credit for EOHS 457.

Course: BPS 494 — Special Topics of Current Interest in Biopharmaceutical Sciences Subject: Biopharmaceutical Sciences (BPS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Courses offered by faculty or a visiting Lecturer on a current topic of selected interest. Topics are available on an experimental basis for one offering only. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor; good academic standing as defined by UIC policies. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics of Current Interest in Biopharmaceutical Sciences
metadata.subject: Biopharmaceutical Sciences (BPS)

text: Course: BSTT 400 — Biostatistics I Subject: Biostatistics (BSTT) Credits: 4 Description: Descriptive statistics, basic probability concepts, one- and two-sample statistical inference, analysis of variance, and simple linear regression. Introduction to statistical data analysis software. Course Information: Enrollment restricted to public health students and healthcare administration students; other graduate, professional and advanced undergraduate students admitted by consent as space permits. To obtain consent, see the SPH registrar.

Course: BSTT 401 — Biostatistics II Subject: Biostatistics (BSTT) Credits: 4 Description: Simple and multiple linear regression, stepwise regression, multifactor analysis of variance and covariance, non-parametric methods, logistic regression, analysis of categorical data; extensive use of computer software. Prerequisites: BSTT 400.

Course: BSTT 402 — Health Policy for Epidemiologists and Biostatisticians Subject: Biostatistics (BSTT) Credits: 1 Description: Epidemiological data and biostatistics provide the evidence to support the development and justification of policies. Public health policy interventions, factors influencing political and social environments and the evaluation of policy-making. Course Information: Same as EPID 402.

metadata.class_name: Health Policy for Epidemiologists and Biostatisticians
metadata.subject: Biostatistics (BSTT)

text: Course: BSTT 413 — Introduction to Data Analysis w/ R Subject: Biostatistics (BSTT) Credits: 2 Description: An introductory overview of statistical programming using R in the context of describing and analyzing public health data. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: BSTT 400 ; or IPHS 402.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Data Analysis w/ R
metadata.subject: Biostatistics (BSTT)

text: Course: BSTT 426 — Python for Data Science and Large Language Models Subject: Biostatistics (BSTT) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a comprehensive introduction to Python programming in the context of data science and natural language processing (NLP). Students will learn essential data manipulation, visualization, and machine learning techniques. Prerequisites: No prerequisites except that some very basic understanding of programming in SAS or R or some other programming language is needed along with basic analytical knowledge. Motivation to learn programming concepts is key. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: IPHS 402 or EPID 406 or BSTT 413.

metadata.class_name: Python for Data Science and Large Language Models
metadata.subject: Biostatistics (BSTT)

text: Course: BSTT 494 — Introductory Special Topics in Biostatistics Subject: Biostatistics (BSTT) Credits: 1-4 Description: Special topics in biostatistics. Content varies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CC 100 — Registration Placeholder Course Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 0 Description: Special administrative course created to represent a temporary placeholder registration for students wishing to drop their only course registration for a term and add a new course registration for the same day and time. Course Information: Intended as a course used to facilitate registration only. Must be added by the Office of Registration and Records.

Course: CC 175 — Student Resource Center Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 0 Description: Information to help students be successful in an online environment. Tutorials on Blackboard learning management system, access to the bookstore and library, course and program information, and success strategies for adult learners. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Placeholder course used for Blackboard resource center information access only. This course is NOT graded and rolled to academic history; does not appear on a transcript.

Course: CC 250 — Survey of American Law Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an overview of several substantive current legal issues and how to read and study the law. Course Information: Co-requisite(s): CC 251.

Course: CC 251 — Legal Analysis and Communication Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 3 Description: Simulation of the work of an attorney including critical reading and thinking, legal writing and organization, analysis of law, and client interview skills. Course Information: Co-requisite(s): CC 250.

Course: CC 300 — Urbana Registration Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 0-16 Description: Special course created to represent Urbana registation for upper division undergraduate students pursuing a degree on the Chicago campus. Facilitates proper UIC assessment, application of financial aid awards, and registration. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

Course: CC 301 — Springfield Registration Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 0-16 Description: Special course created to represent Springfield registration for upper division undergraduate students pursuing a degree on the Chicago campus. Facilitates proper UIC assessment, application of financial aid awards, and registration. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

Course: CC 400 — Urbana Registration Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 0-16 Description: Special course created to represent Urbana registration for upper division undergraduate and graduate students pursuing a degree on the Chicago campus. Facilitates proper UIC assessment, application of financial aid awards, and registration. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

Course: CC 401 — Springfield Registration Subject: Campus Courses (CC) Credits: 0-16 Description: Special course created to represent Springfield registration for upper division undergraduate and graduate students pursuing a degree on the Chicago campus. Facilitates proper UIC assessment, application of financial aid awards, and registration. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit.

Course: CEES 208 — Central and Eastern European Cinema Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of the main trends in the central and eastern European cinematic tradition and its role in the history of world cinema. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 ; or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as MOVI 208. Taught in English. Weekly film screenings.

Course: CEES 220 — Modern Polish-Jewish Culture and Literatures Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: Polish-Jewish literature and non-fiction works in English translation from Polish, Yiddish and Hebrew are studied as expressions of a distinct Ashkenazi or East European Jewish culture that developed on historically Polish lands. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or ENGL 161. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as POL 220 and JST 220.

Course: CEES 224 — Introduction to Literary Analysis of Central Eastern European Texts Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: Reading and interpreting seminal texts from different traditions of Central and Eastern European (CEE) literature in historical and cultural contexts. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161. Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Course Information: Previously listed as SLAV 224. Taught in English. Prereq Codes (parsed): ENGL 160, ENGL 161 Coreq Codes (parsed): ENGL 160, ENGL 161

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Literary Analysis of Central Eastern European Texts
metadata.subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES)

text: Course: CEES 225 — Introduction to Central and Eastern European Cultures Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the rich, multinational, and polyglot cultures of Central and Eastern Europe through different media. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 ; or completion of the english composition requirement Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 ; or completion of the english composition requirement. Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 160 Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Course Information: Taught in English. Prereq Codes (parsed): ENGL 160, ENGL 161 Coreq Codes (parsed): ENGL 160, ENGL 161

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Central and Eastern European Cultures
metadata.subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES)

text: Course: CEES 246 — European Avant-Garde Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: Major movements of the avant-garde, including Cubism, Futurism, Suprematism, Surrealism, and Constructivism. Cross -fertilization of ideas between cultures and media, including literature, film, architecture and visual arts. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as AH 246. Previously listed as RUSS 246. Taught in English.

Course: CEES 247 — Central and Eastern European Science Fiction and Fantasy Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: Genres of science fiction and fantasy includes literature by prominent writers from Central and Eastern Europe read in English translation, as well as films with English subtitles. Course Information: Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Central and Eastern European Science Fiction and Fantasy
metadata.subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES)

text: Course: CEES 250 — Cinema and Empire Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 4 Description: Explores the legacy of Eurasian cinema with films from the Russian empire, the Soviet Union, the Caucasus, and Central Asia. Topics include: silent film, montage, animation, transition to sound cinema, cinematic realism, and digital media. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Course Information: Same as MOVI 250. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. All assignments and course interactions will utilize internet technologies. Students are required to have access to a computer, internet, and the following software packages: A web browser (compatible with Blackboard), Adobe Acrobat Reader or any other free PDF reader, Microsoft Word or Google Docs. Students are responsible for having a reliable computer and internet connection throughout the course. Recommended Background: RUSS 150. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: CEES 320 — Great Stories from Central and Eastern Europe Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: Shorter works of fiction written by Nobel Laureates and other great writers from Central and Eastern Europe read in English translation. Course Information: Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Great Stories from Central and Eastern Europe
metadata.subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES)

text: Course: CEES 323 — Modernism in Central and Eastern Europe Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of key Central and Eastern European contributions to literary modernism approached from a comparative perspective. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Modernism in Central and Eastern Europe
metadata.subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES)

text: Course: CEES 400 — A Survey of Central and Eastern Europe Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An interdisciplinary historical and cultural overview of Central and Eastern Europe. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: A Survey of Central and Eastern Europe
metadata.subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES)

text: Course: CEES 406 — History of European Standard Languages Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The phenomenon of the "standard language" in Western and Eastern Europe. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LCSL 406 and LING 406. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. Previously listed as CEES 405. In cases where students speak languages other than English, they might receive tasks to research literature in that language (and on that language) and to present their research results.

Course: CEES 411 — The City as Cultural Focus Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Interdisciplinary study of urban culture with focus on German-speaking countries. Prerequisites: For majors and minors in the Department of Germanic Studies only: GER 212 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GER 411. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Taught in English. No knowledge of German required. Students who intend to use GER 411 toward a degree offered by the Department of Germanic Studies will do assignments in German. Area: literature/culture.

Course: CEES 418 — Topics in German History Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of European history, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 418. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CEES 433 — Topics in Eastern European History Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of European history or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 433. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CEES 435 — Topics in Russian History Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of European history or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 435. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CEES 438 — The Faust Legend Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Discusses Goethe's Faust within the context of European and non-European literatures. Traces the origins, significance, and interpretation of the Faust figure. Course Information: Same as GER 438. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. Area: literature/culture.

Course: CEES 439 — Gender and Cultural Production Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Issues of gender representation and gender politics examined through the use of theoretical texts or through the study of women authors. Prerequisites: GER 212 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GER 439 and GWS 439. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Taught in English. Students who intend to use GER 439 toward a degree offered by the Department of Germanic Studies will do assignments in German. Area: literature/culture.

Course: CEES 460 — Topics in Central and Eastern European Literature and Culture Subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a time period, movement, genre, or special topic. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as SLAV 460. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), with consent of the instructor, and if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Central and Eastern European Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES)

text: Course: CHE 101 — Introduction to Chemical Engineering and Sustainability Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of chemical engineering principles and unit operations. Introduction to sustainable chemical engineering practices and techniques applied to air, water, food, energy and health.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Chemical Engineering and Sustainability
metadata.subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE)

text: Course: CHE 150 — Climate Engineering for Global Warming Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of the engineering perspective on climate change and strategies to engineer the earth’s climate and mitigate risks associated with global warming. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: CHE 201 — Introduction To Thermodynamics Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Work and energy; conversion of energy; theory of gases and other states of matter; applications to energy conversion devices. Second Law of thermodynamics, entropy, and equilibrium, with applications. Prerequisites: MATH 181 and PHYS 141. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: CHE 205 — Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Computational methods and software relevant to unit operations. Excel spreadsheets (curve fitting, heat conduction), Matlab, Aspen Plus (process simulation), algorithms and object oriented concepts in chemical engineering. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 201 ; and credit or concurrent registration in MATH 210. Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 201 Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 210 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 201 Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 210 Prereq Codes (parsed): CHE 201, MATH 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHE 201, MATH 210

Course: CHE 210 — Material and Energy Balances Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 4 Description: Material and energy balances applied to chemical systems. Introduction to chemical and physical properties. Introduction to the use of computers for chemical process calculations. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 201 ; and credit or concurrent registration in CHE 205. Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 201 Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 205 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 201 Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 205 Prereq Codes (parsed): CHE 201, CHE 205 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHE 201, CHE 205

Course: CHE 230 — Molecular Systems in Chemical Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to fundamental concepts in molecular engineering and materials chemistry; properties of molecular systems and applications of macromolecules, bio-macromolecules and nanomaterials in energy, medicine, environment and technology. Prerequisites: CHEM 232.

Course: CHE 301 — Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Review of classical engineering thermodynamics. Multicomponent systems & multicomponent phase equilibria. Equilibrium in chemically reacting systems, heterogeneous equilibrium, Gibbs phase rule, and electrochemical processes. Prerequisites: CHE 201 and CHE 205.

Course: CHE 311 — Transport Phenomena I Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Momentum transport phenomena in chemical engineering. Fluid statics. Fluid mechanics; laminar and turbulent flow; boundary layers; flow over immersed bodies. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 210 ; and MATH 220 ; and CHE 205. Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 210 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 210 Prereq Codes (parsed): CHE 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHE 210

Course: CHE 312 — Transport Phenomena II Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Heat and mass transport phenomena. Heat conduction, convection and radiation. Heat exchanger design. Diffusion. Mass transfer coefficients. Prerequisites: CHE 311.

Course: CHE 313 — Transport Phenomena III Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Mass transfer and phase equilibria. Multistage separations; applications in distillation; extraction; absorption and drying. Prerequisites: CHE 301.

Course: CHE 321 — Chemical Reaction Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Kinetics of homogeneous single reactions. Ideal reactors: batch, stirred tank and plug flow systems. Conversion and yield in multiple reactions. Design and optimization of reactors. Non-isothermal reactors. Prerequisites: CHE 210 ; and MATH 220 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 301. Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 301 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 301 Prereq Codes (parsed): CHE 301 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHE 301

Course: CHE 330 — Polymer Science Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of polymer science and engineering. Introduction to polymers as an engineering material; basic concepts of properties; synthesis and structure of polymeric materials, polymer production, property prediction and performance in products. Prerequisites: CHE 230 or CME 260 ; and CHEM 232.

Course: CHE 341 — Chemical Process Control Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and design of chemical processes and control systems. Feedback and feedforward controllers. Stability, tuning, and simulation of P-I-D controllers. Introduction to the control of chemical plants and digital process control. Prerequisites: MATH 220 and CHE 312 and CHE 313 and CHE 321.

Course: CHE 381 — Chemical Engineering Laboratory I Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 2 Description: Heat and momentum transfer operations associated with chemical processes. These include heat exchangers, fluid properties, and fluid flow. Technical report writing, computer calculations. Prerequisites: CHE 312.

Course: CHE 382 — Chemical Engineering Laboratory II Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 2 Description: Heat momentum and mass transfer operations associated with chemical processes; these include distillation columns, reactors, humidifiers, and evaporators. Prerequisites: CHE 381 and concurrent registration in CHE 313.

Course: CHE 391 — Chemical Engineering Practicum Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge gained in previous engineering courses within a professional, working environment. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 1 hour awarded toward degree requirements.

Course: CHE 392 — Undergraduate Research Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 1-3 Description: Undergraduate research project in any area of Chemical Engineering. Projects may be theoretical, experimental, or literature surveys. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CHE 396 — Senior Design I Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to modern, process design and development, engineering economics, and report writing. Design and cost of equipment relating to materials handling to heat transfer, mass transfer, and reactors. Prerequisites: CHE 312 and CHE 313 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 321. Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 321 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHE 321 Course Information: Continuing students will take the course for 4 hours and students entering after Fall 2020 will take the course for 3 hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): CHE 321 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHE 321

Course: CHE 397 — Senior Design II Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 4 Description: Application of principles and design methodology of chemical engineering to the design of large-scale chemical processes and plants. A major design project is assigned for solution and presentation by students working in small groups. Prerequisites: CHE 396. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: CHE 410 — Transport Phenomena Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Continuum theory of momentum, energy, and mass transfer. Viscous behavior of fluids. Laminar and turbulent flow. Thermal conduction and convection, diffusion and coupled operations. Prerequisites: CHE 312 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as MENG 410. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 413 — Introduction to Flow in Porous Media Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theoretical modeling of single-phase and multiphase flow in porous media. Darcy's law and relative permeabilities. Oil production and hydrology. Capillary phenomena. Dispersion and miscible displacement. Prerequisites: CHE 312 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Flow in Porous Media
metadata.subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE)

text: Course: CHE 421 — Combustion Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Combustion chemistry and thermochemistry. Kinetics and mechanism of combustion; ignition and pollutant formation. Detonation and deflagration; premixed and diffusion flames. Surface reaction and droplet combustion. Applications. Prerequisites: CHE 301 and CHE 321. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 422 — Biochemical Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Enzyme-catalyzed and microbially-mediated processes. Free and immobilized enzymes. Batch and continuous cell cultures. Transport phenomena in microbial systems and fermentation processes. Design of biological reactors. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 423 — Catalytic Reaction Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Catalytic reactions which occur under conditions for which heat and mass transfer cannot be neglected are considered. Includes porosimetry, surface area measurements and catalyst deactivation. Prerequisites: CHE 321 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 425 — Nanotechnology for Pharmaceutical Applications Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Emerging role of nanostructures in drug development and delivery. Principles of nanostructure formation, characterization, surface functionalization, in vitro and in vivo transport, and visualization. Prerequisites: CHE 301 and CHE 311 and CHE 312 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 426 — Biopharmaceutical Process Development and Manufacturing Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamental concepts of biopharmaceutical process development and manufacturing; active pharmaceutical ingredients, polymorph screening, drug process development, scale-up, and safety. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 427 — Entrepreneurship in Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 0-4 Description: Fundamentals of entrepreneurship and technology commercialization for engineers. Introduction to intellectual property, marketing studies, business development, pitching new technology ideas to investors, guidelines for starting a business. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: CHE 433 — Process Simulation With Aspen Plus Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Application of Aspen Plus to design, modeling and simulation of process flow sheets. Property models, unit operations, heat integration and pinch analysis, electrolytes, nonconventional solids (e.g., coal), computational aspects. Course Information: CHE 312 and CHE 313 and CHE 321 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CHE 438 — Computational Molecular Modeling Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provide students with a fundamental understanding of the methods, capabilities and limitations of molecular simulations. Prerequisites: CHE 301. Course Information: Same as MENG 412. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Engineering/Science.

Course: CHE 440 — Non-Newtonian Fluids Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fluid mechanics and transport processes involving non-Newtonian fluids. Purely viscous and viscoelastic behavior. Viscometric functions and rheometry. Heat and mass transfer in non-Newtonian fluids. Prerequisites: CHE 410 or MENG 410 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as MENG 411. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 441 — Computer Applications in Chemical Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Nonnumerical applications of computers: artificial intelligence and expert systems for chemical engineering design and online diagnosis; data acquisition and control for digital process control; process design calculations. Prerequisites: Senior standing in chemical engineering. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 450 — Air Pollution Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Environmental aspects of combustion processes, pollutant formation. Control of pollutants and particulates. Air quality control. Fundamentals of combustion. Prerequisites: ME 321 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ENER 485 and ME 450. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 451 — Renewable Energy Technologies Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamentals of renewable energy technologies; solar, wind, biomass. Introduction to energy storage technologies; batteries and fuel cells, and analysis of the hydrogen economy. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 453 — Fundamentals of Electrochemistry Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the fundamentals of electrochemistry and its application in a variety of technologies (i.e., batteries, fuel, cells, electrolysis cells). Includes methods for the analysis of cells using electrochemical techniques. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 454 — Molecular and Macromolecular Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced course in polymer science and engineering. Polymerization, polydispersity, molecular configuration, solution properties, thermodynamics, glass and rubbery states, crystallization, viscoelasticity, elastic properties, multiphase systems. Prerequisites: CHE 330. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 455 — Nanoscale Systems in Chemical Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Basic principles associated with nanoscience and nanotechnology; fabrication and synthesis, size dependent properties, characterization; applications of materials at nanometer length scales; emphasis on recent technological breakthroughs. Prerequisites: CHE 230. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 456 — Fundamentals and Design of Microelectronics Processes Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design and practical aspects of the most advanced state of micro- and nano-electronics processing with emphasis on thin film deposition, substrate passivation, lithography and etching with thermodynamics, kinetics, reactor design, and optimization. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as MENG 413. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Engineering/Science.

metadata.class_name: Fundamentals and Design of Microelectronics Processes
metadata.subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE)

text: Course: CHE 457 — Colloidal and Interfacial Phenomena Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Interfacial phenomena in practice: soap bubbles, emulsions, foams, detergents; surface tension driven flows, Marangoni effect; enterfacial rheology; colloids, emulsions, 3D-printing; interfacial thermodynamics, biological interfaces. Prerequisites: CHE 301 and CHE 312. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHE 494 — Selected Topics in Chemical Engineering Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 1-4 Description: Systematic study of selected topics in chemical engineering theory and practice. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CHE 496 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis I Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 0-8 Description: Introduction to modern process design and development, engineering economics of chemical processes and equipment, process simulation, report writing and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: CHE 497 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis II Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 0-8 Description: Applications of modern process design principles and design methodology to large-scale chemical processes and plants; team design project with industrial mentor, process simulation, reports, presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: CHE 499 — Professional Development Seminar Subject: Chemical Engineering (CHE) Credits: 0 Description: Weekly seminars provide career information about chemical engineering and professional job search skills. Students provide evaluations of their engineering knowledge and educational experience in the Chemical Engineering Department. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors. Must be taken in the Fall semester of the student's last year of study. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: CHEM 100 — Chemistry and Life Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 5 Description: Principles of structural and environmental chemistry underlying the phenomenon of life on Earth, discussed in a historical, cultural and philosophical framework. Includes weekly two-hour laboratory. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 100 if the student has credit in CHEM 112 or CHEM 116 or CHEM 122. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: CHEM 101 — Preparatory Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 4 Description: Emphasis on problem solving. Metric units, dimensional analysis, chemical nomenclature, the mole concept, chemical stoichiometry. Prerequisites: Adequate performance on the UIC chemistry placement examination. Course Information: For students without entrance credit in high school chemistry or inadequately prepared. Credit is not given for CHEM 101 if the student has credit in CHEM 116 or CHEM 122. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion, one Lecture and one Quiz.

Course: CHEM 105 — Chemistry and the Molecular Human: An Inquiry Perspective Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 4 Description: A general education chemistry course that uses the empirical inquiry methods of science applied to the interaction of molecules--in foods, in the environment, and in medicines--with humans. Course Information: 4 hours. Credit is not given for CHEM 105 if the student has credit in CHEM 112 or CHEM 114 or CHEM 122 or CHEM 123 or CHEM 124 or CHEM 125. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion, one Discussion and one Laboratory. Natural World - With Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Chemistry and the Molecular Human: An Inquiry Perspective
