metadata.subject: Chemistry (CHEM)

text: Course: CHEM 110 — Chemistry Problem Solving Workshop Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 1 Description: Problem solving and study strategies in study of general chemistry courses. Techniques for learning technical terms in textbooks will be covered. Methods of analyzing complex problems conceptually and solving them appropriately. Corequisites: Students will be enrolled in a UIC course in chemistry or a related area. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated for credit. Credit is not given for CHEM 110 if the student has credit in CHEM 124 or CHEM 116.

Course: CHEM 115 — Comprehensive General and Organic Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 5 Description: One-semester introduction to general chemistry and organic chemistry including periodicity, stoichiometry, acid base equilibria, carbonyl compounds, amines, amides. It includes a weekly 3-hr lab. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 115 if the student has credit in CHEM 112 or CHEM 116 or CHEM 122 or CHEM 123. This course is intended for pre-nursing students and should not be taken by those who need CHEM 122 /123 or CHEM 116. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture, one Laboratory, and one Quiz. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: CHEM 116 — Honors and Majors General and Analytical Chemistry I Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 5 Description: General and analytical chemistry with laboratory. Coverage of the fundamentals of chemistry including stoichiometry and equilibrium. Coverage of the principles of analytical chemistry, including the use of instrumentation. Prerequisites: Superior performance on the UIC chemistry placement examination. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 116 if the student has credit in CHEM 112 or CHEM 122 and CHEM 123. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory, one Lecture and one Quiz. Natural World - With Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Honors and Majors General and Analytical Chemistry I
metadata.subject: Chemistry (CHEM)

text: Course: CHEM 118 — Honors and Majors General and Analytical Chemistry II Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 5 Description: General and analytical chemistry with laboratory. Coverage of the fundamentals of chemistry including atomic and molecular structure, thermodynamics, and kinetics. Coverage of principles of analytical chemistry, including the use of instrumentation. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 116. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 118 if the student has credit in CHEM 114 or CHEM 124 and CHEM 125. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory, one Lecture and one Quiz. Natural World - With Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Honors and Majors General and Analytical Chemistry II
metadata.subject: Chemistry (CHEM)

text: Course: CHEM 122 — Matter and Energy Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: An introductory one-semester course in chemical principles, including the quantum model of the atom, periodicity, bonding, reaction types, solutions, stoichiometry, thermochemistry, intermolecular forces, chemical equilibrium, acid-base equilibria. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 101 or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 122 if the student has a C or better in CHEM 112 or a C or better in CHEM 116. Students should complete CHEM 123 within a semester of completing CHEM 122. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: CHEM 123 — Foundations of Chemical Inquiry I Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 Description: Laboratory in general chemistry, including the quantum model of the atom, stoichiometry, periodicity, reaction types, intermolecular forces, and pH. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 101 ; and concurrent registration or Grade of C or better in CHEM 122. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 123 if the student has a C or better in CHEM 112 or a C or better in CHEM 116. Students should complete CHEM 123 within one semester of completing CHEM 122. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Discussion. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: CHEM 124 — Chemical Dynamics Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: A second semester course in chemical principles including chemical thermodynamics, phase transitions, spontaneity/equilibrium, electrochemistry, kinetics, bonding, molecular spectroscopy, coordination compounds, and buffer solutions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 116 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 122 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in CHEM 123 ; or Grade of B or better in CHEM 115 and department consent. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 124 if the student has a grade of C or better in CHEM 114 or CHEM 118. Students should complete CHEM 125 within a semester of completing CHEM 124. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: CHEM 125 — Foundations of Chemical Inquiry II Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 Description: Laboratory in general chemistry including chemical thermodynamics, spontaneity, chemical equilibrium, acid-base equilibrium, electrochemistry, kinetics, bonding, order/symmetry in condensed phases, coordination compounds, and spectroscopy. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 116 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 122 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 123 ; or Grade of B or better in CHEM 115 and department consent; and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in CHEM 124. Natural World - With Lab course. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 125 if the student has a grade of C or better in CHEM 114 or CHEM 118. Students should complete CHEM 125 within one semester of completing CHEM 124.

Course: CHEM 130 — Survey of Organic and Biochemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 5 Description: Chemistry of classes of carbon compounds relevant to life sciences, and an introduction to the structure and metabolism of proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 115 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 116 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 122 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 123. This course is intended for pre-nursing students and should not be taken by those who need CHEM 124 / CHEM 125 or CHEM 118. Course Information: Credit Restrictions: Credit is not to be given for CHEM 130 if the student has credit in CHEM 114 or CHEM 118 or CHEM 124 or CHEM 125. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory, one Lecture and one Quiz. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: CHEM 201 — Elements of Glass Blowing Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 1 Description: Demonstrations and practice in glass blowing and the construction of simple laboratory equipment. Prerequisites: Senior standing in chemistry and consent of the instructor.

Course: CHEM 222 — Analytical Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 4 Description: Theory and application of chemical equilibria and instrumentation in quantitative analysis. Includes two weekly three-hour laboratories. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 114; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 124 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 125 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 118 or the equivalent. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: CHEM 230 — Organic Chemistry of Biological Systems Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 4 Description: One-semester introduction to organic chemistry as it pertains to biological systems, biomedical sciences and chemical biology. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 122 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 123 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 116 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 115 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 130 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 230 if student has credit in CHEM 232 or CHEM 234. Class Schedule Information: This course is intended for students intending to major in Biological Sciences and Integrated Health Studies and should not be taken by those who need CHEM 232.

Course: CHEM 232 — Structure and Function Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: First semester of a one-year sequence. Structure, reactivity, and synthesis of organic molecules. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 122 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 123 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 116 ; or a grade of B or better in CHEM 115 and consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Quiz. Recommended Background: Concurrent registration in CHEM 233.

Course: CHEM 233 — Synthesis Techniques Laboratory Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 Description: Introductory organic chemistry laboratory. Basic techniques (distillation, crystallization, chromatography, MP and BP), reactions (substitution, elimination, Diels-alder, oxidation-reduction), instrumentation (gas and liquid chromatography, IR.). Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 230 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in CHEM 232 ; and Grade of C or better in CHEM 122 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 123 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 116 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 118 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CHEM 234 — Chemical Synthesis Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Second semester of a one-year organic chemistry sequence; continuation of CHEM 232. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 232 ; and Grade of C or better in CHEM 124 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 125 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 118. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Quiz.

Course: CHEM 235 — Advanced Synthesis Techniques Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 Description: Advanced organic chemistry laboratory. Synthesis, stereochemistry, spectrometry (IR, NMR), organic analytical chemistry (TLC, HPLC), microscale techniques. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 233 ; and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in CHEM 234. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Discussion.

Course: CHEM 240 — Mathematical Methods in Physical Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 Description: Chemistry workshop to support the development of students' math skills applied to physical chemistry courses at UIC. Course Information: Co-requisite(s): Students must be enrolled concurrently in CHEM 340 or CHEM 342.

Course: CHEM 305 — Environmental Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: The chemistry of the environment and the consequences of pollution brought about by natural and synthetic materials and modern energy usage. Prerequisites: CHEM 230 or CHEM 232.

Course: CHEM 314 — Inorganic Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 4 Description: Chemistry of the main-group elements, coordination chemistry and the transition elements, bioinorganic chemistry. Includes a weekly laboratory. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 232 and grade of C or better in CHEM 233. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: CHEM 333 — Interdisciplinary Approach to Chemical Synthesis Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced organic/inorganic chemistry laboratory. Multi-step synthesis of small molecule sensing and molecular recognition, nucleic acid chemistry, bio-inspired catalysis, structure-function studies of therapeutics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 235 and Grade of C or better in CHEM 314. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: CHEM 340 — Physical Chemistry for Biochemists I Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Thermodynamics of gases, solutions, reaction equilibria, and phase transitions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181 ; and Grade of C or better in CHEM 118 or Concurrent registration or Grade of C or better in CHEM 222 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 132 or Grade of C or better in PHYS 142. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 340 if the student has credit for CHEM 342.

Course: CHEM 342 — Physical Chemistry I Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Thermodynamics of gases, solutions, reaction equilibria, and phase transitions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181 ; and Grade of C or better in CHEM 118 or Concurrent registration or Grade of C or better in CHEM 222 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in MATH 210. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 342 if the student has credit for CHEM 340. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: CHEM 343 — Physical Chemistry Laboratory Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Experiments demonstrating principles of thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, spectroscopy and quantum mechanics in chemical systems using modern instrumentation and methods of data analysis. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 340 or Grade of C or better in CHEM 342. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Laboratory.

Course: CHEM 344 — Physical Chemistry for Biochemists II Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to molecular kinetics, quantum mechanics, and spectroscopy with applications of principles of physical chemistry to biochemical systems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 340 or Grade of C or better in CHEM 342 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 132 or Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; and Grade of C or better in MATH 181. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 344 if the student has credit for CHEM 346. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: CHEM 346 — Physical Chemistry II Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Kinetic and molecular theory of gases; introduction to the principles of quantum mechanics with application to model systems, multi-electron atoms, diatomic molecules, and bonding. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 342 and Grade of C or better in MATH 210. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHEM 346 if the student has credit for CHEM 344. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: CHEM 352 — Introductory Biochemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Structure and function of cellular constituents; enzymology; metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, nucleotides; molecular biology of biosynthesis of proteins and nucleic acids. Prerequisites: BIOS 100 or BIOS 110 ; and BIOS 101 or BIOS 120 ; and CHEM 230 or CHEM 232. Course Information: Same as BIOS 352. No credit given for BIOS 352 if student has credit in BIOS 452 or BIOS 454 or CHEM 452 or CHEM 454. No credit toward the degree in biochemistry.

Course: CHEM 402 — Chemical Information Systems Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 Description: Introduction to chemical information, including the use of databases for searching chemical information and the use of molecular modeling and related computational systems to determine calculated properties of chemical substances. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 234 , or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as CHEM 302. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Discussion.

Course: CHEM 414 — Advanced Inorganic Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: Introduction to the principles of inorganic chemistry. Structural and descriptive chemistry of the main-group elements. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 314 ; and Grade of C or better in CHEM 340 or Grade of C or better in CHEM 342 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 2 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours.

Course: CHEM 415 — Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 0-4 Description: Advanced inorganic chemistry laboratory. Preparative methods, Schlenk techniques, dry box, Fourier-transform infra-red and UV-visible spectroscopy, crystal growth. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 314. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: CHEM 416 — Inorganic Chemistry II Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Structural and descriptive chemistry of the transition elements. Prerequisites: CHEM 414. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHEM 421 — Instrumental Analysis Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 0-4 Description: A survey of contemporary instrumentation for chemical analysis. Emphasis on fundamentals of instrumental methods with actual experience on typical equipment. Includes a weekly three-hour laboratory. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 222 ; or Grade of C or better in CHEM 118. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CHEM 432 — Advanced Organic Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Rigorous treatment of the physical principles upon which modern organic chemistry is developed to understand the interplay between chemical structure and reactivity. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 235. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CHEM 444 — Spectroscopy in Chemistry and Biochemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Applications of theory and experiment to the spectroscopy of molecules and biological macromolecules. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 346 or Grade of C or better in CHEM 344. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHEM 448 — Statistical Thermodynamics Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to statistical mechanics, partition functions, chemical equilibrium, ensembles, fluctuations, real gases, Einstein and Debye models of solids, magnetic materials, electrolytes, introduction to liquids. Prerequisites: CHEM 346. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHEM 452 — Biochemistry I Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 4 Description: Chemistry of proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates and lipids. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 230 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 234. Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 234 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 234 Course Information: Same as BIOS 452. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Prereq Codes (parsed): CHEM 234 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHEM 234

Course: CHEM 454 — Biochemistry II Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 4 Description: Continues Chemistry 452. Carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, electron transport. Metabolism of amino acids, nucleic acids, proteins. Biosynthesis of macromolecules and regulation of macromolecular synthesis. Prerequisites: BIOS 452 or CHEM 452. Course Information: Same as BIOS 454. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: CHEM 455 — Biochemistry Laboratory Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to modern biochemistry and molecular biology research. Includes recombinant DNA techniques, protein purification, site-directed mutagenesis, polymerase chain reaction, enzyme kinetics, protein structure data analysis and molecular graphics. Prerequisites: CHEM 222 or CHEM 118 ; and CHEM 452 or BIOS 452. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Laboratory-Discussion.

Course: CHEM 456 — Natural Products Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Biogenetic approach to secondary metabolites. General principles and selected studies of phenolic compounds, terpenes, alkaloids, and other interesting natural products. Prerequisites: One year of organic chemistry. Course Information: Same as BIOS 416. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CHEM 458 — Biotechnology and Drug Discovery Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Molecular and gene therapy, using small molecules including antisense, aptamers, and proteins. Structure-based drug design. Structural bioinformatics and drug discovery program. High-throughput screening. Combinatorial chemistry technology. Prerequisites: BIOS 352 or CHEM 352 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 452 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 452 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 452 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 452 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BIOS 452 or Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 452 Course Information: Same as BIOS 458. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): BIOS 452, CHEM 452 Coreq Codes (parsed): BIOS 452, CHEM 452

Course: CHEM 470 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the department. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: CHEM 471 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 470 , and approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 470 , and approval of the department Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 470 , and approval of the department Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): CHEM 470 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHEM 470

Course: CHEM 472 — Teaching Methods in Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: A course in the methods of teaching high school chemistry, including the integration of technology. Prerequisites: 24 semester hours of undergraduate chemistry, including two semesters of laboratory chemistry. Course Information: 2 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ED 210.

Course: CHEM 474 — Teaching Chemistry in High Schools Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 1 Description: Modern ways to help beginning learners construct in their own minds an understanding of scientific concepts and scientific method. Emphasis on the concepts of chemistry. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated.

Course: CHEM 475 — Learning and Teaching of Physical Sciences Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Provides teacher candidates with the foundation and experience necessary to teach physical sciences in secondary schools. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as PHYS 475. Recommended Background: Knowledge of first-year college physics and chemistry. Class Schedule: To be properly registered: Students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Learning and Teaching of Physical Sciences
metadata.subject: Chemistry (CHEM)

text: Course: CHEM 480 — Elements of Machining Scientific Equipment Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 1 Description: Elements of machining scientific equipment, including the use of machine shop tools and technical drawing of scientific apparatus. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; and approval of the department. Course Information: Same as EAES 478 and PHYS 480. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: CHEM 488 — Cooperative Chemistry Practice Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 1 Description: Off-campus participation in a governmental or industrial training program. Credit is contingent on the submission of a final report. Prerequisites: Concurrent registration in LAS 289 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 6 hours of CHEM 488 , CHEM 492 and CHEM 499 combined may be credited toward departmental undergraduate degree course requirements.

Course: CHEM 492 — Independent Study Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 1-2 Description: Individual study under supervision of a faculty member in areas not covered in standard courses. Credit is contingent on the submission of a final report. Prerequisites: 2.50 grade point average in science courses and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 6 hours of CHEM 488 , CHEM 492 and CHEM 499 combined may be credited toward departmental undergraduate degree course requirements. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major.

Course: CHEM 494 — Special Topics in Chemistry Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which the course is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CHEM 499 — Supervised Research Subject: Chemistry (CHEM) Credits: 3 Description: Individual research performed under supervision of a faculty member. Credit is contingent on the submission of a final report. Research experience is strongly encouraged for career students. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above, approval of the department, consent of the instructor and a grade point average of 2.50 in science courses; or graduate standing. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. A maximum of 6 hours of CHEM 488 , CHEM 492 and CHEM 499 combined may be credited toward departmental undergraduate degree course requirements. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major. Recommended Background: Credit in CHEM 333 or CHEM 314.

Course: CHIN 101 — Elementary Chinese I Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 4 Description: Basic grammar; sentence patterns; vocabulary study; reading and writing with Chinese characters; simple oral practice. Prerequisites: Appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This course is taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Credit is not given for CHIN 101 if the student has credit in CHIN 111.

Course: CHIN 102 — Elementary Chinese II Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of Chinese 101. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHIN 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHIN 102 if the student already has credit in CHIN 111.

Course: CHIN 103 — Intermediate Chinese I Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 4 Description: Study of Mandarin Chinese language and culture. Intensive practice in speaking, listening, reading and writing at the intermediate level. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHIN 102 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test or the equivalent AP or IB test score. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHIN 103 if the student already has credit in CHIN 112. This course is taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use and internet access are required. A high-speed internet connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: CHIN 104 — Intermediate Chinese II Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of Chinese 103. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHIN 103 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test or the equivalent AP or IB test score. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHIN 104 if the student already has credit in CHIN 112. This course is taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use and internet access are required. A high-speed internet connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: CHIN 196 — Independent Study Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual study under faculty direction for qualified students with special interests and needs. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: CHIN 200 — Advanced Communication in Chinese Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 3 Description: The study of Mandarin Chinese at the high intermediate to advanced level. Interpersonal, interpretative, and presentational modes of communication used in formal and informal communicative situations. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHIN 104 ; or Grade of C or better in CHIN 112; or appropriate score on the department placement test or equivalent AP or IB Test score. Course Information: Not intended for students with native proficiency in Chinese; This course may be taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: CHIN 209 — Advanced Chinese Language and Culture Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 3 Description: Chinese culture as reflected in language, communication, daily life, and creative works. Intensive listening, speaking, reading and writing at the intermediate-advanced level. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHIN 104 ; or Grade of C or better in CHIN 112; or appropriate score on the department placement test or equivalent AP or IB Test score. Course Information: Same as GLAS 209. Not intended for students with native proficiency in Chinese. This course may be taught in a blended-online format. See class schedule for specifics. Extensive computer and internet use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: CHIN 210 — Understanding Contemporary Chinese Society Through Shanghai Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 3 Description: Shanghai as a case study to explore contemporary Chinese society, highlighting Shanghai’s unique historical and cultural position within China. Course Information: Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. The course may meet for 15 weeks or 8 weeks. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Contemporary Chinese Society Through Shanghai
metadata.subject: Chinese (CHIN)

text: Course: CHIN 296 — Independent Study Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual study under faculty direction for qualified students at the intermediate level who have special interests and needs. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: CHIN 300 — Special Topics in Advanced Chinese Skills Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 3 Description: A content-based approach to developing advanced Chinese language skills. Students will develop real-world skills in Chinese and gain deep understanding of various aspects of Chinese culture, history and society. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in CHIN 200 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in CHIN 209 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours, if topics vary. This course may be taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Advanced Chinese Skills
metadata.subject: Chinese (CHIN)

text: Course: CHIN 330 — A Linguistic Introduction to Chinese Subject: Chinese (CHIN) Credits: 3 Description: A linguistic introduction to Chinese including sounds/tones, words, and sentence patterns; regional and social dialects; evolution of writing system; language policies; language contact and change; Chinese L2 acquisition; Chinese language communities. Prerequisites: CHIN 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LING 330. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. The course may be offered in 15 weeks or 8 weeks. Class format varies by section. Check the class schedule for details. Online sections involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Recommended Background: LING 150.

Course: CHSC 411 — Nutrition for Public Health Professionals Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Foundation course to introduce nutrition principles and their application to public health populations and problems. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; or approval of the department.

Course: CHSC 415 — Racism and Health: History and Embodiment of a Harmful Illusion Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the underlying power hierarchy and set of false ideas that give rise to numerous “risk factors” for poor health in contemporary racialized society. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: The course format will be weekly lectures and group discussions. Three short papers and a book report will be assigned.

metadata.class_name: Racism and Health: History and Embodiment of a Harmful Illusion
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 421 — Community Health 1: Assessing, Promoting and Improving Community Health Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 4 Description: Provides an introduction to theory and methods for community health assessment, promotion, and improvement. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 401 and credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 402. Credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 401 and credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 402 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 401 and credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 402 Course Information: Credit is not given for CHSC 421 if the student has credit in CHSC 431 or CHSC 480. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): IPHS 401, IPHS 402 Coreq Codes (parsed): IPHS 401, IPHS 402

metadata.class_name: Community Health 1: Assessing, Promoting and Improving Community Health
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 422 — Community Health 2: Evidence-Informed Community Health Interventions Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 4 Description: Provides an introduction to quantitative, qualitative and mixed research methods which are applied in planning, implementing, and evaluating evidence-informed community health interventions and policies. Prerequisites: CHSC 421 and Credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 403. Credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 403 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IPHS 403 Course Information: Credit is not given for CHSC 422 if the student has credit for 433 or CHSC 446. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): IPHS 403 Coreq Codes (parsed): IPHS 403

metadata.class_name: Community Health 2: Evidence-Informed Community Health Interventions
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 423 — Community Health 3: Professional Development for Public Health Practice Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 4 Description: Emphasizes critical thinking, communication and professional development skills for public health practice and prepares students to complete an integrative individual capstone project. Prerequisites: CHSC 421 and CHSC 422.

metadata.class_name: Community Health 3: Professional Development for Public Health Practice
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 430 — Public Health Policy and Advocacy Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Frameworks and tools for understanding, developing and analyzing public health policy issues and processes. Prerequisites: IPHS 401 ; and graduate standing; or approval of the department. MPH and Certificate students in Community Health Sciences will have priority in registration. Course Information: Credit is not given for CHSC 430 if the student has credit for HPA 432.

Course: CHSC 433 — Public Health Planning and Evaluation Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Planning, implementation and evaluation of community health programs, including proposal development and evaluation and considerations for community/consumer involvement throughout the process. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BSTT 400 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 431 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 480; and graduate or professional standing; or approval of the department. MPH and Certificate students in Community Health Sciences will have priority in registration. Credit or concurrent registration in BSTT 400 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 431 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 480 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in BSTT 400 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 431 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 480 Prereq Codes (parsed): BSTT 400, CHSC 431, CHSC 480 Coreq Codes (parsed): BSTT 400, CHSC 431, CHSC 480

Course: CHSC 434 — Introduction to Qualitative Methods in Public Health Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to major methods and techniques used in qualitative research (observation, participant observation, in-depth interviews, focus groups); includes field and in-class exercises, and introduces computer-assisted qualitative data analysis. Prerequisites: CHSC 421 and credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 ; and graduate or professional standing; or approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 Prereq Codes (parsed): CHSC 422 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHSC 422

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Qualitative Methods in Public Health
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 446 — Research Methods in Community Health Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Principles and techniques for scientific investigation of problems in public health research and practice. Prerequisites: CHSC 421 and CHSC 422 ; and graduate or professional standing; or approval of the department.

Course: CHSC 447 — Survey Planning and Design Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and applications of sample survey planning and design for conducting research in health sciences and related fields. Addresses three major topics: survey design and planning, sampling, and data collection procedures. Prerequisites: CHSC 421 and credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 ; and graduate or professional standing; or approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 Course Information: Same as PA 447. Prereq Codes (parsed): CHSC 422 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHSC 422

Course: CHSC 460 — Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an overview of and introduction to public health emergency preparedness concepts and practice. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing. Course Information: Same as EOHS 406.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 461 — Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Assessment Methods Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 4 Description: Focuses on analytic skills and assessment tools used in public health emergency preparedness and response activities.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Assessment Methods
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 462 — Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Management Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 4 Description: Focuses on the management of public health emergency preparedness and response activities.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Management
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 464 — Survey of Developmental Disabilities Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the developmental disabilities field, including basic definitions, history of DD services, relevant public policies and legislation, service delivery systems, and research. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as DHD 464.

Course: CHSC 485 — Communications, Mass Media and Public Health Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the development, theoretical basis, and applications of mass media strategies in public health. Prerequisites: CHSC 421 and credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 ; and graduate or professional standing; or approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHSC 422 Prereq Codes (parsed): CHSC 422 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHSC 422

metadata.class_name: Communications, Mass Media and Public Health
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CHSC 494 — Special Topics in Community Health Sciences Subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC) Credits: 1-4 Description: Study of topics in maternal and child health, gerontology, behavioral science of health and illness, international health, community health and public health practice. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Restricted to graduate or professional standing, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Topics vary by semester.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Community Health Sciences
metadata.subject: Community Health Sciences (CHSC)

text: Course: CI 400 — Anthropology & Education Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: This course uses an anthropological approach in the study of formal and informal educational processes to understand the relationship between education, culture and society as represented in ethnographic texts. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: ED 100 , and ED 135 , and ED 205 ; and ANTH 100 or ANTH 101.

Course: CI 401 — Methods of Reading: Early Literacy in Urban Classrooms Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of literacy assessment and teaching (including decoding, early writing, spelling, oral language, and comprehension), with a focus on learning to read and write. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 257.

metadata.class_name: Methods of Reading: Early Literacy in Urban Classrooms
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 402 — Reading and Writing in the Content Areas: Intermediate Literacy in Urban Classrooms Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of advanced aspects of literacy instruction (e.g., comprehension, writing, literacy in the content areas), with a focus on reading and writing to learn. Prerequisites: CI 401 and junior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Elementary Education program. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 340.

metadata.class_name: Reading and Writing in the Content Areas: Intermediate Literacy in Urban Classrooms
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 403 — Literacy in the Disciplines: Adolescent Literacy in Urban Classrooms Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of using literacy in disciplinary content areas, including building prior knowledge and specialized vocabulary. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and admission to the B.A. in Urban Education, Concentration in Elementary Education Program. Successful completion of CI 402. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 341.

metadata.class_name: Literacy in the Disciplines: Adolescent Literacy in Urban Classrooms
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 404 — Teaching and Learning Mathematics in the Urban Classroom Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Helps prospective teachers create a foundation from which they can develop an exemplary mathematics teaching practice. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education, and MATH 140 and MATH 141 ; or the equivalent courses. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 342.

metadata.class_name: Teaching and Learning Mathematics in the Urban Classroom
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 405 — Teaching and Learning Science in the Urban Classroom Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Learning how to teach core scientific and engineering ideas, crosscutting concepts, and practices to advance student learning with a focus on community and societal relevance. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 343.

metadata.class_name: Teaching and Learning Science in the Urban Classroom
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 406 — Teaching and Learning Social Sciences in the Urban Classroom Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Models effective teaching of history and social sciences in urban classroom, in a way that is inclusive of diverse peoples, cultures, and histories. Students learn to teach core concepts, intellectual skills, and participatory dispositions. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 344.

metadata.class_name: Teaching and Learning Social Sciences in the Urban Classroom
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 410 — Literature, Social Studies, and the Arts in the Elementary School Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Theory and practice in curriculum development, planning instruction, and assessing learning in elementary classrooms. Literature, social studies, and the arts content foci. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Literature, Social Studies, and the Arts in the Elementary School
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 411 — Creating Learning Environments in the Elementary School Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of beliefs about teaching culture and learning in urban America in relation to the creation of learning environments with emphasis on application of state standards in classrooms and the development of a electronic teaching portfolio. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and CI 412. Course Information: 30 hours of fieldwork required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion, one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Creating Learning Environments in the Elementary School
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 412 — Dynamics of Learning Environments Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of multiculturalism and bilingualism/biculturalism in schools and families. Continued development of electronic portfolio for meeting Illinois professional teaching and technology standards. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and Enrollment in M.Ed. in Elementary Education Program. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion, one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: CI 413 — Foundations of Literacy Instruction, K-8 Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: For prospective teachers, introduction to teaching literacy K-8; examining cognitive, social, developmental perspectives; relationships between language and literacy; connections to school subjects; aligning instruction, assessment, standards. Prerequisites: Graduate standing. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Word processing on writing; search engines for examining literacy curriculum, professional organizations, email networks.

Course: CI 414 — Middle and High School Literacy Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on the teaching of reading and writing strategies appropriate for disciplinary learning and expression. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: CI 428 — Curriculum and Teaching in Secondary Education Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the study of curriculum and teaching. Specifically designed for graduate students wanting to become middle and high school teachers, students who are newly admitted to the secondary education program. Prerequisites: Open only to Master's degree students in the Secondary Education Program; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for CI 428 if the student has credit for ED 430. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Curriculum and Teaching in Secondary Education
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 429 — Secondary Science Education in Urban Settings Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the study of curriculum and teaching for those interested in urban education and who want to become secondary science teachers at the high school level. Course Information: Previously listed as CI 529. Recommended Background: At least 18 credit hours of coursework in a science field.

metadata.class_name: Secondary Science Education in Urban Settings
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 430 — Teaching Middle Grades Social Sciences: Content and Methods Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Models effective teaching of history and the social sciences in the urban elementary classroom grades 5-8, in a way that is inclusive of the diverse peoples, cultures, and histories that make up our society. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Restricted to students in the College of Education and Secondary History Education Program students in LAS.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Middle Grades Social Sciences: Content and Methods
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 450 — Societal Bases of Languages, Literacies and Learning Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to social and cultural processes by which languages and literacies are learned and develop in and out of school within the broader policy and ideological contexts. Prerequisites: Graduate standing.

metadata.class_name: Societal Bases of Languages, Literacies and Learning
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 451 — Foundations of Writing Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to writing research, theory and practice, including writing development, processes, digital writing, pedagogy, assessment. Combines academic study of writing theory/research with guided inquiry into writing processes and pedagogy. Prerequisites: CI 401 and CI 402. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as CI 544. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Admission to the M.Ed. in Instructional Leadership: Literacy, Language and Learning, or the B.A. in Urban Education program.

Course: CI 452 — Children’s and Young Adult Literature and Media Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of trade books and media for children from preschool through adolescence. Emphasizes critically reading, selecting, evaluating materials appropriate for developmental stages, curricular connections, and students in our multicultural society. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as CI 546.

metadata.class_name: Children’s and Young Adult Literature and Media
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 453 — Digital Literacies and Learning Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Theoretical foundations of digital literacies and learning focusing on critical interpretation/production involving texts, tools, and technologies that are online, mobile, and/or networked. Includes methods for teaching digital literacies P-12.

Course: CI 464 — Bilingualism and Literacy in a Second Language Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Theoretical foundations of second language acquisition and the teaching of English as second language. Methods and materials for teaching reading and writing in bilingual/ESL settings. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470. Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470 Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): CI 481, CI 470 Coreq Codes (parsed): CI 481, CI 470

metadata.class_name: Bilingualism and Literacy in a Second Language
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 470 — Language, Culture, and Learning in Urban Classrooms Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the study of multilingualism, language development, learning, and methodologies for teaching in linguistically and culturally diverse educational settings. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 346.

metadata.class_name: Language, Culture, and Learning in Urban Classrooms
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 472 — Language Proficiency Assessment and ESL Instruction Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Study of and practicum in English language proficiency assessment; methods, materials, and resources for assessing oral language, reading, and writing in P-12 school settings. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470. Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470 Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): CI 481, CI 470 Coreq Codes (parsed): CI 481, CI 470

metadata.class_name: Language Proficiency Assessment and ESL Instruction
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 475 — Teaching and Learning of the Natural Sciences Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Prepares teacher candidates with the knowledge, skills and dispositions needed for teaching science in urban contexts by investigating big questions and concepts in natural sciences education. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as CI 530. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Teaching and Learning of the Natural Sciences
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 481 — Foundation and Current Issues in Educating English Language Learners Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Philosophical, theoretical, socio-cultural and educational examination of learning and achievement issues that culturally and linguistically diverse students face in American schools. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Foundation and Current Issues in Educating English Language Learners
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 482 — Assessment and Instruction: A Multilingual/Multicultural Perspective Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 4 Description: Methods and materials for teaching English language learners (ELLs) in bilingual/ESL classrooms. Emphasis upon curricular and methodological practices, assessment for academic placement, and instruction. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470. Field work required. Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CI 481 or Credit or concurrent registration in CI 470 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): CI 481, CI 470 Coreq Codes (parsed): CI 481, CI 470

metadata.class_name: Assessment and Instruction: A Multilingual/Multicultural Perspective
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 484 — Curriculum and Instruction in the Middle School Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophy, curriculum, and instructional methods for teaching middle grade students (grades five through eight). Content area reading is included. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 or both ED 200 and ED 210 ; or graduate standing and either ED 402 or ED 403 , and ED 421 ; and approval of the of the College of Education.

metadata.class_name: Curriculum and Instruction in the Middle School
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CI 494 — Special Topics in Curriculum and Instruction Subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI) Credits: 1-4 Description: Exploration of an area not covered in existing course offerings. Content varies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Curriculum and Instruction
metadata.subject: Curriculum and Instruction (CI)

text: Course: CL 100 — Greek Civilization Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the life, society and culture of the ancient Greeks. Course Information: All readings are in English. Past course.

Course: CL 101 — Roman Civilization Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the life, society and culture of the ancient Romans. Course Information: All readings are in English. Past course.

Course: CL 102 — Introduction to Classical Literature Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: The main literary forms of Classical Antiquity: epic, tragedy, comedy, the philosophical dialogue, history. Course Information: All readings are in English. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CL 103 — Introduction to Classical and Mediterranean Archaeology Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Contributions of archaeological excavations to the study of ancient Greece, Rome, Egypt and the Near East; architecture, painting, and sculpture in their social and historical contexts. Course Information: All readings are in English. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Classical and Mediterranean Archaeology
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 120 — Introduction to Ancient Philosophy Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to issues and methods of philosophy through engagement with classic Greek and Roman texts (read in translation). Course Information: Same as PHIL 120. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: CL 124 — Introduction to the Hebrew Bible Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: A study of the Five Books of Moses (a.k.a Torah or Pentateuch) within the contexts of the ancient Near East and biblical literature. Course Information: Same as JST 124 and RELS 124. Taught in English. Past course.

Course: CL 128 — The Jesus Movement and the New Testament Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Investigates the Jesus movement from its beginnings as a small Jewish reform sect through its development into the religion known as Christianity. Uses New Testament writings as primary sources for reconstructing the past. Course Information: Same as CST 128 and RELS 128. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Jesus Movement and the New Testament
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 201 — Medical Terminologies: Ancient Roots in Modern Medicine Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: The structure and formation of technical terms used in the health sciences, based on roots and elements from Greek and Latin. Course Information: Same as LING 201.

metadata.class_name: Medical Terminologies: Ancient Roots in Modern Medicine
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 202 — Ancient Greece Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Greece from the Mycenaean through the Hellenistic periods; political, social, economic, and religious life of the Greek city-state and the Hellenistic kingdoms. Course Information: Same as HIST 202. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: CL 203 — Ancient Rome Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: History of Rome from its origins to the end of the Roman Empire; emphasis on transformation of Rome from city-state to world empire, with attention to social, cultural, and economic background. Course Information: Same as HIST 203. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: CL 204 — Greek Art and Archaeology Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Contributions of archaeological excavations to the study of ancient Greece, 600 BC to 31 BC. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as AH 204 , and HIST 204. Credit is not given for CL 204 if the student has credit in CL 215. Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CL 205 — Roman Art and Archaeology Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Contributions of archaeological excavations to the study of ancient Rome and her empire 1000 BC-400 AD. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as AH 205 , and HIST 205. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CL 208 — Classical Mythology Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Intensive study of the gods and heroic sagas of the cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, through original sources in translation. Course Information: Same as RELS 208. All readings are in English. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: CL 209 — Near Eastern Art and Archaeology Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the art, archaeology, and material culture of ancient societies in western Asia (Mesopotamia, Syria, the Levant, Anatolia, and Iran) from the first settled villages of the Neolithic to Alexander the Great (ca 9600-330 BCE). Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as AH 209. Credit is not given for CL 209 if the student has credit in AH 209 or ARST 209. Class Schedule Information: To be properly, registered students should enroll in one Lecture and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Recommended Background: AH 110.

Course: CL 210 — Ancient Egyptian Art and Archaeology Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Ancient Egypt from 6000-1000 BCE. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as AH 210 and BLST 210. Credit is not given for CL 210 if the student has credit in ARST 210 or AH 210 or BLST 210. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Recommended Background: Credit in AH 100 or AH 110.

Course: CL 211 — Sex and Gender in the Ancient World Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of the construction of gender and its relationship to love and sexuality in the ancient world through literature and art. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as GWS 211.

metadata.class_name: Sex and Gender in the Ancient World
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 218 — Pompeii: Everyday Life in a Roman Town Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the Roman town of Pompeii, including its history, society, politics, economy, religion, art, architecture, and entertainments. Course Information: Same as AH 218 and HIST 218. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Pompeii: Everyday Life in a Roman Town
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 219 — Sport in the Ancient World Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of Greek and Roman sport from the Bronze Age to the demise of pagan athletic festivals in late antiquity (c. fifth century CE). Course Information: Same as HIST 219.

Course: CL 220 — Ancient Philosophy I: Plato and His Predecessors Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Plato and his predecessors in the ancient period. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PHIL 220. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Philosophy I: Plato and His Predecessors
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 221 — Ancient Philosophy II: Aristotle and His Successors Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Aristotle and his successors in the ancient period. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PHIL 221. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Philosophy II: Aristotle and His Successors
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 225 — Topics in Muslim-Jewish Relations Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Muslim-Jewish interactions from the rise of Islam until contemporary times, the relationship between Biblical and Quranic materials, the Jewish and Islamic interpretive tradition and the legal systems of the two religious traditions. Course Information: Same as JST 225 and RELS 225.

Course: CL 232 — The Religious World of the Earliest Christians Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the religious world of the earliest Christians, focusing on the ways in which early Christian ideas and practices arose out of the cultures, religions, and philosophies of the ancient Mediterranean basin. Course Information: Same as HIST 232 and RELS 232. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Religious World of the Earliest Christians
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 242 — The History of Jewish Biblical Interpretation Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Jewish interpretation of the Hebrew bible. A survey of the span of Jewish history and the wide range of cultural contexts that have impacted the understanding of the Torah. Same as JST 242 and RELS 242. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The History of Jewish Biblical Interpretation
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 249 — Beauty, Power, Imagination: The Italian Renaissance Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the radical changes brought forth by the Italian Renaissance in the way people thought and acted in the world, and in almost every aspect of life: art, architecture, culture, economics, politics, and society. Course Information: Same as AH 249 and ITAL 249. Taught in English. The program includes optional activities such as field trips to the Art Institute and to the Daley Library Rare Book Collection. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Beauty, Power, Imagination: The Italian Renaissance
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 250 — Greek and Roman Epic Poetry Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: The epic poems of Homer, Apollonius of Rhodes, Vergil, and others in the Greco-Roman tradition. Prerequisites: CL 100 or CL 101 or CL 102 or CL 103 or the equivalent. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Course Information: All readings are in English.

Course: CL 251 — Greek Tragedy Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: The plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides, and their reception. Course Information: All readings are in English. Recommended Background: CL 100 and CL 102 and CL 103 or the equivalent. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CL 252 — Greek and Roman Comedy Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: The plays of Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus, and Terence. Course Information: All readings are in English. Recommended Background: CL 100 or CL 101 or CL 102 or CL 103 or the equivalent. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CL 253 — Roman Satire and Rhetoric Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of Roman literature with special emphasis on satire and rhetoric. Course Information: All readings are in English. Recommended Background: CL 101 or CL 102 or CL 103 or the equivalent. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CL 260 — Near Eastern Myths & Epic Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Literature and religious traditions from the ancient Near East and Egypt in the first and second millennia BCE. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: All texts read in translation. Recommended Background: ARST 209 or ARST 210.

Course: CL 290 — History of Political Thought I Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Western political theorists from ancient Greece and Rome through the end of the classical era, including Thucydides, Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, and Augustine. Course Information: Same as POLS 290. Recommended Background: POLS 120.

Course: CL 291 — Topics in Latin Prose Authors Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Readings in Latin prose chosen from a single author, period, or single genre. Prerequisites: LAT 104 or equivalent for students who register in LAT 291 only. Course Information: Same as LAT 291. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary. Taught in English. Students who register in CL 291 will complete assignments in English translation. Students who register in LAT 291 will complete more than half of the readings in Latin. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Recommended Background: CL 102.

Course: CL 293 — Dante's Divine Comedy Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: An in-depth study of the Divine Comedy, read in English, against the historical, religious, philosophical and cultural background of the Middle Ages. Course Information: Same as ITAL 293 and RELS 293. Previously listed as ITAL 193. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CL 297 — Studies in the Classical Tradition Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of selected texts of ancient Greek and Roman literature, such as the novel, drama, and epic, and how they inform English and American literature and culture. Prerequisites: CL 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Course Information: Same as ENGL 297.

Course: CL 298 — Topics in Classical Civilization Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics at an intermediate level in Greek and Roman civilization. Prerequisites: Any 100-level classics course or the equivalent. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. All readings are in English.

Course: CL 299 — Independent Reading: Special Topics in Classics in Translation Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Individual study under faculty direction. Reading and papers on chosen topics for qualified students based on preparation and interest; students must confer with faculty. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

metadata.class_name: Independent Reading: Special Topics in Classics in Translation
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 304 — Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic World Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the career of Alexander the Great of Macedon and his legacy in Greece, Egypt and the Near East, up until the arrival of the Romans. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as AH 304.

metadata.class_name: Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic World
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 340 — The Trojan War and Its Legacies Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: An examination of the literary and cultural significance of the Iliad both within its own culture, and in its continuing legacy.

metadata.class_name: The Trojan War and Its Legacies
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 390 — Seminar in Mediterranean Literature Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Comparative readings in selected texts from the literatures of Ancient Greece, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam with an emphasis on writing and research skills. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: CL 391 — Topics in Latin Poetry Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced readings in Latin poetry chosen from a single author, period, or single genre in different periods. Prerequisites: CL 250 or CL 252 or CL 253 ; or consent of the instructor; and LAT 291 or the equivalent for students who register for LAT 391 only. Course Information: Same as LAT 391. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary. Taught in English. Students who register in CL 391 will complete assignments in English translation. Students who register in LAT 391 will complete more than half of the readings in Latin. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Recommended Background: CL 102.

Course: CL 398 — Advanced Topics in Classical Civilization Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 1-3 Description: Capstone research course, for variable credit. Emphasis on research and writing on an advanced topic in classical studies. Prerequisites: At least two Classics (or approved) courses at the 100 or 200-level. Course Information: Students may either: 1) register for 1-2 credit hours of CL 398 while concurrently enrolled in a CL (or other approved) course at the 200-level or above; or 2) register for 2-3 credits as an independent study with permission of faculty. Discuss with faculty to determine appropriate number of credit hours.

Course: CL 399 — Independent Study: Honors Project Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 1-3 Description: Selected topics for individual study. Prerequisites: A minimum 3.75/4.00 GPA in major courses and the completion of and/or concurrent registration in four advanced 200- and/or 300-level courses in the major, in consultation with the academic advisor. Course Information: Restricted to students seeking Highest Distinction in Classics.

Course: CL 401 — Topics in Greek History Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history or classics. Course Information: Same as HIST 401. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated.

Course: CL 405 — Herodotus and His World Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the Histories of Herodotus - both the text and the culture of Classical Greece compared to the Near East and Egypt. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as HIST 405. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.
