Course: CL 408 — Athenian Democracy and Society in the Age of Aristophanes Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: A careful examination of the comedies of Aristophanes, his acute criticism of Athenian politics, and his account of the war between Athens and Sparta. Prerequisites: CL 202. Course Information: Same as HIST 408. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: one of the following courses: CL 251 , CL 252 , CL 405 or HIST 405.

metadata.class_name: Athenian Democracy and Society in the Age of Aristophanes
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 466 — Material Worlds: Topics in Material Culture Studies Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines current theories of material culture, drawn from art history, archaeology and anthropology to reflect on technologies of production and social life of things. Case studies will be drawn from ancient, medieval and modern historical context. Course Information: Same as AH 466 and ANTH 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Material Worlds: Topics in Material Culture Studies
metadata.subject: Classics (CL)

text: Course: CL 499 — Advanced Independent Study Subject: Classics (CL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced independent study under faculty direction. Reading and papers on chosen topics for qualified students based on preparation and interest. Students must consult with faculty. Prerequisites: Consent of the faculty member and department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major.

Course: CLJ 101 — Introduction to Criminology, Law, and Justice Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to key components of the justice system (including police, courts, and corrections) and contemporary trends in crime and delinquency. Critiques of the effectiveness and fairness of the system and emerging ideas for advancing justice. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Criminology, Law, and Justice
metadata.subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ)

text: Course: CLJ 102 — Foundations of Law and Justice Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical origins and historical development of U.S. criminal law in comparative perspective. Transformation of rights and due process; approaches to punishment and social control; legal institutions and procedures. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. US Society course.

Course: CLJ 110 — Rights, Justice and the Law Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: The historical development, philosophical justification and political underpinnings of the human rights framework. Exploration of specific human rights in U.S. vs. non-U.S. contexts. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. US Society course.

Course: CLJ 114 — Race, Class, Gender and the Law Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the relationship between social inequality and law/justice in the US, with specific attention to the importance of race, class, and gender. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Race, Class, Gender and the Law
metadata.subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ)

text: Course: CLJ 120 — Crime and Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to theories of social deviance and control. The historical development, empirical basis, strengths, and limitations of various theories are analyzed. Course Information: This course may be taught in a blended-online and classroom format. When that is the case, use of a computer and Internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended. Please check the online class schedule for blended-online sections. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. US Society course.

Course: CLJ 121 — Violence in Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical perspectives on the causes and consequences of violence in society. Examination of violence perpetrated by individuals, groups, and the state. Course Information: This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of a computer and Internet access is required. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. US Society course.

Course: CLJ 122 — Gangs and the Media Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Popular images of gangs in the mass media are contrasted with perspectives from social science literature. Course Information: Blended online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. US Society course.

Course: CLJ 200 — Law and Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Development of law and legal institutions from historical, comparative, and contemporary perspectives; interrelationships of law, custom, morality, and social change; the legal profession. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. US Society course.

Course: CLJ 210 — Principles of Criminal Law Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the basic principles of criminal law and procedure: proof of fact, act and intent, responsibility.

Course: CLJ 220 — Criminology Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of theories exploring the origins, organization, meanings, and control of crime. Course Information: Same as SOC 231. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: CLJ 261 — Research Methods I Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to research in criminology, law, and justice. From conceptualization to description of results. Research design, observation, archival, survey, and experimental methodologies in criminal justice related settings. Prerequisites: CLJ 101.

Course: CLJ 262 — Research Methods II Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Statistical data analysis in the criminology, law, and justice context. Probability, t-tests, correlation, regression, sampling theory, tests of significance. Problems with police and crime survey data. Prerequisites: MATH 090 or MATH 105 or MATH 108.

Course: CLJ 265 — Intergroup Dialogue in Criminology, Law, and Justice Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: A dialogue intensive course that explores social identity and access to power and privilege in the criminal justice system. Students will explore these themes by reading, discussing, and analyzing scholarly texts as well as their own experiences. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in CLJ 101.

metadata.class_name: Intergroup Dialogue in Criminology, Law, and Justice
metadata.subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ)

text: Course: CLJ 271 — Race and the Politics of Incarceration Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Examines how incarceration and criminalization affects black people in contemporary society. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in BLST 100 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SOC 100 or Grade of C or better in CLJ 101. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 271 and SOC 271.

metadata.class_name: Race and the Politics of Incarceration
metadata.subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ)

text: Course: CLJ 303 — Introduction to Forensic Science Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the basic principles and judicial uses of forensic science. Reviews the applications of the biological, physical, and behavioral sciences to questions of evidence and the law. Prerequisites: Junior standing and major in either Criminology, Law, and Justice or a natural sciences discipline; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: CLJ 311 — Criminal Procedure Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Legal problems associated with the investigation of crime, acquisition of evidence, commencement of adjudication, sentencing and appellate rights. Prerequisites: One 200-level criminology, law, and justice course.

Course: CLJ 321 — Youth, Crime, Law and Justice in Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Theories of juvenile delinquency and rule-breaking; juvenile rights; organization and administration of the juvenile justice system in the U.S. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level CLJ courses; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as CLJ 421.

metadata.class_name: Youth, Crime, Law and Justice in Society
metadata.subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ)

text: Course: CLJ 340 — Immigration, Law, and Rights Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the histories, cultures, and experiences of immigration to the United States by examining legal discourses and historical analyses alongside cultural productions such as literary and visual narratives. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100. Course Information: Same as GLAS 340.

Course: CLJ 345 — Police in Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: The functions and organization of police/investigative agencies, especially those on the local level, the nature of the experience of being a police officer. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level criminal justice courses; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CLJ 350 — Courts in Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Behavior and structure of state and federal criminal courts including preadjudication processing, prosecutorial and defense decisions, guilty-plea processes, bench and jury trials, sentencing, judicial selection, court administration. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level criminology, law, and justice courses; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CLJ 355 — Punishment, Prisons and Corrections Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of American corrections from local jails to mega prisons; correctional field services; probation and parole and recent developments in alternatives to incarceration. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level criminology, law, and justice courses; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CLJ 356 — Community Corrections and Reentry Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Experience of the reentry process in the context of enrollment in programs organized for supervising offenders in community setting, such as probation, parole, halfway houses, restitution, treatment facilities, community service, home confinement. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level CLJ courses; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as CLJ 456.

Course: CLJ 361 — Criminal Investigation Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Methods used for reconstructing crimes and criminal intent, incorporating information derived from people, physical evidence, institutional and electronic data. Scientific, organizational, legal, and ethical considerations informing the process. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level criminal justice courses; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CLJ 363 — Drugs and Addiction in Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Explores drugs and addiction in US society. Topics include history and classifications of drugs, drug policies in the US, the social, psychological, physical effects of substance use, and how drug use shapes interaction in social systems. Course Information: Credit is not given for CLJ 363 if student has credit for the comparable CLJ 394 topic section Drugs, Addiction and Society. Recommended Background: CLJ 101 and two 200-level Criminology, Law and Justice courses; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CLJ 373 — Introduction to the School-Prison Nexus Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Using contemporary social theory, this course investigates the disciplining, punishing, and criminalization of youth in urban schools, paying particular attention to the racialized, classed, gendered, and ableist contours of these social processes. Course Information: Same as ED 373. Recommended Background: CLJ 101 and two 200-level CLJ courses.

Course: CLJ 374 — Dismantling the School and Prison Nexus Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Political relationship between historically dis-invested K to 12 schools and prisons. Parallels in disciplinary practices and rationales in both. Engagement with affected communities that challenge carceral logics in education. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level CLJ courses; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ED 374. Recommended Background: CLJ 373.

metadata.class_name: Dismantling the School and Prison Nexus
metadata.subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ)

text: Course: CLJ 375 — Introduction to Poverty Law Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Examines poverty and the history of anti-poverty policy in the United States. Themes include the welfare state, criminalization, litigation, labor, and social movements. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level Criminology, Law, and Justice courses; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: CLJ 200.

Course: CLJ 394 — Topics in Criminology, Law, and Justice Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: The analysis and exposition of historical or contemporary issues in the Criminology, Law, and Justice field. Topics may vary from semester to semester. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level Criminology, Law, and Justice courses; junior or senior standing; or consent of instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Criminology, Law, and Justice
metadata.subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ)

text: Course: CLJ 395 — Internship Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Observation of and participation in the daily work of a criminal justice agency, private or public. Work is supervised by a faculty member and the managment of personnel of the agency. Prerequisites: A cumulative grade point average of 2.50. Preregistration in the department is required. Completion of five CLJ courses and junior or senior standing; or consent of the Director of Undergraduate Studies. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. A maximum of three credit hours may be used to satisfy the nine credit hour upper-division (300 and 400 level) requirement for the Major in Criminology, Law, and Justice.

Course: CLJ 399 — Independent Study Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 2-6 Description: Independent study and research under the supervision of a faculty member on a subject not covered in the regular curriculum. Prerequisites: Preregistration with the Department is required. Nine credit hours at the 200 level and three credit hours at the 300 level; a 3.00 overall grade point average, and a 3.50 grade point average in CLJ coursework, or consent of the Director of Undergraduate Studies. For criminology, law, and justice minors and majors only. Course Information: May be repeated for up to 8 credit hours.

Course: CLJ 402 — Trial Interaction Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Language use, culture, and law in the trial process. Analysis of qualitative methods applied to legal processes and change. Prerequisites: CLJ 261 and CLJ 350 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LING 402. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 405 — The Problem of Justice Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Pre-modern, modern and non-western views of justice and their practical utility in analyzing legislative, executive, and judicial programs for enhancing or restricting justice. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 , plus two 200-level courses in CLJ or two 200-level courses in POLS. Course Information: Same as POLS 405. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 422 — Victimization Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey of criminal victimization theory and research. Examination of causes, consequences, and prevention of violent crime and of victims' experiences in the criminal justice system. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 423 — Violence Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey of violence theory and research. Examination of types, causes and consequences of violence historically and in the present. Exploration of acts of resistance to violence. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 424. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 424 — Gender, Crime, and Justice Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An in-depth examination of the etiology of female crime and the involvement of females in the criminal justice system as offenders, victims, and workers/professionals. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 424. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 425 — Violence Prevention Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of contemporary approaches to violence prevention at the individual, family, community, and organizational levels, as well as within the larger society. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor.

Course: CLJ 430 — Homicide Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of forms and patterns of homicide in the US. Theories of homicide. Situational dynamics, types of offender motivation, investigative techniques (including profiling), impact on families and society, and intervention strategies. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 435 — White Collar Crime Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examination of how white-collar crime is defined, investigated, defended, and adjudicated. Comparison of "suite" and "street" crime from a socio-legal perspective. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 442 — Comparative Criminal Justice Institutions Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Comparative study of law, jurisprudence, enforcement, and punishment in Western and non-Western societies, including civil law, common law, and Islamic systems. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 450 — Surveillance and Society Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theoretical and empirical overview of the conceptualization, application and interpretation of surveillance in society, examined through the lens of various social topics. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CLJ 491 — Topics in Rule Breaking Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Content of course varies, addressing forms of deviance and illegality. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses, Junior standing or above, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CLJ 492 — Topics in Rule Application Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Content of course varies, addressing major issues. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses, junior standing, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: CLJ 493 — Topics in Critical Criminology Subject: Criminology, Law, and Justice (CLJ) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Content of course varies, addressing major issues in critical criminology. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: CME 111 — The Art of Structural Form Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of aesthetic, economic, and structural considerations of engineered structures since the start of the industrial revolution. Analysis of different design choices of bridges, tall buildings, thin shell, and other structures. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course.

Course: CME 112 — Evolution of Infrastructure and Society Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Evolution of infrastructure and its interaction with US society. Examples include development of transportation systems, water infrastructure, electrical grid, structural and geotechnical technology. Ethical and societal implications of new systems. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 ; or consent of the instructor. US Society course. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: CME 119 — Introduction to Environmental Engineering and Science Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Pollution and the environment. Impact of human economic activity on the environment. Principles of environmental engineering and science with application to natural and engineered environmental systems. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Environmental Engineering and Science
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 197 — Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 0 Description: Introduction to careers in civil and environmental engineering, introduction to business practice in civil and environmental engineering, professional ethics and challenges currently faced by the civil and environmental engineering profession. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. All CME freshmen and transfer students will be required to take course during the first year of enrollment at UIC.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 201 — Statics Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of forces, equilibrium of two- and three-dimensional structures, frames and machines. Friction, centroids, virtual work and energy. Prerequisites: MATH 181 and PHYS 141.

Course: CME 203 — Strength of Materials Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Relationships between the stresses and strains within a deformable body. Axially loaded members, torsion and the bending of bars. Stress transformation equations. Column theory. Prerequisites: CME 201.

Course: CME 205 — Structural Analysis I Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of trusses, beams and frames. Classical methods and analysis with microcomputers. Displacements, shear and bending moments, influence lines. Prerequisites: CME 203.

Course: CME 207 — Engineering Probability and Economics Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of probability in civil and environmental engineering; theories and principles of economics in civil and environmental engineering; managerial decision making techniques for design and construction of projects. Prerequisites: MATH 181.

Course: CME 211 — Fluid Mechanics and Hydraulics Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Covers the basic fluid mechanics topics of statics and kinematics, with emphasis on civil engineering aspects of open channel hydraulics and pipe flow. Prerequisites: MATH 181 ; and PHYS 141. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: CME 215 — Hydraulics and Hydrology Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Hydraulics of pipe flow, open channel flow and hydraulic machinery. Ground water and surface water hydrology. Prerequisites: ME 211. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 260 — Properties of Materials Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the relationships between composition and microstructure; correlation with physical and mechanical behavior of metals, ceramics, and polymers. Manufacturing methods. Service performance. Materials selection. Prerequisites: CHEM 122 and CHEM 123 and PHYS 141 and MATH 181. Course Information: Credit is not given for CME 260 if the student has credit for CME 261 or ME 261.

Course: CME 261 — Materials for Manufacturing Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 2 Description: Introductory-level course in materials engineering to familiarize students with relationships between processing, structure and properties of materials used to manufacture devices. Prerequisites: CHEM 122 and CHEM 123 and PHYS 141 and MATH 181. Course Information: Same as ME 261. Credit is not given for CME 261 if the student has credit for CME 260.

Course: CME 290 — Engineering Surveying Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 1 Description: Theory and practice of fundamentals of horizontal and vertical measurement of distances, angles and directions, leveling, traverses, topography, road and curve field layout, control and construction surveys, coordinate systems, GPS and Map Production. Prerequisites: MATH 181 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: CME 297 — Civil and Environmental Engineering Drawing and Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Manual and computer-aided drawing and drafting principles for civil and environmental engineering practice. Application of building information modeling in civil and environmental engineering professional practice. Prerequisites: Eligibility to register for ENGL 160. Interested students not enrolled in a degree program in the College of Engineering shall obtain permission from the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Drawing and Design
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 300 — Composition and Properties of Concrete Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 2 Description: Properties and types of cements and aggregates, hydration, mix design, properties of fresh and hardened concrete. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CME 203. Credit or concurrent registration in CME 203 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CME 203 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): CME 203 Coreq Codes (parsed): CME 203

Course: CME 301 — Behavior and Design of Metal Structures Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Design of metal structures, behavior of members and their connections, theoretical, experimental and practical basis for proportioning members. Prerequisites: CME 205.

metadata.class_name: Behavior and Design of Metal Structures
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 302 — Transportation Engineering Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Fundamentals of transportation engineering. Design, operations and planning of transportation systems of various technologies, emphasizing road and public transit. Prerequisites: MATH 210 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trips and computer laboratory required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 310 — Design of Reinforced Concrete Structures Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and design of reinforced concrete structural elements: beams, slabs, columns, and foundations. Use of current ACI 318 building code. Prerequisites: CME 205 and credit or concurrent registration in CME 300. Credit or concurrent registration in CME 300 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CME 300 Prereq Codes (parsed): CME 300 Coreq Codes (parsed): CME 300

Course: CME 311 — Water Resources Engineering Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of water-resources engineering including hydrologic processes and frequency analysis; fluids mechanics applied to closed conduits and open channels; groundwater engineering; urban water distribution. Laboratory experiments. Prerequisites: CME 211. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 315 — Soil Mechanics and Laboratory Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 4 Description: Soil formation, phase relationships, index properties and soil classification, soil composition, soil compaction, water in soils, stresses in soils, consolidation, shear strength, soils laboratory. Prerequisites: CME 203 and CME 211. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 322 — Environmental Engineering Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Environmental engineering and design for water and waste problems. Interactive effects of man-made projects on resources and the environment. Prerequisites: CHEM 122 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in CME 211. Credit or concurrent registration in CME 211 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CME 211 Course Information: Previously listed as CME 216. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): CME 211 Coreq Codes (parsed): CME 211

Course: CME 359 — Mechanical Vibrations Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Free and forced vibrations of damped linear single and multiple degree of freedom systems. Approximate methods, instrumentation, and applications. Prerequisites: CS 109 ; and ME 210 ; and MATH 220. Course Information: Same as ME 308.

Course: CME 391 — Civil and Materials Engineering Practicum Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge gained in previous engineering courses within a professional, working environment. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 1 hour awarded toward degree requirements.

Course: CME 392 — Undergraduate Research Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research and indepth study of a subject of interest under the close supervision of a faculty member. A report is required. Prerequisites: Senior standing.

Course: CME 394 — Undergraduate Seminar Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 1-3 Description: Students conduct an indepth study of areas of engineering of special interest to them which will be presented to the class in a seminar format. Prerequisites: Senior standing.

Course: CME 396 — Civil Engineering Systems Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 2 Description: Introduction to design process and methodologies. Aspects of civil engineering project management and the deterministic and probabilistic design methods. Professional Verbal and Written Communication. Preparation of senior design projects. Course Information: Pre-requisite(s): Senior Standing in Civil and Materials Engineering; Students who will be graduating any time during the next calendar year are eligible to enroll.

Course: CME 400 — Advanced Design of Reinforced Concrete Structures Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design of reinforced concrete building structures, including design for lateral loads due to wind, structural systems for reinforced concrete buildings, shear walls, and design for seismic forces. Prerequisites: CME 310 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Design of Reinforced Concrete Structures
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 401 — Advanced Design of Metal Structures Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Plate girders; unsymmetrical bending; torsion of thin-walled structures; lateral-torsional instability; composite construction. Prerequisites: CME 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 402 — Geometric Design of Highway Facilities Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Elements of geometric design. Driver, vehicle and roadway system characteristics. Horizontal and vertical alignment design. Intersection design and operation. Capacity and level of service. Prerequisites: CME 302 ; and CME 297 or ME 250 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 403 — Hydraulic Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Groundwater hydraulics, movement, recharge and well design; migration and drainage; design of dams, spillways and turbines; wave and coastal engineering design. Prerequisites: CME 311. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 404 — Railroad Track Engineering Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Railroad track engineering concepts including track components, response of track to wheel loads, design and analysis of railroad tracks, construction, evaluation, and maintenance of railroad tracks, load distribution, and track substructures. Prerequisites: CME 315 ; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Basic knowledge of strength of materials, soil mechanics, and structures.

Course: CME 405 — Foundation Analysis and Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3-4 Description: Site characterization; analysis and design of shallow foundations, deep foundations and earth retaining structures; foundations on difficult soils; effects of construction; instrumentation and monitoring. Prerequisites: CME 315. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 406 — Bridge Design I Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory and design procedures related to the analysis and design of modern bridges. Using the AASHTO Code, includes concrete and steel structures, construction practices and procedures. Prerequisites: CME 301 and CME 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 407 — Soil and Site Improvement Methods Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Compaction, preloading, vertical drains, grouting, admixture stabilization, thermal stabilization, soil reinforcement, geosynthetics; construction of embankments on soft clay, embankments on mechanically stabilized earth walls, hydraulic barriers; case studies. Prerequisites: CME 315. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 408 — Traffic Engineering and Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Highway Traffic control with an emphasis on highway capacity analysis and Traffic Signal Design. Queuing theory, traffic flow theory, corridor management, and Taffic Safety. Prerequisites: CME 302 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Field work required.

Course: CME 409 — Structural Analysis II Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Approximate analysis of structures including trusses and multistory frames. Influence lines, cables and arches. Principles of limit analysis for structures and structural elements. Prerequisites: CME 205 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 410 — Design of Prestressed Concrete Structures Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Principles of prestressed concrete. Analysis and design of statically determinate prestressed concrete members. Introduction to design and detailing of connections. Prerequisites: CME 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 411 — Chemistry for Environmental Professionals Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory atmospheric chemistry, aspects of air pollution, chemistry related to natural water and water treatment; priority organic pollutants and heavy metals. Prerequisites: One year of college chemistry. Course Information: Same as EOHS 440.

Course: CME 412 — Structural Strengthening Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: State-of-the-art introduction to structural strengthening including condition assessment, strengthening system selection, and strengthening system design. Fundamental behavior and design of structures strengthened with externally bonded composites. Prerequisites: CME 301 ; and CME 310 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 413 — Design of Wood Structures Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Covers the properties and behavior of wood as a structural material; the focus will be on the analysis of structural wood elements. Prerequisites: CME 301 ; or CME 310 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 414 — Design of Masonry Structures Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Material characteristics of masonry as an engineering material, design of masonry members subjected to axial loads, bending, combined axial and bending loads, design of masonry shear walls, and design of multi-story masonry buildings. Prerequisites: CME 301 ; or CME 310 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 415 — Environmental Geotechnology Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Environmental laws and regulations, sources and types of waste materials, waste materials in geotechnical engineering applications, geotechnical management of municipal, industrial, mine and nuclear wastes. Prerequisites: CME 315. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 419 — Structural Loads Determination Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Loads applied to buildings and other structures. Live and dead loads. Snow, wind, earthquake and flood loads. Historical overview of loading standards and current loading standards. Prerequisites: CME 205 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 420 — Water and Wastewater Analysis Laboratory Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 0-4 Description: Laboratory class for environmental engineering. Analysis of water, wastewater and soil for nutrients, pollutants, physical parameters and biological parameters. Prerequisites: CME 216; or graduate standing. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 421 — Water Treatment Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Water quality control systems. Physical-chemical unit processes applied to systems designed for treatment of municipal and industrial waters. Prerequisites: CME 322. Students in programs outside stated restrictions may be admitted with the consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Field trip required at nominal fee.

Course: CME 422 — Wastewater Treatment Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Processes involved in the biological treatment of wastewater. Aerobic and anaerobic treatment, sludge stabilization, and nutrient removal. Prerequisites: CME 322 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Field trip required.

Course: CME 423 — Management of Solid and Hazardous Wastes Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 Description: Management of solid and hazardous waste, including radioactive waste: landfills, incineration, recycling, composting, source reduction, groundwater and air pollution impacts, control, regulations, siting, health impacts. Course Information: Same as EOHS 472 , and GEOG 444.

metadata.class_name: Management of Solid and Hazardous Wastes
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 425 — Environmental Remediation Engineering Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Sources of contamination, regulations, site characterization, impact assessment, waste disposal and containment options, waste treatment options, case studies. Prerequisites: CME 315. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 427 — Engineering Hydrology Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Processes, techniques and concepts in hydrology of interest to the engineer: precipitation, interception, evaporation, groundwater, unit hydrographs, flood routing, and statistics. Prerequisites: CME 211 and senior standing. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 429 — Introduction to AI for Civil & Environmental Engineers Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduces graduate and undergraduate civil engineering students to various machine learning and AI techniques and demonstrates their applications in the Civil/Environmental engineering fields. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to AI for Civil & Environmental Engineers
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 430 — Theory of Elasticity I Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The boundary value problems of linear elasticity. Uniqueness of solution. Reduction to two dimensions: the plane problems, torsion, bending. Polar coordinates and general orthogonal coordinates. Prerequisites: CME 205 and MATH 220 ; or the equivalents. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 431 — Introduction to Continuum Mechanics Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Vectors and tensors, stress, principal stresses and principal axes, deformation, compatability conditions, constitutive equations, isotropy and mechanical properties of fluids and solids. Prerequisites: CME 203 and CME 211 ; or CME 203 and ME 211. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 432 — Energy Methods in Mechanics Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Variational theorems of elasticity. Applications to establish approximate systems and their solution. Beams (including shear deformation.) Introduction to instability theory. Prerequisites: CME 205. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 433 — Fracture Mechanics and Failure Analysis I Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Classical theory of strength of materials. Fracture mechanisms maps. Continuum damage mechanics. Introduction to fracture mechanics. Singular problems of elasticity. Stress intensity. Energy release rates. Irwin-Orowan, Barenblatt-Dugdale theories. Prerequisites: CME 430. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Fracture Mechanics and Failure Analysis I
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 434 — Finite Element Analysis I Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Establishment of basic finite element, matrix relations for one-dimensional heat conduction problems: Truss, beam and frame structural systems. Solution methods of the resulting equations. Introduction to two-dimensional analysis. Prerequisites: CS 109 ; and CME 205 or ME 347. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 435 — Theory of Vibrations I Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Analytical and numerical treatment of linear, discrete systems. Nonlinear discrete systems. Prerequisites: CME 200 or the equivalent and MATH 220. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 440 — Cities and Sustainable Infrastructure Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 0-4 Description: Integrated urban infrastructure planning based on sustainability and resilience; energy, water and transportation systems; design of green buildings; urban network design; methods of environmental assessment and infrastructure economics. Prerequisites: CME 302 and CME 311 ; or consent of the instructor For graduate students: consent of instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

Course: CME 441 — City Logistics Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Understanding the basics of the logistics planning, operation, and design for cities and urban environment in regard to people, goods and freight, and sustainability and the environment. Prerequisites: CME 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 450 — Probability and Reliability in Structural Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Maximum uncertainty principle and probability distributions of random variables. Distributions of extremes and their applications. Statistics of failure. The weakest link theory. Time to failure. Structural reliability. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Probability and Reliability in Structural Design
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 453 — Experimental Stress Analysis Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 0-4 Description: Structural similitude and dimensional analysis. Strain measurement techniques. Introduction to photoelasticity. Prerequisites: CME 430. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: CME 454 — Structural Analysis and Design of Tall Buildings Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: State-of-the-art introduction to structural analysis and design of tall buildings. Load impact on different structural systems. Prerequisites: CME 401 or CME 409 or the equivalent, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Major structural analysis and design courses.

metadata.class_name: Structural Analysis and Design of Tall Buildings
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 460 — Crystallography and X-Ray Diffraction Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 4 Description: Fundamentals of crystallography. Theory of x-ray diffraction, experimental methods and applications. Prerequisites: CME 260. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 470 — Physical and Mechanical Properties of Materials Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamentals of physical and mechanical metallurgy; unit cells and defects; elasticity and plasticity; phase equilibria; materials processing; modern metallurgy – high entropy alloys, nanostructured metals, and shape memory materials. Prerequisites: CME 260 ; or CME 261 ; or ME 261 ; and graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Physical and Mechanical Properties of Materials
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 471 — Thermodynamics of Materials Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 0-4 Description: Application of chemical and thermodynamic principles to processing and characterization of materials. Prerequisites: CME 260. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 480 — Welding Metallurgy Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 4 Description: Metallurgy of metals joining processes. Selection of processes and design of products manufactured by joining processes. Prerequisites: CME 260. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CME 481 — Risk Management and Decision-Making in Construction Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Application of decision analysis, optimization, and risk management tools in construction engineering and management, selection of contractors, site layout planning, quantifying impact of weather, change orders, resource utilization, optimal planning. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Risk Management and Decision-Making in Construction
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 485 — Construction Engineering and Management Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of construction engineering and project management. Construction industry, project cycles, contract administration, financing, legal management structures. Resource management; planning, quality control, productivity and safety. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Non-COE students shall obtain permission from the instructor prior to enrolling in the course.

Course: CME 486 — Construction Equipment and Design Methods Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of the equipment and machinery that is used in construction engineering; Calculating Cycle Times, Production Rates and Cost; Earthwork Estimations; Construction Methods and Design. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Other non-COE students shall obtain permission from the instructor prior to enrolling in the course.

Course: CME 487 — Construction Accounting and Financial Management Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Accounting fundamentals and financial business management in construction engineering and management. The organizational management in civil infrastructure engineering, and project financial management, strategic management of civil environmental engineering enterprise. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 488 — Sustainable Construction Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Coverage of construction methods and techniques that employ the principles of sustainable development. Materials and methods of construction, infrastructure planning and development, and environmental implications of construction activities. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CME 490 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis I Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 0-8 Description: Introduction to engineering design and research methods: design tools, product conception and development, simulation, optimization, technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit only given to non-degree students. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in Engineering. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CME 491 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis II Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 0-8 Description: Introduction to engineering design and research methods: design tools, product conception and development, simulation, optimization, technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: CME 493 — Seminar Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 1-3 Description: Topics of mutual interest to a faculty and a group of students. Offered as announced in the Timetable.

Course: CME 494 — Special Topics in Civil and Materials Engineering Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 1-4 Description: Subject matter varies from section to section and from semester to semester, depending on the specialties of the instructor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Civil and Materials Engineering
metadata.subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME)

text: Course: CME 496 — Special Problems Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 1-4 Description: Special problems or reading by special arrangement with a faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

Course: CME 497 — Capstone Design Subject: Civil, Materials, and Environmental Engineering (CME) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: Application of principles of engineering and design methods to the solution of a large-scale design program. Communicating design solu- tions through verbal and written media. Prerequisites: CME 396 CME 396 and at least three courses from the following list: CME 301 , CME 302 , CME 310 , CME 311 , CME 315 , CME 322. Course Information: Previously listed as CME 397.

Course: COMM 100 — Fundamentals of Human Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasis on strategies for public speaking, public presentations, and conducting meetings. Effective approaches to audience analysis, speaker/presenter credibility, using evidence, argument development, delivery, and planning meetings. Course Information: No Credit given toward major in Communication. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Individual and Society course.

Course: COMM 101 — Introduction to Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to central concepts in communication, including key terms and theories, specific contexts and key debates. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Individual and Society course.

Course: COMM 102 — Introduction to Interpersonal Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Effective communication in human relationships; verbal and nonverbal messages; reflective listening, disclosure, showing affection, empathy, assertiveness; handling interpersonal conflict; cultural and gender differences. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Individual and Society course.

Course: COMM 103 — Introduction to Media Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Conceptualizing mass communication. Internal and external controls. Media and minorities. Individual and societal functions of the media. Individual and societal effects of the media. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Individual and Society course.

Course: COMM 105 — Black Film, 1900 - Present: Images, Individuals and Ideas on Screen Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the history of black people in film – looking both at films by black people in the United States and the diaspora, and at the relationship between black filmmakers, performers, and audiences to national and global film industries. Course Information: Same as BLST 105 and MOVI 105. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Black Film, 1900 - Present: Images, Individuals and Ideas on Screen
metadata.subject: Communication (COMM)

text: Course: COMM 140 — Fundamentals of Social Media and Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Instruction and practice in the composition, analysis and dissemination of messages that employ media and social media in professional contexts. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Fundamentals of Social Media and Communication
metadata.subject: Communication (COMM)

text: Course: COMM 200 — Communication Technologies Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Focus on historical and cultural aspects of technology, including identity, community, social justice, popular culture, everyday life. Technologies covered range from early nonverbal communication to AI and technologies of the future. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Individual and Society course. Course Information: Same as MOVI 200. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. Consult the schedule of classes for mode of instruction. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 201 — Statistics in Communication Research Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Processes of communication research as a social science; variables, hypotheses, and theories; conceptual and operational definition; sampling; research design; statistics; use of computers for research. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 101 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103 ; and MATH 090 or MATH 105 or MATH 108 or any advanced math course with a minimum grade of C, or math placement above MATH 090 or MATH 105 or MATH 108. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 101 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 101 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103 Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 101, COMM 102, COMM 103 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 101, COMM 102, COMM 103

Course: COMM 203 — Gender, Race, Inclusion and Diversity (GRID) in Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Focus on gender, race, inclusion, and diversity (GRID) in professional, personal, and social communication contexts. Emphasis on empathy, equity, intersectionality, cultural identity, dialogue, class, power, ability, work, technology, and mobility. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

metadata.class_name: Gender, Race, Inclusion and Diversity (GRID) in Communication
metadata.subject: Communication (COMM)

text: Course: COMM 204 — Gender and Popular Culture Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of representations of gender and sexuality in popular and material culture, using contemporary theories. Focus is on US popular culture. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 101 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 101 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103 Course Information: Same as GWS 204. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 101 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Prereq Codes (parsed): GWS 101, COMM 102, GWS 102, COMM 103 Coreq Codes (parsed): GWS 101, COMM 102, GWS 102, COMM 103

Course: COMM 205 — The Health Media Environment Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Health issues coverage in the media (traditional, social, and future); misinformation, disinformation, fake news, health literacy, best practices. Foundational theory on health, news, and the media. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 206 — Public Relations and Digital Media Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: The basics of public relations strategy applied to a contemporary digital media environment. The ethics and practice of public relations. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161.

Course: COMM 207 — The Mass Media and Politics Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Impact of mass media coverage on political attitudes and the conduct of American politics. Communication policies and media institutions in times of rapid technological change. Prerequisites: One course in political science, sociology or contemporary history. Course Information: Same as POLS 207. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 210 — Race, Media and Culture Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: The construction and dissemination of race through mediated structures. Includes but not limited to news, television, children's literature, advertising, movies, music, social media, and video games. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement.

Course: COMM 216 — Digital Journalism Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Basics, best practices, and ethics of digital journalism. Assembling, producing, and publicizing news content for the contemporary digital news environment. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 220 — Social Media and Marketing Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: The basics of marketing in the social media age.Theoretical and practical strategies used by corporations and non-profits to leverage digital communication and enhance brand identity, loyalty, and consumer engagement. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Course may be offered in a traditional, blended, or online format. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction.

Course: COMM 225 — Advertising and Society Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: History and ethics of advertising in society and culture. Focus on controversies and exemplars, visual and design theory, and advertising processes. Emphasis on digital content creation, critique, and impact on society. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 230 — AI and Journalism Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Reporting with Artificial Intelligence (AI). Focus on knowledge production, research & experimentation. Infusion of AI tools into workflow. Ethical & legal copyright issues. Fact checking & transparency in the production & publishing process with AI. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 234 — History of Television Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: A critical history of television. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ENGL 234 and MOVI 234. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 240 — Data Journalism Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: The basics of journalism/reporting in the social media age. Theoretical and practical strategies used gather, analyze, and report data for current events, crime, politics and other news topics toward crafting interactive storytelling. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 250 — Social Media and Society Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Social media platforms as they affect crucial social, political, and economic aspects of society. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 254 — Future Television Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: The expansion of television and the forces shaping its future. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as MOVI 254. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 260 — Games as Social Technology Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Games as networked and collaborative technologies. Focus on community building and interaction; the social impact of gaming; use of gaming technologies for communication; representation in gaming. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement.

Course: COMM 270 — Digital Influencers Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Examines digital influencers and influencer culture. Focus on history, branding, content creation and analytics. Emphasis on impact on society, popular communication, and culture. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 294 — Introductory Topics Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory analysis of contemporary issues in media, technology, and communication. Topics vary per semester and instructor. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 301 — Communication Research Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Designs and measurements for conducting empirical analyses of communication activities in both laboratory and business settings. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 102 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Open only to juniors and seniors and quantitative reasoning requirement met. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 200

Course: COMM 303 — Communication and Culture Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the relationship between communication and culture through an exploration of the general theoretical principles linking cultural influences and communicative acts. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 304 — Gender and Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Speech differences and universals across genders. Talk in gendered interaction. Communication in romantic relationships. Gender issues in work and other settings. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 ; or GWS 204. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Same as GWS 304. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 305 — Technology and Wellness Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Wellness within new media technology studies. Focus on how wellness is communicated, branded, and supported and/or hindered through digital media. Emphasis on healthism, moralization, social support, capitalism, neoliberalism, and misinformation. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 306 — Organizational Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of communication issues in organizational settings. Exposure to topics such as rules, networks, leadership, and decision making as well as methods of analyzing communication problems. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200.
