Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 309 — Environmental Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Description and analysis of communication practices about environmental issues with attention to conflict resolution, media coverage, advocacy initiatives and marketing campaigns. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 311 — Interviewing and Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Study of the forms and principles of information-seeking interviews, with special attention to fact-finding and data gathering missions. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 315 — Group Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Study and practice in the theories and techniques of group communication; the nature of small group decision-making; observation and analysis of established work groups. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 316 — Writing for the Electronic Media Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of writing applied to the presentation of information in electronic media. Practical applications and analysis of relations between form and content. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 323 — Argument and Persuasion Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and application of historical and contemporary theories of argument and persuasion as they function to form or change opinions and beliefs. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. English majors or minors must seek approval from the Communication department. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Same as ENGL 356. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 326 — Public Relations and Social Responsibility Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Foundational public relations (PR) theory and practices. Focus on how PR plays a more active role in the betterment of organizations and society. Emphasis on corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives and case studies. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 330 — Mass Media and Popular Culture Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: A theoretical and analytical examination of the media and popular arts as cultural artifacts. Focus on form, content, design, and effects of cultural commodities. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 334 — Latinx Sound Studies Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Experience and experiment with sound to imagine and enact social identities and leverage political power. Intersections of race, class, gender and sexuality, geography and citizenship through sounded and aural frameworks. Course Information: Same as LALS 335.

Course: COMM 335 — Digital Storytelling Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of traditional storytelling followed by introduction to tools of digital storytelling. Focus on storytelling to communicate meanings about self, identity, community. Emphasis on digital ways of creating narratives that include and diversify. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 350 — Personal Relationships and Technology Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of personal connections in the digital age. Focus on romantic relationships, friendships, families and other social relationships. Topics include identity, intimacy, and relationship development. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 360 — Public Relations Campaigns Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and analysis of public relations campaigns. Focus on strategic communication, campaign process, research, and analysis. Emphasis on case studies, campaign plan development, and professional collaboration practice. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 394 — Special Topics in Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of contemporary or historical issues in media and communication. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours if topic is different for each registration. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: COMM 410 — Race, Gender and Representation: Black Bodies in Media and Mass Culture Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the ideological, cultural and economic structures that shape the representation of Black subjects in performance, visual arts, and mass media, paying close attention to gender and sexuality. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as BLST 410 and GWS 410. Recommended Background: Three or more credit hours in Black Studies or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Race, Gender and Representation: Black Bodies in Media and Mass Culture
metadata.subject: Communication (COMM)

text: Course: COMM 416 — Conflict and Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Students learn to manage and resolve conflict in business, governmental, and community settings. Practical analysis of interpersonal and group conflict cases. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: COMM 423 — Discourse and Rhetoric Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of interconnections between language and social practices with attention to multiple components of discursive situations: senders, receivers, context, code, media, and content. Prerequisites: COMM 301. English majors or minors must seek approval from the Communication department. Course Information: Same as ENGL 463. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: COMM 425 — Digital Advocacy Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Social media, social movements and advocacy efforts in the digital era. Topics covered include hashtag activism, global movements, digital activism, online mobilization around social injustice. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 428 — Latin@ Futurity Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An exploration of utopic and dystopic imaginations in Latin@ literature, media, and popular culture. Discusses coloniality, precarity, an alternate timeline as (re)imagined through queer, indigenous, and femme epistemologies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as LALS 428.

Course: COMM 430 — Media, Information and Society Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of social functions and the impact of information and communication technologies. Focus on facts, truth, knowledge, and values. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 433 — Mobile Media and the City Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Relationship between contemporary technologies - new media, urban screens, mobile and wireless technologies, ubiquitous computing - and cities. Foundational theory on mobile media and communication. Prerequisites: COMM 301.

Course: COMM 434 — Global Communication Systems Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Structure and flow of international communication. Media organization systems. International impact of new media and information technology. Impact of U.S. media reporting on foreign affairs. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: COMM 435 — Data, Privacy and Ethics in the Digital Age Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Datafication and privacy. Topics include commodification of personal information through various devices and platforms; the quantified self; legal, ethical, and contextual approaches to privacy; politics of algorithms. Prerequisites: COMM 301 ; or admission to the MA in Communication, Digital Media, and AI. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

metadata.class_name: Data, Privacy and Ethics in the Digital Age
metadata.subject: Communication (COMM)

text: Course: COMM 440 — Technology, Social Justice, and Sustainable Futures Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Complex interplay between technology, humans and the environment. Anthropocene and climate change. Sustainable design. Electronic waste. Environmental racism. Futurology and Afrofuturism. Technological diffusion and planned obsolescence. Prerequisites: COMM 301 ; or approval of the department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

metadata.class_name: Technology, Social Justice, and Sustainable Futures
metadata.subject: Communication (COMM)

text: Course: COMM 445 — Politics of Platforms Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of the politics embedded in digital platforms’ policies and practices. Topics include content moderation, mis/disinformation, AI, digital activism, privacy and surveillance, influence, and community. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 458 — Minorities and Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Description and analysis of the processes through which ethnic and racial perceptions shape public discourse. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: COMM 460 — Visual Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of processes through which meaning is derived from visible signs, and the role of media images in the cultural context. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: COMM 465 — Video Games and Society Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Games and their complex socio-cultural impact on society. Explores what games say about the nature of identity, community, presence, learning, and communication. Prerequisites: COMM 301.

Course: COMM 467 — Public Opinion and Political Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Nature of public opinion and political communication systems. Patterns of opinion distribution and its measurement. Forces shaping public opinion and its impact on public policy. Prerequisites: POLS 200 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 467. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: COMM 470 — Communication and Music Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Study of music as a medium of communication, including the use of various platforms of music creation, performance, and consumption, roles of fans, musicians, and the music industry, and the use of AI and cultural practices in music. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 471 — Communication and Sound Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Study of sound communication, technology, new media, and AI. Understanding of audio recording, reproduction, manipulation, and design. Theory of sound including history, technology, culture, method, and practices. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 474 — Internship Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 1-8 Description: Students work in an approved professional setting. Individual projects developed through conferences with a faculty member and a field supervisor. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. No more than 3 credit hours of COMM 474 or COMM 498 may be applied toward the major. May not be counted toward the minimum Master of Arts degree requirements. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 490 — Seminar in Culture and Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of contrastive cultural paradigms (interethnic, gender, class) to develop student's awareness of own socialization and cultural orientation. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 491 — Seminar in Media and Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of contemporary or historical issues in mediated communication. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 493 — Communication and Social Networks Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the impact and significance of social networks as a construct and platform for reshaping and restructuring of our media, political institutions, and democracy. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 494 — Special Topics in Communication Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Contemporary trends in the field of communication. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s). Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 495 — Happiness and Social Media Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines how happiness is imagined, constructed, and lived through daily experiences with technology. Emphasis on the impact of social media on feelings of happiness. Focus on historical, cross-cultural, and diverse understandings of well-being. Prerequisites: COMM 301. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: COMM 498 — Independent Study Subject: Communication (COMM) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual investigation of special problems (student-initiated or related to faculty research). May be used for special projects, such as interdisciplinary seminars. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department and Junior or Senior standing. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. No more than 3 credit hours of COMM 474 or COMM 498 may be applied toward the major. Credit earned may not be applied toward the minimum Master of Arts in Communication degree requirements.

Course: CS 100 — Discovering Computer Science Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Fundamentals of computing; history of computation; computer organization; program design, testing and debugging; web design; computer animation; software tools; societal and legal issues in computing. Course Information: Credit is not given for CS 100 if the student has credit in CS 111 or CS 112 or CS 113 or CS 107 or CS 109 or MCS 160 or MCS 260. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in a major offered by the Departments of Biomedical Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Civil Materials and Environmental Engineering, Computer Science, Electrical and Computer Engineering, or Mechanical and Industrial Engineering. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: CS 107 — Introduction to Computing and Programming Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 4 Description: Access and use of computing resources. Programming and program design. Problem solving. Data types, control structures, modularity, and information hiding. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Course Information: Credit is not given for CS 107 if the student has credit in CS 141. Previously listed as EECS 171. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180

Course: CS 109 — Programming for Engineers with MatLab Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Program design and problem solving using MATLAB. Numeric computation, data types and operators, control structures, functions, file I/O, arrays and structures. Engineering applications: Matrices, equation solution. Programming assignments. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Course Information: Credit is not given for CS 109 if the student has credit for CS 107 or CS 111 or CS 112 or CS 113 or MCS 160 or MCS 260. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180

Course: CS 111 — Program Design I Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to programming: control structures; variables and data types; problem decomposition and procedural programming; input and output; aggregate data structures including arrays; programming exercises. Course Information: 3 hours. Extensive computer use required. Credit is not given for CS 111 if student has credit in CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 112 or CS 113 or MCS 160 or MCS 260. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CS 112 — Program Design I in the Context of Biological Problems Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to programming using Biology as the context for programming in a high-level language; control structures, variables, simple and aggregate data types; problem-solving techniques; biology topics include central dogma and genetics. Course Information: Same as BIOS 112. Credit is not given for CS 112 if the student has credit in CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 111 or CS 113 or MCS 160 or MCS 260. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Program Design I in the Context of Biological Problems
metadata.subject: Computer Science (CS)

text: Course: CS 113 — Program Design I in the Context of Law and Public Policy Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to programming using law and public policy as the context for programming; control structures, variables, simple and aggregate data types; problem-solving techniques; legal topics: security, privacy, encryption, and predictive policing. Course Information: Credit is not given for CS 113 if the student has credit in CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 111 or CS 112 or MCS 160 or MCS 260. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in on Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Program Design I in the Context of Law and Public Policy
metadata.subject: Computer Science (CS)

text: Course: CS 141 — Program Design II Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Data abstraction and modular design; recursion; lists and stacks; dynamic memory allocation; file manipulation; programming exercises. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 111 or Grade of C or better in CS 112 or Grade of C or better in CS 113 or Grade of C or better in CS 107 or Grade of C or better in CS 109 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Course Information: 3 hours. Previously listed as CS 102. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180

Course: CS 151 — Mathematical Foundations of Computing Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Discrete mathematics concepts fundamental to computing: propositional logic, predicates and quantifiers; proofs; sets; recursive definitions and induction; functions, relations and graphs; combinatorics and discrete probability; applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 111 or Grade of C or better in CS 112 or Grade of C or better in CS 113 or Grade of C or better in CS 107 or Grade of C or better in CS 109 or Grade of C or better in MCS 160 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test Note that a grade of C in MCS 260 (the prior course number for MCS 160 ) is also considered a valid prerequisite replacement for MCS 160. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Course Information: 3 hours. Credit is not given for CS 151 if the student has credit in MCS 361. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180

Course: CS 194 — Special Topics in Computer Science Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Multidisciplinary computer science topics at first-year level that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests.

Course: CS 211 — Programming Practicum Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Software development tools and practices; debugging and testing; advanced language features; standard libraries; code management. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 141 ; or Grade of C or better in CS 107. The option to use CS 107 as a prerequisite (in place of CS 141 ) is only for Computer Engineering majors or students doing a Computer Engineering minor. Course Information: 2 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

Course: CS 251 — Data Structures Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 4 Description: Design, usage and analysis of data structures: review of lists, stacks and queues; hash tables, priority queues, search trees, introduction to graphs; searching and sorting; runtime analysis; programming projects and lab exercises. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 211 or Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 266 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 211 or Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 266 Course Information: 4 hours. Prerequisite (s): Grade of C or better in CS 141 or Grade of C or better in CS 107 ; and Grade of C or better in CS 151 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in CS 211 or Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 266. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): CS 211, ECE 266 Coreq Codes (parsed): CS 211, ECE 266

Course: CS 261 — Machine Organization Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 4 Description: Data representation and computer arithmetic; machine language; addressing; memory hierarchy; subroutines; data structures; processor architecture: hardware components, pipelining. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 141 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in CS 211. Credit or concurrent registration in CS 211 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 211 Course Information: Credit is not given for CS 261 if the student has credit for ECE 267 or ECE 366. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): CS 211 Coreq Codes (parsed): CS 211

Course: CS 277 — Technical and Professional Communication in Computer Science Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Communication skills for computing students and professionals in various contexts: technical writing, portfolios, job interviews, demos, sales, with speech organization, visuals, and delivery. Attendance, participation, and presentations required. Prerequisites: CS 141. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Technical and Professional Communication in Computer Science
metadata.subject: Computer Science (CS)

text: Course: CS 292 — Undergraduate Teaching Assistants Training Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1 Description: Required for all first-time, CS undergraduate TAs; filling out timesheets; working with students; supporting professors; holding office hours; leading labs; grading assignments; accommodations and accessibility. Prerequisites: Hired first-time TA's in the Department. There are no course prerequisites. Meets eight weeks of the semester. On-campus class meets the first 8 weeks of the semester; there will be occasional Zoom meetings and asynchronous work during the second 8 weeks of the semester.

Course: CS 294 — Special Topics in Computer Science Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Multidisciplinary computer science topics at sophomore level that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

Course: CS 301 — Languages and Automata Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Regular sets and finite automata. Context-free languages and push-down automata. Parsing. Computability theory including Turing machines and decidability. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 151 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in CS 251. Credit or concurrent registration in CS 251 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 251 Course Information: Previously listed as EECS 361. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Prereq Codes (parsed): CS 251 Coreq Codes (parsed): CS 251

Course: CS 341 — Programming Language Design and Implementation Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Programming language paradigms, design and implementation: syntax and semantics; parsing; runtime systems; control; data types; subroutines and exceptions; data and procedural abstraction; functional programming. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 211 and Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 342 — Software Design Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Software design principles and practices: Object-oriented design; design patterns; software reuse; testing; event driven programming and concurrency; graphical user interface design and development; Team development. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 and Grade of C or better in CS 211. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Credit is not given for CS 342 if the student has credit for CS 340.

Course: CS 351 — Advanced Data Structure Practicum Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Design and implementation details of advanced data structure and non-trivial algorithms with an emphasis on amortized analysis. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; and Grade of C or better in CS 211.

Course: CS 361 — Systems Programming Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 4 Description: Study of computer systems emphasizing impact on application level programming. Virtual memory and memory management; code optimization; system-level I/O; concurrency: processes, threads, synchronization; introduction to network programming. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 and Grade of C or better in CS 211 ; and CS 261. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: CS 362 — Computer Design Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 4 Description: Computer hardware building blocks. logic gates; combinational circuits; arithmetic circuits; flip flops and sequential circuits; registers and memory; CPU design; I/O design. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 211 ; and CS 261. Course Information: 3 hours. Extensive computer use required. Credit is not given for CS 362 if the student has credit in ECE 265. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: CS 377 — Ethical Issues in Computing Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Communication skills for computing professionals: presentation organization, visual aides, delivery techniques, argument support. Ethical and societal issues in computing: privacy, intellectual property and ownership, crime. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 251. Credit or concurrent registration in CS 251 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 251 Course Information: 3 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): CS 251 Coreq Codes (parsed): CS 251

Course: CS 378 — Framework-based Software Development for Hand-held Devices Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 Description: Multi-platform app development using software frameworks; the integration of framework-generated code with native code of mobile operating systems; numerous programming assignments in multiple programming languages. Prerequisites: CS 342.

metadata.class_name: Framework-based Software Development for Hand-held Devices
metadata.subject: Computer Science (CS)

text: Course: CS 391 — Computer Science Practicum Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge gained in previous engineering courses within a professional, working environment. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 3 hour awarded toward degree requirements.

Course: CS 394 — Special Topics in Computer Science Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Multidisciplinary computer science topics at junior-senior level that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

Course: CS 398 — Undergraduate Design/Research Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Design and/or research experience for undergraduate Computer Science majors under close supervision of a CS faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as EECS 398.

Course: CS 401 — Computer Algorithms I Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design and analysis of computer algorithms. Divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, greedy method, backtracking. Algorithms for sorting, searching, graph computations, pattern matching, NP-complete problems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MCS 360 ; or Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: Same as MCS 401. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 402 — Algorithms in Practice Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design, implementation and presentation of algorithms and data structures emphasizing dynamic programming and both exact and heuristic approaches to NP-hard problems; problem solving sessions, programming projects and presentations. Prerequisites: CS 401 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 407 — Economics and Computation Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Techniques for analysis of markets, making decisions with other strategic agents, and understanding how algorithms affect the incentives of market participants. These include game theory, mechanism design, auction theory, and social choice theory. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 411 — Artificial Intelligence I Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Definitions of intelligence and AI, autonomous agents, architectures of agents and types of environments, search techniques, adversarial search, search in complex environments, logic and probability, learning, generative AI. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 412 — Introduction to Machine Learning Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Mechanism, implementation, and application of systems that improve automatically based on past experience, including classification, density estimation, clustering, and online learning tasks and solutions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; and IE 342 or STAT 381 or ECE 341. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. MATLAB will be used for some of the homework assignments, but prior experience with it is not required.

Course: CS 415 — Computer Vision I Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamental concepts and techniques in computer vision; image filtering, feature detection, description, matching, image segmentation, and object recognition; hands-on projects and assignments. Prerequisites: CS 202 or MCS 360 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for CS 415 if the student has credit in ECE 415.

Course: CS 418 — Introduction to Data Science Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an in-depth overview of data science in engineering. Topics include modeling, storage, manipulation, integration, classification, analysis, visualization, information extraction, and big data in the engineering domain. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; and STAT 381 or IE 342 or ECE 341. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 421 — Natural Language Processing Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design of natural language processing systems; part-of speech tagging, statistical and symbolic parsers; semantic interpretation; discourse and dialogue processing; natural language generation; applications. Prerequisites: CS 301 or MCS 441. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 422 — User Interface Design and Programming Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: User interface design, implementation, and evaluation: user-centered design methodologies, windowing systems, I/O devices and techniques, event-loop programming, user studies. Programming projects. Prerequisites: CS 342. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 423 — Natural User Interactions Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduces students to the field of natural user interactions, including topics such as design principles, hardware-to-software development pipeline (including various existing platforms, toolkits and APIs), as well as effective evaluation techniques. Prerequisites: CS 342. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: CS 422 or CS 522.

Course: CS 424 — Visualization and Visual Analytics Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Geospatial visualization, scientific visualization, medical visualization, information visualization, and social network visualization, interaction, data analysis, human factors, dynamic data, privacy, uncertainty, data transforms. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 425 — Computer Graphics I Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 0-4 Description: Principles of interactive computer graphics. Raster and vector display, techniques and hardware considerations. Introduction to two-dimensional and three dimensional rendering. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: CS 426 — Video Game Design and Development Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory and practice of video game design and programming. Students will form interdisciplinary teams, to design, build and demonstrate video games or related interactive simulation environments. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; or Grade of C or better in DES 450. Course Information: Same as DES 426. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 427 — Creative Coding Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Creative Coding investigates how contemporary computational techniques can inspire novel forms of art making, providing students with the skills to make use of technology for expressive purposes. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: Same as DES 427. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 428 — Virtual, Augmented and Mixed Reality Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Virtual reality, augmented reality, and mixed reality environments, display devices, input devices, tracking, navigation, interaction, collaboration, generating visuals and sounds, software tools, applications, evaluation, safety. Prerequisites: CS 342 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 440 — Software Engineering I Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Software life-cycle model, requirement specification techniques, large-scale software design techniques and tools, implementation issues, testing and debugging techniques, software maintenance. Prerequisites: CS 342. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as EECS 470.

Course: CS 441 — Engineering Distributed Objects For Cloud Computing Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides a broad but solid overview of engineering distributed object for cloud computing. Students will learn the theory and principles of engineering distributed objects for cloud environments. Programming assignments required. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 341 or Grade of C or better in CS 342 ; and Grade of C or better in CS 361. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Engineering Distributed Objects For Cloud Computing
metadata.subject: Computer Science (CS)

text: Course: CS 442 — Software Engineering II Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced concepts in software development: requirements engineering, cost estimation, risk analysis, extreme programming, regression test case selection, and design patterns. Software lab assignments required. Prerequisites: CS 440. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 450 — Introduction to Networking Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Network protocols, algorithms, and software issues. Topics include the Open Systems Interconnect model, data link, network and transport layers, TCP/IP, ATM, mobile networks. Prerequisites: CS 361. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for CS 450 if the student has credit for ECE 433.

Course: CS 453 — Introduction to Parallel and Distributed Processing Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Foundations of parallel and distributed processing; clusters and parallel systems; communication primitives; programming with MPI; scalability; distributed graph algorithms; distributed mutual exclusion, deadlock detection, peer-to-peer systems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: CS 401.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Parallel and Distributed Processing
metadata.subject: Computer Science (CS)

text: Course: CS 454 — Principles of Concurrent Programming Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Focuses on the foundations and basic principles of concurrent programming, covering high-level notions of concurrent correctness and connecting those abstract concepts to real-world programming constructs and algorithms used in practice. Prerequisites: CS 361. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 455 — Introduction to High Performance Computing Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Explore the foundations of high-performance computing (HPC), the architecture of supercomputers, and the challenges in developing massive heterogeneous systems to address complex real-world problems. Prerequisites: CS 361 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 461 — Operating Systems Design and Implementation Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Kernel design and implementation; process management; effective management of machine resources: resource allocation and scheduling, mutual exclusion, deadlock avoidance, memory management policies, devices and file systems, and client-server systems. Prerequisites: CS 361. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as CS 385. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 463 — Systems Performance and Concurrent Computing Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Understanding the many systems factors that affect program performance, including program design for concurrent computing, profiling and program optimization. Prerequisites: CS 361. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: CS 461.

Course: CS 466 — Computer Architecture Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design principles of computer architecture. Topics include: instruction set architecture, pipelining, instruction-level parallelism, caches, main memory, and thread-level parallelism. Prerequisites: ECE 366 or CS 261. Course Information: Same as ECE 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 468 — Network Security Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduces basic concepts of security and privacy, and covers the principles and practice of network security. Given the ubiquitousness of network communications, this course explores a range of systems and applications, and the threats they face. Prerequisites: CS 361. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 472 — Provably Correct Programming Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to interactive theorem proving and program logics, with the goal of specifying and proving the correctness of programs. Learn to develop machine-assisted formal mathematical proofs and prove that programs satisfy their specifications. Prerequisites: CS 341. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: CS 341 or experience with functional programming.

Course: CS 473 — Compiler Design Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Language translation: lexical analysis, parsing schemes, symbol table management, syntax and semantic error detection, and code generation. Development of fully-functional compiler. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 301 or Grade of C or better in MCS 441 ; and Grade of C or better in CS 251 or Grade of C or better in MCS 360 ; and Grade of C or better in CS 261. Course Information: Same as MCS 411. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 474 — Object-Oriented Languages and Environments Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Data abstraction, classes and objects, messages and methods, polymorphism and dynamic binding, inheritance. Object-oriented design. Pure and hybrid object-oriented languages. Prerequisites: CS 342. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as EECS 474.

Course: CS 475 — Object-Oriented Programming Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: OO Paradigm: classes, messages, methods, variables, inheritance, polymorphism; the C++ and Java languages; programming labs required. Prerequisites: CS 202; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for CS 475 if the student has credit for CS 340 or CS 474. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 476 — Programming Language Design Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Definition, design, and implementation of programming languages. Syntactic and semantic description; variable bindings, control and data structures, parsing, code generation, optimization; exception handling; data abstraction. Prerequisites: MCS 360 ; or CS 341. Course Information: Same as MCS 415. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as EECS 476.

Course: CS 477 — Public Policy, Legal, and Ethical Issues in Computing, Privacy, and Security Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Contemporary topics involving legal, public policy, and/or ethical issues in computing, especially privacy, security, and surveillance. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Public Policy, Legal, and Ethical Issues in Computing, Privacy, and Security
metadata.subject: Computer Science (CS)

text: Course: CS 478 — Software Development for Mobile Platforms Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design and implementation of mobile applications; operating systems, object-oriented languages and programming environments for mobile platforms; integration with hardware components; and location-aware applications. Programming assignments required. Prerequisites: CS 342. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 479 — Wearables and Nearables Technology Laboratory Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Practical experience in design and development of wearable and nearable devices. Acquisition and processing of sensors data. Design and development of user-friendly user interface. Prerequisites: BME 240 ; or CS 251 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BME 479. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ECE 210 and CS 109.

Course: CS 480 — Database Systems Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Database design, logical design, physical design. Relational databases. Recovery, concurrency control. Normalization. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 483 — Big Data Mining Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Data mining for very large datasets from a foundational and practical standpoint including similarity search, data-stream processing, advanced technology for search engines, recommendation systems, and graph analytics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; and ECE 341 or IE 342 or STAT 381. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for CS 483 if the student has credit in CS 583. Recommended Background: CS 401 and CS 480.

Course: CS 484 — Secure Web Application Development Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Web applications integrate concepts from software engineering, systems programming, and computer security. Teaches security through web development, enabling students to design, deploy, scale, attack, and defend modern web applications. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 341. Credit or concurrent registration in CS 341 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CS 341 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Prereq Codes (parsed): CS 341 Coreq Codes (parsed): CS 341

Course: CS 485 — Networked Operating Systems Programming Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 4 or 5 Description: Concepts, design, and programming of multi-process and distributed systems; inter-process communications; fault tolerance; distributed programming semantics. Programming assignments and project required. Prerequisites: CS 385. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Previously listed as EECS 471.

Course: CS 487 — Building Secure Computer Systems Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Building and programming secure systems; protecting systems from threats and reduction of vulnerabilities; Includes application, host and network security. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 385; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 488 — Introduction to Cryptography Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Foundational concepts: encryption schemes, hash functions, message authentication codes, digital signatures. Practical systems: stream and block ciphers, SHA. Advanced topics: secure computation, zero-knowledge proofs, blockchain. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; and IE 342 or STAT 381 or STAT 401. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 489 — Human Augmentics Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of technologies for augmentation of human capabilities; human limitations; implants and wearable technologies; implants; brain-computer interfaces; exoskeletons; sensors and networks. Includes project work. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BME 489. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: CS 491 — Seminar Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Topics of mutual interest to a faculty member and a group of students. Offered as announced by department bulletin or the Timetable. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Previously listed as EECS 491.

Course: CS 494 — Special Topics in Computer Science Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Multidisciplinary computer science topics for undergrad seniors and graduate student that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 1 to 3 undergraduate hours; 2 to 4 graduate hours.

Course: CS 499 — Professional Development Seminar Subject: Computer Science (CS) Credits: 0 Description: Graduating seniors will be provided with information regarding future career paths and will provide information regarding the program to be used for assessment purposes. Students take the CS Major Field Exam as part of this course. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors; and approval of the department. Must be taken in the student's last semester of study. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: CST 120 — Catholic Thought: An Introduction Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the main topics, interests, and methods of Catholic thought. Course Information: Same as RELS 120. Past course.

Course: CST 128 — The Jesus Movement and the New Testament Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 3 Description: Investigates the Jesus movement from its beginnings as a small Jewish reform sect through its development into the religion known as Christianity. Uses New Testament writings as primary sources for reconstructing the past. Course Information: Same as CL 128 and RELS 128. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Jesus Movement and the New Testament
metadata.subject: Catholic Studies (CST)

text: Course: CST 150 — Catholicism in U.S. History Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 3 Description: The Catholic experience in the United States from its colonial origins to the present. Course Information: Same as HIST 150 and RELS 150. US Society course.

Course: CST 293 — Dante's Divine Comedy Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 3 Description: An in-depth study of the Divine Comedy, read in English, against the historical, religious, philosophical and cultural background of the Middle Ages. Course Information: Same as RELS 293 and ITAL 293. Previously listed as CST 193. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: CST 294 — Topics in Catholic History Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 3 Description: An investigation of the impact of human migration and cultural pluralism on Catholicism and an analysis of the role of the Catholic Church in group relations. Topics will vary. Course Information: Same as HIST 294 and RELS 294. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: CST 295 — Topics in Catholic Thought Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 3 Description: Critical investigation of a topic or topics central to the development of Catholic thought, carried on by study of its proponents and opponents. Topics will vary. Course Information: Same as RELS 295. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: CST 394 — Topics in Catholic History and Culture Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of various topics in Catholic history and culture. Prerequisites: One course in history or Catholic studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 394 and RELS 394.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Catholic History and Culture
metadata.subject: Catholic Studies (CST)

text: Course: CST 396 — Independent Study Subject: Catholic Studies (CST) Credits: 1-3 Description: Selected topics for individual study. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hour(s). Students may register for more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major. Recommended Background: CST 120 or CST 150.

Course: DES 110 — Design Colloquium Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces students to the breadth and the depth of design theory of practice. Broadens students' view of design. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: DES 120 — 2D Form Studio Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to fundamentals of graphic composition (symbols, images, and letterforms) with emphasis on observation, process, hierarchy and abstraction. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 110. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 130 — 3D Form Studio Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the fundamentals of three-dimensional form-making, design thinking and design process. Emphasis on conceptual visualization and physical and digital fabrication. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 120. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 140 — Design Drawing Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the fundamentals of drawing in the context of design studies. One, two, and three-point perspective for objects and environments as well as application of light and shadow. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 150 — Digital Media Design I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the fundamentals of design theory and process in digital media. Utilizes current technologies to explore basics of motion graphics and interaction design. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 205. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 160 — Design Photography Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to photography used in the context of design studies. Familiarity with the camera, studio, digital techniques and software programs in the contacts of observation, composition, and meaning. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 170 — Color Theory Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to color theory, aesthetics, and systems with emphasis on the definition, replication, and interaction of color in design applications across various media. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 208 — Typography I: Form Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the aesthetics and mechanics of typographic form and usage. Study of typographic measurement system; recognition and classification; alignment, hierarchy and legibility. Prerequisites: Completion of the design foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 219. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 209 — Typography II: Systems Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: The connections beteween material and immaterial space in typographic systems. Introduction to micro and macro typographic patterns with emphasis on theory and practice of grids, proportions, formats, and part to whole. Prerequisites: DES 208. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 314. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 220 — Form and Image Studio Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Principles of creation, comparison and sequencing of symbols, letterforms, and images. Study of materials and processes in visual communication and image-making for theoretical and practical application. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 210. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 222 — Human Experience in Design Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the relationship design has to people, both in terms of process and execution. Structured around human-centered design, understanding the five human factors: social, cognitive, emotional, physical, and cultural. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 230 — Industrial Design II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Furthers knowledge of design process through focused exercises emphasizing functional, formal aspects of design and product semantics. Understanding design through making and specific fabrication materials and methods. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the design foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 220. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 231 — Industrial Design III Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Emphasis on connecting skills learned in previous ID courses through the design of small, simple objects according to recognized user needs. Iterative work with digital and physical tools within constrained criteria. Prerequisites: DES 230 and sophomore standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 221. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 235 — History of Design I: 1760-1925 Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of industrial and graphic design from the Industrial Revolution to 1925. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as AH 235. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: DES 236 — History of Design II: 1925 to the Present Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of industrial and graphic design from 1925 to the present. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Art History at the 100-level or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as AH 236. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Recommended Background: AH 235 or DES 235.

metadata.class_name: History of Design II: 1925 to the Present
metadata.subject: Design (DES)

text: Course: DES 240 — Visualization I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Freehand sketch intensive studio with focus on rapid conceptional visualization. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 223. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 241 — Visualization II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to digital design tools and techniques, building expertise and comfort with prominent visualization and CAD software and hardware platforms. Prerequisites: DES 240 and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 425. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 250 — Digital Media Design II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Expands basic principles of interaction design and motion graphics with emphasis on motion literacy. Introduction to user-interface design and web-based publishing. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 211. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 251 — Digital Media Design III: Motion Design Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Advanced narrative and storytelling through motion. Expands motion literacy into narrative sequence planning, animation design process, and multi-media technologies. Prerequisites: DES 250. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 317. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Digital Media Design III: Motion Design
metadata.subject: Design (DES)

text: Course: DES 255 — Integrative Design Studio I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to design process: ideation and iteration. Emphasis on understanding design through physical investigations utilizing specific fabrication materials and methods for prototype and critique. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the design foundation program or concurrent registration in DES 208 and CS 211. Corequisites: DES 208. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: DES 256 — Integrative Design Studio II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to interactions and systems in design. Emphasis on understanding design through digital investigations utilizing specific software tools for creative and analytic discovery. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and completion of the design foundation program or concurrent registration in DES 209 and CS 251. Corequisites: DES 209. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 308 — Typography III: Expression Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Textual investigations of typographic form of expression with an emphasis on composition (contrast, rhythm, tension), non-linearity, visual argumentation, dimensions, and the interplay between digital and analog operations. Prerequisites: DES 209. Course Information: Previously listed as DES 318. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 309 — Typography IV: Advanced Topics Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Advanced studio addressing current topics in typography. Content varies per course offering. Topic descriptions are publicized during registration period and may include dimensional typography, environmental graphics, type design, information design. Prerequisites: DES 308. Course Information: May be repeated for credit. Students may register for more than one section per term. Previously listed as DES 319. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 322 — Design Research Methods Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Overview of the role of research in human-centered design process and development with emphasis on research support in identifying new opportunities, concept definition, realization, and refinement. Prerequisites: DES 222 and junior standing or above. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 326 — Materials and Methods Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the vocabulary and processes involved in mass production with emphasis on major materials and manufacturing methods, design control drawings and basic principles of sustainable design. Prerequisites: DES 330 and junior standing or above, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 326. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 330 — Industrial Design IV Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to specialty areas of concentration, including visual brand language, service design, and design for sustainability and social responsibility. Builds upon foundational skills through projects. Prerequisites: DES 231 and junior standing or above, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 320. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 331 — Industrial Design V Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Human-centered design thinking and mastery of design process with opportunity for collaborative work in small teams focused on user and client-based project. Prerequisites: DES 330 and junior standing or above, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 321. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 350 — Digital Media Design IV: Advanced Topics Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Advanced topics in design and the interplay between digital and analog operations. Prerequisites: DES 251. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Digital Media Design IV: Advanced Topics
metadata.subject: Design (DES)

text: Course: DES 355 — Design Seminar Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 3 Description: Seminar on current topics in contemporary design theory and practice. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of the design foundation program or concurrent registration in DES 357 and CS 261. Corequisites: DES 357. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

Course: DES 357 — Integrative Design Studio III Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Orients toward increasing complexity and deeper understanding of design making and thinking. Subjects of investigation respond to current, emerging trends in design practice. Collaborative team-based projects combine multiple tools and technologies. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of the design foundation program or concurrent registration in DES 355 and CS 261. Corequisites: DES 355. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 400 — Independent Study in Graphic Design Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 1-5 Description: Supervised independent study in graphic design. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above and consent of instructor. Taken by faculty invitation only.
