Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours for undergraduate students or 10 hours for graduate students. Previously listed as AD 418. Extensive computer use required.

Course: DES 410 — Senior Design Colloquium I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 1 Description: Advanced overview of design practice. Includes lectures representing current and emerging forms of commercial and social practice. Prerequisites: DES 319 or DES 322 , and senior standing or above, and consent of instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 415.

Course: DES 411 — Senior Design Colloquium II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 1 Description: This course is a continuation of DES 410 which introduces students to the breadth and depth of design theory and practice. The course focuses on the student's individual skills, interests and possibilities for professional engagement. Prerequisites: DES 410.

Course: DES 420 — Professional Practice Project I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 0-5 Description: Year-long course sequence option allowing students to engage in an interdisciplinary professional project with industry or community partners. Emphasis on teamwork and client interaction. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above and completion of the design foundation program. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 411. Class Schedule Information: To be properly, registered students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 421 — Professional Practice Project II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Year-long course sequence option allowing students to engage in an interdisciplinary professional project with industry or community partners. Emphasis on teamwork and client interaction. Prerequisites: DES 420. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, student must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 426 — Video Game Design and Development Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory and practice of video game design and programming. Students will form interdisciplinary teams, to design, build and demonstrate video games or related interactive simulation environments. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251 ; or Grade of C or better in DES 450. Course Information: Same as CS 426. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: DES 427 — Creative Coding Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Creative Coding investigates how contemporary computational techniques can inspire novel forms of art making, providing students with the skills to make use of technology for expressive purposes. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: Same as CS 427. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: DES 430 — Interdisciplinary Product Development I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduces cross-functional team-based work focusing on problem identification and use-centered research methods in the fuzzy front end of new product development. Prerequisites: DES 319 or DES 322 and senior standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 420. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 431 — Interdisciplinary Product Development II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Continues cross-functiuonal team-based work focused on problem identification and user-centered research methods in the fuzzy front end of new product development. Prerequisites: DES 430 and senior standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 421. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 432 — Interaction Design Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Design thinking and mastery of design process with opportunity for collaborative work in small teams focused on client-based project. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 413. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 440 — Design and Identity I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Year-long course sequence option allowing students to engage in an interdisciplinary professional project involving design research and civic or social engagement. Emphasis on teamwork, advocacy and presentation. Prerequisites: DES 319 or DES 322. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 441 — Design and Identity II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Year-long course sequence option allowing students to engage in an interdisciplinary professional project involving design research and civic or social engagement. Emphasis on teamwork, advocacy and presentation. Prerequisites: DES 440. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 450 — Advanced Topics in Design Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Advanced special topics in design theory and practice. Prerequisites: Open only to advanced undergraduate and graduate students in the School of Design. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 452 — Information Aesthetics I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to information visualization and programming in the context of art and design. Project oriented course using computer code and custom software for information analysis, representation and creative expression. Prerequisites: DES 319 or DES 322 and sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 4 hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Previously listed as AD 452. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 453 — Information Aesthetics II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Intermediate course emphasizing the database as cultural form. Creative projects and research in information aesthetics through date driven two, three and four dimensional visualizations and custom computer interfaces. Prerequisites: DES 452 or ART 452 and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: 4 hours. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours. Previously listed as AD 453. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 458 — Integrative Studio Project Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Exploration, deduction and design of student-selected research topic. Accumulated knowledge and skills are utilized to develop a year-long capstone project. Prerequisites: DES 357. Course Information: Previously listed as DES 358. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 470 — Industrial Design Thesis I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Research and design of student-selected topic. Accumulated knowledge and skills are utilized to develop a year-long capstone project providing opportunity to develop a specific focus within design. Prerequisites: DES 236 and DES 331 and senior standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 423. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 471 — Industrial Design Thesis II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Research and design of student-selected topic. Accumulated knowledge and skills are utilized to develop a year-long capstone project providing opportunity to develop a specific focus within design. Prerequisites: DES 470 and senior standing or above. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 480 — Graphic Design Thesis I Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Exploration, deduction and design of student-selected research topic. Accumulated knowledge and skills are utilized to develop a year-long capstone project. Prerequisites: DES 236 and DES 319. Course Information: Previously listed as AD 412. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 481 — Graphic Design Thesis II Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 4 Description: Exploration, deduction and design of student-selected research topic. Accumulated knowledge and skills are utilized to develop a year-long capstone project. Prerequisites: DES 480. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: DES 499 — Design Internship Subject: Design (DES) Credits: 1 Description: Academic learning is coupled with professional experience in an off-campus design studio or department. Co-operative education placement is arranged by the student. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 3 hours. Previously listed as AD 499. Requirements of organization offering internship: understanding/agreement that a student intern is a design professional in training (not a volunteer, not a freelancer), positions are paid (at or above federal minimum wage), student is seeking professional experience (not a portfolio piece), setting is a design department or student environment (the student is not the only designer on site), 15 hours per week expected, 20 hours per week maximum.

Course: DHD 100 — Disability and Human Development Seminar Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces students to resources, academic skill building, professional development, and career exploration in the field of Disability and Human Development. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: DHD 101 — Disability in U.S. Society Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the variety of approaches to understanding disability in personal, social, economic, artistic, and political contexts. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll ine one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: DHD 102 — Disability in American Film Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the portrayal of disability in American cinema. What does cinema offer to our cultural understanding of disability? Course Information: Previously listed as DHD 176. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll ine one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: DHD 201 — Disability, Rights, and Culture Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an overview of disability rights and disability culture. Focuses on moral, legal, cultural, and economic aspects of the lives of people with disabilities in history and at present. Individual and Society course.

Course: DHD 202 — Disability, Health, and Society Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: The notion of disability and health through the use of the World Health Organization’s (WHO) International Classification of Functioning, Disability, and Health (ICF) focusing on influence of family, culture, and policies. Individual and Society course.

Course: DHD 203 — Disability in World Cultures Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the ways in which different social, cultural, political and economic systems shape experiences of disability by looking at disability in different contexts throughout the world. Recommended Background: DHD 101. World Cultures course.

Course: DHD 204 — Disability in the Humanities Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students with a survey of humanities approaches to the study of disability. The course explores disability in literature, art, performance, mass media, and historical archives. Creative Arts course.

Course: DHD 205 — Disability, Race, Class and Gender Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Invites students to engage in a critical dialogue around disability, race, class and gender through an intersectional and interdisciplinary frame of analysis. Course Information: Same as GWS 205. Individual and Society course.

Course: DHD 206 — Disability, Inclusive Cities, and Environmental Accessibility Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces disability within a geographic framework, considering socio-spatial patterns that reflect and shape disability in modern cities. Explores applied urban planning practices and policies related to disability. Natural World - No Lab course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Disability, Inclusive Cities, and Environmental Accessibility
metadata.subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD)

text: Course: DHD 301 — Disability, Research, and Interdisciplinary Methods Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to disability studies methodological approaches, focusing on the major traditions of inquiry used in the study of disability and the basics of conducting research related to disability and disabled people. Recommended Background: DHD 101 and an additional 6 credit hours of DHD coursework.

Course: DHD 302 — Disability, Policy, and Law Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the major laws and policies relevant to people with disabilities. Provides an overview of the historical, political, legal, socio-cultural and economic forces that shape policy and legislation. Recommended Background: DHD 101 and an additional 6 credit hours of DHD coursework.

Course: DHD 303 — Disability Activism: From the Local to the Global Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Traces the emergence of disability activism across historical periods and cultural locations, offering an in-depth look at issues raised, strategies used for social change, coalitions built, and global networks established.

metadata.class_name: Disability Activism: From the Local to the Global
metadata.subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD)

text: Course: DHD 390 — Co-Op Internship Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: An opportunity for students to develop and explore career interests related to their area of focus, which couples academic learning with professional experience in an off-campus setting. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Field work required.

Course: DHD 400 — Disability and Human Development Capstone Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 1 Description: Students work with advocacy, research and/or policy organizations to apply the knowledge they gained through disability and human development coursework in a practical setting that addresses issues related to people with disabilities. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors; and consent of the instructor. Juniors must have the consent of instructors in order to be allowed to register. A minimum of 18 credits of DHD completed coursework is required. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Field work required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Recommended Background: Seniors in their final year of the Bachelor of Science program in Disability and Human Development.

Course: DHD 401 — Disability, Human Development and Community Participation Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Surveys foundational concepts and issues in disability studies and human development. Students will develop a framework for understanding disability from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Prerequisites: Students enrolled in the BS in Disability and Human Development: DHD 101 and at least 6 additional hours of disability and human development coursework must be completed or consent of the instructor; Graduate students: no prerequisites. Course Information: Taught online.

metadata.class_name: Disability, Human Development and Community Participation
metadata.subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD)

text: Course: DHD 403 — Disability in Latino Communities Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Designed to examine the distinct needs of Latino families and communities in the US and in Latin American countries, and their experiences with disabilities.

Course: DHD 404 — Disability, Sexuality, and Health Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Explores how political, social, and cultural systems as well as historical contexts shape understandings and experiences of disability, sexuality, and health. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 404. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: DHD 407 — Cultural Politics of Disability and Health Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the construction and circulation of knowledge about bodies, health, medicine and impairment from a disability studies perspective. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Cultural Politics of Disability and Health
metadata.subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD)

text: Course: DHD 408 — Disability Through the Lifecourse Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an overview of varying approaches to the study of disability through the life course from early childhood to adulthood and aging. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor.

Course: DHD 409 — Disability Legal Studies Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 2 Description: An interdisciplinary approach to key debates, theories, research, and practices related to disability and law within the critical framework of Disability Legal Studies. Course Information: Taught online.

Course: DHD 411 — Disability Policy, Technology, and Practice Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to a broad range of disability policies and technologies, focusing on application of policy and technology in practice across a range of contexts.

Course: DHD 412 — Disability Representation, Culture, and Practice Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to disability culture best practices for creating accessible and inclusive representations across a range of contexts from social media to non-profit messaging and marketing.

Course: DHD 420 — Mental Health, Asian Americans, and Community Engagement Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In partnership with Chicago’s Asian American communities and using community engagement methodologies, this course will offer an interdisciplinary, team-approach to explore taboo-related mental health issues. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Mental Health, Asian Americans, and Community Engagement
metadata.subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD)

text: Course: DHD 440 — Introduction to Assistive Technology: Principles and Practice Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in this course will introduce students to the principles and practices of assistive technology devices and services used by people with disabilities. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Assistive Technology: Principles and Practice
metadata.subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD)

text: Course: DHD 441 — Adaptive Equipment Design and Fabrication Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the interaction between design and disability, through comparison of appropriate design theories, materials, and work on consumer-based issues. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; or DHD 440 and consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Undergraduates enrolled in health sciences, education, or engineering, or working professionals seeking to develop assistive technology as an area of concentration.

Course: DHD 442 — Disability, Communication, and Social Participation Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: Focuses on communication within disability across the lifespan. Topics include Communication Bill of Rights, varying communication disabilities, and the use of augmentative and alternative communication strategies and tools. Prerequisites: DHD 440. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: DHD 450 — Topics in Disability Studies Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: This course will focus on topics structured around particular aspects of Disability Studies and its practical, cultural, and theoretical implications. Course Information: Same as ENGL 450. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as DHD 445. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 245, 344, 345, 347, or 350. Junior standing or above.

Course: DHD 451 — Disability Communities, Careers, and Professionalism Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 3 Description: Explores current trends regarding career paths and communities within disability fields, while honing essential skills for professionalism including disability access and accessibility, effective communication, and meaningful collaboration. Recommended Background: It is highly recommended for students to take at least nine (9) credits hours of DHD courses prior to registration.

Course: DHD 494 — Special Topics in Disability and Human Development Subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD) Credits: 1-4 Description: Systematic study of selected topics in disability and human development. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Disability and Human Development
metadata.subject: Disability and Human Development (DHD)

text: Course: DLG 120 — UIC First-Year Dialogue Seminar Subject: Dialogue (DLG) Credits: 1 Description: Students become familiar with multidisciplinary theory and research on diversity, social justice, culture, and identity, through participation in critical dialogues with each other to explore differences. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as CC 120. Some sections of this course meet during weeks 1-8 and other sections meet during weeks 9-16, as described in the Class Schedule.

Course: DLG 220 — Intergroup Dialogue Subject: Dialogue (DLG) Credits: 3 Description: Designed to promote students’ exploration of social identity group membership, conflict, collaboration, and social justice. Each dialogue involves groups with a history of social conflict. Prerequisites: CC 120. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: EAES 101 — Global Environmental Change Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Natural and anthropogenic controls on the structure and evolution of the earth's surface environment. Interactions among the Earth's solid surface, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere and human impacts on these processes. Course Information: Field trip required at nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: EAES 105 — Climate, Contamination, and Chicago Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 2 Description: Environmental earth science issues relevant to Chicago’s economy and history. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: EAES 108 — Environmental History of the World Since 1500 Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: A history of the world since 1500 through the lens of the environment, with topics including indigenous relationships to nature, colonial and industrial capitalism, imperialism, disease, petro-politics, and the politics of climate change. Course Information: Same as HIST 108. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Environmental History of the World Since 1500
metadata.subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES)

text: Course: EAES 111 — Earth, Energy, and the Environment Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Nature and evolution of Earth from the scale of minerals and rocks to tectonic plates. Earthquakes and volcanoes, their hazards and effects on humans. Natural resources, sources of energy, and their environmental impacts. Course Information: Previously listed as EAES 102. Field trip required at nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: EAES 116 — Energy for Future Decision-Makers Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of energy sustainability and environmental issues. All energy forms of production, sources, storage, and uses; their environmental implications on a global scale within the scientific, technological, political, economic, and social context. Course Information: Same as PHYS 116. Recommended Background: High school algebra. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: EAES 180 — Honors Earth and Environmental Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 1 Description: Provides honors students with the opportunity to explore in depth a topic treated in the concurrent lecture course. Prerequisites: Concurrent registration in EAES 101 or EAES 111. Honors course. Course Information: May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Students may register in more than one section per term. May be taken a total of 2 times, each time with concurrent registration in EAES 101 or EAES 111.

Course: EAES 203 — The Science and Rhetorics of Climate Change Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Explores climate change as a physical and cultural phenomenon through the rhetorical analysis of texts, data, and primary research. Course Information: Same as ENGL 203. Extensive computer use required. Natural World - No Lab course.

metadata.class_name: The Science and Rhetorics of Climate Change
metadata.subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES)

text: Course: EAES 290 — Communication in Earth and Environmental Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 2 Description: Seminar on current issues in earth and environmental sciences. Introduction to reading, interpretation, and writing of scientific papers. Prerequisites: Completion of at least one 100-level course in earth and environmental sciences. Course Information: Previously listed as EAES 390.

metadata.class_name: Communication in Earth and Environmental Sciences
metadata.subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES)

text: Course: EAES 300 — Fieldwork in Missouri Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 2 Description: Field observations in the St. Francois Mountains and vicinity, southeast Missouri. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in EAES 101 and Grade of C or better in EAES 111 and Grade of C or better in EAES 330 ; or consent of the instructor. Registration may be limited if student is not majoring in Earth and Environmental Sciences. Course Information: Previously listed as EAES 200. Field work required. Full participation in pre-field trip class meetings is mandatory. Three two-hour meetings and one-week field trip during the spring vacation. Will count as elective if student already has credit for EAES 302. Credit is given upon completion of assignments that include a satisfactory written report. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Studio.

Course: EAES 302 — Methods in Environmental Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 2 Description: Survey of field methods and lab analyses relevant to investigation and assessment of environmental systems. Multiple local field trips will allow for hands-on experience with soil, water, ground, plant, and microbial measurement techniques. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in EAES 330 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in EAES 330 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in EAES 330 Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Elective credit if students have credit in EAES 300. Lab hours will be flexible to accommodate field trips - consult instructor for schedule details. Registration may be limited if student is not a declared major or minor in Earth and Environmental Sciences. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, student must enroll in one Laboratory and one Laboratory-Discussion. Recommended Background: Introductory Biology and Chemistry. Prereq Codes (parsed): EAES 330 Coreq Codes (parsed): EAES 330

Course: EAES 330 — Earth Materials Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to physical and chemical properties, uses, and distribution of earth materials including minerals, rocks, water, and gasses. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in EAES 101 and Grade of C or better in EAES 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as EAES 230. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion. Recommended Background: Introductory Chemistry.

Course: EAES 350 — Sedimentary Environments Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Characterization of sediments and sedimentary rocks, sediment transport, deposition and sedimentary structures, depositional environments. Stratigraphic principles, introductory sequence stratigraphy. Applied sedimentary geology. Prerequisites: EAES 330 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trips required at nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: EAES 360 — Introduction to Paleontology Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: The morphology, ecology, and relationships of fossil organisms. Basic principles of paleontology, including evolution, paleoecology and functional morphology. Prerequisites: EAES 101 or EAES 111 ; or BIOS 110 and BIOS 120. Course Information: Same as BIOS 360. Field trip required at a nominal fee. One day field trip to collect fossils. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: EAES 380 — Earth and Environmental Data Science Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to scientific programming for Earth and environmental data science in R or Python, including how to import, tidy, visualize, analyze, and communicate data, and ensure reproducible research with version control software. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in EAES 101 ; or Grade of C or better in EAES 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as EAES 420. Extensive computer use required. WIFI-enabled laptop computer required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Recommended Background: Introductory Chemistry; Introductory Biology; Introductory Earth Science; Spreadsheet data analysis.

Course: EAES 385 — Earth Systems Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Earth systems and global change; climate forcing and feedback; greenhouse gases and global warming; oceans and carbon cycle; brief history of Earth’s climate and climatic variability; tectonic systems; introduction to remote sensing of Earth. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in EAES 101 and Grade of C or better in EAES 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as EAES 285. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture. Recommended Background: EAES 290.

Course: EAES 396 — Independent Research Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 2-8 Description: Individual study under supervision of a faculty member in areas not covered in standard courses. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. A combined maximum of 6 hours of credit in EAES 396 and EAES 492 may be applied toward the degree. Independent research and a resulting undergraduate thesis are required for graduating with highest departmental distinction. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: EAES 400 — Field Experience in Earth Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 1-6 Description: Training in and application of field methods (geological, geochemical, and geophysical) to solution of problems in earth and environmental sciences. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students who wish to use EAES 400 to satisfy the summer course selective must register for at least 4 credit hours.

Course: EAES 415 — Environmental Geochemistry Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Origin and distribution of elements in the earth. Thermodynamics and kinetics of mineral-solution reactions. Behavior of stable and radioisotopes in geochemical processes. Elemental Cycles. Prerequisites: EAES 330 and EAES 385 ; and CHEM 122 and CHEM 123 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: EAES 416 — Organic Geochemistry Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Global carbon cycle, chemical composition of biogenic matter, sedimentology and diagenesis of organic matter, molecular fossils, geopolymers, fossil fuels, anthropogenic organic compounds, carbon isotope geochemistry. Prerequisites: EAES 330 ; and CHEM 122 and CHEM 123 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: EAES 418 — Introduction to Biogeochemistry Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the interaction of the biosphere, geosphere, and atmosphere on Earth, with focus on biogeochemical cycles and the methods used to study them. Examination of conditions on Early Earth and the changes brought by the introduction of life. Prerequisites: CHEM 122 and CHEM 123 ; and EAES 330 or EAES 385 or EAES 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: BIOS 110.

Course: EAES 430 — Petrology Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the formation and classification of igneous and metamorphic rocks, as well as discussion of their implications for global-scale processes on Earth including formation of mineral deposits and earthquakes. Prerequisites: EAES 111 and EAES 330 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: EAES 440 — Structural Geology and Tectonics Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to deformation structures recorded in the lithosphere as well as discussion of deformation mechanisms and their relationship with plate tectonics. The course also explores key processes occurring in different tectonic settings. Prerequisites: EAES 111 and EAES 330 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: EAES 444 — Geophysics Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to basic principles of geophysics applicable for environmental problems and the solid earth including magnetics, electric, seismic, gravity, geophysical well logging, radioactivity and heat flow. Prerequisites: EAES 111 or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: EAES 385 and completion of introductory courses in physics and calculus.

Course: EAES 460 — Earth System History Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Earth history in the context of the interactions of the components of the Earth system; methods used to establish the ages of geologic events and to reconstruct ancient geographies and environments; implications for current issues of global change. Prerequisites: EAES 330 and EAES 385. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee. Field trip cost assessed prior to trip, depending on destination and vehicle expenses. Recommended Background: EAES 360 and EAES 440.

Course: EAES 470 — Environmental Geomorphology Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Quantitative analysis of the mechanics, rates, and distribution of physical processes that modify Earth's and other planets' surfaces. Introduction to field, theoretical, and modelling approaches. Prerequisites: EAES 330 or EAES 385 ; and MATH 181 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: EAES 472 — Remote Sensing and GIS for Earth and Environmental Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and visualization of spatial datasets in Earth and environmental science obtained by remote sensing techniques. Passive and active remote sensing methods to identify geohazards and monitor environmental changes. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in EAES 380 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Remote Sensing and GIS for Earth and Environmental Sciences
metadata.subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES)

text: Course: EAES 473 — Soils and the Environment Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Soil science, emphasizing local soils and parent materials, soil classification and mapping, soil physics, soil gases and greenhouse gas emissions, soil chemistry and biogeochemistry, soil-plant interactions, and soil invertebrates. Course Information: Same as BIOS 473. Field work required. Recommended Background: Introductory courses in Chemistry and Biology. Coursework in EAES (such as EAES 101 and/or EAES 111 ) is preferred.

Course: EAES 475 — Hydrology/Hydrogeology Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: The occurrence, storage, movement, and quality of water above, on and below the Earth's surface. Topics progress through atmospheric water vapor processes, Earth surface hydrology, and groundwater hydrology. Prerequisites: EAES 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trip required at nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Recommended Background: EAES 385 and EAES 330 and MATH 181.

Course: EAES 478 — Elements of Machining Scientific Equipment Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 1 Description: Elements of machining scientific equipment, including the use of machine shop tools and technical drawing of scientific apparatus. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; and approval of the department. Course Information: Same as CHEM 480 and PHYS 480. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: EAES 480 — Modern Statistics in Earth and Environmental Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Scientific programming in R for modern statistical applications in Earth and environmental science. Study design, linear regression, hypothesis testing with bootstrapping, and inference for proportions, means, and regression models. Prerequisites: EAES 380 or equivalent experience in a scientific programming language with consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. WIFI-enabled laptop computer required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Modern Statistics in Earth and Environmental Sciences
metadata.subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES)

text: Course: EAES 484 — Planetary Science Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the study of the solar system, exploring the expressions of geologic processes on planetary bodies other than Earth. Prerequisites: EAES 330 and EAES 385 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: EAES 487 — Introduction to Geobiology and Astrobiology Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasis on the emergence of microbiological life on Earth; evolution of the biosphere and life on early Earth; adaptations of life to extreme conditions, habitability, biosignatures; and the possibility of life elsewhere. Prerequisites: EAES 418 and CHEM 122 ; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Introductory Biology; Introductory Earth Science.

Course: EAES 490 — Climate Change and Extreme Weather Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 4 Description: Exploration of fundamental knowledge of climate change and extreme weather, their causes, and driving mechanisms. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Introductory Physics, Calculus, Meteorology, Earth Science and/or Environmental Science.

Course: EAES 492 — Internship in the Earth and Environmental Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 1 Description: Off-campus participation in governmental or private-sector training program. Credit is contingent on submission of a final report. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated with approval. A combined maximum of 6 hours of credit in EAES 492 and EAES 396 may be applied toward the degree.

metadata.class_name: Internship in the Earth and Environmental Sciences
metadata.subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES)

text: Course: EAES 494 — Current Topics in Earth and Environmental Sciences Subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES) Credits: 1-4 Description: Discussion of current research topics in earth and environmental sciences. Prerequisites: Junior or Senior standing and 12 hours of advanced courses in earth and environmental sciences are recommended. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Current Topics in Earth and Environmental Sciences
metadata.subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences (EAES)

text: Course: ECE 115 — Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Concepts of electrical and computer engineering including: ciruit analysis, fundamental electromagnetics, electronic devices, sensors, communication, digital logic, programming, numerous practical applicaitons; laboratory. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 ; or Grade of C or better in MATH 165. Natural World - With Lab course. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Course Information: Much MATLAB programming, which is taught in the course, is required. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 194 — Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 1-4 Description: Multidisciplinary electrical and computer engineering topics at first-year level that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Course Information: May be repeated.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 210 — Electrical Circuit Analysis Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 Description: Linear circuit analysis: networks, network theorems, dependent sources, operational amplifiers, energy storage elements, transient analysis, sinusoidal analysis, frequency response, filters. Laboratory. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180

Course: ECE 225 — Circuit Analysis Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Electric circuit elements; Ohm's Law; Kirchhoff's laws; transient and steady-state analysis of circuits; Laplace transform methods; network theorems. Laboratory. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 220 ; and a Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; and Grade of C or better in ECE 115. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 220 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 220 Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 225 if the student has credit for ECE 210. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 220 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 220

Course: ECE 265 — Introduction to Logic Design Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Number Systems; Binary arithmetic; Boolean/Logic functions; Boolean Algebra; logic gates, their CMOS design; function minimization, analysis and synthesis of combinational and sequential circuits. Prerequisites: MATH 180 and grade of C or better in ECE 115. Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 265 if the student has credit for CS 266 or CS 366. Laboratory. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 266 — Introduction to Embedded Systems Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to embedded systems and microcontroller; instruction set; data representations; assembly programming; mixed C/assembly programming; memory organization; interrupt processing; I/O devices and interfacing; programming laboratory. Prerequisites: CS 107 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 265. Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 265 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 265 Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 266 if the student has credit in CS 261. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): ECE 265 Coreq Codes (parsed): ECE 265

Course: ECE 267 — Computer Organization I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to computer organization and assembly language programming. Memory, CPU, and I/O organization. Programming techniques and tools. Prerequisites: CS 107 ; and credit or concurrent registration in ECE 265. Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 265 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 265 Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 267 if the student has credit for CS 266 or CS 366. Prereq Codes (parsed): ECE 265 Coreq Codes (parsed): ECE 265

Course: ECE 294 — Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 1-4 Description: Multidisciplinary electrical and computer engineering topics at second-year level that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 310 — Discrete and Continuous Signals and Systems Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 Description: Signals; systems; convolution; discrete and continuous Fourier series and transforms; Z-transforms; Laplace transforms; sampling; frequency response; applications; computer simulations. Prerequisites: MATH 220 and credit or concurrent registration in ECE 225 ; or credit or concurrent registration in ECE 210 for non-ECE students. Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 225 Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 210 for non-ECE students Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 225 Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 210 for non-ECE students Prereq Codes (parsed): ECE 225, ECE 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): ECE 225, ECE 210

metadata.class_name: Discrete and Continuous Signals and Systems
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 311 — Communication Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Continuous-time signals and spectra; amplitude and angle modulation, sampling and quantization theory; digital pulse modulation, error probability, commercial broadcasting practices. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECE 310 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 341. Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 341 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 341 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): ECE 341 Coreq Codes (parsed): ECE 341

Course: ECE 317 — Digital Signal Processing I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Sampling theorem; discrete signals and systems; discrete time Fourier transform; DFT; FFT; IIR and FIR digital filter design; stability; DSP applications. Laboratory. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECE 310. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 322 — Introduction to Electromagnetics and Applications Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Transmission lines. Plane waves in various media. Polarization and Stoke's parameters. Scalar and vector potentials. Guided wave propagation. Radiation. Linear antennas and antenna parameters. Prerequisites: ECE 225. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: ECE 333 — Computer Communication Networks I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: A balanced presentation focuses on the internet as a specific motivating example of a network and also introduces internet protocols in a more theoretical context. Prerequisites: ECE 341 and CS 107. Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 333 if the student has credit for CS 450. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 340 — Electronics I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Operational amplifiers. Semiconductor junctions. Bipolar and field-effect transistors. Simple transistor amplifier and switching applications. Introduction to digital logic circuits. Laboratory experience. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECE 225. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 341 — Probability and Random Processes for Engineers Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 Description: Probability, random variables, discrete and continuous distributions, transformation of random variables, expectation, generating functions, statistical inference, hypothesis testing, estimation, random processes, stationarity, applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210. Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 341 if the student has credit for IE 342.

metadata.class_name: Probability and Random Processes for Engineers
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 342 — Electronics II Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Differential amplifiers. Feedback amplifiers. Frequency response, stability and compensation of amplifiers. Circuit implementation of logic gates in various logic families. Bistable and memory circuits. Laboratory. Prerequisites: ECE 340. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 346 — Solid State Device Theory Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to semiconductors, Energy bands, Electron and hole transport mechanisms in semiconductor devices, recombination and generation, P-N Junctions. Intro to metal-oxide-semiconductor field effect transistors. Practical laboratory. Prerequisites: MATH 220 and a grade of C or better in ECE 115 and a grade of C or better in PHYS 142. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 347 — Integrated Circuit Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 Description: Students learn to make real semiconductor devices, what are the most common techniques for integrated circuits fabrication, and what are the limitations. Students learn concepts of diffusion, oxidation, implantation, lithography, etching, and deposition. Prerequisites: CHEM 122 ; and Grade of C or better in ECE 225.

Course: ECE 350 — Principles of Automatic Control Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Transfer function; block diagrams; flow graphs; state space canonic forms; stability analysis; steady state and transient analysis; feedback control; continuous to discrete conversion; digital control. Prerequisites: MATH 310 and grade of C or better in ECE 310. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 366 — Computer Organization Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 Description: Software/hardware interaction in a computer. Compiler, assembler and linker, machine code. Clocking, datapath, control unit, ALU and memory design, cache memory, pipelining. Prerequisites: ECE 266. Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 366 if the student has credit for CS 261 or CS 262.

Course: ECE 367 — Microprocessor-Based Design Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Microprocessor architecture; microprogrammed machines; programmer's model; control signals and timing; system buses; parallel and serial interfacing; interrupt processing; I/O devices; memory devices; direct memory access; assembly language. Laboratory. Prerequisites: ECE 267; and a grade of C or better in ECE 265 or a grade of C or better in CS 366. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 368 — CAD-Based Digital Design Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 4 Description: Semi-complex circuit and system design techniques, data path control using FSMs, VHDL programming, circuit/system design projects using VHDL and CAD tools (VHDL Simulation, Circuit Synthesis). Prerequisites: ECE 366. Course Information: Credit is not given for ECE 368 if the student has credit for CS 469. Laboratory. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ECE 391 — Electrical and Computer Engineering Practicum Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge gained in previous engineering courses within a professional, working environment. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 1 hour awarded toward degree requirements.

Course: ECE 392 — Undergraduate Research Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 1-5 Description: Research under close supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: ECE 394 — Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 1-4 Description: Multidisciplinary electrical and computer engineering topics at third-year level that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 396 — Senior Design I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 2 Description: Introduction to the principles and practice of product design: specifications, evaluation of design alternatives, technical reports, and oral presentations. Independent design projects. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; and ECE 225 ; and ECE 340 or ECE 346 or ECE 366. Open only to seniors.

Course: ECE 397 — Senior Design II Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 2 Description: Implement and test the group project designed in ECE 396 ; professional development; group presentations including participation at EXPO. Prerequisites: ECE 396. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: ECE 407 — Pattern Recognition I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The design of automated systems for detection, recognition, classification and diagnosis. Parametric and nonparametric decision-making techniques. Applications in computerized medical and industrial image and waveform analysis. Prerequisites: ECE 341 or BME 339 or IE 342 or STAT 381. Course Information: Same as BME 407. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 410 — Advanced Circuit Analysis Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Matrix algebra for network analysis, network parameters, macromodeling, high-frequency measurements, network functions and theorems. Topics in computer-aided analysis. Prerequisites: MATH 310 and grade of C or better in ECE 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 412 — Introduction to Filter Synthesis Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamentals of network synthesis, filter approximations and frequency transformations. Active filter synthesis using bi-linear and bi-quad circuits. Topics in computer-aided design. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECE 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 415 — Image Analysis and Computer Vision I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Image formation, geometry and stereo. Two-dimensional image analysis by fourier and other 2-D transforms. Image enhancement, color, image segmentation, compression, feature extraction, object recognition. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECE 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Image Analysis and Computer Vision I
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 417 — Digital Signal Processing II Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Computer-aided design of digital filters; FFT algorithms and applications; multirate signal processing and wavelets; random signals and Wiener filtering; basics of 2-D DSP. Prerequisites: ECE 317. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 418 — Statistical Digital Signal Processing Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Stochastic signal models, LMS identification, identification of signals from noise, Wiener filtering, blind separation of mixed signal, discrete Wavelet Transforms, compression and denoising, ceptral analysis. Prerequisites: ECE 317 and ECE 341. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 421 — Introduction to Antennas and Wireless Propagation Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Potential, antenna parameters, radiation from linear wires and loops, impedance, arrays, communication links and path loss, tropospheric propagation, fading and diversity. Prerequisites: ECE 225 and ECE 322. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Antennas and Wireless Propagation
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 423 — Electromagnetic Compatibility Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: EMC requirements for electronic systems. Nonideal behavior of components. Radiated and conducted emissions. Susceptibility. Coupling and shielding. Electrostatic discharge. System design for EMS. Prerequisites: MATH 310 and ECE 322. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: ECE 424 — RF and Microwave Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Transmission lines, Smith chart, strip, active RF devices and components, power amplifiers, voltage-controlled oscillators, mixers, wireless communication and radar systems, resonators, two-port parameters, power and energy considerations. Prerequisites: ECE 225 and ECE 322. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 432 — Digital Communications Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Source coding, quantization, signal representation, channel noise, optimum signal reception, digital modulation: ASK, PSK, FSK, MSK, M-ary modulation. Probability of error. Inter-symbol interference. Prerequisites: MATH 310, ECE 311 and ECE 341. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 434 — Multimedia Systems Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Multimedia systems; compression standards; asynchronous transfer mode; Internet; wireless networks; television; videoconferencing; telephony; applications. Prerequisites: ECE 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ECE 436 — Computer Communication Networks II Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Explores integrated network architecture of service, control signaling and management, examples of high-speed LAN/WAN, next generation Internet and mobile wireless network. Prerequisites: ECE 333. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ECE 437 — Wireless Communications Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Cellular concept, frequency reuse, mobile radio propagation, channel fading, noise in analog communications, mobile radio channel equalization, multiple access techniques (FDMA, TDMA, CDMA), wireless networking. Prerequisites: ECE 311 and ECE 341. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 440 — Nanoelectronics Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Wave-particle duality, Schrodinger equation, atomic orbitals, band theory of solids. Semiconductor and carbon nanoelectronic materials. Nanostructure device fabrication. Nanoelectromechanical systems. Prerequisites: ECE 346 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 442 — Power Semiconductor Devices and Integrated Circuits Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Encompasses fundamentals of primarily silicon based power semiconductors with regard to basic physical principles, breakdown mechanisms, high voltage bipolar and insulated gate devices, and basic packaging issues. Prerequisites: ECE 346. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Credit is not given for ECE 442 if the student has credit for EECS 442. ECE 442 is a supplement for ECE 445 and ECE 545. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Power Semiconductor Devices and Integrated Circuits
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 445 — Analysis and Design of Power Electronic Circuits Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Analysis of different isolated and non-isolated power-converter topologies, understanding of power-converter components, switching schemes. Prerequisites: ECE 342. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Analysis and Design of Power Electronic Circuits
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 448 — Transistors Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Bipolar junction transistors, electronic processes in surface-controlled semiconductor and dielectric devices. Metal oxide semiconductor filed effect transistors, surface and interface effects, diode lasers, integrated optoelectronic devices. Prerequisites: ECE 346. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 449 — Microdevices and Micromachining Technology Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Microfabrication techniques for microsensors, microstructures, and microdevices. Selected examples of physical/chemical sensors and actuators. Simulation experiments. Prerequisites: ECE 347 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ME 449. 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Laboratory. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 451 — Control Engineering Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Continuous-and discrete-time state-space models; solutions to state equations; stability; reachabilty/controllability, state feedback, tracking; observability, observers, output feedback; optimal control and estimation. Prerequisites: ECE 350 ; and Grade of C or better in MATH 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 452 — Robotics: Algorithms and Control Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Kinematic and dynamic modeling of robots; configuration space; motion planning algorithms; control of robots; sensors and perception; reasoning; mobile robots. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECE 310 ; and MATH 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 454 — Mechatronic Embedded Systems Design Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Design and fabrication of scaled-down autonomous vehicles, from an embed system perspective; mechatronic components such as motors, microcontrollers, power supply, sensors, control algorithms, project oriented, culminating in racing competition. Prerequisites: ECE 266 and ECE 310 and ECE 340 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Recommended Background: ECE 350 and ECE 412 and ECE 451.

Course: ECE 458 — Electromechanical Energy Conversion Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-4 Description: Electromagnetic forces and torque; magnetic circuits and transformers; DC machines; three-phase AC synchronous and induction machines; laboratory-demonstrations. Projects are required. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECE 225. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 464 — Testing and Reliability of Digital Systems Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory, practice and recent innovations in the testing and reliability of modern digital systems. Topics: fault modeling / simulation, automatic test pattern generation, built-in self-test, fault tolerance. Prerequisites: CS 251 ; and ECE 366. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Testing and Reliability of Digital Systems
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 465 — Digital Systems Design Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Switching algebra, combinational circuits, Mux, ROM, DCD, PLA-based designs, advanced combinational circuit minimization techniques, sychronous and asynchronous sequential circuit synthesis (minimization, hazards, races, state assignment) testing. Prerequisites: Grade C or better in PHYS 142 ; and ECE 366. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 466 — Computer Architecture Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design principles of computer architecture. Topics include: instruction set architecture, pipelining, instruction-level parallelism, caches, main memory, and thread-level parallelism. Prerequisites: ECE 366 or CS 261. Course Information: Same as CS 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECE 467 — Introduction to VLSI Design Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: MOS, CMOS circuits VLSI technology, CMOS circuit characterization and evaluation. Static and dynamic MOS circuits, system design, faults, testing, and symbolic layout. Laboratory. Prerequisites: ECE 340. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ECE 468 — Analog and Mixed - Signal Integrated Circuits Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Review of basic analog concepts; Sampling and mixed-signal interface circuits; analytical analysis and CAD-based design/simulation; emphasis on compact modeling, design tradeoffs, and intuitive design approaches. Prerequisites: ECE 342. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Analog and Mixed - Signal Integrated Circuits
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 469 — Hardware Description Language Based Digital and Computer System Design Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-5 Description: Hardware description language (HDL) introduction; digital system design including arithmetic circuit, datapath and control; basic processor architecture and design; use of CAD tools for simulation, synthesis, and verification. Prerequisites: ECE 366 ; and ECE 465. Course Information: 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Hardware Description Language Based Digital and Computer System Design
metadata.subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

text: Course: ECE 491 — Seminar Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 1-4 Description: Topics of mutual interest to a faculty member and a group of students. Offered as announced by department bulletin or the Timetable. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: ECE 493 — Special Problems Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 1-5 Description: Special problems or reading by special arrangement with the faculty. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: No graduation credit for students in the following: MS in Electrical and Computer Engineering or PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

Course: ECE 496 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis I Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-8 Description: Introduction to engineering design and research methods: design tools, product conception and development, simulation, prototyping, technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit for ECE 496 only given to non-degree students. No graduation credit is given for ECE 496 to students enrolled in any degree program in Engineering. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ECE 497 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis II Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0-8 Description: Introduction to engineering design and research methods: design tools, product conception and development, simulation, prototyping, technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit only given to non-degree students. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in Engineering. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ECE 499 — Professional Development Seminar Subject: Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Credits: 0 Description: Graduating seniors will be provided with information regarding future career paths and will provide information regarding the program to be used for assessment purposes. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors; and approval of the department. Must be taken in the student's last semester of study. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: ECON 106 — Tobacconomics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: A comprehensive, multidisciplinary overview of tobacco use and its consequences, tobacco control, and related issues, from both a US and global perspective. Course Information: Previously listed as ECON 115. Individual and Society course, and Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: ECON 111 — Freakonomics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to how economists think about problems; how economic analysis illuminates current events and puzzles by focusing on people's responses to incentives. Individual and Society course.

Course: ECON 120 — Principles of Microeconomics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 0-4 Description: Scarcity and choice, price system, decision making by consumers, individual and market demand, optimal input decisions by firms, perfect and imperfect competition, international trade. Course Information: College of Business Administration undergraduate students will enroll for 3 hours and all other students will enroll for 4 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: ECON 121 — Principles of Macroeconomics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 0-4 Description: Determinants of the level of economic activity, inflation, unemployment, interest rates, the roles of fiscal and monetary policies, exchange rates, international trade. Course Information: College of Business Administration undergraduate students will enroll for 3 hours and all other students will enroll for 4 hours. ECON 121 may be taken before or after taking ECON 120 - this is not a sequence. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: ECON 212 — Law and Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Economic analysis of law and legal processes; economic theory and applications of property law, contract law, and criminal law. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: Previously listed as ECON 320.

Course: ECON 213 — Economic History of the United States Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Growth and structural changes in the American economy from colonial times to the present; special emphasis on economic causes and consequences of major events in U.S. history. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: Previously listed at ECON 324.

metadata.class_name: Economic History of the United States
metadata.subject: Economics (ECON)
