text: Course: ECON 214 — Economics of Education Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Examines education issues: test score accountability, charter schools, school spending, educator compensation, teacher certification, college costs, and financial aid, using basic economic tools. Focuses on elementary and secondary education. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: Previously listed as ECON 351.

Course: ECON 215 — Health Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Supply and demand for health services, the role of insurance in the health care industry, public policy issues, cost and quality regulation. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: Previously listed as ECON 354.

Course: ECON 216 — Economics of Sports and Entertainment Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of economic issues in the sports and entertainment industries--industrial organization, financing, pricing, labor, and regulatory issues. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: Previously listed as ECON 350.

Course: ECON 220 — Microeconomics: Theory and Applications Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: The price system, consumer behavior, market demand, the firm's technology and costs, perfect and imperfect competition, government regulation, general equilibrium and resource allocation, applications. Prerequisites: ECON 120 ; and MATH 121.

Course: ECON 221 — Macroeconomics in the World Economy: Theory and Applications Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Determinants of the level of economic activity, inflation, unemployment, international economics, impact of domestic and world economy on business decisions, applications of the theory. Prerequisites: ECON 120 and ECON 121 ; and MATH 121. Course Information: Same as INST 221.

metadata.class_name: Macroeconomics in the World Economy: Theory and Applications
metadata.subject: Economics (ECON)

text: Course: ECON 270 — Statistics for Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the application of statistical concepts to economic data. Topics covered include descriptive statistics, probability theory, discrete and continuous probability distributions, sampling distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing. Prerequisites: MATH 121. Course Information: Credit is not given for ECON 270 if the student has credit for IDS 270. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: ECON 300 — Econometrics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Casual estimation of economic relationships and testing of economic hypotheses; ordinary least squares regression and extensions; evaluating empirical research; specification of econometric models. Prerequisites: ECON 120 or ECON 121 ; and ECON 270 , or IDS 270 , or STAT 101 ; and MATH 121. Course Information: Credit is not given for ECON 300 if the student has credit in ECON 400. Previously listed as ECON 346.

Course: ECON 311 — Introduction to Urban Real Estate Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of urban real estate; business, legal, economic and financial perspectives. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: Previously listed as ECON 371.

Course: ECON 322 — Managerial Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Application of economic theory to decision making by business firms; demand and cost analysis, demand forecasts; pricing policies; capital budgeting; production analysis; globalization, multinational corporations, game theory, and market structures. Prerequisites: ECON 220 ; and IDS 270 or ECON 270.

Course: ECON 323 — Business Conditions Analysis Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Application of economic theory to analysis of changes in aggregate income and employment; quantitative economic models and their uses in the prediction of aggregate and more refined levels of business activity; stabilization theory and policy. Prerequisites: ECON 221 ;and ECON 300 or ECON 400 or IDS 371.

Course: ECON 326 — History of Economic Thought Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the evolution of positive and normative economics from the seventeenth century to the present. Prerequisites: ECON 220 or ECON 221.

Course: ECON 328 — Public Finance Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: The economic effects of taxes and government expenditures on the allocation of resources and income distribution, public goods and externalities, public choice, the principles and application of cost-benefit analysis; optimal taxation. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 329 — Industrial Organization Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Non-cooperative game theory used to analyze the strategic behavior and interaction of firms in imperfectly competitive markets. Topics include pricing strategies of monopolists and oligopolists, price discrimination, durable goods pricing, etc. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 330 — Government and Business Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and survey of U.S. market structure; antitrust policy and monopoly power; economic regulation including price and quality regulation; social regulation. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 331 — Labor Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Application of economic theory to labor markets and related economic phenomena; earnings, employment, unemployment, immigration, education, minimum wages, discrimination. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 332 — Urban Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of economic problems of cities; demand for and supply of housing and urban land; residential segregation; suburbanization; impact of government programs. Focus on relationship between city and suburbs, and special attention paid to Chicago. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 333 — International Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Operation of the international economy. Covers the theory and practice of international trade and international macroeconomics. Topics include exchange rates, the balance of payments, and operation of fiscal and monetary policy. Prerequisites: ECON 220 or ECON 221 or INST 221. Course Information: Same as INST 333.

Course: ECON 334 — Economic Development Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Uses economic tools to investigate the prevalence, causes and consequences of global poverty. Study the range of market failures that contribute to the persistence of poverty. Prerequisites: ECON 220 or ECON 221 or INST 221. Course Information: Same as INST 334.

Course: ECON 339 — Monetary Theory Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Modern money supply and demand theory; the role of money in domestic and international financial markets and in determining economic growth and inflation. Prerequisites: ECON 221 or FIN 300.

Course: ECON 342 — Regional Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Location of economic activity, systems of cities, economic base theory, regional input-output analysis, neo-classical models of factor mobility and local area economic development. Prerequisites: ECON 220 or ECON 221 or INST 221.

Course: ECON 344 — Behavioral Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Studies deviations from the standard neoclassical model in terms of preferences, beliefs, learning, decision-making, and market reactions to such deviations. Analyze assumptions behind the standard economic models. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 350 — Economics of Sports and Entertainment Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of economic issues in the sports and entertainment industries--industrial organization, financing, pricing, labor, and regulatory issues. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 353 — Economic Demography Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of family decision making focusing on the economics of time allocation, marriage, divorce, fertility, and mortality; relationship between population growth and economic development. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 370 — Environmental Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of major environmental problems as market and policy failures. Benefit-cost methods evaluated. Equity and efficiency aspects of market-based approaches to environmental policy evaluated. Prerequisites: ECON 220.

Course: ECON 390 — Special Topics in Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of an area not covered in existing course offerings, or study in greater depth of a subject covered in an existing course. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

Course: ECON 395 — Research and Writing in Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 1 Description: This course is used to identify the "Writing in the Disciplines" requirement. Development of analytical and writing skills in economics. Prerequisites: Concurrent registration in a designated 300-level economics course. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ECON 399 — Independent Study in Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent study in an area not covered by existing courses or exploration in greater depth of issues covered in a previously taken course. Prerequisites: 9 hours of economics courses at the 300-level or above, an overall GPA of at least 3.25 (A=4.00), and consent of a faculty member and the director of undergraduate studies. Course Information: May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the LAS degree and the major.

Course: ECON 400 — Honors Econometrics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Data-driven analysis of economic relationships using real-world datasets to estimate parameters, test hypotheses, and employ modern causal inference methods. Topics such as ordinary least squares regression, large and complex datasets. Prerequisites: ECON 120 or ECON 121 ; and MATH 180 ; and ECON 270 or IDS 270 or STAT 381. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECON 436 — Mathematical Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Application of mathematics to theories of consumer and producer behavior, determination of prices in markets, growth and stability features of macroeconomic models. Prerequisites: ECON 220 ; and MATH 180 or MATH 165. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECON 450 — Business Forecasting Using Time Series Methods Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Autoregressive, moving average, and seasonal models for time series analysis and business forecasting. Forecasting using multi-variable transfer function models. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or ECON 300 or ECON 400 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IDS 476. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Business Forecasting Using Time Series Methods
metadata.subject: Economics (ECON)

text: Course: ECON 453 — Economics of Family Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Microeconomic analysis of families’ economic decisions such as marriage, fertility, labor supplies, and consumption. Modern econometric methods will be covered to understand recent literature on the topic. Prerequisites: ECON 220 ; and ECON 300 or ECON 400. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: ECON 331 and ECON 353.

Course: ECON 473 — Game Theory Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the basic ideas of game theory. Static and dynamic games; mixed strategies, imperfect information; economic, political and biological applications. Prerequisites: STAT 381 ; or ECON 270 ; or equivalents. Course Information: Same as STAT 473. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ECON 475 — Urban Economics and Public Policy Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Microeconomic analysis of individual and firm location choices and outcomes in urban settings. Modern econometric methods to test theories and evaluate policy interventions. Prerequisites: ECON 220 ; or ECON 300 or ECON 400 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ECON 328 and ECON 331 and ECON 332.
Course: ECON 481 — Mathematical Methods for Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 4 Description: Survey of mathematical techniques used in applied economics theory and econometrics courses.

Course: ECON 482 — Probability and Statistics for Econometrics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to methods in probability and statistics that provide a foundation for the applied econometrics and research design courses.

Course: ECON 499 — Independent Study in Economics Subject: Economics (ECON) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent study of a topic not covered in a graduate-level course. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the director of graduate studies and the instructor.

Course: ED 100 — Introduction to Urban Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory and cross-disciplinary examination of issues related to education in urban America, with particular attention paid to policies and practices impacting diversity and equity in public schools. Course Information: Students need College approval to concurrently enroll in ED 100 and ED 205. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: ED 101 — Critical Literacies in a Digital Democracy Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Digital consumption, creation, and collaboration have significant impacts on participation in democratic processes. In this class we will learn about and engage in digital literacy practices including critical analysis and multimedia composing. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Critical Literacies in a Digital Democracy
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 131 — Educational Ethics Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: A practical, case-based introduction to ethical issues that arise in the daily life of classroom teachers, and techniques and strategies for thinking well about them. Of particular interest to students in teacher training programs, but open to all. Course Information: Same as PHIL 131. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: ED 135 — Child and Youth Policies in Urban America Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Examines policies and practices for children and youth in urban America using historical, sociological, psychological and economic frameworks. Integrates disciplinary knowledge of educational policies and practices. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Child and Youth Policies in Urban America
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 151 — College Connection I Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1 Description: Strategies to facilitate the transition from high school to college by helping students develop skills with faculty and staff guidance, to utilize resources that will lead to success in college, specific to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education program. Prerequisites: Open only to first year students admitted to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Should be taken in the first semester of the freshman year.

Course: ED 152 — College Connection II Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1 Description: A continuation of ED 151 College Connection I which facilitates the transition from high school to college by helping students develop specific skills and utilize resources that will help lead to success in college. Prerequisites: College approval required. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Should be taken in the second semester of the first-year.

Course: ED 160 — Games, Learning, and Society Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the development and design of games for teaching and learning. Critical analysis of games and how they shape interactions among players, their learning, and their connection to society. Course Information: Same as EPSY 160. Individual and Society course.

Course: ED 194 — Special Topics in Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1-4 Description: Introductory exploration of a topic not covered in existing course offerings. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ED 199 — Study Abroad Seminar: College Success and Leadership in a Global Context Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Combines a study abroad experience and seminar with a focus on globalization and experiential learning to support students in their transition to collegiate academic life. Prerequisites: Approval of the department and completion of application from the Study Abroad Office; and completion of interview.

metadata.class_name: Study Abroad Seminar: College Success and Leadership in a Global Context
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 200 — Education Policy Foundations Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Social, cultural, political, and intellectual forces that influence and shape educational policy in the learning process. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing. US Society course.

Course: ED 201 — Children’s Literature and Disabilities Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of children’s and young adult literature focused on how disabilities are portrayed and how literature encapsulates societal attitudes, beliefs, and stereotypes contributing to access and equity of children with disabilities in schools. Course Information: Same as SPED 201. This is a blended course. Creative Arts course.

Course: ED 202 — International Perspectives: Inclusive Education and Schooling Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on international comparative views of how different educational systems include students with disabilities. Course Information: Same as SPED 202. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: International Perspectives: Inclusive Education and Schooling
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 205 — Introduction to Race, Ethnicity, and Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory and cross-disciplinary examination of issues related to race, ethnicity, and cultural diversity in education. Course Information: Students need College approval to concurrently enroll in ED 100 and ED 205. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Race, Ethnicity, and Education
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 210 — Principles of Learning and Instruction Across the Lifespan Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: How people learn and the design of instruction and assessment across a broad set of formal and informal instructional environments and populations. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Secondary Teacher Education students should enroll in the ED 210 section. All other students should enroll in the EPSY 210 section. Course Information: Same as EPSY 210.

metadata.class_name: Principles of Learning and Instruction Across the Lifespan
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 211 — Special Topics in Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1 Description: Topics vary. Prerequisites: Membership in the Honors College or approval of the College of Education. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the college.

Course: ED 217 — STEM, Education, and Society: Exploring Identity, Community, Ethics, Politics, and Ideology Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: A focus on political, economic, social, and environmental implications of STEM education. Cross-disciplinary examination of math, sciences, engineering, and related disciplines, with attention to identity, experience, and social disparities. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: STEM, Education, and Society: Exploring Identity, Community, Ethics, Politics, and Ideology
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 222 — Introduction to Gender, Sexuality, and Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory and cross-disciplinary examination of issues related to gender and sexuality in education. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Gender, Sexuality, and Education
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 252 — Contemporary Controversies in U.S. Schools Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory and cross-disciplinary examination of contemporary controversies related to public education in the United States. US Society course.

Course: ED 253 — Current Debates in Higher Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory and cross-disciplinary examination of current debates related to higher education in the United States. US Society course.

Course: ED 258 — Language Development and Learning in a Diverse Society Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an overview of the key issues and concepts related to the study of language development, learning, and multilingualism in a diverse society. Prerequisites: Completion of the English composition requirement. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Language Development and Learning in a Diverse Society
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 264 — Sport, Education, and Society Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Students will explore how sport has shaped society and effects social change; paying particular attention to issues of access and equity, focusing on how sport influences human, social, and community development, as well as societal values and priorities. Recommended Background: : EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 or SOC 100. Individual and Society course.

Course: ED 294 — Special Topics in Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1-4 Description: Introductory exploration of a topic not covered in existing course offerings. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ED 299 — Education, Globalization, and the Child Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the experiences of childhood and how educational experiences are often contextualized by region, country, and culture. Students will have an embedded study abroad experience in order to do a comparative analysis. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department and GPA of 2.7 or above and good standing; and completion of application from the Study Abroad Office; and completion of interview. Course Information: Expectation to go abroad.

Course: ED 307 — Nature and Practices of Natural Sciences Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Learning crosscutting concepts and practices across science and engineering, applying practices in designing, conducting, and presenting a scientific research project, and considering teaching implications for elementary and middle grades students. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Nature and Practices of Natural Sciences
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 316 — Teacher Development I: Curating Teacher Agency in Urban Education Contexts Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Foundational examination and analysis of urban schools as sites of systemic inequities and rich learning opportunities. Development of professional and pedagogical frameworks for emerging teachers through theory and practice. Prerequisites: ED 100 and ED 205 ; or consent of the instructor Admission to the Bachelor of Arts, Concentration in Elementary Education. Corequisites: ED 350. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Teacher Development I: Curating Teacher Agency in Urban Education Contexts
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 317 — Teacher Development II: Curating Teacher Identity in Urban Classrooms Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Foundational development of teacher identity through dispositional assessment, pedagogical practices that sustain and cultivate culture in classrooms, and design and creation of vibrant and inclusive learning communities. Prerequisites: ED 100 and ED 316 and ED 350 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Corequisites: ED 351. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Teacher Development II: Curating Teacher Identity in Urban Classrooms
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 350 — Foundations of Professional Practice in Comparative Contexts: Fieldwork I Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: First course in a 4-course sequence that provides urban fieldwork experience across multiple school contexts. Students develop their pedagogical practice and make connections across university coursework and elementary school classrooms. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor; and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education, Concentration in Elementary Education. Corequisites: ED 316. Course Information: Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Foundations of Professional Practice in Comparative Contexts: Fieldwork I
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 351 — Foundations of Professional Practice in Urban Classrooms: Fieldwork II Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Fieldwork experience in this course continues teacher candidates’ clinical practice in urban classrooms. Provides teacher candidates with mentoring opportunities in which to develop their pedagogical practices. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor; and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education, Concentration in Elementary Education. Corequisites: ED 317. Course Information: Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Foundations of Professional Practice in Urban Classrooms: Fieldwork II
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 360 — Education and Community Transformation Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 4 Description: Enables students to understand how community activism contributes to change in the sociopolitical landscape in the United States and abroad with particular attention to education policies and social justice issues. Course Information: 4 hrs. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Recommended Background: ED 100 , ED 135 or ED 205.

Course: ED 373 — Introduction to the School-Prison Nexus Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Using contemporary social theory, this course investigates the disciplining, punishing, and criminalization of youth in urban schools, paying particular attention to the racialized, classed, gendered, and ableist contours of these social processes. Course Information: Same as CLJ 373. Recommended Background: ED 100 and ED 200 and ED 205.

Course: ED 374 — Dismantling the School and Prison Nexus Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Political relationship between historically dis-invested K to 12 schools and prisons. Parallels in disciplinary practices and rationales in both. Engagement with affected communities that challenge carceral logics in education. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 and two 200-level CLJ courses; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CLJ 374. Recommended Background: CLJ 373.

metadata.class_name: Dismantling the School and Prison Nexus
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 375 — Perspectives on Health Disparities/Pathways to Careers in the Health Professions Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses health inequities, cultural competence, and opportunities/pathways to traditional and paraprofessional careers in health care. Implications of health inequities for educational outcomes are also covered. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 or the equivalent and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Participation in an interdisciplinary case study project. Recommended Background: Sophomore or Junior standing; and participation in the Urban Health Program Learning Community.

metadata.class_name: Perspectives on Health Disparities/Pathways to Careers in the Health Professions
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 394 — Special Topics in Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1-4 Description: Exploration of a topic not covered in existing course offerings. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ED 396 — Independent Study Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1-4 Description: For students who wish to do independent study on specific educational processes or independently to carry on projects related to education or extensive reading assignments. Prerequisites: A written proposal for faculty approval and junior standing. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

Course: ED 398 — Directed Research in Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1-4 Description: Students carry out directed research under the mentorship of a College of Education faculty member. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours.

Course: ED 402 — Philosophy of Education and Urban School Policy Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Selected social and education philosophies and their impact on urban school curriculum design, school organization and control.

metadata.class_name: Philosophy of Education and Urban School Policy
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 403 — Policy Issues in the History of American Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Political, economic, and cultural influences shaping the development of American education policy; emphasis on issues of education theory and practice in their historical settings.

metadata.class_name: Policy Issues in the History of American Education
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 410 — Capstone Inquiry on Critical Issues in Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Students design and complete projects connected to an educational issue, challenge, or theme. Includes discussion of critical educational issues from cross-disciplinary perspectives. Designed to be a culminating experience. Prerequisites: Prior College of Education coursework and consent of instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Capstone Inquiry on Critical Issues in Education
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 416 — Practical Inquiry I: Teacher Competencies and Performance-Based Assessment Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to examining teaching through practitioner inquiry, including teacher performance assessment, as a way of learning to teach and beginning a lifelong process of professional development.

metadata.class_name: Practical Inquiry I: Teacher Competencies and Performance-Based Assessment
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 417 — Practical Inquiry II: Teacher Competencies and Performance-Based Assessment Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: A developing examination of teaching through practitioner inquiry, including teacher performance teacher assessment, as a way of learning to teach and fostering a lifelong process of professional development.

metadata.class_name: Practical Inquiry II: Teacher Competencies and Performance-Based Assessment
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 421 — Advanced Educational Psychology Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Examines current theory and research on the teaching-learning process with particular attention to general learning and curriculum-relevant problem solving skills. Prerequisites: EPSY 210 ; or graduate standing.

Course: ED 422 — Advanced Developmental Psychology and Educational Processes Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on cognitive and social development from birth to early adolescence. Examines relations between development, learning, and educational processes. Prerequisites: PSCH 100 and any one from EPSY 210 , PSCH 259, PSCH 320 and consent of the instructor; or graduate standing. Course Information: Same as PSCH 422.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Developmental Psychology and Educational Processes
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 424 — Social and Emotional Learning: Research, Practice, and Policy Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Research, theory, educational practices, and federal/state policies that promote the social, emotional, and academic competence of students who are in preschool, middle school, or high school. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 or equivalent; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PSCH 424. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Experience working with children or adolescents.

metadata.class_name: Social and Emotional Learning: Research, Practice, and Policy
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 425 — Curriculum, Instruction, and Assessment in the Urban Secondary Classroom Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 4 Description: Developing professional practice that meets the diverse learning needs of students from different backgrounds and experiences. Prerequisites: Admission to an approved teacher licensure program in secondary education, and ED 200 , ED 210 and SPED 410 , and consent of the instructor and Council of Teacher Education. Course Information: Previously listed as ED 330. Field experience in urban schools is required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Curriculum, Instruction, and Assessment in the Urban Secondary Classroom
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 430 — Curriculum and Teaching Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to curriculum and teaching as areas of inquiry; implications of these areas of inquiry for educational practice; related contemporary problems and issues. Prerequisites: Admission to graduate study in Education, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for ED 430 if the student has credit for CI 428.

Course: ED 431 — Improving Learning Environments Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of structural, normative, and social dimensions of learning environments and their relationships to student learning. Exploration of change processes to improve those environments. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor.

Course: ED 432 — Instruction and Assessment in the Urban Secondary Classroom Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 5 Description: Learning to teach, how to plan for diverse learners, design differentiated instruction, assess student learning and develop classroom discipline. Prerequisites: Completion of education core courses in Graduate Teacher Certification Program: ED 402 or ED 403 and ED 445. Course Information: Field experience in urban schools is required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Instruction and Assessment in the Urban Secondary Classroom
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 445 — Adolescence and the Schools Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Physiological, intellectual, and social development of adolescence. Relations between aspects of adolescent development and the academic and social demands of secondary schools. Prerequisites: EPSY 210 , or the equivalent, or graduate standing.

Course: ED 450 — Pre-Student Teaching in the Urban Elementary Classroom, Fieldwork III: Arts, Health, and Physical Ed Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 1-12 Description: This pre-student teaching experience immerses teacher candidates in classrooms in a supervised experience of learning to teach; and develop effective practices with an emphasis in arts, health and physical education. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education, Concentration in Elementary Education. Course Information: May be repeated. Field work required. Field work: total of 180 hours, coordinated by the program director and in collaboration with field instructors.

metadata.class_name: Pre-Student Teaching in the Urban Elementary Classroom, Fieldwork III: Arts, Health, and Physical Ed
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 451 — Student Teaching in the Urban Elementary Classroom: Fieldwork IV Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 0-12 Description: Student teaching is a full-time experience of learning to teach in a classroom with university mentoring and supervision. Prerequisites: ED 450 and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education, Concentration in Elementary Education and senior standing. Course Information: May be repeated. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Student Teaching in the Urban Elementary Classroom: Fieldwork IV
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 461 — Political and Socio-Cultural Perspectives on Special Education Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Students will examine issues of access and equity through legislation, litigation, and socio-cultural perspectives and be introduced to major theoretical frameworks that influence special education programs. Course Information: Same as SPED 461. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Political and Socio-Cultural Perspectives on Special Education
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 470 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 0-12 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the college or department of specialization. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the college. 1 to 12 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: ED 471 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 0-12 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, credit or concurrent registration in ED 470 , and approval of the college or department of specialization. Credit or concurrent registration in ED 470 , and approval of the college or department of specialization Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ED 470 , and approval of the college or department of specialization Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the college. 1 to 12 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): ED 470 Coreq Codes (parsed): ED 470

Course: ED 472 — Promoting Academic and Prosocial Behavior I Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: The importance of school-wide and classroom structure and climate in the educational process. Strategies to promote academic success and desired social behavior. Prerequisites: SPED 461 or ED 461 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as SPED 472. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Promoting Academic and Prosocial Behavior I
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 473 — Teaching Math and Science with Adaptations Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 3 Description: Provides prospective teachers with assessment strategies and a range of adaptations, modifications, and interventions in math and science for students with disabilities. Prerequisites: SPED 461. Course Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Math and Science with Adaptations
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: ED 499 — Critical Perspectives on Language Policy and the Construction of Ability in Schools Subject: Education (ED) Credits: 4 Description: Focuses on the role of cultural, historical, and political contexts in shaping language politics regulating school and their implications for notions of competence. Students will do data collection in a study abroad site. Recommended Background: Conversational Spanish.

metadata.class_name: Critical Perspectives on Language Policy and the Construction of Ability in Schools
metadata.subject: Education (ED)

text: Course: EDPS 104 — Race, Place, and Schooling: Black Americans and Education Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the social, political, cultural, and economic factors shaping Black Americans' educational experiences in the United States historically and currently. Course Information: Same as BLST 104. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Race, Place, and Schooling: Black Americans and Education
metadata.subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS)

text: Course: EDPS 361 — Education in Urban Context Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 3 Description: Cross-disciplinary, critical analysis of relationships between public schools and their urban contexts, with attention to implications for teaching and learning. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in elementary Education program.

Course: EDPS 412 — Politics of Urban Education Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Relations between school governance and politics. The role of educational interest groups, school boards, professional educators, and citizens in formulation and execution of educational policy. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: EDPS 415 — Current Controversies in Urban Higher Education Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines critical issues in urban higher education such as academic freedom, free speech, college affordability, alcohol/drugs, and student mental health, as well as the legal consequences of these and other issues. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Current Controversies in Urban Higher Education
metadata.subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS)

text: Course: EDPS 449 — Early Childhood /Early Childhood Special Ed: Perspectives, Policies and History Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 3 Description: Perspectives, policies, history, and foundations of Early Childhood Education and Early Childhood Special Education. Emphasis on the effects of changing economic, political, legal, social, and views of human development. Course Information: Same as EPSY 449 and SPED 449.

metadata.class_name: Early Childhood /Early Childhood Special Ed: Perspectives, Policies and History
metadata.subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS)

text: Course: EDPS 453 — Topics in Educational Policy Studies Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics are announced at the time the class is scheduled. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours.

Course: EDPS 470 — Collective Bargaining Practice and Policy in K-12 and Higher Education Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduces students to the major issues surrounding collective bargaining practice and policy in K-12 and higher education in Chicago, Illinois, and the U.S. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; and consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Collective Bargaining Practice and Policy in K-12 and Higher Education
metadata.subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS)

text: Course: EDPS 480 — Youth Culture Community Organizing and Education Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the tenets of community organizing in partnership with contemporary interpretations of youth culture as a means to interpret urban public education. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Experience with working with youth in K-12 classrooms, community organizations, community centers, and faith-based groups.

metadata.class_name: Youth Culture Community Organizing and Education
metadata.subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS)

text: Course: EDPS 488 — Education and Social Movements Subject: Educational Policy Studies (EDPS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Focuses on relationships between education and social movements in US and internationally. Examines centrality of education in social justice movements, social movements as public pedagogy, and public education as a focus of social justice movements. Prerequisites: Consent of instructor for advanced undergraduates. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Coursework in one or more of the following: Sociology, Urban Studies, Black Studies, Gender and Women’s Studies, Ethnic Studies, Latinx and Latin American Studies, Critical Theory, Social Foundations of Education.

Course: ELSI 010 — Reading/Writing Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 10 Description: Develops reading, writing, vocabulary, and grammar skills as well as cultural awareness and preparation for the U.S. academic environment through activities appropriate to the student’s level. Corequisites: One of the following as assigned through placement testing: ELSI 021 , ELSI 022 , ELSI 023 , ELSI 024 , ELSI 025. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Previously listed as CC 060. Taught in English.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 011 — Reading/Writing 1, Intensive English for High-Beginning Non-Native Speakers Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 10 Description: Development of reading, writing, vocabulary, and grammar skills in English as well as cultural awareness and preparation for the U.S. academic environment. For students at a high beginning language proficiency level. Prerequisites: Appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Taught in English. Open only to non-native speakers of English. No graduation credit. Recommended Background: Students in this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological, semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at an A1+ CEFR level.

text: Course: ELSI 031 — Exploring Liberal Arts and Sciences Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 0-6 Description: Provides international students with an introduction to various fields within Liberal Arts and Sciences. The purpose of this course is to build a connection between the students, their field of study, and the respective department at UIC. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 032 — Exploring Business Administration Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 0-6 Description: Provides international students with an introduction to fields within Business Administration. Builds a connection between the students, their field of study, and the respective department at UIC. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 033 — Exploring Engineering Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 0-6 Description: Provides international students with an introduction to fields within engineering. The purpose of this course is to build a connection between the students, their field of study, and the respective department at UIC. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English.

The purpose of this course is to build a connection between the students, their field of study, and the respective department at UIC. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. metadata.class_name: Exploring Architecture, Design, and the Arts

text: Course: ELSI 041 — English for Academic Purposes I Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 10 Description: Introduces students to the knowledge and skills necessary to comprehend written and spoken academic English with a high degree of accuracy, and to speak and write accurately and fluently in various academic contexts. Prerequisites: ELSI 014 and 024 (formerly CC 050 and 060) or a 5.0 total on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS) test or equivalent score on other approved test. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as ASP 031. Features active and peer-learning activities to give students opportunities to practice and improve their existing skills in these areas. In addition, introduces students to a variety of relevant technologies, texts and contexts across disciplines with an express purpose of supporting them in becoming successful English-language users in their professional and personal lives. No graduation credit given. Recommended Background: Students in this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological. semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B1+/B2- CEFR Level.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 043 — English for Academic Purposes II Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 3 Description: In English for Academic Purposes II (EAP II) students will continue to hone their academic English language skills, particularly reading and writing, as they prepare for further university study. Prerequisites: ELSI 041 (formerly ASP 031) or a 5.5 total on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS) test or equivalent score on other approved test. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as ASP 032. Introduces students to necessary skills to effectively, accurately and fluently read and write in English with particular focus on academic purposes and contexts. Features active- and peer-learning activities so students may practice and improve existing skills in these areas. Also introduces students to variety of relevant technologies, texts and contexts across disciplines with an express purpose of supporting students in becoming successful English-language users in their professional and personal lives. No graduation credit given. Recommended Background: Students in this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological. semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B2 CEFR Level.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 044 — English for Academic Purposes II Lab Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1 Description: EAP II Lab is designed to provide reading and writing support to students taking ELSI 043. Students will make critical reading and writing connections, shape and communicate meaning, and to meet the demands of academic writing conventions. Corequisites: ELSI 043. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit given. Recommended Background: Students in this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological. semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B2 CEFR Level.

metadata.class_name: English for Academic Purposes II Lab
metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 045 — Reading for Academic Purposes Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 3 Description: Reading for Academic Purposes is a companion course for ELSI 043 English for Academic Purposes II that provides students with strategies and additional practice for improving various academic reading skills to aid comprehension and fluency. Corequisites: ELSI 043. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit given. Recommended Background: Students in this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological. semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B2 CEFR Level.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 047 — Live, Learn, Grow: Foundation Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1 Description: This foundation semester provides students with essential information and exposure to key services at a university. It also helps to familiarize students with their physical and cultural surroundings. Prerequisites: For UIC Global International Accelerator Program (IAP) students entering at the Extended Accelerator Program level. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as ASP 033. No graduation credit given.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 048 — Live, Learn, Grow: Bridge Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1 Description: Bridge semester of Live Learn Grow series focuses on exploring and developing personal qualities that foster student success in various interpersonal dynamics, analyzing career and life prospects, and further surveying campus and community services. Prerequisites: For UIC Global International Accelerator Program (IAP) students entering at the Academic Accelerator Program level and all students who completed ELSI 047 in the previous semester. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as ASP 034. No graduation credit given.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 049 — Live, Learn, Grow: Learning Track Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1 Description: In this third Learning Track term of the freshman orientation series, the focus will be on the continuation of the development of students’ future outlook by guiding their examination of education, career, and networking opportunities. Prerequisites: For UIC Global International Accelerator Program (IAP) students entering at the Academic Accelerator Program level and all students who completed ELSI 048 in the previous semester. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as ASP 035. No graduation credit given.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 061 — Introduction to Applied Linguistics Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Introduction to linguistic concepts including the nature of language, non-native language acquisition, intercultural communication, and the structure of English with a focus on how concepts apply to language teaching. Course Information: May be repeated. No graduation credit. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 062 — Language Teaching Methodologies Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Focuses on effective language instruction and assessment. Provides best practices for teaching languages including TESOL. Course Information: May be repeated. No graduation credit. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 069 — Practicum in Language Teaching Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Focuses on the experience of teaching a language with guidance from an experienced instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in term A and term B. No graduation credit. Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 070 — Pronunciation Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Teaches pronunciation and speech modification techniques such as sounds, stress, rhythm, intonation, and pitch to intermediate and advanced non-native speakers of English. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Recommended Background: Students entering this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological, semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B1+ CEFR level.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 071 — Test Preparation Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Prepares students for a specific standardized test. Test varies by course section. Students gain experience and confidence with the specific test, awareness of its specific characteristics, and learn specific techniques and skills needed for success. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Recommended Background: Students entering this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological, semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B1+ CEFR level.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 073 — Test Preparation: Reading and Listening Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Teaches test-taking strategies for the Reading and Listening sections of the standardized test of focus. Students receive feedback, working at their own pace reviewing presentations, studying vocabulary, and completing practice exercises and tests. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Taught on-line. Recommended Background: Students entering this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological, semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B1+ CEFR level.

metadata.subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI)

text: Course: ELSI 074 — Test Preparation: Writing Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Teaches test-taking strategies for the writing section of standardized tests. Students work at their own pace reviewing presentations, studying grammar, and completing practice tasks and tests, and receive feedback from instructors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Taught online. Recommended Background: Students entering this course are expected to have the syntactic, phonological, semantic, and rhetorical English language skills needed to function at a B1+ CEFR level.

text: Course: ELSI 075 — Test Preparation: Speaking Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Teaches test-taking strategies for the speaking section of standardized tests. Students work at their own pace reviewing presentations, listening to sample responses, and completing practice tasks and tests, and receive feedback from instructors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Taught online. text: Course: ELSI 076 — Grammar for Clear Writing Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Focuses on producing clear, error-free paragraphs. Guides participants through a review of key grammar structures, writing sample analysis, and development of effective self-editing techniques. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Taught online. text: Course: ELSI 077 — Developing Effective Writing Subject: English Language and Support for Internationals (ELSI) Credits: 1-6 Description: Focuses on concise, clear academic or professional writing. Teaches techniques for implementing the writing process from crafting paragraphs to writing strong longer texts. Includes instruction on cohesiveness and clarity in writing. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Taught online. Participants learn strategies for effective communication and techniques for improving pronunciation. Prerequisites: ELSI 024 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or approval of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. No graduation credit. Open only to non-native speakers of English. Non-native English speakers interested in this course should contact the Tutorium in Intensive English at tutorium@uic.edu. Participants learn strategies to present, support and defend viewpoints as well as techniques to engage in discussions and answer discussion questions. Students also increase their ability to follow advanced academic lectures and professional speeches. Prerequisites: ELSI 024 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or approval of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Organizational patterns, types of development, methods of audience interaction, and appropriate use of visual aids are addressed and practiced. text: Course: ENGL 060 — English as a Second Language Composition II Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 4 Description: Basic writing for ESL students. Students write in a variety of genres with an emphasis on argument and sentence-level grammar. Topics vary by section. Prerequisites: Open only to freshmen and sophomores. Eligibility as determined by performance on the Department placement test. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Previously listed as ESL 060. This class may be taught in a blended an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Please check the online class schedule for blended-online sections.

metadata.class_name: English as a Second Language Composition II
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 101 — Understanding Literature and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Reading and analysis of texts from a variety of literary forms and periods that reflect key developments in history and culture. Special attention to methods for determining literary meaning and how texts reveal the complexities of cultural activity. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 103 — Understanding Poetry Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A representative selection of poetry from a variety of periods and forms. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 104 — Understanding Drama Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Examination and analysis of the form and content of works of drama based upon representative selections from a variety of periods. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 105 — Understanding Fiction Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Reading and analysis of representative selections from a variety of periods and forms in fiction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 118 — Introduction to African American Literature, 1760-1910 Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Comprehensive survey, 1760-1910, from earliest folk roots to formal literary tradition. Course Information: Same as BLST 110. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: ENGL 119 — Introduction to African American Literature Since 1910 Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Comprehensive survey of African American literature from 1910 to the present. Course Information: Same as BLST 111. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to African American Literature Since 1910
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 123 — Introduction to Asian American Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of a wide range of Asian American literature in various socio-historical contexts. Course Information: Same as GLAS 123. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: ENGL 131 — Understanding Moving Image Arts Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Examination and interpretation of moving image texts such as film, television, and new digital media. Course Information: Same as MOVI 131. Previously listed as ENGL 121. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 132 — Understanding Film Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Representative selections of film, from a variety of periods and forms. Development of analytical and interpretive skills in understanding film. Course Information: Same as MOVI 132. Previously listed as ENGL 102. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 135 — Understanding Popular Genres and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to pulp fiction, young adult fiction, graphic novels and comic books, speculative fiction, film, television, and other popular discourses. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 110. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: ENGL 150 — Introduction to Academic Writing for Nonnative Speakers of English Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Preparatory class for nonnative speakers of English. Students write in a variety of genres with an emphasis on argument and sentence-level grammar. Topics vary by section. Prerequisites: Grade of D or better in ENGL 060 or Eligibility as determined by performance on the Department placement test. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 070. Extensive computer use required. Eligibility as determined by performance on the Department placement test. This class may be taught in an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Please check the online class schedule for online sections. Based on final course assessment, the English Department may recommend a waiver of ENGL 160 , allowing students to move directly into ENGL 161.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Academic Writing for Nonnative Speakers of English
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 151 — Introduction to Academic Writing Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Preparatory writing course in different genres with a focus on argument, sentence-level grammar and rhetorical effectiveness. Prerequisites: Eligibility determined by performance on the Department placement test. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 071. Extensive computer use required. Eligibility as determined by performance on the Department placement test. This class may be taught in an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Please check the online class schedule for online sections. Based on final course assessment, the English Department may recommend a waiver of ENGL 160 , allowing students to move directly into ENGL 161.

Course: ENGL 153 — Understanding Grammar and Style Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to basic grammatical structures and semantics of English and general strategies for effective written communication. A focus on interrelationships, how aesthetic choices shape meaning, how grammatical techniques create semantic and stylistic effects. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 158.

Course: ENGL 154 — Understanding Rhetoric Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: An introductory examination of rhetoric as an intellectual force shaping discourse in both academic and public domains. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 122. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: ENGL 159 — Academic Writing Workshop Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 1 Description: Critical reading and writing genres with an emphasis on argument and sentence-level grammar. Topics/Genres vary by section. Prerequisites: Placement into ENGL 071 and Consent of the Director First-Year Writing Program. Corequisites: Students must enroll concurrently in ENGL 160 in their first semester and continue in ENGL 160 throughout the semester. Restricted to Fall semester freshmen. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This class may be taught in an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Please check the online class schedule for online sections.

Course: ENGL 160 — Academic Writing I: Writing in Academic and Public Contexts Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Students write in a variety of genres with an emphasis on argument and sentence-level grammar. Topics vary by section. Prerequisites: Eligibility as determined by performance on the Department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This class may be taught in an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Please check the online class schedule for online sections. Class Schedule Information: Course descriptions for composition courses are available at the First-Year Writing Program website: http://www.uic.edu/depts/engl/programs/1styearwriting/.

metadata.class_name: Academic Writing I: Writing in Academic and Public Contexts
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 161 — Academic Writing II: Writing for Inquiry and Research Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Students learn about academic inquiry and complete several writing projects including a documented research paper. Topics vary by section. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or the equivalent. All students take the Writing Placement test except for those with test-based exemptions noted here. If students place into ENGL 060 , ENGL 070, ENGL 071, and ENGL 160 , the student must take the course (or courses) prior to enrolling in ENGL 161. Students with an ACT English subscore of 27 or higher, SAT Evidence-Based Critical Reading score of 630 or higher, AP English Language & Composition score of 3 or higher, or IB English Language A: Language & Literature score of 6 or higher, receive credit for ENGL 160 and permission to enroll in ENGL 161. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This class may be taught in an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: Students may register for any section. Course descriptions for composition courses are available at the First-Year Writing Program website: http://www.uic.edu/depts/engl/programs/1styearwriting/.

metadata.class_name: Academic Writing II: Writing for Inquiry and Research
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 175 — Understanding the Bible as Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A broad overview of various literary genres in the Bible such as origin narrative, historical narrative, poetry, wisdom literature, prophetic/apocalyptic literature, parable, and epistle. Course Information: Same as RELS 175. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 198 — Field Research in Writing and Rhetoric Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 1-3 Description: Students apply the academic features of reading and writing texts to contexts outside the classroom through the design and execution of field-based research projects. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and admission to the Chicago Civic Leadership Certificate Program (CCLCP). Corequisites: Students must enroll concurrently in one of four required CCLCP courses, taken during the freshman and sophomore years. Contact program advisor for additional details. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Field work required. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

metadata.class_name: Field Research in Writing and Rhetoric
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 203 — The Science and Rhetorics of Climate Change Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Explores climate change as a physical and cultural phenomenon through the rhetorical analysis of texts, data, and primary research. Course Information: Same as EAES 203. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: The Science and Rhetorics of Climate Change
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 207 — Interpretation and Critical Analysis Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction on how to read, interpret, analyze and write critically about texts and other cultural productions--literary, theoretical, rhetorical, and/or critical. Course Information: Credit is not given for ENGL 207 if the student has credit in ENGL 240. Previously listed as ENGL 240. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course. Recommended Background: Completion of ENGL 161 and 3 hours from ENGL 101 -125.

Course: ENGL 208 — English Studies I: Beginnings to the 17th Century Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of significant works in the field of English studies, beginnings to the 17th century, their historical, cultural, aesthetic, and rhetorical dimensions, from a number of critical perspectives. Course Information: Credit is not given for ENGL 208 if the student has credit in ENGL 241. Previously listed as ENGL 241. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Recommended Background: Completion of ENGL 161 and 3 hours from ENGL 101 -125.

metadata.class_name: English Studies I: Beginnings to the 17th Century
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 209 — English Studies II: 17th Century to Today Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of significant works in the field of English studies, from the 17th century to today, their historical, cultural, aesthetic, and rhetorical dimensions, from a number of critical perspectives. Course Information: Credit is not given for ENGL 209 if the student has credit in ENGL 242 or ENGL 243. Previously listed as ENGL 242. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion. Creative Arts course. Recommended Background: Completion of ENGL 161 and 3 hours of ENGL 101 -125.

metadata.class_name: English Studies II: 17th Century to Today
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 213 — Introduction to Shakespeare Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of Shakespeare's major plays and poems. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 107. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and Past course.
