Course: ENGL 223 — Introduction to Colonial and Postcolonial Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the literature in English most directly representative of the historical processes of colonialism and decolonization that have shaped the modern world. Course Information: Previously listed ENGL 114. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Colonial and Postcolonial Literature
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 229 — Introduction to Asian Film Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A theoretical analysis of films by recognized masters of Asian cinema. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 229 and MOVI 229. Taught in English. Films contain English subtitles. One film per week will be screened outside of class. Students may choose to attend the official screenings or watch the films on their own.

Course: ENGL 230 — Introduction to Film and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of representative works that reflect the relationship between cinema and its cultural context. Course Information: Same as MOVI 230. Previously listed as ENGL 120. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: ENGL 232 — History of Film I: 1890 to World War II Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: History of film from its beginnings in the 1890s up to World War II. Course Information: Same as AH 232 and MOVI 232. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: ENGL 131 , 132 , or 230. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: History of Film I: 1890 to World War II
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 233 — History of Film II: World War II to the Present Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: History of film from World War II to contemporary movements in world cinema. Course Information: Same as AH 233 and MOVI 233. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: ENGL 131 or ENGL 132. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: History of Film II: World War II to the Present
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 234 — History of Television Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A critical history of television. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as COMM 234 and MOVI 234. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: ENGL 236 — Young Adult Fiction Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of young adult fiction and literature, from a range of periods and traditions. Content varies. Recommended Background: ENGL 101. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 237 — Graphic Novels Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the graphic novel; definition and variations in form and historical development related to the graphic novel. Recommended Background: ENGL 101. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 238 — Speculative Fiction, Sci-Fi and Fantasy Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of science fiction, utopian, and dystopian literature, from a range of periods and traditions. Content varies. Recommended Background: ENGL 101. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 243 — American Literature: Beginnings to 1900 Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of significant works of American literature, beginnings to 1900, their cultural, historical, and aesthetic dimensions, from a number of critical perspectives. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: Completion of ENGL 161 and 3 hours from ENGL 101 -125.

Course: ENGL 245 — Introduction to Gender, Sexuality and Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to literary texts in Western and other traditions that explore issues of gender and sexuality. Course Information: Same as GWS 245. Previously listed as ENGL 117. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Gender, Sexuality and Literature
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 247 — Women and Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to reading English, American, and global literature in English with a focus on gender, genre, and women's representation and authorship. Course Information: Same as GWS 247. Previously listed as ENGL 111. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: ENGL 251 — Literature and Environment Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Explores environmental issues in various literary genres. Content varies. Recommended Background: ENGL 101. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 253 — Environmental Rhetoric Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: The study of movements, activism, and public persuasion on environmental issues. Recommended Background: ENGL 154. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: ENGL 258 — The Grammar and Style of Non-Standard Englishes in the U.S Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A sociolinguistic and formal syntactical approach to the study of African-American and Appalachian English, Spanglish, and American Creole grammars. Students practice writing in English varieties beyond and including “Standard” Written English. Recommended Background: Fulfillment of the university writing requirement and ENGL158. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: The Grammar and Style of Non-Standard Englishes in the U.S
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 260 — Comparative Black Literatures Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Selected works of literature and criticism in the context of the U.S. and the Black diaspora. Comparative study of race, culture, and politics in literature. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or completion of the English composition requirement. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as BLST 250.

Course: ENGL 261 — Reading Black Women Writing Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Examines inscriptions of race, gender, class, and sexuality as they shape the literary and critical practices of black women writers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in a 100-level Black Studies or African American literature course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 261 and GWS 261.

Course: ENGL 262 — Black Cultural Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of approaches, methods, and key debates in the study of black culture in a transnational and diasporic context. Prerequisites: BLST 100. Creative Arts course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 262.

Course: ENGL 264 — Introduction to Native American Literatures Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the oral and written literatures of indigenous peoples of North America. Course Information: Same as NAST 264. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: ENGL 265 — The Harlem Renaissance Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: The intellectual, cultural, and artistic expressions among African Americans from 1912 to 1933, with an emphasis on the literary texts and social history. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in BLST 100 ; and Grade of C or better in BLST 110 or Grade of C or better in BLST 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 265.

Course: ENGL 266 — Topics in African Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Examination and analysis of selected works of African literature, history, and criticism. Topics will vary. Course Information: Same as BLST 266. May be repeated.

Course: ENGL 267 — Introduction to U.S. Latinx Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of a wide range of U.S. Latinx literature in various genres and various ethnic, geographical and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as LALS 267. Previously listed as ENGL 125. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Creative Arts course.

Course: ENGL 269 — Introduction to Multiethnic Literatures in the United States Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the literature of diverse racial and ethnic groups in the United States, including questions of representation, class, and difference in relation to realities, attitudes, and beliefs concerning dominant US/American culture. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 113. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Multiethnic Literatures in the United States
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 270 — The Sopranos Effect: Myth, Migration and the Italian-American Identity Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Immigrants’ identity formation and representation as seen through literature and visual media. Focus on Italian and Italian American transnational identities and narratives in their interactions with their socio-historical contexts. Course Information: Same as ITAL 270. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. No knowledge of Italian required. This course is offered in both face-to-face (16 weeks) and online asynchronous format (8 weeks). Online courses involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Recommended Background: Completion of the University Writing Requirement. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: The Sopranos Effect: Myth, Migration and the Italian-American Identity
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 280 — Media and Professional Writing Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Media analysis and writing, including interviews, news, features, and public relations communications. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 202. Recommended Background: ENGL 161.

Course: ENGL 282 — Peer Tutoring in the Writing Center: Introduction to Theory and Practice Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Through hands-on experience and assignments, students develop their ability to analyze writing, provide constructive feedback, facilitate writer-centered learning, adapt to diverse learning styles, and reflect critically on their tutoring practices. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Students meet once per week for class and schedule two hours per week to tutor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Conference.

metadata.class_name: Peer Tutoring in the Writing Center: Introduction to Theory and Practice
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 290 — Introduction to the Writing of Poetry Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Practice in writing poetry, beginning with exercises and analysis of published models and advancing toward student presentations of their original works of poetry in class. Workshop format. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 210. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Writing of Poetry
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 291 — Introduction to the Writing of Fiction Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Practice in the writing of fiction; emphasis on analysis of student work and published examples. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 212. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 or ENGL 208 or ENGL 209. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Writing of Fiction
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 292 — Introduction to the Writing of Nonfiction Prose Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory practice in writing personal essays, literary journalism, travel-writing, cultural criticism, or other forms of creative nonfiction prose. Content varies. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 201. Recommended Background: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Writing of Nonfiction Prose
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 295 — Latino Literary Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Major trends, genres, works, themes, and writers related to Latino history and culture, mainstream and minority U.S., Latin American and third world literatures. Course Information: Same as LALS 295 and SPAN 295. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: ENGL 297 — Studies in the Classical Tradition Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of selected texts of ancient Greek and Roman literature, such as the novel, drama, and epic, and how they inform English and American literature and culture. Prerequisites: CL 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and Past course. Course Information: Same as CL 297.

Course: ENGL 299 — Introduction to Special Topics in English Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to special topics in English. Course Information: May be repeated for credit if topic is different for each registration. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Special Topics in English
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 303 — Studies in Poetry Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of traditions and movements in various periods of English, American, and global Anglophone poetry. Recommended Background: ENGL 103 , 207 , 208 , or 209.
Course: ENGL 304 — Studies in Drama Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of an author, topic, or movement in drama. Recommended Background: ENGL 104 , 207 , 208 , or 209.
Course: ENGL 305 — Studies in Fiction Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of a topic or a movement in fiction. Recommended Background: ENGL 105 or ENGL 207 or ENGL 208 or ENGL 209.

Course: ENGL 311 — Medieval English Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major works from the period 450-1500. Readings may include Beowulf, Chaucer, Langland, the Gawain-poet. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 208.

Course: ENGL 312 — Sixteenth and Seventeenth Century Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of important works written in English between 1500 and 1700. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 208.

Course: ENGL 313 — Major Plays of Shakespeare Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Major comedies, histories, tragedies and romances; the development of Shakespeare's career in relation to his theater and his society. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 208.

Course: ENGL 314 — Milton Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to Milton's life and works, this course focuses primarily on the major poetry (Paradise Lost, Paradise Regained, Samson Agonistes) and selected prose. Couse Information: Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 208.

Course: ENGL 315 — Eighteenth Century Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of representative texts in the major genres of Restoration and eighteenth-century literature. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 208.

Course: ENGL 316 — British Romantic Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Surveys the work of important British Romantic writers such as Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, Austen, and Scott, with particular emphasis on analyzing a variety of typical genres. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 209.

Course: ENGL 317 — Victorian Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the literature of the Victorian period in England, with representative fiction, poetry, and non-fictional prose. Some attention to other aspects of Victorian culture (visual arts, architecture, music) as appropriate. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 209.

Course: ENGL 319 — 20th and 21st Century British Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: British Literature in the contemporary context. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 209.

Course: ENGL 322 — Colonial and Postcolonial Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Studies a range of works produced in the context of nineteenth- and twentieth-century colonialism, as well as from the postcolonial period. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 358. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , 208 , 209 , or 223.

Course: ENGL 324 — American Literature to the 20th Century Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of representative works in American literature from the beginning to the 20th century. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 209.

Course: ENGL 325 — 20th and 21st Century American Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Representative selections with emphasis on the poetry and fiction of the period. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 209.

Course: ENGL 328 — Asian American Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Historical development of Asian American literature. It will identify specific cultural and political issues that have shaped the broad range and diverse ethnic interests of that writing. Course Information: Same as GLAS 328. Recommended Background: ENGL 123 , ENGL 240, or ENGL 243.

Course: ENGL 329 — Literatures in English Other than English and American Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Comparative study of literature in English from the colonial territories, the independent former colonies, and/or the Commonwealth nations. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 333. Recommended Background: ENGL 101 , 105 , 135 , 207 , or 209.

metadata.class_name: Literatures in English Other than English and American
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 330 — Cultural and Media Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: General introduction to Cultural Studies, with special attention to film and television and other new media. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 342. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 101 , 135 , 207 -209, or 230.

Course: ENGL 331 — Studies in the Moving Image Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of a topic or movement in film and/or other media forms. Course Information: Same as MOVI 331. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Previously listed as ENGL 302. Recommended Background: ENGL 131.

Course: ENGL 335 — Studies in Literature and Popular Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of what constitutes popular culture, how it identifies itself, how it works, and how it can be analyzed. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 341. Recommended Background: ENGL 101 , ENGL 105 , ENGL 135 , ENGL 207 , or ENGL 209.

metadata.class_name: Studies in Literature and Popular Culture
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 340 — Literary Theory Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to and survey of literary theory. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 370. Recommended Background: ENGL 101 , 207 , 208 , or 209.

Course: ENGL 344 — Gender Theory Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of theories of gender in culture. Course Information: Same as GWS 344. Previously listed as ENGL 361. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, ENGL 245 , or GWS 101 -102.

Course: ENGL 345 — Queer Theory Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of theoretical concerns and historical issues that inform and shape the field of queer studies. Course Information: Same as GWS 345. Previously listed as ENGL 362. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, ENGL 245 , or GWS 203.

Course: ENGL 346 — History of Literary Criticism Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: This course provides an overview of the foundations of literary criticism in English from the ancient Greeks to the present time. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 372. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , 208 , or 209.

Course: ENGL 347 — Gender and Sexuality in Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of works that take the status of gender and sexuality as one of their central thematic or aesthetic concerns. Course Information: Same as GWS 347. Previously listed as ENGL 363. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, ENGL 247 , or GWS 101 -102.

Course: ENGL 350 — Disability Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: This course surveys the representation of physical and cognitive disability in U.S. culture, 1622-present, in order to examine the ways in which impairment impacts definitions of American-ness. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 364. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , 208 , or 209.

Course: ENGL 351 — Topics in Black Art and Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of literature and the other arts in the context of the African diaspora. Topics Vary. Prerequisites: Introductory course in Black Studies or English; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 351. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Black Art and Literature
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 354 — Rhetorical Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical and practical studies of the social contexts, uses, and effects of various kinds of discourse and communication, whether oral, written, or electronic. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 374. Recommended Background: ENGL 154 , 207 , 208 , or 209.

Course: ENGL 355 — Rhetoric and Public Life Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: The study of how language and other media intersect with material conditions to make political belief and political change. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 375. Recommended Background: ENGL 101 , 207 , 208 , or 209.

Course: ENGL 356 — Argument and Persuasion Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and application of historical and contemporary theories of argument and persuasion as they function to form or change opinions and beliefs. Prerequisites: COMM 101 and COMM 103 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200. English majors or minors must seek approval from the Communication department. Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 200 Course Information: Same as COMM 323. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Prereq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200 Coreq Codes (parsed): COMM 102, COMM 200

Course: ENGL 357 — Philosophy of Rhetoric Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: The philosophical basis of the rhetorical tradition—from ancient Greece to today. We ask how language and persuasion function in society, focusing on how rhetorical form, proof, audience, and context shape meaning, belief, and understandings of truth. Prerequisites: Credit in a 200-level course in Philosophy or English or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PHIL 357. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Credit in PHIL 102 or ENGL 154.

Course: ENGL 367 — Latinx Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Development of Latinx literature from different historical periods and diasporic communities. Analysis of political and social concerns relevant to Latinx literature and culture. Course Information: Same as LALS 367. Previously listed as ENGL 353. Recommended Background: Any of LALS 101 -102 or ENGL 207 , 209 , or 267.

Course: ENGL 369 — Multiethnic American Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Representative selections from a number of ethnic and minority literatures. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 359. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , 209 , or 269.

Course: ENGL 376 — Literature and Religion Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Studies in the relation of literature to doctrines, imagery, practices, experiences, or history of one or more religious traditions. Course Information: Same as RELS 376. Previously listed as ENGL 343. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 101 , 105 , 175 , or 207-209.

Course: ENGL 378 — Special Topics in English Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in English Studies. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours of credit. Previously listed as ENGL 394. Recommended Background: Sophomore standing or above.

Course: ENGL 379 — Independent Study in English Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent study. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. The student must first consult with the instructor of the independent study, and the instructor and Director of Undergraduate Studies must approve the student's written prospectus specifying the topic, required work, and number of credit hours the student will receive for the course. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours. This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major. Recommended Background: Senior standing.

Course: ENGL 380 — Advanced Professional Writing Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of genres and forms across the professional spectrum, including but not limited to individual profiles, corporate publications, healthcare newsletters, grant writing. Course Information: Previously listed as ENGL 381. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ENGL 161 or ENGL 280 ; sophomore standing or above.

Course: ENGL 382 — Editing and Publishing Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of editorial oversight, copyediting technique, style requirements, use of grammar as a stylistic tool, publishing industry standards. Recommended Background: ENGL 158 or ENGL161 or ENGL 280 ; and sophomore standing or above.

Course: ENGL 383 — Writing Digital and New Media Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Rhetorical, practical and ethical aspects of digital writing; digital literacy, and the use of digital platforms in professional environments. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ENGL 161 or ENGL 280 ; sophomore standing or above.

Course: ENGL 384 — Technical Writing Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Students will study the conventions and strategies common to the field of technical writing and its forms, including technical reports in science and engineering, technical memos, literature reviews, instructional and procedural materials. Recommended Background: ENGL 158 or ENGL 161.

Course: ENGL 388 — Writing for the Health Professions Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: A writing course for pre-health and English students interested in health humanities to explore how structural racism, social inequities, and medical biases perpetuate health disparities, and the ways writing can advocate for health justice. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ENGL 153 or ENGL 161 ; Sophomore standing or above.

Course: ENGL 389 — Writing for Community Advocacy and Activism Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Topics and genres related to non-profit work, community organizing, social advocacy and activism. Addresses how writing can advocate for social justice; writing across genres, from mission statements, ask letters, social media, grant proposals, etc. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: ENGL 153 or ENGL 161 ; and ENGL 280 ; Sophomore standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Writing for Community Advocacy and Activism
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 404 — Topics in Performance Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In-depth study of a topic, movement, artist or author in the field of drama and performance studies, broadly defined. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 438. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 304, 313, 330, or 340. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 406 — Topics in Poetry and Poetic Theory Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Investigations into the nature of poetry. Discussions of issues such as technical, theoretical, formal and historical developments. Topics and readings vary. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 437. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209. Six hours at the 300-level. Junior standing above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Poetry and Poetic Theory
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 407 — Topics in Fiction and Theories of Fiction Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of fiction related to a particular theory of fiction (Realism, Romance, Literary Naturalism, Narrative Theory, Fictional Poetics). Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 439. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209 or 305. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Fiction and Theories of Fiction
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 409 — Topics in Literature and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a specific topic relating literature to society, culture, history, race, gender, ethnicity. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 429. Recommended Background: Six hours of English at the 300-level or above; and junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 410 — Topics in Old English Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Studies in the language and literature of pre-Conquest England. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 405. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 and ENGL 208.

Course: ENGL 411 — Topics in Medieval Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in English literature from the period 450-1500. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 408. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , or ENGL 311 ; junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 412 — Topics in Renaissance Literature and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a topic in English literature written between 1500 and 1700. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 416. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209 or ENGL 312 -315. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Renaissance Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 413 — Topics in Shakespeare Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a genre, topic or period in Shakespeare's work. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 312 -314. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 414 — Topics in Restoration and Eighteenth-century Literature and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Focus on a particular topic or theme in British literature 1660-1780. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 417. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209 or ENGL 315. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Restoration and Eighteenth-century Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 415 — Topics in Romantic Literature and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Concentrates on a particular aspect of British Romantic writing in order to provide a greater depth of study in the period. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 419. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209 or ENGL 313 -317. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Romantic Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 418 — Topics in Victorian Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a major author, genre, or theme in the Victorian period. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 421. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209 or ENGL 315 -319. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 422 — Topics in Postcolonial and World Literature in English Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a major author, topic, movement, or genre within postcolonial and world literatures in English. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 223, 322, or 329. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Postcolonial and World Literature in English
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 423 — Topics in American Literary Nonfiction Prose Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a specific topic in the literary nonfiction of the United States, which may include its history, development and classification. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 462. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 or ENGL 209. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in American Literary Nonfiction Prose
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 424 — Topics in American Literature and Culture to the 20th Century Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Analyzes selected topics in American literature and culture to 1900. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 426. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , ENGL 209 or ENGL 324 ; junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in American Literature and Culture to the 20th Century
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 425 — Topics in 20th and 21st Century American Literature and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a specific topic relating American literature to society, culture, history, race, gender, ethnicity. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 427. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , ENGL 209 or ENGL 324 , ENGL 325 ; junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in 20th and 21st Century American Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 430 — Topics in Cultural and Media Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a medium, genre, theme, period, influence, or problem in Culture and Cultural Theory. Topics Vary. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 440. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , or ENGL 209 or ENGL 330 , ENGL 331 ; junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Cultural and Media Studies
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 434 — Literature of the Americas Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Transnational or hemispheric approach to Latin American literature. Writers whose work moves back and forth between nations. Identities across borders, languages, and nations. Course Information: Same as LALS 434. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ENGL 435 — Topics in Popular Culture and Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a specific topic relating literature to popular culture, such as sport, television, and best sellers. Critical analysis of the cultural mythology encasing these subjects. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 474. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , ENGL 209 , ENGL 330 , or ENGL 335 ; junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Popular Culture and Literature
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 441 — Topics in Asian American Literature and Culture Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An advanced seminar that examines various forms of cultural production by Asian American artists of diverse ethnic backgrounds. Topics vary. Course Information: Same as GLAS 441. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: ENGL 327, ENGL 328 , or ENGL 359; senior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Asian American Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 443 — Topics in Gender, Sexuality and Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific study of topics in gender and literature. Content varies. Course Information: Same as GWS 443. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 245, 247, 344, 345, or 347, or GWS 101 -102. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Gender, Sexuality and Literature
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 444 — Topics in Theories of Gender and Sexuality Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced study of topics related to theories of gender and sexuality. Course Information: Same as GWS 444. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 245, 247, 344, 345, 347 or GWS 101 -102. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Theories of Gender and Sexuality
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 446 — Topics in Criticism and Theory Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Focus on a particular critical or theoretical topic, movement, tradition or figure. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 251, 340, or 346. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 449 — Women and Film Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Roles and representations of women in classical Hollywood, European art and independent feminist cinemas. Course Information: Same as AH 449 and GWS 449. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 472. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 330 , 344 , 345 , or 347. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 450 — Topics in Disability Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: This course will focus on topics structured around particular aspects of Disability Studies and its practical, cultural, and theoretical implications. Course Information: Same as DHD 450. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 445. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 245, 344, 345, 347, or 350. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 451 — English as Public Practice Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced writing seminar on public-facing research in English studies; writing for academic and non-academic audiences. Students are expected to produce long-form essays and/or portfolio of written work. Content varies. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , 208 , 209 , or any 300-level ENGL course.

Course: ENGL 452 — The UIC Freshwater Lab Course Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Brings a Humanities lens to the Great Lakes watershed to examine how water interacts with socio-political systems, legal structures, cultural perceptions, and artistic visions. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as PA 452 and UPP 452. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ENGL 453 — Freshwater Lab in Practice: Environmental Research, Projects, and Internships Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Investigates key issues surrounding Great Lakes water governance through a combination of hands-on research and professional development in fields related to environmental policy, planning, writing and communication. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as PA 453 and UPP 453. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. This course offers an internship placement opportunity. Depending on placement/start date, students may begin internship work during the second half of the semester or during the summer.

metadata.class_name: Freshwater Lab in Practice: Environmental Research, Projects, and Internships
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 454 — Rhetoric Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive study of central topics in rhetorical theory in their historical depth. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 402. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 330 , 340 , 344 , 345 , 354 , or 355. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 455 — Topics in Rhetorical Studies Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of theoretical intersections between Rhetoric and Cultural Studies to describe and explain the ways in which discourse constructs identity, knowledge, and values. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 448. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 330, 354, or 355. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 456 — Topics in Language and Rhetoric Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a particular topic or movement in language or rhetoric. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 483. Recommended Background: ENGL 354 or ENGL 355. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 457 — Topics in the English Language & Linguistics Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a topic such as language diversity and literacy, theories of grammar, literacy in society, ethnicity and language. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as ENGL 485. Recommended Background: ENGL 354 or ENGL 355. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the English Language & Linguistics
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 458 — History of the English Language Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Development of English from its Proto-Indo-European origin to the present; detailed examination of the external and internal history of Old, Middle, and Modern English. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 400. Recommended Background: ENGL 158 or ENGL 258. Junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 463 — Discourse and Rhetoric Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of interconnections between language and social practices with attention to multiple components of discursive situations: senders, receivers, context, code, media, and content. Prerequisites: COMM 301. English majors or minors must seek approval from the Communication department. Course Information: Same as COMM 423. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ENGL 466 — Topics in Multiethnic Literatures in the United States Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in the literatures of American racial and ethnic groups. Content varies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 470. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , ENGL 209 , ENGL 269 , ENGL 367 , or ENGL 369 ; junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Multiethnic Literatures in the United States
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 467 — Topics in Latinx Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a specific topic in Latinx literature and literary studies, which may examine a single or select group of authors, a particular genre, or a particular regional or aesthetic focus. Topics vary. Course Information: Same as LALS 467. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 442. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , ENGL 209 , ENGL 327 or LALS 101 , LALS 102 ; junior standing or above.

Course: ENGL 469 — Women's Literary Traditions Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An exploration of issues such as the female aesthetic; women's popular literature; factors that enable creativity; differences of race and class. Prerequisites: ENGL 361 or ENGL 362 or ENGL 363; and senior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 469. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ENGL 473 — Topics in Black Literature Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The study and analysis of selected works of Black literature and culture for students with significant background in the field. Topics vary by semester. Prerequisites: BLST 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 490. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ENGL 475 — The Bible as Literature: Hebrew Bible Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Literary analysis of genres and themes of the Hebrew Bible and close reading of the biblical texts. Sources of the Bible and their historical context. Course Information: Same as JST 475 and RELS 475. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 478. Taught in English. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 175 or ENGL 207 -209.

metadata.class_name: The Bible as Literature: Hebrew Bible
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 476 — The Bible as Literature: New Testament Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Literary analysis of the New Testament and its historical and religious contexts, focusing on the gospels and Pauline letters. Course Information: Same as RELS 476. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 479. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 175 , 207 -209, 475.

metadata.class_name: The Bible as Literature: New Testament
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 480 — Introduction to the Teaching of English in Middle and Secondary Schools Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intended as a general initiation to the field of secondary English teaching, the course focuses on many of the crucial issues facing teachers in contemporary language arts classrooms. Prerequisites: Completion of the University Writing requirement; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 459. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Teaching of English in Middle and Secondary Schools
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 482 — Campus Writing Consultants Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 4 Description: Tutoring in the Writing Center. Students are required to consult with others on their writing. Emphasis on practice and theories of writing. Appropriate for prospective teachers. Prerequisites: Senior standing or 9 hours of English and consent of the instructor. Students must obtain override from the Writing Center. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Practice.

Course: ENGL 484 — Topics in the Teaching of English Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 1-4 Description: Study of a topic in literature, composition, and/or pedagogy. The content varies with each offering. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Previously listed as ENGL 494.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the Teaching of English
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 486 — The Teaching of Writing in Middle and Secondary Schools Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Rhetoric and composition pedagogy. Study of a topic. Content varies. Prerequisites: ENGL 480 ; and completion of the English composition requirement; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. 12 hours field work required for licensure.

metadata.class_name: The Teaching of Writing in Middle and Secondary Schools
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 487 — The Teaching of Reading and Literature in Middle and Secondary Schools Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intended as a part of the English education methods sequence, with particular emphasis on helping prospective teachers assist struggling readers in the study of literature. Prerequisites: ENGL 480 and completion of the University Writing requirement; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 489. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: The Teaching of Reading and Literature in Middle and Secondary Schools
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 488 — Methods of Teaching English in Middle and Secondary Schools Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory and practice; emphasis on current approaches to language and literature in multicultural settings. Prerequisites: Senior standing or 9 hours of English or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGL 481. All students in the teacher education program must take this course in the term preceding their student teaching.

metadata.class_name: Methods of Teaching English in Middle and Secondary Schools
metadata.subject: English (ENGL)

text: Course: ENGL 490 — Advanced Writing of Poetry Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced work on poetic techniques and practices; emphasis on analysis of student work, using published examples; particular attention to individual student development. Prerequisites: ENGL 290. Registration restrictions: Graduate students must obtain approval of the Department of English. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) by undergraduates.

Course: ENGL 491 — Advanced Writing of Fiction Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced practice; emphasis on analysis of student work and published examples. Prerequisites: ENGL 291. Registration restrictions: Graduate students must obtain approval of the Department of English. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) by undergraduates.

Course: ENGL 492 — Advanced Writing of Nonfiction Prose Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced practice in writing personal essays, literary journalism, travel-writing, cultural criticism, or other forms of creative nonfiction prose. Content varies. Prerequisites: ENGL 292. Registration restrictions: Graduate students must obtain approval of the Department of English. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) by undergraduates.

Course: ENGL 493 — Internship in Nonfiction Writing Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 0-6 Description: Approved internship where students learn professional writing and organizational communication with an emphasis on initiative, planning, and meeting deadlines. Both the instructor and a supervisor mentor students during the course. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 280 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. A maximum of 6 hours may be applied toward either the undergraduate major in English or a graduate degree in English. Credit is not given for ENGL 493 if the student has credit in ENGL 593. English majors, English minors, and Professional Writing minors must register for 3-6 credit hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Recommended Background: Junior or senior standing.

Course: ENGL 495 — Playwriting Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: The development of scripts for stage performance. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as THTR 431. Recommended Background: For BA Theatre majors: THTR 101 , 201 , and 230.

Course: ENGL 496 — Portfolio Practicum Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Students will reflect upon, organize and present a working portfolio of professional, academic, and/or creative writing samples. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Junior or senior standing; Students should have a body of written work produced during their coursework. This will serve as the preliminary content for their writing portfolios.

Course: ENGL 497 — Senior Thesis Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 3 Description: Supervised research and writing of a senior thesis on a topic agreed upon by student and faculty sponsor. Students who complete this course and fulfill all of the other honors prerequisites will be awarded highest distinction in the major. Previously listed as ENGL 398. Prerequisites: Faculty sponsor and the approval of the department. Recommended Background: Completion or simultaneous enrollment in a 400-level seminar.

Course: ENGL 498 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the department. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: ENGL 499 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: English (ENGL) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 498 , and approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 498 , and approval of the department Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 498 , and approval of the department Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): ENGL 498 Coreq Codes (parsed): ENGL 498

Course: ENGR 100 — Engineering Success Seminar for Freshmen Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: A general orientation course on skills pertinent to students for successful completion of their undergraduate degree. Prerequisites: Admission to the College of Engineering. Degree-seeking students only. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Should be taken within the first semester after enrolling in the College of Engineering.

Course: ENGR 101 — Engineering Success Seminar for Transfer Students Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: A general orientation course on skills pertinent to students for successful completion of their undergraduate degree. Prerequisites: Degree-seeking transfer students only. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Should be taken within the first semester after enrolling in the College of Engineering.

metadata.class_name: Engineering Success Seminar for Transfer Students
metadata.subject: Engineering (ENGR)

text: Course: ENGR 111 — Engineering Practicum in Additive Manufacturing Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Polymeric materials and process-specific aspects of lab safety; computer aided design for 3D printing including support structures; hand-on 3D printing projects; post-processing; integration with subtractive manufacturing. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: ENGR 112 — Engineering Practicum in Subtractive Manufacturing Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Relevant aspects of shop and machine safety; computer aided machining software; usage of manual and computer numerical control mill and router, laser cutter, lathe, drill press, belt sander and cutoff saw; integration with additive manufacturing. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: ENGR 189 — Minority Engineering Freshman and Transfer Student Orientation Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Orientation for undergraduate minority engineering students; seminars, lectures and workshops by faculty, upperclass students, administration and industry representatives on topics relevant to ethnic minority groups. Prerequisites: Admission to the College of Engineering. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Should be taken in the first semester after acceptance into the College of Engineering. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Minority Engineering Freshman and Transfer Student Orientation
metadata.subject: Engineering (ENGR)

text: Course: ENGR 193 — Engineering Student Leadership Seminar Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Peer student leadership topics in Engineering, team building events, self reflection, feedback and program assessment. Prerequisites: Open only to freshmen. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. No graduation credit.

Course: ENGR 194 — Special Topics in Engineering Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Multidisciplinary engineering topics that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ENGR 214 — Advanced Practicum in Physical Prototyping Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Advanced design software for digital manufacturing, 3d printing, CNC milling, laser and vinyl cutting, circuit boards and basic electronics and micro-controllers, shop and machine safety, relevant material properties. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: ENGR 289 — Cooperative Engineering Practice Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 0 Description: Off-campus participation in a governmental or industrial training program. Prerequisites: Enrollment in the Cooperative Engineering Program. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated.

Course: ENGR 293 — Engineering Student Leadership Seminar Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Peer student leadership topics in Engineering, team building events, self reflection, feedback and program assessment. Prerequisites: Open only to sophomores. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. No graduation credit.

Course: ENGR 294 — Special Topics in Engineering Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Course on multidisciplinary engineering topics that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ENGR 393 — Engineering Student Leadership Seminar Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Peer student leadership topics in Engineering, team building events, self reflection, feedback and program assessment. Prerequisites: Open only to juniors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. No graduate credit.

Course: ENGR 394 — Special Topics in Engineering Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Course on multidisciplinary engineering topics that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ENGR 400 — Engineering Law Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of the legal system. Legal principles affecting the engineering profession. Professional ethics in engineering. Intellectual property law. Basic contract and tort principles. Environmental law. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: Same as MENG 400. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. This is an online web-based course.

Course: ENGR 401 — Engineering Management Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory, strategy, and tactics of the use of project management including project planning, matrix management concept, and team meetings. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: Same as MENG 401. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. This is an online web-based course.

Course: ENGR 402 — Intellectual Property Law Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Patent, copyright, trade secret, mask work, and cyber-squatting legal and procedural principles; protection for novel software, biotech inventions, and business methods; and trademark protection for domain names. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: Same as MENG 402. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. This is an online web-based course.

Course: ENGR 403 — Reliability Engineering Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Probability overview; statistics overview; system reliability modeling and prediction-static methods; system reliability modeling and prediction-dynamic methods; maintainability and availability; reliability optimization; and risk analysis. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: Same as MENG 403. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. This is an online web-based course.

Course: ENGR 404 — Entrepreneurship Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 3 Description: Identify new business opportunities in technology, market value assessment, competition, business plan, funding acquisition, intellectual property protection and case studies. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors; and consent of the instructor.

Course: ENGR 420 — Engineering for Success Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Interactive seminars will be given by persons with engineering degrees having shown high achievement in either engineering or non-engineering endeavors. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: ENGR 436 — Wireless Data Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Data communications, existing Wireless Data Networks, planning, topology, performance, and operation. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above and a course in digital communications and an introductory course in wireless communications. Course Information: Same as MENG 436. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENGR 410. Extensive computer use required. This is an online web-based course.

Course: ENGR 493 — Engineering Student Leadership Seminar Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1 Description: Peer student leadership topics in Engineering, team building events, self reflection, feedback and program assessment. Prerequisites: Open only to Seniors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. No graduation credit.

Course: ENGR 494 — Special Topics in Engineering Subject: Engineering (ENGR) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course on multidisciplinary engineering topics that vary from term to term depending on current student and instructor interests. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ENTR 200 — Survey of Entrepreneurship Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces the discipline of entrepreneurship, which examines when, how and by what means individuals choose entrepreneurship over paid employment; examines the relationship between individual entrepreneurs and society over time. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Previously listed as ENTR 300.

Course: ENTR 310 — Introduction to Entrepreneurship Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the concepts of entrepreneurship, opportunity recognition, characteristics of entrepreneurs, creativity, the role of the entrepreneur in the economy and society, and entrepreneurship in non-entrepreneurial settings. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or ENTR 200.

Course: ENTR 320 — Entrepreneurship Internship Program Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 1 or 3 Description: Cooperative education provides students an opportunity to gain access to mentors and practical work experience in entrepreneurial settings. Prerequisites: ENTR 310. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximamum of 6 hours.

Course: ENTR 360 — Data Analytics for Management Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Examines types and sources of information used by managers and investors to make strategic decisions; provides working knowledge of tools used to effectively manage, analyze and report strategic information. Prerequisites: IDS 270 and MGMT 340 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as MGMT 360. Extensive computer use required.

Course: ENTR 420 — Social Entrepreneurship Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on using entrepreneurial skills to craft innovative responses to social problems. Social entrepreneurship applies to both profit and non-profit firms that have programs designed to create social value. Prerequisites: ENTR 310.

Course: ENTR 430 — Family Business Management Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Competitive strengths/weaknesses of a family business, dynamics of family interactions within the overlapping family, management and ownership systems. Prerequisites: ENTR 310.

Course: ENTR 435 — International Entrepreneurship Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students with knowledge useful for creating an international new venture by focusing on the identification and evaluation of international business opportunities, as well as building and managing an international organization. Prerequisites: ENTR 310.

Course: ENTR 444 — Entrepreneurial Finance Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Develops the skills necessary to analyze the unique financial issues facing entrepreneurs, such as valuation of new ventures, financial tools useful in venture capital markets, deal structuring, governance, and harvesting. Prerequisites: ENTR 310. Course Information: Previously listed as FIN 444.

Course: ENTR 445 — New Venture Planning Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on strategic analysis and strategic planning for new ventures and provides students with the skills necessary to develop entry strategies for new ventures in uncertain environments. Prerequisites: ENTR 310.

Course: ENTR 450 — Entrepreneurship for Scientists and Engineers Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Gives non-business students an appreciation for the rewards and challenges of entrepreneurship, especially as it relates to commercializing emerging technologies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for students enrolled in a Business Administration degree program.

Course: ENTR 454 — Entrepreneurship New Venture Formation Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on analyzing the value propositions of a new business venture, and garnering and employing resources in pursuit of that new venture. Prerequisites: ENTR 310.

Course: ENTR 464 — Entrepreneurial Consulting Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 3 Description: Student teams diagnose and recommend solutions to problems and opportunities facing Chicago area entrepreneurs and smaller enterprises. Application of previous coursework. Prerequisites: ENTR 310.

Course: ENTR 494 — Special Topics in Entrepreneurship Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Exploration of areas not covered in existing course offerings or study of selected topics in greater depth. Subject will vary from semester to semester. Prerequisites: ENTR 310. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: ENTR 499 — Research Experience Subject: Entrepreneurship (ENTR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the supervision of a faculty member. The faculty member and student will determine the research project. Each student must submit a written report and each student must participate at a research event on campus. Prerequisites: Approval of the department head and the instructor required. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: EPSY 100 — Introduction to Human Development and Learning Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Examines basic concepts and theories in human development. Discusses relationships between biological, cognitive, social, and cultural aspects of development with learning across the lifespan. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Human Development and Learning
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 150 — Human Development and Learning Academic Success Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 2 Description: Provides new students in Human Development & Learning (for example, transfers, first year students) an introduction to the college experience, HDL Program, College of Education, and UIC to facilitate students' adjustment to university life. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

metadata.class_name: Human Development and Learning Academic Success
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 160 — Games, Learning, and Society Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the development and design of games for teaching and learning. Critical analysis of games and how they shape interactions among players, their learning, and their connection to society. Course Information: Same as ED 160. Individual and Society course.

Course: EPSY 210 — Principles of Learning and Instruction Across the Lifespan Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: How people learn and the design of instruction and assessment across a broad set of formal and informal instructional environments and populations. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Secondary Teacher Education students should enroll in the ED 210 section. All other students should enroll in the EPSY 210 section. Course Information: Same as ED 210.

metadata.class_name: Principles of Learning and Instruction Across the Lifespan
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 242 — Introduction to Sexuality Development Across the Lifespan Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Examine all aspects of the development of sexuality across the lifespan. Course covers physiological, cognitive, behavioral, emotional, identity, and relational components of sexuality development and how contextual factors shape sexual development. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or PSCH 100. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Sexuality Development Across the Lifespan
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 255 — Child Development in Contemporary Society Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of theories on child development that explain age-related differences in cognition, socio-emotional development, physical development, and social changes and how this relates to 0-12-year-old children's learning and educational needs. Prerequisites: ED 100 or PSCH 100 or EPSY 100 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: EPSY 256 — Adolescent and Early Adulthood Development in Contemporary Society Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of social, cognitive, and physiological development of adolescent and early adult development. Examines the contexts and institutions that influence adolescent and adult development, with a particular interest in the urban context. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 , or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: EPSY 210 and EPSY 255.

metadata.class_name: Adolescent and Early Adulthood Development in Contemporary Society
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 257 — Adult Development and Aging in Contemporary Society Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of social, emotional, personality, cognitive, behavioral, and physiological changes associated with adult development and aging (young adulthood through late age). Will examine influence of cultural contexts and institutions on development. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in EPSY 100 or Grade of C or better in PSCH 100 ; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Adult Development and Aging in Contemporary Society
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 263 — Sport, Global Cultures, and Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Students will explore different regions of the world through sport, and will consider how sport is a means of identifying, sharing, and even transforming the values and cultural norms in these regions.

Course: EPSY 320 — Understanding Children’s Social Development & Socialization in an Urban Context Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces social development and socialization theories as it relates to children growing and learning in an urban context. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 or ED 100 ; and EPSY 255 or PSCH 320 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Children’s Social Development & Socialization in an Urban Context
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 326 — Child Health, Safety, and Nutrition Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Early childhood curriculum, regulations, standards, policies, and procedures related to child health, safety, and nutrition birth - age 8. Emphasis on partnering with families and community and integrating and maintaining health, safety, and nutrition. Prerequisites: EPSY 255.

Course: EPSY 340 — Self and Identity Development Across the Lifespan Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of theories, research, and contextual factors related to self and identity development across the lifespan, as well as developmental implications for individuals' learning, health, and well-being. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in two of the following: EPSY 255 , EPSY 256 , or EPSY 257 or equivalent, or consent of instructor. Recommended Background: Coursework in human development and learning, psychology, and/or sociology.

metadata.class_name: Self and Identity Development Across the Lifespan
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 360 — Assessment in the Urban Elementary Classroom I Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 2 Description: Beginning concepts in the design, administration, and scoring of assessments useful in urban elementary classrooms for measuring different types of learning outcomes, from simple to complex. The focus will be on achievement assessments. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 ; and junior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education, Concentration in Elementary Education. Course Information: 2 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Thirty hours of fieldwork required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Assessment in the Urban Elementary Classroom I
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)
