text: Course: EPSY 361 — Assessment in the Urban Elementary Classroom II Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 2 Description: Continuing and advancing concepts of design, administration, and scoring of assessments useful in urban elementary classrooms for measuring different types of learning outcomes, from simple to complex. The focus will be on performance assessments. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 and EPSY 360 ; and junior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Urban Education, Concentration in Elementary Education. Course Information: 2 hours. Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Assessment in the Urban Elementary Classroom II
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 363 — Understanding and Applying Research in Human Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students with the necessary skills to become critical consumers of research in human development, learning, and instruction. Emphasis on making sense of research findings and when and how to apply findings in a variety of settings. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in two of the following: EPSY 255 , EPSY 256 , EPSY 257 or equivalent, or consent of instructor.

metadata.class_name: Understanding and Applying Research in Human Development
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 364 — Sport and Human Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Students will learn how sport and athletics influence human learning and development across the lifespan, paying particular attention to changes in affect, cognition, ethical behavior, and social interactions in educational settings. Recommended Background: An interest and/or expertise in physiology, psychological and biological factors associated with human development.

Course: EPSY 370 — ECE and Curriculum Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasizes planning, organizing, implementing, and evaluating programs for young children with diverse learning needs birth - 8 years. Students will be provided with an understanding of developmentally appropriate programs and practice. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 and EPSY 255 and EPSY 210 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: EPSY 371 — Human Development and Learning in the Context of Institutions Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores human development and learning within the context of institutional systems such as juvenile justice, child protective services, residential treatment, and hospitals. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 or EPSY 255 or EPSY 256 or EPSY 257 or ED 210 ; or EPSY 210 or EPSY 363.

metadata.class_name: Human Development and Learning in the Context of Institutions
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 372 — Youth, Families, Communities, and Justice Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores research and literature on the experiences of youth, families, and communities as they relate to the justice system. Emphasis on the effects of incarceration on human development and learning, and children of incarcerated parents. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 or EPSY 255 or EPSY 256 or ED 210 or EPSY 210 Or consent of instructor.

Course: EPSY 373 — Advanced Research Methods in Human Development and Learning Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Conducting research in human development and learning. Emphasis on designing and implementing studies, analyzing data, interpreting findings, and communicating with the scientific and broader community. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in EPSY 363 or equivalent, or consent of instructor.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Research Methods in Human Development and Learning
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 374 — Observation, Curriculum, and Learning Environments for Very Young Children Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 4 Description: Explores principles and practices needed to provide high quality infant/toddler care and education. Prerequisites: EPSY 255. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Observation, Curriculum, and Learning Environments for Very Young Children
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 380 — Instructional Design and Training Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the field of instructional design and training, current trends and issues impacting the field, and future directions and careers in the field. Topics include visual literacy, ADDIE, technology tools, and technology integration. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: EPSY 382 — Child, Family, and Community Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the importance of relationships between young children, their families, the community, and the early childhood setting. Examines issues of diversity and anti-bias approaches as well as current policies and practices that influence families. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or EPSY 255 or EPSY 210 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: EPSY 383 — Critical Perspectives in Latinx Human Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on the contextual, cultural and societal factors that influence the healthy development of Latinx people in the U.S. Major topics are immigration, racial/ethnic identity, racism, acculturation, resistance and social change. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 ; or SOC 100 or SOC 105 ; or LALS 101. Open only to juniors and seniors; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Critical Perspectives in Latinx Human Development
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 384 — Critical Perspectives in LGBTQ+ Human Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores LGBTQ+ human development across the lifespan with a focus on intersecting ecological factors (e.g., social, cultural, political, educational, generational) and an emphasis on promoting resilience, well-being, and queer joy. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 ; or PSCH 100 ; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Critical Perspectives in LGBTQ+ Human Development
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 394 — Special Topics in Educational Psychology Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 1-4 Description: Exploration of a topic not covered in existing course offerings. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: EPSY 396 — Independent Study Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 1-4 Description: Students carry out independent study under the direction of educational psychology faculty member. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours.

Course: EPSY 398 — Directed Research in Human Development and Learning Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 1-4 Description: Students carry out directed research under the mentorship of educational psychology faculty member. Prerequisites: EPSY 363 or equivalent course, and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours.

metadata.class_name: Directed Research in Human Development and Learning
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 400 — Print-based Instructional Materials: Design and Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on the design and development process for creating and presenting print-based instructional materials for various learning contexts, to include basic analysis, design, layout, and development guidelines. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Print-based Instructional Materials: Design and Development
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 405 — Educational Assessment and Evaluation Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Design, administration and scoring of assessments and evaluations useful in educational contexts for measuring different types of learning, program and developmental outcomes, from simple to complex. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 ; or junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor.

Course: EPSY 413 — Youth Development Colloquium Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 1 Description: Focuses on current issues and trends in the field of youth development. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated.

Course: EPSY 414 — Developing Programs For Youth Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Survey, evaluation, and development of models and programs designed to facilitate growth, development and learning for diverse youth. Specific focus will be on planning programs for youth (ages 10 - 25). Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor or enrollment in the Youth Development Program. Course Information: Previously listed as CI 416.

Course: EPSY 415 — Fieldwork in Human Development and Learning in Urban Contexts Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Experience working with programs that foster the developmental needs of young people in urban contexts. Students will design, implement and evaluate programs that promote personal development and independent action among youth. Prerequisites: EPSY 363 ; and junior standing or above. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Previously listed as CIE 415. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Recommended Background: EPSY 414.

metadata.class_name: Fieldwork in Human Development and Learning in Urban Contexts
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 416 — Systematic Approaches to Program Quality Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of theories and practical methods in exploring the interrelated system of program development, quality implementation, and evaluation. Relevant for those working in diverse settings and with diverse youth. Prerequisites: EPSY 363 or EPSY 414 ; or junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: coursework in psychology or educational psychology.

Course: EPSY 420 — Advanced Social Development of Children in an Urban Context Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Course examines some general principles of children’s (3-14 years old) social development and socialization and the applicability of these principles for urban-dwelling children. Prerequisites: Admission to the graduate program in education, psychology, social work, public health, or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Social Development of Children in an Urban Context
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 424 — Family Diversity and Film: A Resilience Framework Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Examines diverse families through the use of films as "case studies." Using classic/contemporary films that depict multiple family structures, social-classes, and experiences within families, the internal dynamics of family life are explored. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: EPSY 100 and SOC 100 and PSCH 100.

metadata.class_name: Family Diversity and Film: A Resilience Framework
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 426 — Development, Health and Wellness: Conception to age 8 Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 4 Description: Focuses on the developmental processes in cognitive, social/emotional, language, and physical domains. Special consideration will be given to the interaction:health, wellness, social, cultural, and interpersonal environments of children. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 ; and senior standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as EPSY 526. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Development, Health and Wellness: Conception to age 8
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 428 — Young Children, Nature and Sustainability Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Participants explore the theories and research on the relationship between children’s health, development and wellness and their access to and engagement in nature. The four pillars of sustainability are integrated throughout the course.

Course: EPSY 429 — Constructivist Approaches to Development: Piaget and Vygotsky Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Piaget's and Vygotsky's theories of development of knowledge. Empirical and logico-mathematical forms of knowledge. Thought and action. Thought and language. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 or EPSY 426 or ED 422 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PSCH 429.

metadata.class_name: Constructivist Approaches to Development: Piaget and Vygotsky
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 430 — Interactive Online Instruction: Design and Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on the design and development process for creating interactive e-learning for various learning contexts. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Interactive Online Instruction: Design and Development
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 440 — Engaging Multimedia Instruction: Design and Development Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on the design and development of interactive instructional animations that may stand-alone or be integrated as part of a learning program. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Engaging Multimedia Instruction: Design and Development
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 446 — Characteristics of Early Adolescence Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Physiological, social, emotional and cognitive development of early adolescence. The relationship between these developmental characteristics and success in the middle grades. Prerequisites: Admission to a program in psychology or education; or approval of the College of Education or consent of the instructor, EPSY 210 or EPSY 255 or ED 421 or ED 422. Course Information: Same as PSCH 423.

Course: EPSY 449 — Early Childhood/Early Childhood Special Education: Perspectives, Policies and History Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Perspectives, policies, history, and foundations of Early Childhood Education and Early Childhood Special Education. Emphasis on the effects of changing economic, political, legal, social, and views of human development. Course Information: Same as SPED 449 and EDPS 449.

metadata.class_name: Early Childhood/Early Childhood Special Education: Perspectives, Policies and History
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 450 — Assessment and Evaluation of Learning Outcomes and Instructional Products Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Designed to develop knowledge and skills in systematically evaluating student learning and instructional technology product outcomes related to program goals and standards. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Assessment and Evaluation of Learning Outcomes and Instructional Products
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 451 — Staff Management and Human Relations for Leaders in Early Childhood Education Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Designed for directors, supervisors and managers in early childhood programs. Focuses on the administrator's role in staff development and human relations, including recruitment, hiring, retaining, training, support and evaluation of personnel.

metadata.class_name: Staff Management and Human Relations for Leaders in Early Childhood Education
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 452 — Legal, Fiscal and Program Management for Leaders in Early Childhood Education Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students with opportunities to learn and apply current theories of administration in order to improve their skills in managing early childhood education programs.

metadata.class_name: Legal, Fiscal and Program Management for Leaders in Early Childhood Education
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 453 — Educational Programming and Community Relations for Leaders in Early Childhood Education Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Designed for directors and managers in early childhood programs. Focuses on development and implementation of a program philosophy, curriculum for typically and atypically developing children; and promoting a positive image to the public.

metadata.class_name: Educational Programming and Community Relations for Leaders in Early Childhood Education
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 461 — Seminar and Fieldwork in Human Development and Learning Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: The culminating course for students in the Child and Youth Development and Early Childhood Education concentration of the Human Development and Learning BA program. Students have opportunities to bridge theory and research with professional practice. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 and EPSY 256 or consent of instructor. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Seminar and Fieldwork in Human Development and Learning
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 464 — Psychology of Sport and Wellness Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Students will learn specialized ways in which sport and exercise influence wellness, paying particular attention how learning and wellness are fostered when individuals participate in age-bound and lifetime sports. Recommended Background: Psychology, Physiology, and Biological factors associated with wellness.

Course: EPSY 465 — Understanding Students with High Incidence Disabilities Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Uses major theoretical frameworks of human development to examine the characteristics and development of students with high incidence disabilities, ages 3-21. Course Information: Same as SPED 465. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Students with High Incidence Disabilities
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 466 — Language Development, Diversity, and Disabilities Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and research on language development in children with disabilities, in the context of typical development. Models for language assessment and intervention. Course Information: Same as SPED 466.

Course: EPSY 467 — Understanding Students With Low Incidence Disabilities Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores characteristics and development of children and youth with low incidence disabilities, ages 3-21, as well as how schools address their instructional needs. Course Information: Same as SPED 467.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Students With Low Incidence Disabilities
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 471 — Facilitating Healthy Development in the Context of Trauma Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the impact of trauma on youth and ways to facilitate healthy development among youth who have experienced trauma. Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 or EPSY 255 or EPSY 256 or EPSY 363 ; or graduate standing.

metadata.class_name: Facilitating Healthy Development in the Context of Trauma
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 472 — Justice, Discipline, and Human Development and Learning Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores several disciplinary frameworks and how these frameworks affect human development and learning and how structural oppression is connected to discipline disparities across a variety of contexts (e.g., school-to-prison pipeline). Prerequisites: EPSY 100 or PSCH 100 or EPSY 255 or EPSY 256 or EPSY 257 or EPSY 363 ; and graduate standing.

metadata.class_name: Justice, Discipline, and Human Development and Learning
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 482 — Collaborating with Families, Community, and Professionals Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the dynamics of professional collaboration with families, addressing characteristics, structures, and processes of collaboration for children and youth with and without disabilities. Course Information: Same as SPED 482. Previously listed as EPSY 582. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Collaborating with Families, Community, and Professionals
metadata.subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY)

text: Course: EPSY 494 — Topics in Educational Psychology Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 1-4 Description: Seminar on a pre-announced topic focusing on methodology, research and educational implications of recent models of learning, problem solving, and thinking. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours.

Course: EPSY 496 — Independent Study Subject: Educational Psychology (EPSY) Credits: 1-4 Description: Students carry out independent study under the direction of educational psychology faculty member. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor.

Course: FIN 250 — Personal Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the interaction between individual and society in the framework of financial decision-making and in the context of the U.S. financial markets. Analyzes the impact of financial choices on the lives of individuals, families, and communities. Prerequisites: MATH 110. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Any 100-level MATH, ACTG, or FIN course. Individual and Society course.

Course: FIN 294 — Special Topics in Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 1-3 Description: Multidisciplinary finance topics at sophomore or junior level that vary from term to term, depending on current student and instructor interests. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours. May be repeated if topics varies. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: FIN 300 — Introduction to Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Description of financial markets. Time value of money. Risk and return. Market valuation of securities. Capital budgeting, capital structure and dividend policy of firms. Course Information: Credit is not given for FIN 300 if the student has credit in FIN 301 or FIN 302. Recommended Background: ACTG 210 and ECON 120.

Course: FIN 301 — Introduction to Managerial Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to managerial finance: the valuation of future cash flows, capital budgeting, capital structure, and banking. Current events and policy issues are discussed. Couse Information: Credit is not given for FIN 301 if the student has credit in FIN 300.

Course: FIN 302 — Introduction to Investments Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to investments: risk/return, models of risk, efficient markets, derivative securities, fixed income securities, international aspects. Current events and policy issues are discussed. Couse Information: Credit is not given for FIN 302 if the student has credit in FIN 300.

Course: FIN 310 — Investments Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Organization of security markets. Legal and institutional environment, mechanics of trade, financial intermediation, security classification. General principles of asset valuation with application to specific securities. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302.

Course: FIN 320 — Managerial Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Short-term asset management, capital budgeting under certainty and uncertainty, capital structure and dividend policy, valuation and risk, capital asset prices, financial policy for firms. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302.

Course: FIN 330 — Quantitative Methods Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the quantitative methods needed for advanced finance coursework: point/interval estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, cross-section analysis, time series analysis, portfolio modeling, advanced topics. Prerequisites: IDS 270. Recommended Background: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 & FIN 302.

Course: FIN 340 — International Financial Markets Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Evaluation of exchange rate regiments and international financial institutions; develop critical understanding of the asset approach to exchange rates and international financial markets. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302.

Course: FIN 396 — Independent Study Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent study, under the direction of a faculty member, must be arranged before the start of the semester. Prerequisites: FIN 310 and FIN 320 ; and consent of the instructor and the Department Head. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: FIN 411 — Retirement and Estate Planning Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Provides tools for a financial planner to advise clients on issues of education, retirement, and estate planning, accounting for numerous tax implications. Prerequisites: FIN 250.

Course: FIN 412 — Portfolio Management Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Development of portfolio theory; establishment of portfolio objectives for individuals, corporations, banks, pension and mutual funds; evaluation of portfolio performance. Prerequisites: FIN 310.

Course: FIN 414 — Financial Plan Development Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Multifaceted task of financial plans, wealth accumulation, includes employee benefit programs, insurance policies, investments, estate planning, federal income tax, annuities, banking, borrowing. Students develop financial plans, orally and written. Prerequisites: FIN 250 and FIN 300 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: FIN 415 — Fixed Income Securities Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Valuation of fixed income securities, term structure estimation and arbitrage trading with practical application using real data. Prerequisites: FIN 310.

Course: FIN 416 — Options and Futures Markets Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: History and institutional structure of options and futures markets. Uses of futures and options for arbitrage, speculation and hedging by managers of domestic and multinational organizations. Analysis of factors which determine futures and options prices. Prerequisites: FIN 310.

Course: FIN 418 — Commodities, Energy, and Related Markets Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Covers markets; physicality; laws and regulations; market participants; fundamentals (ags, metals, petroleum, electricity, emissions, and shipping); spreads; options; and, risk management. Prerequisites: FIN 310 ; and FIN 330 or IDS 270 (undergraduate students); FIN 510 (graduate students). Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: IDS 371 (undergraduate students); IDS 570 (graduate students).

Course: FIN 419 — Behavioral Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an understanding of the individuals' behavioral biases and their effects on financial markets. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Graduate students are expected to complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: FIN 421 — Advanced Corporate Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Uses the case method to provide an in-depth treatment of corporate financial decisions pertaining to investment and financing choices, corporate policies, and valuation of businesses. Prerequisites: FIN 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Understanding financial statements, time value of money, rates of return, market efficiency, and basic concepts of risk, and discount rates. This class cannot serve as an introductory level course for unprepared students. For students who lack confidence in their mastery of the prerequisite material, self-study review of chapters 1–12 of Essentials of Corporate Finance by Ross, Westerfield, and Jordan, the required text for FIN 320 , is strongly recommended.

Course: FIN 422 — Alternative Investments: Venture Capital, Private Equity, and Hedge Funds Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Aims to help students understand the investment opportunities available in venture capital, private equity, and hedge funds, both from a quantitative and a qualitative perspective, using a combination of lectures and case discussions. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302. Course Information: Credit is not given for FIN 422 if the student has credit in FIN 445. Recommended Background: FIN 310 and FIN 320.

metadata.class_name: Alternative Investments: Venture Capital, Private Equity, and Hedge Funds
metadata.subject: Finance (FIN)

text: Course: FIN 423 — Financial Modeling, Analysis, and Decision Making Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Teaches financial modeling and firm valuation skills using a set of case studies. Using financial data from real firms, students compute and forecast cash flows to evaluation day-to-day business decisions. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Financial Modeling, Analysis, and Decision Making
metadata.subject: Finance (FIN)

text: Course: FIN 424 — Financial Communication Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: This learn-by-doing course concentrates on developing strong communication skills with topics based on economic and financial scenarios. Prerequisites: FIN 300 or FIN 301. Recommended Background: Basic Excel and PowerPoint skills.

Course: FIN 425 — Energy Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses finance topics in the context of the energy industry, including valuation, lending, trading, and risk management. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: FIN 310 and FIN 320.

Course: FIN 430 — Introduction to Money and Banking Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Payment and banking systems; credit and market risk management; The Federal Reserve System; globalization of monetary, banking, and regulatory systems. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302.

Course: FIN 431 — Management in the Financial Services Industry Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: The principles of management of corporations in the financial services industry, emphasizing commercial bank management and risk. Methodology includes computerized bank management simulation or case studies. Prerequisites: FIN 300.

metadata.class_name: Management in the Financial Services Industry
metadata.subject: Finance (FIN)

text: Course: FIN 442 — International Corporate Financial Management Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Financial management within an international context. International monetary system and financial markets, management of foreign investments, working capital management, exchange risks, taxation and earnings reports. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302.

Course: FIN 445 — Financing Entrepreneurship Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Helps students understand the opportunities and challenges faced by entrepreneurs seeking to finance high-potential ventures by raising venture capital or other forms of private equity or debt. Course Information: Credit is not given for FIN 445 if the student has credit in FIN 422 or ENTR 444. Recommended Background: FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302.

Course: FIN 449 — Applied Equity Investment Management Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Puts financial theory to practice by giving students real life, hands-on experience in managing an equity investment process, from stock selection to portfolio management. Prerequisites: FIN 310. Recommended Background: A keen interest/ passion for the markets in general and the equity markets in particular.

Course: FIN 455 — Asset Management Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Applied course in Investments. The emphasis is on modern quantitative techniques for asset management. Prerequisites: FIN 310 (undergraduate students); FIN 510 (graduate students). Course Information: Students will use real data, and learn to create their own spreadsheet optimization programs in MS excel. Recommended Background: Students must be comfortable with linear regressions matrix algebra, basic calculus. Spreadsheet proficiency is essential.

Course: FIN 456 — Advanced Investment Management Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: This fund is a one-of-a-kind educational opportunity that prepares students for success in the investment industry by managing real money in a highly unstructured setting using the best research and research tools. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in FIN 310 and Grade of B or better in FIN 320.

Course: FIN 460 — Corporate Valuation Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines corporate valuation with tools and techniques such as valuation multiples, discounted cash flows, cost of capital, and the adjusted present value method. Prerequisites: FIN 320 or FIN 520. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Basic understanding of accounting and statistics.

Course: FIN 472 — Real Estate Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Finance principles applied to real estate; financing of residential and income-producing real estate; real estate development finance; secondary mortgage market; taxation and real estate finance. Prerequisites: FIN 300. Course Information: Same as RES 472. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May not be used to satisfy the economics credit requirement for the MA in Economics and PhD in Economics. Only elective credit will be applied toward these degrees. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: FIN 473 — Risk Management and Insurance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to risk management. Loan and credit management; credit scoring. Risk measurements and reserves; banking and insurance capital requirements, the BASEL accord, tail events and catastrophic event insurance. Financial contracts and hedging. Prerequisites: IDS 270 or IE 342 or STAT 381 or PSCH 343 or SOC 401 ; and FIN 300. Course Information: Same as IDS 473.

Course: FIN 479 — Enterprise Risk Management Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of enterprise-wide risk management strategies and techniques: strategies that firms employ to enhance value and minimize exposure; techniques used to identify, measure, reduce, and transfer risk. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IDS 479. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: IDS 473 or FIN 473.

Course: FIN 480 — Securities Markets and High-Frequency Trading Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: How securities are traded in modern financial markets; design, operation, and regulation of trading processes; real-time algorithmic trading exercises and high-frequency trading strategies. Recommended Background: FIN 310.

Course: FIN 481 — Introduction to Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to blockchain and cryptocurrencies so they can safely navigate these spaces and apply their knowledge in future crypto related opportunities. Prerequisites: FIN 300. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: FIN 494 — Special Topics in Finance Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 1-4 Description: An intensive study of a selected topic in finance. Topics vary by sections and by term. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 1 to 3 undergraduate hours. 2 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours for undergraduates; may be repeated to a maximum of 8 hourse for graduate students.

Course: FIN 495 — Competitive Strategy Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 4 Description: Multidisciplinary analysis of organization strategy and policy using case method and/or business simulation. Assignments involve extensive library research as well as oral and written reports. Prerequisites: FIN 310 and FIN 320 and Senior Standing and completion of all Business Core courses; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for FIN 495 if the student has credit in ACTG 495 or IDS 495 or MGMT 495.

Course: FIN 499 — Research Experience Subject: Finance (FIN) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the supervision of a faculty member. The faculty member and student will determine the research project. Each student must submit a written report and each student must participate at a research event on campus. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and department head. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: FR 101 — Elementary French I Subject: French (FR) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to French language and culture. Intensive practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Course Information: For students who have not studied French or placement as determined by test score. This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high- speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined-section final exam will be held Tuesday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: FR 102 — Elementary French II Subject: French (FR) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of introduction to French language and culture. Intensive practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Prerequisites: A grade of C or better in FR 101 , or the equivalent as determined by test score. Course Information: This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined-section final exam will be held Tuesday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: FR 103 — Intermediate French I Subject: French (FR) Credits: 4 Description: Intensive practice in conversation (speaking, listening), reading, composition; vocabulary and grammar acquisition and practice. Prerequisites: FR 102 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of a computer and internet access is required. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined-section final exam will be held Tuesday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: FR 104 — Intermediate French II Subject: French (FR) Credits: 4 Description: Intensive practice in conversation (speaking, listening), reading, composition; vocabulary and grammar acquisition and practice. Prerequisites: FR 103 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of a computer and internet access is required. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined-section final exam will be held Tuesday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: FR 191 — African and Caribbean Francophone Literature in Translation Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the Francophone literature of Africa and the Caribbean and to its historical and cultural contexts. Course Information: Same as BLST 191. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: African and Caribbean Francophone Literature in Translation
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 196 — Totalitarianism, Writing and Cinema Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to French, Spanish, and Italian writing and films dealing with the issue of totalitarianism. Various authors are examined within a broad context of European thinking on totalitarianism. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ITAL 196 , and SPAN 196. Taught in English. Two additional hours for viewing films (every two weeks).

Course: FR 200 — French Creative Writing and Translation Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Develop creative writing and translation skills while expanding vocabulary and French grammar. Writing cues are oral, visual, and written. Materials for translation include music, Instagram, films, and texts from the French-speaking world. Prerequisites: FR 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in French.

Course: FR 201 — French Theater Workshop Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Study, stage, and perform scenes from famous French plays, as a way of improving spoken French and learning about French and Francophone theater. Prerequisites: FR 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in French.

Course: FR 210 — French Conversation Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Interactive preparation for conversation with native French speakers. Development of skills in conversation, grammar, vocabulary, and culture by engaging with current events in graphic novels, online news, and social media. Prerequisites: FR 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Taught in French.

Course: FR 211 — French in the Professions Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the vocabulary, practices, history, and expectations of a professional field in France, including science, law, medicine, business and human rights. High-intermediate language training using authentic texts. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: FR 104 (or equivalent), or consent of instructor.

Course: FR 212 — Stories, Sights, and Sounds from the French-Speaking World Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the culture, history, and geography of the French-speaking world outside of France, including Sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa, Quebec, and the Caribbean. Prerequisites: FR 104 (or equivalent), or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Stories, Sights, and Sounds from the French-Speaking World
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 213 — France Past and Present Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of the cultural history of France through literary texts, original source documents and other cultural artifacts. Prerequisites: FR 104 (or equivalent), or consent of the instructor.

Course: FR 214 — Conversational French through Popular Culture and Media Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of French popular culture and media using authentic materials. Intermediate to advanced training in developing and refining communication skills with emphasis on pronunciation, idiomatic expressions, and monitoring grammatical errors. Prerequisites: FR 104 (or equivalent), or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Conversational French through Popular Culture and Media
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 215 — Paris in Film Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of multicultural Paris in French films. Conversational and writing practice with grammar, vocabulary, and cultural information about films, the history and culture of Paris, and comparisons between Paris and Chicago as global cities. Prerequisites: FR 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in French.

Course: FR 295 — Science Fiction and Fantasy in the French-Speaking World Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of science fiction and fantasy through literature, graphic novels, and film in the French-speaking world. Course Information: Taught in English. Recommended Background: Successful completion of a 100-level class in the Humanities and ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Science Fiction and Fantasy in the French-Speaking World
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 296 — Independent Study Subject: French (FR) Credits: 1-3 Description: For majors and minors in French who wish to supplement regular courses or undertake individual study projects. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: FR 297 — Paris in Literature, Film, and Culture Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Examines cultural and literary representations of Paris as well as the influence of Parisian urbanism on French cultural and literary genres and forms. Course Information: Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Paris in Literature, Film, and Culture
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 298 — French Literature, Drama and/or Film in Translation Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: In-depth examination of a topic relevant to French literature, culture, or film, focusing on critical thinking and analysis. Course Information: Previously listed as FR 198. Taught in English. Recommended Background: Successful completion of a 100-level class in the Humanities and ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: French Literature, Drama and/or Film in Translation
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 300 — Topics in Film and Media of the French-Speaking World Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to film history and analysis; includes reading, writing, and speaking about both film and text. Prerequisites: Two 200-level French courses (or equivalent); or one 200-level French course plus concurrent registration in a second 200-level French course; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Film and Media of the French-Speaking World
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 301 — Topics in French and Francophone Literature Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Intensive study of a period, theme, genre, or author within French or Francophone literature, with emphasis on literary analysis and critical writing. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in FR 211 or Grade of C or better in FR 212 or Grade of C or better in FR 213 or Grade of C or better in FR 214 ; and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 211 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 212 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 213 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 214 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Taught in French.

metadata.class_name: Topics in French and Francophone Literature
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 302 — Topics in French and Francophone Culture Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 Description: Intensive study of French or Francophone culture within a particular period; focus on literary and/or historical texts in the context of social and intellectual movements. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in FR 211 or Grade of C or better in FR 212 or Grade of C or better in FR 213 or Grade of C or better in FR 214 ; and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 211 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 212 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 213 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 214 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Taught in French.

metadata.class_name: Topics in French and Francophone Culture
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 303 — Writing in the Discipline Subject: French (FR) Credits: 1 Description: Focus on raising students' skills of written expression and critical research in French to a high level proficiency. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above, and approval of the department. Corequisites: In order to register for FR 303 , students must be concurrently registered for either FR 300 , FR 301 or FR 302. Course Information: Taught in French.

Course: FR 370 — Writing and Research in the Major Subject: French (FR) Credits: 1 Description: Perfecting writing and expository skills in English. Required for majors in the department. Prerequisites: Junior or senior standing and approval of the department. Course Information: Same as ITAL 370 and SPAN 370.

metadata.class_name: Writing and Research in the Major
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 397 — Internship Subject: French (FR) Credits: 0-3 Description: Professional field experience with an agency, organization, or firm that has significant ties to a French-speaking region or community, in the private or public sector. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in FR 211 or Grade of C or better in FR 212 or Grade of C or better in FR 213 or Grade of C or better in FR 214 ; and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice.

Course: FR 398 — Research Subject: French (FR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Experience with designing, implementing and presenting a research project in collaboration with a member of the French and Francophone faculty. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in FR 211 or Grade of C or better in FR 212 or Grade of C or better in FR 213 or Grade of C or better in FR 214 ; and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours. No more than 3 credit hours of FR 398 may be applied toward the major or minor.

Course: FR 400 — French in Style: Advanced Speaking, Writing and Research Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced study of grammar and syntax, with emphasis on precision and flexibility of oral and written expression, critical awareness of style, and fundamentals of translation. Prerequisites: One 300-level course (or equivalent), or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: French in Style: Advanced Speaking, Writing and Research
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 401 — Reading French for Graduate Students Subject: French (FR) Credits: 4 Description: Grammar, vocabulary, general and specialized reading practice; for graduate students wishing to fulfill French reading requirements for the Ph.D. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit may not be applied toward a graduate degree. Taught in English. Recommended Background: Some prior experience with elementary French.

Course: FR 417 — Topics in Seventeenth-Century French Literature Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Significant works, authors, and cultural developments from seventeenth-century France, including but not limited to the reign of Louis XIV, will be studied in their historical, intellectual, and cultural context. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), if topics vary. Taught in French.

Course: FR 418 — Topics in Eighteenth-Century French Literature Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Significant genres, movements, authors, and works from the French Enlightenment and Revolution will be studied within the context of artistic, social, cultural, legal and political developments of the era. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), if topics vary. Taught in French.

Course: FR 419 — Topics in Nineteenth-Century French Literature Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Significant genres, movements, authors, and works from the "long" nineteenth century (1789-1914) in France and the French-speaking world will be studied within the context of artistic, social, cultural and political developments of the era. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), if topics vary. Taught in French.

Course: FR 420 — Topics in Twentieth-Century French Literature Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Significant works, authors, and cultural developments from twentieth-century France will be studied in their historical, intellectual, and cultural context. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), if topics vary. Taught in French.

Course: FR 422 — Topics in Francophone Literature Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Significant genres, movements, authors, and works from areas of the Francophone World outside metropolitan France will be studied within the context of their historical, literary, cultural and political developments. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; or consent of the instructor FR 301 (Topics in French and Francophone Literature) or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), if topics vary. Taught in French.

Course: FR 440 — Topics in French and Francophone Cinema Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Significant films from either France or another Francophone part of the world will be studied in their historical, intellectual, and cultural context. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hour. Same as MOVI 440. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hours of credit for undergraduates, or 12 hours of credit for graduate students, as long as the topic is different for each registration. Taught in English. Students who intend to use French 440 toward the major in French must complete assignment in French.

metadata.class_name: Topics in French and Francophone Cinema
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 448 — Foundations of Second Language Teaching Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an introduction to second language acquisition research and its implications for communicative language teaching. Emphasis is on creating activities to develop high school students' communicative abilities in speaking and listening. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor and three courses at the 200 and 300 levels. Course Information: Same as GER 448 and SPAN 448. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English.

Course: FR 449 — Teaching Second Language Literacy and Cultural Awareness Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the nature of literacy as a reciprocal relationship between readers, writers, texts and culture. Students learn the practical and theoretical foundations of classroom teaching of second language reading and writing skills. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor and three courses at the 200 and 300 levels. Course Information: Same as GER 449 , and SPAN 449. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Second Language Literacy and Cultural Awareness
metadata.subject: French (FR)

text: Course: FR 464 — Topics in French Cultural Studies Subject: French (FR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An interdisciplinary approach to French culture, including history, literature, beaux-arts, and philosophy. Each topic focuses on a specific period between the Middle Ages and the present. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), if topics vary. Taught in French.

Course: FR 470 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: French (FR) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the department. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: FR 471 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: French (FR) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, credit or concurrent registration in FR 470 , and approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in FR 470 , and approval of the department Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in FR 470 , and approval of the department Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): FR 470 Coreq Codes (parsed): FR 470

Course: FR 496 — Independent Study Subject: French (FR) Credits: 1-4 Description: Supervised study in an area not covered by regularly scheduled courses under the direction of a faculty member designated by the chairperson of the department. Prerequisites: French major with senior or graduate standing and consent of the department. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major.

Course: GAMD 200 — GPPA Special Topics in Medicine Subject: Guaranteed Admissions Medicine (GAMD) Credits: 1 Description: Exploration of the interplay of scientific foundations of medicine, the skills of the physician-patient interaction, and the necessary use of emerging medical technologies. Course Information: May be repeated for credit. Students may register for more than one section per term with the approval of the College of Medicine.

Course: GEOG 100 — Concepts in Geography Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 Description: Geographic concepts drawn from the areas of cultural, urban, economic, global, and regional geography. Course Information: Same as US 100. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GEOG 161 — Introduction to Economic Geography Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 Description: With a focus on non-Western cultures and economies, this course examines how factors of production, economic activities, and institutions alter local economies, individual and collective livelihoods and cultural practices. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GEOG 203 — Human Geography of Latin America including the Caribbean Region Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 Description: Culture, settlement, political and economic development problems in Latin America, with special attention to Puerto Rico, the Caribbean Region, and Mexico. Course Information: Same as LALS 217. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Human Geography of Latin America including the Caribbean Region
metadata.subject: Geography (GEOG)

text: Course: GEOG 207 — Ancient Civilizations of Mexico and Central America Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and interpretation of the archaeological evidence on the process of development of native civilization in the Meso-American area from the beginnings of agricultural settlement to the eve of the Spanish conquest. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 ; or sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 227 , and LALS 258.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Civilizations of Mexico and Central America
metadata.subject: Geography (GEOG)

text: Course: GEOG 208 — Mapping the Urban: Cartography and its Alternatives Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 Description: Maps both represent space and influence the spatial imaginary. From traditional cartography to new media, the course will explore the power and possibilities of mapping and counter-mapping as narratives of space, power and social relations. Course Information: Same as US 208. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Mapping the Urban: Cartography and its Alternatives
metadata.subject: Geography (GEOG)

text: Course: GEOG 273 — Ethnography of Southeast Asia Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of selected cultures of mainland Southeast Asia, with emphasis on cultural ecology, tribal formation, and nationalism. Course Information: Same as ANTH 273. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GEOG 418 — Ethnographic and Qualitative Research Methods Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Practical introduction to the techniques of social scientists for research in natural social settings: participant observation/non-participant observation, interviewing, use of documentary sources, etc. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Same as ANTH 418. 3 undegraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GEOG 425 — Field Techniques in Archaeology Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 4 Description: Exposure to field methods in archaeology through participation in an actual research project. Students are instructed in field excavation techniques. Usually offered in summer session. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 or consent of the instructor. Recommended: Concurrent registration in ANTH 426 or GEOG 426. Course Information: Same as ANTH 425. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Practice.

Course: GEOG 426 — Laboratory Techniques in Archaeology Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 4 Description: Exposes students to laboratory methods in archaeology through the analysis of excavated materials. Students are instructed in laboratory techniques. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 or consent of the instructor. Recommended: Concurrent registration in ANTH 425 or GEOG 425. Course Information: Same as ANTH 426. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: GEOG 429 — Archaeological Methods Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: This course will familiarize students with various methodologies used by archaeologists and geo-archaeologists. Course will concentrate on a different method each time it is taught. Course Information: Same as ANTH 429. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s). Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: GEOG 444 — Management of Solid and Hazardous Wastes Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 Description: Management of solid and hazardous waste, including radioactive waste: landfills, incineration, recycling, composting, source reduction, groundwater and air pollution impacts, control, regulations, siting, health impacts. Course Information: Same as CME 423 , and EOHS 472.

metadata.class_name: Management of Solid and Hazardous Wastes
metadata.subject: Geography (GEOG)

text: Course: GEOG 453 — Seminar in Cultural Ecology Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Cultural ecology and cultural evolution, emphasizing peasant farming and other subsistence systems. Soil management under shifting and sedentary agriculture. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 or GEOG 151 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 453. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GEOG 455 — Quantitative Methods Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introductory statistics course in statistical methods for anthropological problem-solving. Primary emphasis is on univariate and bivariate statistics, such as means standard deviations, correlation, chi square, t-tests, and simple regressions. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 455. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: GEOG 469 — Geographic Information Systems for Planning and Policy Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Applications of Geographic Information Systems to understanding spatial relationships for their importance in planning use and policy making across a variety of disciplines/policy sectors. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Students in the Geospatial Analysis and Visualization minor must first complete US 261 and US 361 , in this sequential order. Priority registration will be given to students admitted to a campus certificate program in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization. Course Information: Same as UPP 461. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Geographic Information Systems for Planning and Policy
metadata.subject: Geography (GEOG)

text: Course: GEOG 477 — Remote Sensing of the Environment Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 4 Description: Principles and practices of processing and interpretation of remotely sensed imagery including aerial photographs, radar and multispectral satellite images. Hands-on use of image-processing software. Course Information: Same as ANTH 477. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: GEOG 481 — Geographic Information Systems I Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 4 Description: Components and performance properties of geographic information systems. Geographic hierarchies and data structures. Problems and solutions in handling large geographic files. Geocoding. Prerequisites: GEOG 100 and one from GEOG 278, GEOG 386, IDS 100; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 481. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: GEOG 482 — Geographic Information Systems II Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 4 Description: Application of raster (or grid) based geographic information systems to the spatial analysis of landscapes. Course Information: Same as ANTH 482. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: GEOG 483 — Geographic Information Systems III Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 4 Description: Problems encountered in the analysis and portrayal of geographic data. Topics include taxonomy, regionalization, trend surface analysis, time series, markov probabilities, and computer cartographic procedures for displaying output from analytic procedures. Prerequisites: GEOG 482 or ANTH 482 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 483.

Course: GEOG 496 — Internship Subject: Geography (GEOG) Credits: 1-4 Description: Professional field experience with an agency or organization in the private or public sector on projects related to the student's area of specialization. Prerequisites: Declared major in anthropology, minor in geography or full graduate standing in anthropology or geography and consent of the faculty advisor, head of the department, or the director of internship programs. Course Information: Same as ANTH 496. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Only 4 hours of credit may be applied toward the Minor in Geography. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: GER 100 — Introduction to Germanic Cultures and Literatures Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory texts on culture and literature of German-speaking countries are studied in the context of their European and international significance. Course Information: No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Germanic Cultures and Literatures
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 101 — Elementary German I Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 4 Description: Introductory exposure to language and culture of German-speaking countries with use of current materials. Prerequisites: For students who have not studied German or placement as determined by test score. Course Information: This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: GER 102 — Elementary German II Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of GER 101. Increased exposure to language and culture of German-speaking countries, with use of current materials. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GER 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of a computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: GER 103 — Intermediate German I Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of GER 102. Intensive exposure to the language and culture of German-speaking countries, with use of current materials. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GER 102 or grade of C or better in GER 106; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: GER 104 — Intermediate German II Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of GER 103. Exposure to multiple textual and aural genres and socio-cultural situations to familiarize students with contemporary life in the German-speaking world. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GER 103 ; or appropriate score on the placement test. Course Information: A blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: GER 120 — Study of Gender, Class, and Political Issues in German Texts Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Portrayal of relationships between men and women, classes, and political interest groups in German literature. Course Information: Same as GWS 120. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Readings, lectures, and discussions in English. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Study of Gender, Class, and Political Issues in German Texts
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 122 — Minority Perspectives in the Germanic Context Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Investigation of the challenges and/or opportunities of multicultural societies by examining in a socio-historical context texts created by members of Europe's ethnic, religious, and national minorities. Course Information: Same as JST 122 and RELS 122. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Minority Perspectives in the Germanic Context
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 123 — Introduction to Yiddish Culture and Literature Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Yiddish culture in Europe and the U.S. in socio-historical context. Focus on the role of Yiddish in conceptions of secular, cultural, religious, national Jewish identities. Course Information: Same as JST 123 and RELS 123. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture and Literature
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 125 — Diaspora, Exile, Genocide: Aspects of the European Jewish Experience in Literature and Film Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Literature and films on European Jewish responses to anti-Semitism and persecution in a historical context to reveal the condition of post-Enlightenment German-speaking Jewish and Yiddish-speaking societies. Course Information: Same as JST 125 and RELS 127. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Taught in English. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Diaspora, Exile, Genocide: Aspects of the European Jewish Experience in Literature and Film
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 161 — German Language Studies Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3-16 Description: A four-week summer course taken in a German-speaking country. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours.

Course: GER 207 — European Cinema Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of the major developments in European cinema from the post-World II period to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as MOVI 207 and SPAN 207.

Course: GER 211 — Exploring German-Speaking Cultures Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of cultural and political aspects of German-speaking cultures. High-intermediate to advanced language training using authentic written, visual and oral texts. Prerequisites: GER 104 or the equivalent. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: GER 212 — Rural, Urban, Global: Germanic Geographies Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of cities and places within the German-speaking world along with their correlative cultures. High-intermediate to advanced language training using authentic written, visual and oral texts. Prerequisites: GER 104 or the equivalent. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: GER 214 — Conversational German through Popular Culture and Media Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of German popular culture and media using authentic materials. Intermediate to adv training in developing and refining effective communication skills by emphasizing pronunciation, idiomatic expressions, and monitoring grammatical errors. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 104 or the equivalent. Credit or concurrent registration in GER 104 or the equivalent Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 104 or the equivalent Course Information: May be repeated. Prereq Codes (parsed): GER 104 Coreq Codes (parsed): GER 104

metadata.class_name: Conversational German through Popular Culture and Media
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)
