text: Course: GER 215 — Business Culture in German-Speaking Countries Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Oral and written communication in professional settings, including business and industry. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 104 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent. Credit or concurrent registration in GER 104 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 104 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent Course Information: Previously listed as GER 315. Prereq Codes (parsed): GER 104, GER 211, GER 214 Coreq Codes (parsed): GER 104, GER 211, GER 214

Course: GER 217 — Introduction to German Cinema Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 4 Description: German cinema as communication and art; its production, reception and ideological perspectives. Course Information: Taught in English. No knowledge of German required. Area literature/culture. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GER 219 — Princesses and Storytellers: Fairy Tales by the Brothers Grimm and Their Cultural Afterlives Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Analyzes the structure, meaning, and function of fairy tales and their continuing impact on literature, film, and contemporary culture since the Brothers Grimm. Course Information: Taught in English. Area literature/culture. No knowledge of German required. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: Princesses and Storytellers: Fairy Tales by the Brothers Grimm and Their Cultural Afterlives
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 228 — The Making of Modern Germany: The Nation in the World, 1750-1918 Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the history of the Germans in Central Europe and beyond, from 1750 to 1918. The course considers the multifaceted processes of nation-building in politics, socioeconomic, and especially culture, in a global context. Course Information: Same as HIST 228. Taught in English. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Making of Modern Germany: The Nation in the World, 1750-1918
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 240 — Classical German Thought Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of classical German thought and history through literature, philosophy, and culture. Course Information: Taught in English. No knowledge of German required. Students who intend to use GER 240 toward an undergraduate major or minor in the Department of Germanic Studies will do assignments in German. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: GER 299 — Becoming Transcultural: Study Abroad Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 0-17 Description: Provides credit for foreign study in German-speaking countries. Proposal for Study Abroad must have prior approval of Department of Germanic Studies and College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. Final determination of credit made upon completion of work. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; and approval of the department and approval of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. In exceptional cases students may be permitted to take this course after the first freshman semester. Students must be in good academic standing. Course Information: May be repeated. May be repeated for a maximum of 34 hours of credit per academic year.

Course: GER 300 — Writing in the Study of German Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 1 Description: Perfecting skills of written expression in English or German. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or approval of the department. Must be taken concurrently with a course that receives credit toward a major offered by the Department of Germanic Studies, as specified in the Timetable. Restricted to majors and minors in the Department of Germanic Studies.

metadata.class_name: Writing in the Study of German
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 302 — Topics in German Cinema Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: In-depth focus on a particular area of German cinema, such as Weimar cinema, Nazi cinema, queer cinema, etc. Topics vary. Prerequisites: Any MOVI course. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: GER 310 — Contemporary German Language, Culture and Society Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Focus on contemporary German culture and society through analysis of visual, written and oral texts. Advanced training in German language skills and in cultural competence. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 212 or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent. Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 212 or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 212 or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): GER 211, GER 212, GER 214 Coreq Codes (parsed): GER 211, GER 212, GER 214

metadata.class_name: Contemporary German Language, Culture and Society
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 311 — German Literature in a Global Context Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of German literature within a European and international context. Advanced training in German language skills. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 212 ; or Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent. Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 212 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 211 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 212 Credit or concurrent registration in GER 214 or the equivalent Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): GER 211, GER 212, GER 214 Coreq Codes (parsed): GER 211, GER 212, GER 214

metadata.class_name: German Literature in a Global Context
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 318 — Topics in Germanic Literatures and Cultures Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Prominent persons, genres, themes or movements in the areas of Germanic literature, ideas, and art. Topics vary. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary. Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Germanic Literatures and Cultures
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 333 — Topics in Genres in Germanic Studies Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: The study of genres such as novel, drama, poetry, autobiography, philosophy; and critical reflections on the genre. Prerequisites: GER 211 or GER 212 or the equivalent. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term. Area: literature/culture.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Genres in Germanic Studies
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 398 — Honors Project Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 Description: Independent study. Prerequisites: Completion of 12 hours of courses toward the major, with a grade point average of at least 3.60 in these courses, and prior approval of the department. Restricted to majors in the Department of Germanic Studies. Course Information: May not be taken in the term in which student expects to graduate.

Course: GER 399 — Independent Study Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 1-3 Description: Individual study under faculty direction for qualified students with special interests and needs not met by regularly offered courses. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: GER 401 — Research in German Studies Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Capstone course with focus on research in a variety of areas under the umbrella of German Studies. Individual research projects and focused analysis of visual, written and oral texts. Advanced training in German language skills. Prerequisites: GER 211 or GER 212 or the equivalent. Credit or concurrent registration in GER 310 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 310 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours for undergraduates, or 0 hours for graduate students. Majors and minors outside the Department of Germanic Studies may repeat this course to a maximum of 6 hours. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 310. Prereq Codes (parsed): GER 310 Coreq Codes (parsed): GER 310

Course: GER 404 — Yiddish for Reading Knowledge Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Preparation for the Graduate Proficiency Exam. Basic components of Yiddish grammar, sentence structure, and vocabulary. Selected texts in the original language will be studied. Prerequisites: GER 211 ; or consent of the instructor or graduate standing. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Does not satisfy the graduation requirement in foreign languages.

Course: GER 408 — Introduction to Translation Theory Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The study of translation theory and its application to translating German texts of various types into English. Appropriate for students who want to become translators. Prerequisites: GER 212 or the equivalent, or graduate standing. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Area: language.

Course: GER 411 — The City as Cultural Focus Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Interdisciplinary study of urban culture with focus on German-speaking countries. Prerequisites: For majors and minors in the Department of Germanic Studies only: GER 212 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CEES 411. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Taught in English. No knowledge of German required. Students who intend to use GER 411 toward a degree offered by the Department of Germanic Studies will do assignments in German. Area: literature/culture.

Course: GER 415 — Business Practices in German-Speaking Countries Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Extensive practice in the writing of business correspondence and formal presentations. Prerequisites: GER 215 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GER 437 — Contemporary Germanic Literature Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Literature of the German-speaking world since World War II, with emphasis on current issues and recent critical approaches to literature. Prerequisites: GER 211 or the equivalent, or graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Area: literature/culture.

Course: GER 438 — The Faust Legend Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Discusses Goethe's Faust within the context of European and non-European literatures. Traces the origins, significance, and interpretation of the Faust figure. Course Information: Same as CEES 438. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. Area: literature/culture.

Course: GER 439 — Gender and Cultural Production Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Issues of gender representation and gender politics examined through the use of theoretical texts or through the study of women authors. Prerequisites: GER 212 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CEES 439 and GWS 439. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Taught in English. Students who intend to use GER 439 toward a degree offered by the Department of Germanic Studies will do assignments in German. Area: literature/culture.

Course: GER 448 — Foundations of Second Language Teaching Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an introduction to second language acquisition research and its implications for communicative language teaching. Emphasis is on creating activities to develop high school students' communicative abilities in speaking and listening. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor and three courses at the 200 and 300 levels. Course Information: Same as FR 448 and SPAN 448. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English.

Course: GER 449 — Teaching Second Language Literacy and Cultural Awareness Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the nature of literacy as a reciprocal relationship between readers, writers, texts and culture. Students learn the practical and theoretical foundations of classroom teaching of second language reading and writing skills. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor and three courses at the 200 and 300 levels. Course Information: Same as FR 449 , and SPAN 449. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Second Language Literacy and Cultural Awareness
metadata.subject: Germanic Studies (GER)

text: Course: GER 461 — German Abroad Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 0-17 Description: Taken in a German-speaking country. Lectures, seminars, and practical work in German language, literature, and civilization. Prerequisites: GER 104 or the equivalent, a 2.75 overall grade point average, a 3.00 grade point average in Germanic Studies, and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 34 hours.

Course: GER 487 — Computer Assisted Language Learning Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An introduction to computer assisted language learning (CALL): the use of computer technology in second language reading and research. The effectiveness of CALL technology is assessed based on SLA theory and research studies. Prerequisites: LING 483 or CIE 483 or GER 448 or FR 448 or SPAN 448 or GER 449 or FR 449 or SPAN 449 ; or SPAN 502 or FR 502 or the equivalent; and senior standing or above. Course Information: Same as LING 487 and SPAN 487. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required.

Course: GER 492 — Internship in International Business Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 0-12 Description: Student placement in an international organization or firm in a German-speaking country or its U.S. subsidiary or division. Prerequisites: GER 211 ; and consent of the instructor and a GPA of 2.00. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. Recommended Background: Concurrent registration in GER 493 or registration in GER 493 in the semester immediately following.

Course: GER 493 — Internship Seminar: Business Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 1-4 Description: Academic component of the internship experience. Studies in the field of the internship and further investigation of related topics. Prerequisites: GER 211 and credit or concurrent registration in GER 492 and consent of the instructor and a grade point average of 2.00. Credit or concurrent registration in GER 492 and consent of the instructor and a grade point average of 2 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 492 and consent of the instructor and a grade point average of 2 Course Information: May be repeated with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. A maximum of 3 hours of credit may be applied toward an undergraduate degree offered by the Department of Germanic Studies, and a maximum of 4 hours of credit may be applied toward a graduate degree offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Prereq Codes (parsed): GER 492 Coreq Codes (parsed): GER 492

Course: GER 494 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the department. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: GER 495 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: Germanic Studies (GER) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, credit or concurrent registration in GER 494 , and approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in GER 494 , and approval of the department Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GER 494 , and approval of the department Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): GER 494 Coreq Codes (parsed): GER 494
Course: GKA 101 — Elementary Ancient Greek I Subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA) Credits: 4 Description: The fundamentals of ancient classical Greek, including the reading of simple prose.
Course: GKA 102 — Elementary Ancient Greek II Subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA) Credits: 4 Description: Continues GKA 101. Grammar and reading. Prerequisites: GKA 101.

Course: GKA 103 — Intermediate Ancient Greek I Subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to Greek philosophers and historians. Selections from Plato, Thucydides, Demosthenes, and other Attic prose writers. Prerequisites: GKA 102.

Course: GKA 104 — Intermediate Ancient Greek II Subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to Greek epic and tragedy. Readings from Homer and Euripides. Prerequisites: GKA 103.

Course: GKA 299 — Independent Reading Subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA) Credits: 3 Description: Individual study under faculty direction. For students qualified by preparation and interest. Prerequisites: GKA 104 or the equivalent. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: GKA 498 — Advanced Topics in Ancient Greek Literature Subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive reading of ancient Greek literature. Topics vary. Prerequisites: 4 hours of ancient Greek at the 200-level or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Ancient Greek Literature
metadata.subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA)

text: Course: GKA 499 — Independent Reading Subject: Greek, Ancient (GKA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Individual study under faculty direction. For students qualified by preparation and interest. Prerequisites: 4 hours of ancient Greek at the 200-level or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: GKM 101 — Elementary Modern Greek I Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 4 Description: Fundamentals of standard modern Greek at the beginning level, including pronunciation, grammar, reading, conversation, and composition.

Course: GKM 102 — Elementary Modern Greek II Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 4 Description: Continues study of standard modern Greek grammar, reading, conversation, and composition. Prerequisites: GKM 101.

Course: GKM 103 — Intermediate Modern Greek I Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 4 Description: Introduces complex grammatical constructions. Improves speaking and writing ability. Develops oral composition of standard modern Greek. Greek used for conversation, English for explanation. Prerequisites: GKM 102 or the equivalent.

Course: GKM 104 — Intermediate Modern Greek II Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 4 Description: Further develops writing, speaking, and comprehension. Focuses on idiomatic expressions. Lectures often conducted in Modern Greek. Prerequisites: GKM 103 or the equivalent.

Course: GKM 105 — Modern Greek Culture Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to a variety of aspects of modern Greek culture, including basic information about the country. Readings consist partly of secondary literature (i.e., non-literary texts) and partly of relevant examples of Modern Greek literature. Course Information: Taught in English. World Cultures course.

Course: GKM 203 — Modern Greek Authors in Translation Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 3 Description: Basic introduction to the literary output of Modern Greece, looking at its historical and literary background, sampling some of the main poets and novelists (particularly of the 19th and 20th centuries), also with a look at Greek-American writing. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. World Cultures course. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: GKM 209 — The Byzantine Empire Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 3 Description: The East Roman Empire from its creation by Diocletian and Constantine to its conquest by the Ottoman Turks. Course Information: Same as HIST 209.

Course: GKM 285 — Cultural History of Modern Greece: 1453 to the Present Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the cultural history of modern Greece, from the end of the Byzantine Empire in 1453 to the end of the present. Course Information: Taught in English. Same as HIST 285. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Cultural History of Modern Greece: 1453 to the Present
metadata.subject: Greek, Modern (GKM)

text: Course: GKM 286 — Modern Greek Cities: Historical-Ethnographic Survey Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 3 Description: This course is designed as an historical and ethnographic survey of the communities and culture of Modern Greek urban centers, from the early modern period to the present. Course Information: Taught in English. Same as HIST 286. Past course.

Course: GKM 296 — Fascism and Dictatorship in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 3 Description: Establishment of fascist and authoritarian regimes in 20th-century Spain, Italy and Greece. Fascist ideology, leadership cult, mass politics, violence and propaganda, uses of antiquity, resistance and consent, legacy and memory of fascism. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Past course. Course Information: Same as HIST 296 and POLS 296. Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Fascism and Dictatorship in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean
metadata.subject: Greek, Modern (GKM)

text: Course: GKM 298 — Topics in Modern Greek Studies Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics at an intermediate level in Modern Greek Studies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term. Taught in English. Recommended Background: GKM 105.

Course: GKM 299 — Independent Study Subject: Greek, Modern (GKM) Credits: 1-4 Description: An individual study under faculty direction in which a student can examine various apects of Modern Greek culture & languge through readings and papers. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: GKM 105.

Course: GLAS 100 — Introduction to Global Asian Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the study of Asia as well as transoceanic and transnational Asian diasporas, emphasizing the study of Asian histories, languages, cultures, and politics, Asian American histories and cultures. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. World Cultures course.

Course: GLAS 105 — Asian and/or Asian American Studies Seminar Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 1 Description: A seminar on an area of current interest in the field of Asian and/or Asian American studies. Topics may vary. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Previously listed as ASAM 105.

metadata.class_name: Asian and/or Asian American Studies Seminar
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 109 — East Asian Civilization: Ancient China Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to Chinese civilization, including history, philosophy, and religions from earliest times to c. 1500. Course Information: Same as HIST 109. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GLAS 120 — Introduction to Asian American Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of Asian American experiences and perspectives in socio-historical context. Introduction to major concepts, issues, and debates in the field of Asian American Studies. Course Information: Same as SOC 120. Previously listed as ASAM 125. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: GLAS 123 — Introduction to Asian American Literature Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of a wide range of Asian American literature in various socio-historical contexts. Course Information: Same as ENGL 123. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: GLAS 125 — Introduction to the Art and Architecture of Asia Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Using cross-cultural case studies, this course introduces students to some of the major artistic methods, monuments, and themes associated with Asian art and architecture. Course Information: Same as AH 125. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Art and Architecture of Asia
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 200 — Gandhi: The History and Practice of Nonviolence Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: The history of Gandhian practice of nonviolent resistance through a variety of thinkers and movements. Course Information: Same as HIST 200. Recommended Background: ENGL 160 or completion of any 100-level history course. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Gandhi: The History and Practice of Nonviolence
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 201 — Asian Markets, Corporations, and Social Justice Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: A critical analysis of multinational corporations as social institutions and their commodification and representation of Asian and Asian American cultures and economies. Includes topics like KPop, fair trade, sweatshops, and the beauty industry. Prerequisites: GLAS 100 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 201.

metadata.class_name: Asian Markets, Corporations, and Social Justice
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 207 — Asian Cities: Urban Cultures of the Global South Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: The dynamics of urbanization in a number of Asian cities, including Mumbai, Shanghai, Singapore and Dubai, that have emerged as important nodes in the global economy, and that exemplify contemporary urban culture as it manifests cross-culturally. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 207.

metadata.class_name: Asian Cities: Urban Cultures of the Global South
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 209 — Advanced Chinese Language and Culture Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Chinese culture as reflected in language, communication, daily life, and creative works. Intensive listening, speaking, reading and writing at the intermediate-advanced level. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHIN 104 ; or Grade of C or better in CHIN 112; or appropriate score on the department placement test or equivalent AP or IB Test score. Course Information: Same as CHIN 209. Not intended for students with native proficiency in Chinese. This course may be taught in a blended-online format. See class schedule for specifics. Extensive computer and internet use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: GLAS 210 — Asian American Histories Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the main historical events that define the Asian experience in the United States, from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. Course Information: Same as HIST 210. Previously listed as ASAM 210. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: GLAS 215 — Techno-Orientalism: Race, Media and Society Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: An investigation of the historical entanglements of race, politics, and technoscience in the Pacific world from the 19th century to the present. Throughout, we examine representations of Asian and Asian American cultures of science and technology. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course. Course Information: Same as HIST 215.

Course: GLAS 217 — Introduction to Filipino American Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the experiences of Filipinos in the U.S. that explores issues of colonialism, immigration, culture, and politics. Course Information: US Society course.

Course: GLAS 219 — Art and Architecture of East Asia Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the historic and contemporary art and architecture of China, Korea and Japan, as well as the architecture and art of Asian Diasporas. Course Information: Same as AH 219. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Art and Architecture of East Asia
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 220 — Buddhist Art and Architecture Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: A chronologically and thematically organized survey of Buddhist art and architecture in Asia and beyond. Course Information: Same as AH 220 and RELS 220. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GLAS 223 — Global Hip-hop and Asian Diasporas Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Hip-hop across Asian and Asian American communities through diasporic, transnational, comparative, and performance perspectives. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100. Creative Arts course.

Course: GLAS 224 — Archaeology of Mainland Southeast Asia Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the archaeology of mainland Southeast Asia, ranging from the appearance of early peoples to the rise of states such as the Angkorian Khmer Empire. Prerequisites: ANTH 101 or ANTH 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 224.

Course: GLAS 228 — Sociology of Asia and Asian Americans Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Asian and Asian-American culture, institutions, and organization; immigration, population, settlement patterns; occupations and poverty; family and ethnic identification; inequality and politics; values, prejudice, discrimination. Prerequisites: SOC 100. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as SOC 228.

metadata.class_name: Sociology of Asia and Asian Americans
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 229 — Introduction to Asian Film Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: A theoretical analysis of films by recognized masters of Asian cinema. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as MOVI 229 and ENGL 229. Previously listed as ASST 229. Taught in English. Films contain English subtitles. One film per week will be screened outside of class. Students may choose to attend the official screenings or watch the films on their own.

Course: GLAS 230 — Cultural Politics of Asian American Food Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: A cross-disciplinary examination of Asian American identity and community formations through an analysis of the intersections of food, culture, and Asian American experiences. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as ASAM 230. Recommended Background: GLAS 120. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Cultural Politics of Asian American Food
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 231 — Politics and Society of China Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Main issues of contemporary Chinese politics and social change; the decline of the last imperial dynasty; the republican era; the rise of communism and China under the rule of Mao Zedong; and the reform period (post-1978). Prerequisites: POLS 130 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as HIST 231 and POLS 231.

Course: GLAS 232 — Politics in Korea Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Sources, dynamics, and patterns of politics in the two Koreas. Comparison of North and South Korea. Prerequisites: POLS 130 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as POLS 232.

Course: GLAS 242 — Introduction to Arab American Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses key themes in Arab American Studies: immigration and racism; family, gender, and sexuality; socio-economic class; religious affiliation; arts and cultures; and politics and political activism. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. US Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 242.

Course: GLAS 244 — Arab and Asian Connections in the U.S. and Globally Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: A comparative study of contemporary Arab and Asian communities in the US and around the globe that examines issues of militarism/war; immigration/displacement; racism; and social justice activism. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. US Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 244.

metadata.class_name: Arab and Asian Connections in the U.S. and Globally
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 248 — Afro Asian Solidarities Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of the radical possibilities of transnational alliances and the long history of cross-racial solidarities between Asia and Africa, Asians and Africans, both globally and in the U.S. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. US Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 248 and GWS 248.

Course: GLAS 250 — Critical Issues in Community Engagement Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: A cross-disciplinary and critical examination of community engagement, activism, and social justice in the context of Asian America. Prerequisites: GLAS 120. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Previously listed as ASAM 275.

Course: GLAS 252 — U.S. Racism and Imperialism Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines histories and narratives of U.S. imperialism and racism. Investigates how U.S. imperial power is inextricably tied to the workings of racial difference and hierarchy. Same as BLST 252. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100 or Grade of C or better in BLST 100 or Grade of C or better in BLST 101. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: GLAS 255 — Introduction to Middle East and Muslim Feminisms Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to Middle East and Muslim feminisms that draws on the social sciences. Emphasizes intersections of family, religion, nation, colonialism, militarism, gender, and sexuality. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 255 and GWS 255.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Middle East and Muslim Feminisms
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 263 — Asian American Gender and Sexual Diversity Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory, cross-disciplinary examination of issues related to gender and sexuality among Asian Americans, with critical attention paid to diverse experiences across various social and political contexts. Prerequisites: GLAS 120 or GLAS 123 or GWS 101 or GWS 102. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as GWS 263. Previously listed as ASAM 263.

metadata.class_name: Asian American Gender and Sexual Diversity
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 264 — The Pacific Rim in Modern History Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Critical examination of the connected histories of various societies in the modern Pacific Rim world, including the American West, Asia, and Latin America, since the nineteenth century. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Past course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as HIST 264.

metadata.class_name: The Pacific Rim in Modern History
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 270 — Topics in Asian Cultures and Societies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of a specific theme that will introduce in comparative context the major countries in Asia. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary. Previously ASST 270.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Asian Cultures and Societies
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 271 — Late Imperial China Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: A detailed survey of China's late imperial period, covering a broad range of issues from state institutions and elite power, to popular culture and peasant revolt. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 271. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GLAS 272 — China Since 1911 Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Twentieth-century China from 1911 to the present, including warfare; areas of intellectual inquiry; changes in government, family, and the role of women. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 272. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: GLAS 274 — Cultures of Global Vietnam Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Vietnamese American histories, culture, politics, and creative arts in comparative, relational, and transnational perspectives. Emphasis on artists, activists, and scholars living in Vietnam and in the diaspora. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 274 and HIST 274.

Course: GLAS 275 — History of South Asia to 1857 Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: South Asian history from the earliest times to 1857, in regional and global contexts. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 275. Course is offered in both face-to-face and hybrid/online formats. Check the class schedule for details. When taught online or hybrid, students will be required to have reliable internet access and a means for accessing it (computer preferable). Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GLAS 276 — Modern South Asia Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines anti-colonial resistance to British rule starting with the 1857 Revolt, Indian nationalism, and the formation of independent nation-states in South Asia. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 276. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GLAS 278 — Topics in the Art, Architecture and Visual Culture of Asia Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in the art, architecture, and visual cultures of Asia and Asian diasporas. Course Information: Same as AH 278. May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the Art, Architecture and Visual Culture of Asia
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 279 — South Asian Cultures and Societies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the people and cultures of South Asian Cultures; emphasis on social structure, religion, and recent cultural changes. Course Information: Same as ANTH 279. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GLAS 290 — Special Topics in Asian American Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Study of a specific intermediate topic in Asian American studies. May be repeated if content does not duplicate previous coursework. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Previously listed as ASAM 290.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Asian American Studies
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 300 — Global Asia in Chicago Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Interdisciplinary exploration of Asian diasporic histories and community formations in Chicago through academic coursework that examines dynamics of globalization in the local context. Prerequisites: GLAS 100.

Course: GLAS 328 — Asian American Literature Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Historical development of Asian American literature. It will identify specific cultural and political issues that have shaped the broad range and diverse ethnic interests of that writing. Course Information: Same as ENGL 328. Recommended Background: ENGL 123 , ENGL 240, or ENGL 243.

Course: GLAS 340 — Immigration, Law, and Rights Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the histories, cultures, and experiences of immigration to the United States by examining legal discourses and historical analyses alongside cultural productions such as literary and visual narratives. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100. Course Information: Same as CLJ 340.

Course: GLAS 390 — Special Topics in Asian American Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Reading, study, and discussion of selected topics in Asian American Studies. Prerequisites: GLAS 120. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Previously listed as ASAM 390.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Asian American Studies
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 394 — Special Topics in Asian Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 Description: Special topics of study in Asian history and culture. Prerequisites: At least one Global Asian Studies course at the 100 or 200 level; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary.Students may register for more than one section per term. Previously listed as ASST 394.

Course: GLAS 400 — Blacks and South Asians in London Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 6 Description: A survey of the separate and overlapping politics, cultures, and histories of London's Black and South Asian communities since World War II. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as AAST 400.

metadata.class_name: Blacks and South Asians in London
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 428 — Asian/Asian American Women in the Global Economy Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the racialization and feminization of a global division of labor and focuses primarily on Asian and Asian American women's participation and incorporation as workers and key actors in the development of the global economy. Prerequisites: At least one GLAS or GWS or SOC course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 428 and SOC 428. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ASAM 428.

metadata.class_name: Asian/Asian American Women in the Global Economy
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 437 — The Indian Ocean World: Contact, Commerce, Culture Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The movement of people, goods, religious movements and ideas, throughout the Indian Ocean region from earliest times to the colonial era. Course Information: Same as ANTH 436 and HIST 437. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: The Indian Ocean World: Contact, Commerce, Culture
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 438 — Women in South Asian History Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: A study of the diversity of women's experiences in South Asia in a range of social, cultural, and religious contexts from the ancient period to the present. Prerequisites: 3 hours of History or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 438 and GWS 438. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GLAS 441 — Topics in Asian American Literature and Culture Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An advanced seminar that examines various forms of cultural production by Asian American artists of diverse ethnic backgrounds. Topics vary. Course Information: Same as ENGL 441. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: ENGL 327, ENGL 328 , or ENGL 359; senior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Asian American Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 458 — Asian America and Transnational Feminism Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced, cross-disciplinary examination of feminism among Asian Americans from critical race and decolonizing perspectives and in a transnational context. Prerequisites: At least one GLAS or GWS course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 458. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ASAM 458.

Course: GLAS 463 — Politics of Gender and Sexuality in Asian America Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced, cross-disciplinary examination of issues related to gender and sexuality among Asian Americans, with critical attention paid to feminist and queer perspectives on the politics of representation and identity construction. Course Information: Same as GWS 463. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ASAM 463.

metadata.class_name: Politics of Gender and Sexuality in Asian America
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 465 — Asian Diasporas in Latin America Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines Asian migration to Latin America, covering topics such as labor and economic systems, transnational networks, community building, racism, identity, and serial migration. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100 or Grade of C or better in HIST 161. Course Information: Same as HIST 465 and LALS 465. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: HIST 264.

Course: GLAS 471 — Topics in Asian Art and Architecture Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in the art and architecture of Asia. Prerequisites: 3 hours of Asian art and/or architecture or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as AH 471. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Asian Art and Architecture
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 473 — Topics in East Asian History Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of East Asian history or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 473. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: GLAS 479 — Culture and Colonialism in South Asia Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the emergence of colonial cultures of domination and resistance on the Indian subcontinent from the 18th century to 1947. Course Information: Same as ANTH 479 and HIST 479. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Culture and Colonialism in South Asia
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 490 — Advanced Topics in Asian American Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a specific advanced topic within Asian American Studies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours if topics vary. Previously listed as ASAM 490.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Asian American Studies
metadata.subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS)

text: Course: GLAS 494 — Advanced Topics in Asian Studies Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of selected topics in Asian history and culture. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. Previously listed as ASST 494.

Course: GLAS 495 — Independent Study Subject: Global Asian Studies (GLAS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Faculty-supervised independent reading or research on a specialized topic in Asian studies and/or Asian American studies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Previously listed as ASAM 495.

Course: GWS 101 — Gender in Everyday Life Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An interdisciplinary introduction to GWS that draws on the humanities and social sciences. Emphasizes intersections of gender, race, sexuality, class, and nation. Addresses historical and contemporary debates, focusing primarily on U.S. concerns. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: GWS 102 — Global Perspectives on Women and Gender Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An interdisciplinary introduction to Gender and Women's Studies that draws on the humanities and social sciences. Emphasizes intersections among gender, race, sexuality, class and nation. Addresses historical and contemporary debates, focusing primarily on global concerns. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Global Perspectives on Women and Gender
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 120 — Study of Gender, Class, and Political Issues in German Texts Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Portrayal of relationships between men and women, classes, and political interest groups in German literature. Course Information: Same as GER 120. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Readings, lectures, and discussions in English. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Study of Gender, Class, and Political Issues in German Texts
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 192 — Latin American Women Writers in Translation Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to literature by Latin American women from the seventeenth century to the present. Focus on the role literature has played in the negotiation of gender identities in the private and the public spheres. Course Information: Same as LALS 192 and SPAN 192. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Women Writers in Translation
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 202 — Comparative Social Movements Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: International social movements involving issues of women, gender, and sexuality. Content varies. Prerequisites: GWS 101 or GWS 102 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: GWS 203 — Introduction to Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Studies Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: LGBTQ studies; current personal, political, and cultural issues, including: coming out, hate crimes, transgender communities, queer of color critique, military, AIDS, families, religion, activism, representations in literature, film, and media.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Studies
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 204 — Gender and Popular Culture Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of representations of gender and sexuality in popular and material culture, using contemporary theories. Focus is on US popular culture. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 101 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 101 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103 Course Information: Same as COMM 204. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 101 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in GWS 102 or Credit or concurrent registration in COMM 103. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Prereq Codes (parsed): GWS 101, COMM 102, GWS 102, COMM 103 Coreq Codes (parsed): GWS 101, COMM 102, GWS 102, COMM 103

Course: GWS 205 — Disability, Race, Class and Gender Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Invites students to engage in a critical dialogue around disability, race, class and gender through an intersectional and interdisciplinary frame of analysis. Course Information: Same as DHD 205. Individual and Society course.

Course: GWS 211 — Sex and Gender in the Ancient World Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of the construction of gender and its relationship to love and sexuality in the ancient world through literature and art. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Same as CL 211.

metadata.class_name: Sex and Gender in the Ancient World
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 224 — Gender and Society Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Sociological perspectives on gender as a factor in social stratification; gender role acquisition; individual and social consequences of changing social definitions of gender roles. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or GWS 101 or GWS 102. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as SOC 224.

Course: GWS 232 — Sex Roles: Moral and Political Issues Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical inquiry into controversies surrounding the changing roles of men and women. Course Information: Same as PHIL 232. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Sex Roles: Moral and Political Issues
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 238 — Biology of Women Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An evolutionary perspective on the biology of women from conception to menopause, in light of current research on genetics, hormones, and development. Topics include sexual differentiation, sex differences, and life history. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ANTH 105 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 238. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: GWS 240 — Music, Gender and Culture Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the intersection of music, gender and sexuality in different historical periods and cultures. Study of music's role in the formation and expression of gender identity in classical and popular music. Course Information: Same as MUS 240. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: GWS 244 — Women in Russian Literature Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Major works by and about women in Russian literature: experiences of women and societal attitudes toward them. Course Information: Same as RUSS 244. Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GWS 245 — Introduction to Gender, Sexuality and Literature Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to literary texts in Western and other traditions that explore issues of gender and sexuality. Course Information: Same as ENGL 245. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Gender, Sexuality and Literature
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 247 — Women and Literature Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to reading English, American, and global literature in English with a focus on gender, genre, and women's representation and authorship. Course Information: Same as ENGL 247. Previously listed as ENGL 111. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: GWS 248 — Afro Asian Solidarities Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of the radical possibilities of transnational alliances and the long history of cross-racial solidarities between Asia and Africa, Asians and Africans, both globally and in the U.S. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. US Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 248 and GLAS 248.

Course: GWS 252 — Sexuality in America: Historical Perspectives Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Sexuality as a force in U.S. history. Topics include Victorianism, marriage and courtship, sexual subcultures, censorship and purity crusades, popular culture, and various "sexual revolutions." Course Information: Same as HIST 252. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: GWS 255 — Introduction to Middle East and Muslim Feminisms Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to Middle East and Muslim feminisms that draws on the social sciences. Emphasizes intersections of family, religion, nation, colonialism, militarism, gender, and sexuality. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 255 and GLAS 255.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Middle East and Muslim Feminisms
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 259 — Women and Gender in American History Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Cultural, social, economic developments of gender relationships and women's lives from the seventeenth century to the present; political and ideological responses; feminism. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 259. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Women and Gender in American History
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 261 — Reading Black Women Writing Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines inscriptions of race, gender, class, and sexuality as they shape the literary and critical practices of black women writers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in a 100-level Black Studies or African American literature course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 261 and ENGL 261.

Course: GWS 262 — Constructions of Gender, Race, Health, and Human Rights Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores issues at the intersections of gender, race, and sexuality through the lens of health in both U.S. and non-U.S. contexts. Prerequisites: GWS 101 or GWS 102 ; and sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 262.

metadata.class_name: Constructions of Gender, Race, Health, and Human Rights
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 263 — Asian American Gender and Sexual Diversity Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory, cross-disciplinary examination of issues related to gender and sexuality among Asian Americans, with critical attention paid to diverse experiences across various social and political contexts. Prerequisites: ASAM 123 or ASAM 125 or GWS 101 or GWS 102. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 263. Previously listed as ASAM 263.

metadata.class_name: Asian American Gender and Sexual Diversity
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 272 — Race, Gender, and Sexuality Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores how Black feminist and queer intellectual work on race, gender and sexuality has been used to radically reimagine what a just world would look like. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ENGL 161 Course Information: Same as BLST 272. Prereq Codes (parsed): ENGL 161 Coreq Codes (parsed): ENGL 161

Course: GWS 275 — Gender in Latin America Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Latin American women in historical perspective from pre-Columbian and Iberian societies to the present. Course Information: Same as LALS 275 and POLS 275. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: GWS 276 — Latinas in the United States Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Socioeconomic conditions and cultural experiences of Latinas in the U.S. Historical and contemporary views of labor, health, education, family, identity formation and leadership. Course Information: Same as LALS 276 , and SOC 226. Grade of C or better in ENGL 160 ; Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in ENGL 161. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: GWS 290 — Topics in the Study of Sexuality Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of a topic concerning the subject of sexuality. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the Study of Sexuality
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 292 — History and Theories of Feminism Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to feminist theory and practice throughout the world from the 19th century to the present. Course Information: Same as HIST 292. Recommended Background: GWS 101 or GWS 102.

Course: GWS 294 — Topics in Gender and Women's Studies Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Study of a problem, topic, or issue relevant to the interdisciplinary area of gender and women's studies. Content varies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor or one gender and women's studies course. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Gender and Women's Studies
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 304 — Gender and Communcation Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Speech differences and universals across genders. Talk in male-female interaction. Communication in romantic relationships. Gender issues in work settings. Prerequisites: COMM 200 and COMM 201 ; or GWS 204. Course Information: Same as COMM 304.

Course: GWS 311 — Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity and Judaism Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the root of contemporary perspectives on gender and sexuality in the early traditions of Judaism and Christianity including the Bible, the Epic of Gilgamesh, the Church Fathers, the Talmud, and legends of the saints. Course Information: Same as JST 311 and RELS 311.

metadata.class_name: Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity and Judaism
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 315 — Psychology of Women and Gender Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Critical examination of research on women and gender across the life span, including psychological aspects of reproduction, and the way that gender shapes cognition, sexuality, family, friendship, and work experiences. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PSCH 315.

Course: GWS 344 — Gender Theory Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of theories of gender in culture. Course Information: Same as ENGL 344. Previously listed as GWS 361. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, ENGL 245 , or GWS 101 -102.

Course: GWS 345 — Queer Theory Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of theoretical concerns and historical issues that inform and shape the field of queer studies. Course Information: Same as ENGL 345. Previously listed as GWS 362. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, ENGL 245 , or GWS 203.

Course: GWS 347 — Gender and Sexuality in Literature Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of works that take the status of gender and sexuality as one of their central thematic or aesthetic concerns. Course Information: Same as ENGL 347. Previously listed as GWS 363. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, ENGL 247 , or GWS 101 -102.

Course: GWS 356 — Constitutional Law: Women, Gender and Privacy Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: A multidisciplinary examination of U.S. constitutional law and politics in shaping issues of gender, privacy, race, and sexual orientation; including reproduction, labor, sexual harassment, political participation, and women and crime. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in POLS 101 or grade of C or better in POLS 112 or grade of C or better in BLST 100 or grade of C or better in BLST 103 or grade of C or better in GWS 101 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 356 , and POLS 356.

metadata.class_name: Constitutional Law: Women, Gender and Privacy
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 390 — Feminism and Social Change Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An examination of the historical development of feminist models of social change, as well as strategies of contemporary feminist activism. Prerequisites: GWS 101 and GWS 102 and GWS 292 ; and junior standing or above.

Course: GWS 394 — Intermediate Topics in Gender and Women's Studies Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: Study of a problem, topic or issue relevant to the interdisciplinary area of gender and women's studies at the intermediate level. Content varies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor or one course in gender and women's studies. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Intermediate Topics in Gender and Women's Studies
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 396 — Independent Study/Research Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent study or research in specialized area of women's studies or gender-related scholarship. Extensive reading and individual research projects. Prerequisites: Junior standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: GWS 403 — Queer Histories Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Lesbian/gay studies; issues in the history of (homo)sexuality; cultural and historical analysis of same-sexuality in several periods, including our own. Prerequisites: Junior standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 403. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 404 — Disability, Sexuality, and Health Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Explores how political, social, and cultural systems as well as historical contexts shape understandings and experiences of disability, sexuality, and health. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as DHD 404. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 406 — Topics in Black Feminist and Queer Studies Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced study of topics related to theories of race, gender and sexuality with a specific focus on black feminist and queer studies. Topics may vary. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and one 100-level course in Black Studies or one 100-level course in Gender and Women’s Studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 406. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Black Feminist and Queer Studies
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 407 — Advanced Seminar in Queer and Trans Studies Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced interdisciplinary seminar at the nexus of queer and trans studies, with a focus on the intellectual and social struggles for liberation at the intersection of race, sexuality, nation, class, indigeneity, and gender self-determination. Prerequisites: GWS 101 and GWS 102 ; or GWS 203 ; or graduate standing. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: GWS 403.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Seminar in Queer and Trans Studies
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 408 — Global Black Feminisms Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines transnational, Third Wave and Third World Black feminist approaches to global politics from historical and contemporary perspectives with a particular emphasis on the late 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century. Course Information: Same as BLST 408 and LALS 408. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Undergraduate students: at least three credit hours in BLST or GWS or LALS.

Course: GWS 409 — Women and Gender in the Middle East Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced interdisciplinary seminar examining issues of women and gender in the Middles East and Muslim societies. Historical and contemporary analyses, case studies with regional and transnational focus. Prerequisites: GWS 255 ; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Women and Gender in the Middle East
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 410 — Race, Gender and Representation: Black Bodies in Media and Mass Culture Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the ideological, cultural and economic structures that shape the representation of Black subjects in performance, visual arts, and mass media, paying close attention to gender and sexuality. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as BLST 410 and COMM 410. Recommended Background: Three or more credit hours in Black Studies or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Race, Gender and Representation: Black Bodies in Media and Mass Culture
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 417 — Latina and Latin American Feminist Thought Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Chicana/Latina and Latin American feminist texts and methods. Differential consciousness, spirituality (spiritual activism and spiritual mestizaje), curanderismo, and decolonial epistemologies. Course Information: Same as LALS 417.

metadata.class_name: Latina and Latin American Feminist Thought
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 419 — Public Health Aspects of Sexuality and Women's Health Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of human sexuality from a public health perspective with special emphasis on family planning, sexuality and behavioral effects on women's health. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as CHSC 419.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Aspects of Sexuality and Women's Health
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 424 — Gender, Crime, and Justice Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An in-depth examination of the etiology of female crime and the involvement of females in the criminal justice system as offenders, victims, and workers/professionals. Prerequisites: Two 200-level CLJ courses; junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CLJ 424. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 425 — Sociology of Gender Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Variety and change in gender roles; patterns and consequences of gender inequality; gender and sexuality; gender and social institutions such as family, economy. Prerequisites: SOC 224 , or any 100 or 200-level GWS course and an additional 200 or 300-level elective in sociology or gender and women studies; Junior standing or above; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as SOC 424. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 428 — Asian/Asian American Women in the Global Economy Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the racialization and feminization of a global division of labor and focuses primarily on Asian and Asian American women's participation and incorporation as workers and key actors in the development of the global economy. Prerequisites: At least one GLAS or GWS or SOC course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GLAS 428 and SOC 428. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours.Previously listed as ASAM 428.

metadata.class_name: Asian/Asian American Women in the Global Economy
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 438 — Women in South Asian History Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: A study of the diversity of women's experiences in South Asia in a range of social, cultural, and religious contexts from the ancient period to the present. Prerequisites: 3 hours of History or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GLAS 438 and HIST 438. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 439 — Gender and Cultural Production Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Issues of gender representation and gender politics examined through the use of theoretical texts or through the study of women authors.
