Prerequisites: GER 212 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CEES 439 and GER 439. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Taught in English. Students who intend to use GER 439 / GWS 439 toward a degree offered by the Department in Germanic Studies will do assignments in German. Area: Literature/Culture.

Course: GWS 440 — Language and Gender Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examination of sociolinguistic research and theories on the interrelationships between language and gender, including gender categories in linguistic systems, gender differences in language use, interaction, and cross-cultural comparisons. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LING 440. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as GWS 540.

Course: GWS 443 — Topics in Gender, Sexuality and Literature Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific study of topics in gender and literature. Content varies. Course Information: Same as ENGL 443. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 245, 247, 344, 345, or 347, or GWS 101 -102. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Gender, Sexuality and Literature
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 444 — Topics in Theories of Gender and Sexuality Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced study of topics related to theories of gender and sexuality. Course Information: Same as ENGL 444. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 207 -209, 245, 247, 344, 345, 347 or GWS 101 -102. Junior standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Theories of Gender and Sexuality
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 449 — Women and Film Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Roles and representations of women in classical Hollywood, European art and independent feminist cinemas. Course Information: Same as AH 449 and ENGL 449. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as GWS 472. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 330 , 344 , 345 , or 347. Junior standing or above.

Course: GWS 455 — Advanced Seminar in Feminism and Justice Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced interdisciplinary seminar on feminist theories of social justice, histories of freedom movements, and intersectional feminist theories and analyses of justice that ignited these movements. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: GWS 101 and GWS 102. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours of credit for undergraduates, or 8 hours of credit for graduate students. May be repeated if topics vary. Recommended Background: SJ 101 or SJ 201.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Seminar in Feminism and Justice
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 458 — Asian America and Transnational Feminism Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced, cross-disciplinary examination of feminism among Asian Americans from critical race and decolonizing perspectives and in a transnational context. Prerequisites: At least one GLAS or GWS course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GLAS 458. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 462 — AIDS, Politics and Culture Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the study of AIDS as a medical, social, political and cultural construction. Explores the epidemiology of AIDS, the politics of the state¿s response, how activists have addressed AIDS, and media representations of AIDS. Prerequisites: GWS 101 or GWS 102 or GWS 203 or GWS 214 and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 462. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 463 — Politics of Gender and Sexuality in Asian America Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced, cross-disciplinary examination of issues related to gender and sexuality among Asian Americans, with critical attention paid to feminist and queer perspectives on the politics of representation and identity construction. Course Information: Same as GLAS 463. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ASAM 463.

metadata.class_name: Politics of Gender and Sexuality in Asian America
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 469 — Women's Literary Traditions Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An exploration of issues such as the female aesthetic; women's popular literature; factors that enable creativity; differences of race and class. Prerequisites: ENGL 361 or ENGL 362 or ENGL 363; and senior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Same as ENGL 469. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 476 — Latinx Youth: Coming of Age in the U.S Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Discursive and cultural positioning of Latina/o/x youth in the US. Explores how youth shape identity, culture, education, politics, community. Using concept of intersectionality, explores links to gender, class, and sexuality. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Same as LALS 476 and SOC 474.

metadata.class_name: Latinx Youth: Coming of Age in the U.S
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 478 — Women in Chinese History Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Focuses on scholarship on women in Chinese society throughout history, dealing with topics such as marriage and family, literacy, career options, women in revolution and the historiography of the field. Course Information: Same as ASST 478 , and HIST 478. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Previous course work in Chinese history or women's studies.

Course: GWS 484 — Topics in the History of Women Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history or gender and women's studies or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 484. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in the History of Women
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 485 — Gender and Politics Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Impact of gender on basic categories of western political thought. Distinctions between reason and emotion, public and private, among others, examined from feminist perspective. Prerequisites: POLS 190 and one 200-level course in political theory; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 485. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: GWS 490 — Advanced Topics in the Study of Sexuality Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Special study at an advanced level of a topic concerning sexuality. Prerequisites: 3 hours of gender and women's studies, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in the Study of Sexuality
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 494 — Advanced Topics in Gender and Women's Studies Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specialized study of a problem, topic or issue relevant to the interdisciplinary area of gender and women's studies at the advanced level. Content varies. Prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Gender and Women's Studies
metadata.subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS)

text: Course: GWS 496 — Independent Study Subject: Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Individual advanced reading or research in Gender and Women's Studies, under the supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: GWS 101 and GWS 102 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Recommended Background: GWS 292 and GWS 390.

Course: HEB 101 — Elementary Hebrew I Subject: Hebrew (HEB) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the vocalization, basic vocabulary, and grammatical structure of the Hebrew language. Spoken and written Hebrew are both stressed. Prerequisites: For students who have not studied Hebrew or placement as determined by test score or consent of instructor.

Course: HEB 102 — Elementary Hebrew II Subject: Hebrew (HEB) Credits: 4 Description: The second part of an introduction to the study of the basic vocabulary and grammatical structure of the Hebrew language. Spoken Hebrew is also stressed. Prerequisites: HEB 101 or adequate performance on the placement test or consent of the instructor.

Course: HEB 103 — Intermediate Hebrew I Subject: Hebrew (HEB) Credits: 4 Description: The second year of Hebrew language study. Study of Hebrew grammar with emphasis on sentence structure for speaking and writing Hebrew. Prerequisites: HEB 102 or adequate performance on the placement test or consent of instructor.

Course: HEB 104 — Intermediate Hebrew II Subject: Hebrew (HEB) Credits: 4 Description: Focused study of Hebrew grammar and reading comprehension. Emphasis on writing and speaking Hebrew with fluency. Prerequisites: HEB 103 or adequate performance on the placement test or consent of the instructor.

Course: HIM 101 — Health Information Management First Year Seminar Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 1 Description: Overview of health information management emphasizing the key concepts of the diverse range of careers in the field. Focuses on academic and professional preparation given the integrative nature of the discipline and current trends. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Credit is not given for HIM 101 if the student has credit in HIM 410 or HIM 317 or HIM 319. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have an active UIC Net ID with valid password and access to a computer and the internet.

metadata.class_name: Health Information Management First Year Seminar
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 317 — Principles of Health Information Management Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Uses, format and content of inpatient health records; accreditation and documentation guidelines; indexes/registries, record processing and management. Virtual lab/professional site visit required. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in HIM 410. Credit or concurrent registration in HIM 410 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in HIM 410 Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): HIM 410 Coreq Codes (parsed): HIM 410

Course: HIM 319 — Alternative Health Records Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Health information systems in non-hospital care settings in the US, including organization and management, resources development, economic support and reimbursement, registries, and delivery of services. Prerequisites: HIM 317 and HIM 410 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: HIM 320 — Technical Affiliation Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 2 Description: Provides an orientation to health information management practice via assignments and field work in affiliated institution’s health information management departments. Prerequisites: Completion of 32 credit hours of HIM course work or approval of the BSHIM Program Director. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Students must have an active UIC Net ID with valid password and access to a computer and the internet.

Course: HIM 329 — Legal Aspects of Health Information Management Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Study of the principles of law, confidentiality and ethics, and their application in the healthcare field with particular reference to health records and health information management practice. Prerequisites: HIM 317 and HIM 410. Course Information: Note to Students: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Students must have an active UIC Net ID with valid password and access to a computer and the internet.

metadata.class_name: Legal Aspects of Health Information Management
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 337 — Analysis of Health Care Data Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Collection, evaluation and interpretation of HIM data will be covered. Lab section will include stats software used in HIM dept.; healthcare stats and data display. Continuing Education (CE) presentation can be used by HIM professionals CE credit. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in BHIS 406 and Grade of C or better in HIM 410 and Grade of C or better in BHIS 460 and Grade of C or better in HIM 317. Course Information: Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Students must have an active UIC Net ID with valid password and access to a computer and the internet with the ability to download data analysis software. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: HIM 343 — Quality Evaluation and Management Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of processes, internal and external to an organization, used to measure, evaluate and improve the quality, efficiency and effectiveness of health care. Directed Practice. Prerequisites: HIM 317 and HIM 329 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: HIM 361 — Human Resources Management Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasis on management of health information management staff, including hiring, discipline, union relations, inservice education, productivity measurement. Prerequisites: BHIS 480 ; and consent of the instructor.

Course: HIM 367 — Systems Analysis Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Fundamentals and tools of systems analysis. Students participate in a systems analysis project for directed practice experience. Focus on healthcare computer applications and facilities design and layout. Prerequisites: Completion of 44 semester hours of health information management coursework. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: HIM 374 — Health Information Research Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Development of a research project and CEU training program are course projects. Statistical software, research principles and methodology will be used to analyze health data. Prerequisites: HIM 337. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: HIM 377 — Current Issues in Health Information Management Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 2 Description: Discussion of current issues relevant to the health information management profession. Prerequisites: Completion of 44 semester hours of health information management coursework or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Current Issues in Health Information Management
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 384 — Clinical Practicum Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 5 Description: Consists of of field work and classroom presentations. Field work on-site at an affiliated health care organization. Insight, understanding, and skills in health information management practices, procedures and administration. Prerequisites: Completion of 44 semester hours of health information management coursework or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: HIM 386 — Independent Study Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 1-5 Description: An optional course where students perform lab work, field work, and/or in-depth descriptive studies regarding topics related to health information management. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and enrollment in health information management or health informatics program. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 5 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HIM 410 — Introduction to the Health Care System Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of the U.S. Health Services System, including its organization and management, economic support system, health care workforce, and delivery system. Course Information: Previously listed as HIM 310. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught partially or fully online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Health Care System
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 432 — Coding and Classification Systems Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to nomenclatures and classification systems with an emphasis on the ICD-10-CM coding system. The use of these systems in the inpatient hospital environment will be emphasized. Other selected coding systems also will be discussed. Prerequisites: BHIS 405 and BHIS 406 and HIM 317. Course Information: Previously listed as HIM 332. Extensive computer used required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught partially or fully online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: HIM 433 — Coding and Reimbursement Systems Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Advanced course focusing on coding and reimbursement systems; ICD-Procedure Coding System (ICD-PCS), Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) coding, data quality management, revenue cycle, coding compliance and management reporting. Prerequisites: BHIS 405 and HIM 432. Course Information: Previously listed as HIM 333. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught partially or fully online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: HIM 450 — Health Information Technology and Systems Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of information technology concepts applied to the practice of health information management. Topics include electronic health record systems, information governance, privacy and security, data collection, storage, retrieval and analysis. Prerequisites: HIM 451. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have and active UIC Net ID with valid password and access to a computer and the internet.

Course: HIM 451 — Health Information Management Theory and Practice Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: An introduction to the data elements and health information systems that comprise the patient's health record in acute and alternative settings, including records management and registries. Prerequisites: Acceptance to the Mater of Science in Health Information Management program. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have an active UIC Net ID with valid password and access to a computer and the internet. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

metadata.class_name: Health Information Management Theory and Practice
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 452 — Quality Management and Data Analysis Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Examination of processes used to measure and improve the quality and effectiveness of health care, including health care research statistics and data display. Prerequisites: HIM 534 and HIM 557. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, student must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: HIM 453 — Principles of Management and Human Resources Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Principles of management with emphasis on business functions, procedures, personnel management, workforce development and productivity measurements as applied to health care settings. Prerequisites: HIM 450 and HIM 451. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet.

metadata.class_name: Principles of Management and Human Resources
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 454 — Legal Aspects, Risk Management, and Security of Health Information Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of law, confidentiality, and ethics, and their application to health records, including risk management and security in clinical information systems. Prerequisites: HIM 450 and HIM 451. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet.

metadata.class_name: Legal Aspects, Risk Management, and Security of Health Information
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 455 — Health Information Systems Analysis and Design Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 4 Description: Advanced topics in information technology and systems in healthcare. Fundamentals and tools of systems analysis and design. Use of data structures in clinical information systems including data design and management. Prerequisites: HIM 534 and HIM 557. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet.

metadata.class_name: Health Information Systems Analysis and Design
metadata.subject: Health Information Management (HIM)

text: Course: HIM 481 — Healthcare Financial Management Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 2 Description: An introduction to the principles of healthcare finance. Sources of revenue and expenses, financial statement analysis, budget, and tools to analyze financial performance will be covered. Prerequisites: BHIS 480 or equivalent experience. Course Information: Previously listed as HIM 381. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught partially or fully online. Students must have an active UIC NetID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet.

Course: HIM 486 — Foundations of Health Information Management Subject: Health Information Management (HIM) Credits: 2 Description: Provides students new to the health informatics field with knowledge of the U.S. healthcare system and health record content and practice. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and enrollment in the MS in Health Informatics program or Post Master's Certificate in Health Informatics. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Taught on-line, students must have an active UIC netID with valid password and access to a computer and the Internet.

Course: HIST 100 — Western Civilization to 1648 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the development of Western civilization and the modern world: ancient medieval and early modern history. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 101 — Western Civilization Since 1648 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the development of Western civilization in the early modern and modern world. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 103 — Early America: From Colonization to Civil War and Reconstruction Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Covers political, cultural, and social developments during the Colonial and early American period. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Early America: From Colonization to Civil War and Reconstruction
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 104 — Modern America: From Industrialization to Globalization Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the political, cultural, and social developments in American society since the end of the Civil War. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Modern America: From Industrialization to Globalization
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 105 — Global Transformations and the Rise of the West Since 1000 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of historical transformations that led to the rise of Europe and the wider West to global preeminence. Emphasizes contributions of other world cultures to this development. Course Information: Same as INST 105. This class may be taught in an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Please check the online class schedule for online sections. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Global Transformations and the Rise of the West Since 1000
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 106 — The World Since 1400: Converging Worlds, New Circulations Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of historical developments that created an interconnected world. Explorations, rise of capitalism, European colonialism, nationalism and development, and post-colonialism. Course Information: Same as INST 106. Course is offered in both face-to-face and hybrid/ online formats. Check the class schedule for details. When taught online or hybrid, students will be required to have reliable internet access and a means for accessing it (computer preferable). Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: The World Since 1400: Converging Worlds, New Circulations
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 108 — Environmental History of the World Since 1500 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: A history of the world since 1500 through the lens of the environment, with topics including indigenous relationships to nature, colonial and industrial capitalism, imperialism, disease, petro-politics, and the politics of climate change. Course Information: Same as EAES 108. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Environmental History of the World Since 1500
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 109 — East Asian Civilization: Ancient China Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to Chinese civilization, including history, philosophy, and religions from earliest times to 1500. Course Information: Same as GLAS 109. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 114 — Topics in World History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to history through global events and the historical development of diverse cultural, religious, social, economic, and political institutions. Course Information: Same as INST 114. May not be repeated for credit. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: HIST 117 — Understanding the Holocaust Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the Holocaust of European Jewry as the result of antisemitic ideology and the development of modern German political forces; implementation of the Final Solution. Course Information: Same as JST 117 and RELS 117. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 137 — Russia in War and Revolution, 1904-1922 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The revolutionary era in Russia. Exploration of the historical background of the Russian Revolution, the social and political tensions leading to revolutionary upheaval, and the roles of major leaders and ordinary citizens. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 150 — Catholicism in U.S. History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The Catholic experience in the United States from its colonial origins to the present. Course Information: Same as CST 150 and RELS 150. US Society course.

Course: HIST 161 — Introduction to Latin American History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to major themes in Latin American history from pre-Colombian society and the European conquest to the present. Course Information: Same as LALS 161. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 170 — The Ottoman Empire Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of the Ottoman Empire from the fourteenth century to World War I, with emphasis on its structure and governance in a global perspective. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 177 — Middle Eastern Civilization Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the culture and society of the Middle East, with special attention to the development of Islam and the consequences of westernization. Course Information: Same as RELS 177. Course is offered in both face-to-face and hybrid/ online formats. Check the class schedule for details. When taught online or hybrid, students will be required to have reliable internet access and a means for accessing it (computer preferable). Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 199 — Chicago and the World Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to American history, key institutions, culture, and society through the lens of Chicago as a global city. Introduction to the college experience and development of key academic skills. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: HIST 200 — Gandhi: The History and Practice of Nonviolence Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The history of Gandhian practice of nonviolent resistance through a variety of thinkers and movements. Course Information: Same as GLAS 200. Recommended Background: ENGL 160 or completion of any 100-level history course. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Gandhi: The History and Practice of Nonviolence
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 202 — Ancient Greece Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Greece from the Mycenaean through the Hellenistic periods; political, social, economic, and religious life of the Greek city-state and the Hellenistic kingdoms. Course Information: Same as CL 202. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 203 — Ancient Rome Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: History of Rome from its origins to the end of the Roman Empire; emphasis on transformation of Rome from city-state to world empire, with attention to social, cultural, and economic background. Course Information: Same as CL 203. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 204 — Greek Art and Archaeology Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Contributions of archaeological excavations to the study of ancient Greece, 600 BC to 31 BC. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as AH 204 , and CL 204. Credit is not given for HIST 204 if the student has credit in CL 215. Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 205 — Roman Art and Archaeology Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Contributions of archaeological excavations to the study of ancient Rome and her empire 1000 BC-400 AD. Architecture, sculpture and painting in their social and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as AH 205 , and CL 205. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 208 — History of Science in a Global Context Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the history of science from the 16th century to the present. From colonial science to atomic diplomacy and entrepreneurial science, this course explores how certain spaces, practices, and people—but not others—came to be called scientific. Recommended Background: Completion of any 100-level history course. Past course.

metadata.class_name: History of Science in a Global Context
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 209 — The Byzantine Empire Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The East Roman Empire from its creation by Diocletian and Constantine to its conquest by the Ottoman Turks. Course Information: Same as GKM 209.

Course: HIST 210 — Asian American Histories Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the main historical events that define the Asian experience in the United States, from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. Course Information: Same as GLAS 210. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 211 — The Dawn of European Modernity, 1500-1715 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Social, economic, political, and cultural analysis of western Europe in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discusion and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 212 — Europe: 1715 to 1815 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Europe from the death of Louis XIV to Napoleon's fall, with special emphasis on building of states, urban development, and political change.

Course: HIST 213 — Europe in the Age of Capitalism and Imperialism, 1815 - 1914 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the history of Europe from the Congress of Vienna to World War I. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: Europe in the Age of Capitalism and Imperialism, 1815 - 1914
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 214 — Twentieth-Century Europe Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Social, political, cultural, and economic changes in Europe including: WWI, Great Depression, rise of totalitarian states, WWII, the Cold War, rise and fall of communist states, and the European Union. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 215 — Techno-Orientalism: Race, Media and Society Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: An investigation of the historical entanglements of race, politics, and technoscience in the Pacific world from the 19th century to the present. Throughout, we examine representations of Asian and Asian American cultures of science and technology. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 215.

Course: HIST 217 — Introduction to United States Military History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Analytical study of American military history, doctrine, strategy, and tactics from their origin through the present. Emphasis on leadership, strategy, the principles of war, and growth of the military in the US. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. Past course. Course Information: Same as MILS 217.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to United States Military History
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 218 — Pompeii: Everyday Life in a Roman Town Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the Roman town of Pompeii, including its history, society, politics, economy, religion, art, architecture, and entertainments. Course Information: Same as AH 218 and CL 218. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Pompeii: Everyday Life in a Roman Town
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 219 — Sport in the Ancient World Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of Greek and Roman sport from the Bronze Age to the demise of pagan athletic festivals in late antiquity (c. fifth century CE). Course Information: Same as CL 219.

Course: HIST 220 — Modern Germany, 1848 to the Present Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Unification and industrialization in the nineteenth century; world wars and the development of the two Germanies in the twentieth century. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 221 — The Atlantic Slave Trade Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Thematic social, cultural and economic history tracing rise and fall of Atlantic slave trade from African supply systems to New world consumption 1550-1880 with focus on slave experiences. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as BLST 221. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 222 — England to 1689 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: England from the Celtic immigration to the Glorious Revolution. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course.

Course: HIST 223 — Modern Britain Since 1689 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: History of Britain from the Glorious Revolution to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course.

Course: HIST 224 — France: 1500 to 1715 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: French society, culture and politics, 1500-1715. It traces the development of the French monarchy and its relation to its subjects from the Renaissance to Versailles, with special emphasis on the period's cultural production and self-image. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: HIST 225 — The Age of Revolution in France: 1715-1848 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Major political, social, and economic forces in French history 1715 to 1848, including the Ancien Regime, the Enlightenment, the French Revolution, Napoleon, and the Restoration. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: The Age of Revolution in France: 1715-1848
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 226 — France and the World, 1848-present Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The history of France and its empire from 1848 to today. Takes a global approach to exploring the influence of political revolution, state building, imperialism, World Wars, decolonization, and immigration in modern France. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 228 — The Making of Modern Germany: The Nation in the World, 1750-1918 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the history of the Germans in Central Europe and beyond, from 1750 to 1918. The course considers the multifaceted processes of nation-building in politics, socioeconomic, and especially culture, in a global context. Course Information: Same as GER 228. Taught in English. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Making of Modern Germany: The Nation in the World, 1750-1918
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 229 — Black Diaspora Studies Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Interdisciplinary, in-depth study of the making of the African Diaspora--the forced and voluntary movement of African peoples around the globe. Topics may vary. Prerequisites: BLST 100 ; or BLST 101. Course Information: Same as BLST 229. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours.

Course: HIST 231 — Politics and Society of China Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Main issues of contemporary Chinese politics and social change; the decline of the last imperial dynasty; the republican era; the rise of communism and China under the rule of Mao Zedong; and the reform period (post-1978). Course Information: Same as GLAS 231 and POLS 231. Recommended Background: POLS 130 or INST 130.

Course: HIST 232 — The Religious World of the Earliest Christians Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the religious world of the earliest Christians, focusing on the ways in which early Christian ideas and practices arose out of the cultures, religions, and philosophies of the ancient Mediterranean basin. Course Information: Same as CL 232 and RELS 232. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Religious World of the Earliest Christians
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 233 — East Central Europe and the Balkans: From Empires to Nation-States Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Political, socioeconomic, and cultural developments in East Central Europe and the Balkans between the German and Russian states from the medieval period to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: East Central Europe and the Balkans: From Empires to Nation-States
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 234 — The Making of Modern Poland Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of political, socioeconomic, and cultural developments since the first Polish state, the union with Lithuania, the struggle for independence, and Communist rule to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or completion of any 100-level history course. Individual and Society course, and Past course. Course Information: Same as POL 234.

Course: HIST 235 — The Rise and Fall of Communism in Eastern Europe Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: History of state socialism in east central and southeastern Europe from the establishment of communist regimes in 1945 to their collapse in 1989 and early years of transition. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Rise and Fall of Communism in Eastern Europe
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 236 — Russia Between Europe and Asia: Eurasian Spaces and Peoples in the Premodern Era Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major political, social, economic, and cultural developments from the beginnings of Russian history to the Napoleonic invasion. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Russia Between Europe and Asia: Eurasian Spaces and Peoples in the Premodern Era
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 237 — The Russian Empire in the Modern Period: History, Culture and the Challenges of Diversity Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Major political, social, and cultural developments in the Russian empire from the time of Peter the Great to the collapse of imperial Russia in October of 1917. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Russian Empire in the Modern Period: History, Culture and the Challenges of Diversity
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 238 — Russia from Vladimir Lenin to Vladimir Putin Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of political, economic, social, and cultural development in Russia from the Revolutionary era until the present day with an emphasis on the emergence and collapse of the USSR. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Past course.

metadata.class_name: Russia from Vladimir Lenin to Vladimir Putin
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 239 — Twentieth-Century Russia in Film Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of social, political and cultural development of the Russian Empire and Soviet Union through the use of film as a historical source. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or completion of any 100-level history course. Course Information: Same as MOVI 239 and RUSS 239. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course.

Course: HIST 240 — Radicalism in America: From the Revolution to Occupy Wall Street Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The course is a sweeping survey of radical political movements and ideas in the United States from the American Revolution to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Radicalism in America: From the Revolution to Occupy Wall Street
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 241 — Precolonial Africa in World History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The history of African societies in the period before 1850 through the rise of kingdoms and territorial states, migration of peoples, the spread and impact of Islam, and west African trading networks. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 241. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 242 — History of Modern Africa Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The effect of European partition and colonialism; African military and political resistance; economic imperialism; the rise of nationalism; the problems of independence. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 242. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 243 — Black Lives in Historical Context Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Interdisciplinary survey of key episodes in black history and their relationship to contemporary black life such as slavery, abolition and resistance. The course will draw connections between historical and current aspects of black life. Course Information: Same as BLST 246. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 244 — Native American History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the history of Native North Americans from ancient to recent times, emphasizing peoples and events in what became the United States. Topics include politics, economics, diplomacy, religion, gender, race, and agency. Course Information: Same as NAST 244. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course.

Course: HIST 245 — Imagining the American West Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the political, economic, and social history of US western societies, beginning with colonization and ending with the present with special attention to persistent myths about the region. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 246 — History of American Capitalism Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the political, economic, cultural, and social history of capitalism in colonial British America and the United States, with special attention to property, labor, finance, public policy, ideology, and class relations. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 246. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 247 — African American History to 1877 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major social, economic, political, and cultural developments in African American history from the rise of the Atlantic Slave Trade to Reconstruction. Prerequisites: One course in Black Studies or History; or consent of the instructor. Past course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 247.

Course: HIST 248 — African American History since 1877 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major social, economic, and political developments in African American history since Reconstruction. Topics include Jim Crow, black leadership, migration, civil rights and nationalism. Prerequisites: One course in Black Studies or History, or consent of the instructor. Past course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 248.

Course: HIST 249 — The American Civil War Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The social, economic, and military events leading up to, during, and after the American Civil War. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 251 — War, Society, and Institutions Since 1815 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the global contexts and historical conditions of warfare in the modern era and how societies and individuals experience conflict. Past course.

Course: HIST 252 — Sexuality in America: Historical Perspectives Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Sexuality as a force in U.S. history. Topics include Victorianism, marriage and courtship, sexual subcultures, censorship and purity crusades, popular culture, and various "sexual revolutions." Course Information: Same as GWS 252. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 253 — The Worker in American Life Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the major historical transformations in the lives of American working people and the ideas, movements and organization through which they have defined a collective response to changing conditions. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 255 — History of Chicago Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: The development of Chicago from frontier outpost to post-industrial metropolis; economic, social, political, and cultural changes and institutions; suburbanization and deindustrialization. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Course is offered in both face-to-face and hybrid/ online formats. Check the class schedule for details. When taught online or hybrid, students will be required to have reliable internet access and a means for accessing it (computer preferable). Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 256 — Religion in American History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the varieties of religious experience in American history from the sixteenth to the twentieth-first centuries, with emphasis on group formation and the social and cultural consequences of American religious diversity. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as RELS 256. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 257 — U.S. Immigration History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: History of European, African, Asian and Latin American immigration to the U.S. from the colonial era to the present. Examines how ethnicity, race, gender, and age shaped immigrants’ experiences and U.S. immigration law and policy. Past course.

Course: HIST 258 — Topics in Intellectual History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Intellectual history, focusing on the development of ideas in their political, social and cultural contexts or the relationship between diverse fields, such as science, philosophy and religion. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Consent of the instructor required to repeat course.

Course: HIST 259 — Women and Gender in American History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Cultural, social, economic developments of gender relationships and women's lives from the seventeenth century to the present; political and ideological responses; feminism. text: Course: HIST 261 — Latin America to 1850 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a survey of the pre-Columbian and early national periods in Latin America. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 263 — Black Intellectual History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Key debates and contributions of black thought to national and global politics and culture since the 19th century. text: Course: HIST 266 — Modern Mexico Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction into the social, cultural, and political history of Mexico from the decades after independence to the present. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: HIST 267 — American Intellectual History to 1865 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Major issues in American intellectual history from the contacts of culture begun by European exploration on the land now known as the United States to the end of the American Civil War in 1865. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: HIST 272 — China Since 1911 Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: Twentieth-century China from 1911 to the present, including warfare; areas of intellectual inquiry; changes in government, family, and the role of women. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

text: Course: HIST 294 — Topics in Catholic History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 Description: An investigation of the impact of human migration and cultural pluralism on Catholicism and an analysis of the role of the Catholic Church in group relations. text: Course: HIST 489 — Topics in Military History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HIST 490 — Topics in Diplomatic History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HIST 492 — Topics in Intellectual History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 Hours of history. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HIST 494 — Topics in Political History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HIST 495 — Topics in Religious History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as RELS 495. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HIST 496 — Topics in Race, Ethnic and Minority History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Race, Ethnic and Minority History
metadata.subject: History (HIST)

text: Course: HIST 497 — Topics in Cultural History Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HIST 499 — History Internship Subject: History (HIST) Credits: 0-4 Description: Practical experience working "in the field" with partner institutions such as museums, historical societies and/or archives. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may take HIST 499 as many times as they wish but will only receive credit toward their major or minor the first time they take it. Repeat courses will not replace other 400-level requirements. Field work required. Students interested in the internship should contact the course instructor or the Director of Undergraduate Studies, ideally the semester before they enroll in this course. The course will sometimes be offered in face-to-face format and sometimes in a hybrid format. Check the class schedule for details. When taught with an online component, reliable internet access and a means for accessing it (computer preferable) are required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: HN 100 — Introduction to Nutrition: New Student Seminar Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Overview of nutrition emphasizing the key concepts of the discipline and the diverse range of careers in the field. Focuses on professional preparation.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Nutrition: New Student Seminar
metadata.subject: Human Nutrition (HN)

text: Course: HN 110 — Foods Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: The principles of food components, component interactions, food selection, preparation and service. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: HN 111 — Food Handling and Safety Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 1 Description: Covers principles of safe food handling, sanitation and hygiene practices to prevent foodborne illnesses. Prepares students for eligibility for the Illinois and national sanitation certification examination. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: HN 190 — Introduction to Dietetics Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 1 Description: Overview of the dietetics profession: career options, professional development (dietetics portfolio), code of ethics, standards of practice, Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics position papers, the legislative process, and professional resources. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above.

Course: HN 196 — Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Covers fundamental principles of nutrition as a science through examination of the relationship between diet and health. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: HN 201 — Essentials of Nutrition, Physical Activity and Health Assessment Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Evidence-based tools and resources for using food and physical activity to maintain health and prevent chronic disease. Prerequisites: HN 196 ; and approval of the department. Course Information: Credit is not given for HN 201 if the student has credit in HN 302.

metadata.class_name: Essentials of Nutrition, Physical Activity and Health Assessment
metadata.subject: Human Nutrition (HN)

text: Course: HN 202 — Culture and Food Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Provides a perspective on factors that affect the development of food habits, similarities and differences across cultures, and how the use of foods provides a window to multiculturalism. Course Information: Previously listed as HN 302. World Cultures course.

Course: HN 203 — Culture and Food Lab Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Practical application of accurately preparing, presenting, and modifying cultural specific foods. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in HN 202 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in HN 202 Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in HN 202. Prereq Codes (parsed): HN 202 Coreq Codes (parsed): HN 202

Course: HN 213 — Food, Health and Equity Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the interconnectedness of food systems, health equity, healthcare systems, and societal structures through the lens of the socio-ecological model. Individual and Society course.

Course: HN 296 — Nutrition and Physical Activity Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Integrates the fundamental principles of nutrition and physical activity to provide students with knowledge of proper nutrition for improving health, fitness and performance. Prerequisites: HN 196 or consent of the instructor.

Course: HN 300 — Science of Foods Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Explores relationship between the chemical structure of food components and their functional properties and applications in food product development. Covers principles of food safety, sensory evaluation, food additives and fermentation. Prerequisites: HN 111 or HN 110 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: HN 302 — Nutritional Assessment Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: In-depth training of nutrition assessment tools that Registered Dietitians will use for measuring dietary intake and anthropometric measurements in different populations and in different settings. Prerequisites: HN 196. Course Information: Previously listed as HN 200. Credit is not given for HN 302 if the student has credit in HN 200.

Course: HN 306 — Nutrition Education Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Study of theoretical and applied strategies for instructional planning and assessment that are applied to both group and individual nutrition education. Prerequisites: HN 302 or HN 201 ; or approval of the department.

Course: HN 307 — Human Nutrition and Metabolism Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Human nutrient requirements and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, vitamins, minerals and non-nutritive substances found in foods. Prerequisites: HN 196 and one semester of college level general chemistry; or consent of the instructor.

Course: HN 308 — Nutrition Science I Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Metabolism, dietary regulation and requirements for energy, protein, fat and carbohydrates, including issues of under/over nutrition and regulation of food intake. Prerequisites: HN 196 and Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 352 and Credit or concurrent registration in KN 230 and KN 231 ; and approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 352 and Credit or concurrent registration in KN 230 and KN 231 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 352 and Credit or concurrent registration in KN 230 and KN 231 Prereq Codes (parsed): CHEM 352, KN 230, KN 231 Coreq Codes (parsed): CHEM 352, KN 230, KN 231

Course: HN 309 — Nutrition Science II Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Continuation of HN 308. Metabolism, dietary regulation and requirements for micronutrients such as vitamins and minerals, including issues of under/over nutrition and regulation of food intake. Prerequisites: HN 308.

Course: HN 311 — Nutrition During the Life Cycle Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of nutrition through the life cycle, including weight management. Prerequisites: HN 307 ; or HN 308 and HN 309.

Course: HN 313 — Introduction to Community Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Assessment, planning and evaluation of community nutrition programs using a systems approach. Course Information: Previously listed as HN 413.

Course: HN 318 — Genetic, Molecular and Cellular Mechanisms of Chronic Diseases Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses the most important mechanisms of pathogenesis, with an emphasis on chronic conditions. The role of inflammation and of genetic variability in modulating disease susceptibility will be addressed in detail. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in KN 230 ; and approval of the department.

metadata.class_name: Genetic, Molecular and Cellular Mechanisms of Chronic Diseases
metadata.subject: Human Nutrition (HN)

text: Course: HN 320 — Clinical Nutrition I Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of nutrition, biochemistry, physiology, and pathology related to the management of starvation, obesity and gastrointestinal diseases, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. Prerequisites: HN 308 ; and approval of the department.

Course: HN 330 — Quantity Food Production Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Lecture/discussion on kitchen layout and design, menu planning, food procurement, storage, production and service. Prerequisites: HN 110 ; or approval of the department. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee.
Course: HN 332 — Food Service Management Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Application of management principles to food service system functions. Prerequisites: HN 110.

Course: HN 355 — Supervised Practice I Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 1-4 Description: A supervised practicum in a professional setting to prepare for entry-level dietetics practice. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in HN 320 and senior standing; and approval of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

Course: HN 394 — Special Topics in Human Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Selected nutrition topics. Topics vary from year to year and may include nutrition and physical activity, nutrition assessment, nutrition and behavior, nutrition education, food sustainability, or community engagement. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HN 396 — Independent Undergraduate Study in Human Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Study in selected areas of human nutrition carried out under the direction of a faculty member. Exact nature of the project is determined by the selected area of interest. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Independent Undergraduate Study in Human Nutrition
metadata.subject: Human Nutrition (HN)

text: Course: HN 405 — Food as Medicine I: Cooking for Healing and Wellness Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: A new disease state or medical diet will be covered each week and students will learn how to plan menus and prepare foods that are appropriate for each diet. Prerequisites: HN 110.

metadata.class_name: Food as Medicine I: Cooking for Healing and Wellness
metadata.subject: Human Nutrition (HN)

text: Course: HN 406 — Food as Medicine II Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: A wellness related diet, a disease state, or a medical topic will be covered each week. Students will learn how to plan menus and prepare foods that are appropriate to each diet. Prerequisites: HN 110 ; and approval of the department This course is designed for undergraduate and graduate students majoring in nutrition.

Course: HN 407 — Writing Process in Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Approaches writing as an instrument of thought and a tool of persuasion. Students will learn to effectively communicate nutrition information through writing. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161 ; and junior standing or above; and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated for credit. Recommended Background: HN 196 and HN 110.

Course: HN 410 — Food Microbiology Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 4 Description: Discusses food-borne pathogens, toxins, and contaminants. Covers spoilage, pathogenic and beneficial microorganisms in the food industry and microbiological techniques for isolating and quantifying microorganisms of public health concern. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: HN 411 — Food Analysis Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 4 Description: Principles and application of the chemical, physical and instrumental methods used to determine the constituents of foods. Prerequisites: CHEM 222 and HN 300 ; and approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: HN 412 — Sensory Evaluation for Foods and Beverages Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Teaches the physiological and psychological basis of human subjects, chemistry of aroma and taste, basic sensory methodologies in food evaluation and analysis and interpretation of sensory data. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department.

metadata.class_name: Sensory Evaluation for Foods and Beverages
metadata.subject: Human Nutrition (HN)

text: Course: HN 413 — Food Product Development Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of food product development: target market evaluation, concept development and presentation, formulation, manufacturing, packaging, product costs, pricing, safety and marketing. Prerequisites: HN 300 ; and approval of the department.

Course: HN 414 — Fermented Foods and Beverages Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Covers the health benefits and the chemistry and microbiology in making fermented foods and beverages. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department.

Course: HN 420 — Clinical Nutrition II Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of nutrition, biochemistry, physiology, pathology, education, and psychology related to management of selected diseases (diabetes, cancer, HIV/AIDS, renal diseases, and metabolic stress). Prerequisites: HN 308 ; or approval of the department.

Course: HN 422 — Clinical Nutrition III Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Principles of nutrition, biochemistry, physiology, and pathology related to the management of critically ill patients. Prerequisites: HN 309 and HN 420 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: HN 423 — Nutrition Counseling Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Teaches theory and skill development for effective nutrition interviewing and counseling. Experiential opportunities to practice various counseling approaches are provided. Prerequisites: HN 302 or HN 201 ; or approval of the department.

Course: HN 425 — Sports Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Designed to teach the foundations and application of sports nutrition, including how to assess, counsel and address the nutritional needs of athletes and active individuals. Prerequisites: HN 302 ; and approval of the department.

Course: HN 440 — The Research Process in Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 3 Description: Covers methods for reading and critiquing current scientific literature, overview of study designs used to address different types of research questions, basic overview of study design, data analysis and interpretation of results. Prerequisites: HN 196 ; and approval of the department.

Course: HN 455 — Supervised Practice II Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 1-11 Description: An advanced supervised practicum in a professional setting to prepare for entry-level dietetics practice. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in HN 420 and senior standing or above; and approval of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 15 hours.

Course: HN 480 — Field Study Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 2 Description: Provides practical experience to develop/strengthen the student's knowledge and skills in an area of nutrition practice. Prerequisites: HN 410 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Clinical Practice and one Conference.

Course: HN 494 — Special Topics in Human Nutrition Subject: Human Nutrition (HN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Selected nutrition topics. Topics vary from year to year and may include nutrition and physical activity, nutrition assessment, nutrition and behavior, nutrition education, food sustainability, or community engagement. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HNUR 101 — Elementary Hindi-Urdu I Subject: Hindi-Urdu (HNUR) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to and practice in speaking and comprehending spoken Hindi-Urdu and in reading and writing Hindi-Urdu in Devanagari script. Prerequisites: For students who have not studied Hindi-Urdu, or placement as determined by test score, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Four additional half hours each week in the language laboratory.

Course: HNUR 102 — Elementary Hindi-Urdu II Subject: Hindi-Urdu (HNUR) Credits: 4 Description: Continues HNUR 101. Speaking and comprehending Hindi-Urdu. Reading and writing in both Devanagari script and Urdu script. Prerequisites: HNUR 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Four additional half hours each week in the language laboratory.

Course: HNUR 103 — Intermediate Hindi-Urdu I Subject: Hindi-Urdu (HNUR) Credits: 4 Description: This course builds on the foundation of HNUR 101 and HNUR 102. Emphasis will be placed on advanced structures, reading unedited texts in both devanagari (Hindi) and nastaliq (Urdu) and the development of oral and aural competency. Prerequisites: HNUR 102 or the equivalent, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Two additional hours each week in the language laboratory.

Course: HNUR 104 — Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II Subject: Hindi-Urdu (HNUR) Credits: 4 Description: A continuation of HNUR 103. Modern prose literature and poetry in Hindi-Urdu and an introduction to the language of films. Emphasis on developing oral and aural competency. Prerequisites: HNUR 103 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Two additional hours each week in the language laboratory.

Course: HNUR 196 — Independent Study Subject: Hindi-Urdu (HNUR) Credits: 1-4 Description: Independent study under faculty direction for qualified students with special interests and needs. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: HON 101 — Freshman Orientation Seminar Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to UIC and Honors College opportunities and resources, with emphasis on strategies for success and current issues in higher education. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Honors course.

Course: HON 120 — Honors Core in Understanding Individual and Society and Understanding the Past Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 3 Description: An interdisciplinary general education course designed around a central theme. Themes address topics related to understanding the individual and society and understanding the past. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Honors course, and Honors College Reg 1 course, and Individual and Society course, and Past course.
