text: Course: HON 200 — Honors Lectures Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 0 Description: A series of special non-credit lectures arranged for honors students. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Honors course.

Course: HON 201 — Honors Seminar Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 1 Description: A series of specially arranged seminars in different areas of interest. Prerequisites: Enrollment eligibility may vary from section to section, depending upon topic. Honors course. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the Honors College.

Course: HON 202 — Honors Tutoring Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 0 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to tutor students in approved subjects. Prerequisites: Approval of the Honors College. Honors course. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the Honors College.

Course: HON 222 — Honors Activity Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 0 Description: Honors work in an approved course or individual project. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Required each fall and spring term for all Honors College students; optional for Honors College students who complete an Honors activity during the summer session. Honors course.

Course: HON 225 — Honors Research Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 0 Description: Individual research not covered by standard courses under close supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the Honors College. Honors course. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the Honors College.

Course: HON 294 — Honors Inquiries Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 3 Description: An in-depth exploration of issues confronting a topic of significance. Through reading and engaged discussion, students will learn substantive material as well as critical thinking skills. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Honors course. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: HON 301 — Foundations for the Future Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 1 Description: This 1-hour seminar provides upper-level Honors students structured support, focusing on preparation for topics in four primary areas: (1) scholarship; (2) awards; (3) career/graduate schools; and (4) long-term future issues. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Honors course.

Course: HON 322 — Honors Capstone Activity Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 0 Description: Independent, in-depth examination of an approved topic under the close supervision of a faculty advisor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Honors course.

Course: HON 401 — Advanced Honors Seminar Subject: Honors College Courses (HON) Credits: 3 Description: Student, faculty, and invited guests act as partners in the in-depth exploration of a focused topic. This interaction is fostered though common readings, written assignments, and open discussions. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and consent of the instructor. Graduate students may obtain instructor consent. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: HON 201. Honors course.

Course: HUM 110 — Introduction to the Humanities I: Critical Thinking, Writing, and Literature Subject: Humanities (HUM) Credits: 4 Description: An exploration of modes of thought and self-expression through literature and philosophy. Topics will vary. Course Information: This course is open only to students in the Odyssey Project.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Humanities I: Critical Thinking, Writing, and Literature
metadata.subject: Humanities (HUM)

text: Course: HUM 111 — Introduction to the Humanities II: U.S. History and Visual Studies Subject: Humanities (HUM) Credits: 4 Description: How humans experience, investigate, make, and represent the world. Course Information: Open only to students in the Odyssey Project.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Humanities II: U.S. History and Visual Studies
metadata.subject: Humanities (HUM)

text: Course: HUM 120 — Engaged Humanities: Understanding the Individual and Society Subject: Humanities (HUM) Credits: 4 Description: An exploration of the complex relationship between the individual and society, with special attention given to the Chicago context and activities designed to develop student research and writing skills. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ENGL 160 or placement into ENGL 161. Open only to freshmen. Course Information: Credit is not given for HUM 120 if student has credit in ENGL 161.This is a writing-intensive course with extensive practice in expository writing and revision. A grade of B or better in HUM 120 will satisfy the ENGL 161 requirement. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Engaged Humanities: Understanding the Individual and Society
metadata.subject: Humanities (HUM)

text: Course: HUM 201 — Topics in the Humanities Subject: Humanities (HUM) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to key concepts and ideas in the humanities. Students in this course may join the Engaged Humanities Initiative and receive funding for humanities research. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or HUM 120 ; or consent of the Engaged Humanities Initiative (https://ehi.uic.edu/). Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary.

Course: HUM 210 — Seminar in the Humanities Subject: Humanities (HUM) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on in-depth discussion of topics in the humanities and builds on methods introduced in HUM 110 and HUM 111. Prerequisites: HUM 110 and HUM 111 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Open only to students in the Odyssey Project.

Course: IDEA 110 — Creativity and Innovation in Design and Arts Subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA) Credits: 4 Description: Provides knowledge of the issues and factors that motivate, influence, and materialize creativity and innovation in design and arts disciplines. Course Information: Previously listed as ISA 110. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Creativity and Innovation in Design and Arts
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA)

text: Course: IDEA 120 — Digital Practices in Design and Arts Subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to key ideas and fundamentals of computing in contemporary digital practices in design and the arts disciplines. Class will expose students to exciting practitioners in the field. Course Information: Previously listed as ISA 120. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Digital Practices in Design and Arts
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA)

text: Course: IDEA 130 — Introduction to Game Studies: Play and Praxis Subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA) Credits: 4 Description: Overview of game studies as an interdisciplinary field concerning game creation, and the historical, cultural, social, and technological importance of games. Emphasis on game theory, gamification, game creation methods, and game cultures. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Game Studies: Play and Praxis
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA)

text: Course: IDEA 210 — Topics in IDEAS: Intermedia and Interdisciplinary Artforms Subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA) Credits: 4 Description: Topics designed specifically of interdisciplinary subject matter. Topics will be determined by faculty and student interest in interdisciplinary, intermedia, and transdisciplinary forms of cultural production. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Recommended Background: IDEA 110 and IDEA 120.

metadata.class_name: Topics in IDEAS: Intermedia and Interdisciplinary Artforms
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA)

text: Course: IDEA 310 — Independent Study Course for IDEA Majors Subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA) Credits: 1-4 Description: Subject matter is determined by student in collaboration with supervising faculty member. Prerequisites: IDEA 110 and IDEA 120. Recommended Background: Comfort with interdisciplinary creative practices.

metadata.class_name: Independent Study Course for IDEA Majors
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA)

text: Course: IDEA 322 — Introduction to Arts-Based Research Methods Subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA) Credits: 4 Description: Overview of arts-based research as an interdisciplinary, humanistic, and qualitative research methodology. Emphasis on applied, practice-led research in realization and refinement of interdisciplinary art projects. Prerequisites: DES 222. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Recommended Background: One year in any major in the College of Architecture, Design, and the Arts.

Course: IDEA 410 — Interdisciplinary Capstone for IDEA Majors Subject: Interdisciplinary Education in the Arts (IDEA) Credits: 4 Description: A sustained practicum in the production, discussion and theorization of work produced by seniors (in the last two semesters) of IDEA coursework. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Field work required.

Course: IDS 200 — Intro to Management Information Systems Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to concepts and application of information technology for solving business problems and supporting organizational functions. Includes hands-on instruction on use of computer-based productivity tools. Course Information: Previously listed as IDS 100. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined section final exam will be held on Thursday of finals week from 3:30 to 5:30 p.m. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: IDS 201 — Introduction to Business Programming Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: Disciplined computer-assisted problem solving. Structured programming, data types and data structures, modularization. Program design for business information- and decision-support. Prerequisites: IDS 200 and MATH 160 or the equivalent courses. Course Information: Credit is not given for IDS 201 if the student has credit for MCS 260. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: IDS 270 — Business Statistics I Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 4 Description: Working with business data. Data summarization, visualization, business insights. Probability, sampling distributions, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and introduction to linear regression. Use of software for data visualization and analysis. Prerequisites: MATH 160 or an upper-level MATH course. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: IDS 312 — Business Project Management Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: An integrative approach to learning how projects contribute to the strategic goals of the organization. Major issues: selecting projects, project management techniques and tools, budgeting, monitoring, risk mitigation, and interpersonal skills.

Course: IDS 313 — Internet Applications in Business Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: Internet business applications in entrepreneurship, finance, accounting, and marketing. Assessing business problems, planning Internet-based solutions, and understanding web tools. Students interested in further studies can continue with IDS 413.

Course: IDS 331 — Business Analysis Using Spreadsheets Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: Analyzing business cases using spreadsheet software. Effective and efficient use of Excel. Spreadsheet automation using Visual Basic for Applications. Prerequisites: IDS 200. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Recommended Background: ACTG 210.

Course: IDS 355 — Operations Management Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: Application of management sciences to the planning and design of production, distribution, and service systems. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined section final exam will be held on Thursday of finals week from 3:30 to 5:30 p.m. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: IDS 371 — Business Statistics II Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: Continuation of statistical concepts, techniques for managerial decisions. Analysis of variance, multivariate regression, time series, statistical process control, non-parametric methods. Use of statistical software for data visualization, analysis. Prerequisites: IDS 270 and MATH 165.

Course: IDS 400 — Programming for Data Science in Business Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Aims to provide students the knowledge and skills for designing and developing data science applications in various business areas, using a language such as Python. Focuses on programming constructs and use of functions and packages. Prerequisites: IDS 201and basic knowledge of programming at the level of IDS 201 or equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: IDS 270.

metadata.class_name: Programming for Data Science in Business
metadata.subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS)

text: Course: IDS 401 — Business Object Programming using Java Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 0-4 Description: Basic concepts in object-oriented programming such as objects, classes, class inheritance and interfaces, data abstraction and encapsulation, polymorphism, and dynamic binding. Prerequisites: IDS 201 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: IDS 403 — Information Security Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examine the field of information security to prepare students for their future roles as business decision-makers. Presents a balance of the managerial and technical aspects of information security. Prerequisites: IDS 200 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 405 — Business Systems Analysis and Design Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory of analysis, design and development of information systems; information management and database management systems; data management and analysis; case studies in systems implementation and evaluation. Prerequisites: IDS 201 or IDS 331. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 406 — IDS Consulting Practicum Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Students interact with businesses or non-profit organizations to design and develop technology, business and analytics-related solutions in IDS areas. Experiential learning on all project phases from investigation and analysis, through presentation. Prerequisites: Knowledge of databases, programming, statistics; or consent of instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Senior standing; and familiarity with systems analysis and design.

Course: IDS 410 — Business Database Technology Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Computer software techniques used in business with emphasis on information management and database management systems. Data management and analysis. Major types of database management systems, query languages. Prerequisites: IDS 201 or IDS 331. For BS in Data Science prerequisite is an equivalent course like CS 141. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 412 — Distributed Business Systems Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Organizational aspects and underlying concepts of distributed business systems, decentralization versus centralization issues, costs of distributed computing, and performance evaluation measures. Prerequisites: IDS 201 or IDS 330; and credit or concurrent registration in IDS 410. Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 410 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 410 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): IDS 410 Coreq Codes (parsed): IDS 410

Course: IDS 413 — Internet Technology and Management Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: The technologies of World Wide Web development. Topics include: TCP/IP, HTTP, HTML, HTML authoring, XML, ASP programming, client-side programming, and Web 2.0, web servers, database servers, business application servers and Internet. Prerequisites: IDS 201 or IDS 331 ; and IDS 410. Course Information: Credit is not given for IDS 413 if the student has credit for IDS 424. Extensive computer use required.

Course: IDS 420 — Business Model Simulation Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Simulation analysis of strategic business decision models for investment, marketing, product introduction, and operational policies concerning inventory, production planning, quality assurance and supply chain management. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 355 ; or credit or concurrent registration in IDS 331 or the equivalent. Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 355 Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 331 or the equivalent Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 355 Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 331 or the equivalent Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): IDS 355, IDS 331 Coreq Codes (parsed): IDS 355, IDS 331

Course: IDS 422 — Text Mining for Business Applications Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Text mining for business applications. It will cover document representation, text categorization and clustering, basic natural language processing techniques, sentiment analysis, probabilistic topic models and text visualization. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or FIN 330 or ECON 300 or ACTG 392 or STAT 382 or STAT 481 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 435 — Optimization for Analytics Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Optimization methods for machine learning and data science applications in business, engineering, sciences. Core formulations and algorithms for continuous, discrete, dynamic optimization problems. Why algorithms work, and implementation of methods. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or FIN 330 or ECON 300 or ACTG 392 or STAT 382 or STAT 481 and knowledge of programming at the level of IDS 201 or equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 437 — Stochastic Methods Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Stochastic processes and other applications of probability theory. Use of spreadsheet and other software tools for analysis, simulation and decision theory. Models for business operations and planning, computer systems, transportation, finance. Prerequisites: IDS 355 and IDS 371. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 446 — Decision Analysis Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Prior and posterior distributions; conjugate priors; value of information; applications to decision making in business. Prerequisites: IDS 371. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 450 — Supply Chain Planning and Logistics Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Covers concepts in designing, analyzing, improving, measuring and controlling logistics operations in modern supply chains. Students are presented with logistics concepts, techniques, planning tools, and case studies to facilitate learning. Prerequisites: IDS 355 ; and IDS 454. IDS 454 can be taken as a corequisite; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Prior coursework/experience in operations management.

Course: IDS 451 — Enterprise Operations and Supply Chain Systems Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 0-4 Description: Provides an overview of how enterprise business systems operate and are used to manage operations and supply chains in order to make effective business decisions. Prerequisites: IDS 200 and credit or concurrent registration in IDS 355 ; or credit or concurrent registration in IDS 532. Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 355 Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 532 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 355 Credit or concurrent registration in IDS 532 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Extensive computer use required. Shows students how business processes integrate within an enterprise and across the supply chain. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): IDS 355, IDS 532 Coreq Codes (parsed): IDS 355, IDS 532

metadata.class_name: Enterprise Operations and Supply Chain Systems
metadata.subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS)

text: Course: IDS 452 — Sustainability in Supply Chain Management and Operations Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: A holistic view of sustainable supply chain operations is introduced. Issues such as pollution, climate change, energy, water scarcity are discussed. LCA analyses, IPAT equation, sustainability index, recycling are covered to address the issues. Prerequisites: Concurrent registration in IDS 355. Recommended Background: Prior coursework/experience in supply chain and operations management and proficiency in Excel.

metadata.class_name: Sustainability in Supply Chain Management and Operations
metadata.subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS)

text: Course: IDS 453 — Supply Chain Management: Sourcing and Procurement Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The course materials will focus on the fundamental tools, processes and techniques in sourcing and procurement strategies, contract negotiation and management, managing supplier relationships, evaluating supplier performance, and global sourcing. Prerequisites: IDS 355 or IDS 532. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Prior coursework/experience in supply chain management.

metadata.class_name: Supply Chain Management: Sourcing and Procurement
metadata.subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS)

text: Course: IDS 454 — Introduction to Supply Chain Management Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Supply Chain Management is studied as an information-intensive, integrated system for managing material flows, logistics and inter-organizational partnership to deliver products and services. Prerequisites: IDS 355. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 455 — Data-Driven Decisions for Sustainable Business Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Leverages an evidence and data-driven approach to convert sustainability goals into decisions, evaluating financial, environmental, and social impacts. Employs a risk-focused perspective to manage short- and long-term objectives. Prerequisites: IDS 400 or equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: IDS 457 — Foundations Sustainable Bus Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to sustainable business foundations: setting sustainability goals and key performance indicators, governance, stakeholder engagement and communication, strategic operations, technology integration, financial accountability, and reporting. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ACTG 457 and MGMT 457.

Course: IDS 460 — Causal Inference Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: Conceptual foundations and methods for causal inference, using causal diagrams as well as the potential outcomes framework. Identification and estimation of causal effects in randomized control trials and observational studies. Prerequisites: STAT 481 or IDS 371 ; and STAT 382 or IDS 462. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Familiarity with statistical packages such as R, Stata, and/or SAS is recommended.

Course: IDS 462 — Statistical Software for Business Applications Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Hands-on experience with statistical software commonly used in industry. Data preparation, advanced statistical methods for business problems - marketing, finance, operations, etc. Interpretation and communication of results to guide decision making. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or FIN 330 or ECON 300 or ACTG 392 or STAT 382 or STAT 481 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 470 — Multivariate Analysis Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the structure and analysis of multivariate data. Emphasis on the multivariate normal model. Regression; tests concerning multivariate means, classification; discriminant analysis, principal components. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or FIN 330 or ECON 300 or ACTG 392 or MATH 310 or MATH 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 472 — Business Data Mining Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Data mining for business insights and decisions. Classification, trees, random forests, naïve Bayes, clustering, association rules, neural nets, recommender systems, text mining. Hands-on application to problems in finance, marketing, and operations. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or FIN 330 or ECON 300 or ACTG 392 or STAT 382 or STAT 481 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for IDS 472 if the student has credit for IDS 572.

Course: IDS 473 — Risk Management and Insurance Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to risk management. Loan and credit management; credit scoring. Risk measurements and reserves; banking and insurance capital requirements, the BASEL accord, tail events and catastrophic event insurance. Financial contracts and hedging. Prerequisites: IDS 270 or IE 342 or STAT 381 or PSCH 343 or SOC 401 ; and FIN 300. Course Information: Same as FIN 473.

Course: IDS 474 — Quality and Productivity Improvement Using Statistical Methods Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Directed experimentation for quality and productivity improvement, quality surveillance, design and analysis of two-level factorial experiments and multi-level experiments, data transformation. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Quality and Productivity Improvement Using Statistical Methods
metadata.subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS)

text: Course: IDS 475 — Database Accounting Systems Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Concepts and principles of designing database systems to perform accounting functions, applications of microcomputer accounting software packages systems design tools, and computerized transaction cycles. Prerequisites: A passing grade in both ACTG 211 and IDS 200. Course Information: Same as ACTG 475. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: IDS 476 — Business Forecasting Using Time Series Methods Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Autoregressive, moving average, and seasonal models for time series analysis and business forecasting. Forecasting using multi-variable transfer function models is also included. Prerequisites: IDS 371 or ECON 300 or ECON 400 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ECON 450. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Business Forecasting Using Time Series Methods
metadata.subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS)

text: Course: IDS 478 — Regression Analysis Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Data collection and exploration; model building; variable least squares; residual analysis; variable selection; multicollinearity; ridge regression; nonlinear regression; nonparametric regression. Prerequisites: IDS 371. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IDS 479 — Enterprise Risk Management Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Overview of enterprise-wide risk management strategies and techniques: strategies that firms employ to enhance value and minimize exposure; techniques used to identify, measure, reduce, and transfer risk. Prerequisites: FIN 300 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as FIN 479. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: IDS 473 or FIN 473.

Course: IDS 494 — Topics in Information and Decision Sciences Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics vary; selected readings; case analysis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Information and Decision Sciences
metadata.subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS)

text: Course: IDS 495 — Competitive Strategy Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 4 Description: Multidisciplinary analysis of organizational strategy and policy using case method and/or business simulation. Assignments involve extensive library research and oral and written reports. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above Senior standing in the College of Business Administration and completion of all other CBA core courses. Course Information: Credit is not given for IDS 495 if the student has credit in MGMT 495 or ACTG 495 or FIN 495.

Course: IDS 499 — Research Experience Subject: Information and Decision Sciences (IDS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the supervision of a faculty member. The faculty member and student will determinne the research project. Each student must submit a written report and each student must participate at a research event on campus. Prerequisites: Consent of the department and the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: IE 118 — Energy for Sustainable Society Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on how energy systems work today and how they can work in a decarbonized sustainable future, while still meeting the critical energy needs of global developed and developing societies. Course Information: Same as ME 118. Individual and Society course.

Course: IE 198 — Special Topics in Engineering Graphics Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 1-4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: Prerequisite may vary by section according to topic. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: IE 201 — Financial Engineering Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Principles and techniques of economic analysis in engineering; Financial decision making; Single and multi project selection techniques. Prerequisites: MATH 181.

Course: IE 312 — Dynamic Systems and Control Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Dynamics of linear systems. Modeling of mechanical, electrical, fluid, and thermal systems. Analysis and design of feedback control systems. Analytical, computer and experimental solution methods. Time and frequency domain techniques. Prerequisites: CS 109 and ECE 210 and MATH 220 ; and sophomore standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as ME 312.

Course: IE 342 — Probability and Statistics for Engineers Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Probability, random variables, mathematical expectation, discrete and continuous distributions, sampling distributions, estimation theory, and test of hypothesis. Prerequisites: MATH 181.

Course: IE 345 — Regression Applications and Forecasting in Engineering Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Single and multiple regression analysis of variance, examination of residuals, introduction to time series analysis, and analytical forecasting techniques; application to engineering system. Prerequisites: IE 342.

metadata.class_name: Regression Applications and Forecasting in Engineering
metadata.subject: Industrial Engineering (IE)

text: Course: IE 348 — Artificial Intelligence and Data Mining for Engineering Applications Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of artificial intelligence (AI), data analytics, and ethics in AI in the context of Operations and Industrial Engineering Applications. Prerequisites: IE 342. Course Information: Same as ME 348. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Artificial Intelligence and Data Mining for Engineering Applications
metadata.subject: Industrial Engineering (IE)

text: Course: IE 365 — Work Productivity Analysis Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 4 Description: Operations analysis; man-machine relationship; motion study; micromotion study, time study; predetermined time systems; performance rating; standard data techniques; work sampling; wage payment plans. Prerequisites: IE 342. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: IE 380 — Manufacturing Process Principles Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to basic manufacturing processes such as casting, bulk deformation, sheet metal forming, metal cutting. Interaction between materials, design and manufacturing method. Economics of manufacturing. Prerequisites: CME 203. Course Information: Same as ME 380.

Course: IE 391 — Industrial Engineering Practicum Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge gained in previous engineering courses within a professional, working environment. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 1 hour awarded toward degree requirements.

Course: IE 392 — Undergraduate Research Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research under close supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the head of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: IE 394 — Senior Capstone Design Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 4 Description: Systematic approach to the design process. Creative problem solving. Design methodology and engineering principles applied to open-ended design problems with inherent breadth and innovation. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as ME 394. Credit is not given for IE 394 if the student has credit for ME 396 or IE 396.

Course: IE 396 — Senior Design I Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 Description: Systematic approach to the design process. Creative problem solving. Design methodology and engineering principles applied to open-ended design problems with inherent breadth and innovation. Prerequisites: ME 347 and IE 201 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 370 ; or IE 201 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365. Open only to seniors. Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 370 Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 370 Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365 Course Information: Same as ME 396. Credit is not given for IE 396 if the student has credit in IE 444 or ME 444 or IE 445 or ME 445. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): ME 211, ME 370, IE 345, IE 365 Coreq Codes (parsed): ME 211, ME 370, IE 345, IE 365

Course: IE 397 — Senior Design Il Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: The systematic approach to the design process; creative problem solving; design methodology and engineering principles learned in ME 396 are applied to complete the Senior Design project. Prerequisites: ME 396 ; or IE 396 ; and senior standing or above. Corequisites: ME 499 or IE 499. Course Information: Same as ME 397. Credit is not given for IE 397 if the student has credit for IE 444 or ME 444 or IE 445 or ME 445.

Course: IE 411 — Mechatronics I Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 0-4 Description: Elements of mechatronic systems, sensors, actuators, microcontrollers, modeling, hardware in the loop simulations, real time software, Electromechanical systems laboratory experiments. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as ME 411. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: IE 412 — Dynamic Systems Analysis I Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Classical control theory, concept of feedback, laplace transform, transfer functions, control system characteristics, root locus, frequency response, compensator design. Prerequisites: ME 308. Course Information: Same as ME 412. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IE 441 — Ergonomics and Human Factors Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The study of principles and techniques associated with ergonomic problems. Topics include human information input and processing, human output and control, and ergonomic considerations in safety. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IE 342 or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in IE 342 or consent of the instructor Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IE 342 or consent of the instructor Course Information: Same as EOHS 441. Previously listed as IE 341. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): IE 342 Coreq Codes (parsed): IE 342

Course: IE 442 — Design and Analysis of Experiments in Engineering Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 0-4 Description: Covers different methods for statistical design of engineering experiments, executing them and analyzing their results. Prerequisites: IE 342. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, student must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Design and Analysis of Experiments in Engineering
metadata.subject: Industrial Engineering (IE)

text: Course: IE 444 — Interdisciplinary Product Development I Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Systematic approach to the design process. Creative problem solving. Cross-functional teams (w/students from other departments/colleges) research and apply new product concepts to open-ended design problems. Prerequisites: ME 347 and IE 201 ; or IE 345 and IE 201 ; and senior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ME 444. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit for IE 444 is not given if the student has credit in ME 396 or ME 397 or IE 396 or IE 397. Year-long (with IE/ ME 445 ) project course.

Course: IE 445 — Interdisciplinary Product Development 2 Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 4 Description: Cross-functional teams (w/students from AD 420 and MKTG 594 ) research and develop new product concepts. Focus on solutions to the opportunities identified in IE/ ME 444 to functional prototypes. Serves as a replacement for IE/ ME 396. Prerequisites: IE 444 or ME 444 ; and senior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ME 445. Credit is not given for IE 445 if the student has credit in ME 396 or ME 397 or IE 396 or IE 397. Year-long (with IE/ ME 444 ) project course.

Course: IE 446 — Advanced Quality Control and Reliability Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Principles of statistical quality control including control by variable and by attribute, construction and use of control charts for variables, fraction defectives and number of defects and use of standard plans, reliability and life cycle testing. Prerequisites: IE 342. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IE 461 — Safety Engineering Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Human protection systems; accident and emergency handling; manufacturing and service hazard systems. Prerequisites: IE 342 and IE 365 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as EOHS 460. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IE 463 — Manufacturing Facilities Design and Material Handling Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Facilities design functions, computer-aided plant layout, facility location, warehouse layout Minimax location, deterministic and probabilistic conveyor models. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IE 201 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 472. Credit or concurrent registration in IE 201 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 472 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IE 201 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 472 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): IE 201, IE 345, IE 365, IE 472 Coreq Codes (parsed): IE 201, IE 345, IE 365, IE 472

metadata.class_name: Manufacturing Facilities Design and Material Handling
metadata.subject: Industrial Engineering (IE)

text: Course: IE 464 — Virtual Automation Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 0-4 Description: Fundamentals of manufacturing and automation modeling using CAD/CAM and computer-integrated manufacturing methods; concepts of virtual manufacturing; industrial robots and automated factory models within virtual environments. Prerequisites: CS 107 or CS 108. Course Information: Same as ME 464. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion, and one Laboratory.

Course: IE 465 — Manufacturing Information Systems Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 0-4 Description: Design and implementation of supervisory control and data acquisition systems; manufacturing systems controller and communication networks. Prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing, or consent of the instructor; and familiarity with computer programming. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: IE 466 — Production Operation Analytics and Inventory Control Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Principles of production planning, master scheduling, job sequencing, design and control of deterministic and stochastic inventory systems, material requirement planning, and supply chain management. Prerequisites: IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 472. Credit or concurrent registration in IE 472 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IE 472 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): IE 472 Coreq Codes (parsed): IE 472

metadata.class_name: Production Operation Analytics and Inventory Control
metadata.subject: Industrial Engineering (IE)

text: Course: IE 467 — Discrete Event Computer Simulation Application Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The solution of industrial application problems by means of discrete event computer simulation. Simulation model building. Input analysis. Output analysis. In depth study of some specific simulation programming languages, with projects. Prerequisites: IE 342. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IE 468 — Virtual Manufacturing Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Virtual reality applications in manufacturing systems design, manufacturing applications of networked virtual reality, virtual reality modeling of occupational safety engineering. Prerequisites: CS 107 or CS 108. Course Information: Same as ME 468. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IE 471 — Operations Research I Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to operations research, formulation of linear programming problems, simplex methods, duality theory, sensitivity analysis, network models, and integer linear programming. Prerequisites: MATH 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. No graduate credit for industrial engineering majors.

Course: IE 472 — Operations Research II Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Nonlinear programming problems, unconstrained optimization search techniques. Kuhn-Tucker theorems, quadratic programming, separable programming, meta heuristics, goal programming, and dynamic programming. Prerequisites: CS 107 or CS 109 , and IE 471 or graduate standing. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: IE 473 — Stochastic Processes and Queuing Models Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Stochastic dynamic systems, queuing networks, probabilistic state transition models and nondeterministic decision making models. Prerequisites: IE 342 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 471 and MATH 210. Credit or concurrent registration in IE 471 and MATH 210 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IE 471 and MATH 210 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): IE 471, MATH 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): IE 471, MATH 210

Course: IE 481 — Additive Manufacturing Process Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Covers aspects of additive manufacturing. The types that are covered are generic process, design, vat photopolymerization, extrusion based, jetting, direct writing, 3D bio-printing, powder bed fusion, slicing, and data representation. Course Information: Same as ME 481. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Manufacturing Processes.

Course: IE 494 — Special Topics in Industrial Engineering Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Particular topics vary from term to term depending on the interests of the students and the specialties of the instructor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated.

Course: IE 496 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis I Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 0-8 Description: Introduction to the principles and practice of product design: specifications, evaluation of design alternatives, technical reports, and oral presentations, through independent design projects. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ME 496. Credit only given to nondegree students. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in Engineering. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: IE 497 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis II Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 0-8 Description: ntroduction to engineering design and research methods: design tools, product conception and development, simulation, prototyping, technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ME 497. Credit only given to nondegree students. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in Engineering. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: IE 499 — Professional Development Seminar Subject: Industrial Engineering (IE) Credits: 0 Description: Students are provided general information about their role as UIC MIE alumni in society and the role of the University in their future careers. Students provide evaluations of their educational experience in the MIE department. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors; and approval of the department. Must be taken in the student's last semester of study. Course Information: Same as ME 499. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: INST 105 — Global Transformations and the Rise of the West Since 1000 Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of historical transformations that led to the rise of Europe and the wider West to global preeminence. Emphasizes contributions of other world cultures to this development. Course Information: Same as HIST 105. This class may be taught in an online format. When that is the case, internet access will be required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Please check the online class schedule for online sections. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Global Transformations and the Rise of the West Since 1000
metadata.subject: International Studies (INST)

text: Course: INST 106 — The World Since 1400: Converging Worlds, New Circulations Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of historical developments that created an interconnected world. Explorations, rise of capitalism, European colonialism, nationalism and development, and post-colonialism. Course Information: Same as HIST 106. Course is offered in both face-to-face and hybrid/ online formats. Check the class schedule for details. When taught online or hybrid, students will be required to have reliable internet access and a means for accessing it (computer preferable). Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: The World Since 1400: Converging Worlds, New Circulations
metadata.subject: International Studies (INST)

text: Course: INST 114 — Topics in World History Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to history through global events and the historical development of diverse cultural, religious, social, economic, and political institutions. Course Information: Same as HIST 114. May not be repeated for credit. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: INST 130 — Introduction to Comparative Politics Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Comparative study of political institutions, political culture, and political processes in selected major countries of the world. Course Information: Same as POLS 130. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the relevant semester to determine the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: INST 184 — Introduction to International Relations Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Political, military, and economic relations between states, international organizations and transnational actors. Problems of war, imperialism and the world economy. Prospects for global cooperation. Course Information: Same as POLS 184. Extensive computer use required. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the relevant semester to determine the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: INST 200 — Topics in International Studies Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of various topics in international studies through an interdisciplinary lens, addressing issues related to world markets and development, global cultures and societies, and international security and governance. Prerequisites: Completion of a 100-level INST course. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary.

Course: INST 221 — Macroeconomics in the World Economy: Theory and Applications Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Determinants of the level of economic activity, inflation, unemployment, international economics, impact of domestic and world economy on business decisions, applications of the theory. Prerequisites: ECON 118 and ECON 119; or ECON 120 and ECON 121 ; and MATH 121. Course Information: Same as ECON 221.

metadata.class_name: Macroeconomics in the World Economy: Theory and Applications
metadata.subject: International Studies (INST)

text: Course: INST 250 — Eastern and Western Philosophies of Religion Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Eastern and Western philosophies of religion: Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, and Christianity. Course Information: Same as RELS 250. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Eastern and Western Philosophies of Religion
metadata.subject: International Studies (INST)

text: Course: INST 283 — International Political Economy Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Political underpinnings and ramifications of international economic relations. Foreign trade policy, multinational corporations, oil North-South relations, economic warfare. Course Information: Same as POLS 283. Recommended Background: POLS 184 or INST 184.

Course: INST 284 — International Security Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: International conflict and cooperation, including war, nationalism, global inequality, and the environment. Prerequisites: POLS 184 or INST 184 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 284.

Course: INST 301 — Seminar in International Studies Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Seminar in international studies addressing global themes and issues. Content varies. Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: Junior standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary. Previously listed as LAS 301.

Course: INST 333 — International Economics Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Operation of the international economy. Covers the theory and practice of international trade and international macroeconomics. Topics include exchange rates, the balance of payments, and operation of fiscal and monetary policy. Prerequisites: ECON 220 or ECON 221 or INST 221. Course Information: Same as ECON 333.

Course: INST 334 — Economic Development Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Uses economic tools to investigate the prevalence, causes and consequences of global poverty. Study the range of market failures that contribute to the persistence of poverty. Prerequisites: ECON 220 or ECON 221 or INST 221. Course Information: Same as ECON 334.

Course: INST 349 — Topics in Comparative Politics Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Selected problems in comparative politics. Prerequisites: POLS 130 or INST 130 ; and POLS 200 ; or consent of the instructor. Students seeking to register with instructor approval should contact the academic advisor for Political Science, in addition to securing permission to enroll from the course instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 349. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

Course: INST 400 — Advanced Seminar in International Studies Subject: International Studies (INST) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced examination of various topics in international studies through an interdisciplinary lens, addressing specialized issues related to world markets and development, global cultures and societies, and international security. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary.

Course: IPHS 401 — Determinants of Population Health Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduces students to where one is born, lives, learns, plays, works and ages influences overall health and health outcomes.

Course: IPHS 402 — Analytic and Research Methods in Public Health Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 6 Description: Introduces students to the analytic and research methods used to carry out the core functions of evidence-based public health.

metadata.class_name: Analytic and Research Methods in Public Health
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 403 — Public Health Systems, Management and Community Health Methods Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduces problem and case-based pedagogy in public health systems and practice, including community health intervention planning and evaluation, and organizational planning and management.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Systems, Management and Community Health Methods
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 404 — Analytic and Research Methods in Population Health Part I Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the analytic and research methods used to carry out the core functions of evidence-based public health. Corequisites: IPHS 401 or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Analytic and Research Methods in Population Health Part I
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 405 — Analytic and Research Methods in Population Health Part II Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the analytic and research methods used to carry out the core functions of evidence-based public health. Prerequisites: IPHS 404.

metadata.class_name: Analytic and Research Methods in Population Health Part II
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 409 — Global Public Health Challenges Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: An ecological approach to public health to provide a broad overview of current health problems around the world, with an emphasis on low income countries.

Course: IPHS 410 — Global Public Health Solutions Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: Utilizes readings and case studies of successful health interventions in the developing world to orient students to the field of global public health. Prerequisites: Graduate standing.

Course: IPHS 415 — Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health I Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Explores the field of cultural medical anthropology and provides a theoretical foundation allowing for understanding and exploration of anthropology's role in international health. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ANTH 216 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 415. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health I
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 416 — Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health II Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an evolutionary and biocultural approach to human biology, physiology, health and disease. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ANTH 232; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 416. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Anthropology and Global Health II
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 420 — Interprofessional Education Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 0 Description: This experience focuses on the principles in working with professions outside the discipline of public health. Prerequisites: Completion of a minimum of 10 hours of SPH credit. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Recommended Background: IPHS 401 and IPHS 402 ; and IPHS 404. Concurrent registration of IPHS 403.

Course: IPHS 421 — SPH Success Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 0 Description: Required of all incoming graduate students and is designed to help them prepare for and succeed in SPH coursework. Requirements differ by degree program and students retain access for the duration of their academic program.

Course: IPHS 430 — Epidemics of Injustice Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 2 Description: Developed through a collaboration between members of Radical Public Health and faculty who were brought together by a sense of urgency to address ongoing threats to democracy, social justice, and the public's health.

Course: IPHS 440 — Implementation Sci Research Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 4 Description: Explores the rapidly evolving topic of dissemination and implementation research and practice. Topics include theories, frameworks and models, research methods and designs, intervention adoption, fidelity, adaptation and sustainability. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Prior graduate-level introductory health care or social science research course.

Course: IPHS 450 — Foundations and Determinants of Public Health Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the foundations of public health and application of these principles to addressing key factors and determinants of population health and health equity. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; and approval of the department.

metadata.class_name: Foundations and Determinants of Public Health
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 451 — Public Health Policy, Systems and Advocacy Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: A survey course that introduces public health policies and how they come into existence and work to improve public health. Prerequisites: Graduate standing.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Policy, Systems and Advocacy
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 452 — Public Health Planning, Practice, and Evaluation Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces concepts, principles, and skills for administering public health programs (e.g. community health assessment/improvement, intervention planning, program evaluation), emphasizing community-based organizations and public agencies. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; and approval of the department. Corequisites: IPHS 450.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Planning, Practice, and Evaluation
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 453 — Public Health Management and Leadership Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 2 Description: Introduces concepts, principles, and skills relevant to public health administration, management and leadership across a wide variety of organizations. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; and approval of the department.

Course: IPHS 454 — Quantitative Methods and Analysis I Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to analytic and research methods widely used in evidence-based public health. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; and approval of the department.

Course: IPHS 455 — Quantitative Methods and Analysis II Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 3 Description: Builds on similar analytic territory content covered in Part I, but from a statistical modeling perspective. Prerequisites: IPHS 454 ; and graduate or professional standing; and approval of the department.

Course: IPHS 456 — Introduction to Research Design for Public Health Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces students to data collection techniques for qualitative and quantitative research, with an emphasis on qualitative methods, and demonstrates several methods of data collection and analysis common in public health practice. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; and approval of the department.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Research Design for Public Health
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS)

text: Course: IPHS 494 — Introductory Special Topics - Interdepartmental Subject: Interdisciplinary Public Health Sciences (IPHS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Introductory special topics in public health. Course content will vary from semester to semester. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: ISA 100 — Freshman Seminar: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Practice in the Arts Subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA) Credits: 1 Description: Focuses on methods of making connections in which students will have the opportunity to engage in relevant interdisciplinary inquiry and practice. Prerequisites: Open only to freshmen. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Freshman Seminar: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Practice in the Arts
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA)

text: Course: ISA 200 — Introduction to Interdisciplinary Arts Subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory topics course that explores the interdisciplinary thematic ties between the arts and humanities. Topics will vary between the visual and performing arts. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: ISA 299 — College of Architecture and the Arts Study Abroad Subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA) Credits: 0-18 Description: Provides credit for foreign study. Student's proposal for study abroad must have prior approval of the major department or school and the College of A & A office. Final determination of credit is made on student's portfolio and completion of work. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and approval of the department, the College of Architecture and the Arts, and the Study Abroad Office. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 36 hours per academic year or for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year.

metadata.class_name: College of Architecture and the Arts Study Abroad
metadata.subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA)

text: Course: ISA 300 — Interdisciplinary Topics Subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA) Credits: 3 Description: Studies in interdisciplinary arts which will explore significant and relevant topics in the visual and performing arts. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 and junior standing or above. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: ISA 399 — Research Experience in the Arts Subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the guidance of a faculty member who will act as research supervisor. Prerequisites: Approval of the department or college and consent of the instructor supervising the research experience. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

Course: ISA 400 — Advanced Topics in Interdisciplinary Arts Subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of advanced topics in interdisciplinary arts which include architecture, art and design, art history, music and theatre. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s).

Course: ISA 490 — International Student Exchange Program Subject: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Arts (ISA) Credits: 0-18 Description: The Student Exchange Program enables the reciprocal exchange of students between UIC and colleges or universities in other countries. There are a variety of program tailored to meet the needs of both graduate and undergraduate students. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and approval of the student's major department, the AA College office, and the Office of International Affairs. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 48 hours of credit. May be repeated for a maximum of 36 hours per academic year or for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year. Determination of the number of credits to be granted is part of the proposal approval process. Students from other UIC Colleges and Schools are eligible for the program. For more information, visit the website at http://www.uic.edu/depts/oia/resources-student/studentexchange.html.

Course: IT 101 — Java Programming for Information Technology Subject: Information Technology (IT) Credits: 3 Description: Elementary data types, arithmetic & logical operations, control structures & error handling, methods & functions, introduction to object-oriented programming design & implementation. Emphasis is placed on the development of problem-solving skills. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 121. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: CS 100 or basic computer literacy.

Course: IT 201 — Introduction to Computer Configuration and Operating System Software Subject: Information Technology (IT) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to concepts of computer configuration, and Operating System Software. Comparisons of commercially available CPU families, peripherals, system performance and evaluation. Discussions of technological developments and commercially available systems. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IT 101 or credit or concurrent registration in CS 102 or CS 107. Credit or concurrent registration in IT 101 or credit or concurrent registration in CS 102 or CS 107 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IT 101 or credit or concurrent registration in CS 102 or CS 107 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): IT 101, CS 102, CS 107 Coreq Codes (parsed): IT 101, CS 102, CS 107

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Computer Configuration and Operating System Software
metadata.subject: Information Technology (IT)

text: Course: IT 202 — Web and Multimedia Technology Subject: Information Technology (IT) Credits: 3 Description: Introduciton to internet, multimedia concepts, protocols, and tools. HTML document markup language. Web site design. Script programming for interactive web pages. Creating, editing images, video, and audio for internet use. Programming exercises. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IT 101 or credit or concurrent registration in CS 102 or CS 107. Credit or concurrent registration in IT 101 or credit or concurrent registration in CS 102 or CS 107 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in IT 101 or credit or concurrent registration in CS 102 or CS 107 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): IT 101, CS 102, CS 107 Coreq Codes (parsed): IT 101, CS 102, CS 107

Course: IT 301 — Networks and Distributed Computing Technology Subject: Information Technology (IT) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the use of computers on a network. Installation and configuring of networking components: Firewalls, nameserver and gateways. Use of both wired and wireless networks. Prerequisites: IT 201. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: IT 302 — Database Administration and Installation Subject: Information Technology (IT) Credits: 3 Description: A study of the use of existing databases (bibliographic and non-bibliographic formats), their data structure, processing and retrieval data, integrity and security, and interface design issues. Prerequisites: IT 202. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ITAL 101 — Elementary Italian I Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 4 Description: Exposure to multiple, basic textual and aural genres and socio-cultural situations to familiarize students with contemporary life in the Italian-speaking world. Course Information: No credit given if the student has credit in ITAL 102 or ITAL 103 or ITAL 104 ; or has completed any 200-, 300-, 400-, or 500-level Italian language courses; or has placed into ITAL 102 or above. This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined section final exam will be held on Monday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: ITAL 102 — Elementary Italian II Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of Italian 101. Exposure to multiple, basic textual and aural genres and socio-cultural situations to familiarize students with contemporary life in the Italian-speaking world. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ITAL 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: No credit given if the student has credit in ITAL 103 or ITAL 104 ; or has completed any 200-, 300-, 400-, or 500-level Italian language courses; or has placed into ITAL 103 or above. This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined section final exam will be held on Monday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: ITAL 103 — Intermediate Italian I Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of Italian 102. Exposure to a variety of socio-cultural situations as well as textual genres to familiarize students with contemporary Italian society. Prerequisites: ITAL 102 or ITAL 140 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Credit is not given for ITAL 103 if the student has credit in ITAL 104 or has completed any 200-, 300-, 400-, or 500- level Italian language courses; or has placed into ITAL 104 or above. This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. In the Summer this course may be available in Siena, Italy. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined section final exam will be held on Tuesday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: ITAL 104 — Intermediate Italian II Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of ITAL 103.
