Exposure to a variety of socio-cultural situations as well as textual genres to familiarize students with contemporary Italian society and public discourse. Prerequisites: ITAL 103 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Credit is not given for ITAL 104 if the student has completed any 200, 300, 400, or 500-level Italian language courses. This is a blended-online and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. In the summer, this course may be available in traditional (non-blended) format as part of the study abroad curriculum in Siena, Italy. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined section final exam will be held on Tuesday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m.

Course: ITAL 140 — Rapid Italian Language for Romance Language Speakers Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 4 Description: Italian for students who already speak one or more Romance languages. Drawing from a variety of cultural objects (e.g. film, music) this course aims at promoting comparative linguistic analysis and effective communication skills in Italian. Prerequisites: FR 104 or SPAN 104 or SPAN 114 or PORT 201 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for ITAL 140 if the student has credit in ITAL 101 or ITAL 102. Previously listed as ITAL 240. Extensive computer use required. May be offered as an 8-week asynchronous online course or 16-week blended (3 days in-person with additional online work) course.

metadata.class_name: Rapid Italian Language for Romance Language Speakers
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 196 — Totalitarianism, Writing and Cinema Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to French, Spanish, and Italian writing and films dealing with the issue of totalitarianism. Various authors are examined within a broad context of European thinking on totalitarianism. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as FR 196 , and SPAN 196. Taught in English. Two additional hours for viewing films (every two weeks).

Course: ITAL 200 — Italian at Work: Language and Culture in Practice Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Develop practical Italian language skills through real-world communication, with a focus on culture, society, and professional contexts. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in ITAL 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in Italian.

metadata.class_name: Italian at Work: Language and Culture in Practice
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 201 — Exploring Italy Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Through a critical approach to the historical identities and key socio-cultural issues of Italy’s regions, students will investigate the interconnections between geographical and social, economic, political, linguistic, and cultural differences. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in ITAL 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in Italian.

Course: ITAL 210 — Narrating Italy: Stories, Sounds, and Screens Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Italian cultural expression through storytelling in film, music, visual arts, print media, and other creative forms. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in ITAL 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in Italian.

metadata.class_name: Narrating Italy: Stories, Sounds, and Screens
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 230 — Italian and Italian American Culture and Civilization Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Italian and Italian American culture and civilization will explore key moments in Italian social history and its connection to the Italian diaspora. Course Information: Taught in English. No knowledge of Italian required. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Italian and Italian American Culture and Civilization
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 240 — Rapid Italian Language for Spanish Speakers Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 4 Description: Comparative linguistic differences between Spanish and Italian; practice in speaking, reading, and writing. Prerequisites: Native speakers of Spanish, or any 200-level Spanish courses, or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Rapid Italian Language for Spanish Speakers
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 249 — Beauty, Power, Imagination: The Italian Renaissance Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the radical changes brought forth by the Italian Renaissance in the way people thought and acted in the world, and in almost every aspect of life: art, architecture, culture, economics, politics, and society. Course Information: Same as AH 249 and CL 249. Taught in English. The program includes optional activities such as field trips to the Art Institute and to the Daley Library Rare Book Collection. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Beauty, Power, Imagination: The Italian Renaissance
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 270 — The Sopranos Effect: Myth, Migration and the Italian-American Identity Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Immigrants’ identity formation and representation as seen through literature and visual media. Focus on Italian and Italian American transnational identities and narratives in their interactions with their socio-historical contexts. Course Information: Same as ENGL 270. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. No knowledge of Italian required. This course is offered in both face-to-face (16 weeks) and online asynchronous format (8 weeks). Online courses involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Recommended Background: Completion of the University Writing Requirement. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: The Sopranos Effect: Myth, Migration and the Italian-American Identity
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 280 — Italian and Italian American Cinema Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Italian and Italian American films and cinematic movements presented within the context of Italian culture and its diaspora. Course Information: Same as MOVI 280. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. No knowledge of Italian required. Films screened with English subtitles. This course is offered in both face-to-face (16 weeks) and online asynchronous format (8 weeks). Online courses involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: ITAL 285 — Zombies, Plagues, and Other Pandemics in Literature and Visual Media Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Pandemics and their effects on human beings on a physical, emotional, and societal level, as seen through literature and visual media across nations. Course Information: Same as LCSL 285 and SPAN 285. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Zombies, Plagues, and Other Pandemics in Literature and Visual Media
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 293 — Dante's Divine Comedy Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: An in-depth study of the Divine Comedy, read in English, against the historical, religious, philosophical and cultural background of the Middle Ages. Course Information: Same as CL 293 and RELS 293. Previously listed as ITAL 193. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: ITAL 300 — Advanced Topics in Italian Literary and Cultural Studies Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced exploration of topics relating to Italian cultural studies with a special focus on Italian literature and other media. Prerequisites: ITAL 200 or ITAL 201 or ITAL 210 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours if topic is different for each registration and with consent of the instructor. Taught in Italian.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Italian Literary and Cultural Studies
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 301 — Advanced Topics in Italian Visual Media and Film Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced topics course on specific periods or movements in Italian film and other visual media. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: ITAL 200 or ITAL 201 or ITAL 210 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours if topic is different for each registration and with consent of the instructor. Taught in Italian. Recommended Background: ITAL 280.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Italian Visual Media and Film
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 302 — Advanced Topics in Gender, Politics, and Cultural Difference in Italian Studies Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Study of different cultural movements and their effect on the construction and deconstruction of national, regional, class, and gender identities in the Italian context. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: ITAL 200 or ITAL 201 or ITAL 210 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours if topic is different for each registration and with consent of the instructor. Taught in Italian.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Gender, Politics, and Cultural Difference in Italian Studies
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 303 — Contemporary Italian Language, Culture and Society Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 3 Description: Focus on contemporary Italian culture and society through the exploration of audio-visual (music, films) and written texts. Learners refine their communicative competence in Italian, critical thinking skills, and cultural and intercultural awareness. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ITAL 200 or ITAL 201 or ITAL 210 or equivalent; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in ITAL 200 or ITAL 201 or ITAL 210 or equivalent Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ITAL 200 or ITAL 201 or ITAL 210 or equivalent Course Information: Taught in Italian. Prereq Codes (parsed): ITAL 200, ITAL 201, ITAL 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): ITAL 200, ITAL 201, ITAL 210

metadata.class_name: Contemporary Italian Language, Culture and Society
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 370 — Writing and Research in the Major Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 1 Description: Perfecting writing and expository skills in English. Required for majors in the department. Prerequisites: Junior or senior standing and approval of the department. Course Information: Same as FR 370 and SPAN 370.

metadata.class_name: Writing and Research in the Major
metadata.subject: Italian (ITAL)

text: Course: ITAL 399 — Independent Study Subject: Italian (ITAL) Credits: 1-3 Description: For majors and minors in Italian who wish to supplement regular courses or undertake individual study projects. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: JPN 101 — Elementary Japanese I Subject: Japanese (JPN) Credits: 4 Description: First course of the four-semester program to develop basic Japanese skills for both oral and written communication and to develop cultural awareness and competence through learning various aspects of Japanese cultures. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This course is taught in a blended-online format. Use of computer and internet access are required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Seniors interested in this course must contact the Japanese BLP Coordinator.

Course: JPN 102 — Elementary Japanese II Subject: Japanese (JPN) Credits: 4 Description: Second course of the four-semester program to develop basic Japanese skills for both oral and written communication and to develop cultural awareness and competence through learning various aspects of Japanese cultures. Prerequisites: A grade of C or above in JPN 101 , or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This course is taught in a blended-online format. Use of computer and internet access are required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: JPN 103 — Intermediate Japanese I Subject: Japanese (JPN) Credits: 4 Description: Third course of the four-semester program to develop basic Japanese skills for both oral and written communication and to develop cultural awareness and competence through learning various aspects of Japanese cultures. Prerequisites: A grade of D or above in JPN 102 , appropriate score on the department placement test, or the equivalent AP test score. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This course is taught in a blended-online format. Use of computer and internet access are required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: JPN 104 — Intermediate Japanese II Subject: Japanese (JPN) Credits: 4 Description: Fourth course of the four-semester program to develop basic Japanese skills for both oral and written communication and to develop cultural awareness and competence through learning various aspects of Japanese cultures. Prerequisites: A grade of D or above in JPN 103 , appropriate score on the department placement test, or the equivalent AP test score. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This course is taught in a blended-online format. Use of computer and internet access are required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: JPN 196 — Independent Study Subject: Japanese (JPN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual study under faculty direction for qualified students with special interests and needs. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: JPN 200 — Advanced Spoken Japanese Subject: Japanese (JPN) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasis on advanced oral and aural proficiency. Expression of cultural and personal topics using formal and informal language. Prerequisites: JPN 104 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: JPN 210 — Advanced Japanese Language and Culture Subject: Japanese (JPN) Credits: 3 Description: Expansion of communication skills, especially speaking, through an exploration of contemporary Japanese culture. Course Information: Grade of C or better in JPN 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test.

Course: JST 101 — Introduction to Judaism Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the Jewish religion as it has developed from its roots in the Hebrew Bible until today, emphasizing its central texts and concepts. Same as RELS 121. Individual and Society course.

Course: JST 102 — Introduction to Jewish History Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of Jewish history from Biblical times until the present. Topics will range from second Temple Judea and the beginning of the diaspora through 21st-century Jewish life in America and Israel. Course Information: Same as RELS 126. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: JST 103 — Introduction to Israel Studies Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to major themes, issues, writers and contexts of the founding, establishment, and conflicts of the modern state of Israel. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: JST 117 — Understanding the Holocaust Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the Holocaust of European Jewry as the result of antisemitic ideology and the development of modern German political forces; implementation of the Final Solution. Course Information: Same as HIST 117 and RELS 117. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: JST 122 — Minority Perspectives in the Germanic Context Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Investigation of the challenges and/or opportunities of multicultural societies by examining in a socio-historical context texts created by members of Europe's ethnic, religious, and national minorities. Course Information: Same as GER 122 and RELS 122. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Minority Perspectives in the Germanic Context
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 123 — Introduction to Yiddish Culture and Literature Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Yiddish culture in Europe and the U.S. in socio-historical context. Focus on the role of Yiddish in conceptions of secular, cultural, religious, national Jewish identities. Course Information: Same as GER 123 and RELS 123. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture and Literature
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 124 — Introduction to the Hebrew Bible Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: A study of the Five Books of Moses (a.k.a Torah or Pentateuch) within the contexts of the ancient Near East and biblical literature. Course Information: Same as CL 124 and RELS 124. Taught in English. Past course.

Course: JST 125 — Diaspora, Exile, Genocide: Aspects of the European Jewish Experience in Literature and Film Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Literature and films on European Jewish responses to anti-Semitism and persecution in a historical context to reveal the condition of post-Enlightenment German-speaking Jewish and Yiddish-speaking societies. Course Information: Same as GER 125 and RELS 127. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Taught in English. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Diaspora, Exile, Genocide: Aspects of the European Jewish Experience in Literature and Film
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 203 — Israel Film: Aspects of History, Life, and Culture Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of major themes related to life in Israel via its national cinema. Historical, social, and cultural aspects of Israeli society are examined through film. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Israel Film: Aspects of History, Life, and Culture
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 220 — Modern Polish-Jewish Culture and Literatures Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Polish-Jewish literature and non-fiction works in English translation from Polish, Yiddish and Hebrew are studied as expressions of a distinct Ashkenazi or East European Jewish culture that developed on historically Polish lands. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or ENGL 161. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as POL 220 and CEES 220.

Course: JST 225 — Topics in Muslim-Jewish Relations Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Muslim-Jewish interactions from the rise of Islam until contemporary times, the relationship between Biblical and Quranic materials, the Jewish and Islamic interpretive tradition and the legal systems of the two religious traditions. Course Information: Same as CL 225 and RELS 225.

Course: JST 230 — Topics in Jewish Thought Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major topics in Jewish theology, philosophy, ethics and political thought. Course Information: Same as RELS 231. May be repeated if topics vary. Recommended Background: JST 101 or the equivalent.

Course: JST 240 — Philosophy and Revelation: Jewish and Christian Perspectives Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to philosophical ways of addressing the claim that a book (the Bible, the Quran) comes from God. Texts by Immanuel Kant, Moses Mendelssohn, and Soren Kierkegaard, among others. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as JST 141. Same as RELS 240 and PHIL 240. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Philosophy and Revelation: Jewish and Christian Perspectives
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 242 — The History of Jewish Biblical Interpretation Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Jewish interpretation of the Hebrew bible. A survey of the span of Jewish history and the wide range of cultural contexts that have impacted the understanding of the Torah. Course Information: Same as CL 242 and RELS 242. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The History of Jewish Biblical Interpretation
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 243 — Politics and Government of the Middle East Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Contemporary Middle East political institutions, culture, processes, and conflicts. Emphasis on interaction of traditional and modern forces, such as Islam, nationalism, political elites, ideologies, states. Prerequisites: POLS 130 or POLS 190; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as POLS 243.

metadata.class_name: Politics and Government of the Middle East
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 296 — Topics in Jewish Studies Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: How Jews became a modern ethnic group, how their experiences compare with other ethnic groups, and how their experiences in modern times vary from nation to nation. Course Information: Same as RELS 296. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Previously listed as JST 294.

Course: JST 311 — Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity and Judaism Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the root of contemporary perspectives on gender and sexuality in the early traditions of Judaism and Christianity including the Bible, the Epic of Gilgamesh, the Church Fathers, the Talmud, and legends of the saints. Course Information: Same as GWS 311 and RELS 311.

metadata.class_name: Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity and Judaism
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 394 — Topics in Jewish Studies Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in Jewish culture and history. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as RELS 395. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: JST 410 — Advanced Studies in Jewish Literature, Art and Culture Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in Jewish literature and/or arts, in one or more places and time periods. Prerequisites: One course in Jewish Studies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary. Recommended Background: JST 102.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Studies in Jewish Literature, Art and Culture
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 420 — Advanced Studies in Jewish Religion Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In-depth study of a period or mode of Jewish religious development or textual production, or an examination of a religious tenet or practice across various historical periods. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: JST 101 ; and JST 230 or JST 242 or JST 254. Course Information: Same as RELS 420. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary.

Course: JST 430 — Advanced Studies in Jewish Thought Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced topics in Jewish theology, philosophy, ethics or political thought. Prerequisites: One 100-level and one 200-level course in Jewish Studies. Course Information: Same as RELS 430. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: JST 475 — The Bible as Literature: Hebrew Bible Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Literary analysis of genres and themes of the Hebrew Bible and close reading of the biblical texts. Sources of the Bible and their historical context. Course Information: Same as ENGL 475 and RELS 475. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as JST 478. Taught in English. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 175 or ENGL 207 -209.

metadata.class_name: The Bible as Literature: Hebrew Bible
metadata.subject: Jewish Studies (JST)

text: Course: JST 494 — Topics in Jewish Studies Subject: Jewish Studies (JST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in Jewish studies. Prerequisites: JST 101 or JST 102 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as RELS 494. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

Course: KOR 101 — Elementary Korean I Subject: Korean (KOR) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to Korean language and culture. Intensive practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Course Information: Course is taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Seniors interested in this course must contact the Korean BLP Coordinator.

Course: KOR 102 — Elementary Korean II Subject: Korean (KOR) Credits: 4 Description: A continuation of KOR 101. An elementary level examination of Korean language and culture. Intensive practice in speaking, listening, reading and writing. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in KOR 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This course is taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: KOR 103 — Intermediate Korean I Subject: Korean (KOR) Credits: 4 Description: A continuation of KOR 102. An intermediate-level examination of Korean language and culture. Intensive practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in KOR 102 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This course is taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: KOR 104 — Intermediate Korean II Subject: Korean (KOR) Credits: 4 Description: This fourth of a four-semester basic language program in Korean and continuation of KOR 103. An intermediate level examination of Korean language and culture. Intensive practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in KOR 103 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This course is taught in a blended-online format. Extensive computer use is required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested.

Course: KOR 130 — Understanding Korean History, Culture and Society through Contemporary Korean Films Subject: Korean (KOR) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of contemporary Korean history and culture through film. Course Information: Same as MOVI 130. Taught in English. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Korean History, Culture and Society through Contemporary Korean Films
metadata.subject: Korean (KOR)

text: Course: KOR 201 — Advanced Korean I Subject: Korean (KOR) Credits: 3 Description: The study of Korean at a low-advanced level. Students will be involved with intensive listening, speaking, reading and writing used in low-advanced formal and informal communicative situations. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in KOR 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test.

Course: KOR 230 — Korean Popular Culture in a Global World Subject: Korean (KOR) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the global phenomenon of Korean popular culture, including music, film, and television. Examines diverse K-Pop themes such as cross-cultural impacts and its possibilities for the future. Course Information: Taught in English. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Korean Popular Culture in a Global World
metadata.subject: Korean (KOR)

text: Course: LALS 100 — Skills and Career Readiness in Latin American and Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 1 Description: Success skills and career readiness for the major or minor, developing a career plan with an LALS degree, identifying and taking advantage of college resources, and learning to meet university expectations. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading. LALS 100 does not count toward the LALS major or minor.

metadata.class_name: Skills and Career Readiness in Latin American and Latino Studies
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 101 — Introduction to Latin American Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the major concepts, issues, and debates in the field of Latin American Studies. Overview of history, cultures, and issues of race, ethnicity, gender, class in Latin America. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 102 — Introduction to Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the major concepts, issues, and debates in the field of U.S. Latina/o Studies. Overview of the history, cultures, and issues of race, ethnicity, gender, and class among Latinos in the United States. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: LALS 103 — Introduction to Latino Urban Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Demographic, economic, political, cultural, and social dimensions of Latino communities in the United States. Includes Chicanos/Mexicanos Puerto Ricans, Cubans, and Central and South Americans. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: LALS 104 — Introduction to Puerto Rican Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of historical, cultural, political, social and economic issues of Puerto Rico: the political status of Puerto Rico, problems of cultural identity, migration and economic dependence. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 105 — Introduction to Mexican Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to major issues in the formation of modern Mexico (conquest, Revolution of 1910) and to major historical and contemporary literary works which depict and interpret the Mexican and Mexico. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 107 — Introduction to Nahua Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of key aspects of Aztec (Nahua) society, culture, and language in the era before and during European colonization (1300 CE-present). Introduces basic reading skills in Nahuatl, a major indigenous language in Central Mexico. World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 108 — Indigenous Culture Change in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of Latin American indigenous societies from the Precolumbian era to the present, using archaeological, historical, and anthropological findings to analyze the changes and adaptations of native cultures from Latin America. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Indigenous Culture Change in Latin America
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 109 — Introduction to Latino Cultures Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the cultural and artistic productions of U.S. Latinos and/or Latin Americans through historical processes of mainstreaming, transculturation, and hybridity. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: LALS 110 — Introduction to Latin American Cultures Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the cultural and artistic productions of Latin Americans and constructions of Latin American heritage and tradition. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecure and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 120 — Introduction to Research in Latin American and Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Immersion experience with research in the Latino community. A guided exploration of the research process, including production of a research question, choosing methods for collecting data, and producing a poster presentation to share findings. Course Information: Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Research in Latin American and Latino Studies
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 127 — Latin American Music Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey class that introduces students to the rich repertoire of music in Latin America. It explores the history of genres, their development, instruments and representative artists in their geographical, social and cultural contexts. Course Information: Same as MUS 127. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 161 — Introduction to Latin American History Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to major themes in Latin American history from pre-Colombian society and the European conquest to the present. Course Information: Same as HIST 161. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 192 — Latin American Women Writers in Translation Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to literature by Latin American women from the seventeenth century to the present. Focus on the role literature has played in the negotiation of gender identities in the private and the public spheres. Course Information: Same as GWS 192 and SPAN 192. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Women Writers in Translation
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 217 — Human Geography of Latin America including the Caribbean Region Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Culture, settlement, political and economic development problems in Latin America, with special attention to Puerto Rico, the Caribbean Region, and Mexico. Course Information: Same as GEOG 203. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Human Geography of Latin America including the Caribbean Region
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 220 — Latin American Cities in a Global Context: Environment, Employment, and Housing Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Global economic trends impacting Latin American cities, with a focus on three urban planning issues: environment, employment and housing. Growing inequality, precarious employment, spatial segregation, and squatter settlements will be explored. Course Information: Same as US 220. Recommended Background: LALS 101. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Cities in a Global Context: Environment, Employment, and Housing
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 223 — Southwestern Archaeology Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the archaeology of ancient Native American cultures of the North American Southwest, emphasizing processes of culture change from earliest times until European contact, with focus on current debates and relevant methods and theories. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 102 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ANTH 102 Course Information: Same as ANTH 223. Prereq Codes (parsed): ANTH 102 Coreq Codes (parsed): ANTH 102

Course: LALS 225 — Racial and Ethnic Groups Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Sociological and social-psychological analysis of racial, religious, and other ethnic groups; consideration of historical and current social problems arising from their relationships in society. Prerequisites: SOC 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 225 and SOC 225.

Course: LALS 229 — Sociology of Latinos Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines social, political and economic issues affecting Latino groups. While focusing on the process of racialization, the course also examines immigration, language rights, gender and sexuality, labor market, media, and youth. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or LALS 102 or SOC 105 or LALS 103 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as SOC 229.

Course: LALS 233 — Latinos in Chicago Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Development and dynamics of Chicago's Mexican, Puerto Rican, Cuban, Central and South American communities: settlement, demographics, economics, culture, social institutions and political participation.

Course: LALS 234 — Politics of Immigration Enforcement Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: How immigrants in the United States have been constructed as a “problem” and ways that authorities have consequently sought to govern them. Topics include nativism, illegalization, criminalization, border policing, detention, deportation, and rights. Course Information: Same as ANTH 246.

Course: LALS 239 — Visual Culture of the Ancient Andes Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the visual expressions, material culture, and built environment of ancient Andean civilization, from the earliest manifestations of societal complexity through the Spanish Conquest, with particular attention to the environmental, ideologi. Course Information: Same as AH 273. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Visual Culture of the Ancient Andes
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 240 — Visual Culture of Ancient Mesoamerica Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the visual expressions, material culture, and built environment of ancient Mesoamerican civilization, from the earliest manifestations of societal complexity through the Spanish Conquest, with particular attention to the environmental, id. Course Information: Same as AH 274. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 242 — Government and Politics of Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: An examination of government and politics in selected Latin American countries. Comparative and historical analysis of dictatorship, democracies, political institutions, and parties. Course Information: Same as POLS 242.

metadata.class_name: Government and Politics of Latin America
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 257 — Archaeology of North America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the prehistoric cultures of North America from earliest times until the arrival of Europeans. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 226.

Course: LALS 258 — Ancient Civilizations of Mexico and Central America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis and interpretation of the archaeological evidence on the process of development of native civilization in the Meso-American area from the beginnings of agricultural settlement to the eve of the Spanish conquest. Prerequisites: ANTH 102 ; or sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 227 and GEOG 207.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Civilizations of Mexico and Central America
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 260 — Indigenous Storytelling in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Study of Legend of the Suns, the Quetzalcoatl cycle, pictographic stories, the Popol Vuh and tales from Huarochirí in the colonial context. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 261 — Latin America to 1850 Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a survey of the pre-Columbian and early national periods in Latin America. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 261. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 262 — Latin America Since 1850 Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction to Latin American socioeconomic, political, and cultural development since 1850 with emphasis on major countries and regions. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 262. Course is offered in both face-to-face and online formats. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 263 — Latin American Colonial Art Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of Latin American art and architecture from European contact to independence. Prerequisites: Three hours of art history at the 100 level, or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as AH 263.

Course: LALS 266 — Modern Mexico Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction into the social, cultural, and political history of Mexico from the decades after independence to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 266. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 267 — Introduction to U.S. Latinx Literature Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of a wide range of U.S. Latinx literature in various genres and various ethnic, geographical and historical contexts. Course Information: Same as ENGL 267. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Creative Arts course.

Course: LALS 268 — History of Central America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: The human and territorial characteristics of Central America, including facets of Spanish colonialism and the history of revolutions and modernity in the region, including a history of U.S. - Central American relations. Prerequisites: Completion of the English composition requirement. Past course. Course Information: Same as HIST 269.

Course: LALS 269 — Latin American Environmental Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of environmental challenges in Latin America caused by mining, export agriculture, petroleum exploration, urbanization, and climate change. Social and political responses to environmental change and conservation regulation. Recommended Background: EAES 101. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 270 — Ethnography of Meso-America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the contemporary indigenous cultures of Meso-America, studied against their pre-conquest history and in their development since the Spanish Conquest. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 277.

Course: LALS 274 — The Politics of Blackness in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines race, culture, and politics in Latin America from historical and contemporary perspectives with a particular emphasis on the latter half of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century. Course Information: Same as BLST 274 and POLS 274. Recommended Background: Three credit hours in BLST or LALS or POLS.

metadata.class_name: The Politics of Blackness in Latin America
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 275 — Gender in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Latin American women in historical perspective from pre-Columbian and Iberian societies to the present. Course Information: Same as GWS 275 and POLS 275. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 276 — Latinas in the United States Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Socioeconomic conditions and cultural experiences of Latinas in the U.S. Historical and contemporary views of labor, health, education, family, identity formation and leadership. Course Information: Same as GWS 276 , and SOC 226. Grade of C or better in ENGL 160 ; Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in ENGL 161. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: LALS 277 — Issues of Race, Class, and Gender Among Latinos Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Institutional, cultural and psychological components of race, class, and gender relations. Institutional inequality, questions of assimilation and identity, attitudes, and effects of inequality on community.

metadata.class_name: Issues of Race, Class, and Gender Among Latinos
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 278 — Latin American/Latino Film Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the history and major aesthetic movements of Latin American cinema. Course Information: Same as MOVI 278 and SPAN 278. Taught in English. Includes a film screening component. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LALS 283 — Latinos and Politics Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Latino politics and politicians in the context of the American political system. The political system, Latino participation, experience, and research on political processes. Course Information: Same as POLS 209. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. US Society course.

Course: LALS 286 — Issues in Latino Identity Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines one or more topics of central importance to U.S. Latino populations. Topics may be related to such issues as youth, migration, family, religion, or cultural production.

Course: LALS 288 — History of Modern Puerto Rico Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of political and socioeconomic history from 1868 to the present. Course Information: Same as HIST 288.

Course: LALS 289 — Latina/o History Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Latinas/os in the United States from the colonial era to the present. Empire and imperialism, migration and citizenship, diversity and community formation, politics, labor, activism, and transnational ties to Latin America. Same as HIST 289. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course.

Course: LALS 290 — Mexican-American History Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: The political, social, economic, and cultural development of the Mexican people in the U.S. from colonial times until the present. Course Information: Same as HIST 290. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: LALS 291 — Topics in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: In-depth focus on a particular theme or topic relating to Latin American society, politics, culture, or economics. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Recommended Background: LALS 101.

Course: LALS 292 — Topics in Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: In-depth focus on a particular theme or topic relating to Latinos in the US or transnational issues relating to society, politics, culture, or economics. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: LALS 295 — Latino Literary Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Major trends, genres, works, themes, and writers related to Latino history and culture, mainstream and minority U.S., Latin American and third world literatures. Course Information: Same as ENGL 295 and SPAN 295. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: LALS 296 — Latin American and Latino Studies Study Abroad Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: International field work exploring cultural, historical, and sociopolitical issues of different communities within Latin American and Latino Studies. Prerequisites: Acceptance to the program via the Study Abroad Office application process and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Taught in English. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Field work required. Students must apply and be accepted by the UIC Study Abroad Office in order to register for this course. Visit www.studyabroad.uic.edu for more information. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Latin American and Latino Studies Study Abroad
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 299 — Independent Study Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3-6 Description: Individual reading or research project and paper in Latin American or U.S. Latino Studies, with instructor's consent and supervision. Prerequisites: A 2.50 grade point average. Open to undergraduate students with consent of the appropriate instructor and the Latin American and Latino Studies director. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: LALS 301 — Research Methods in Latin America and Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: An examination of various research methods used in Latin America and Latino Studies. Qualitative research methods used in the humanities and social sciences with emphasis on how to formulate ideas, develop them, and carry out a research project. Prerequisites: Two 200-level LALS courses; LALS major or minor or consent of the instructor; junior standing or above or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Research Methods in Latin America and Latino Studies
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 302 — Research Workshop in Latin American and Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Workshop where students will engage in individual research projects related to Latin American and/or Latino Studies. Prerequisites: LALS 301 , junior standing or above, and consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Research Workshop in Latin American and Latino Studies
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 304 — Introduction to Spanish Creative Writing for Heritage Speakers Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of writing tools through analysis of Spanish literary texts and through creative writing exercises. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 204 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as SPAN 304. This course may not be used to satisfy the prerequisite for ENGL 490 , ENGL 491 , or ENGL 492. Extensive computer use required. This course is intended for heritage students, but may be taken by students demonstrating near-native writing proficiency with the permission of the course instructor. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in SPAN 210.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Spanish Creative Writing for Heritage Speakers
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 328 — Child Migration Across the Americas Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines why and how migrant children have played a central role in the past and present migratory dynamics of the Americas. Course Information: Same as ANTH 328.

Course: LALS 333 — Undocumented Social Movements Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Undocumented coalitions, visibility, and refusal. Poetry, films, artivism, movement journalism, and secondary readings. Visibility, claiming and redefining citizenship, and building power alongside other racialized communities. Course Information: Same as ANTH 333.

Course: LALS 335 — Latinx Sound Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Experience and experiment with sound to imagine and enact social identities and leverage political power. Intersections of race, class, gender and sexuality, geography and citizenship through sounded and aural frameworks. Course Information: Same as COMM 334.

Course: LALS 337 — Latino/a Religions in the US Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: How Latinx communities venerate ancestors and deities, create and remake sacred space, practice healing, and organize politically through the lens of of documentaries, fiction and literature, visual art, and ethnographic studies. Course Information: Same as RELS 337.

Course: LALS 348 — Seminar: Political Problems of Developing Societies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected aspects of the politics and countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America. Prerequisites: POLS 200 and POLS 130 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 348.

metadata.class_name: Seminar: Political Problems of Developing Societies
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 367 — Latinx Literature Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Development of Latinx literature from different historical periods and diasporic communities. Analysis of political and social concerns relevant to Latinx literature and culture. Course Information: Same as ENGL 367. Previously listed as LALS 353. Recommended Background: Any of LALS 101 -102 or ENGL 207 , 209 , or 267.

Course: LALS 376 — Politics of the Latinx Body Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on the social construction of raced, gendered, and sexed bodies as deviant, abnormal, and pathological, and on how such bodies are rendered objects of surveillance, discipline, and regulation. Particular attention is paid to Latinx bodies.

Course: LALS 380 — Social Movements in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: The different ways in which different groups have used non-traditional means to change the social and political circumstances that have conditioned their lives. Prerequisites: One course in LALS or consent of the instructor.

Course: LALS 385 — Latino Social Movements in the United States Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Activism and social movements of Latina/o populations in the United States. Topics may include labor organizing, civil rights and power movements, immigrant mobilizations, feminism, and environmental justice. Prerequisites: One course in LALS or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Latino Social Movements in the United States
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 391 — Seminar in Latin American Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Diverse aspects of modern Latin American society, politics, culture and economics from the wars of independence to contemporary times. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Recommended Background: LALS 101.

Course: LALS 395 — Seminar in Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: Diverse aspects of the U.S. Latino experience at more theoretical and advanced levels. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Recommended Background: LALS 102.

Course: LALS 403 — Interdisciplinary Research Methods in Latin American and Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examination of research methods in social sciences and current trends in Latin American and Latino Studies. Emphasis on critical analysis of research methods, use of analytical approaches for particular kinds of investigation, and hands on application to case studies. Prerequisites: Graduate standing. Undergraduates may register with consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in LALS 501 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in LALS 501 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in LALS 501. Prereq Codes (parsed): LALS 501 Coreq Codes (parsed): LALS 501

metadata.class_name: Interdisciplinary Research Methods in Latin American and Latino Studies
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 408 — Global Black Feminisms Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines transnational, Third Wave and Third World Black feminist approaches to global politics from historical and contemporary perspectives with a particular emphasis on the late 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century. Course Information: Same as BLST 408 and GWS 408. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Undergraduate students: at least three credit hours in BLST or GWS or LALS.

Course: LALS 409 — Ancient Maya Writing, Language and Culture Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Recent trends in Maya epigraphy, information gained from Maya hieroglyphs, linguistics, and historical ethnographies are applied to anthropological analyses of past lifeways. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 409. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Maya Writing, Language and Culture
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 417 — Latina and Latin American Feminist Thought Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Chicana/Latina and Latin American feminist texts and methods. Differential consciousness, spirituality (spiritual activism and spiritual mestizaje), curanderismo, and decolonial epistemologies. Course Information: Same as GWS 417.

metadata.class_name: Latina and Latin American Feminist Thought
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 422 — Chicanas and Latinas: Self and Society Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 Description: The experiences of Chicanas and Latinas through the lens of contemporary sociological research. Topics to be discussed include: community formation and activism, feminisms, sexuality, religion, health, family, immigration, education, work, media, etc. Course Information: Same as SOC 422.

metadata.class_name: Chicanas and Latinas: Self and Society
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 423 — Andean Prehistory Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An overview of the cultural evolution of the Andean region from the arrival of the first inhabitants to the development of the Inca empire. Prerequisites: ANTH 269 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 423. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LALS 425 — Urban Field Research in Latino/a Communities Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Field work in Chicago Latino/a neighborhoods. Observing, taking field notes, analyzing issues of workforce, homelessness, street vending, affordable housing, community organizing, educational infrastructure, environmental degradation, gentrification. Prerequisites: LALS 403. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Urban Field Research in Latino/a Communities
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 428 — Latin@ Futurity Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An exploration of utopic and dystopic imaginations in Latin@ literature, media, and popular culture. Discusses coloniality, precarity, an alternate timeline as (re)imagined through queer, indigenous, and femme epistemologies. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as COMM 428.

Course: LALS 433 — Latin American Migration to the U.S Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Latin American migration to the U.S. International migration theories, family remittances, transnational linkages, dual citizenship, and past and current U.S. immigration policy debates. Prerequisites: One course in LALS or SOC; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as SOC 433. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Migration to the U.S
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 434 — Literature of the Americas Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Transnational or hemispheric approach to Latin American literature. Writers whose work moves back and forth between nations. Identities across borders, languages, and nations. Course Information: Same as ENGL 434. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LALS 436 — Borders and Borderlands: Method and Theory Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Borders as theory and method in Latino/a and Latin American Studies. Borders and bordering practices, mobile, transnational communities, mapping and policing, and migrant mobility and autonomy. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Borders and Borderlands: Method and Theory
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 437 — Global Migrations Across the Americas Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Processes of migrant mobilities and control in the Americas. Structural causes, social groups, and role of global inequality. Case studies in the US and Latin America regarding the securitization of migration and growth patterns in migrant mobility. Course Information: Same as ANTH 435. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LALS 461 — Topics in Latin American History Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history, Latin American and Latino studies, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 461. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: LALS 465 — Asian Diasporas in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines Asian migration to Latin America, covering topics such as labor and economic systems, transnational networks, community building, racism, identity, and serial migration. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in GLAS 100 or Grade of C or better in HIST 161. Course Information: Same as GLAS 465 and HIST 465. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: HIST 264.

Course: LALS 466 — Criminal Governance in Latin America Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Emergence of criminal politics in Latin America. Engagement of politicians, organized crime actors, and state agents in the pursuit goals (economic, political, personal). Root sources, logic and consequences of this new, prevalent order. Course Information: Same as POLS 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LALS 467 — Topics in Latinx Literature Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a specific topic in Latinx literature and literary studies, which may examine a single or select group of authors, a particular genre, or a particular regional or aesthetic focus. Topics vary. Course Information: Same as ENGL 467. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time. Previously listed as ENGL 442. Recommended Background: ENGL 207 , ENGL 208 , ENGL 209 , ENGL 327 or LALS 101 , LALS 102 ; junior standing or above.

Course: LALS 476 — Latinx Youth: Coming of Age in the U.S Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Discursive and cultural positioning of Latina/o/x youth in the US. Explores how youth shape identity, culture, education, politics, community. Using concept of intersectionality, explores links to gender, class, and sexuality. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Same as GWS 476 and SOC 474.

metadata.class_name: Latinx Youth: Coming of Age in the U.S
metadata.subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS)

text: Course: LALS 491 — Topics in Latin American Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In-depth study of selected topics such as state formation, education, populism, the family, democratization, industrialization, and ideological currents in Latin America. Prerequisites: One LALS course or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: LALS 495 — Topics in Latino Studies Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In-depth study of topics in Latino studies, including communities and current issues from an interdisciplinary perspective. Prerequisites: One LALS course or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: LALS 497 — Community Research Internship Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Work in community-based organizations and cultural institutions to develop experiential knowledge about social, political and cultural issues facing Latinos and Latin Americans. Placements introduce issues of ethnicity, identity, and transnationalism. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Concurrent registration in LALS 498. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: LALS 403.

Course: LALS 499 — Advanced Independent Study Subject: Latin American and Latino Studies (LALS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual advanced reading or research project in Latin American or U.S. Latino studies, with instructor's consent and supervision. Prerequisites: Open, with consent of the instructor, to graduate students and Latin American and Latino studies majors with at least a 3.00 grade point average. Students in other programs or with lower than a 3.00 grade point average are admitted at the instructor's discretion only. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major.

Course: LAS 110 — Experience UIC Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to campus and college resources that support transition to university life and foster a sense of belonging. Strategies for developing academic and professional goals, engaging with classmates and faculty, and attaining academic success. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Strongly recommended for LAS first-year students. Field trips outside of class hours required.

Course: LAS 120 — Career Readiness and Major Exploration Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 1 Description: Support for LAS undeclared students to align their skills, strengths, interests, values and motivations to make informed decisions about their academic and career paths. Prerequisites: Open only to freshmen. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Taught over 8 weeks. Support for undeclared second-semester first-year students in their major exploration.

Course: LAS 200 — LAS Career Success and Professional Development Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 1 Description: Strategies and tools to promote career readiness, articulating the value of an LAS degree, and building a professional network. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as LAS 101. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

metadata.class_name: LAS Career Success and Professional Development
metadata.subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS)

text: Course: LAS 289 — LAS Internship Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 1-3 Description: An opportunity to connect internship experiences to future career interests and goals through development and exploration of professional identity, best practices of professionalism and networking, and understanding of workplace cultures. Prerequisites: A cumulative grade point average of 2.50, completion of 30 hours of course work; transfer students must have completed 12 hours of coursework at UIC. Approval by the LAS Internship Program Office. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. An internship must be secured before enrolling in the course. Some sections may be offered fully online. Use of a computer and internet access are required for online sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Credit cannot be applied toward the major. Credit earned in course counts toward the limit on credit for internships. One internship course per semester is allowed.

Course: LAS 294 — Topics in Liberal Arts and Sciences Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 3 Description: Study of a specific intermediate topic in the liberal arts. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for credit if topic is different for each registration. Students may register for more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Liberal Arts and Sciences
metadata.subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS)

text: Course: LAS 296 — Independent Study in Liberal Arts and Sciences Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Individual study and other special projects supervised by a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: No more than 16 semester hours of independent study credit in any discipline may apply toward the degree.

metadata.class_name: Independent Study in Liberal Arts and Sciences
metadata.subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS)

text: Course: LAS 299 — Liberal Arts and Sciences Study Abroad Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 0-18 Description: Provides credit for foreign study. Student's proposal for study abroad must have prior approval of the major department and the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences office. Final determination of credit is made on the student's completion of the work. Prerequisites: Approval of the student's major department and the College office, and the Study Abroad Office. Course Information: May be repeated. A maximum of 36 hours per academic year is allowed, for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year.

metadata.class_name: Liberal Arts and Sciences Study Abroad
metadata.subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS)

text: Course: LAS 490 — International Student Exchange Program Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 0-18 Description: The Student Exchange Program enables the reciprocal exchange of students between UIC and colleges or universities in other countries. There are a variety of programs tailored to meet the needs of both graduate and undergraduate students. Prerequisites: Approval of the student's major department, the LAS College office, and the Study Abroad Office. Consent of the Instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 36 hours per academic year or for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year. Determination of the number of credits to be granted is part of the proposal approval process. Students from other UIC Colleges and Schools are eligible for the program. For more information, visit the Study Abroad Office website at https://studyabroad.uic.edu/.

Course: LAS 492 — Topics in Sustainability Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An interdisciplinary approach to current issues in sustainability and transportation. Topics may vary, but will include climate change/environmental, technological, societal and economic impacts, and programs/policies for sustainability. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Field work required.

Course: LAS 493 — Topics in Energy Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An interdisciplinary approach to issues in energy. Topics will include energy storage, electricity systems, energy technology, economics of energy, life cycle analysis, climate and environmental impact, and energy and environmental policy. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: LAS 494 — Topics in Cultural Studies Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An interdisciplinary approach to a current cultural debate. Topics will vary. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Taught at the Field Museum.

Course: LAS 495 — The Newberry Library Undergraduate Seminar Subject: Liberal Arts and Sciences (LAS) Credits: 6 Description: Seminar with a topic related to the holdings of the Newberry Library. Classes held in Newberry Library. Topics vary. Prerequisites: Consent of UIC's Newberry Library seminar coordinator. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Previously listed as LAS 395. Students are required to conduct research at the Newberry Library beyond designated class hours. Pre-tour of the Newberry is recommended.

Course: LAT 101 — Elementary Latin I Subject: Latin (LAT) Credits: 4 Description: Fundamentals of the Latin language. Grammar and reading. Course Information: For students who have no credit in Latin. One additional hour of computer-assisted instruction each week.

Course: LAT 102 — Elementary Latin II Subject: Latin (LAT) Credits: 4 Description: Continues LAT 101. Grammar and reading. Prerequisites: LAT 101 or the equivalent. Course Information: One additional hour of computer-assisted instruction each week.

Course: LAT 103 — Intermediate Latin I Subject: Latin (LAT) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to Roman historians and oratory. Selections from Cicero, Sallust, Livy, and other Latin prose writers. Review of forms and grammar. Prerequisites: LAT 102 or the equivalent.

Course: LAT 104 — Intermediate Latin II Subject: Latin (LAT) Credits: 4 Description: Completes study of Latin at intermediate level. Latin poetry as well as prose, and grammar. Prerequisites: LAT 103 or the equivalent.

Course: LAT 291 — Topics in Latin Prose Authors Subject: Latin (LAT) Credits: 3 Description: Readings in Latin prose chosen from a single author, period, or single genre. Prerequisites: LAT 104 or equivalent for students who register in LAT 291 only. Course Information: Same as CL 291. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary. Taught in English.
