Students who register in CL 291 will complete assignments in English translation. Students who register in LAT 291 will complete more than half of the readings in Latin. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Recommended Background: CL 102.

Course: LAT 299 — Independent Reading Subject: Latin (LAT) Credits: 3 Description: Individual study under faculty direction. For students qualified by preparation and interest. Prerequisites: LAT 104 or the equivalent. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: LAT 391 — Topics in Latin Poetry Subject: Latin (LAT) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced readings in Latin poetry chosen from a single author, period, or single genre in different periods. Prerequisites: CL 250 or CL 252 or CL 253 ; or consent of the instructor; and LAT 291 or the equivalent for students who register for LAT 391 only. Course Information: Same as CL 391. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours if topics vary. Taught in English. Students who register in CL 391 will complete assignments in English translation. Students who register in LAT 391 will complete more than half of the readings in Latin. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Recommended Background: CL 102.

Course: LCSL 101 — CIC Course Share Foreign Language I Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 4 Description: Holding course for UIC students taking approved foreign language coursework at other institutions through the CIC CourseShare program. Prerequisites: Must be enrolled in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and meet prerequisite requirements of the offering institution and approval of the CIC CourseShare coordinator. Course Information: May be repeated for credit. Students may register for more than one section per term. Consult with College of Liberal Arts and Sciences CIC coordinator regarding CourseShare opportunities.

metadata.class_name: CIC Course Share Foreign Language I
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 102 — CIC Course Share Foreign Langauge II Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 4 Description: Holding course for UIC students taking approved foreign language coursework at other institutions through the CIC CourseShare program. Prerequisites: Must be enrolled in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and meet prerequisite requirements of the offering institution and approval of the CIC CourseShare coordinator. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Consult with College of Liberal Arts and Sciences CIC coordinator regarding CourseShare opportunities.

metadata.class_name: CIC Course Share Foreign Langauge II
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 103 — CIC Course Share Foreign Langauge III Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 4 Description: Holding course for UIC students taking approved foreign language coursework at other institutions through the CIC CourseShare program. Prerequisites: Must be enrolled in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and meet prerequisite requirements of the offering institution and approval of the CIC CourseShare coordinator. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Consult with College of Liberal Arts and Sciences CIC coordinator regarding CourseShare opportunities.

metadata.class_name: CIC Course Share Foreign Langauge III
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 104 — CIC Course Share Foreign Langauge IV Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 4 Description: Holding course for UIC students taking approved foreign language coursework at other institutions through the CIC CourseShare program. Prerequisites: Must be enrolled in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and meet prerequisite requirements of the offering institution and approval of the CIC CourseShare coordinator. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Consult with College of Liberal Arts and Sciences CIC coordinator regarding CourseShare opportunities.

metadata.class_name: CIC Course Share Foreign Langauge IV
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 250 — Introduction to Comparative Cultural Studies Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 Description: Debates in comparative cultural studies, global arts and world literatures. Emphasis on diverse worldviews across Europe, Latin America, Francophone cultures. Competencies developed: critical thinking, equity & inclusion, intercultural communication. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LCSL 260 — Tales of Healing: Intro to Narrative Medicine Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the role of stories in defining and treating illness and helping us cope in times of crisis. Traces how medical ideas and history find reflection in literature and how literary concepts get utilized in medicine. Course Information: Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Tales of Healing: Intro to Narrative Medicine
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 261 — The Image of Health: Visuality and Medicine Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 Description: Approaches to visual thinking strategies in art and medicine as vital for clinical, medical practice and patient care. Course Information: Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Field trip required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: The Image of Health: Visuality and Medicine
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 275 — Encoding Text Cultures: Reading with AI in the Humanities Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 Description: What does it mean to think about literary and cultural texts as data? Exploration of the ways in which computational approaches enrich, challenge, and transform how we read texts and engage with subjects in text-based humanities. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Encoding Text Cultures: Reading with AI in the Humanities
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 285 — Zombies, Plagues, and Other Pandemics in Literature and Visual Media Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 Description: Pandemics and their effects on human beings on a physical, emotional, and societal level, as seen through literature and visual media across nations. Course Information: Same as ITAL 285 and SPAN 285. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Zombies, Plagues, and Other Pandemics in Literature and Visual Media
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 294 — Topics in Cultural Studies Abroad Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 Description: Immersive learning experience abroad; topics may include cultural, historical, social, political, or economic issues pertaining to the location of study. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Taught in English unless otherwise noted. Participation requires admission to the relevant UIC Study Abroad program. For more information, visit the Study Abroad Office website at https://studyabroad.uic.edu.

Course: LCSL 296 — Independent Study Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent reading or research under the supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: LCSL 391 — Internship in Global Studies Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 Description: Professional field experience with an international agency or organization in the private or public sector.

Course: LCSL 392 — Internship in Global Engagement and Public Humanities Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 0-3 Description: Professional field experience with an international agency or organization in the private or public sector. Prerequisites: Completion of one year of a basic language program and approval of a pre-arranged internship by the School of Literatures, Cultural Studies and Linguistics. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Internship in Global Engagement and Public Humanities
metadata.subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL)

text: Course: LCSL 406 — History of European Standard Languages Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The phenomenon of the "standard language" in Western and Eastern Europe. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CEES 406 and LING 406. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. In cases where students speak languages other than English, they might receive tasks to research literature in that language (and on that language) and to present their research results.

Course: LCSL 459 — Topics in Linguistics Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics vary. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LING 459. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Only 6 hours may be counted towards a major or minor in the Department of Linguistics. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: LCSL 483 — Methodology of Second Language Teaching Subject: Literatures, Cultural Studies, and Linguistics (LCSL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Approaches, methods, and techniques for teaching second languages with a focus on speaking, listening, writing, reading, and on assessment and curriculum/syllabus design. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LING 483. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LIB 399 — Research Experience in Library and Information Science Subject: Library and Information Science (LIB) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience in Library and Information Science under the guidance of a faculty member who will act as research supervisor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

metadata.class_name: Research Experience in Library and Information Science
metadata.subject: Library and Information Science (LIB)

text: Course: LING 150 — Introduction to the Study of Language Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: The nature of human language, including analysis of structure and use in social context. Course Information: May be offered in a traditional, blended, or online remote format. Check the class schedule for specifics. For both the online and hybrid ("blended-online") formats, computer and internet access are required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Study of Language
metadata.subject: Linguistics (LING)

text: Course: LING 160 — Language and Society Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Language and its social context: linguistic variation and diversity in the community involving bilingualism, language contact, dialects, style, class, gender, age, and change. Course Information: May be offered in a traditional, blended, or online remote format. Check the class schedule for specifics. For both the online and hybrid ("blended-online") formats, computer and internet access are required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Recommended Background: LING 150. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: LING 170 — Languages of the World Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the world's languages: their cultural origins, relationships, similarities, and differences. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: LING 201 — Medical Terminologies: Ancient Roots in Modern Medicine Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: The structure and formation of technical terms used in the health sciences, based on roots and elements from Greek and Latin. Course Information: Same as CL 201.

metadata.class_name: Medical Terminologies: Ancient Roots in Modern Medicine
metadata.subject: Linguistics (LING)

text: Course: LING 206 — Introduction to the Philosophy of Language Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical issues concerning meaning, the relationship between language and thought, how language is to be distinguished from other forms of communication, and how truth relates to meaning. Course Information: Same as PHIL 206. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Recommended Background: One non-logic course in philosophy.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Philosophy of Language
metadata.subject: Linguistics (LING)

text: Course: LING 210 — Introduction to Natural Language Syntax Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to concepts and methodologies for the syntactic analysis of natural language. Emphasis on recursive phrase structures, feature structures, and feature dependencies. Prerequisites: LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: ENGL 200.

Course: LING 220 — Introduction to Phonetics and Phonology Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: This introduction to concepts and methodologies for the phonetic and phonological analysis of natural language emphasizes the description and analysis of phonological patterns using feature specification and analysis of acoustic properties of speech. Prerequisites: LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: LING 230 — Semantics, Pragmatics, and Discourse Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the core issues in semantics, pragmatics, and discourse studies. Emphasis is on lexical semantics, meaning as conceptualization, relation between pragmatics and semantics, and relation between pragmatics and discourse structuring. Prerequisites: LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: LING 260 — Language Acquisition, Language Contact and Bilingualism Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: The social and psychological aspects of three major areas of language acquisition and use will be addressed: child language acquisition, adult second language acquisition and bilingualism/language contact. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Course Information: May be offered in a traditional, blended, or online remote format. Check the class schedule for specifics. For both the online and hybrid ("blended-online") formats, computer and internet access are required. A high-speed connection is strongly suggested. Recommended Background: LING 150 or LING 160 or a similar course. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Language Acquisition, Language Contact and Bilingualism
metadata.subject: Linguistics (LING)

text: Course: LING 270 — Language in Healthcare Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Review and practice of research on linguistic and cultural factors in (mis)communication in healthcare settings. Course Information: Field work required. Fieldwork will take place during regularly scheduled class time (approximately 6 of 45 contact hours) and outside of class as homework assignments. Recommended Background: LING 150 or LING 160.

Course: LING 300 — Seminar in Linguistic Analysis Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Special topics course introduces students to the current developments and tools in a specific area of linguistic analysis; provides students with in-depth understanding of the theoretical issues and methodologies in the topic area. Prerequisites: LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Only 6 hours may be counted towards a major or minor in the Department of Linguistics. Students may register for more than one section per term. Recommended Background: At least one of LING 210 , LING 220 , or LING 230.

Course: LING 310 — Language and Discrimination Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Analyzes how language is used to discriminate in education, policy, law, work, media, technology, and other fields using seminal texts, case studies, and authentic examples from global and local perspectives. Prerequisites: LING 150. Recommended Background: LING 160.

Course: LING 320 — Linguistics and Speech-Language Pathology Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the intersections of linguistics and speech-language pathology throughout historical periods, in communication development throughout an individual's lifetime and current trends in both fields. Prerequisites: LING 150 and LING 220 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in LING 160 or LING 260 or LING 300 or LING 310 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in LING 160 or LING 260 or LING 300 or LING 310 Course Information: Extensive computer use required. The course may be offered in 8 or 15 weeks. Class format varies by section. Check the class schedule for details. Online sections involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in LING 160 or LING 260 or LING 300 or LING 310. Prereq Codes (parsed): LING 160, LING 260, LING 300, LING 310 Coreq Codes (parsed): LING 160, LING 260, LING 300, LING 310

Course: LING 330 — A Linguistic Introduction to Chinese Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: A linguistic introduction to Chinese including sounds/tones, words, and sentence patterns; regional and social dialects; evolution of writing system; language policies; language contact and change; Chinese L2 acquisition; Chinese language communities. Prerequisites: CHIN 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CHIN 330. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. The course may be offered in 15 weeks or 8 weeks. Class format varies by section. Check the class schedule for details. Online sections involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Recommended Background: LING 150.

Course: LING 340 — Vocabulary in Action: How do we learn, process, and use words as multilinguals Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Helps students understand multilingual vocabulary acquisition, processing and usage. Students will additionally learn how to use corpus research tools. Prerequisites: LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Class format varies by section. Check the class schedule for details. Online sections involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Recommended Background: LING 260.

metadata.class_name: Vocabulary in Action: How do we learn, process, and use words as multilinguals
metadata.subject: Linguistics (LING)

text: Course: LING 350 — Are Algorithms Biased Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Guides students to explore aspects of how human bias is reflected in algorithms that are increasingly used in daily interactions with a focus on biases in language technologies. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. The course may be offered in 15-weeks or 8-weeks. The course may be offered online. Recommended Background: LING 310.

Course: LING 360 — Basic Statistics for Language Research Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to basic statistical techniques and procedures for quantitative research in language science working with R under the RStudio environment. Prerequisites: LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: MATH 180 ; and Credit in at least one 200-level LING course.

Course: LING 370 — Introduction to Computational Linguistics Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 Description: Explores how computers process data for language research, specifically focusing on how to apply NLP techniques to language-data-related tasks using Python. Prerequisites: LING 150 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Credit in at least one 200-level LING course.

Course: LING 402 — Trial Interaction Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Language use, culture, and law in the trial process. Analysis of qualitative methods applied to legal processes and change. Prerequisites: CLJ 261 and CLJ 350 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CLJ 402. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LING 405 — Introduction to General Linguistics Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Linguistics, the scientific study of language as knowledge, structure, and use, involves Phonetics, Phonology, Morphology, Syntax, Semantics, and Pragmatics. Introduction to Linguistics explores these disciplines. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LING 406 — History of European Standard Languages Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The phenomenon of the "standard language" in Western and Eastern Europe. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CEES 406 and LCSL 406. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. In cases where students speak languages other than English, they might receive tasks to research literature in that language (and on that language) and to present their research results.

Course: LING 410 — AI for Language Research Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Comprehensive exploration of the intersection between AI and language sciences, with emphasis on how to address linguistic inquiries by way of computational methods and techniques. Prerequisites: A 200-level LING course and LING 370 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Credit in LING 360.

Course: LING 440 — Language and Gender Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examination of sociolinguistic research and theories on the interrelationships between language and gender, including gender categories in linguistic systems, gender differences in language use, interaction, and cross-cultural comparisons. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 440. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as LING 540.

Course: LING 459 — Topics in Linguistics Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics vary. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LCSL 459. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Only 6 hours may be counted towards a major or minor in the Department of Linguistics. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: LING 480 — Sociolinguistics Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The study of language structure and use involving socially-informed pragmatics, ethnography of communication, sociolinguistic variation and dialectology, and issues of bilingualism. Prerequisites: LING 405 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ANTH 480. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LING 483 — Methodology of Second Language Teaching Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Approaches, methods, and techniques for teaching second languages with a focus on speaking, listening, writing, reading, and on assessment and curriculum/syllabus design. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LCSL 483. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: LING 487 — Computer Assisted Language Learning Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An introduction to computer assisted language learning (CALL): the use of computer technology in second language reading and research. The effectiveness of CALL technology is assessed based on SLA theory and research studies. Prerequisites: LING 483 or CIE 483 or GER 448 or FR 448 or SPAN 448 or GER 449 or FR 449 or SPAN 449 ; or SPAN 502 or FR 502 or the equivalent; and senior standing or above. Course Information: Same as GER 487 and SPAN 487. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required.

Course: LING 496 — Independent Study Subject: Linguistics (LING) Credits: 1-4 Description: Students are assigned to this course at the discretion of the department. Independent study in an area of linguisitics not normally covered by regular course offerings. Prerequisites: 9 hours of linguistics and approval of the head of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. A maximum of 6 hours is allowed for undergraduate students, and 8 hours of credit for graduate students. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major.

Course: LITH 101 — Elementary Lithuanian I Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 4 Description: Basic grammar and vocabulary; developing effective speaking skills. Students will be introduced to the Lithuanian culture. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. For students who have had no formal work in Lithuanian. This class is taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: LITH 102 — Elementary Lithuanian II Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of LITH 101. The objective of the course is to provide students with basic skills for understanding and speaking Lithuanian. Prerequisites: Grade of C or higher in LITH 101 or appropriate score on the departmental placement test. Course Information: Four additional half hours each week in the language laboratory. The class is taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: LITH 103 — Intermediate Lithuanian I Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 4 Description: Further development of grammar and vocabulary; developing effective communicative skills. Students will be introduced to Lithuanian culture. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in LITH 102 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. This class is taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: LITH 104 — Intermediate Lithuanian II Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 4 Description: Builds upon the previous three terms work. It continues the development of students' reading, speaking, listening, and writing skills in Lithuanian. Prerequisites: Grade of C or higher in LITH 103 or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This class is taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: LITH 115 — Lithuanian Culture Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 3 Description: A thematic study of Lithuanian culture from antiquity to the present in an historical and political context. Course Information: Knowledge of Lithuanian is not required. World Cultures course.

Course: LITH 130 — Lithuanian Prose Fiction in International Context Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of Lithuanian prose fiction with reference to its major influences from Europe, North and South America; the development of international style. Course Information: Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Lithuanian Prose Fiction in International Context
metadata.subject: Lithuanian (LITH)

text: Course: LITH 221 — Lithuanian Literature I Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 3 Description: Reading and analysis of the works of selected nineteenth- and twentieth-century authors. The evolution of Lithuanian literature up to 1940. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: LITH 222 — Lithuanian Literature II Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 3 Description: Reading and analysis of the works of selected authors from 1940 to the present. Prerequisites: LITH 221. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: LITH 230 — Lithuanian Literature Abroad Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 3 Description: Lithuanian writers in exile: themes, trends in development, comparison with writers in Lithuania; influences of the new environment, writing in English. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: LITH 399 — Independent Study Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Investigation of special problems under the general direction of a staff member. Prerequisites: Junior standing, consent of the instructor and the head of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: LITH 499 — Independent Study Subject: Lithuanian (LITH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Investigation of special problems under the general direction of a staff member. Prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing, consent of the instructor and the head of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Graduate students may register for more than one section per term; undergraduates may only register for one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the undergraduate degree and the major.

Course: MATH 077 — Mathematical Reasoning Workshop Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: A refresher of the algebra used in Math 118. A more detailed reminder of algebraic techniques will be given in a student-centered environment with personalized homework and worksheets to address individual needs. Corequisites: MATH 118. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Extensive computer use required.

Course: MATH 088 — Intermediate Algebra Workshop Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Individualized lesson plans including: order of operations, properties of real numbers, linear equations, problem solving, graphing linear equations. Corequisites: MATH 108. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Extensive computer use required.

Course: MATH 100 — Exploring Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to resources and offerings in the Department of Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science with a focus on departmental advising procedures and career and post-graduation opportunities. Recommended Background: After earning credit in at least one mathematics course.

metadata.class_name: Exploring Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science
metadata.subject: Mathematics (MATH)

text: Course: MATH 104 — Mathematical Reasoning Workshop Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: A refresher of the algebra used in MATH 105. A more detailed reminder of algebraic techniques will be given in a student-centered environment with personalized homework and worksheets to address individual needs. Corequisites: MATH 105. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Previously listed as MATH 077. Credit is not given for MATH 104 if the student has credit in MATH 077.

Course: MATH 105 — Mathematical Reasoning Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 4 Description: Mathematical problem solving with a hands-on and learn-by-doing approach, using topics from linear equations, personal finance, geometry, probability, and statistics. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory-Discussion. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 104 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 104 Course Information: Previously listed as MATH 118. May serve as a prerequisite for statistics courses in the social sciences. It does not replace MATH 108 as a prerequisite for any other mathematics department course. Credit is not given for MATH 105 if the student has credit in MATH 118 or MATH 121 or MATH 160 or MATH 165 or MATH 170 or MATH 180 or the equivalent. No graduation credit for architecture, business administration, or engineering students. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 104 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 104

Course: MATH 108 — Intermediate Algebraic Concepts Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: Linear equations and inequalities, absolute values, linear graphs and modeling, systems of equations, functions, quadratic equations, exponents and polynomials, factoring, radicals and rational exponents. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 088 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 088 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 088 Course Information: Previously listed as MATH 090. Extensive computer use required. Students with credit in a mathematics course at or above the 100-level may not enroll. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 088 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 088

Course: MATH 109 — College Algebra Workshop Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: A refresher of material prerequisite for and used in MATH 110 , including: functions, polynomial and rational equations, graphs and transformations, exponentials and logarithms, trigonometry. Prerequisites: Appropriate ALEKS placement score. Corequisites: MATH 110. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: MATH 110 — College Algebra Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 4 Description: Functions, composition and inverses; graphs and transformations, polynomial and rational functions, exponential functions, logarithms and applications; circles and introduction to trigonometry. Prerequisites: MATH 090 or MATH 108 ; credit or concurrent registration in MATH 109 ; or an appropriate score on the department placement test. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 109 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 109 Course Information: Credit is not given for MATH 110 if the student has credit in MATH 121 or MATH 165 or MATH 170 or MATH 180. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 109 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 109

Course: MATH 121 — Precalculus Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 5 Description: Functions, graphs, exponentials and logarithms, radicals, complex numbers, trigonometry (circle and triangle approaches), trigonometric graphs and inverses, introduction to polar coordinates and vectors Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 110 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: No credit will be given for MATH 121 if students have credit in MATH 165 or MATH 170 or MATH 180. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: MATH 122 — Emerging Scholars Workshop for Precalculus Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Intensive math workshop for students enrolled in MATH 121. Students work together in groups to solve challenging problems. Prerequisites: Admission to the Emerging Scholars Program. Must enroll concurrently in MATH 121. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Emerging Scholars Workshop for Precalculus Mathematics
metadata.subject: Mathematics (MATH)

text: Course: MATH 125 — Elementary Linear Algebra Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 5 Description: Introduction to systems of linear equations, matrices and vector spaces, with emphasis on business applications. Prerequisites: Appropriate score on the department placement test; or Grade S in MATH 090 or Grade of C or better in MATH 108 ; or Grade of C or better in MATH 110 ; or equivalent. Course Information: Credit is not given for MATH 125 if the student has credit in MATH 160. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: MATH 140 — Arithmetic and Algebraic Structures Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 4 Description: Problem solving; algebraic thinking; number systems; numeration; number theory; mathematical operations over natural, integer, and rational numbers; and proportional reasoning. Prerequisites: Grade of S in MATH 090 or a grade of C or better in MATH 108 or appropriate score on the department placement test.

Course: MATH 141 — Algebraic and Geometric Structures Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 4 Description: Area, perimeter, volume, surface area of plane and solid figures; integers, real and rational numbers; trigonometry and extended solution of general polygons; probability. Full purpose calculators used. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 140. Course Information: Designed for students in the B.A. in Elementary Education program.

Course: MATH 160 — Finite Mathematics for Business Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 5 Description: Introduction to probability, statistics, and matrices, with emphasis on business applications. Prerequisites: Appropriate score on the department placement test; or Grade of C or better in MATH 110 ; or equivalent. Course Information: Credit is not given for MATH 160 if the student has credit in MATH 125. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: MATH 165 — Calculus for Business Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 5 Description: Introduction to differential and integral calculus of algebraic, exponential and logarithmic functions and techniques of partial derivatives and optimization. Emphasis on business applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 110 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Prior credit for MATH 170 or MATH 180 will be lost with subsequent completion of MATH 165. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: MATH 170 — Calculus for the Life Sciences Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to calculus with applications to the life sciences, mathematical modeling, differentiation, integration and applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 110 or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Prior credit in MATH 165 or MATH 180 will be lost with subsequent completion of MATH 170. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: MATH 178 — Preparation for Calculus Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Asynchronous online supplement for some students in MATH 180. Uses adaptive individualized assessment and learning to refresh and fill gaps in background knowledge. By invitation only. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 121 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; and approval of the department. Corequisites: MATH 180. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Students eligible to enroll will be contacted by the department.

Course: MATH 179 — Emerging Scholars Workshop for Calculus I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Intensive math workshop for students enrolled in MATH 180. Students work together in groups to solve challenging problems. Prerequisites: Admission to the Emerging Scholars Program. Must enroll concurrently in MATH 180. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Emerging Scholars Workshop for Calculus I
metadata.subject: Mathematics (MATH)

text: Course: MATH 180 — Calculus I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 4 Description: Differentiation, curve sketching, maximum-minimum problems, related rates, mean-value theorem, antiderivative, Riemann integral, logarithm, and exponential functions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 121 or appropriate performance on the department placement test. Course Information: Prior credit in MATH 165 or MATH 170 will be lost with subsequent completion of MATH 180. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: MATH 181 — Calculus II Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 4 Description: Techniques of integration, arc length, solids of revolution, applications, polar coordinates, parametric equations, infinite sequences and series, power series. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 180. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: MATH 182 — Emerging Scholars Workshop for Calculus II Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Intensive math workshop for students enrolled in MATH 181. Students work together in groups to solve challenging problems. Prerequisites: Admission to the Emerging Scholars Program. Must enroll concurrently in MATH 181. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Emerging Scholars Workshop for Calculus II
metadata.subject: Mathematics (MATH)

text: Course: MATH 194 — Special Topics in Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: MATH 210 — Calculus III Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: Vectors in space, functions of several variables, partial differential and optimization, multiple integrals, vector fields, Green’s Theorem, Stokes Theorem. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: MATH 211 — Emerging Scholars Workshop for Calculus III Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Intensive math workshop for students enrolled in MATH 210. Students work together in groups to solve challenging problems. Prerequisites: Admission to the Emerging Scholars Program. Must enroll concurrently in MATH 210. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Emerging Scholars Workshop for Calculus III
metadata.subject: Mathematics (MATH)

text: Course: MATH 215 — Introduction to Advanced Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to methods of proofs used in different fields in mathematics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181 and approval of the department.

Course: MATH 218 — Applied Linear Algebra Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: Matrices, row reduction algorithm, vector spaces, LU-decomposition, orthogonality, Gram-Schmidt process, determinants, inner products, eigenvalue problems, applications to differential equations and Markov processes. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181. Course Information: Previously listed as MATH 310. Credit is not given for MATH 218 if the student has credit in MATH 310.

Course: MATH 220 — Introduction to Differential Equations Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques and applications of differential equations, first and second order equations, Laplace transforms, series solutions, graphical and numerical methods, and partial differential equations. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: MATH 294 — Special Topics in Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: MATH 300 — Writing for Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1 Description: Fulfills Writing-in-the-Discipline requirement. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 or the equivalent, and a grade of C or better in MATH 210. Students must have declared a major in the Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science Department.

Course: MATH 313 — Analysis I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: The real number system, limits, continuous functions, differentiability, the Riemann integral. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215 or consent of the instructor.

Course: MATH 320 — Linear Algebra I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: Linear equations, Gaussian elimination, matrices, vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Prerequisites: A grade of C or better in MATH 215.
Course: MATH 330 — Abstract Algebra I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 Description: Sets, properties of integers, groups, rings, fields. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215.

Course: MATH 394 — Special Topics in Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 2-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MATH 410 — Advanced Calculus I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Functions of several variables, differentials, theorems of partial differentiation. Calculus of vector fields, line and surface integrals, conservative fields, Stokes's and divergence theorems. Cartesian tensors. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 411 — Advanced Calculus II Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Implicit and inverse function theorems, transformations, Jacobians. Point-set theory. Sequences, infinite series, convergence tests, uniform convergence. Improper integrals, gamma and beta functions, Laplace transform. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 410. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 414 — Analysis II Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Riemann-Stieltjes integration. Topology of metric spaces with emphasis on R^n. (Uniform) Continuity of functions on metric spaces. Multi-dimensional differentiation theory. Implicit and Inverse Function Theorem and applications. Introduction to Lebes. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 313 and MATH 218 , or MATH 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 417 — Complex Analysis with Applications Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Complex numbers, analytic functions, complex integration, Taylor and Laurent series, residue calculus, branch cuts, conformal mapping, argument principle, Rouche's theorem, Poisson integral formula, analytic continuation. Prerequisites: Grade C or better in MATH 210. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 419 — Models in Applied Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to mathematical modeling; scaling, graphical methods, optimization, computer simulation, stability, differential equation models, elementary numerical methods, applications in biology, chemistry, engineering and physics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 220 and grade of C or better in MCS 260. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 425 — Linear Algebra II Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Canonical forms of a linear transformation, inner product spaces, spectral theorem, principal axis theorem, quadratic forms, special topics such as linear programming. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 430 — Formal Logic I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: First order logic, syntax and semantics, completeness-incompleteness. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 202 or grade of C or better in MCS 261 or grade of C or better in MATH 215. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for MATH 430 if the student has credit for PHIL 416.

Course: MATH 431 — Abstract Algebra II Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Further topics in abstract algebra: Sylow Theorems, Galois Theory, finitely generated modules over a principal ideal domain. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 320 and grade of C or better in MATH 330. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 435 — Foundations of Number Theory Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Primes, divisibility, congruences, Chinese remainder theorem, primitive roots, quadratic residues, quadratic reciprocity, and Jacobi symbols. The Euclidean algorithm and strategies of computer programming. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 436 — Number Theory for Applications Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Primality testing methods of Lehmer, Rumely, Cohen-Lenstra, Atkin. Factorization methods of Gauss, Pollard, Shanks, Lenstra, and quadratic sieve. Computer algorithms involving libraries and nested subroutines. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 435. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 442 — Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Frenet formulas, isoperimetric inequality, local theory of surfaces, Gaussian and mean curvature, geodesics, parallelism, and the Guass-Bonnet theorem. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces
metadata.subject: Mathematics (MATH)

text: Course: MATH 445 — Introduction to Topology I Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Elements of metric spaces and topological spaces including product and quotient spaces, compactness, connectedness, and completeness. Examples from Euclidean space and function spaces. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 313. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 446 — Introduction to Topology II Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in topology chosen from the following: advanced point set topology, piecewise linear topology, fundamental group and knots, differential topology, applications to physics and biology. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 445. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 480 — Applied Differential Equations Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Linear first-order systems. Numerical methods. Nonlinear differential equations and stability. Introduction to partial differential equations. Sturm-Liouville theory. Boundary value problems and Green's functions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 220. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 481 — Applied Partial Differential Equations Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Initial value and boundary value problems for second order linear equations. Eiqenfunction expansions and Sturm-Liouville theory. Green's functions. Fourier transform. Characteristics. Laplace transform. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 220. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MATH 494 — Special Topics in Mathematics Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MATH 496 — Independent Study Subject: Mathematics (MATH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Reading course supervised by a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the instructor and the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: MCS 160 — Introduction to Computer Science Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 4 Description: Computer literacy, number systems, concepts of operation systems, storage, files, databases, logic gates, circuits, networks, internet. Introduction to programming in Python, variables, assignments, functions, objects. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 180 Course Information: Previously listed as MCS 260. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 180 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 180

Course: MCS 275 — Programming Tools and File Management Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 4 Description: Theory, techniques, and tools of the Python programming language, with applications to data structures, algorithms, web programming, and selected topics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 180 , and grade of C or better in MCS 160 or MCS 260 or CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 111 or equivalent. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: MCS 294 — Special Topics in Computer Science Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: MCS 320 — Introduction to Symbolic Computation Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to computer algebra systems (MAPLE), symbolic computation, and the mathematical algorithms employed in such computation, with examples and applications to topics in undergraduate mathematics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210 ; and grade of C or better in: MCS 160 or MCS 260 or CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 111 or equivalent.

Course: MCS 360 — Introduction to Data Structures Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 4 Description: Pointers and dynamic memory allocation in C/C++, recursion, stacks, queues, heaps, binary and multiway trees, graphs, hash tables. Sorting and searching algorithms. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MCS 160 or Grade of C or better in MCS 260; and Grade of C or better in MCS 275. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: MCS 361 — Discrete Mathematics Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 Description: Discrete mathematical structures used in computer science: sets, functions and relations; induction, recursive definitions and relations, methods of proof, quantifiers; counting; graphs and trees; algorithms. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215 ; or grade of C or better in CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 111 ; or equivalent. Course Information: Previously listed as MCS 261.

Course: MCS 394 — Special Topics in Computer Science Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 2-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MCS 401 — Computer Algorithms I Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Design and analysis of computer algorithms. Divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, greedy method, backtracking. Algorithms for sorting, searching, graph computations, pattern matching, NP-complete problems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MCS 360 ; or Grade of C or better in CS 251. Course Information: Same as CS 401. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 411 — Compiler Design Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Language translation: lexical analysis, parsing schemes, symbol table management, syntax and semantic error detection, and code generation. Development of fully-functional compiler. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CS 301 or Grade of C or better in MCS 441 ; and Grade of C or better in CS 251 or Grade of C or better in MCS 360 ; and Grade of C or better in CS 261. Course Information: Same as CS 473. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 415 — Programming Language Design Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Definition, design, and implementation of programming languages. Syntactic and semantic description; variable bindings, control and data structures, parsing, code generation, optimization; exception handling; data abstraction. Prerequisites: MCS 360 ; or CS 341. Course Information: Same as CS 476. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 421 — Combinatorics Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The pigeonhole principle, permutations and combinations, binomial coefficients, inclusionexclusion principle, recurrence relations and generating functions, special counting sequences, Polya theory of counting. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215 ; and Grade of C or better in MATH 218 or Grade of C or better in MATH 320 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 423 — Graph Theory Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Basic concepts of graph theory including Eulerian and hamiltonian cycles, trees, colorings, connectivity, shortest paths, minimum spanning trees, network flows, bipartite matching, planar graphs. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215 ; and Grade of C or better in MATH 218 or Grade of C or better in MATH 320 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 425 — Codes and Cryptography Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Mathematics of communications theory, basic information theory necessary to understand both coding theory and cryptography, basic ideas and highlights for both coding theory and cryptography, including public-key cryptosystems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215 ; and Grade of C or better in MATH 218 or Grade of C or better in MATH 320 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 441 — Theory of Computation I Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to formal languages; relations between grammars and automata; elements of the theory of computable functions. Prerequisites: MATH 215. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 451 — Object-Oriented Programming in C++ Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: C++ as an object-oriented language, classes and member functions, access control, class scope, constructors, destructors, overloading, conversions, streams, derived classes, polymorphism through virtual functions, templates, class libraries. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MCS 360 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for MCS 451 if the student has credit for CS 474. Extensive computer use required.

Course: MCS 471 — Numerical Analysis Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to numerical analysis; floating point arithmetic, computational linear algebra, iterative solution to nonlinear equations, interpolation, numerical integration, numerical solution of ODEs, computer subroutine packages. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MCS 260; or grade of C or better in CS 107 or CS 109 or CS 111 ; or consent of instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 472 — Introduction to Industrial Math and Computation Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Technical writing and oral presentations in preparation for industrial projects. Topics include quality control, operations research, cost-benefit analysis, differential equations, using scientific software. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MCS 471 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Designed for students with a desire to explore mathematics via practical field work.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Industrial Math and Computation
metadata.subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS)

text: Course: MCS 481 — Computational Geometry Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Algorithmic problems on sets of points, rectangles, intervals, arcs, chords, polygons. Counting, reporting, location, intersection, pairing; static and dynamic data structures. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MCS 401 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MCS 494 — Special Topics in Computer Science Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in mathematical computer science, such as symbolic compution, automated reasoning, cryptography or geometric algorithms. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MCS 496 — Independent Study Subject: Mathematical Computer Science (MCS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Reading course supervised by a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the instructor and the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limted number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: ME 118 — Energy for Sustainable Society Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on how energy systems work today and how they can work in a decarbonized sustainable future, while still meeting the critical energy needs of global developed and developing societies. Course Information: Same as IE 118. Individual and Society course.

Course: ME 205 — Introduction to Thermodynamics Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of energy transport and work; properties of substances and equations of state; first and second laws of thermodynamics; applications to mechanical cycles and systems. Prerequisites: PHYS 141 and MATH 181.

Course: ME 210 — Engineering Dynamics Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. Introduction to Linear Algebra. Kinematics in different coordinate systems, coordinate transformations. Kinetics: Newton's second law, work energy relations, impulse-momentum relations, impact problems. Prerequisites: CME 201.

Course: ME 211 — Fluid Mechanics I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 4 Description: Fluid properties. Dimensional analysis. Statics and kinematics. Conservation equations. Inviscid and incompressible flows. Bernoulli's equation. Integral momentum theorems. Viscous flows. Boundary layer theories. Compressible Flows. Prerequisites: PHYS 141 and MATH 220. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ME 250 — Introduction to Engineering Design and Graphics Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Engineering design process, modeling, analysis. Product dissection, prototyping. Technical communication, AutoCAD, engineering graphics software, 3-D views, multiview projection, dimensioning and tolerancing, standards. Team design project. Prerequisites: Eligibility to register for ENGL 160. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Engineering Design and Graphics
metadata.subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME)

text: Course: ME 261 — Materials for Manufacturing Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 2 Description: Introductory-level course in materials engineering to familiarize students with relationships between processing, structure and properties of materials used to manufacture devices. Prerequisites: CHEM 122 and CHEM 123 and PHYS 141 and MATH 181. Course Information: Same as CME 261. Credit is not given for ME 261 if the student has credit for CME 260.

Course: ME 293 — Special Problems Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 1-4 Description: Special problems, readings or research under close supervision of a faculty member in the area of engineering graphics. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: ME 308 — Mechanical Vibrations Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Free and forced vibrations of damped linear single and multiple degree of freedom systems. Approximate methods, instrumentation, and applications. Prerequisites: CS 109 ; and ME 210 ; and MATH 220. Course Information: Same as CME 359.

Course: ME 312 — Dynamic Systems and Control Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Dynamics of linear systems. Modeling of mechanical, electrical, fluid, and thermal systems. Analysis and design of feedback control systems. Analytical, computer and experimental solution methods. Time and frequency domain techniques. Prerequisites: CS 109 and ECE 210 and MATH 220 ; and sophomore standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as IE 312.

Course: ME 318 — Fluid Mechanics II Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Conservation equations for fluid mechanics, inviscid ideal flows, viscous flow solutions of Navier-Stokes equations, pipe flows and boundary flows, compressible flow, computer solutions and applications. Prerequisites: ME 211.

Course: ME 320 — Mechanisms and Dynamics of Machinery Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Kinematic analysis and synthesis of mechanisms; linkages, cams, spur gears, gear trains. Dynamic forces in machines; bearing reactions, balancing, flywheel design, friction, efficiency. Prerequisites: ME 210.

Course: ME 321 — Heat Transfer Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 4 Description: Modes of heat transfer, material properties, one- and two-dimensional conduction. Extended surfaces. Forced and free convection. Heat exchangers. Radiation. Shape factors. Laboratories in conduction, convection, and radiation. Prerequisites: ME 205 and credit or concurrent enrollment in ME 211. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ME 325 — Intermediate Thermodynamics Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: In-depth study of thermodynamic principles, thermodynamics of state, vapor and gas power cycles, refrigeration cycles, thermodynamics of nonreacting and reacting mixtures, internal combustion engines, and thermodynamics of equilibrium. Prerequisites: ME 205 and credit or concurrent registration in ME 211. Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 Prereq Codes (parsed): ME 211 Coreq Codes (parsed): ME 211

Course: ME 328 — Numerical Methods in Mechanical Engineering Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to numerical solution methods for problems in mechanical engineering. Example problems include heat transfer, fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, mechanical vibrations, dynamics, stress analysis, and other related problems. Prerequisites: CS 109 and Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 310. Open only to juniors and seniors. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 310 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 310 Course Information: Previously listed as ME 428. Extensive computer use required. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 310 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 310

Course: ME 341 — Experimental Methods in Mechanical Engineering Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the theory and practice of experimental methods, measurement techniques, instrumentation, data acquisition and data analysis in mechanical and thermal-fluid systems. Experiments and reports. Prerequisites: CME 203 ; and ME 211. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ME 347 — Engineering Design and Graphics with Computer-Aided Design and Simulation Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Conventional and computer-assisted methods in design. Geometric manipulation. Computer-aided modeling with curves, surfaces, and solids. Design with finite-element analysis. Prerequisites: MATH 220 and CME 203 and ME 250. Course Information: Previously listed as ME 447. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture. Recommended Background: Credit in MATH 310.

metadata.class_name: Engineering Design and Graphics with Computer-Aided Design and Simulation
metadata.subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME)

text: Course: ME 348 — Artificial Intelligence and Data Mining for Engineering Applications Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of artificial intelligence (AI), data analytics, and ethics in AI in the context of Operations and Industrial Engineering Applications. Prerequisites: IE 342. Course Information: Same as IE 348. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Artificial Intelligence and Data Mining for Engineering Applications
metadata.subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME)

text: Course: ME 370 — Mechanical Engineering Design Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Mechanical design concepts, failure prevention under static and variable loading, application of engineering mechanics and materials to analysis, selection and design of mechanical elements such as shafts, fasteners, springs, bearings, and gears. Prerequisites: CME 203 and ME 250. Recommended Background: ME 320.

Course: ME 380 — Manufacturing Process Principles Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to basic manufacturing processes such as casting, bulk deformation, sheet metal forming, metal cutting. Interaction between materials, design and manufacturing method. Economics of manufacturing. Prerequisites: CME 203. Course Information: Same as IE 380.

Course: ME 391 — Mechanical Engineering Practicum Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply the skills and knowledge gained in previous engineering courses within a professional, working environment. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 1 hour awarded toward degree requirements.

Course: ME 392 — Undergraduate Research Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research under close supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the head of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: ME 394 — Senior Capstone Design Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 4 Description: Systematic approach to the design process. Creative problem solving. Design methodology and engineering principles applied to open-ended design problems with inherent breadth and innovation. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as IE 394. Credit is not given for ME 394 if the student has credit for ME 396 or IE 396.

Course: ME 396 — Senior Design I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 Description: Systematic approach to the design process. Creative problem solving. Design methodology and engineering principles applied to open-ended design problems with inherent breadth and innovation. Prerequisites: ME 347 and IE 201 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 370 ; or IE 201 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365. Open only to seniors. Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 370 Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in ME 211 and Credit or concurrent registration in ME 370 Credit or concurrent registration in IE 345 and Credit or concurrent registration in IE 365 Course Information: Same as IE 396. Credit is not given for ME 396 if the student has credit in IE 444 or ME 444 or IE 445 or ME 445. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Prereq Codes (parsed): ME 211, ME 370, IE 345, IE 365 Coreq Codes (parsed): ME 211, ME 370, IE 345, IE 365

Course: ME 397 — Senior Design Il Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 2 or 3 Description: The systematic approach to the design process; creative problem solving; design methodology and engineering principles learned in ME 396 are applied to complete the Senior Design project. Prerequisites: ME 396 ; or IE 396 ; and senior standing or above. Corequisites: ME 499 or IE 499. Course Information: Same as IE 397. Credit is not given for ME 397 if the student has credit for IE 444 or ME 444 or IE 445 or ME 445.

Course: ME 401 — Applied Stress Analysis I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Complex bending and torsion, curved flexural members, energy methods in design, theories of failure. Prerequisites: CME 203. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 408 — Intermediate Vibration Theory Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Free and forced vibrations of multi-degree of freedom linear systems. Lagrangian dynamics, matrix, approximate and numerical methods. Prerequisites: ME 308. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 409 — Advanced Kinematics I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Kinematic synthesis of planar linkages. Higher-order, precision point and approximate synthesis. Unified treatment of position, function, and path-angle problems. Consideration of branching and rotatability. Prerequisites: ME 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 410 — Automation and Robotics Applications Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Basic pneumatic and hydraulic systems. Design of sequential control circuits and ladder diagrams. Robot kinematics and dynamics. Robot design. Trajectory planning. Applications and demonstrations. Prerequisites: ME 210. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 411 — Mechatronics I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 0-4 Description: Elements of mechatronic systems, sensors, actuators, microcontrollers, modeling, hardware in the loop simulations, real time software, Electromechanical systems laboratory experiments. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as IE 411. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: ME 412 — Dynamic Systems Analysis I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Classical control theory, concept of feedback, laplace transform, transfer functions, control system characteristics, root locus, frequency response, compensator design. Prerequisites: ME 308. Course Information: Same as IE 412. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 413 — Dynamics of Mechanical Systems Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Degrees of freedom, generalized coordinates, principle of virtual work.
