D'Alembert's Principle, Lagrange's Equation, Hamilton's Principle. Equations of motion and Newton-Euler equations for rigid bodies. Prerequisites: ME 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 414 — Theory of Gearing and Applications Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Classification of gear drives. Geometry of plane and spatial gears. Analysis and synthesis of gears with approximate meshing. Applications to spur, helical, worm and bevel gear drives. Prerequisites: ME 320. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 415 — Propulsion Theory Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Thermodynamics and fluid mechanics of air-breathing engines, performance of rockets; chemical and nuclear rockets. Prerequisites: ME 419 or the equivalent. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 416 — Railroad Vehicle Dynamics Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduces analytical and computational methods used for the computer aided dynamic and stability analysis of railroad vehicle systems. Prerequisites: ME 413 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 417 — Intermediate Fluid Mechanics Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Development of conservation equations for Newtonian-fluids; continuity, Navier-Stokes and energy equations. Some exact and approximate solutions of highly viscous, viscous and inviscid flows. Boundary layer flows, jets and wakes. Prerequisites: ME 321. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 418 — Transport Phenomena in Nanotechnology Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Free surface flows, rheologically complex liquids, colloidal suspensions, emulsions, Brownian motion, flows in micro- and nanochannels, and multiple applications. Prerequisites: ME 325 and ME 211. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 419 — Compressible Flow Theory Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Conservation laws, one-dimensional flows. Normal and oblique shock waves, Prandtl-Meyer expansion, flow over airfoils. Applications to nozzles, shock-tubes, wind-tunnels. Flow with friction and heat addition or loss. Prerequisites: ME 321. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 420 — Combined Heat and Power Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Presents fundamental issues of successfully integrating and implementing energy systems. Combined heat and power (e.g. CHP, cogeneration) strategies, integration of renewable with nonrenewable energy sources, and impacting policies are discussed. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Same as ENER 420. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: ME 321 and ME 325.

Course: ME 421 — Intermediate Heat Transfer Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in conduction, convection and radiation with emphasis on exact solutions: extended surfaces, internal and external flows, surface radiation, combined modes of heat transfer and selected topics. Prerequisites: ME 321 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 422 — Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Refrigeration systems and heat-pump, mass transfer in humidification, solar heat transfer in buildings, heating and cooling loads, air-conditioning computer project. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Same as ENER 482. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: ME 321.

Course: ME 423 — Heat Exchangers Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Classification; heat transfer and pressure drop analysis, flow distribution, transient performance, surface selection and geometrical properties, codes and standards. Prerequisites: ME 211 and ME 321. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 424 — Energy Management Solutions for Industry: Theory and Practice Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Emphasis on real world applications including: understanding utility billing and identifying costs; identifying and quantifying energy savings opportunities at industrial facilities; determining investment payback scenarios and considerations. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Same as ENER 483. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Extensive use of Microsoft Excel.

metadata.class_name: Energy Management Solutions for Industry: Theory and Practice
metadata.subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME)

text: Course: ME 425 — Second Law Analysis in Energy Engineering Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamentals: lost available work. Entropy generation minimization, optimal thermal design of: heat transfer augmentation devices, thermal energy storage, cryogenics, heat exchangers, thermal insulations, solar collectors. Prerequisites: ME 321. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Second Law Analysis in Energy Engineering
metadata.subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME)

text: Course: ME 426 — Applied Combustion Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in combustion, providing both a theoretical and applied understanding of combustion processes as they relate to furnaces. Internal and external combustion engines; pollutant formation. Prerequisites: ME 325. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 427 — Solar Engineering Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Applications; solar geometry and intensities; applied heat transfer topics; flat plate and concentrating collectors; energy storage; analysis of heating and cooling systems. Prerequisites: ME 321 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 429 — Internal Combustion Engines Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to engine types, characteristics and performance. Combustion processes in spark and compression ignition engines; combustion abnormalities. Analysis of intake, exhaust and fuel system. Prerequisites: Junior standing. Course Information: Same as ENER 482. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: ME 325.

Course: ME 433 — Non-Equilibrium Thermal Processes Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Molecular engineering. Non-equilibrium statistical mechanics. Distribution functions. Molecular excitation and de-excitation. Ionization and dissociation. Laser engineering. Non-equilibrium chemical kinetics. Surface processes. Chemisorption and physosorption. Prerequisites: ME 325 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 441 — Optical Methods in Mechanical Engineering Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 0-4 Description: Optical measurement techniques in solid mechanics and thermal-fluid engineering. Fundamentals of optics. Use of holography, interferometry, LDV, lasers, light scattering, diffraction, and other relevant techniques. Prerequisites: Senior standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ME 444 — Interdisciplinary Product Development I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Systematic approach to the design process. Creative problem solving. Cross-functional teams (w/students from other departments/colleges) research and apply new product concepts to open-ended design problems. Prerequisites: ME 347 and IE 201 ; or IE 345 and IE 201 ; and senior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IE 444. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit for ME 444 is not given if the student has credit in ME 396 or ME 397 or IE 396 or IE 397. Year-long (with IE/ ME 445 ) project course.

Course: ME 445 — Interdisciplinary Product Development 2 Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 4 Description: Systematic approach to the design process. Creative problem solving. Cross-functional teams (w/students from other departments/colleges) research and apply new product concepts to open-ended design problems. Focus on solutions to the opportunities. Prerequisites: IE 444 or ME 444 ; and senior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IE 445. Credit is not given for ME 445 if the student has credit in ME 396 or ME 397 or IE 396 or IE 397.Year-long (with IE/ ME 444 ) project course.

Course: ME 449 — Microdevices and Micromachining Technology Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 0-5 Description: Microfabrication techniques for microsensors, microstructures, and microdevices. Selected examples of physical/chemical sensors and actuators. Simulation experiments. Prerequisites: ECE 347 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ECE 449. 4 undergraduate hours. 5 graduate hours. Laboratory. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: ME 450 — Air Pollution Engineering Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Environmental aspects of combustion processes, pollutant formation. Control of pollutants and particulates. Air quality control. Fundamentals of combustion. Prerequisites: ME 321 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CHE 450 and ENER 485. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 451 — Electric Power Generation Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Comprehensive study of the fossil fuel fired power plants cycles with emphasis on their efficient performance and exergy analysis. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as ENER 451. Recommended Background: ME 321 and ME 325.

Course: ME 453 — Sustainable Energy Engineering and Renewable Energy Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An in-depth study of renewable energy systems, focusing on the principles, technologies, and applications. It focuses on various renewable energy sources, including solar, wind, hydro, biomass, and geothermal etc. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Course Information: Same as ENER 453. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ENER 553. Recommended Background: ME 321 and ME 325.

metadata.class_name: Sustainable Energy Engineering and Renewable Energy
metadata.subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME)

text: Course: ME 464 — Virtual Automation Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 0-4 Description: Fundamentals of manufacturing and automation modeling using CAD/CAM and computer-integrated manufacturing methods; concepts of virtual manufacturing; industrial robots and automated factory models within virtual environments. Prerequisites: CS 107 or CS 108. Course Information: Same as IE 464. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion, and one Laboratory.

Course: ME 468 — Virtual Manufacturing Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Virtual reality applications in manufacturing systems design, manufacturing applications of networked virtual reality, virtual reality modeling of occupational safety engineering. Prerequisites: CS 107 or CS 108. Course Information: Same as IE 468. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: ME 481 — Additive Manufacturing Process Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Covers aspects of additive manufacturing. The types that are covered are generic process, design, vat photopolymerization, extrusion based, jetting, direct writing, 3D bio-printing, powder bed fusion, slicing, and data representation. Course Information: Same as IE 481. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Manufacturing Processes.

Course: ME 494 — Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Particular topics vary from term to term depending on the interests of the students and the specialties of the instructor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated.

Course: ME 496 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis I Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 0-8 Description: Introduction to the principles and practice of product design: specifications, evaluation of design alternatives, technical reports, and oral presentations, through independent design projects. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IE 496. Credit only given to nondegree students. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in Engineering. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: ME 497 — Undergraduate Senior Design Thesis II Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 0-8 Description: ntroduction to engineering design and research methods: design tools, product conception and development, simulation, prototyping, technical reports and presentations, literature survey and undergraduate thesis. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as IE 497. Credit only given to nondegree students. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in Engineering. Extensive computer use required. Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: ME 499 — Professional Development Seminar Subject: Mechanical Engineering (ME) Credits: 0 Description: Students are provided general information about their role as UIC MIE alumni in society and the role of the University in their future careers. Students provide evaluations of their educational experience in the MIE department. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors; and approval of the department. Must be taken in the student's last semester of study. Course Information: Same as IE 499. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: MGMT 115 — Introduction to Global and Cross-Cultural Studies Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: A multidisciplinary and comparative approach to globalization and its economic, social, cultural and political impact. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Global and Cross-Cultural Studies
metadata.subject: Management (MGMT)

text: Course: MGMT 340 — Introduction to Organizations Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Organization and management concepts and applications. Individual and organizational goal attainment. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Recommended Background: General knowledge of microeconomics.

Course: MGMT 350 — Business and Its External Environment Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Concerns the political, economic, social, legal, regulatory and international environment of business and the ethics and social responsibility of business actions. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 and MATH 160.

Course: MGMT 355 — Structured Problem Solving for Consulting Projects Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Teaches structured problem-solving methods for consulting projects, introduces management frameworks, and covers methods and tools to facilitate implementation. Prerequisites: IDS 200 and IDS 270 and ACTG 210 and BA 200 and MGMT 340.

metadata.class_name: Structured Problem Solving for Consulting Projects
metadata.subject: Management (MGMT)

text: Course: MGMT 360 — Data Analytics for Management Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Examines types and sources of information used by managers and investors to make strategic decisions; provides working knowledge of tools used to effectively manage, analyze and report strategic information. Prerequisites: IDS 270 and MGMT 340 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ENTR 360. Extensive computer use required.

Course: MGMT 370 — Foundations of Sports Management Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the field of sports management and an overview of relevant functional areas of the industry and an examination of current and new trends affecting sport management. Prerequisites: ENGL 161.

Course: MGMT 445 — Organizational Theory Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasis on organizational theories and models to analyze and improve functioning and performance of organizations. Structure, technology, environmental adaptation, and managerial control systems. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and junior standing.

Course: MGMT 447 — Organizations Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Characteristics of business, government, and not-for-profit organizations; approaches used to study organizations; theoretical and empirical analysis of organizational processes. Prerequisites: SOC 241 or MGMT 340 or SOC 244 ; and junior standing or above and an additional 200 or 300-level elective in sociology; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as SOC 447. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MGMT 452 — Organizational Behavior Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasis on understanding and managing people at work. Analysis of individual, group and organization topics including leadership, motivation, attitudes, group dynamics, and organizational culture. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: MGMT 453 — Human Resource Management Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the activities involved in attracting, retaining, and motivating employees. Topics include planning, selection, compensation, performance appraisal, succession, and legal issues. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: MGMT 454 — Labor-Management Relations Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Labor unions and their impact on business firms and society. Labor-management relationships and collective bargaining practices. Public policy, union structure and bargaining theory. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and MGMT 350 and junior standing.

Course: MGMT 455 — Talent Management and Global Human Resources Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of topics related to performance appraisal: motivating, retaining, and separating employees; compensation and benefits; managing human resources in a global economy. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and credit or concurrent registration in MGMT 453. Credit or concurrent registration in MGMT 453 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MGMT 453 Prereq Codes (parsed): MGMT 453 Coreq Codes (parsed): MGMT 453

metadata.class_name: Talent Management and Global Human Resources
metadata.subject: Management (MGMT)

text: Course: MGMT 457 — Foundations Sustain Business Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to sustainable business foundations: setting sustainability goals and key performance indicators, governance, stakeholder engagement and communication, strategic operations, technology integration, financial accountability, and reporting. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ACTG 457 and IDS 457.

Course: MGMT 460 — Managing Globally Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Understanding the opportunities and problems that confront managers as they lead a company through complex global economic, political, legal, technological and cultural environment. Focus on people, values and culture. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and MGMT 350 Admission to Master of Science in Human Resources, or post-baccalaureate leadership certificate; or consent of Instructor.

Course: MGMT 463 — Negotiation and Conflict Resolution Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Strategies and techniques for successful agreement negotiation and business conflict resolution. Includes applications to classic situations such as collective bargaining, interpersonal relations, and stakeholder concerns. Prerequisites: MGMT 340.

Course: MGMT 464 — Employment Recruitment and Selection Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: The design and application of internal and external recruitment, selection and retention systems for the effective management of human capital by line managers and HR professionals. Prerequisites: MGMT 452 and MGMT 453.

Course: MGMT 465 — Compensation and Reward Systems Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of compensation and reward systems designed to enhance employee motivation and performance. Topics include pay structure design, incentive systems, and benefits. Prerequisites: MGMT 452 and MGMT 455 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: MGMT 466 — Managerial Effectiveness Through Diversity Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Management of diverse work forces. Discrimination, affirmative action, career development, socialization and social change policies; historical, psychological, sociological, legal and managerial viewpoints. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and admissions to Master of Science in Human Resources or post-baccalaureate leadership certificate; or consent of Instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MGMT 467 — Impact of Technological Change Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the impact of technological change upon the business environment and the managerial process. Emphasis on alternative futures and the planning necessary to attain desired ends. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and MGMT 350.

Course: MGMT 470 — Training and Development Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the science, methods, and practice of personnel training and development. Topics include needs determination, training design and delivery, training assessments. Prerequisites: MGMT 452 and MGMT 453 ; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Experience as an intern or practitioner in an area of human resource management or organizational development.

Course: MGMT 471 — Organizational Design Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Covers how a firm’s people, resources, processes, and culture are arrayed and deployed to help implement firm strategies, pursue key objectives, and respond to environmental demands. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and MGMT 452 , or consent of the instructor.

Course: MGMT 475 — Leadership Theories and Personal Leadership Skills Development Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of leadership theories, assessment of leadership strengths and weaknesses, and leadership skills training. Prerequisites: MGMT 340.

metadata.class_name: Leadership Theories and Personal Leadership Skills Development
metadata.subject: Management (MGMT)

text: Course: MGMT 480 — Transportation Systems Management Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a fundamental knowledge of problems and practices encountered in the management of transportation systems. Includes impact of public policy; capital facilities; industry structure; costs; operations pricing and environmental relationships. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and MGMT 350 , or consent of the instructor.

Course: MGMT 481 — Managerial Logistics Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Management of activities governing flow of materials and products through stages of production and distribution. Includes design of logistical systems and use of mathematical techniques. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 ; and MATH 165 or MATH 180 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: MGMT 485 — Corporate Sustainability and Responsibility Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Theories and techniques for designing and implementing corporate sustainability and responsibility programs to create private and social value. Prerequisites: MGMT 340 and MGMT 350.

Course: MGMT 486 — Managerial Consulting Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Development of knowledge and critical skills necessary to operate effectively as internal or external management consultants through an applied experience with an organization. Prerequisites: MGMT 452 and MGMT 453 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MGMT 490 — Cracking the Case: Case Analysis for Consulting Projects Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Develops students’ ability to understand analytical variations across industries and identify relevant data and facts to solve managerial issues. This course will introduce students to the case methodology. Prerequisites: ACTG 210 and ACTG 211 and BA 200 and FIN 301 and FIN 302 and IDS 200 ; and IDS 270 and IDS 355 and MGMT 340 and MGMT 350 and MKTG 360 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: MGMT 355 and MGMT 360.

metadata.class_name: Cracking the Case: Case Analysis for Consulting Projects
metadata.subject: Management (MGMT)

text: Course: MGMT 494 — Special Topics in Management Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of areas not covered in existing course offerings or study of selected topics in greater depth. Subject matter will vary from semester to semester. Prerequisites: Senior standing and 9 hours of 400-level management courses, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MGMT 495 — Competitive Strategy Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 4 Description: Multidisciplinary analysis of organization strategy and policy, using case method and/or business simulation. Assignments involve extensive library research and oral and written reports. Prerequisites: IDS 355 or IE 365 ; and FIN 300 Senior standing in the College of Business Administration or senior standing in Engineering Management, and completion of all other CBA core courses. Course Information: Credit is not given for MGMT 495 if the student has credit in ACTG 495 or FIN 495 or IDS 495.

Course: MGMT 499 — Research Experience Subject: Management (MGMT) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the supervision of a faculty member. The faculty member and student will determine the research project. Each student must submit a written report and each student must participate at a research event on campus. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MILS 101 — Leadership and Personal Development Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 1 Description: Examines the personal development of life skills such as cultural understanding, goal setting, time management, mental/physical resiliency, and stress management related to leadership, officership, and the Army profession. Course Information: Open to all students and enrollment does not require a commitment to join the US Army. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MILS 102 — Introduction to Leadership Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 1 Description: Investigate leadership fundamentals such as problem-solving, listening, presenting briefs, providing feedback, and using effective writing skills. Course Information: Open to all students and enrollment does not require a commitment to join the US Army. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MILS 131 — ROTC Cadet Military Physical Fitness Training Program Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 1 Description: Intended for students participating in ROTC. The students will gradually improve their level of physical fitness over the course of a semester. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

metadata.class_name: ROTC Cadet Military Physical Fitness Training Program
metadata.subject: Military Science (MILS)

text: Course: MILS 151 — Civilian Introduction to Military Physical Fitness Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 1 Description: Intended as an introduction for civilians to Army Physical Fitness. The students will gradually improve their level of physical fitness over the course of a semester. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

metadata.class_name: Civilian Introduction to Military Physical Fitness
metadata.subject: Military Science (MILS)

text: Course: MILS 171 — Advanced Physical Fitness Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 1 Description: This group exercise class incorporates CrossFit type methods along with Army philosophy and teachings. It is focused on advanced weight training, metabolic conditioning, movement skill and technique.

Course: MILS 201 — Foundations of Leadership Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 2 Description: Continues to build on developing knowledge of leadership attributes and core leader competencies through the understanding of Army rank, structure, and duties as well as broadening knowledge of land navigation and squad tactics. Course Information: Enrollment does not require a commitment to join the US Army. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MILS 202 — Foundations of Tactical Leadership Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 2 Description: Examine and practice the challenges of leading teams in the complex operational environment. Study dimensions of terrain analysis, patrolling, and operation orders. Explores the dynamics of adaptive leadership in the context of military operations. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MILS 217 — Introduction to United States Military History Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 3 Description: Analytical study of American military history, doctrine, strategy, and tactics from their origin through the present. Emphasis on leadership, strategy, the principles of war, and growth of the military in the US. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161. Past course. Course Information: Same as HIST 217. Previously listed as MILS 107.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to United States Military History
metadata.subject: Military Science (MILS)

text: Course: MILS 301 — Adaptive Team Leadership Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 3 Description: An academically challenging course where you will study, practice, and apply the fundamentals of Army leadership, officership, Army values and ethics, and small unit tactics. Prerequisites: MILS 101 and MILS 102 and MILS 201 and MILS 202 or attendance at the Leader's Training Course (LTC) and approval of the department. Contact the Military Science Department for more details. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MILS 302 — Applied Team Leadership Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 3 Description: Continue to learn and apply the fundamentals of Army leadership, officership, Army values and ethics as you hone your leadership abilities in a variety of tactical environments and the classroom. Prerequisites: MILS 101 and MILS 102 and MILS 201 and MILS 202 and MILS 301 or attendance at the Leader's Training Course (LTC) and approval of the department. Contact the Military Science Department for more details. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MILS 399 — Advanced Independent Research Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 0-3 Description: Intensive research and study of selected topics. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. A practical laboratory may be required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Conference.

Course: MILS 401 — Adaptive Leadership Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 3 Description: Study the special trust reposed to Army Officers by the US Constitution and the President of the United States--a special trust given to no other civilian professions. Prerequisites: MILS 101 and MILS 102 and MILS 201 and MILS 202 and MILS 301 and MILS 302 or attendance at the Leader Assessment Development Course (LDAC) and approval of the department. Contact the Military Science Department for more details. Course Information: Previously listed as MILS 311. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MILS 402 — Leadership in a Complex World Subject: Military Science (MILS) Credits: 3 Description: Students will learn about aspects of interacting with non-government organizations, civilians on the battlefield and host nation support as well as staff operations and problem solving in a complex environment. Prerequisites: MILS 101 and MILS 102 and MILS 201 and MILS 202 and MILS 301 and MILS 302 and MILS 401 or attendance at the Leader Assessment Development Course (LDAC) and approval of the department. Contact the Military Science Department for more details. Course Information: Previously listed as MILS 394. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: MIM 322 — Microbiology for Dental Students Subject: Microbiology and Immunology (MIM) Credits: 4 Description: Characteristics, transmission, pathogenesis of, and immune response to microorganisms causing human oral and systemic disease. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: MIM 399 — Undergraduate Laboratory Research Subject: Microbiology and Immunology (MIM) Credits: 1-4 Description: Laboratory research for advanced undergraduates. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Live bacteria, viruses and/or animals used in instruction. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

Course: MKTG 360 — Introduction to Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: The role of marketing in business and society. How organizations make marketing decisions and develop effective marketing strategies. Prerequisites: ENGL 160.

Course: MKTG 370 — Quantitative Marketing Skills Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Foundational knowledge in the quantitative analysis of marketing problems and marketing research methods. Prerequisites: MKTG 360. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: MKTG 452 — Principles of Retailing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: The theory and practice of making retailing decisions regarding pricing, product, place and promotion, and the development of strategy based on market competition and trends. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 455 — Multichannel Retailing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: The role of multichannel retail strategies: the development and management of successful online retail models and the coordination of retail activities across multiple platforms and physical stores. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 458 — Digital Marketing Research Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Covers advanced methodologies in market research and data analysis in digital platforms. This includes qualitative and quantitative techniques to understand and analyze data collected from the web and social media. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 and MKTG 462. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: MKTG 459 — Qualitative Research and Discovery: Uncovering Consumer Insights in Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Hands-on experience with qualitative research methods including focus groups, interviews, ethnography, and netnography. Develops skills to uncover actionable consumer insights, contribute to marketing plans, and craft compelling data-driven stories. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

metadata.class_name: Qualitative Research and Discovery: Uncovering Consumer Insights in Marketing
metadata.subject: Marketing (MKTG)

text: Course: MKTG 460 — Marketing Analytics Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to data-centered analysis for critical aspects of marketing, such as sales forcasting, profitibility analysis, market segmentation, promotion budgeting, and database marketing. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 and IDS 270.

Course: MKTG 461 — Consumer Behavior Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the psychology of consumer behavior, focusing on how individuals select, purchase, and use products. Topics include perception, attitudes, cultural and social influences, and motivation, with applications to real-world marketing strategies. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 or consent of the instructor.

Course: MKTG 462 — Marketing Research Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: An investigation of the gathering, analyses and interpretation of information used in solving marketing problems. Both qualitative and quantitative methods are employed in developing an analytical framework. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 ; and IDS 270 or MKTG 370 or STAT 101.

Course: MKTG 463 — Marketing and Sales Channels Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Develop an integrated distribution strategy driven by product and customer needs; understand the selection and roles of channel partners; explore the management of channel relationships. Prerequisites: MKTG 360. Business Administration students must have declared a major; or consent of instructor.
Course: MKTG 464 — Content Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: The planning, design, distribution and management of content for digital marketing. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 465 — Strategic Marketing Management Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of marketing problems, development of marketing strategies, and persuasive communication of strategic and tactical marketing decisions. Prerequisites: 15 hours of marketing course work. Recommended Background: MKTG 461 and MKTG 462.

Course: MKTG 467 — Business Intelligence in Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Provides knowledge of critical concepts and tools in the use of business intelligence in marketing. Students will learn to use business intelligence to gain market and competitive insights and support marketing decision making. Prerequisites: MKTG 462 and IDS 270. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: MKTG 460.

Course: MKTG 468 — Advanced Marketing Research Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced knowledge of critical concepts and tools in marketing research related to problem identification, data collection, and analysis in conventional and digital media. Prerequisites: MKTG 462 and IDS 270. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: MKTG 469 — Global Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: The strategic and tactical marketing of goods and services to countries beyond domestic or current markets. Distinct economic, socio-cultural, and political-legal-regulatory environments are considered. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 and BA 200 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: MKTG 470 — Branding Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of how firms can connect with consumers to build, measure, leverage and protect strong brands. Prerequisites: MKTG 360. Recommended Background: MKTG 462.

Course: MKTG 471 — Services Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of the special challenges of services marketing, including analyzing and developing solutions for new services, services quality, design and delivery of services, and services recovery. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 473 — Introduction to Sales Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Detailed exploration of the steps in a standard selling process; explores buyers motivations; sales presentations skills and sales technologies. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 or consent of the instructor.

Course: MKTG 474 — Integrated Marketing Communications Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Explores Integrated Marketing Communication (IMC): blending different media and communication tools to create cohesive communication campaigns; developing, implementing, and evaluating strategies that align messaging across communication activities. Prerequisites: MKTG 461 or consent of the instructor.

Course: MKTG 475 — Product Management Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Development and management of products and services from a marketing perspective; various aspects of the new product development process from idea generation to product launch; strategic thinking and analytical tools to make decisions in product management. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 476 — Business-to-Business (B2B) Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Unique concepts and strategies applied when businesses market to other organizations and institutions. Derived demand, systems selling, bid pricing, national account programs, and using distributors. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 477 — Interdisciplinary Research and Development I Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Multidisciplinary teams (w/students typically from Design, Engineering, Public Health, etc.) research and develop solutions related to business, social, or healthcare-related topics. Emphasis: problem solving, collaboration, sponsor engagement, and prototyping. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 ; and consent of the instructor. This is the first half of a year-long course. Students will be required to take MKTG 478 in the following semester. Course Information: Students complete a product development project in conjunction with students enrolled in ME 444 and AD 420.

Course: MKTG 478 — Interdisciplinary Research and Development II Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Multidisciplinary teams (w/students typically from Design, Engineering, Public Health, etc.) research and develop solutions related to business, social, or healthcare-related topics. Emphasis: problem solving, collaboration, sponsor engagement, and prototyping. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 and MKTG 477. This is the second half of a year-long course. Students will be required to take MKTG 477 in the previous semester. Course Information: Students complete a product development project in conjunction with students enrolled in ME 445 and AD 421.

Course: MKTG 479 — Digital and Social Media Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Creation, evaluation, and implementation of effective digital and social media marketing strategies and tactics. Prerequisites: MKTG 360. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: BA 200 and MKTG 461 and general computer skills.

Course: MKTG 480 — Approaches to Creativity Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Students will be taught, and have an opportunity to use, the dominant contemporary creative ideation methods used in business, particularly in regards to new products/services and advertisements. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 481 — Advanced Sales Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced selling strategies, including key account and relationship management, team selling, solution presentation techniques, effective negotiation skills, and using sales technology to facilitate connections between the company and its customers. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 and MKTG 473.

Course: MKTG 482 — Innovation Management Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to a human-centered approach to designing products, services and business systems using a Design Thinking methodology. Prerequisites: MKTG 360 and MKTG 462.

Course: MKTG 485 — Customer Experience Management Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 3 Description: Applying customer experience concepts, tools, and research methods in order to understand and manage customer-centric business models across industries. Prerequisites: MKTG 360.

Course: MKTG 494 — Special Topics in Marketing Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 1-4 Description: Exploration of area not covered in existing course offerings or study of selected topics in greater depth. Subject matter may vary from semester to semester. Prerequisites: Business administration students must have declared a major. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MKTG 499 — Research Experience Subject: Marketing (MKTG) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the supervision of a faculty member. The faculty member and student will determine the research project. Each student must submit a written report and each student must participate at a research event on campus. Prerequisites: Major in marketing. Consent of the head of the department and the instructor required. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MOVI 105 — Black Film, 1900 - Present: Images, Individuals and Ideas on Screen Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the history of black people in film – looking both at films by black people in the United States and the diaspora, and at the relationship between black filmmakers, performers, and audiences to national and global film industries. Course Information: Same as BLST 105 and COMM 105. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Black Film, 1900 - Present: Images, Individuals and Ideas on Screen
metadata.subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI)

text: Course: MOVI 130 — Understanding Korean History, Culture and Society through Contemporary Korean Films Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of contemporary Korean history and culture through film. Course Information: Same as KOR 130. Taught in English. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Korean History, Culture and Society through Contemporary Korean Films
metadata.subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI)

text: Course: MOVI 131 — Understanding Moving Image Arts Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Examination and interpretation of moving image texts such as film, television, and new digital media. Course Information: Same as ENGL 131. Creative Arts course.

Course: MOVI 132 — Understanding Film Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Representative selections of film, from a variety of periods and forms. Development of analytical and interpretive skills in understanding film. Course Information: Same as ENGL132. Creative Arts course.

Course: MOVI 200 — Communication Technologies Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Focus on historical and cultural aspects of technology, including identity, community, social justice, popular culture, everyday life. Technologies covered range from early nonverbal communication to AI and technologies of the future. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Individual and Society course. Course Information: Same as COMM 200. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. Consult the schedule of classes for mode of instruction. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: MOVI 207 — European Cinema Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of the major developments in European cinema from the post-World II period to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GER 207 and SPAN 207.

Course: MOVI 208 — Central and Eastern European Cinema Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of the main trends in the central and eastern European cinematic tradition and its role in the history of world cinema. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 ; or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as CEES 208. Taught in English. Weekly film screenings.

Course: MOVI 225 — Spanish and Latin American Culture through Literature and Film Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the Hispanic cultures, both Peninsular and Latin American, as represented in literature and film throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. Prerequisites: Completion of the university writing requirement. Course Information: Same as SPAN 225. Taught in English. Two hours per week to view films. Class Schedule Information: To be properly enrolled, students must register for one Lecture/Discussion and one Lab. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Spanish and Latin American Culture through Literature and Film
metadata.subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI)

text: Course: MOVI 229 — Introduction to Asian Film Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: A theoretical analysis of films by recognized masters of Asian cinema. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 229 and ENGL 229. Taught in English. Films contain English subtitles. One film per week will be screened outside of class. Students may choose to attend the official screenings or watch the films on their own.

Course: MOVI 230 — Introduction to Film and Culture Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of representative works that reflect the relationship between cinema and its cultural context. Course Information: Same as ENGL 230. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: MOVI 232 — History of Film I: 1890 to World War II Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: History of film from its beginnings in the 1890s up to World War II. Course Information: Same as AH 232 and ENGL 232. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: ENGL 131 or ENGL 132 or ENGL 230. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: History of Film I: 1890 to World War II
metadata.subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI)

text: Course: MOVI 233 — History of Film II: World War II to the Present Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: History of film from World War II to contemporary movements in world cinema. Course Information: Same as AH 233 and ENGL 233. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Recommended Background: ENGL 131 or ENGL 132. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: History of Film II: World War II to the Present
metadata.subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI)

text: Course: MOVI 234 — History of Television Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: A critical history of television. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as COMM 234 and ENGL 234. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: MOVI 239 — Twentieth-Century Russia in Film Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of social, political and cultural development of the Russian Empire and Soviet Union through the use of film as a historical source. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or completion of any 100-level history course. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: MOVI 250 — Cinema and Empire Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 4 Description: Explores the legacy of Eurasian cinema with films from the Russian empire, the Soviet Union, the Caucasus, and Central Asia. Topics include: silent film, montage, animation, transition to sound cinema, cinematic realism, and digital media. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Course Information: Same as CEES 250. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. All assignments and course interactions will utilize internet technologies. Students are required to have access to a computer, internet, and the following software packages: A web browser (compatible with Blackboard), Adobe Acrobat Reader or any other free PDF reader, Microsoft Word or Google Docs. Students are responsible for having a reliable computer and internet connection throughout the course. Recommended Background: RUSS 150. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: MOVI 254 — Future Television Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: The expansion of television and the forces shaping its future. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as COMM 254. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: MOVI 270 — The Reel Arab Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of how Arabs are portrayed in the cinema. Exploration of popular films (both Western and Arab) and their prominent conventions. Focus on gender issues, racial and ethnic representations, and analysis of patriarchal attitudes. Prerequisites: Completion of ENGL 160 ; or any 100- or 200-level film course. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as ARAB 270. Taught in English.

Course: MOVI 278 — Latin American/Latino Film Studies Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the history and major aesthetic movements of Latin American cinema. Course Information: Same as LALS 278 and SPAN 278. Taught in English. Includes a film screening component. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: MOVI 280 — Italian and Italian American Cinema Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Italian and Italian American films and cinematic movements presented within the context of Italian culture and its diaspora. Course Information: Same as ITAL 280. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. No knowledge of Italian required. Films screened with English subtitles. This course is offered in both face-to-face (16 weeks) and online asynchronous format (8 weeks). Online courses involve heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: MOVI 331 — Studies in the Moving Image Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 Description: Study of a topic or movement in film and/or other media forms. Course Information: Same as ENGL 331. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Recommended Background: ENGL 131.

Course: MOVI 440 — Topics in French and Francophone Cinema Subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Significant films from either France or another Francophone part of the world will be studied in their historical, intellectual, and cultural context. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 300 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 301 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in FR 302 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hour. Same as FR 440. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hours of credit for undergraduates, or 12 hours of credit for graduate students, as long as the topic is different for each registration. Taught in English. Students who intend to use FR 440 toward the major in French must complete assignment in French.

metadata.class_name: Topics in French and Francophone Cinema
metadata.subject: Moving Image Arts (MOVI)

text: Course: MTHT 400 — Methods of Teaching Secondary Mathematics I Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Teacher preparation with a focus on mathematics education research including analysis of students' thinking using records of practice in the form of case studies both on video and paper. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215 ; or consent of the instructor Enrollment in B.S. or M.S. in the Teaching of Mathematics program in Secondary Mathematics Education, and a 2.50 grade point average in mathematics courses at the level of calculus or above. Student must be admitted to candidacy. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. To be taken in the year prior to student teaching.

metadata.class_name: Methods of Teaching Secondary Mathematics I
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 401 — Methods of Teaching Secondary Mathematics II Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Secondary teacher preparation with focus on practice of teaching and responsibilities of instructional leader based on the Professional Teaching Standards, current research, and best practice. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210 ; Enrollment in the B.S. or M.S. in the Teaching of Mathematics program in Secondary Mathematics Education; and a 2.50 grade point average in mathematics courses at the level of calculus or above. Student must be admitted to candidacy. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. 20 hours observation in secondary mathematics classes. To be taken in year prior to student teaching.

metadata.class_name: Methods of Teaching Secondary Mathematics II
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 411 — Advanced Euclidean Geometry Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Axioms for Euclidean geometry are developed based upon reflections. Further concepts in Euclidean geometry which arise from these axioms are explored. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 215. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MTHT 420 — Computers in Secondary School Mathematics Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An overview of techniques, topics and tools for teaching secondary level mathematics using computers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MTHT 430 — Real Analysis for Teachers I Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Major topics include real number system with emphasis on the completeness axiom, limits of sequences and functions, derivatives, Riemmann integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210 and Grade of C or better in MATH 215. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MTHT 435 — Abstract Algebra Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Sets, properties of integers, groups, rings, fields. Focus on concepts applicable to high school teaching. Prerequisites: MATH 210 and MATH 215. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MTHT 438 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: 2.50 grade point average in mathematics courses at the level of calculus or above, successful completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the department. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: MTHT 439 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MTHT 438 ; and approval of the department and a 2.50 grade point average in mathematics courses at the level of calculus or above and successful completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student teaching field experiences. Credit or concurrent registration in MTHT 438 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MTHT 438 Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): MTHT 438 Coreq Codes (parsed): MTHT 438

Course: MTHT 450 — Concepts and Methods in Elementary and Middle School Mathematics I Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Emphasizes the methods of teaching elementary and middle school mathematics in the context of investigating patterns, functions, number theory, and proportional reasoning. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. For elementary and middle school teachers.

metadata.class_name: Concepts and Methods in Elementary and Middle School Mathematics I
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 465 — Teaching Algebra for Understanding Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Manipulatives and other representations of mathematical concepts used for teaching algebra to middle grade students. Prerequisites: Admission to the M.S. in the Teaching of Mathematics program (Option for Elementary School Teachers) or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: MTHT 466 — Introduction to Calculus and the Graphing Calculator Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 4 Description: Problem solving using derivatives, differentials, and their applications followed by integrals and their applications. Maximumminimum problems solved directly by graphing, then by derivatives. Prerequisites: Admission to the Mathematics Education Concentrators Program or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Calculus and the Graphing Calculator
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 467 — Introduction to Number Theory with Application Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 4 Description: Classical topics of elementary number theory and how they pertain to teaching the upper grades. Primes, GCF, LCM, divisibility, floor and ceiling functions, Gaussian Residue, lattices. Prerequisites: Admission to the Mathematics Education Concentrators Program or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Number Theory with Application
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 468 — Geometry with Applications for Middle Grade Teachers Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 4 Description: Plane and solid figures and their properties. Polygons and polyhedra. Euler's formula. Volume versus surface area. Spacial visualization; two dimensional representations of three dimensional figures. Prerequisites: Admission to the Mathematics Education Concentrators Program or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Geometry with Applications for Middle Grade Teachers
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 470 — Teaching Mathematics with Science: An Activity Approach I Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to basic variables (length, area, volume, mass, time) and the Scientific Method (picture, table, graph, questions). Extensive use of TIMS project curriculum. Prerequisites: Admission to the M.S. in the Teaching of Mathematics program (Option for Elementary School Teachers) or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. For elementary school teachers.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Mathematics with Science: An Activity Approach I
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 490 — Topics in Teaching Secondary Mathematics Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 1-5 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Prerequisites may vary according to topic. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MTHT 491 — Topics in Teaching Elementary/Junior High School Mathematics Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 1-5 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Prerequisites: Prerequisites may vary according to topic. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Teaching Elementary/Junior High School Mathematics
metadata.subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT)

text: Course: MTHT 496 — Independent Study Subject: Mathematics Teaching (MTHT) Credits: 1-4 Description: Reading course supervised by a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the instructor and the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: MUS 100 — Introduction to Music I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Listening, understanding, and enjoying music. Course Information: May not be taken for credit by music majors or minors. Creative Arts course.

Course: MUS 101 — Music Theory I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Notation of rhythm and pitch; scales, intervals, triads, and seventh chords; principles of voice leading and harmonic progression. Course Information: Must enroll concurrently in MUS 103 and MUS 170.

Course: MUS 102 — Music Theory II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Non-chord tones; cadences, phrases, and periods; introduction to Schenkerian analysis; inversions of triads and seventh chords. Prerequisites: MUS 101. Must enroll concurrently in MUS 104 and MUS 171.

Course: MUS 103 — Ear Training I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: The development of aural perception and sight-singing ability; material is correlated with MUS 101. Course Information: Must enroll concurrently in MUS 101 , and MUS 170.

Course: MUS 104 — Ear Training II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: The development of aural perception and sight-singing ability; material is correlated with MUS 102. Prerequisites: MUS 103 or the equivalent; and concurrent registration in MUS 102 and MUS 171.

Course: MUS 107 — Fundamentals of Music Theory Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Notation, metrical organization and rhythmic structure, scales and key signatures, intervals, triads, ear training, and sight singing. Course Information: For the general student. May not be taken for credit by music majors or minors. Creative Arts course. Creative Arts course.

Course: MUS 108 — Jazz Fundamentals I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: The study and execution of fundamental jazz terminology, skills, and applications of major-scale melody and harmony. Corequisites: MUS 101. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion.

Course: MUS 109 — Jazz Fundamentals II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: The study and execution of jazz fundamental terminology, skills, and applications of minor-scale melody and harmony. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 108. Corequisites: MUS 102. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: MUS 110 — Convocation/Recital Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 0 Description: A weekly convocation presenting concerts by faculty, visiting artists, or students. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: MUS 111 — Master Class in Performance Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 0 Description: Three to six master classes are offered per semester. Students must attend at least half of those offered; students must perform in one class each year. Prerequisites: Enrollment in the Music Performance option. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Recommended Background: Three years of private lessons.

Course: MUS 113 — Art Song Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the core art song repertoire of German Romantic song and the French, Russian and American art song repertoires of the 19th and 20th centuries. Creative Arts course.

Course: MUS 114 — Jazz History Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: A nontechnical survey of the history and development of jazz from its West African roots to contemporary styles. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: MUS 115 — Opera Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Representative operas from Mozart through the early 20th century from the point of view of how music contributes to drama in opera. Creative Arts course.

Course: MUS 116 — The Science and History of Sound in the Arts Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Investigates physical properties of sound and their application in the arts. Students will explore sound through math, physics, and acoustics fundamental principles. Principles of sound will be tested/evaluated through research/applied projects. Course Information: Same as ART 116. Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Natural World - No Lab course.

metadata.class_name: The Science and History of Sound in the Arts
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 117 — Music for Symphony Orchestra Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines representative works for symphony orchestra from Haydn through the 20th century focusing on the most important genres; symphony, overture and tone poem. Creative Arts course.

Course: MUS 118 — American Popular Music since 1850 Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: History of American popular music from 1850 to the twenty-first century. Analysis of musical characteristics, survey of traditions, and examination of social/cultural contexts of popular music developments. Creative Arts course, and Past course.
Course: MUS 119 — Music for the Piano Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of piano music from the Classical period through the 20th century. Creative Arts course.

Course: MUS 120 — Jazz Improvisation I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: A study of the techniques and methods of jazz improvisation. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 101 and grade of C or better in MUS 102. Corequisites: Concurrent registration in MUS 150 , MUS 159 or MUS 160. Course Information: Non-music majors must pass theory / ear-training pre-test. Recommended Background: Previous performance in jazz big band or jazz combo.

Course: MUS 127 — Latin American Music Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey class that introduces students to the rich repertoire of music in Latin America. It explores the history of genres, their development, instruments and representative artists in their geographical, social and cultural contexts. Course Information: Same as LALS 127. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: MUS 150 — Vocal Jazz Ensemble Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Study/performance of jazz ensemble techniques and the performance of standard vocal jazz repertoire. Prerequisites: Basic music reading skills and an audition required. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Recommended Background: Previous choir experience.

Course: MUS 151 — Concert Band Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to varied symphonic band and wind ensemble literature. Regular performances during the school year; occasional field trips. Prerequisites: Audition and/or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Occasional field trips.

Course: MUS 152 — Instrumental Ensembles Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Performance of chamber ensemble literature of varied types. Prerequisites: Audition and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Occasional concerts on and off campus.

Course: MUS 153 — University Choir Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Student performance of choral literature of all musical periods. Prerequisites: Audition required. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Occasional concerts off-campus.

Course: MUS 154 — Chamber Choir Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Study/performance of choral literature for 16 to 24 voices. Prerequisites: Audition required. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Occasional concerts off-campus.

Course: MUS 155 — Treble Choir Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Study/performance of choral literature of all musical periods. Prerequisites: Basic music-reading skills and an audition required. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Occasional concerts off-campus.

Course: MUS 156 — Pep Band Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Performs at home basketball games. Prerequisites: Consent of instructor. Must enroll concurrently in MUS 151. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Practice.

Course: MUS 157 — University Orchestras Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Designed for the study and performance of traditional and contemporary literature for symphony orchestra. Prerequisites: Audition and/or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Participation in rehearsals and field trip performances required. Due to the nature of music ensembles, required performances will occur at times other than class times, and additional required rehearsals may be announced. Recommended Background: Three years of private lessons and/or high school orchestra experience.

Course: MUS 159 — Jazz Ensemble Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Practical experience in the preparation and public performance of big band and small ensemble jazz. Prerequisites: Audition or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Field trips may be required.

Course: MUS 160 — Small Jazz Ensemble Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Various instrumental ensembles focusing on performance techniques within the historical development of the American jazz ensemble. Performances at various events across the UIC campus and the greater Chicago community. Prerequisites: Audition or consent of the instructor. Recommended backgroud: Minimum three years private instruction on student's preferred instrument. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

Course: MUS 161 — Teaching and Learning Brass Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Instructs students in the effective teaching and learning of brass instruments in K-12 school settings. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 162 — Teaching and Learning Jazz Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Prepares students to teach techniques and styles of jazz from early blues and dixieland through current trends of jazz within K-12 classrooms. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 163 — Teaching and Learning Percussion Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Provides music education majors with fundamental information regarding performance techniques and teaching methods for musical instruments in the percussion family. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 164 — Teaching Popular Music Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Prepares students to teach popular music techniques and styles in K-12 classrooms. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 165 — Teaching and Learning Strings Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Provides music education majors with fundamental information regarding performance techniques and teaching methods for bowed string instruments. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 166 — Teaching and Learning Voice Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Prepares students to teach vocal techniques and styles in various K-12 classrooms. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 167 — Teaching and Learning Woodwinds Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to woodwind pedagogy, performance practice, and techniques. Coverage of instrumental methods for flute, oboe, clarinet, saxophone, and bassoon. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 168 — Banda, Mariachi, & Salsa Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Prepares students to establish banda, salsa, and mariachi ensembles in K-12 schools and teach their instrumental techniques and stylistic parameters in K-12 classroom settings. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 170 — Keyboard Skills I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Development of basic keyboard skills including sight reading, transposition, improvisation, and ensemble playing. Prerequisites: Concurrent registration in MUS 101 and 103, or approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Laboratory.
Course: MUS 171 — Keyboard Skills II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Continues MUS 170. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 170 ; Concurrent registration in MUS 102 and MUS 104.

Course: MUS 180 — Private Instrumental Lessons Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Applied music instruction in strings, woodwinds, brass, percussion, piano, guitar or organ. Prerequisites: Audition prior to initial registration and approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice.

Course: MUS 181 — Private Instrumental Lessons-30 Minutes Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Applied music instruction on musical instruments. Lessons last 30 minutes.
