Prerequisites: Approval of the Department and admission to the music major and successful completion of an audition. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Practice and Conference. Recommended Background: Previous music and instrumental study.

Course: MUS 182 — Private Voice Lessons Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Applied music instruction in voice. Prerequisites: Approval of the department and admission to the music major and successful completion of an audition. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Recommended Background: Previous music and vocal study.

Course: MUS 183 — Private Vocal Lessons-30 Minutes Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Applied music instruction in voice. Lessons last 30 minutes. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department and admission to the music major and successful completion of an audition. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Practice and Conference. Recommended Background: Previous music and voice study.

Course: MUS 190 — Class Voice Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Group instruction in singing. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and concurrent registration in MUS 153 or MUS 155. May not be taken concurrently with MUS 180. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: MUS 191 — Commercial and Legal Foundations of the Music Industry Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Historical survey of the music industry since 1900. Examination of business sectors associated with music products and services. Survey of intellectual property law and contractual agreements associated with arts organization. Course Information: No graduation credit. Previously listed as MUS 290.

metadata.class_name: Commercial and Legal Foundations of the Music Industry
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 201 — Theory of Music III Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Continues MUS 102. Chromatic harmony of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Study of two- and three-part forms. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 102 and grade of C or better in MUS 104 or the equivalents.

Course: MUS 202 — Theory of Music IV Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Continues MUS 201. Harmony in the late nineteenth century; introduction to twentieth-century practices. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 201 and Grade of C or better in MUS 203 , or the equivalents.

Course: MUS 203 — Ear Training III Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Aural perception and sight singing. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 104 or the equivalent; and concurrent registration in MUS 201.

Course: MUS 204 — Ear Training IV Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Advanced aural perception and sight singing. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 203. Must enroll concurrently in MUS 202.

Course: MUS 220 — Jazz Aesthetics Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: A technical survey of the factors and topics that permeate and surround the development and production of jazz. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and MUS 114 ; and grade of C or better in MUS 102 and grade of C or better in MUS 104. Corequisites: MUS 150 , or MUS 159 or MUS 160. Recommended Background: Jazz ensemble performance.

Course: MUS 221 — Jazz Improvisation II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Continues the study of the technique and methods of jazz improvisation. Prerequisites: Grade of C of better in MUS 102 and grade of C or better in MUS 104 and grade of C or better in MUS 120 and grade of C or better in MUS 171 ; and sophomore standing or above; or approval of the department.

Course: MUS 223 — Music Technology Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the techniques and applications of music technologies. Students trained in music software, applications to education, composition, and performance. MIDI, analog and digital audio, acoustics, notation, multimedia, and sequencing. Prerequisites: MUS 107 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test; or consent of the instructor. Due to number of workstations, enrollment will be capped at 14. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: MUS 227 — Music Cultures of the World Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of music throughout the world from an ethnomusicological perspective. Emphasis on classical, tribal, and folk musics; music as a cultural phenomenon. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: MUS 230 — History of Western Music I: Music of the Middle Ages and Renaissance Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Principal styles and composers from the Middle Ages through the Renaissance. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 102 and Grade of C or better in MUS 104 or the equivalents. Music Majors may have only one Grade of D among MUS 230 , MUS 231 , and MUS 232.

metadata.class_name: History of Western Music I: Music of the Middle Ages and Renaissance
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 231 — History of Western Music II: Music of the Baroque and Classical Periods Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Principal styles and composers from the baroque period through the classical period. Prerequisites: MUS 230 ; and a Grade of C or better in MUS 202 and MUS 204 , or the equivalents. Music Majors may have only one Grade of D among MUS 230 , MUS 231 , and MUS 232.

metadata.class_name: History of Western Music II: Music of the Baroque and Classical Periods
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 232 — History of Western Music III: Music from Romanticism through the Present Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Principal styles and composers from the nineteenth through the twenty-first centuries. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 202 and grade of C or better in MUS 204 ; and MUS 231. Music Majors may have only one Grade of D among MUS 230 , MUS 231 , and MUS 232.

metadata.class_name: History of Western Music III: Music from Romanticism through the Present
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 240 — Music, Gender and Culture Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the intersection of music, gender and sexuality in different historical periods and cultures. Study of music's role in the formation and expression of gender identity in classical and popular music. Course Information: Same as GWS 240. Creative Arts course, and Individual and Society course.

Course: MUS 270 — Keyboard Skills III Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Continues MUS 171. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 171 and concurrent registration in MUS 201 and MUS 203 or approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Laboratory.

Course: MUS 271 — Keyboard Skills IV Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Advanced keyboard skills, including keyboard harmony, improvisation, accompanying, and score reading. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 270 and concurrent registration in MUS 202 and MUS 204 or approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Laboratory.

Course: MUS 280 — Advanced Private Instrumental Lessons Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Private instruction at an advanced level in strings, woodwinds, brass, percussion, or piano, culminating in a jury exam. Prerequisites: Four semesters of MUS 180 and approval of the department. Students must receive a grade of B or better in order to repeat this course. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice.

Course: MUS 282 — Advanced Private Voice Lessons Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced applied music instruction in voice. Prerequisites: Approval of the department and admission to the music major and successful completion of four terms of MUS 182. Students must receive a grade of B or better in order to repeat this course. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Recommended Background: Performance experience beyond regular UIC studies.

Course: MUS 298 — Selected Topics in Music Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Study in specialized areas of music history, music theory, jazz, and ethnomusicology. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours.

Course: MUS 299 — Independent Study Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Projects and topics for individual investigation. Course number may be used for student-initiated courses. Prerequisites: MUS 202 and MUS 204 and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: MUS 300 — Counterpoint Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Written exercises and study of contrapuntal techniques in a variety of styles. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 202 and grade of C or better MUS 204 ; or approval of the department. Music major may have only one grade of D in 300-level coursework.

Course: MUS 301 — Analytic Techniques Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of representative works in a variety of genres from the seventeenth through the twentieth centuries. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 202. Music majors may have only one grade of D in 300-level coursework.

Course: MUS 302 — Composing for Small Ensembles Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Class and individual instruction in the basic techniques composition. Practice in the use of twentieth-century and twenty-first century musical materials. Focus is on strategies for composing for small ensembles. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 202 and grade of C or better in MUS 204 or approval of the department. Music majors may have only one grade of D in 300-level coursework.

Course: MUS 303 — Composing for Large Ensembles Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Class and individual instruction in the basic techniques composition. Practice in the use of twentieth-century and twenty-first century musical materials. Focus is on strategies for composing for large ensembles. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 302. Music majors may have only one grade of D in 300-level coursework. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: MUS 304 — Conducting Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Basic techniques; body position; beat patterns; use of baton; division of beats; starting and stopping; the left hand; dynamics; fermatas; ensemble application; score preparation; memorization. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 202 and Grade of C or better in MUS 204 ; and junior standing or above; or approval of the department. Majors may have only one D in 300-level courses.

Course: MUS 305 — Advanced Conducting Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Builds upon the basic techniques established in MUS 304 Conducting, including gestural skills, continued work on the analysis and interpretation of music, rehearsal techniques and the synthesis of those skills in real-world applications. Prerequisites: MUS 304 or approval of the instructor.

Course: MUS 306 — Orchestration and Arranging I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: The acoustical properties, musical characteristics, and scoring problems of string, woodwind, and brass and percussion instruments. Scoring for string, woodwind, and brass ensembles. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better MUS 202 and grade of C or better in MUS 204 or approval of the department. Music majors may have only one grade of D in 300-level coursework.

Course: MUS 307 — Orchestration and Arranging II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: The acoustical properties, musical characteristics, and scoring problems of percussion, keyboard, and electronic instruments. Scoring for mixed ensembles, band, orchestra. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 306. Music majors may have only one grade of D in 300-level coursework.

Course: MUS 310 — Jazz Theory and Keyboard I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory course designed to acquaint students with rhythmic, melodic, harmonic, and structural aspects of jazz. Prerequisites: Grade of C of better in MUS 202 , and Grade of C or better in MUS 204 , and Grade of B or better in MUS 271 ; and junior standing or above; or approval of the department. Majors may have only one D in 300-level courses.

Course: MUS 311 — Jazz Theory and Keyboard II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced course to continue exploration of rhythmic, melodic, harmonic, and structural aspects of jazz. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 310. Majors may have only one D in 300-level courses.

Course: MUS 312 — Jazz Arranging I Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Concentration on developing compositional and orchestration/arranging skills in various jazz and commercial styles. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 120 and Grade of C or better in MUS 221 ; and junior standing or above; or approval of the department. Majors may have only one D in 300-level courses.

Course: MUS 313 — Jazz Arranging II Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced course for developing compositional and orchestration/arranging skills in various jazz and commercial styles. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 312 ; or approval of the department. Majors may have only one D in 300-level courses.

Course: MUS 314 — Advanced Topics in Jazz History and Analysis Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Transcription/analysis is widely acknowledged to be an essential study to develop a jazz student’s expressive voice. Students study great jazz recordings in historical context. Compositions/improvised solos are transcribed, analyzed, and performed. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 221.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Jazz History and Analysis
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 320 — Music Proseminar Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Selected topics for intensive study in specialized areas of music history or music theory. Prerequisites: Senior standing with major in music and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: MUS 323 — Digital Music Engraving Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: A hands-on music notation and engraving course designed to give the student professional-level fluency in music notation software. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion.

Course: MUS 324 — Music Teaching in Ensemble Settings Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Study of philosophies and approaches of teaching and conducting music in ensemble settings. Prerequisites: MUS 101 and MUS 102 and MUS 103 and MUS 104 and MUS 170 and MUS 304. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: MUS 325 — Participatory and Digital Music Practices Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction and application of digital and participatory music practices. Topics center around diversity, creativity, identity formation, and the use of popular, culturally responsive, and critical pedagogies in music. Prerequisites: MUS 101 and MUS 102 and MUS 103 and MUS 104. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 326 — Teaching Music to Children Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 4 Description: Study and evaluation of philosophies, approaches, and materials of teaching and learning music with children from birth to adolescence. Prerequisites: MUS 101 and MUS 102 and MUS 103 and MUS 104 and MUS 170. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: MUS 330 — Advanced Topics in Music History and Ethnomusicology Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced study of topics relating to music history, music literature, and music theory and ethnomusicology. Subject chosen by instructor. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 230 and Grade of C or better in MUS 101 and Grade of C or better in MUS 102 ; and consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in MUS 230 or Grade of C or better in MUS 231 or Grade of C or better in MUS 232 ; and Grade of C or better in MUS 113 or Grade of C or better in MUS 114 or Grade of C or better in MUS 115 or Grade of C or better in MUS 116 or Grade of C or better in MUS 117 or Grade of C or better in MUS 118 A grade of C or above in any Music Literature course ( MUS 113 , 114 , 115 , 117 , 118 , 127 , 119 , 240.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Topics in Music History and Ethnomusicology
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 340 — Choral Music Methods and Materials Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Covers the organization of choral music programs; the methods, materials, and technology used; as well as a survey of music literature appropriate for choral ensembles of various ages and contexts. Course Information: Field work required. MUS 101 and MUS 102 and MUS 103 and MUS 104 and MUS 170.

Course: MUS 341 — Instrumental Music Methods and Materials Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 2 Description: Covers the organization of instrumental music programs; the methods, materials, and technology used; as well as a survey of music literature appropriate for instrumental ensembles of various ages and contexts. Prerequisites: MUS 101 and MUS 102 and MUS 103 and MUS 104. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: MUS 350 — Music Classrooms for All Learners Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Enables the prospective music teacher to learn how to coordinate the classroom learning environment to effectively address the diverse needs of students in music classrooms. Prerequisites: ED 100 and EPSY 255.

Course: MUS 351 — Assessment in Music Classrooms Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides future music teachers an introduction to the methods, assumptions, and practical applications of measurement, evaluation, and assessment in classroom settings.

Course: MUS 390 — Record Company Marketing and Operations Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Study of marketing and operations practices employed by record companies. Understanding of analytic techniques used to inform marketing decisions. Analysis of music industry marketing research methodology. Survey of promotion practices. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 290 and Grade of C or better in MUS 202 and Grade of C or better in MUS 201 and Grade of C or better in MKTG 360 and Grade of C or better in ACTG 210. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Recommended Background: Fluency in reading and performing music.

Course: MUS 391 — Study Abroad in Music Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 0-16 Description: Study abroad within an approved foreign exchange program or department-sponsored program. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: MUS 395 — Internship in Music Business Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Cooperative education that provides students with opportunities, mentors and practical work experience in music businesses. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MUS 390 and consent of the program coordinator. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours of credit. Students may register for more than one section per term. Field work required.

Course: MUS 396 — Music Publishing Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the music publishing industry. Issues of rights and ownership in music, songwriting collaboration agreements and music licensing are analyzed. The role of the Music Supervisor is discussed. Issues of negotiation and compliance are covered. Prerequisites: ACTG 210 and MKTG 360 and MUS 201 and MUS 202 and MUS 290. Course Information: Field work required. Recommended Background: Fluency in reading and performing music.

Course: MUS 397 — Concert Promotion and Venue Management Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the concert and event promotion industry. Analysis of legal aspects of concert promotion. Survey of the process of selling and staging musical performances. Survey of practices and procedures of public assembly and venue management. Prerequisites: ACTG 210 and MKTG 360 and MUS 201 and MUS 202 and MUS 290 and MUS 390. Course Information: Field work required. Recommended Background: Fluency in reading and performing music.

Course: MUS 465 — Teaching Music to Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Students Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 4 Description: Provides principles of second language learning and teaching in music classrooms. Students develop understandings of the impact of cultural diversity, immigration, and legacies of colonialism on policy, schools, and learning. Prerequisites: ED 100 and EPSY 255.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Music to Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Students
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 466 — Music Student Teaching in Grades PreK-8 with Seminar Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 4 Description: Students will practice teaching music in schools to students in grades PreK-8 under the guidance of a certified music teacher and university supervisor. Course includes an accompanying weekly seminar. Prerequisites: MUS 350 and MUS 351 and MUS 465. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Practice and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Music Student Teaching in Grades PreK-8 with Seminar
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 467 — Music Student Teaching in Grades 9-12 with Seminar Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 4 Description: Students will practice teaching music in schools to students in grades 9-12 under the guidance of a certified music teacher and university supervisor. Course includes an accompanying weekly seminar. Prerequisites: MUS 350 and MUS 351 and MUS 465. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Practice and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Music Student Teaching in Grades 9-12 with Seminar
metadata.subject: Music (MUS)

text: Course: MUS 490 — Music Education: Special Topics Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1-4 Description: An investigation of various topics in music education pertinent to practicing music teachers. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: MUS 498 — Advanced Music Ensembles Subject: Music (MUS) Credits: 1 Description: Participation in a UIC music ensemble. Performance of music literature of varied types, corresponding to the ensemble: band, choir, chamber music, jazz bands, mariachi, and orchestra. Occasional concerts on and off campus. Course Information: May be repeated for credit. Students may register for more than one section per term. Due to the nature of music ensembles, required performances will occur at times other than class times, and additional required rehearsals may be announced. Open to all students who have been accepted by audition, with assignments made according to proficiency and instrumentation. Placement auditions are required for all students and held at the beginning of each semester.

Course: MUSE 400 — Topics in Museum and Exhibition Studies Subject: Museum and Exhibition Studies (MUSE) Credits: 3-5 Description: Investigation of a problem, topic or issue relevant to the interdisciplinary field of Museum and Exhibition Studies. Content varies. Course Information: 3 to 4 undergraduate hours. 4 to 5 graduate hours. May be repeated for credit. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Museum and Exhibition Studies
metadata.subject: Museum and Exhibition Studies (MUSE)

text: Course: NAST 113 — Native American Studies: Sovereignty Subject: Native American Studies (NAST) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of Native and non-Native perspectives of American Indian sovereignty in historical context. Primary focus on spiritual, political, ethnic, and legislative aspects of sovereignty. Past course, and US Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: NAST 244 — Native American History Subject: Native American Studies (NAST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the history of Native North Americans from ancient to recent times, emphasizing peoples and events in what became the United States. Topics include politics, economics, diplomacy, religion, gender, race, and agency. Course Information: Same as HIST 244. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course.

Course: NAST 264 — Introduction to Native American Literatures Subject: Native American Studies (NAST) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the oral and written literatures of indigenous peoples of North America. Course Information: Same as ENGL 264. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: NAST 271 — Native American Art Subject: Native American Studies (NAST) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the arts of the indigenous peoples of the United States and Canada. Prerequisites: 3 hours of art history at the 100 level or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as AH 271.

Course: NAST 415 — American Indian Ethnohistory Subject: Native American Studies (NAST) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to ethnohistory, an interdisciplinary approach to researching, conceptualizing, and writing American Indian history. The course is organized topically and centers on classic and current monographs and articles. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 415. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Courses in Cultural Anthropology, American Indian Anthropology, American Indian Literature.

Course: NATS 105 — Physical Systems in Earth and Space Science Subject: Natural Sciences (NATS) Credits: 4 Description: A multidisciplinary course that uses physics to understand earth, space, and environmental science phenomena and ideas related to sensing the universe, movements on the earth and in the solar system, and past and future of the earth and universe. Course Information: 4 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture -Discussion and one Laboratory and one Laboratory-Discussion. Natural World - With Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Physical Systems in Earth and Space Science
metadata.subject: Natural Sciences (NATS)

text: Course: NATS 106 — Chemical and Biological Systems Subject: Natural Sciences (NATS) Credits: 4 Description: A multidisciplinary course that uses biological and chemical concepts to understand the organization of the physical world, processes and energy exchanges at the atomic and molecular levels, and interactions of organisms and the environment. Course Information: 4 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: NATS 200 — Tutoring in the Science Learning Center Subject: Natural Sciences (NATS) Credits: 1 Description: Study, analysis, and implementation of best practices in tutoring and peer-leadership. Effective facilitation of student group discussions and communication in STEM disciplines. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students meet once per week. Volunteers schedule 2-3 hours per week to tutor; peer-leaders schedule 4-6 hours per week to tutor.

metadata.class_name: Tutoring in the Science Learning Center
metadata.subject: Natural Sciences (NATS)

text: Course: NEUS 403 — Human Neuroanatomy Subject: Neuroscience (NEUS) Credits: 3 Description: Morphological organization of the nervous system. Functional correlations of neural structures. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the instructor. Must be in a degree program. Course Information: Same as ANAT 403. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: NEUS 444 — Data Literacy in Neuroscience Subject: Neuroscience (NEUS) Credits: 3 Description: This course provides an overview of experimental design, statistics, data mining, modeling and informatics with an emphasis on the types of experiments pursued in neuroscience.

Course: NEUS 483 — Neuroanatomy Subject: Neuroscience (NEUS) Credits: 4 Description: Organization of the nervous system, with an emphasis on mammals. Prerequisites: BIOS 272 or BIOS 286 or BIOS 325 or PSCH 262 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BIOS 483 and PSCH 483. Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: NS 101 — Introduction to Naval Science Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 2 Description: Introduction to sea-power and the naval service. Includes an overview of officer and enlisted rank and rating structures, training, promotion and military courtesy. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 200 — Naval Ships Systems Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: The types, structure and purpose of naval ships. Includes nuclear, gas turbine, and steam propulsion systems, auxiliary systems, interior communications and damage control. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 201 — Naval Weapons Systems Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the theory and principles of naval weapons systems. Covers type of weapons, capabilities and limitations and theory of operation. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 202 — Sea Power and Maritime Affairs Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: Concept of seapower and its effect on history, naval strategies of past and present, the role of U.S. seapower from the Revolutionary War to the present. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 294 — Topics in Naval Science Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Study of topics in naval science. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: NS 301 — Navigation Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: Ship navigation. Covers areas of piloting, celestial and electronic means of shipboard navigation. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 302 — Naval Operations Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: Ship operations and movement. Covers maneuvering, seamanship, communications, and command and control. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 310 — Evolution of Warfare Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of all military history thereby providing a very basic understanding of the art and concepts of warfare from the beginning of recorded time to the present. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 320 — Amphibious Warfare Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: Historical survey of the evolution of amphibious warfare in the twentieth century. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 350 — Naval Leadership and Management Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: A comprehensive, advanced-level study of organizational behavior and management. Topics include a survey of principle management functions. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: NS 351 — Naval Leadership and Ethics Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 3 Description: Responsibilities of the junior Naval Officer and Division Officer. Professional responsibilities that the junior officer will have after commissioning will be covered. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 360 — Leadership Seminar Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 0 Description: Application of the study of organizational behavior and management to naval science. Case studies. Prerequisites: Concurrent registration in MGMT 340 and approval of the department. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: NS 394 — Advanced Topics in Naval Science Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Study of advanced topics in naval science. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: NS 399 — Independent Study in Naval Science Subject: Naval Science (NS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent study of an area within naval science under the direction of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: NUEL 244 — History of Professional Nursing in the U.S Subject: Nursing Elective (NUEL) Credits: 3 Description: Presents 400-year history of nursing in the U.S. through a social history framework. Traces nurses’ work in health promotion/disease prevention/direct patient care recognizing the contribution of people of varying races, social classes, and genders. Past course.

metadata.class_name: History of Professional Nursing in the U.S
metadata.subject: Nursing Elective (NUEL)

text: Course: NUEL 250 — Human Development Across the Life Span Subject: Nursing Elective (NUEL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of biological, psychological and social influences on human development from conception to death. Emphasis is on current research and its application to societal issues. Course Information: Designed for Prenursing students.

metadata.class_name: Human Development Across the Life Span
metadata.subject: Nursing Elective (NUEL)

text: Course: NUEL 394 — Special Topics: Undergraduate Subject: Nursing Elective (NUEL) Credits: 1-6 Description: Discusses selected topics of current interest. Offered according to sufficient student demand and instructor availability. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: NUEL 399 — Independent Study: Undergraduate Subject: Nursing Elective (NUEL) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individually arranged study of a topic selected by the student under the guidance of an individual instructor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: NURS 204 — Professional Nursing 1 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Examination of core concepts in professional nursing which define the role of the nurse. Utilizing principles of evidence-based practice, special emphasis will be placed on ethical, legal, and cultural considerations that impact nursing practice. Prerequisites: Preadmission required courses. Corequisites: NURS 212 and NURS 221.

Course: NURS 212 — Health Assessment and Communication Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces physical assessment and interview skills to assess health status of clients across the lifespan. Concepts of communication, health literacy, patient centeredness and interprofessionalism are investigated as they impact health and risk assessment Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: NURS 221 — Foundations of Nursing Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 6 Description: Introduction to professional nursing emphasizing clinical and scientific concepts; nursing process; patient safety; communication and teaching/learning; and technology in the care of patients and their families. Prerequisites: Preadmission required courses. Corequisites: NURS 204 and NURS 212 and NURS 223. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory and one Clinical Practice.

Course: NURS 223 — Concepts in Pathophysiology and Pharmacology 1 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Provides pathophysiologic and pharmacologic concepts critical to clinical decision making focusing on common disease processes across the lifespan, and on therapeutic and toxic effects of associated major drug classes. Prerequisites: Preadmission prerequisites required.

Course: NURS 228 — Readiness for Professional Nursing Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 2 Description: Prepare students for success in the nursing program. Course Information: Previously listed as NURS 428.

Course: NURS 232 — Concepts in Professional Nursing Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces contemporary concepts for professional nursing practice including the definition of nursing, nursing paradigm, values, ethics, health, and continuity of care in restorative and chronic conditions. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: NURS 233 — Concepts in Pathophysiology and Pharmacology 2 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides pathophysiologic and pharmacological concepts critical to clinical decision making focusing on common disease processes across the lifespan, and on therapeutic and toxic effects of associated major drug classes. Course Information: Grade of C or better in NURS 223.

Course: NURS 242 — Concepts and Processes in Contemporary Nursing Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduces RN/BSN students to contemporary concepts for professional nursing practice in health care systems with emphasis on the definition of nursing; nursing paradigm; health promotion; continuity of care. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in NURS 210; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in NURS 210 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in NURS 210 Prereq Codes (parsed): NURS 210 Coreq Codes (parsed): NURS 210

metadata.class_name: Concepts and Processes in Contemporary Nursing
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 254 — Professional Nursing 2 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of social and ethical issues in nursing with specific emphasis on social determinants of health, health disparities, social justice, utilizing evidence-based practice principles and critique of nursing research. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 204 and Grade of C or better in NURS 212 and Grade of C or better in NURS 221. Corequisites: NURS 321and NURS 351.

Course: NURS 304 — Professional Nursing 3 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Utilize nursing research to investigate concepts of patient safety, quality improvement, and risk management, including ethical and legal consideration. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 221 and Grade of C or better in NURS 254 and Grade of C or better in NURS 321 and Grade of C or better in NURS 351. Corequisites: Concurrent registration in NURS 331 or NURS 341 ; and concurrent registration in NURS 361 or NURS 371.

Course: NURS 312 — Nursing Research and Statistics Methods for EBP Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Basic concepts of research utilization and critique emphasizing relationship between research, scholarship, and evidence based nursing practice. Includes study of basic statistical measures, vocabulary, data analysis, and hypothesis testing. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester. Recommended Background: Successful completion of preadmission required courses.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Research and Statistics Methods for EBP
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 316 — Nursing Informatics Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the concepts of data, information, knowledge, and wisdom as they derive from patient care technology, communication methods, interprofessionalism and computer applications. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Previously listed as NUEL 316. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: NURS 321 — Nursing Care of Adults Across the Life Span Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 7 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in care of adults across the life span. Unique health care needs of older adults will be addressed. Prerequisites: NURS 204 and NURS 212 and NURS 221 and NURS 223. Corequisites: NURS 233 and NURS 254 and NURS 351.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Care of Adults Across the Life Span
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 322 — Introduction to Nursing Research and Statistics for Evidence-Based Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Basic concepts of research utilization and critique emphasizing relationship between research and evidence-based nursing practice. Includes study of basic statistical measures, vocabulary, data analysis, and hypothesis testing. Prerequisites: NURS 210 and NURS 242 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Nursing Research and Statistics for Evidence-Based Practice
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 331 — Nursing Care of Childbearing Women and Families Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in the care of childbearing women and their familes. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 212 and Grade of C or better in NURS 233 and Grade of C or better in NURS 254. Corequisites: NURS 304 and NURS 361 or NURS 371.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Care of Childbearing Women and Families
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 332 — Caring Theory in Professional Nursing Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the complex nature of caring, its critical role in nursing, and its application to acute, chronic, and palliative patient needs, and individual's self-care and wellness. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

metadata.class_name: Caring Theory in Professional Nursing Practice
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 341 — Nursing Care of Children and Families Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in the care of infants, children, and adolescents and their families. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 212 and Grade of C or better in NURS 221 and Grade of C or better in NURS 233 and Grade of C or better in NURS 254. Corequisites: NURS 304 and NURS 361 or NURS 371.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Care of Children and Families
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 342 — Caring in Professional Nursing Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 2 Description: Exploration of the complex nature of caring and its critical role in nursing. Special emphasis is placed on defining caring, describing nurse caring, and investigating caring through application, discussion, research, and teaching. Prerequisites: NURS 210 and NURS 242.

Course: NURS 351 — Nursing Care in Mental and Behavioral Health Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in the integration of biopsychosocial concepts and principles into care of individuals and groups. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 223 and Grade of C or better in NURS 212 and Grade of C or better in NURS 221 and Grade of C or better in NURS 204. Corequisites: NURS 233 and NURS 321 and NURS 254.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Care in Mental and Behavioral Health
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 352 — Population Focused Nursing Care Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores concepts of population focused nursing, public health, community health nursing, social and cultural determinants of health, health disparities, wellness, ethics, leadership, and interprofessionalism. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: NURS 354 — Professional Nursing 4 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Concepts of leadership, management, organizations/systems theory, healthcare finance and policy, and their impact on the role of the nurse are investigated. Intra and interprofessional collaboration and nursing informatics will be examined. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 221 and Grade of C or better in NURS 304 and Grade of C or better in NURS 321 and Grade of C or better in NURS 351. Corequisites: Concurrent registration in NURS 331 or NURS 341 ; and concurrent registration in NURS 361 or NURS 371.

Course: NURS 361 — Nursing Care of Populations Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in the care of populations. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 212 and Grade of C or better in NURS 221 and Grade of C or better in NURS 254 and Grade of C or better in NURS 321 and Grade of C or better in NURS 351. Corequisites: Concurrent registration in NURS 331 or NURS 341.

Course: NURS 362 — Nursing Health Promotion Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces concepts of health promotion and disease prevention for individuals, families, groups, and populations through evidence-based research and interaction with clients and stakeholders. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: NURS 371 — Acute Care Nursing & Care Mgmt Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Integration of nursing knowledge and coordination of clinical skills when caring for multiple patients in acute care settings, with emphasis on care management and care transitions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 233 and Grade of C or better in NURS 254 and Grade of C or better in NURS 321 and Grade of C or better in NURS 351. Corequisites: Concurrent registration in NURS 331 or NURS 341 ; and NURS 304.

Course: NURS 372 — Leadership and Management in Nursing Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration and application of principles of nursing professionalism, leadership, management functions, and the nursing process to the support of clients, groups, and systems. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: NURS 377 — Integrative Practice Experience Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 2 Description: Integration of theory and concepts into complex practice scenarios to develop knowledge and skills needed to provide safe and effective nursing care across diverse populations and settings. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 254 and Grade of C or better in NURS 321. Corequisites: NURS 304 and NURS 331 or NURS 341.

Course: NURS 382 — Nursing Role in Healthcare Quality and Safety Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of healthcare systems’ effectiveness and individual nursing performance as they impact outcomes of patient care and quality and safety within healthcare systems. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Role in Healthcare Quality and Safety
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 385 — Nursing Care of Populations (RN to BSN) Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 5 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in the health promotion of populations. Prerequisites: NURS 210 and NURS 242 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Clinical Practice and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Care of Populations (RN to BSN)
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 387 — Senior Seminar Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Explore transition to the professional role through discussion of career development strategies including NCLEX preparation, graduate education opportunities, professional engagement, and dedication lifelong learning. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in NURS 304 and Grade of C or better in NURS 321 and Grade of C or better in NURS 351. Corequisites: NURS 354 and NURS 331 and NURS 341 and NURS 361 and NURS 371.

Course: NURS 390 — Nursing Leadership and Management in Healthcare Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 6 Description: Exploration and application of principles of nursing leadership and management through an integrative practice experience applying the five functions of nurse managers to the management and support of clients, groups, and systems. Prerequisites: NURS 210 and NURS 242 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Clinical Practice and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Leadership and Management in Healthcare
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 397 — Issues in Nursing Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of social, economic, and policy issues affecting the practice of professional nursing with emphasis on strategies for advancing the profession and professionalism. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Course Information: Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: NURS 403 — Cultural Fluency, Communication, and Ethics Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a foundation of communication skills, teaching and learning theory, ethics, and cultural competence in providing nursing care.

Course: NURS 404 — Integrated Health Care: Concepts and Skills Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides the basis for understanding fundamental concepts to the practice of nursing across the life span. Theoretical concepts will be integrated with skills and clinical in Integrated Practicum I. Prerequisites: NURS 421. Must enroll concurrently in NURS 401.

metadata.class_name: Integrated Health Care: Concepts and Skills
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 406 — Integrated Health Care: Community Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 2 Description: Theories of community assessment, disease prevention, and health behavior are applied to promotion of health for communities and vulnerable populations. Understanding of systems and collaboration with the interprofessional team are emphasized. Prerequisites: NURS 408 and credit or concurrent registration in NURS 414. Credit or concurrent registration in NURS 414 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in NURS 414 Prereq Codes (parsed): NURS 414 Coreq Codes (parsed): NURS 414

Course: NURS 408 — Integrated Health Care: Adult/Older Adult Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Clinical evaluation/management of common/complex problems in adults and older adults, emphasizes pathophysiology and management strategies in context of culture and ethnicity. Prerequisites: NURS 421 and NURS 422 and NURS 404 and NUPR 405.

Course: NURS 409 — Health Assessment and Communications Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 5 Description: Introduction to physical assessment and interview skills necessary to assess health status of clients across the lifespan. Concepts of communication, health literacy, patient-centeredness are investigated as they impact health and risk assessment. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: NURS 411 — Foundations of Nursing Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 7 Description: Introduction to professional nursing emphasizing clinical and scientific concepts, nursing process, clinical judgement, patient safety, communication and teaching/learning, and technology in the care of patients and their care partners. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses. Corequisites: BSN: NURS 420. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice and one Laboratory.

Course: NURS 412 — Integrated Health Care: Women, Children and Family Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Care for women throughout the lifespan, including pregnancy, birth, the postpartum, and interconceptional periods and throughout the aging process. Prerequisites: NURS 408 and NURS 414.

metadata.class_name: Integrated Health Care: Women, Children and Family
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 414 — Integrated Health Care: Mental Health Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 2 Description: Application and integration of biopsychosocial concepts and principles to the mental health care of individuals and groups across the continuum of care, including health promotion and illness prevention, maintenance and rehabilitation. Prerequisites: NURS 401 and NURS 402 and NURS 404 and NUPR 405 ; and graduate standing.

Course: NURS 419 — Pathophysiology and Pharmacology 1 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Provides pathophysiologic and pharmacologic concepts critical to developing clinical judgement focusing on common disease processes across the lifespan, and on therapeutic and toxic effects of associated major drug classes. Prerequisites: Successful completion of preadmission required courses.

Course: NURS 420 — Patho-Pharm 2 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides pathophysiologic and pharmacologic concepts critical to developing clinical judgement focusing on common disease processes across the lifespan, and on therapeutic and toxic effects of associated major drug classes. Prerequisites: NURS 419.

Course: NURS 421 — Pathophysiology Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Pathophysiologic concepts critical to clinical decision making focusing on commonly occurring disease processes across the lifespan.

Course: NURS 422 — Pharmacology Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Pharmacological concepts critical to clinical decision making focusing on therapeutic and toxic effects of major drug classes. Prerequisites: NURS 421.

Course: NURS 423 — Adult Health Nursing 1 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 7 Description: Using clinical and simulation-based education modalities, students apply nursing theory and concepts to develop knowledge and skills needed for safe and effective nursing care across diverse adult and older adult patient populations and settings. Prerequisites: BSN: NURS 409 and NURS 411 and NURS 419 ; MSN-GE: NURS 409 and NURS 411 and NURS 420. Corequisites: BSN: NURS 420. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

Course: NURS 433 — Adult Health Nursing 2 Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 6 Description: Using clinical and simulation-based education modalities, students apply nursing theory and concepts to develop knowledge and skills needed for safe and effective nursing care across diverse adult and older adult patient populations and settings. Prerequisites: NURS 423. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

Course: NURS 438 — Introduction to Evidence-Based Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 3 Description: Builds a foundation of concepts, methodology, and research appraisal associated with evidence-based practice and quality indicators of nursing care. Concepts of patient care technology will be explored. Prerequisites: NURS 423.

Course: NURS 443 — Nursing Care of Women and Childbearing Families Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Applies nursing knowledge and skills in the care of women and childbearing families. Prerequisites: BSN students: NURS 420 and NURS 423. MSN-GE students: NURS 423. Corequisites: BSN students may either take NURS 420 and NURS 423 prior to enrolling in NURS 443 or enroll concurrently these courses. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

metadata.class_name: Nursing Care of Women and Childbearing Families
metadata.subject: Nursing Core (NURS)

text: Course: NURS 448 — Leadership in Professional Nursing Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 6 Description: Application of principles of nursing leadership, management, health policy, and systems thinking to management of diverse groups of clients and systems to promote equity and inclusive care competencies. Prerequisites: NURS 433 and NURS 438 and NURS 443 and NURS 463. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

Course: NURS 453 — Pediatric Health Nursing Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Equips students with the essential skills and knowledge to provide specialized nursing care for infants, children, adolescents, and families addressing developmental, medical, and psychosocial aspects of pediatric patients. Prerequisites: NURS 423. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

Course: NURS 458 — Transition to Professional Nursing Practice Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Prepares students for entry to professional nursing practice. Preparation for successful NCLEX-RN testing and job acquisition is included. Prerequisites: BSN: NURS 433 and NURS 438 and NURS 443 and NURS 463 ; MSN-GE: NURS 443 and NURS 453 and NURS 463 and NURS 473. Corequisites: BSN: NURS 448 and NURS 453 and NURS 473 can be taken either prior to enrolling in NURS 458 or concurrently with NURS 458.

Course: NURS 463 — Psychiatric-Mental Health Nursing Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 4 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in the integration of biopsychosocial concepts and principles into care of individuals and groups across the lifespan. Prerequisites: MSN-GE: NURS 409 and NURS 411 and NURS 420. Corequisites: MSN-GE: NURS 423 ; BSN: Both NURS 420 and NURS 423 can either be taken prior to taking NURS 463 or concurrently with NURS 463. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

Course: NURS 473 — Population Health Nursing Subject: Nursing Core (NURS) Credits: 0-5 Description: Application of nursing knowledge and skills in the care of populations in various community settings. Prerequisites: NURS 423. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Clinical Practice.

Course: OT 350 — Introduction to Occupational Therapy: Occupation and Participation across the Lifespan Subject: Occupational Therapy (OT) Credits: 3 Description: Designed to introduce students to the history, philosophy, and practice of occupational therapy and provide students with a foundational understanding of the role of occupational therapists across settings and populations. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Occupational Therapy: Occupation and Participation across the Lifespan
metadata.subject: Occupational Therapy (OT)

text: Course: OT 360 — Promoting Wellbeing Subject: Occupational Therapy (OT) Credits: 2 Description: Provides opportunities for students to gain knowledge and skills from an occupational therapy perspective to promote self-management and wellbeing for themselves and others, applying the concepts to academic, social, work and professional roles. Prerequisites: Undergraduate standing at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

Course: OT 494 — Special Topics in Occupational Therapy Subject: Occupational Therapy (OT) Credits: 1-4 Description: Selected occupational therapy-related seminar topics of interest or pilot version of new occupational therapy course. Designed for undergraduate and non-occupational therapy major graduate students. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above or graduate standing. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Recommended Background: Undergraduate students: Completion or concurrent registration in OT 350.

Course: OT 496 — Independent Study Subject: Occupational Therapy (OT) Credits: 1-4 Description: For undergraduate students who wish to pursue an independent study experience for credit. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for credit.

Course: PA 401 — Foundations of Public Service Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines political, legal, economic and social environment of public service, internal dynamics of public organizations, relationship between public organizations and external stakeholders, and ethical and moral challenges. Prerequisites: Master of Public Administration or Master of Public Policy or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 400.

Course: PA 402 — Introduction to Data Management and Analysis Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 0-4 Description: Topics and methods related to collecting and analyzing data by government and nonprofit organizations to make better decisions and improve operations. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above Admission to the MPA, MPP, or MSCA program; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 407.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Data Management and Analysis
metadata.subject: Public Administration (PA)

text: Course: PA 403 — Economics for Management and Policy Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Basic economic tools and methods relevant to public admin and current policy: opportunity cost, supply and demand, rational choice, production costs, competition vs monopoly, and economic efficiency versus equity, market failure, and public goods. Prerequisites: Master of Public Administration or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 410.

Course: PA 412 — Addressing Public Problems with Data Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intended to explore best practices for utilizing data and innovative approaches to application development while ensuring commitment to the public values of access, equity, and sustainability. Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Public Administration, Master of Public Policy, or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours.

Course: PA 421 — Public Management Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theories, concepts, and applications of management in public organizations. Topics include bureaucracy, public versus private organizations, leadership, motivation, and managing organization change, discretion, and networks. Prerequisites: Admission to the MPA program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 415. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: PA 422 — Project Management Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 4 Description: A comprehensive review of project management practices and techniques necessary to successfully manage projects in government and non-profit organizations which is rooted largely in Project Management Institute (PMI) standards and practices. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 462.

Course: PA 431 — Civic Technology Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Application of the Internet and related technologies for public management. Topics include, Web-based service delivery, online governance, the technological divide, the use of social media, and the changing role of public managers. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 463. Admission to the Master of Public Administration, Master of Public Policy, or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor.

Course: PA 432 — Management of Information Technology Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The management of technology in government and nonprofit organizations, including typical organizational models; technology roles, skills, and leadership; integration of technology with business operations; and common technology challenges. Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Public Administration, Master of Public Policy, or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 461.

Course: PA 433 — Data Management Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An overview of the use and leveraging of data in order to allow government and nonprofit organizations to make better decisions and improve operations. Topics to be covered will include the concepts of data management and governance. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing; or admission to the MPA program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 460.

Course: PA 434 — Intermediate Data Management and Analysis Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Latest practices for gaining better value from data, emphasizing hands-on use and application of data analytics for univariate and bivariate statistics and data visualization. Prerequisites: PA 402 and Admission to the Master of Public Administration, Master of Public Policy, or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: PA 435 — Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for Public Managers Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 4 Description: Fundamental GIS tools and applications as well as the challenges in implementing and sustaining a GIS function in the public setting. Prerequisites: Latest practices for gaining better value from data, emphasizing hands-on use and application of data analytics for univariate and bivariate statistics and data visualization.

metadata.class_name: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for Public Managers
metadata.subject: Public Administration (PA)

text: Course: PA 446 — Coding for Civic Data Applications Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced tech skills for coding, transforming, and visualizing data using existing platforms, with an emphasis on R. Topics include functional programming, GitHub and webpage creation, web scraping, Shiny applications, and advanced data visualization. Prerequisites: PA 402 ; or PA 434 ; or consent of the instructor and admission to the Master of Public Administration, Master of Public Policy, or Master of Science in Computer Applications program. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Familiarity with coding environments and programming. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

Course: PA 447 — Survey Planning and Design Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and applications of sample survey planning and design for conducting research in health sciences and related fields. Addresses three major topics: survey design and planning, sampling, and data collection procedures. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing and BSTT 400 and CHSC 446 ; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as CHSC 447. Recommended Background: Credit in CHSC 446 or the equivalent.

Course: PA 452 — The UIC Freshwater Lab Course Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Brings a Humanities lens to the Great Lakes watershed to examine how water interacts with socio-political systems, legal structures, cultural perceptions, and artistic visions. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ENGL 452 and UPP 452. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: PA 453 — Freshwater Lab in Practice: Environmental Research, Projects, and Internships Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Investigates key issues surrounding Great Lakes water governance through a combination of hands-on research and professional development in fields related to environmental policy, planning, writing and communication. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ENGL 453 and UPP 453. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. This course offers an internship placement opportunity. Depending on placement/start date, students may begin internship work during the second half of the semester or during the summer.

metadata.class_name: Freshwater Lab in Practice: Environmental Research, Projects, and Internships
metadata.subject: Public Administration (PA)

text: Course: PA 464 — Technology and Innovation Theory Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 4 Description: The course focuses on theories surrounding the creation, development, transfer, and use of technology. Prerequisites: Graduate or professional standing and admission to the Ph.D. in Public Administration program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

Course: PA 466 — Science, Technology and Public Policy Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 4 Description: Addresses the relationships between public policy and science and technology in the United States. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; or consent of the instructor and admission to the Ph.D. in Public Administration program or consent of the instructor.

Course: PA 467 — Civic Engagement Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Analytic frameworks and practical strategies for utilizing public participation in government and community decisions. Investigates interactions between civic participation, efforts to improve administration of programs and develop new public policies. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Policy or Urban Studies; or admission to the Master of Public Administration or Master of Public Policy or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Same as PPOL 467. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 564.

Course: PA 468 — Topics in Management and Leadership of Public Organizations Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines management and leadership issues through experiences of current and former public managers, political appointees, elected officials, and other key public leaders. Emphasis on topics from Illinois and Chicago metropolitan region. Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Public Administration or Master of Public Policy or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Management and Leadership of Public Organizations
metadata.subject: Public Administration (PA)

text: Course: PA 470 — AI & Machine Learning Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduces students to public sector applications of artificial intelligence and machine learning. It begins with the philosophical foundations of artificial intelligence before introducing students to major frameworks for learning. Prerequisites: PA 402 or PA 434 ; and admission to the Master of Public Administration or Master of Public Policy or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: PA 490 — Field Experience in Public Policy and Administration Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 4 Description: Students work in an organization such as a government agency, community group, or nonprofit organization. Students are required to submit written work and meet with professor on periodic basis to review work experience. Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Public Administration or Master of Public Policy or Master of Science in Civic Analytics, Bachelor of Arts in Public Policy, or Bachelor of Arts in Urban Studies program; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 4 hours of credit may be applied to the Master of Public Administration program. Field work required. Students who have no prior work experience in the public or non-profit sectors are strongly recommended to register for this course.

metadata.class_name: Field Experience in Public Policy and Administration
metadata.subject: Public Administration (PA)

text: Course: PA 494 — Special Topics in Public Administration Subject: Public Administration (PA) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Consideration of timely or enduring issues in public administration not available in regularly offered courses. Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Public Administration, Master of Public Policy, or Master of Science in Civic Analytics program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: PATH 399 — Undergraduate Research in Pathology Subject: Pathology (PATH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Laboratory research for advanced undergraduate students. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

Course: PATH 421 — General Pathology - Dental Subject: Pathology (PATH) Credits: 3 Description: Basic principles of pathological processes. Prerequisites: ANAT 440 and PATH 407 and PHYB 401; or consent of instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: PATH 422 — Systemic Pathology - Dentistry Subject: Pathology (PATH) Credits: 3 Description: Disease process affecting specific organs. Prerequisites: PATH 421. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: PCOL 331 — Pharmacology for Dentistry Subject: Pharmacology (PCOL) Credits: 4 Description: Principles of pharmacology with emphasis on drugs for preoperative medication and pain management. Pharmacodynamics, nomenclature, and therapeutics. Prerequisites: Human physiology and introductory biochemistry.

Course: PCOL 399 — Undergraduate Laboratory Research Subject: Pharmacology (PCOL) Credits: 1-4 Description: Laboratory research for advanced undergraduates. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

Course: PCOL 430 — Principles of Toxicology Subject: Pharmacology (PCOL) Credits: 2 Description: Examines the toxic effects of drugs and chemicals on organ systems. Lectures emphasize basic principles, effects on specific organ systems, major classes of toxic chemicals, and specialized topics such as forensic and industrial toxicology. Course Information: Same as BPS 430. Credit is not given for PCOL 430 if the student has credit for EOHS 457.

Course: PHAR 200 — Introduction to Pharmaceutical Sciences Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to pharmaceutical sciences focusing on the process of drug discovery and development and different aspects of basic and applied sciences. Course Information: .

Course: PHAR 201 — Pharmaceutical Care in the US Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the role of pharmacies/pharmacists in U.S. healthcare, the relationship between pharmacy and society, including challenges to pharmacy equity in rural and urban communities and the opioid crisis, and efforts to reduce healthcare inequities.
