Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Hybrid course that integrates online and face-to-face classroom activities. US Society course.

Course: PHAR 385 — Remediation Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2-5 Description: A remediation option for students who previously failed courses that are no longer taught in the PharmD curriculum. Course content will mirror content from the core course that the student failed. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 15 hours.

Course: PHAR 410 — Integrated Physiology Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 3 Description: Reviews and integrates principles introduced in pre-requisite physiology, anatomy and biochemistry courses to human non-pathological and pathological situations. Active learning will promote problem-solving skills. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

Course: PHAR 411 — Introduction Pharmacy Practice Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the practice of pharmacy through a combination of lectures, on-campus introductory pharmacy practice experience (IPPE) simulations, and a one week off-site IPPE. Will cover communication skills and interprofessional interactions. Prerequisites: Current Illinois Pharmacy Technician License and completed college background check and drug screen and immunization records on file with the college. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory-Discussion and one Clinical Practice.

Course: PHAR 412 — Introductory Pharmacy Practice (IPPE): Community Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Overview of contemporary pharmacy practice in a community setting. Students will spend the majority of their time off-site at a community pharmacy enabling them to observe and develop the skills necessary in this setting. Prerequisites: PHAR 411 and PHAR 431 and current Illinois Pharmacy Technician License and must comply with annual college background check and urine drug screen and must have immunization records complete and on file with college and additional site-specific requirements.

Course: PHAR 413 — Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE): Hospital Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Students will be provided an overview of contemporary pharmacy practice in a hospital setting. Students will spend most of their time engaged in actual (off-site at a hospital pharmacy) or simulated (on-site) hospital pharmacy practice activities. Prerequisites: PHAR 411 and PHAR 431 and current Illinois Pharmacy Technician License and must comply with annual college background check and urine drug screen and must have immunization records complete and on file with college and additional site-specific requirements.

Course: PHAR 414 — Introductory Pharmacy Practice (IPPE): Introduction to Patient Care Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Introduction to the skills necessary to provide direct patient care. The goal of this course is to develop the skills necessary for communication of a pharmacotherapeutic recommendation both verbally and in writing. Prerequisites: PHAR 412 and PHAR 413 and current Illinois Pharmacy Technician License and compliance with annual college background check and urine drug screen and immunization records complete and on file with college.

metadata.class_name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice (IPPE): Introduction to Patient Care
metadata.subject: Pharmacy (PHAR)

text: Course: PHAR 422 — Fundamentals of Drug Action Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 4 Description: Comprehensive course in chemical mechanisms of drug action. The major objective is for students to develop an understanding of the connection between the properties of chemical compounds and therapeutic action of drugs. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: PHAR 423 — Fundamentals of Drug Action II Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 4 Description: Covers more advanced topics of medicinal chemistry such as drug metabolism, energy metabolism, enzyme inhibitor drugs, signaling pathways as drug targets, discovery of natural product drugs and new frontiers in drug discovery. Prerequisites: PHAR 422. Recommended Background: Doctor of Pharmacy prerequisites including two years of undergraduateound chemistry with laboratory and at least 3-credit hour biochemistry.

Course: PHAR 431 — Pharmaceutics I - Pharmaceutics Principles, Drug Delivery Systems, and Calculations Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 3 Description: Content will initially focus on basic pharmaceutics principles applicable to all drug delivery systems. Solution products including sterile product solutions will also be addressed. Students will also learn and practice basic pharmacy calculations. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Pharmaceutics I - Pharmaceutics Principles, Drug Delivery Systems, and Calculations
metadata.subject: Pharmacy (PHAR)

text: Course: PHAR 432 — Pharmaceutics II – Pharmaceutical Dosage Forms and Calculations Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Content will focus on basic pharmaceutics principles applicable to suspensions, emulsions, topicals, solids, and other dosage forms will be addressed. Pharmacy calculations relevant to dosage form preparation will also be taught. Prerequisites: PHAR 431.

metadata.class_name: Pharmaceutics II – Pharmaceutical Dosage Forms and Calculations
metadata.subject: Pharmacy (PHAR)

text: Course: PHAR 433 — Pharmaceutics III – Complex Dosage Forms and Calculations Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Content will focus on basic pharmaceutics principles applicable to complex dosage forms (e.g., sterile products, extended release products, vaccines, etc.). Pharmacy calculations relevant to dosage form preparation will also be taught. Prerequisites: PHAR 432.

metadata.class_name: Pharmaceutics III – Complex Dosage Forms and Calculations
metadata.subject: Pharmacy (PHAR)

text: Course: PHAR 434 — Pharmaceutics IV – Drug Delivery Systems Design and Calculations Competency Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Content will focus on dosage form design of sterile and non-sterile dosage forms; compounding; quality control; pharmacist’s role in preparation, compounding, and dispensing of dosage forms; and pharmacy calculations, including a competency exam. Prerequisites: PHAR 433.

metadata.class_name: Pharmaceutics IV – Drug Delivery Systems Design and Calculations Competency
metadata.subject: Pharmacy (PHAR)

text: Course: PHAR 435 — Pharmacokinetics Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 3 Description: Students will be introduced to basic principles of pharmacokinetics (e.g., absorption, distribution, biotransformation, excretion), factors influencing these parameters, and the use of common mathematical equations to calculate these parameters. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

Course: PHAR 438 — Introduction to Drug Information Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 1 Description: Content will focus on omparing and contrasting primary, secondary, and tertiary resources, including their relative value and trustworthiness. Students will gain skills necessary to conduct systematic searches and extract information from appropriate sources.

Course: PHAR 439 — Pharmacoepidemiology and Biostatistical Reasoning Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 1 Description: The principles of biostatistics and epidemiology relevant to pharmacy practice and pharmacoepidemiology (e.g., probability, descriptive and inferential statistics, measures of association and causality, and measures of excess risk) will be reviewed.

Course: PHAR 440 — Evidence-Based Medicine Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Focuses on the evaluation of clinical research in the literature and its application to patient care decisions. Application and interpretation of statistical methods will be reviewed in the context of study designs. Prerequisites: PHAR 438. Corequisites: PHAR 439. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

Course: PHAR 461 — Pharmacy and the U.S. Healthcare System Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Introduction to the philosophy and mission of the pharmacy profession, the evolution of practice, and elements of the U.S. Healthcare System.

metadata.class_name: Pharmacy and the U.S. Healthcare System
metadata.subject: Pharmacy (PHAR)

text: Course: PHAR 462 — Social and Behavioral Pharmacy Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: A survey of topics in the social and behavioral sciences as applied to pharmacy. The course emphasizes the broader social and health systems-related issues that surround and affect patient care provided by pharmacists.

Course: PHAR 463 — Personal and Professional Development Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 2 Description: Imparts knowledge, skills, abilities, behaviors and attitudes necessary for personal and professional competence and development, reinforcing the concepts of self-awareness, leadership, innovation, entrepreneurship, and professionalism. Prerequisites: PHAR 461.

Course: PHAR 464 — Patient Safety Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 1 Description: Reviews topics related to patient safety. Prevalence and risk factors for error in healthcare settings, systematic approaches to risk assessment and error investigation, and methods to improve health system safety will be covered.

Course: PHAR 465 — Pharmacy Learning, Advising, Mentoring, and Engagement for Students (PhLAMES) 1 Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 0 Description: Supports and advances the longitudinal professional and character development of students utilizing network-based mentoring and co-curricular activities that complement the didactic and experiential coursework of the professional PharmD curriculum. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Pharmacy Learning, Advising, Mentoring, and Engagement for Students (PhLAMES) 1
metadata.subject: Pharmacy (PHAR)

text: Course: PHAR 466 — Pharmacy Learning, Advising, Mentoring, and Engagement for Students (PhLAMES) 2 Subject: Pharmacy (PHAR) Credits: 0 Description: Supports and advances the longitudinal professional and character development of students utilizing network-based mentoring and co-curricular activities that complement the didactic and experiential coursework of the professional PharmD curriculum. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

text: Course: PHIL 100 — Introduction to Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of traditional problems concerning the existence and nature of God, freedom, justification, morality, etc. Readings from historical or contemporary philosophers. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 101 — Critical and Analytical Reasoning Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Practical course designed to improve student reasoning skills useful for life, college coursework, and explicitly tested on standardized tests like MCAT, GRE, LSAT. Emphasis is on developing skill at evaluating, formulating and presenting arguments. Course Information: Course is offered in both face-to-face and online formats. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Note that the online format involves heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 102 — Introductory Logic Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Sentential logic: representation of English using truth-functional connectives, decision methods, natural deduction techniques. Introduction to predicate logic: representation of English using quantifiers. Course Information: Course is offered in both face-to-face and online formats. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Note that the online format involves heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: PHIL 103 — Introduction to Ethics Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Surveys attempts to answer central questions of ethics: What acts are right? What things are good? How do we know this? Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 104 — Introduction to Political Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: An introductory survey of topics in political philosophy that bear on U.S. society. Readings will usually be drawn from both classical and contemporary sources. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: PHIL 105 — Science and Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: An exploration of central philosophical (and/or religious) issues as they arise in the sciences. Readings include both scientific (e.g. physics or biology) and philosophical works, and may be drawn from various periods. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: PHIL 106 — What Is Religion Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of issues concerning religion, including varying views of the purposes that religions serve, differences between religions, and arguments for the existence of God. Course Information: Same as RELS 106. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 107 — What is Art Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the fundamental problems in understanding art; the historical background; the concept of the aesthetic; theories of art; intentionalistic criticism; metaphor; symbolism; expression; theories of evaluation. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Creative Arts course.

Course: PHIL 108 — What Is Freedom Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to philosophy through an investigation of freedom. What is freedom, and why do we value it? Do we have free will? What limitations on individual freedom by society are legitimate? What is a free society? Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 109 — Who Am I Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Who am I? What does it mean to be human? How am I different from other humans? What is the source of my identity, and is it something I can control? These questions addressed through philosophical texts from Plato to the present. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 110 — Philosophy of Love and Sex Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: A philosophical inquiry into traditional and contemporary views about love and sex. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 111 — What Is a Fact Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to philosophy via an examination of the notion of a fact, and of methods for discerning facts. Topics include: facts and opinions; facts and theories; facts and expertise; facts and free speech. Course Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in on Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 112 — Morality and the Law Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: What must the law do if it is to protect our rights (such as free speech, privacy, equal treatment)? Why believe we have rights? Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 113 — Philosophy in the Information Age Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to philosophy through an exploration of the ethical, epistemological, and metaphysical implications of and questions arising from the use of digital technology. Examples may be taken from Big Data, social media and autonomous technology. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 115 — Death Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical examination of our attitudes towards death. Our attitudes towards mortality and immortality; definitions of death; treating others as persons; our attitudes towards life, quality of life issues, suicide, rights of the dying. Course Information: Course is offered in both face-to-face and online formats. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Note that the online format involves heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 116 — Biomedical Ethics Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Moral issues as they arise in biomedical research and practice and the use of principles from general ethics to address them. Topics may include euthanasia, paternalism, allocation of medical resources, and healthcare disparities. Course Information: Course is offered in both face-to-face and online formats. Check the class schedule for details on specific sections. Note that the online format involves heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 120 — Introduction to Ancient Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to issues and methods of philosophy through engagement with classic Greek and Roman texts (read in translation). Course Information: Same as CL 120. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: PHIL 131 — Educational Ethics Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: A practical, case-based introduction to ethical issues that arise in the daily life of classroom teachers, and techniques and strategies for thinking well about them. Of particular interest to students in teacher training programs, but open to all. Course Information: Same as ED 131. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: PHIL 184 — The Basics of Neuroscience Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to the scientific study of the brain and behavior. Overview of neuroscience as an integrative discipline. Course Information: Same as BIOS 184 and PSCH 184. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: PHIL 201 — Theory of Knowledge Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Basic issues concerning knowledge, such as knowledge of the external world, other minds, scientific laws, and necessary truths. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 202 — Philosophy of Psychology Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Theories and methods of scientific psychology: modes of explaining the structure of theories, the nature of mental states; implications of commonsense conceptions of the mind. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or junior or senior standing in the physical, biological, or social sciences; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 203 — Metaphysics Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical issues concerning free will, causation, action, mind and body, identity over time, God, universals and particulars. Emphasis varies from term to term. Prerequisites: One course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: PHIL 204 — Introduction to the Philosophy of Science Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: The nature of scientific observation, explanation, and theories; confirmation of laws and theories; the relation between the physical and social sciences. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or junior or senior standing in the physical, biological, or social sciences; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 206 — Introduction to the Philosophy of Language Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical issues concerning meaning, the relationship between language and thought, how language is to be distinguished from other forms of communication, and how truth relates to meaning. Course Information: Same as LING 206. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Recommended Background: One non-logic course in philosophy.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Philosophy of Language
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 210 — Symbolic Logic Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Representation of English sentences using quantifiers and identity; quantificational natural deduction; interpretations. Optional topics include naive set theory; axiomatic systems; theory of descriptions; metatheory. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in PHIL 102 ; or credit in MATH 110 or placement into MATH 121 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 211 — Inductive Logic and Decision Making Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: How to gamble and make other decisions rationally. The role of probability, decision rules, and statistics in real-life contexts. Prerequisites: PHIL 102 ; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 215 — Philosophy of Computing and Machine Learning Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Understanding of the philosophical foundations of computing and machine learning including AI. Exploration of the connections between computing technology and philosophical theories concerning logic, epistemology, mind and metaphysics. Prerequisites: One 100-level non-logic course in Philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: PHIL 210.

metadata.class_name: Philosophy of Computing and Machine Learning
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 220 — Ancient Philosophy I: Plato and His Predecessors Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Plato and his predecessors in the ancient period. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CL 220. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Philosophy I: Plato and His Predecessors
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 221 — Ancient Philosophy II: Aristotle and His Successors Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Aristotle and his successors in the ancient period. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CL 221. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Ancient Philosophy II: Aristotle and His Successors
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 222 — Philosophy in the Islamic World Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of philosophy in the Islamic world from 8th century until today. Topics include: logic and psychology to metaphysics, theology, and politics. Special emphasis on cultural interactions between philosophers of different faiths and cultures. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ARAB 222 and RELS 222.

Course: PHIL 223 — History of Modern Philosophy I: Descartes and His Successors Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Descartes and some of his successors in the early modern period. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: History of Modern Philosophy I: Descartes and His Successors
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 224 — History of Modern Philosophy II: Kant and His Predecessors Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Kant and some of his predecessors in the early modern period. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: History of Modern Philosophy II: Kant and His Predecessors
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 225 — Nineteenth Century Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: A survey course of the works of major nineteenth century philosophers such as: Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Kierkegaard, and Schopenhauer. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: PHIL 226 — Twentieth-Century Analytic Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Historical introduction to the major issues and figures of twentieth-century philosophy in the analytic tradition. Readings from Frege, Russell, Wittgenstein, Quine, and others. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Recommended Background: PHIL 102.

Course: PHIL 227 — Continental Philosophy I: Phenomenology and Existentialism Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Existential themes in dramas and fiction as well as selections from the works of such thinkers as Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Husserl, Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty, Camus and Sartre. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or the consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Continental Philosophy I: Phenomenology and Existentialism
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 230 — Topics in Ethics and Political Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major topics in ethical theory and political philosophy. Emphasis varies. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Recommended Background: PHIL 103 or PHIL 109 or PHIL 112 or PHIL 116.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Ethics and Political Philosophy
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 231 — Philosophy of Race and Racism Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to philosophical arguments about racism, race, and racial identity. What does it mean to call racism "structural"? Is race a harmful fiction, or an important political reality? Does it make sense to say that Muslims are racialized? Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy, or consent of the instructor.

Course: PHIL 232 — Sex Roles: Moral and Political Issues Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical inquiry into controversies surrounding the changing roles of men and women. Course Information: Same as GWS 232. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Sex Roles: Moral and Political Issues
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 234 — Philosophy and Film Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: A philosophical examination of film. Screening accompanies discussion. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 240 — Philosophy and Revelation: Jewish and Christian Perspectives Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to philosophical ways of addressing the claim that a book (the Bible, the Quran) comes from God. Texts by Immanuel Kant, Moses Mendelssohn, and Soren Kierkegaard, among others. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PHIL 141. Same as RELS 240 and JST 240. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Philosophy and Revelation: Jewish and Christian Perspectives
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 241 — Philosophy of Religion Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical inquiry into the grounds of faith and belief, the nature of religious and mystical experience, and the existence and nature of God. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as RELS 241. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 299 — Seminar Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics. Prerequisites: One course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: PHIL 300 — Fundamentals of Philosophical Discourse Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: An intensive course for philosophy majors or minors aimed at introducing and developing skill in philosophical writing and oral presentation. Prerequisites: Major or minor in Philosophy, or major or pre-major in Computer Science and Philosophy; and credit in at least one non-logic 200-level philosophy course or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PHIL 400.

Course: PHIL 310 — Aristotle and the Arabs Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Traces the major topics of ancient Greek philosophy, especially those of Aristotle, and their transformation into the philosophy developed in the Arabic classical period. Prerequisites: CL 221 or PHIL 221 or RELS 230. Course Information: Same as ARAB 310 and CL 310.

Course: PHIL 315 — Ethics of Computing and Artificial Intelligence Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Identification and analysis of ethical challenges specific to computing and artificial intelligence as well as the implications of such technology for important moral concepts such as agency, responsibility, and privacy. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent enrollment in one 200-level non-logic course in Philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Credit in PHIL 215.

metadata.class_name: Ethics of Computing and Artificial Intelligence
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 357 — Philosophy of Rhetoric Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: The philosophical basis of the rhetorical tradition—from ancient Greece to today. We ask how language and persuasion function in society, focusing on how rhetorical form, proof, audience, and context shape meaning, belief, and understandings of truth. Prerequisites: Credit in a 200-level course in Philosophy or English or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ENGL 357. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Credit in PHIL 102 or ENGL 154.

Course: PHIL 390 — Senior Thesis in Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Students will work individually with a member of the faculty on a topic chosen by the student and approved by the faculty. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors; Consent of the instructor and department.

Course: PHIL 399 — Independent Study Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 2-6 Description: Independent study, under the supervision of a staff member, of a topic not covered in the regular curriculum. Offered at the request of the student and only at the discretion of the staff members concerned. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: PHIL 401 — Theory of Knowledge Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey and analysis of key topics in epistemology, such as skepticism, the nature of propositional knowledge, justification, perception, memory, induction, other minds, naturalistic epistemology. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 402 — Topics in Philosophy of Mind Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey and analysis of one or more topics in philosophy of mind, such as the mind-body problem, philosophy of psychology, perception and sensation, intentional content, consciousness, and mental causation. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 403 — Metaphysics Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive treatment of one or more topics, such as free will, personal identity, causation, existence, substance and attribute, the nature of the mind. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: PHIL 102.

Course: PHIL 404 — Philosophy of Science Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected works on the aims and methods of science; the status of scientific theories, natural laws and theoretical entities; the nature of scientific explanation. Prerequisites: PHIL 102 and one non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 406 — Topics in Philosophy of Language Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive treatment of one or more topics, such as meaning and reference, communication, the structure of language, language and thought, and the relation of language to reality. Prerequisites: PHIL 102 and one 200-level non-logic course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 410 — Introduction to Formal Logic Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Review of predicate logic and of introductory set theory. The concept of a formal system. Notions of completeness and soundness. Introduction to Godel's first incompleteness theorem. Prerequisites: PHIL 210 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: PHIL 422 — Studies in Medieval Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 0-4 Description: Study of selected philosophers such as Boethius, Avicenna, Aquinas, William Ockham, and selected issues such as the relationship between faith and reason, the nature of reason, the nature of human cognition, the nature of morality. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level philosophy course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as RELS 422. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics or figures vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PHIL 423 — Studies in Early Modern Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Careful reading of selected works of one or more philosophers, 1600 to 1750, such as Descartes, Hobbes, Spinoza, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, Reid and Rousseau. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics or figures vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 424 — Kant Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive study of Kant's philosophy. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 425 — Studies in Nineteenth-Century Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Careful reading of one or more post-Kantian philosophers such as Hegel, Schelling, Fichte, Schopenhauer, Marx, J.S. Mill, Kierkegaard, Nietzsche. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 426 — Analysis and Logical Empiricism Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Developments in twentieth century analytic philosophy with roots in the study of logic and language, such as logical atomism and logical empiricism. Prerequisites: PHIL 102 and one non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics and figures vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 427 — Continental Philosophy II: European Thought Since 1960 Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: European thought since 1960: Existential Marxism; Critical Theory; Structuralism, Post-Structuralism and Deconstruction. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics or figures vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

metadata.class_name: Continental Philosophy II: European Thought Since 1960
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 428 — Topics in Ancient Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Careful reading of related works by Ancient Philosophers, such as Plato and Aristotle. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics or figures vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 429 — Special Studies in the History of Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced study of a historical school, period, or the development of a historical theme. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in the history of philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics or figures vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

metadata.class_name: Special Studies in the History of Philosophy
metadata.subject: Philosophy (PHIL)

text: Course: PHIL 432 — Topics in Ethics Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in ethics. Prerequisites: One 200-level course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. Recommended Background: Credit in a course in moral, social, or political philosophy.

Course: PHIL 433 — Topics in Social/Political Philosophy Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in social and political philosophy. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 441 — Topics in Philosophy of Religion Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive study of one or more selected topics concerning the philosophical aspects of basic religious beliefs and concepts. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as RELS 441. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: PHIL 484 — Neuroscience I Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Neuroscience as an integrative discipline. Neuroanatomy of vertebrates, neural development, cellular neurobiology, action potential mechanisms, synaptic transmission and neuropharmacology. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or PSCH 262. Course Information: Same as BIOS 484 and PSCH 484.

Course: PHIL 485 — Neuroscience II Subject: Philosophy (PHIL) Credits: 3 Description: Integrative neuroscience, including sensory and motor systems; learning, memory, and language; pathology of nervous systems; philosophical perspectives, and modeling. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or PSCH 262. Course Information: Same as BIOS 485 and PSCH 485.

Course: PHYB 301 — Human Physiology and Pathophysiology I Subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB) Credits: 5 Description: Designed for the College of Pharmacy. Physiology and pathophysiology of the nervous, cardiovascular, and excretory systems at the cell, tissue, organ, and system levels. Prerequisites: Enrollment in the Doctor of Pharmacy program.

Course: PHYB 302 — Human Physiology and Pathophysiology II Subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB) Credits: 5 Description: Continuation of PHYB 301. Physiology and pathophysiology of the blood, respiratory, endocrine, and reproductive systems. General pathology, mechanisms of disease. Prerequisites: PHYB 301 and enrollment in the Doctor of Pharmacy program.

Course: PHYB 321 — Human Physiology for Dental Students I Subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB) Credits: 2 Description: The major concepts involved in the regulation of living processes are introduced. The underlying homeostasis and communication mechanisms by which the major systems are interrelated are emphasized. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in a 300-level biochemistry course. Credit or concurrent registration in a 300-level biochemistry course Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in a 300-level biochemistry course Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Human Physiology for Dental Students I
metadata.subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB)

text: Course: PHYB 322 — Human Physiology for Dental Students II Subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB) Credits: 2 Description: Continuation of PHYB 321. A continuation of the major concepts involved in the regulation of living processes. The underlying homeostasis and communication mechanisms by which the major systems are interrelated are emphasized. Prerequisites: PHYB 321.

metadata.class_name: Human Physiology for Dental Students II
metadata.subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB)

text: Course: PHYB 396 — Independent Study Subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB) Credits: 1-4 Description: Independent study (non-laboratory) for advanced undergraduates majoring in appropriate disciplines. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

Course: PHYB 399 — Laboratory Research Subject: Physiology and Biophysics (PHYB) Credits: 1-4 Description: Laboratory research for advanced undergraduates majoring in appropriate disciplines. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: PHYS 100 — Preparatory Physics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to basic physics concepts, problem-solving skills, and quantitative reasoning. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in MATH 121 ; and appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: No credit toward the Major in Physics, BS in Physics, or Minor in Physics.

Course: PHYS 101 — Active Learning of the Physical World Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: A continuation of the first 7 weeks of PHYS 141 , focusing on the exploration of the physical world through active learning. Student-centered learning through team activities in small group settings, working on problem-solving activities. Prerequisites: Physics 141; and registration and approval of the department. Restricted to students currently enrolled in PHYS 141. Course Information: Credit is not given for PHYS 101 if student has credit in PHYS 141. Enrollment available only after week 7 and only to students currently enrolled in PHYS 141.

metadata.class_name: Active Learning of the Physical World
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 110 — Gateway to Physics: First Year Seminar Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1 Description: Seminar for physics majors and anyone curious about physics as a major, discipline, and career – topics include career options and pathways, navigating the physics major and research opportunities, campus and departmental resources. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No background in physics is necessary.

metadata.class_name: Gateway to Physics: First Year Seminar
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 112 — Astronomy and the Universe Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Astronomy in the context of the scientific process, history and current events. Covers the Solar System, stars and galaxies and the origin and fate of the universe. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: PHYS 116 — Energy for Future Decision-Makers Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of energy sustainability and environmental issues. All energy forms of production, sources, storage, and uses; their environmental implications on a global scale within the scientific, technological, political, economic, and social context. Course Information: Same as EAES 116. Recommended Background: High school algebra. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: PHYS 118 — Physics in Modern Medicine Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey course of physical technologies used in modern medicine and the underlying physics, including applications of optics, imaging, and nuclear medicine to diagnosis, surgery, therapy and treatment. Prerequisites: High school algebra, trigonometry, and biology. Natural World - No Lab course.

Course: PHYS 131 — Introductory Physics for Life Sciences I Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Algebra-based physics and its relationship to the life sciences, including mechanics, waves, diffusion and fluids with applications to molecular, cell and human biology. Prerequisites: High school algebra and trigonometry. Credit for PHYS 131 is not given if the student has credit for PHYS 105 or PHYS 141. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory, one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Natural World - With Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Introductory Physics for Life Sciences I
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 132 — Introductory Physics for Life Sciences II Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Algebra-based physics and its relationship to the life sciences, including electromagnetism, optical, quantum, and thermal physics, with applications to molecular, cell and human biology. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 105 and Grade of C or better in PHYS 106; or Grade of C or better in PHYS 131. Credit for PHYS 132 is not given if the student has credit for PHYS 107 or PHYS 142. To be properly registered, student must enroll in one Laboratory, one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Natural World - With Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Introductory Physics for Life Sciences II
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 141 — General Physics I (Mechanics) Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Kinematics, vectors, Newton’s laws of motion; linear momentum, collisions; work and kinetic energy; potential energy, conservation of energy; rotational kinematics and energy; rotational dynamics, static equilibrium; simple harmonic motion. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in MATH 180 ; or approval of the department ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 100 or adequate performance on the departmental placement test. Course Information: Students may obtain one additional hour of credit by concurrently registering in PHYS 144. Class Schedule Information: During the fall and spring terms, combined-section final exam will be held on Wednesday of finals week from 6 to 8 p.m. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: PHYS 142 — General Physics II (Electricity and Magnetism) Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Electrostatics; electric currents; d-c circuits; magnetic fields; magnetic media; electromagnetic induction; a-c circuits; Maxwell’s equations; electromagnetic waves; reflection and refraction; interference; geometrical optics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 141 ; and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in MATH 181. Natural World - With Lab course.

Course: PHYS 144 — Problem-Solving Workshop for General Physics I (Mechanics) Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1 Description: A workshop where smaller groups of students work together with the instructor to enhance their problem solving skills by solving additional problems both similar to, as well as more challenging than, the ones given in Physics 141. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Must enroll concurrently in PHYS 141.

metadata.class_name: Problem-Solving Workshop for General Physics I (Mechanics)
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 145 — Problem-Solving Workshop for General Physics II (Electricity and Magnetism) Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1 Description: A workshop where smaller groups of students work together with the instructor to enhance their problem-solving skills by solving additional problems both similar to, as well as more challenging than, problems given in Physics 142. Corequisites: PHYS 142. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Problem-Solving Workshop for General Physics II (Electricity and Magnetism)
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 215 — Computational and Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Computational and mathematical methods applied to basic problems in physics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; or Grade of B or better in PHYS 107 or Grade of B or better in PHYS 132 ; and Grade of C or better in MATH 181 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in MATH 210. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Computational and Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 230 — Fundamentals of Relativity Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the theory of relativity, including special relativity (Lorentz contraction, time dilation, energy-mass equivalence, kinematics and electrodynamics) and general relativity (gravity, black holes). Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; or Grade of B or better in PHYS 107 or Grade of B or better in PHYS 132.

Course: PHYS 240 — Fundamentals of Modern Quantum Theory Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 3 Description: Modern introduction to the quantum theory including discrete systems (qubits, etc.), quantum measurement theory, entanglement, Bell’s Theorem, the Uncertainty Principle, one-dimensional potential models, and the Schrodinger-von Neumann equation. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; or Grade of B or better in PHYS 107 or Grade of B or better in PHYS 132. Physics majors (BA and BS) are required to register concurrently for PHYS 241.

Course: PHYS 241 — Experiments in Modern Physics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1 Description: Companion course to PHYS 240 that includes laboratory experiments on introductory quantum theory and modern physics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; or Grade of B or better in PHYS 107 or Grade of B or better in PHYS 132. Corequisites: PHYS 240 or approval of the department.

Course: PHYS 245 — Introduction to Vibrations, Waves, and Thermal Physics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Free, forced, damped, and coupled oscillations; normal modes; Fourier analysis; resonance; waves; interference; diffraction; heat energy; entropy; introduction to thermodynamics, kinetic theory of gases, and basic statistical physics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 142 ; or Grade of B or better in PHYS 107 or Grade of B or better in PHYS 132. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 220 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 220 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 220. Prereq Codes (parsed): MATH 220 Coreq Codes (parsed): MATH 220

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Vibrations, Waves, and Thermal Physics
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 260 — Introduction to Thermal Physics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 2 Description: Calculus-based introduction to thermal physics. The first and second laws of thermodynamics, entropy, free energy, statistical physics, and their applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 141 and Grade of C or better in MATH 181. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Computer and internet access are required. This course does not satisfy the requirements for BA and BS degrees in physics. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: PHYS 391 — Physics Seminar Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1 Description: Preparation and presentation by students of talks on topics of current interest in physics. Prerequisites: Senior standing. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours.

Course: PHYS 392 — Physics Research Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 2-4 Description: Research under the close supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: PHYS 393 — Special Problems Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 2-4 Description: Special problems or reading in modern physics under individual arrangement with a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: PHYS 401 — Electromagnetism I Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Vector calculus; electrostatic and magnetostatic fields in vacuum; electrostatic boundary-value problems; electrodynamics; Maxwell's equations; electromagnetic waves in vacuum; reflection and transmission phenomena in linear media. Prerequisites: MATH 220 ; and Grade of C or better in PHYS 215 ; or approval of the department.

Course: PHYS 402 — Electromagnetism II Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Electrostatics, mangetostatics, and electromagnetic waves in matter; radiation; relativistic electrodynamics; special topics chosen by the instructor. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 230 and Grade of C or better in PHYS 401 ; or approval of the department.

Course: PHYS 411 — Quantum Mechanics I Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Wave particle duality; wave functions; matrix representation; operators and observables; 1-D potentials; harmonic oscillator; eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; time-independent perturbation theory; approximation methods; 3-D Schroedinger’s equation. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 215 and Grade of C or better in PHYS 240 and Grade of C or better in PHYS 245 ; or approval of the department. Recommended Background: MATH 220.

Course: PHYS 412 — Quantum Mechanics II Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: The second semester of a two-semester undergraduate level sequence on the concepts and methods of quantum mechanics and their applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 411 ; or approval of the department.

Course: PHYS 421 — Modern Physics: Atoms and Molecules Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Hydrogenic atoms, electron spin, external fields, multi-electron atoms, diatomic molecules, line widths, photons, radiation from atoms and other electromagnetic processes, positrons, positronium, elastic electron scattering. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 411. Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 411 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 411 Prereq Codes (parsed): PHYS 411 Coreq Codes (parsed): PHYS 411

Course: PHYS 425 — Modern Optics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Review of electromagnetic wave theory and introductory optics; advanced geometrical optics; Fourier transforms and optics; interference and diffraction; solar cells and LEDs; laser cavities and gain media; introduction to nonlinear and fiber optics. Prerequisites: PHYS 240 ; or approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion, one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: PHYS 431 — Modern Physics: Condensed Matter Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Crystal structures; interatomic binding; lattice vibrations; thermal and magnetic properties; quantum statistical mechanics; free electron theory of metals; electronic band theory; semiconductors and insulators; superconductivity. Prerequisites: PHYS 411 and PHYS 461 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: PHYS 441 — Theoretical Mechanics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Review of Newtonian mechanics, variational calculus, Lagrangian mechanics, central force problems, non-inertial frames, rigid body motion, coupled oscillators, non-linear mechanics, Hamiltonian mechanics, and numerical examples. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 215 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in PHYS 245 ; or approval of the department.

Course: PHYS 450 — Molecular Biophysics of the Cell Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to force, time energies at nanometer scales; Boltzmann distribution; hydrodynamic drag; Brownian motions; DNA, RNA protein structure and function; sedimentation; chemical kinetics; general aspects of flexible polymers. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 245 or Grade of C or better in PHYS 260 or the equivalent; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as BIOS 460 and BME 450.

Course: PHYS 451 — Modern Physics: Nuclei and Elementary Particles Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Accelerators, detectors, symmetries, conservation laws, leptons, weak interactions, electroweak theory, strong interactions, hadrons, nuclear forces, systematics and reactions, nuclear models, nuclear astrophysics, quarks, quantum chromodynamics. Prerequisites: PHYS 411.

metadata.class_name: Modern Physics: Nuclei and Elementary Particles
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 461 — Thermal and Statistical Physics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Thermal equilibrium (Zeroth Law); thermodynamic states (First Law); irreversibility; entropy (Second Law); thermodynamic potentials and properties; phase transitions; kinetic theory of gases; classical statistical mechanics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 245 ; or approval of the department.

Course: PHYS 469 — The Learning and Teaching of Physics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Provides teacher candidates with the foundations and experiences necessary for teaching physics in secondary schools. For those currently teaching, it will also provide tools and background to improve their physics instruction. Prerequisites: PHYS 142 ; or PHYS 107 and PHYS 108; or approval of the department. Course Information: 4 hours. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: The Learning and Teaching of Physics
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 470 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the department. Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: PHYS 471 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 470 , and approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 470 , and approval of the department Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 470 , and approval of the department Course Information: Graduate credit only with approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): PHYS 470 Coreq Codes (parsed): PHYS 470

Course: PHYS 475 — Learning and Teaching of Physical Sciences Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 3 Description: Provides teacher candidates with the foundation and experience necessary to teach physical sciences in secondary schools. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Same as CHEM 475. Recommended Background: Knowledge of first-year college physics and chemistry. Class Schedule: To be properly registered students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Learning and Teaching of Physical Sciences
metadata.subject: Physics (PHYS)

text: Course: PHYS 480 — Elements of Machining Scientific Equipment Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1 Description: Elements of machining scientific equipment, including the use of machine shop tools and technical drawing of scientific apparatus. Prerequisites: Graduate standing; and approval of the department. Course Information: Same as CHEM 480 and EAES 478. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: PHYS 481 — Modern Experimental Physics I Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Theory and experimental use of linear circuits, semiconductor devices, amplifiers, oscillators. Techniques and experiments in atomic, molecular and solid-state physics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PHYS 240 ; or approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: PHYS 482 — Modern Experimental Physics II Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 4 Description: Techniques and experiments in nuclear and particle physics. Gamma-gamma correlations, muon lifetime, Compton scattering, alpha particle scattering. Computer-based experimentation. Prerequisites: PHYS 481 ; or approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: PHYS 491 — Special Topics in Physics Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Selected topics of current interest in Physics. Prerequisites: PHYS 215 and sophomore standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated.

Course: PHYS 494 — Special Topics in Physics Teaching Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 2-4 Description: Seminar on various topics related to the teaching of physics. Subjects are announced. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Supervised teaching practice included.

Course: PHYS 499 — Survey of Physics Problems Subject: Physics (PHYS) Credits: 1 Description: Problem-solving techniques applied to the variety of undergraduate physics topics. Course Information: No graduation credit for graduate students. Grade of C or better required to graduate with an undergraduate degree in physics. Co-requisite(s):Concurrent registration in PHYS 481.

Course: PMPR 300 — Undergraduate Research Experience in Pharmacy Practice Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Course is being developed to support the academic environment for undergraduate students at UIC. The research experience will be under the guidance of a faculty member who will act as a research supervisor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor supervising the research experience. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unstatisfatory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

metadata.class_name: Undergraduate Research Experience in Pharmacy Practice
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 313 — The Pharmacist’s Role in Rural and Global Health Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Provides exposure to pharmacist roles in rural and low-resource global communities and reviews the challenges of providing care, including population health, social determinants of health, and service delivery methods.

metadata.class_name: The Pharmacist’s Role in Rural and Global Health
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 315 — Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare I Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Designed to introduce health care professions students to concepts and issues related to rural public health and primary care practice. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Rural Health Professions (RPHARM) Program.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare I
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 316 — Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare II Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces students to concepts of health resources development, rural mental health as well as community based research in rural communities. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Rural Health Professions (RPHARM) Program and successful completion of PMPR 315.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare II
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 317 — Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare III Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Allows students to apply what was learned in the first year by participating in hands on community health education. In addition, clinical aspects of rural healthcare are introduced. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Rural Health Professions (RPharm) Program AND successful completion of RHP Year 1.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare III
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 318 — Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare IV Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Students apply what was learned in the first year by participating in hands on community health education. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Rural Health Professions (RPHARM) Program; and successful completion of PMPR 315 , PMPR 316 and PMPR 317.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare IV
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 319 — Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare V Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: The fifth course in a series of six courses of supplementary education for PharmD students accepted into the Rural Health Professions (RHP) Program. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Rural Health Professions (RPHARM) Program AND successful completion of RHP Years 1 and 2.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare V
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 320 — Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare VI Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: The sixth course in a series of six courses of supplementary education for PharmD students accepted into the Rural Health Professions (RHP) Program. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Rural Health Professions (RPHARM) Program AND successful completion of RHP Years 1 and 2.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Rural Family and Community Healthcare VI
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 321 — Capstone Project in Rural Healthcare Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: The capstone project is a community-based research project which requires study of their chosen community's social, economic, cultural, organizational and political structure. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Rural Health Professions/RPHARM Program and successful completion of Years 1-3 of the RPHARM series of courses.

Course: PMPR 326 — Topics for Professional Student Enrichment Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Students will meet at the beginning of the semester with the course instructor to review and select topics from a schedule of topics. Topics chosen will reflect 15 hours of class time as well as writen journals. Prerequisites: PHAR 341.

Course: PMPR 327 — Lifestyle Modifications in Disease Management Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Provides students with the background and practical knowledge for teaching their patients the best ways to become aware of and implement specific lifestyle modifications for their disease states. Prerequisites: PHAR 501 and PHAR 502 and PHAR 503 and PHAR 504. Course Information: Asynchronously delivered on Blackboard using Panopto videos.

Course: PMPR 328 — Evidence Based Phytotherapy Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Provides a basis for the evidenced-based evaluation of phytotherapy and other Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM) modalities.

Course: PMPR 329 — The Dean’s Seminar: Career Insights from Pharmacy Leaders Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Features distinguished guest speakers, with different backgrounds who share their real‐world career experiences and advice. Guest speakers include established leaders and rising stars from many different pharmacy disciplines. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: The Dean’s Seminar: Career Insights from Pharmacy Leaders
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 330 — Journal Club and Advanced Literature Analysis Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: A course designed to familiarize students with more advanced study design and statistical concepts commonly used in the medical literature. Prerequisites: P3 standing and completion of PHAR 440.

metadata.class_name: Journal Club and Advanced Literature Analysis
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 334 — Mindfulness Practice Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Mindfulness is the practice of focusing in the present moment, without judgment or bias. In this course, students will learn about the science and theory of mindfulness and practice techniques during class time.

Course: PMPR 335 — Academic Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 4 Description: An APPE occurring across the curriculum that exposes fourth-professional year students to academic pharmacy. Prerequisites: P4 level student standing. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.

Course: PMPR 336 — Concepts in Drug Development: From Bench to Bedside Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Designed to give clinician-scientists an overview of the drug development process, from bench to bedside. Prerequisites: Students will be required to search and evaluate scientific literature independently. PharmD candidates must be current second- or third-year students. First-year pharmacy students or graduate students of any year require instructor approval. Course Information: Offered online only.

metadata.class_name: Concepts in Drug Development: From Bench to Bedside
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 337 — Spanish for Pharmacists Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: This online elective course is designed to provide students with the fundamental knowledge they will need to interact with a Spanish speaking patient.

Course: PMPR 338 — Management of the HIV Patient Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Incorporates team and case-based learning. Provides an opportunity to advance HIV understanding and clinical application. Prerequisites: PHAR 403.

Course: PMPR 339 — Exploration of Telemedicine in Pharmacy Practice Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Provides an overview of telemedicine and its role in the healthcare system. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion, one Laboratory, and one Clinical Practice.

metadata.class_name: Exploration of Telemedicine in Pharmacy Practice
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 345 — Clinical Toxicology Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 3 Description: Basic and applied concepts in clinical toxicology including general approach, poisoning prevention measures, retrieval and evaluation of toxicology literature, substance abuse issues and practice site specific toxicology concerns. Prerequisites: Enrollment in the Doctor of Pharmacy program.

Course: PMPR 347 — Advanced Transplant Therapeutics Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Builds upon the fundamentals of solid organ transplantation established in PHAR 504. Prerequisites: PHAR 504.

Course: PMPR 348 — Advanced Topics in Ambulatory Care Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Provides pharmacy students with advanced knowledge of the most common chronic conditions encountered in ambulatory care, a review of practice management and care delivery models, and postgraduate training and certification recommended. Prerequisites: PHAR 505 and PHAR 506.

Course: PMPR 349 — Case Based Infectious Diseases Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Provides an opportunity to advance infectious disease understanding and clinical application. Students will be responsible for providing therapeutic recommendations based on evidence based medicine. Prerequisites: PHAR 506 , current P3 standing.

Course: PMPR 355 — Seminar in Pharmacy Research Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: A weekly 1 hour research seminar provided by the College of Pharmacy faculty who are currently conducting clinical and/or basic science research. Prerequisites: Enrollment in the Doctor of Pharmacy Program.
