Course: PMPR 356 — The Role of the Pharmacist in Tobacco Cessation Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: The intent of this elective course is to provide students a very in-depth knowledge base in tobacco cessation (including Electronic Nicotine Delivery Systems), skills for counseling, and detailed “how to” information on specific counseling techniques.

metadata.class_name: The Role of the Pharmacist in Tobacco Cessation
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 357 — Natural and Recombinant Plasma-Derived Therapeutics Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to plasma-derived therapeutics including albumin, immune globulins, and factor products. Production, viral safety, and clinical applications will be covered. Prerequisites: P3 class standing.

Course: PMPR 358 — Pharmacotherapeutic Issues in Women's Health Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Team taught case-based pharmacotherapeutic lecture course related to women's health. Prerequisites: PHAR 508.

Course: PMPR 359 — Topics and Issues in Clinical Post-Graduate Training Programs Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Increases PharmD students' knowledge and professionalization about post-graduate training. Students will "shadow" residents or fellows during non-class times, overnight and weekends while the resident or fellow is on call. Prerequisites: PHAR 501 and PHAR 502 and second or third year Doctor of Pharmacy student on the Chicago campus in good academic standing. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Clinical Practice and one Lecture.

metadata.class_name: Topics and Issues in Clinical Post-Graduate Training Programs
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 360 — Clinical Aspects of Drug Interactions, Metabolism and Pharmacogenetics Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Clinical perspective in interpreting drug interaction/metabolism and pharmacogenetic data from the literature; application of the information in practice. Hands-on opportunities to manage drug interactions using real-life cases. Prerequisites: Third year standing in the Doctor of Pharmacy program or above; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Clinical Aspects of Drug Interactions, Metabolism and Pharmacogenetics
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 361 — Introduction to Public Health: Concepts and Applications in Pharmacy Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Introduces pharmacy students to major concepts in public health. Emphasizes an interdisciplinary team that focuses on the well being of the population.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Public Health: Concepts and Applications in Pharmacy
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 362 — Clinical Aspects of Diabetes Mellitus Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Discussion and project-based coursework covering more detailed information about diabetes mellitus for students interested in learning more about diabetes beyond the required Principles of Drug Action and Therapeutics course. Prerequisites: PHAR 502.

Course: PMPR 363 — Primary Care Clinical Nutrition Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Students will evaluate the clinical importance of nutritional intervention, and its practical applications for chronic disease prevention and management such as cancer, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and obesity.

Course: PMPR 368 — Media's Influence on Critical Care and Emergency Medicine Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Designed to engage pharmacy students in exploring media’s view, presentation, perception, and subsequent influence on the public’s understanding of critical care and emergency medicine. Prerequisites: PHAR 501 and PHAR 502 and PHAR 503 and PHAR 504 and PHAR 505 and PHAR 506 and completion of all core courses within the program's first year.

metadata.class_name: Media's Influence on Critical Care and Emergency Medicine
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 370 — Pharmacy Grand Rounds Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: A weekly series of contemporary topics on pharmacy practice will be presented. Prerequisites: Enrollment in the Doctor of Pharmacy program. Restricted to first year pharmacy students. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May not be repeated for credit. Mandatory attendance.

Course: PMPR 371 — Professional Development Seminar I Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: A weekly seminar series designed to draw select second year professional students together to discuss educational issues related to the second professional year. Prerequisites: Completion of the first year of the Doctor of Pharmacy program; Student must be listed as an advisee of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for PMPR 371 if the student has credit in BPS 381 or PMAD 381 or PMMP 381.

Course: PMPR 376 — Applied Research Methods and Skill Development Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Prepares students to be involved in basic, clinical, or quality improvement research. Students will develop a research protocol, create an abstract, and prepare a final research presentation.

metadata.class_name: Applied Research Methods and Skill Development
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 377 — Professional Development for Pharmacists Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Designed to develop the skills necessary for the professional development of future pharmacists: resume writing, interview preparation, written correspondence, and verbal presentation skills. Prerequisites: Enrollment in the Doctor of Pharmacy program.

Course: PMPR 378 — Pediatric Therapeutics Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Drug therapy of common pediatric disease states, emphasizing special pediatric considerations in the areas of infectious disease, psychiatry, hematology, neonatology. Prerequisites: Completion of the second year of the Doctor of Pharmacy Program.

Course: PMPR 379 — Advanced Psychiatric Pharmacotherapeutics Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: A synchronous, in-person course that focuses on psychiatric conditions through review of guidelines, literature, therapeutics, patient cases, and psychotropic counseling. The course will progress from faculty led to student led. Prerequisites: PHAR 507.

Course: PMPR 380 — Undergraduate Research in Pharmacy Practice Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Investigation, under the direction of one or more faculty members, of a problem of limited scope. May require literature research related to the research project. Prerequisites: Minimum cumulative grade point average of 2.50 and consent of the instructor, department head, and Associate Dean for Student Affairs. Course Information: May be repeated. A maximum of 6 hours of credit is allowed per department. A total of not more than 8 hours of 380 and 390 numbered courses in the college may be applied toward the 12 hours of PharmD professional electives.

Course: PMPR 381 — Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) - Interventions and Treatment Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Identification and treatment of patients with chronic kidney disease utilizing a multifactorial approach to attain goals set by Kidney Disease Outcome Quality Initiatives (KDOQI), Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO), ADA, ACC-AHA, and lipid guidelines. Prerequisites: PHAR 503.

metadata.class_name: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) - Interventions and Treatment
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 382 — Ethical Considerations in the Practice of Pharmacy Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Students will review ethical principles, identify ethical dilemmas, analyze case studies, and engage in role-playing. Individual and group written/oral presentations will be required. Prerequisites: PHAR 404.

metadata.class_name: Ethical Considerations in the Practice of Pharmacy
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 383 — Managed Care Pharmacy Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Covers fundamental concepts in managed care pharmacy and provide a basic understanding of how managed care pharmacy impacts the US health care system. Goal is to provide students with foundational knowledge that they can apply in career.

Course: PMPR 385 — Special Topics of Current Interest in Pharmacy Practice Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course offered by faculty or a visiting lecturer on a selected topic of current interest. Available on an experimental basis for two offerings only. Prerequisites: Good academic standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics of Current Interest in Pharmacy Practice
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 390 — Special Projects in Pharmacy Practice Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1-2 Description: Special projects within the departmental discipline. Defined and terminal project goals are achieved through independent study. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor, department head, and Associate Dean for Student Affairs. Course Information: May be repeated. A maximum of 4 hours of 390 credit is allowed in all departments. A total of not more than 8 hours of 380 and 390 numbered courses in the college may be applied toward the 12 hours of PharmD professional electives.

Course: PMPR 430 — Critical Care I Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Advanced pharmacotherapeutics course that will concentrate on the medical management and the pharmacotherapist's role in the management of the critically ill patient. This course will also incorporate and apply pharmacokinetic principles. Prerequisites: HAR 401 and PHAR 402 and PHAR 403 and PHAR 404 and PHAR 405 and PHAR 406; and PHAR 407 and PHAR 408; and completion of the second year of the program Beginning Spring 2019: Concurrent enrollment in PHAR 510.

Course: PMPR 436 — Strategic Business Planning Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 or 2 Description: Strategic business planning is crucial for establishing successful clinical practices or programs. Offers a comprehensive exploration of the essential components of developing a robust business plan tailored to clinical pharmacy. Prerequisites: Preferred second or third professional year Doctor of Pharmacy students.

Course: PMPR 440 — Applied Pharmacokinetics Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: An elective course demonstrating practical application of pharmacokinetic principles. Prerequisites: PHAR 401, PHAR 402, PHAR 403, PHAR 404, PHAR 405, and PHAR 406 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PMPR 340. Scientific calculator required.

Course: PMPR 442 — Introduction to Specialty Pharmacy Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Specialty pharmacy practice model and how it impacts access and management of drugs used to treat complex ans chronic disease. Prerequisites: P2 or P3 standing. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PMPR 443 — Advanced Specialty Pharmacy: Administration and Operations Management Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Advanced topics in specialty pharmacy operations management and will build off of the information learned from PMPR 442. Course Information: PMPR 442 and PHAR 565.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Specialty Pharmacy: Administration and Operations Management
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 445 — Interprofessional Approaches to Health Disparities (IAHD) I Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Designed to build upon the concepts of health disparities, social determinants of health, public health, Interprofessional education, quality improvement and community-based participatory research across the PharmD curriculum. Prerequisites: Successful completion of PharmD Curriculum through P2 year. Completion of competitive application packet for the course.

metadata.class_name: Interprofessional Approaches to Health Disparities (IAHD) I
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 446 — Interprofessional Approaches to Health Disparities (IAHD) II Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Equips learners with essential skills to improve health care for underserved populations and transform health disparities through interprofessional education, research and collaborative practice. Prerequisites: PMPR 445.

metadata.class_name: Interprofessional Approaches to Health Disparities (IAHD) II
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR)

text: Course: PMPR 450 — Medical writing Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Students will access weekly online modules that will cover the fundamentals of writing, editing, and publishing scientific medical information. Prerequisites: PHAR 440.

Course: PMPR 485 — Concentration Research Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Investigation, under the direction of one or more faculty members, of a problem of limited scope. May require literature research related to the research project. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours.

Course: PMPR 486 — Concentration Seminar Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 1 Description: Offered in conjunction with the PMPR 485 as a means for students to present and receive feedback on their concentration research projects. Prerequisites: PMPR 485.

Course: PMPR 487 — Clinical Research Design Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Students will practice essential research skills by completing several group projects, including analyzing published research, developing a clinical research idea into a research proposal, writing a letter of intent, and presenting their work.

Course: PMPR 488 — Pharmacy Practice Leadership Subject: Pharmacy Practice (PMPR) Credits: 2 Description: Provides basic concepts in pharmacy practice leadership and serve as a foundation for students interested in a career path in pharmacy management/leadership.

Course: POLS 101 — Introduction to American Government and Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to American political ideas, individual and group political behavior, institutions of national government, and public policy. Course Information: May be taught in blended learning format. Please check the online schedule of classes for blended sections. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to American Government and Politics
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 112 — Black Politics and Culture in the United States Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: The shifting relationship between black politics and black cultural forms across various historical periods. Course Information: Same as BLST 103. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Black Politics and Culture in the United States
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 120 — Introduction to Political Theory Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Competing accounts of the relationships among individuals, society, and the state. Analysis of differing conceptions of human nature through readings in ancient and modern classics. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: POLS 130 — Introduction to Comparative Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Comparative study of political institutions, political culture, and political processes in selected major countries of the world. Course Information: Same as INST 130. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the relevant semester to determine the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: POLS 184 — Introduction to International Relations Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Political, military, and economic relations between states, international organizations and transnational actors. Problems of war, imperialism and the world economy. Prospects for global cooperation. Course Information: Same as INST 184. Extensive computer use required. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the relevant semester to determine the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: POLS 200 — Methods of Political Science Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Methods of political science. Conducting primary research projects using the methods most frequently employed by political scientists.

Course: POLS 201 — Political Data Analysis Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to basic elements of statistics and data analysis for political science. Includes descriptive and inferential statistics; introduction to UIC computer facility and statistics software. Prerequisites: MATH 090; or MATH 105 ; or MATH 108 ; or consent of the instructor.

Course: POLS 202 — Topics in Political Practice Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics and issues in Political Science. Topics vary across the subfields of Political Science. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: POLS 203 — Popular Culture and Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Use of popular culture and its products in the analysis of contemporary political themes through the lens of political processes, state and legal institutions, political behavior, and the exercise of power. Topics may vary. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 204 — Democracy and Its Discontents Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the challenges past and present democracies face. Topics include democratic erosion, weak institutions, polarization, populism, corruption, and violence and democracy. Recommended Background: POLS 130.

Course: POLS 206 — Political Behavior Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to political behavior; includes the structure and functions of political attitudes, the role of personality, political socialization, electoral behavior, and related topics. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 207 — The Mass Media and Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Impact of mass media coverage on political attitudes and the conduct of American politics. Communication policies and media institutions in times of rapid technological change. Prerequisites: One course in political science, sociology or contemporary history. Course Information: Same as COMM 207. Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested.

Course: POLS 209 — Latinos and Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Latino politics and politicians in the context of the American political system. The political system, Latino participation, experience, and research on political processes. Course Information: Same as LALS 283. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. US Society course.

Course: POLS 210 — Introduction to Urban Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Growth and legal problems of cities: intergovernmental relations; powers and forms of government; pressure group activity; municipal functions and services; globalization and global cities; and revenue issues. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 211 — Chicago's Future Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasis on the political and governmental future of Chicago. Covers racial and ethnic politics; metropolitan, city, and neighborhood government; machine versus reform politics; and Chicago as a global city. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 212 — State Government Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Organization and powers of state governments in the U.S.; constitutions and problems of revision; the major institutions and their interrelationships, intergovernmental relations. Recommended Background: POLS 101.
Course: POLS 220 — Mock Trial I Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to the concept of mock trial. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.
Course: POLS 221 — Mock Trial II Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Participation in mock trials. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

Course: POLS 225 — Lobbying, Advocacy, and Social Movements Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: The logic and power of collective action in democracies. Modes of state-societal relations: competition among societal actors or guided coordination between the state and societal actors. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 226 — Political Parties in Modern Democracies Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Organization, role, and function of political parties in democratic settings. Types of party systems and ideological families. Link between elections and party systems. Opportunities for reform of parties and party systems. Recommended Background: POLS 101 or POLS 130 or INST 130.

Course: POLS 227 — Voting Behavior and Elections Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of elections, voting behavior, election law, and voting theories and influences. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 228 — U.S. Congress Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the structures and processes of Congressional politics. Emphasis on elections, organization, interinstitutional relations and authorizations and appropriations processes. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 229 — Executive Powers and the United States Presidency Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of such phenomena as presidential elections; the presidency and the Constitution; the presidency and public administration; the president as policy-maker; presidential leadership. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

metadata.class_name: Executive Powers and the United States Presidency
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 231 — Politics and Society of China Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Main issues of contemporary Chinese politics and social change; the decline of the last imperial dynasty; the republican era; the rise of communism and China under the rule of Mao Zedong; and the reform period (post-1978). Course Information: Same as GLAS 231 and HIST 231. Recommended Background: POLS 130 or INST 130. World Cultures course.

Course: POLS 232 — Politics in Korea Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Sources, dynamics, and patterns of politics in the two Koreas. Comparison of North and South Korea. Prerequisites: POLS 130 ; or consent of the instructor. World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 232.

Course: POLS 234 — Politics and Government of Western Europe Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Comparison of government and politics of major Western European countries. Topics include political culture, political parties, elections, legislatures, executive arrangements, and the European Union. Recommended Background: POLS 130 or INST 130.

metadata.class_name: Politics and Government of Western Europe
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 236 — Politics and Government of Eastern Europe Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Similarities and differences of the political system of eastern European states and the sources and meaning of political change. Recommended Background: POLS 130 or INST 130.

metadata.class_name: Politics and Government of Eastern Europe
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 242 — Government and Politics of Latin America Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: An examination of government and politics in selected Latin American countries. Comparative and historical analysis of dictatorship, democracies, political institutions, and parties. Course Information: Same as LALS 242.

metadata.class_name: Government and Politics of Latin America
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 243 — Politics and Government of the Middle East Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Contemporary Middle East political institutions, culture, processes, and conflicts. Emphasis on interaction of traditional and modern forces, such as Islam, nationalism, political elites, ideologies, states. Course Information: Same as JST 243. Recommended Background: POLS 130 or INST 130. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Politics and Government of the Middle East
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 246 — History of American Capitalism Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the political, economic, cultural, and social history of capitalism in colonial British America and the United States, with special attention to property, labor, finance, public policy, ideology, and class relations. Prerequisites: ENGL 161 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 246. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: POLS 258 — The Judicial Process Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Dispute settlement and policy making in state and federal court systems; judicial decision making and the impact of decisions on the polity. Course Information: Some sections may be offered fully online or in a blended-online and classroom course setting. Consult the Schedule of Classes for the relevant semester to determine the mode of instruction. Use of computer and internet access is required for all online and blended sections. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 259 — Constitutional Conversations: Contemporary Debates in American Constitutional Law and Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of contemporary debates about the US Constitution, regarding foundational doctrines: limited government, republicanism, checks and balances, federalism, separation of powers, popular sovereignty, individual liberty, and equal protection. Prerequisites: POLS 101 ; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Constitutional Conversations: Contemporary Debates in American Constitutional Law and Politics
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 267 — American Intellectual History to 1865 Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Major issues in American intellectual history from the contacts of culture begun by European exploration on the land now known as the United States to the end of the American Civil War in 1865. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as HIST 267. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: POLS 268 — American Intellectual History since 1865 Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Major issues in American intellectual history and the history of ideas from the end of the Civil War to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as HIST 268. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: POLS 274 — The Politics of Blackness in Latin America Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines race, culture, and politics in Latin America from historical and contemporary perspectives with a particular emphasis on the latter half of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century. Course Information: Same as BLST 274 and LALS 274. Recommended Background: Three credit hours in BLST or LALS or POLS.

metadata.class_name: The Politics of Blackness in Latin America
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 275 — Gender in Latin America Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Latin American women in historical perspective from pre-Columbian and Iberian societies to the present. Course Information: Same as GWS 275 and LALS 275. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: POLS 281 — United States Foreign Policy Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Internal and external factors that influence formulation and execution of U.S. foreign policy. Major problems of contemporary foreign policy: constitutional, organizational, and intellectual factors. Recommended Background: POLS 101.

Course: POLS 282 — Simulation on Political Organizations Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical and practical approaches, preparing students for inter-collegiate competitions, role-playing delegates in state, national, international, or legal organizations. Topics vary and include Model United Nations, Model European Union. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours with approval of the department.

Course: POLS 283 — International Political Economy Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Political underpinnings and ramifications of international economic relations. Foreign trade policy, multinational corporations, oil North-South relations, economic warfare. Course Information: Same as INST 283. Recommended Background: POLS 184 or INST 184.

Course: POLS 284 — International Security Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: International conflict and cooperation, including war, nationalism, global inequality, and the environment. Prerequisites: POLS 184 or INST 184 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as INST 284.

Course: POLS 286 — The United Nations and Other International Organizations Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: The development, structure, functioning, and impact of the United Nations and other international organizations. An assessment of their contributions and limitations. Recommended Background: POLS 184 or INST 184.

metadata.class_name: The United Nations and Other International Organizations
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 287 — International Law Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: The nature, scope, and limits of international law in the contemporary world. Examines three dimensions of international law: doctrine, practice, and jurisprudence (case-law). Recommended Background: POLS 184 or INST 184.

Course: POLS 290 — History of Political Thought I Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Western political theorists from ancient Greece and Rome through the end of the classical era, including Thucydides, Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, and Augustine. Course Information: Same as CL 290. Recommended Background: POLS 120.

Course: POLS 291 — History of Political Thought II Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Western political theorists from the seventeenth century through modern times, including Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Marx, Mill and Nietzsche. Recommended Background: POLS 120.

Course: POLS 295 — Introduction to Marxism Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination and evaluation of the basic theories of Marx and Engels to determine their contribution to the understanding of contemporary politics.

Course: POLS 296 — Fascism and Dictatorship in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Establishment of fascist and authoritarian regimes in 20th-century Spain, Italy and Greece. Fascist ideology, leadership cult, mass politics, violence and propaganda, uses of antiquity, resistance and consent, legacy and memory of fascism. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Past course. Course Information: Same as HIST 296 and GKM 296. Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Fascism and Dictatorship in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 297 — American Political Theories Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: American political theorists from the colonial period to the present, including Paine, Madison, Hamilton, Thoreau, Calhoun, Sumner, DuBois, and Dewey. Recommended Background: POLS 120.

Course: POLS 300 — Advanced Topics in Political Science Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected problems in politics. Course content and format will vary to adapt to the changing political scene. Prerequisites: Junior or senior standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: POLS 301 — Internship in Political Science Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 6 Description: Provides students an opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge in “real life” political settings through an internship at governmental agencies, political parties, interest groups, civic associations, international agencies, or law offices. Prerequisites: Junior or senior standing; at least 12 credit hours in political science, including courses relevant to field experience; GPA of 3.00 in political science; and consent of instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: POLS 302 — Great Cities Internship Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 6 Description: Provides students an opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge and conduct research in metropolitan organizations through field placements and seminars. Prerequisites: Junior or senior standing and grade point average of 3.00, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as UPP 302. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: POLS 303 — Supervised Readings and Research Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Supervised readings and research in political science. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: POLS 305 — Honors Course Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3-6 Description: Independent reading and research for students seeking departmental distinction. Prerequisites: Open only to seniors. Requires approval of the department, a 3.25 University grade point average, and a 3.50 political science grade point average. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: POLS 307 — Political Psychology Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of mass and elite political behavior from the perspectives of several psychological approaches including psychoanalytic, behavioral, humanistic and social psychology theories. Prerequisites: One course in political science, psychology, or sociology.

Course: POLS 309 — Topics in Political Behavior Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Intensive analysis of topics in political behavior. Possible topics include: elections and campaigns, political culture. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Recommended Background: POLS 206.

Course: POLS 310 — Governing the Megalopolis Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of political/governmental issues in massive metropolitan areas, utilizing the six-county greater Chicago area for example. Prerequisites: POLS 101 or POLS 200 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor.

Course: POLS 311 — Black Politics in the United States Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Historical analysis of Black electoral politics in the U.S., including traditional political party participation and movement politics. Prerequisites: Three courses in political science, history or sociology, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 306.

metadata.class_name: Black Politics in the United States
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 312 — Topics in Local Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Intensive examination of selected problems of local politics. Actual research involvement. Topics vary. Prerequisites: POLS 101 and POLS 210.

Course: POLS 329 — Seminar on American Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced seminar on special topics in American politics. Content varies. Prerequisites: POLS 101 and POLS 200 ; or consent of the instructor. Students seeking to register with instructor approval should contact the academic advisor for Political Science, in addition to securing permission to enroll from the course instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: POLS 342 — European Union: Politics and Institutions Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of the historical development of the European Union, with a focus on the functioning of its political institutions and policy-making process. Recommended Background: POLS 130 or INST 130.

Course: POLS 348 — Seminar: Political Problems of Developing Societies Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected aspects of the politics and countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America. Prerequisites: POLS 200 and POLS 130 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LALS 348.

metadata.class_name: Seminar: Political Problems of Developing Societies
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 349 — Topics in Comparative Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected problems in comparative politics. Prerequisites: POLS 130 or INST 130 ; and POLS 200 ; or consent of the instructor. Students seeking to register with instructor approval should contact the academic advisor for Political Science, in addition to securing permission to enroll from the course instructor. Course Information: Same as INST 349. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

Course: POLS 353 — Constitutional Law Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected constitutional provisions and principles as they developed through Supreme Court interpretation. Major attention given to powers and practices of, and interactions among governmental institutions. Prerequisites: POLS 101 or consent of the instructor.

Course: POLS 354 — The Constitution and Civil Liberties Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Civil rights, including religion, speech, assembly, press, and rights of the accused. Prerequisites: POLS 101 or consent of the instructor.

Course: POLS 356 — Constitutional Law: Women, Gender and Privacy Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: A multidisciplinary examination of U.S. constitutional law and politics in shaping issues of gender, privacy, race, and sexual orientation; including reproduction, labor, sexual harassment, political participation, and women and crime. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in POLS 101 or grade of C or better in POLS 112 or grade of C or better in BLST 100 or grade of C or better in BLST 103 or grade of C or better in GWS 101 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 356 , and GWS 356.

metadata.class_name: Constitutional Law: Women, Gender and Privacy
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 358 — Constitutional Law: African-American Legal History Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of the African-American constitutional experience from the 1600s to the present, focusing on landmark decisions of the United States Supreme Court. Course Information: Same as BLST 358.

Course: POLS 359 — Topics in Public Law Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected problems arising in public law and judicial arenas. Prerequisites: POLS 258 or POLS 353 or POLS 354 or POLS 356 or POLS 358 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

Course: POLS 384 — International Relations Theory Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical foundations of international relations, including assumptions of anarchy, rationality, power and the state. Applications to security and political economy. Prerequisites: POLS 283 or POLS 284 or consent of the instructor.

Course: POLS 389 — Seminar: Topics in International Relations Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in international relations. Topics may vary and may cover global military, economic, cultural, ecological or methodological issues. Prerequisites: POLS 184 or INST 184 ; and POLS 200 ; or consent of the instructor. Students seeking to register with instructor approval should contact the academic advisor for Political Science, in addition to securing permission to enroll from the course instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

Course: POLS 399 — Seminar in Political Theory Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics and problems in political theory. Prerequisites: POLS 120 and POLS 200 ; or consent of the instructor. Students seeking to register with instructor approval should contact the academic advisor for Political Science, in addition to securing permission to enroll from the course instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: POLS 401 — Data Analysis I Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Statistical inference for the social sciences. Emphasis on univariate and bivariate statistics. Prerequisites: POLS 200 and POLS 201 ; or graduate standing. Course Information: Same as PPA 401. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: POLS 402 — Political Science Data Collection, Wrangling and Visualization Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Collecting original data using tools typical for Political Science, including web scrapping, data from APIs, Qualtrics, and content analysis of documents. Cleaning data using Excel and R. Wrangling and transforming data. Data visualization. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in POLS 200 and Grade of B or better in POLS 201 ; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Undergraduate students seeking to enroll in this course should have experience with data entry. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Political Science Data Collection, Wrangling and Visualization
metadata.subject: Political Science (POLS)

text: Course: POLS 405 — The Problem of Justice Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Pre-modern, modern and non-western views of justice and their practical utility in analyzing legislative, executive, and judicial programs for enhancing or restricting justice. Prerequisites: CLJ 101 , plus two 200-level courses in CLJ or two 200-level courses in POLS. Course Information: Same as CLJ 405. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: POLS 451 — Law and Public Policy Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The role of law and legal institutions in the development and implementation of public policies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: POLS 459 — Advanced Topics in Urban Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Seminar exploring urban politics theory through readings, discussion, and original research. Prerequisites: POLS 210 ; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: POLS 465 — Topics in Sociology of Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive examination of a specialized topic announced when the class is scheduled. Prerequisites: 6 hours of upper-division sociology or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as SOC 465. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: POLS 466 — Criminal Governance in Latin America Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Emergence of criminal politics in Latin America. Engagement of politicians, organized crime actors, and state agents in the pursuit goals (economic, political, personal). Root sources, logic and consequences of this new, prevalent order. Course Information: Same as LALS 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: POLS 467 — Public Opinion and Political Communication Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Nature of public opinion and political communication systems. Patterns of opinion distribution and its measurement. Forces shaping public opinion and its impact on public policy. Prerequisites: POLS 200 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as COMM 467. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: POLS 469 — Advanced Topics in American Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Seminar exploring American politics theory through readings, discussion, and original research. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in POLS 101 and Grade of B or better in POLS 329 ; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: POLS 478 — Advanced Topics in International Relations Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Seminar exploring international relations theory through readings, discussion, and original research. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in POLS 184 ; and Grade of B or better in POLS 281 or Grade of B or better in POLS 283 or Grade of B or better in POLS 284 ; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: POLS 479 — Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Seminar exploring comparative politics theory through readings, discussion, and original research. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in POLS 130 and Grade of B or better in POLS 349 ; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: POLS 482 — Theories of Democracy and Representation Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Democracy as a procedure of government and value commitments associated with this form of government. Special attention paid to classical and modern democracies. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: POLS 485 — Gender and Politics Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Impact of gender on basic categories of western political thought. Distinctions between reason and emotion, public and private, among others, examined from feminist perspective. Prerequisites: One 200-level course in political theory; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 485. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: POLS 489 — Advanced Topics in Political Theory Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Seminar exploring political theory through reading, discussion, and original research. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in POLS 290 or Grade of B or better in POLS 291 ; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: POLS 494 — Topics in Political Science Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected Topics in Political Science. Topics vary and may cover American politics, law, urban and global politics, cultural, ecological or methodological issues. Prerequisites: POLS 200 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated up to 1 time(s).

Course: POLS 497 — Directed Readings in Political Science Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 4 Description: Intensive readings on a topic not covered in regular curriculum. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated with approval. Approval of the graduate director required to repeat course.

Course: POLS 498 — Independent Research in Political Science Subject: Political Science (POLS) Credits: 2-6 Description: Research on special problems not included in course offerings. May not duplicate work done in POLS 598 or POLS 599. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated with approval. Approval of the graduate director required to repeat course.

Course: PORT 201 — Portuguese Blended: Brazilian Popular Culture I Subject: Portuguese (PORT) Credits: 4 Description: Third-semester Portuguese language course that focuses on Brazilian popular culture. This is a hybrid course that combines online and face-to-face activities. Prerequisites: PORT 240 ; and sophomore standing or above; or approval of the department. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Two semesters of basic Portuguese.

metadata.class_name: Portuguese Blended: Brazilian Popular Culture I
metadata.subject: Portuguese (PORT)

text: Course: PORT 240 — Rapid Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers Subject: Portuguese (PORT) Credits: 4 Description: Characteristics of Portuguese grammar from the perspective of Romance Language Speakers, with a linguistic communicative approach to develop the ability of students to understand, speak, read and write in intermediate to advanced level Portuguese. Prerequisites: SPAN 202 or ITAL 201 or FR 232; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: This is a blended-online course and classroom course. Use of computer and internet access is required. A high speed connection is strongly suggested.

metadata.class_name: Rapid Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
metadata.subject: Portuguese (PORT)

text: Course: PPOL 100 — Individual Action and Democratic Citizenship Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Seeks to enhance understanding of the role of the individual as democratic citizen in shaping policy issues and outcomes in today’s world. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 100. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Individual and Society course.

Course: PPOL 101 — Contemporary Issues in Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Examines contemporary policy issues and provides students with the tools to identify and analyze information on the past and current policy making and the role of individual and institutional factors in the policy making process. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: PPOL 105 — Programming and Data Analysis for Public Policy I Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to key programming skills in Excel and R for data management, data visualization, and descriptive statistical analysis for policy making.

metadata.class_name: Programming and Data Analysis for Public Policy I
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 196 — Special Topics: Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Special topics in public policy such as: nonprofit management, racial equity analysis in public administration, deliberative democracy and civic analytics.

Course: PPOL 205 — Programming and Data Analysis for Public Policy II Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students with the data, programming, and inferential statistical skills needed to inform basic policy and management decision making. Prerequisites: PPOL 105. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Programming and Data Analysis for Public Policy II
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 210 — Introduction to Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to public policy and the policy-making process. Course Information: Previously listed PA 210. US Society course.

Course: PPOL 212 — Evidence-Based Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Discusses the role of evidence in the policy process in various policy domains such as health, fiscal, educational, and environmental. It covers different types of evidence, including experimental, statistical, and qualitative evidence. US Society course.

Course: PPOL 220 — Introduction to Civic Technology Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to smart cities, open data, government transparency, ethics, hacktivism, digital inclusion, civic innovation, and data-driven decision making. US Society course.

Course: PPOL 230 — Nonprofit Organizations and Civil Society Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the US nonprofit sector and examines the social, political, and economic impact of these organizations in American society from roughly 1870 to today. Historical emphasis on events that have shaped the modern American nonprofit sector. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 230. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: PPOL 231 — Social Policy and Inequality in the U.S Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a basic introduction to social policy and inequality in the United States, examines the history of social welfare policies and programs in the US, and explores American cultural values and attitudes. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 231. US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Social Policy and Inequality in the U.S
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 232 — International Development Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Provides a basic introduction to globalization and international development, and how public policy can shape and address them. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 232. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: PPOL 240 — Environmental Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction to political, economic and social dimensions of environmental policy and teaches methods needed to understand, evaluate, design and implement environment policies, especially in the United States. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 240. US Society course.

Course: PPOL 296 — Special Topics in Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Special topics in public policy such as: nonprofit management, racial equity analysis in public administration, deliberative democracy and civic analytics.

Course: PPOL 300 — Urban Policy and Metropolitan Governance Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Basic structure of the policy process within the urban context including the nature of urban policy, its formulation, evaluation, and implementation. Emphasis on state and local policy development as it relates to urban areas. Prerequisites: Admission to the BA in Public Policy or Urban Studies and college-level Microeconomics; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 300. Field work required.

Course: PPOL 303 — Policy Implementation and Management Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Policy implementation, management, organizing, budgeting, finance, leadership, motivation, economic development, accountability, ethics, legal and constitutional foundations. Prerequisites: PPOL 210 and admission to the BA in Public Policy or Urban Studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 303.

Course: PPOL 305 — Policy Analysis Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Policy analysis and approaches to assessing policy problems and alternatives in the U.S. context. Prerequisites: PPOL 210 and admission to the BA in Public Policy or Urban Studies or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 305.

Course: PPOL 307 — Policy Analysis III: Identifying and Developing Alternatives Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Policy analysis and approaches to assessing policy problems and alternatives in the U.S. context. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ENGL 161 ; and PPOL 210. Course Information: Previously listed as PPOL 211.

metadata.class_name: Policy Analysis III: Identifying and Developing Alternatives
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 309 — Public Budgeting and Financial Management Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Government budgeting, financial, management and the reciprocal relationship between government and the economy. Prerequisites: PPOL 210 and admission to the BA in Public Policy or Urban Studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as US 309. Previously listed as PA 309.

Course: PPOL 330 — Introduction to Managing Public and Nonprofit Organizations Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction to managing public organizations and the public aspects of nonprofit organizations. Examines the context of public and nonprofit management and consider ways to evaluate and understand organizations. Prerequisites: PPOL 230.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Managing Public and Nonprofit Organizations
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 396 — Special Topics in Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Special topics in public policy such as: nonprofit management, racial equity analysis in public administration, deliberative democracy and civic analytics. Recommended Background: PPOL 100 and PPOL 210.

Course: PPOL 405 — Evaluating Public Policies and Programs Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Designed to introduce students to research methods used in the social sciences to evaluate public programs. There is an overview of evaluation, understanding why we do evaluations and theories impacting evaluations and research design. Prerequisites: PPOL 205. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as PA 405.

Course: PPOL 430 — Fundraising and Development for Nonprofit Organizations Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Designed to help students learn why and how US nonprofit organizations secure philanthropy through charitable giving. Students will be exposed to knowledge, strategies, best practice principles and scholarly research. Prerequisites: PPOL 230. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Fundraising and Development for Nonprofit Organizations
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 467 — Civic Engagement Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Analytic frameworks and practical strategies for utilizing public participation in government and community decisions. Investigates interactions between civic participation, efforts to improve administration of programs and develop new public policies. Prerequisites: Admission to the MPA program or consent of instructor. Course Information: Same as PA 467. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours.

Course: PPOL 490 — Field Experience in Public Policy and Administration Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 4 Description: Students work in an organization such as a government agency, community group, or nonprofit organization. Students are required to submit written work and meet with professor on periodic basis to review work experience. Prerequisites: Graduate standing required and admission to the MPA program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PA 490. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. A maximum of 4 hours of credit may be applied to the Master of Public Administration program. Field work required. Students who have no prior work experience in the public or non-profit sectors are strongly recommended to register for this course.

metadata.class_name: Field Experience in Public Policy and Administration
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 491 — Internship Experience in Public Policy and Urban Studies Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 Description: Students are required to do practical experience through an internship or job placement approved by the College of Urban Planning and Public Affairs. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as US 491. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Previously listed as UPA 491. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Internship Experience in Public Policy and Urban Studies
metadata.subject: Public Policy (PPOL)

text: Course: PPOL 496 — Special Topics in Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Special topics in public policy, such as: nonprofit management, racial equity analysis in public administration, deliberative democracy and civic analytics. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: PPOL 100 ; and PPOL 210.

Course: PPOL 499 — Independent Study in Public Policy Subject: Public Policy (PPOL) Credits: 1-3 Description: Provides an opportunity for students to pursue an independent project that is not available through the required Public Policy coursework. Prerequisites: Admission to the BA in Public Policy program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PA 499. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: PSCH 100 — Introduction to Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 4 Description: Survey of basic concepts of contemporary psychology. Introduction to the nervous system, perception, motivation, learning and memory, social behavior, personality, developmental and clinical psychology. Course Information: Students under 18 years of age need parental consent to participate in research experiments that are part of the course. Instructions for obtaining parental consent will be provided during class early in the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course.

Course: PSCH 184 — The Basics of Neuroscience Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 1 Description: Introduction to the scientific study of the brain and behavior. Overview of neuroscience as an integrative discipline. Course Information: Same as PHIL 184 and BIOS 184. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

Course: PSCH 210 — Theories of Personality Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major theoretical approaches to the study of personality and the evidential basis underlying each approach. Prerequisites: PSCH 100. Individual and Society course.

Course: PSCH 231 — Community Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Psychological principles, research and interventions concerning community settings; community human services, primary prevention, consultation, advocacy, social ecology, organizational change, and citizen participation. Prerequisites: PSCH 100. Individual and Society course.

Course: PSCH 242 — Introduction to Research in Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques and problems associated with the study of behavior. Emphasis on measurement, descriptive statistics, and the principles of experimental design. Exercises involving data collection. Participation in research. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 100. Course Information: Consult the class schedule for details on method of instruction for this course. Course taught in an online or hybrid format involves heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PSCH 262 — Behavioral Neuroscience Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Research and theories concerning the physiological bases of behavior. Understanding of basic brain organization with emphasis on neural substrates of learning, motivation and perception. Prerequisites: PSCH 100.

Course: PSCH 270 — Introduction to Psychological and Behavioral Disorders Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: A survey course covering the assessment, description, causes, and treatments of many psychological disorders, including depression, anxiety disorders, psychosis, sexual dysfunction, and personality disorders. Prerequisites: PSCH 100. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Psychological and Behavioral Disorders
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 271 — Resilience: The Psychology of Positive Adaptation Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of resilience research, definitions, correlates, and causes of successful adaptation in response to stress and adversity. Application on scientifically-validated strategies for improving coping skills and mental health. Prerequisites: PSCH 100. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Resilience: The Psychology of Positive Adaptation
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 272 — Psychology of Climate Change Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Research and theories concerning human behavioral causes of climate change and evidence-based approaches toward addressing mental health impacts. Emphasis on strategies for individual and systemic behavior change. Prerequisites: PSCH 100.

Course: PSCH 303 — Writing in Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Teaches students the fundamentals of scientific writing including literature reviews, research reports and book reviews. Students will write a minimum of three papers dealing with psychological topics. Prerequisites: PSCH 242 and ENGL 161 with a minimum grade of C; MATH 108 or MATH 118 (or the equivalent) with a minimum grade of C or MATH 090; or consent of the instructor. For psychology majors only. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PSCH 312 — Social Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of theory and research in social psychology, emphasizing experimental investigations of attitudes and social cognition, and interpersonal relations and group processes. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 313 — Laboratory in Social Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Conduct laboratory and field experiments in social psychology on problems in attitudes and social cognition, and interpersonal relations and group processes. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 312. For Psychology majors only. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 312 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 312 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must be enrolled in one Lecture/Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 312 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 312

Course: PSCH 315 — Psychology of Women and Gender Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Critical examination of research on women and gender across the life span, including psychological aspects of reproduction, and the way that gender shapes cognition, sexuality, family, friendship, and work experiences. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 315.

Course: PSCH 320 — Developmental Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of research and theory concerning social, cognitive, and biopsychological aspects of human development. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 321 — Laboratory in Developmental Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of dominant research strategies in contemporary developmental psychology. Laboratory experience in developmental research. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 320. For Psychology majors only. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 320 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 320 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture/Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 320 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 320

Course: PSCH 324 — Cultural Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of theory, methods, and research in culture and psychology. Examination of how culture is defined and studied and how it affects development, socialization, personality, interpersonal relations, and mental health. Prerequisites: PSCH 100 and Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 331 — Laboratory in Community and Prevention Research Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Examines how researchers conceptualize, design, implement, and evaluate school and community programs to enhance competence, promote empowerment, and prevent behavioral problems. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 231. For Psychology majors only. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 231 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 231 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture/Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 231 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 231

metadata.class_name: Laboratory in Community and Prevention Research
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 333 — Laboratory in Clinical Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Laboratory practicum in self-change processes, empirically validated treatments, experimental psychopathology, and clinical assessment development. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 210 or PSCH 270. For Psychology majors only. Class Schedule: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 210 or PSCH 270 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 210 or PSCH 270 Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 210, PSCH 270 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 210, PSCH 270

Course: PSCH 340 — Psychological Testing Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to principles of psychological assessment, with an overview of representative techniques. Particular emphasis is placed on objective tests. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 343 — Statistical Methods in Behavioral Science Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to statistical inference, probability distributions, sampling, hypothesis testing, correlation and analysis of variance. Prerequisites: PSCH 242 and ENGL 161 with a minimum grade of C; MATH 105 or MATH 108 (or the equivalent) with a minimum grade of C or satisfactory completion of Math 090. For psychology majors or students in the Neuroscience degree program only. Course Information: Credit is not given for PSCH 343 if the student has credit for IDS 371. Consult the class schedule for details on method of instruction for this course. Course taught in an online or hybrid format involves heavy computer usage; computer and internet access are required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PSCH 350 — Sensation and Perception Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of theories and empirical findings in the study of sensation and perception. Emphasis on human vision and audition as information processing systems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 351 — Laboratory in Perception Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Laboratory practicum in sensation and perception. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 350. For psychology majors or students in the neuroscience degree program only. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 350 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 350 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 350 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 350

Course: PSCH 352 — Cognition and Memory Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of experimental findings in human learning, memory, attention, knowledge representation, problem solving, conceptual behavior, and psycholinguistics. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 353 — Laboratory in Cognition and Memory Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Laboratory practicum in memory, psycholinguistics, problem solving, and reasoning. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 ; and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 352 or credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 320. For psychology majors or students in the neuroscience degree program only. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 352 or credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 320 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 352 or credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 320 Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture/Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 352, PSCH 320 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 352, PSCH 320

Course: PSCH 354 — Knowledge Acquisition Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to belief formation, conceptual change, cognitive development, discovery and invention, schema abstraction, skill acquisition and other cognitive change processes. Research and practical applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 360 — Learning and Conditioning Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Principles of learning; emphasis on parameters of acquisition, extinction and retention of classical and instrumental conditioning and stimulus control of reflexive and voluntary behavior. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 361 — Laboratory in Learning and Conditioning Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Laboratory practicum in conditioning and simple learning using animal subjects. Emphasis on operant conditioning. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 360. For psychology majors or students in the neuroscience degree program only. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 360 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 360 Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture/Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 360 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 360

Course: PSCH 363 — Laboratory in Behavioral Neuroscience Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Laboratory practicum and demonstrations of research techniques used to study the physiological bases of behavior. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 262 or BIOS 286. For psychology majors or students in the neuroscience degree program only. Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 262 or BIOS 286 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 262 or BIOS 286 Course Information: Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lacture/Discussion and one Laboratory. Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 262, BIOS 286 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 262, BIOS 286

Course: PSCH 366 — Cognitive Neuroscience Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of neural basis of cognitive processes; perceptual and motor systems, attention, memory, symbolic representation, executive control of behavior. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 367 — Laboratory in Cognitive Neuroscience Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Laboratory practicum in attention, memory, decision-making and symbolic cognitive processes. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 350 or PSCH 366. For psychology majors or students in the neuroscience degree program only. Class Schedule: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory.
