Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 350 or PSCH 366 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PSCH 350 or PSCH 366 Prereq Codes (parsed): PSCH 350, PSCH 366 Coreq Codes (parsed): PSCH 350, PSCH 366

Course: PSCH 380 — Positive Psychology: The Science of Well-Being Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to the study of topics related to happiness and the positive aspects human experience and overall well-being. Basic areas of research in positive psychology and the methods that researchers use to study happiness. Prerequisites: PSCH 210 or PSCH 231 or PSCH 312 ; and Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

metadata.class_name: Positive Psychology: The Science of Well-Being
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 381 — Psychology of Interviewing Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: The goals of the course are to teach theory, research and practice of interviewing. Students will develop skills for interviewing individuals. Prerequisites: PSCH 210 or PSCH 231 or PSCH 270 or PSCH 271 or PSCH 312 ; and Grade of C or better in PSCH 242. For psychology majors only.

Course: PSCH 382 — Psychological Interventions Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Application of psychological theories and principles used in psychotherapy and behavior change. Emphasis will be on models for assessment of change, the evaluation of psychotherapy, and selecting appropriate interventions. Prerequisites: PSCH 210 or PSCH 231 or PSCH 312 ; and PSCH 270 and a grade of C or better in PSCH 242. For Psychology majors only.

Course: PSCH 384 — Psychology of Groups Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Application of psychological theory and research to group functioning and change. Survey of intervention methods emphasizing the development of competence in group participation and leadership. Prerequisites: PSCH 210 or PSCH 231 or PSCH 312 ; and Grade of C or better in PSCH 242.

Course: PSCH 385 — Field Work in Applied Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 6 Description: Supervised practicum as a paraprofessional worker for a minimum equivalent of one day (8 hours) per week in a mental health, developmental disabilities, or industrial organizational setting. Prerequisites: PSCH 340 and PSCH 343 ; and PSCH 380 or PSCH 381 or PSCH 382 or PSCH 384. For applied psychology majors only. Course Information: 6 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Practice.

Course: PSCH 386 — Crisis Counseling Techniques I Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Application of psychological theories and principles used for telephone crisis counseling, crisis intervention, and referral. Emphasis will be on models for interviewing and assessment and appropriate intervention in crisis situations. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242 ; and PSCH 210 or PSCH 231 or PSCH 270 ; and consent of the instructor.

Course: PSCH 387 — Crisis Counseling Techniques II Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 1 Description: Students will apply skills learned in PSCH 386 as they run weekly support groups providing both peer-to-peer counseling per week in a group format as well as individual peer-to-peer crisis counseling with group members. Prerequisites: PSCH 386 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Field work required.

Course: PSCH 394 — Special Topics in Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Lectures devoted to an announced topic. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSCH 242. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: PSCH 396 — Directed Research Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Participation in ongoing research in psychology under the direction of a faculty member. A final report describing the research and its theory is required. Prerequisites: PSCH 242 and consent of the instructor. Must consult intructor for permission to enroll. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. A combined maximum of 8 hours of credit in PSCH 387 , PSCH 396 , PSCH 397 , and PSCH 399 may be applied toward the degree. Either PSCH 396 or an additional laboratory course is required for High Distinction in Psychology.

Course: PSCH 397 — Readings in Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Bibliographic research on a special topic under the direction of a faculty member. Paper is required for course credit. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 and consent of the instructor. Must consult instructor for permission to enroll. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. A combined maximum of 8 hours of credit in PSCH 387 , PSCH 396 , PSCH 397 , and PSCH 399 may be applied toward the degree.

Course: PSCH 399 — Independent Research Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual research on a special topic under the direction of a faculty member. A paper is required for course credit. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 ; and consent of the instructor and the director of undergraduate studies. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. A combined maximum of 8 hours of credit in PSCH 387 , PSCH 396 , PSCH 397 , and PSCH 399 may be applied toward the degree. Required for earning Highest Distinction in Psychology.

Course: PSCH 411 — The Psychology of Racism Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Within our country’s context of racism, you might ask yourself: What is my role in resisting racism? How might I (as a Person of Color) heal from racism and work in solidarity with other People of Color to dismantle White supremacy? Prerequisites: PSCH 242 , graduate standing, or consent of Instructor.

Course: PSCH 415 — Social Bases of Health Behavior Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Psychological theory and research concerning the coronary-prone personality, pain management, controlling adherence to medical regimens, biofeedback, smoking, and weight control. Prerequisites: PSCH 270 and consent of the instructor, or graduate standing.

Course: PSCH 417 — Psychology and Law Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Application of psychological theories to the development, operation and effects of law; evaluation of different and similar approaches of law and psychology. Prerequisites: PSCH 312 or consent of instructor.

Course: PSCH 420 — Advanced Social Development of Children in an Urban Context Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines some general principles of children’s (3 -14 years old) social development and socialization and the applicability of these principles for urban-dwelling children. Course Information: Same as EPSY 420. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Social Development of Children in an Urban Context
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 422 — Advanced Developmental Psychology and Educational Processes Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on cognitive and social development from birth to early adolescence. Examines relations between development, learning, and educational processes. Prerequisites: PSCH 100 and any one from EPSY 210 , PSCH 259, PSCH 320 and consent of the instructor; or graduate standing. Course Information: Same as ED 422.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Developmental Psychology and Educational Processes
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 423 — Characteristics of Early Adolescence Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Physiological, social, emotional and cognitive development of early adolescence. The relationship between these developmental characteristics and success in the middle grades. Prerequisites: Admission to a program in psychology or education; or approval of the College of Education or consent of the instructor, EPSY 210 or EPSY 255 or ED 421 or ED 422. Course Information: Same as EPSY 446.

Course: PSCH 424 — Social and Emotional Learning: Research, Practice, and Policy Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Research, theory, educational practices, and federal/state policies that promote the social, emotional, and academic competence of students who are in preschool, middle school, or high school. Prerequisites: PSCH 343 or equivalent; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ED 424. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Recommended Background: Experience working with children or adolescents.

metadata.class_name: Social and Emotional Learning: Research, Practice, and Policy
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 429 — Constructivist Approaches to Development: Piaget and Vygotsky Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Piaget's and Vygotsky's theories of development of knowledge. Empirical and logico-mathematical forms of knowledge. Thought and action. Thought and language. Prerequisites: EPSY 255 or EPSY 426 or ED 422 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as EPSY 429.

metadata.class_name: Constructivist Approaches to Development: Piaget and Vygotsky
metadata.subject: Psychology (PSCH)

text: Course: PSCH 443 — Advanced Statistics Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Design and analysis of experiments: between, within factorial and mixed factorial designs and introduction to multiple regression. For students planning research careers or advanced degrees. Prerequisites: PSCH 343. Course Information: 3 hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: PSCH 459 — Cognitive Methods Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Hands-on training in the methods of cognitive psychology, especially computational modeling and the analysis of verbal protocols and other types of trace data. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: PSCH 483 — Neuroanatomy Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 4 Description: Organization of the nervous system, with an emphasis on mammals. Prerequisites: BIOS 272 or BIOS 286 or BIOS 325 or PSCH 262 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BIOS 483 and NEUS 483. Animals used in instruction. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: PSCH 484 — Neuroscience I Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Neuroscience as an integrative discipline. Neuroanatomy of vertebrates, neural development, cellular neurobiology, action potential mechanisms, synaptic transmission and neuropharmacology. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or PSCH 262. Course Information: Same as BIOS 484 and PHIL 484.

Course: PSCH 485 — Neuroscience II Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 3 Description: Integrative neuroscience, including sensory and motor systems; learning, memory, and language; pathology of nervous systems; philosophical perspectives, and modeling. Prerequisites: BIOS 286 or PSCH 262. Course Information: Same as BIOS 485 and PHIL 485.

Course: PSCH 494 — Special Topics in Psychology Subject: Psychology (PSCH) Credits: 1-4 Description: Advanced treatment of an announced topic. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: PSCI 300 — Undergraduate Research Experience in Pharmaceutical Sciences Subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI) Credits: 1-3 Description: Course supports the academic environment for undergraduate students at UIC. The research experience will be under the guidance of a faculty member who will act as a research supervisor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor supervising the research experience. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Previously listed as BPS 300. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

metadata.class_name: Undergraduate Research Experience in Pharmaceutical Sciences
metadata.subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI)

text: Course: PSCI 380 — Undergraduate Research in Pharmaceutical Sciences Subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI) Credits: 1-3 Description: Investigation, under the direction of one or more faculty members, of a problem of limited scope. Prerequisites: Minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.50 and consent of the instructor, department head, and Associate Dean of Student Affairs. Course Information: Previously listed as BPS 380. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours per department. A total of not more than 8 hours of PSCI 380 and PSCI 390 may be applied toward the 12 hours of professional electives. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: PSCI 390 — Special Projects in Pharmaceutical Sciences Subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI) Credits: 1 or 2 Description: Provide professional students in the Pharm.D. program with an opportunity to carry out a special project with defined objectives under the guidance of a faculty mentor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and consent of the department head, and Associate Dean for Student Affairs. Course Information: Previously listed as BPS 390. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. A total of not more than 8 hours of PSCI 380 and PSCI 390 may be applied toward the 12 hours of professional electives. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: PSCI 421 — Advanced Dosage Form Design Subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI) Credits: 1 Description: Students attend fourteen labs where they make sixteen new dosage formulations. Several labs will focus on using new devices and machines that may be seen in compounding practice. Includes veterinary formulations that may be seen in cats and dogs. Prerequisites: PHAR 431 and PHAR 432. Course Information: Previously listed ad BPS 421.

Course: PSCI 425 — College of Pharmacy Colloquium Lecture Series Subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI) Credits: 1 Description: Weekly, one-hour, basic-research seminars given by invited lecturers. Course Information: Previously listed as BPS 425. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 hours. Students will not be able to concurrently enroll in PSCI 425 and PMPR 355 during the Spring semester.

metadata.class_name: College of Pharmacy Colloquium Lecture Series
metadata.subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI)

metadata.class_name: Career Paths in the Pharmaceutical Industry
metadata.subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI)

text: Course: PSCI 485 — Concentration Research Subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI) Credits: 2 Description: Special independent study project of limited scope under the direction of one or more faculty members with specialization in that area. The project may require literature research related to the research project. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and admission to the Doctorate in Pharmaceutical Sciences. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: PSCI 499 — Special Projects in Pharmaceutical Sciences Subject: Pharmaceutical Sciences (PSCI) Credits: 1-3 Description: Special projects in Pharmaceutical Sciences. Course Information: Previously listed as PMPG 499.

Course: PSOP 300 — Undergraduate Research Experience in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1-3 Description: Supports the academic environment for undergraduate students at UIC. The research experience will be under the guidance of a faculty member who will act as a research supervisor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor supervising the research experience. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unstatisfatory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department.

metadata.class_name: Undergraduate Research Experience in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 380 — Undergraduate Research in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1-3 Description: Investigation, under the direction of one or more faculty members, of a problem of limited scope. May require literature research related to the research project. Prerequisites: Minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.50 and consent of the instructor, department head, and Associate Dean for Student Affairs. Course Information: May be repeated. A maximum of 6 hours of credit is allowed per department. A total of not more than 8 hours of 380 and 390 numbered courses in the college may be applied toward the 12 hours of PharmD professional electives.

text: Course: PSOP 381 — Professional Development Seminar I Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 Description: Weekly seminar series for second professional year pharmacy students. Discusses educational issues related to the second professional year. Students create/update Curriculum Vitae; explore various pharmacy career opportunities. Prerequisites: Student must be listed as an advisee of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for PSOP 381 if the student has credit for BPS 381 or PMMP 381 or PMPR 371.

Course: PSOP 382 — Professional Development Seminar II Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 Description: Weekly seminar series for second year pharmacy students. Discusses educational issues related to the second professional year. Students create/update Curriculum Vitae; explore various pharmacy career opportunities. Prerequisites: Student must be listed as an advisee of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not givern for PSOP 382 if the student has credit for BPS 382 or PMMP 382.

Course: PSOP 383 — Professional Development Seminar III Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 Description: Weekly seminar series for third professional year pharmacy students. Discusses relevant educational and professional issues. Update CV/Resume and Portfolio. Explore pharmacy career opportunities with invited guests. Prerequisites: Student must be listed as an advisee of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for PSOP 383 if the student has credit for BPS 383 or PMMP 383.

Course: PSOP 384 — Professional Development Seminar IV Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 Description: Weekly seminar series for third year pharmacy students. Discusses with advisees relevant educational and professional issues. Update CV/Resume and Portfolio. Explore pharmacy career opportunities with invited guests. Prerequisites: Student must be listed as an advisee of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for PSOP 384 if the student has credit for BPS 384 or PMMP 384.

Course: PSOP 385 — Special Topics in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1-3 Description: A selected topic of current interest in pharmacy systems, outcomes and policy; or an experimental course, offered by faculty or a visiting lecturer. Prerequisites: Good standing and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as PMAD 385.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 387 — Critical Dialogue (CD) for Professional Student Development Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 2 Description: This highly interactive course engages pharmacy students in a broad conceptualization of pharmaceutical practice in a multicultural society.

metadata.class_name: Critical Dialogue (CD) for Professional Student Development
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 389 — Online Contemporary Issues in Pharmacy Student Development Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 2 Description: Introduces students to various contemporary pharmacy issues through the lens of a multi-disciplinary health education policy analysis.

metadata.class_name: Online Contemporary Issues in Pharmacy Student Development
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 390 — Special Projects in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 or 2 Description: Special projects within the departmental discipline. Defined and terminal project goals are achieved through independent study. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor, department head, and Associate Dean for Student Affairs. Course Information: 1 to 2 hours. May be repeated. A maximum of 4 hours of 390 credit is allowed in all departments. A total of not more than 8 hours of 380 and 390 numbered courses in the college may be applied toward the 12 hours of PharmD professional electives.

metadata.class_name: Special Projects in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 391 — Foundations in Urban Family and Community Healthcare 1 Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 Description: This course is a first in a series and is designed to introduce students to concepts and issues as it relates to urban public health and primary care practice. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Urban Pharmacy program and consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Urban Family and Community Healthcare 1
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 392 — Foundations in Urban Family and Community Healthcare 2 Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 Description: The second course in a series that is designed to introduce students to concepts and issues as it relates to urban public health and primary care practice. Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Urban Pharmacy program and successful completion of PSOP 391.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Urban Family and Community Healthcare 2
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

Prerequisites: Acceptance into the UPHARM program and successful completion of UPHARM Year 1.

metadata.class_name: Foundations in Urban Family and Community Healthcare 3

Prerequisites: Acceptance into the UPHARM program and successful completion of UPHARM Year 1.

Prerequisites: Acceptance into the UPHARM program and successful completion of UPHARM Year 2. In the UPHARM program and expressed interest in urban pharmacy education practice in underserved Chicagoland communities and interest in health disparities research.

Prerequisites: Acceptance into the UPHARM program and successful completion of UPHARM Year 2. Expressed interest in urban pharmacy education practice in underserved Chicagoland communities and interest in health disparities research.

text: Course: PSOP 397 — Capstone Project in Urban Healthcare Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 2 Description: This is the seventh and final course in a series, and is the capstone project. Prerequisites: Successful completion of UPHARM program years 1-3.

Course: PSOP 400 — Ethics and Privacy Issues in Comparative Effectiveness Research Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1 Description: Covers ethical and privacy issues in comparative effectiveness research. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Extensive computer use required. Taught online.

metadata.class_name: Ethics and Privacy Issues in Comparative Effectiveness Research
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 421 — Pharmaceutical Marketing Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the field of marketing with specific emphasis on pharmaceuticals and the marketing of pharmacy services.

Course: PSOP 470 — Managed Care Pharmacy Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 3 Description: Professional development in managed care pharmacy to learn history, administrative and policy aspects, network with operational managers and leaders in field, visit managed care sites and observe activies of managed care pharmacists. Prerequisites: Third year standing in the Doctor of Pharmacy program or second year standing in the Doctor of Pharmacy program with consent of the instructor, or graduate standing in pharmacy.

Course: PSOP 482 — Professional Practice Management Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 3 Description: Managerial functions of the pharmacist in all practice environments with emphasis on the planning, organizing, staffing, directing and controlling of resources.

Course: PSOP 484 — Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 3 Description: The course will discuss the concepts, process, and statistical methods required to perform a systematic review or meta-analysis of a large body of empirical findings. Prerequisites: EPID 403 or BSTT 400 or PSOP 502 ; or graduate or professional standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Taught online. Recommended Background: Graduate coursework in biostatistics or epidemiology.

Course: PSOP 485 — Concentration Research Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 2 Description: Investigation, under the direction of one or more faculty members, of a problem of limited scope. May require literature research related to the research project. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours.

Course: PSOP 489 — Health Economics and Outcomes Research Overview Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 2 Description: A survey of topics in the field of health economics and outcomes research as applied to pharmacy.

metadata.class_name: Health Economics and Outcomes Research Overview
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PSOP 494 — Special Topics in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy Subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP) Credits: 1-3 Description: Topics will vary, including the on-going analysis of contemporary issues associated with delivery, financing and management of pharmaceutical products and professional services. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes and Policy
metadata.subject: Pharmacy Systems, Outcomes, and Policy (PSOP)

text: Course: PT 350 — Introduction to Physical Therapy Subject: Physical Therapy (PT) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces the career and profession of physical therapy including professional values, care settings, specialties and models of patient/client management. Course Information: Priority registration will be given to students in the B.S. in Rehabilitation Sciences.

Course: PT 440 — Introduction to the Theory and Practice of Physical Therapy in the United States Subject: Physical Therapy (PT) Credits: 0-20 Description: International students further develop and apply learning from their physical therapy curriculum in an academic training environment that fosters learning, inquiry, critical thinking, and global awareness of contemporary physical therapy practice. Prerequisites: Successful completion of all previous didactic and fieldwork courses required by the home institution, and a letter of recommendation from a PT faculty member at the home institution; and English proficiency. Restricted to visiting physical therapy students from international universities. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. No graduation credit. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, student must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Theory and Practice of Physical Therapy in the United States
metadata.subject: Physical Therapy (PT)

text: Course: PT 496 — Independent Study Subject: Physical Therapy (PT) Credits: 1-4 Description: Open to undergraduate, graduate and professional program students to provide exposure and experience to the field of rehabilitation sciences in the classroom, clinic, research and/or community. Prerequisites: Consent of the Instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours.

Course: PUBH 100 — Health and the Public Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Students will examine both historical and contemporary public health stories focusing on the United States to begin to understand the contexts, systems, professions, tools, and skills associated with the public health enterprise. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: PUBH 105 — Foundations for Public Health Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 2 Description: Engages pre-public health students by deepening their knowledge and understanding of careers in the public health arena. Students will develop and refine foundational skills that support successful matriculation into the public health major. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Enrollment will be restricted to first year students in the Public Health - Undecided (Pre-Public Health) program and other Pre-Public Health students by permission of the instructor.

Course: PUBH 110 — Public Health and Global Societies Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to global public health through an exploration of health challenges from the local population to global society perspectives. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: PUBH 120 — Public Health and the Study of Disease and Epidemics Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces basic principles surrounding the distribution of disease and epidemics in human populations. Through lectures and field exercises, students will learn fundamentals of epidemiology, the basic science of public health. Natural World - No Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Public Health and the Study of Disease and Epidemics
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 130 — Introductory Public Health Statistics for Public Health Decision-Making Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 4 Description: An introductory statistics course through the lens of medical, biological, and public health disciplines. Topics covered include study design, sampling, descriptive statistics and basic hypothesis tests for comparing groups. Prerequisites: Satisfactory grade in MATH 090, or passing grade in MATH 108 , or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Natural World - No Lab course.

metadata.class_name: Introductory Public Health Statistics for Public Health Decision-Making
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 194 — Introductory Special Topics in Public Health Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Introductory analysis of selected public health challenges and issues. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Introductory Special Topics in Public Health
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 200 — Exploring Connections between Human Health and the Environment Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of case studies related to human health and the environment, with engagement from community partners. Students evaluate environmental health issues, human health of workers, and use data to plan advocacy activities. Recommended Background: PUBH 100 or other course(s) related to Understanding the Individual and Society. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Exploring Connections between Human Health and the Environment
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 299 — Undergraduate Public Health Study Abroad Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 0-18 Description: Provides credit for foreign study. Student's proposal for study abroad course work must have prior approval of the BA in Public Health Program. Final determination of credit is made upon the student's completion of the study abroad course work. Prerequisites: Consent of the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health Program and the Study Abroad Office. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 36 hours per academic year or 48 hours per calendar year.

Course: PUBH 300 — Critical Thinking in Public Health Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 4 Description: Designed to prepare students to make reasoned, intelligent decisions about public health matters by learning about and practicing how to think, read, write, and speak critically. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program.

Course: PUBH 301 — Critical Thinking in Public Health II Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 2 Description: Designed to prepare students to make reasoned, intelligent decisions about public health matters by learning about and practicing how to think, read, write, and speak critically. Part two of a two course sequence. Prerequisites: PUBH 300 and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program.

metadata.class_name: Critical Thinking in Public Health II
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 310 — Public Health and Global Citizenship Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Encourages a critical examination of the political, religious, social and economic influences on the continuum of local/global health and the role citizenship plays in advocating for the equitable distribution of health across the planet. Prerequisites: Admission to the Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or Bachelor of Science in Public Health program. Non-majors who have completed PUBH 110 may enroll with consent of the instructor.

Course: PUBH 320 — Ecologies of Health and Modern Life Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Human activity has had an impact on the health of people, animals and environments throughout history. This course uses cross-disciplinary frameworks to examine critical issues in public health that can be traced to the impact of modern life. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Ecologies of Health and Modern Life
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 330 — Health Equity and Health Disparities Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: How and why national and local health disparities in the U.S. occur and for what racial and ethnic groups they are most severe. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: No credit given if the student has credit in SOC 426. Students who completed a version of SOC 426 with a topic other than health disparities may receive credit with permission of the instructor.

Course: PUBH 340 — Health Literacy Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Trains students to access, analyze, craft, communicate and use health information in ways that are easily understood and serve to improve public health. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion.

Course: PUBH 350 — Health Systems, Health Policy Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Examines popular perceptions and the reality of how the U.S. Health System is created and evolves. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Classes will alternate between traditional classroom sessions and guest lectures or off-campus field visits to health system and policy-making experiences. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: PUBH 360 — Local Citizenship and Community Health Initiatives Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 4 Description: Explore the concept of community health, identify strategies for developing and implementing community health initiatives, and appreciate community building as an overarching approach for health improvement. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field work required. This course entails two classroom sessions per week (3 credit hours) and three hours per week of field work by arrangement (1 credit hour). Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Local Citizenship and Community Health Initiatives
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 370 — Using the Public Health Toolbox Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Opportunities to synthesize and apply knowledge/skills from the preceding core courses, working individually and in groups. Course is linked with the baccalaureate project to be implemented in the last semester of the program. Prerequisites: Senior standing in the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: PUBH 390 — Sustainability Internship Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an intellectual framework for students to apply classroom learning to hands-on project-based internships that advance the overall mission of greater social, economic and environmental sustainability in the campus community. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in US 130 ; or Grade of C or better in PHYS 116. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PUBH 390. Students will be placed in internships with UIC departments and units for approximately 8 hours per week.

Course: PUBH 393 — Public Health Fieldwork Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Public Health fieldwork is an integrative practicum experience for students who are undergraduate public health majors. Prerequisites: Senior standing in the BA or BS in Public Health program and consent of the SPH Undergraduate Fieldwork Developer. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Field work required. Locations are chosen from an array of public health sites established through the SPH Undergraduate Fieldwork Developer. Students are expected to spend a minimum of 90 hours in the field site. Fieldwork schedules may be configured to the mutual benefit of sites and students.

Course: PUBH 394 — Advanced Special Topics in Public Health Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Intensive analysis of selected public health challenges and issues. Prerequisites: Admission to the BA or BS in Public Health program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Special Topics in Public Health
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 395 — Professional Topics Seminar Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 0 Description: Provides opportunities to communicate skills, tools, and content relevant to students’ development outside of the regular curriculum. Topics may change depending on student needs, interests, and current events. Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program and junior standing. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Juniors in the Public Health major must register for the seminar in both Fall and Spring semesters. The seminar will meet approximately 6-7 times per semester.

Course: PUBH 396 — Independent Study in Public Health Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Self-directed study of a special public health topic under the guidance of a faculty member. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor supervising the independent study and approval of the department/school. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: PUBH 397 — Baccalaureate Project in Public Health Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Implementation and presentation of an integrative project designed to demonstrate students' mastery of the overarching curriculum goals for the undergraduate major in public health; demonstration of critical thinking and analytic skills. Prerequisites: PUBH 370 and Credit or concurrent registration in PUBH 411 and senior standing in the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program. Credit or concurrent registration in PUBH 411 and senior standing in the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in PUBH 411 and senior standing in the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Course will meet weekly. The final will entail up to a full day of presentations of the student projects to peers, faculty, and stakeholders. Prereq Codes (parsed): PUBH 411 Coreq Codes (parsed): PUBH 411

Course: PUBH 399 — Research in Public Health Sciences - Undergraduate Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 1-3 Description: Research experience under the guidance of a faculty member who will act as a research supervisor. Prerequisites: Approval of the department or school and consent of the instructor supervising the research experience. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Application of credit toward the degree is contingent upon the approval of the student's college and/or department. Previously listed as IPHS 399.

metadata.class_name: Research in Public Health Sciences - Undergraduate
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 410 — Historical and Contemporary Public Health Challenges I Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 2 Description: Part one of a two course sequence, historical and contemporary case studies of social movement(s) will be examined to demonstrate the inter-relatedness of social justice, science/medicine, culture, politics, geography and the public's health. Prerequisites: Senior standing in the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Historical and Contemporary Public Health Challenges I
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 411 — Historical and Contemporary Public Health Challenges II Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 2 Description: Part two of a two course sequence, historical and contemporary case studies of social movement(s) will be examined to demonstrate the inter-relatedness of social justice, science/medicine, culture, politics, geography and the public's health. Prerequisites: PUBH 410 and senior standing in the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Historical and Contemporary Public Health Challenges II
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: PUBH 420 — Public Health Problem Solving: Epidemiology in Action! Subject: Public Health (PUBH) Credits: 3 Description: Through student driven discourse, hands-on projects and instructor facilitated case studies, this course is designed to hone previously learned epidemiological principles and apply them to simulated field conditions. Prerequisites: PUBH 120 and senior standing in the Bachelor of Arts in Public Health or the Bachelor of Science in Public Health program or consent of instructor.

metadata.class_name: Public Health Problem Solving: Epidemiology in Action!
metadata.subject: Public Health (PUBH)

text: Course: RELS 100 — Religion in Human Experience Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to basic questions about religion, focusing on the theological and philosophical ways in which humans have sought to understand faith, transcendence, and the nature of god(s). Individual and Society course.

Course: RELS 101 — Introduction to World Religions Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: A historical survey of the origins and development of several of the world's largest religions, including but not limited to Buddhism, Hinduism, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. World Cultures course.

Course: RELS 106 — What Is Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of issues concerning religion, including varying views of the purposes that religions serve, differences between religions, and arguments for the existence of God. Course Information: Same as PHIL 106. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course.

Course: RELS 117 — Understanding the Holocaust Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the Holocaust of European Jewry as the result of antisemitic ideology and the development of modern German political forces; implementation of the Final Solution. Course Information: Same as HIST 117 and JST 117. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: RELS 120 — Catholic Thought: An Introduction Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the main topics, interests, and methods of Catholic thought. Course Information: Same as CST 120. Past course.

Course: RELS 121 — Introduction to Judaism Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the Jewish religion as it has developed from its roots in the Hebrew Bible until today, emphasizing its central texts and concepts. Same as JST 101. Individual and Society course.

Course: RELS 122 — Minority Perspectives in the Germanic Context Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Investigation of the challenges and/or opportunities of multicultural societies by examining in a socio-historical context texts created by members of Europe's ethnic, religious, and national minorities. Course Information: Same as GER 122 and JST 122. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Minority Perspectives in the Germanic Context
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 123 — Introduction to Yiddish Culture and Literature Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Yiddish culture in Europe and the U.S. in socio-historical context. Focus on the role of Yiddish in conceptions of secular, cultural, religious, national Jewish identities. Course Information: Same as GER 123 and JST 123. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture and Literature
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 124 — Introduction to the Hebrew Bible Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: A study of the Five Books of Moses (a.k.a Torah or Pentateuch) within the contexts of the ancient Near East and biblical literature. Course Information: Same as CL 124 and JST 124. Taught in English. Past course.

Course: RELS 125 — Black Religious Traditions Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the religious history of black people in the United States and the diaspora. Examination of religious institutions, the role of religion in black social and political movements, mass rebellions, and revolts. Course Information: Same as BLST 125. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: RELS 126 — Introduction to Jewish History Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of Jewish history from Biblical times until the present. Topics will range from second Temple Judea and the beginning of the diaspora through 21st-century Jewish life in America and Israel. Course Information: Same as JST 102. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: RELS 127 — Diaspora, Exile, Genocide: Aspects of the European Jewish Experience in Literature and Film Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Literature and films on European Jewish responses to anti-Semitism and persecution in a historical context to reveal the condition of post-Enlightenment German-speaking Jewish and Yiddish-speaking societies. Course Information: Same as GER 125 and JST 125. No credit toward a major or minor program offered by the Department of Germanic Studies. Taught in English. Past course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Diaspora, Exile, Genocide: Aspects of the European Jewish Experience in Literature and Film
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 128 — The Jesus Movement and the New Testament Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Investigates the Jesus movement from its beginnings as a small Jewish reform sect through its development into the religion known as Christianity. Uses New Testament writings as primary sources for reconstructing the past. Course Information: Same as CL 128 and CST 128. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Jesus Movement and the New Testament
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 130 — Introduction to Islam Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory study of the religion, culture, and present variety of Islam in Islamic countries and in the West. World Cultures course.

Course: RELS 150 — Catholicism in U.S. History Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: The Catholic experience in the United States from its colonial origins to the present. Course Information: Same as CST 150 and HIST 150. US Society course.

Course: RELS 175 — Understanding the Bible as Literature Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: A broad overview of various literary genres in the Bible such as origin narrative, historical narrative, poetry, wisdom literature, prophetic/apocalyptic literature, parable, and epistle. Course Information: Same as ENGL 175. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Creative Arts course.

Course: RELS 177 — Middle Eastern Civilization Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the culture and society of the Middle East, with special attention to the development of Islam and the consequences of westernization. Course Information: Same as HIST 177. Course is offered in both face-to-face and hybrid/ online formats. Check the class schedule for details. When taught online or hybrid, students will be required to have reliable internet access and a means for accessing it (computer preferable). Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Past course, and World Cultures course.

Course: RELS 208 — Classical Mythology Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Intensive study of the gods and heroic sagas of the cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, through original sources in translation. Course Information: Same as CL 208. All readings are in English. Individual and Society course, and Past course.

Course: RELS 215 — Anthropology of Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of varieties of religious experience, including magic and witchcraft, with emphasis on non-Western religions and the role of religious institutions in social integration. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as ANTH 215.

Course: RELS 220 — Buddhist Art and Architecture Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: A chronologically and thematically organized survey of Buddhist art and architecture in Asia and beyond. Course Information: Same as AH 220 and GLAS 220. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: RELS 222 — Phil in the Islamic World Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of philosophy in the Islamic world from 8th century until today. Topics include: logic and psychology to metaphysics, theology, and politics. Special emphasis on cultural interactions between philosophers of different faiths and cultures. Prerequisites: One logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ARAB 222 and PHIL 222.

Course: RELS 225 — Topics in Muslim-Jewish Relations Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Muslim-Jewish interactions from the rise of Islam until contemporary times, the relationship between Biblical and Quranic materials, the Jewish and Islamic interpretive tradition and the legal systems of the two religious traditions. Course Information: Same as CL 225 and JST 225.

Course: RELS 230 — Topics in Islam Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Topics, issues, and methodologies in Islamic studies. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Recommended Background: ENGL 160. World Cultures course.

Course: RELS 231 — Topics in Jewish Thought Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of major topics in Jewish theology, philosophy, ethics and political thought. Course Information: Same as JST 230. May be repeated if topics vary. Recommended Background: JST 101 or the equivalent.

Course: RELS 232 — The Religious World of the Earliest Christians Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the religious world of the earliest Christians, focusing on the ways in which early Christian ideas and practices arose out of the cultures, religions, and philosophies of the ancient Mediterranean basin. Course Information: Same as CL 232 and HIST 232. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The Religious World of the Earliest Christians
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 233 — Topics in Religious Studies Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Study of a specific topic in religious studies. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: RELS 240 — Philosophy and Revelation: Jewish and Christian Perspectives Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to philosophical ways of addressing the claim that a book (the Bible, the Quran) comes from God. Texts by Immanuel Kant, Moses Mendelssohn, and Soren Kierkegaard, among others. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as RELS 141. Same as PHIL 240 and JST 240. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Philosophy and Revelation: Jewish and Christian Perspectives
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 241 — Philosophy of Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Philosophical inquiry into the grounds of faith and belief, the nature of religious and mystical experience, and the existence and nature of God. Prerequisites: One non-logic course in philosophy or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PHIL 241. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: RELS 242 — The History of Jewish Biblical Interpretation Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Jewish interpretation of the Hebrew bible. A survey of the span of Jewish history and the wide range of cultural contexts that have impacted the understanding of the Torah. Course Information: Same as CL 242 and JST 242. Past course.

metadata.class_name: The History of Jewish Biblical Interpretation
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 243 — The Archaeology of Buddhism Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: The development, spread, integration, and decline of Buddhism in many parts of Asia. The study of material culture as a way of reconstructing and understanding the religious past. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ANTH 243.

Course: RELS 246 — Sociology of Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of the structures and functions of religious institutions in modern society.Special attention to the interplay between religion and other social phenomena, such as economics, politics, and secular culture. Prerequisites: One social sciences Course Distribution Credit (CDC) course and sophomore standing. Course Information: Same as SOC 246. Occasional field trips. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: RELS 250 — Eastern and Western Philosophies of Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Eastern and Western philosophies of religion: Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, and Christianity. Course Information: Same as INST 250. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Eastern and Western Philosophies of Religion
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 255 — Religious Diversity: Conceptual and Practical Issues Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: The facts of religious diversity and the questions raised by them. Special attention to Catholic Christian perspectives, treating them from secular and other religious perspectives.

metadata.class_name: Religious Diversity: Conceptual and Practical Issues
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 256 — Religion in American History Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the varieties of religious experience in American history from the sixteenth to the twentieth-first centuries, with emphasis on group formation and the social and cultural consequences of American religious diversity. Prerequisites: ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as HIST 256. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Past course, and US Society course.

Course: RELS 257 — Religious Diversity in the Healthcare Fields Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the intersection of religion and healthcare with the goal of preparing future healthcare providers to engage with diverse religious perspectives and behaviors in healthcare settings.

metadata.class_name: Religious Diversity in the Healthcare Fields
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 279 — The Qur'an: A Historical and Cultural Approach Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the text, history of interpretation, and the cultural significance of the Qur'an. Course Information: Previously listed as RELS 330. Taught in English. Recommended Background: RELS 130.

metadata.class_name: The Qur'an: A Historical and Cultural Approach
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 292 — Major Religious Thinkers Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: An examination of one or more major/classical thinkers and their writings. Prerequisites: RELS 100 , 101 , 115, 215 , or 241. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Previously listed as RELS 320.

Course: RELS 293 — Dante's Divine Comedy Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: An in-depth study of the Divine Comedy, read in English, against the historical, religious, philosophical and cultural background of the Middle Ages. Course Information: Same as CL 293 and ITAL 293. Previously listed as RELS 193. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: RELS 294 — Topics in Catholic History Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: An investigation of the impact of human migration and cultural pluralism on Catholicism and an analysis of the role of the Catholic Church in group relations. Topics will vary. Course Information: Same as CST 294 and HIST 294. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: RELS 295 — Topics in Catholic Thought Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Critical investigation of a topic or topics central to the development of Catholic thought, carried on by study of its proponents and opponents. Topics will vary. Course Information: Same as CST 295. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: RELS 296 — Topics in Jewish Studies Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: How Jews became a modern ethnic group, how their experiences compare with other ethnic groups, and how their experiences in modern times vary from nation to nation. Course Information: Same as JST 296. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: RELS 311 — Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity and Judaism Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the root of contemporary perspectives on gender and sexuality in the early traditions of Judaism and Christianity including the Bible, the Epic of Gilgamesh, the Church Fathers, the Talmud, and legends of the saints. Course Information: Same as GWS 311 and JST 311.

metadata.class_name: Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity and Judaism
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 337 — Latino/a Religions in the US Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: How Latinx communities venerate ancestors and deities, create and remake sacred space, practice healing, and organize politically through the lens of of documentaries, fiction and literature, visual art, and ethnographic studies. Course Information: Same as LALS 337.

Course: RELS 376 — Literature and Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Studies in the relation of literature to doctrines, imagery, practices, experiences, or history of one or more religious traditions. Course Information: Same as ENGL 376. Previously listed as RELS 343. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 101 , 105 , 175 , or 207-209.

Course: RELS 392 — Major Problems in Religious Studies Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: In-depth examination of a major topic or problem in religious thought. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: At least one course in religious studies. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: RELS 394 — Topics in Catholic History and Culture Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of various topics in Catholic history and culture. Prerequisites: One course in history or Catholic studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as CST 394 and HIST 394.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Catholic History and Culture
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 395 — Topics in Jewish Studies Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected topics in Jewish culture and history. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as JST 394. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: RELS 399 — Independent Study Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Selected topics for individual study. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Recommended Background: Two courses in religious studies.

Course: RELS 420 — Advanced Studies in Jewish Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: In-depth study of a period or mode of Jewish religious development or textual production, or an examination of a religious tenet or practice across various historical periods. Topics will vary. Prerequisites: JST 101 ; and JST 230 or JST 242 or JST 254. Course Information: Same as JST 420. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s) if topics vary.

Course: RELS 422 — Studies in Medieval Philosophy Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 0-4 Description: Study of selected philosophers such as Boethius, Avicenna, Aquinas, William Ockham, and selected issues such as the relationship between faith and reason, the nature of reason, the nature of human cognition, the nature of morality. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level philosophy course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PHIL 422. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics or figures vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: RELS 430 — Advanced Studies in Jewish Thought Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Advanced topics in Jewish theology, philosophy, ethics or political thought. Prerequisites: One 100-level and one 200-level course in Jewish Studies. Course Information: Same as JST 430. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: RELS 441 — Topics in Philosophy of Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive study of one or more selected topics concerning the philosophical aspects of basic religious beliefs and concepts. Prerequisites: One non-logic 200-level course in philosophy; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PHIL 441. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: RELS 446 — Race, Ethnicity, and Gender in American Religion Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Religious institutions in the U.S. as a crucible for racial, ethnic, and gender identities, group formation, and intergroup relations; major world religions represented in the U.S. Prerequisites: SOC 100 and junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Same as SOC 446. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Race, Ethnicity, and Gender in American Religion
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 475 — The Bible as Literature: Hebrew Bible Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Literary analysis of genres and themes of the Hebrew Bible and close reading of the biblical texts. Sources of the Bible and their historical context. Course Information: Same as ENGL 475 and JST 475. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as RELS 478. Taught in English. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 175 or ENGL 207 -209.

metadata.class_name: The Bible as Literature: Hebrew Bible
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 476 — The Bible as Literature: New Testament Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Literary analysis of the New Testament and its historical and religious contexts, focusing on the gospels and Pauline letters. Course Information: Same as ENGL 476. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as RELS 479. Recommended Background: Any of ENGL 175 , 207 -209, 475.

metadata.class_name: The Bible as Literature: New Testament
metadata.subject: Religious Studies (RELS)

text: Course: RELS 494 — Topics in Jewish Studies Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Selected topics in Jewish studies. Prerequisites: JST 101 or JST 102 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as JST 494. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

Course: RELS 495 — Topics in Religious History Subject: Religious Studies (RELS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specific topics are announced each term. Prerequisites: 3 hours of history or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as HIST 495. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: RES 250 — Real Estate Principles Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to real estate, including principles of finance, investments, accounting, management, marketing, and statistic. Provides background necessary for additional courses in real estate.

Course: RES 420 — Real Estate Market Analysis Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Analysis of real property markets, including land, buildings, and improvements. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: RES 425 — Real Estate Valuation Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the valuation of real estate, with focus on the underlying determinants of location value. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: RES 440 — International Real Estate Markets Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey and analysis of issues related to international real estate markets, with an emphasis on North American and Asia. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: RES 450 — Real Estate Data Analysis Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Analysis of real estate data using statistical software programs, with an emphasis on housing data. Prerequisites: ECON 120. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: RES 460 — Commercial Real Estate Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Fundamentals of the commercial real estate, including mortgages and investment analysis. Prerequisites: FIN 300. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: RES 470 — Real Estate Investments Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to investment in real estate, with focus on types of investment and analysis of investment performance. Prerequisites: FIN 300. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: RES 472 — Real Estate Finance Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Finance principles applied to real estate; financing of residential and income-producing real estate; real estate development finance; secondary mortgage market; taxation and real estate finance. Prerequisites: FIN 300. Course Information: Same as FIN 472. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ECON 472. May not be used to satisfy the economics credit requirement for the MA in Economics and PhD in Economics. Only elective credit will be applied toward these degrees. Graduate students will complete a term project to meet the additional credit hour requirement.

Course: RES 494 — Topics in Real Estate Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 1-4 Description: An intensive study of a selected topic in real estate. Prerequisites: RES 250 and FIN 300 ; or FIN 301 and FIN 302. Course Information: May be repeated if topics vary. Students may register for more than one section per term. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours for undergraduates; may be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours for graduate students.

Course: RES 499 — Research Experience Subject: Real Estate Studies (RES) Credits: 1-3 Description: Independent student research experience under the supervision of a faculty member. The faculty member and student will determine a specific, discipline appropriate research project to complete within the semester and submit a written report. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor and Department Head. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

Course: RUSS 101 — Elementary Russian I Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 4 Description: Basics of Russian grammar and vocabulary. Reading and discussing the culture and modern life of Russia. Prerequisites: For students who have had no formal work in Russian. Course Information: Taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: RUSS 102 — Elementary Russian II Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 4 Description: Continues RUSS 101. Prerequisites: RUSS 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This class is taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: RUSS 103 — Intermediate Russian I Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 4 Description: Futher study of Russian grammar and vocabulary. Reading and discussing the culture and modern life of Russia. Introduction to expository, persuasive and argumentative styles. Prerequisites: RUSS 102 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This class is taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: RUSS 104 — Intermediate Russian II Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 4 Description: Continuation of RUSS 103. Futher study of Russian grammar and vocabulary. Reading and discussing the culture and modern life of Russia. Introduction to expository, persuasive and argumentative styles Prerequisites: RUSS 103 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: This class is taught in a blended format. Internet access is required. A high-speed connection is strongly recommended.

Course: RUSS 115 — Russian Culture Before the Revolution Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: The main trends of Russian thought and manners from the beginning to the Revolution: literature, philosophy, religion, art, architecture, intellectual life. Audio-visual emphasis. World Cultures course.

Course: RUSS 116 — Russian Culture: The Soviet Period Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: The transformation of Russian culture after 1917: literature, art, architecture, philosophy, intellectual trends; emphasis on the ideology of Socialist Realism. Audio-visual emphasis. World Cultures course.

Course: RUSS 120 — The Russian Short Story in Translation Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to important Russian short stories of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries; the elements of fiction; close analysis of literary texts. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: The Russian Short Story in Translation
metadata.subject: Russian (RUSS)

text: Course: RUSS 130 — Masterpieces of Russian Literature in Translation Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to Russian novellas and novels of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Masterpieces of Russian Literature in Translation
metadata.subject: Russian (RUSS)

text: Course: RUSS 140 — Understanding the Body: Health, Gender, and Disability in Russian Culture Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the theoretical understanding and representation of the body through examples of Russian literature and arts. Course explores such topics as illness, health, reproduction, disability, gender, and power. Course Information: Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. No knowledge of Russian language or culture required. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Understanding the Body: Health, Gender, and Disability in Russian Culture
metadata.subject: Russian (RUSS)

text: Course: RUSS 150 — Introduction to Russian Cinema Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to major themes, trends, and techniques of Russian/Soviet cinema. Explores film as an expression of social reality and political ideology. Comparisons drawn with American cinema. Course Information: Taught in English. Films screened with English subtitles. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: RUSS 201 — Advanced Russian through Media and Film Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Development of advanced language skills through the study of Russian media and film from a variety of periods. In-depth analysis of past and present Russian cultural artifacts. Prerequisites: RUSS 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Russian through Media and Film
metadata.subject: Russian (RUSS)

text: Course: RUSS 202 — Advanced Russian through Contemporary Culture Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Development of skills in spoken and written Russian, within the context of contemporary Russian culture, via a variety of sources, such as: news articles, comics, music. Prerequisites: RUSS 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test.

Course: RUSS 203 — Advanced Russian through Short Stories Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Development of advanced language skills: writing, reading, listening comprehension, and speaking.
