Exploration and analysis of Russian cultural tropes within the context of short stories. Prerequisites: RUSS 104 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: RUSS 239 — Twentieth-Century Russia in Film Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of social, political and cultural development of the Russian Empire and Soviet Union through the use of film as a historical source. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or completion of any 100-level history course. Course Information: Same as HIST 239 and MOVI 239. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Past course.
Course: RUSS 241 — Dostoyevsky Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Selected short stories and novels. Course Information: Taught in English. Creative Arts course.
Course: RUSS 242 — Tolstoy Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Discussion of selected short stories and plays. Course Information: Taught in English. Creative Arts course.

Course: RUSS 244 — Women in Russian Literature Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Major works by and about women in Russian literature: experiences of women and societal attitudes toward them. Course Information: Same as GWS 244. Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: RUSS 247 — Literature and Fantasy in Russia Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Fantasy as a literary genre. Comparison of the artistic strategies employed by works of literature and film into which the fantastic intrudes in the form of alternate states of consciousness such as dream, inebriation, and madness. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: RUSS 248 — Russian Visual and Material Culture Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Non-textual manifestations of Russian culture such as painting, sculpture, architecture, design and decorative arts in a way that emphasizes how an object's compositional medium relates to its aesthetic and functional purposes. Prerequisites: Completion of ENGL 160 ; or any 100-level RUSS or AH course. Creative Arts course. Course Information: Same as AH 248. Taught in English.

Course: RUSS 321 — Great Russian 19th-Century Novels and the European Tradition Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: Reading and interpretation of various 19th-century novels, including, but not limited to, the works of Pushkin, Lermontov, Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, and Tolstoy. Emphasis on the socio-historic and intellectual context of these works. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Great Russian 19th-Century Novels and the European Tradition
metadata.subject: Russian (RUSS)

text: Course: RUSS 330 — Art and Politics: Soviet and Post-Soviet Literature Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 Description: An examination of various Russian literary and aesthetic practices with a focus on how writers defined their art vis-à-vis its contribution to or autonomy from the ideological goals of the Soviet state. Course Information: Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Art and Politics: Soviet and Post-Soviet Literature
metadata.subject: Russian (RUSS)

text: Course: RUSS 399 — Independent Study Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 1-3 Description: Investigation of special problems under the general direction of a staff member. Prerequisites: Junior standing, consent of the instructor and the head of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: RUSS 410 — Structure of Modern Russian Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to Russian morphology and phonology. Examination of the Russian language as a system with particular attention to verb conjugation and noun declension, with the goal of improving students’ practical language skills. Prerequisites: RUSS 201 ; and credit or concurrent registration in RUSS 202 ; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in RUSS 202 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in RUSS 202 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prereq Codes (parsed): RUSS 202 Coreq Codes (parsed): RUSS 202

Course: RUSS 440 — Topics in Russian Culture and Cultural Studies Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of various topics in Russian culture through an interdisciplinary prism, addressing intersections between visual and verbal arts as well as high and popular culture. Content varies. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours for undergraduate students or 8 hours for graduate students, if topics vary, and with consent of the instructor. Taught in English. All texts are available in English. Students pursuing a major or minor in Russian, or an MA or PhD in Slavic Studies, will be required to read primary texts in the target language.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Russian Culture and Cultural Studies
metadata.subject: Russian (RUSS)

text: Course: RUSS 460 — Topics in Russian Literature Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a major author, movement, genre, or special topic. Content varies. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor Junior, senior, or graduate standing. Or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 time(s) if topics vary. Taught in English.

Course: RUSS 499 — Independent Study Subject: Russian (RUSS) Credits: 1-4 Description: Investigation of special problems under the general direction of a staff member. Prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing, consent of the instructor and the head of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Graduate students may register for more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: SABR 191 — Study Abroad Subject: Study Abroad (SABR) Credits: 0-18 Description: Credit for foreign study. Final determination of credit is approved by the department/college and is based on the student's completion of the work. Course Information: May be repeated. Students do not register for this course. Special administrative course created to transcript study abroad courses. Course detail is added directly to students' academic records by the Office of Registration and Records.

Course: SABR 291 — Study Abroad Subject: Study Abroad (SABR) Credits: 0-18 Description: Credit for foreign study. Final determination of credit is approved by the department/college and is based on the student's completion of the work. Course Information: May be repeated. Students do not register for this course. Special administrative course created to transcript study abroad courses. Course detail is added directly to students' academic records by the Office of Registration and Records.

Course: SABR 391 — Study Abroad Subject: Study Abroad (SABR) Credits: 0-18 Description: Credit for foreign study. Final determination of credit is approved by the department/college and is based on the student's completion of the work. Course Information: May be repeated. Students do not register for this course. Special administrative course created to transcript study abroad courses. Course detail is added directly to students' academic records by the Office of Registration and Records.

Course: SABR 491 — Study Abroad Subject: Study Abroad (SABR) Credits: 0-18 Description: Credit for foreign study. Final determination of credit is approved by the department/college and is based on the student's completion of the work. Course Information: May be repeated. Students do not register for this course. Special administrative course created to transcript study abroad courses. Course detail is added directly to students' academic records by the Office of Registration and Records.

Course: SJ 101 — Introduction to Social Justice: Stories and Struggles Subject: Social Justice (SJ) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the study of social justice through personal narrative, memoir, and biographies of individuals engaged in social and political change. The linkages between individual and broader social and political struggles. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Social Justice: Stories and Struggles
metadata.subject: Social Justice (SJ)

text: Course: SJ 201 — Theories and Practices of Social Justice Subject: Social Justice (SJ) Credits: 3 Description: Critical exploration of major theories of social justice, histories of major social justice movements, and theories and analyses of injustice that ignited these movements. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. US Society course.

metadata.class_name: Theories and Practices of Social Justice
metadata.subject: Social Justice (SJ)

text: Course: SJ 294 — Topics in Social Justice Subject: Social Justice (SJ) Credits: 1-3 Description: Study of a problem, topic, or issue relevant to the interdisciplinary area of Social Justice. Content Varies. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hours. Recommended Background: SJ 101.

Course: SJ 301 — Social Justice Capstone Subject: Social Justice (SJ) Credits: 4 Description: Interdisciplinary exploration of community engagement through a combination of academic course work and service learning activity that examines dynamics of social justice work and organizing practices. Prerequisites: SJ 101 and SJ 201. Course Information: Field work required. Requires 40 hours of service learning over the semester. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: SLAV 460 — Topics in Central and Eastern European Literature and Culture Subject: Slavic and Baltic Languages and Literatures (SLAV) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of a time period, movement, genre, or special topic. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Same as CEES 460. May be repeated up to 2 time(s), with consent of the instructor, and if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Central and Eastern European Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: Slavic and Baltic Languages and Literatures (SLAV)

text: Course: SLAV 499 — Independent Study Subject: Slavic and Baltic Languages and Literatures (SLAV) Credits: 1-4 Description: Investigation of special problems under the general direction of a staff member. Prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing, consent of the instructor and the head of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Graduate students may register for more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

metadata.subject: Slavic and Baltic Languages and Literatures (SLAV)

text: Course: SOC 100 — Introduction to Sociology Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of human societies, organizations and groups, and the interrelations among individuals, groups, and societies. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture-Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 105 — Social Problems Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Contemporary social problems examined from the perspectives of social institutions, culture, inequality, organizations and groups, political and economic structure, social change, and social policy. Course Information: May be substituted for SOC 100 as a prerequisite for other sociology courses. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 120 — Introduction to Asian American Studies Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of Asian American experiences and perspectives in socio-historical context. Introduction to major concepts, issues, and debates in the field of Asian American Studies. Course Information: Same as GLAS 120. Previously listed as SOC 125. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 201 — Introductory Sociological Statistics Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 4 Description: An introduction to the basic statistical methods used in the analysis of sociological data. 3 hours of lecture and 2 hours of laboratory per week. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or SOC 105 ; and either MATH 090, MATH 105 , or MATH 108 or the equivalent; or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: SOC 207 — Racism: Global Perspectives Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to global, transnational, and comparative perspectives on racism. Analysis of race and racism not only in the United States, but also in Africa, the Middle East, Latin America, Europe, and other contexts. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 or ENGL 161. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as BLST 207.

Course: SOC 212 — Human Sexuality: Social Perspectives Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Historical and cultural perspectives on contemporary American sexuality; knowledge, attitudes, and practices; sexuality over the life cycle, socialization; affection, interpersonal attraction; marriage, law, other institutions. Prerequisites: SOC 100.

Course: SOC 215 — Sociology of Childhood and Youth Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the meanings and social position of children and youth in society and examines how contemporary ideas about these categories emerged. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or SOC 105 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 224 — Gender and Society Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Sociological perspectives on gender as a factor in social stratification; gender role acquisition; individual and social consequences of changing social definitions of gender roles. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or GWS 101 or GWS 102. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as GWS 224.

Course: SOC 225 — Racial and Ethnic Groups Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Sociological and social-psychological analysis of racial, religious, and other ethnic groups; consideration of historical and current social problems arising from their relationships in society. Prerequisites: SOC 100 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 225 and LALS 225.

Course: SOC 226 — Latinas in the United States Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Socioeconomic conditions and cultural experiences of Latinas in the U.S. Historical and contemporary views of labor, health, education, family, identity formation and leadership. Course Information: Same as GWS 276 and LALS 276. Grade of C or better in ENGL 160 ; Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in ENGL 161. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 228 — Sociology of Asia and Asian Americans Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Asian and Asian-American culture, institutions, and organization; immigration, population, settlement patterns; occupations and poverty; family and ethnic identification; inequality and politics; values, prejudice, discrimination. Prerequisites: SOC 100. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as GLAS 228.

metadata.class_name: Sociology of Asia and Asian Americans
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 229 — Sociology of Latinos Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Examines social, political and economic issues affecting Latino groups. While focusing on the process of racialization, the course also examines immigration, language rights, gender and sexuality, labor market, media, and youth. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or LALS 102 or SOC 105 or LALS 103 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as LALS 229.

Course: SOC 231 — Criminology Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory survey of theories exploring the origins, organization, meanings, and control of crime. Course Information: Same as CLJ 220. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture.

Course: SOC 241 — Social Inequalities Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Dimensions of inequality: economy, education, housing, health care; power, status and self-esteem; inequality, and social policy. Prerequisites: SOC 100. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 244 — Sociology of Work Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Impact of bureaucracy, technology, and automation; changing composition of labor force: women, youth, elderly, racial and ethnic minorities; international comparisons; policy implications. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or SOC 105 ; or consent of the instructor. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 245 — Marriage and Family Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: The family as an interactional system, an organization, and a social institution; extended family ties, mate selection, marital roles, socialization, marital dissolution, family life course and change. Prerequisites: SOC 100. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 246 — Sociology of Religion Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Analysis of the structures and functions of religious institutions in modern society.Special attention to the interplay between religion and other social phenomena, such as economics, politics, and secular culture. Prerequisites: One social sciences Course Distribution Credit (CDC) course and sophomore standing. Course Information: Same as RELS 246. Occasional field trips. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 251 — Health and Medicine Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Health care systems; special emphasis on United States; dimensions of wellness and sickness including mental health; health providers, organizations, and institutions and their relations. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.
Course: SOC 258 — Race and Urban Life Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Examines the experiences of Blacks in urban areas since the 1900's. Course Information: Same as BLST 258.

Course: SOC 265 — Sociology of Politics Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: The exercise of power and power structures; alternative political systems; relationship between state and society; political attitudes, participation, and organizations; political change, reform, and revolution. Prerequisites: SOC 100. Individual and Society course.

Course: SOC 268 — Introduction to Comparative Sociology Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Comparisons of population, culture, economics, politics, and social relations among contemporary societies. Relations among institutional areas and among societies. Prerequisites: 3 hours of social science courses. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: SOC 271 — Race and the Politics of Incarceration Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Examines how incarceration and criminalization affects black people in contemporary society. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in BLST 100 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SOC 100 or Grade of C or better in CLJ 101. Individual and Society course, and US Society course. Course Information: Same as BLST 271 and CLJ 271.

metadata.class_name: Race and the Politics of Incarceration
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 276 — Urban Sociology Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the history, patterns, and consequences of urban places and life in those places. Prerequisites: SOC 100. Individual and Society course, and US Society course.

Course: SOC 280 — Data and Society Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Examines how data changes society and how those changes differ by social group. Learn how data-driven products and services obtain data, and how those products/services use that data. Includes data science lab to explore and visualize data using R. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory.

Course: SOC 285 — Politics, Algorithms and People Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Political and digital lives have become intertwined with the importance of social media, social media activism, and politics. Explores political agency and political sociology in a digitized society.

Course: SOC 290 — Sociology Major Orientation and Success Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 2 Description: Introduces sociology majors to issues relevant to academic success and orients them to the UIC sociology department’s intellectual life, resources and opportunities. Emphasis on exploring sociological interests and career paths. Prerequisites: SOC 100 or SOC 105 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. Students are advised to enroll in the course within one or two semesters after declaring the major.

Course: SOC 296 — Supervised Study or Research Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 1-3 Description: Special projects arranged in advance by faculty or student initiative. Prerequisites: 9 hours of sociology, consent of the instructor, and approval of the department prior to registration. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours with approval. Students may register in more than one section per term. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: SOC 298 — Internship in Sociological Applications Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Placement in a university or external organization where students participate in a project using sociological skills under the direction of a field supervisor. Prerequisites: SOC 201 and SOC 202; and approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: SOC 300 — Introduction to Sociological Research Methods Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 4 Description: Survey of the principal methods of social research; problem and concept formation, research design, sampling reliability, internal and external validity, control of alternative explanations, ethical responsibilities of researchers. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; and one 100 or 200-level course in Sociology; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as SOC 202. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: SOC 385 — Introduction to Sociological Theory Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: A survey of the major approaches to explaining social pheomena drawn from representative nineteenth and twentieth-century social theorists. Emphasis on present-day applicability of these approaches. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and two 200-level elective courses in sociology or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

Course: SOC 401 — Sociological Statistics Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 4 Description: Descriptive and inferential statistics for graduate and advanced undergraduate sociology majors and related fields. Tests of means, regression, correlation, analysis of variance, and related topics. Prerequisites: SOC 201 and two additional 200-level sociology electives; or graduate standing or consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: SOC 402 — Intermediate Sociological Statistics Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 4 Description: Covers general linear models emphasizing regression, analysis of variance and covariance, simple structural equation models, simple categorical methods and elementary matrix algebra. Prerequisites: SOC 401. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: SOC 405 — Writing in the Social Sciences Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Leads to effective, clear writing for a social science audience. Teaches how to organize ideas, avoid tiresome jargon, and write with precision. Prerequisites: 6 hours of upper-division social science courses. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 407 — Seminar in Comparative Racialization Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an interdisciplinary and comparative approach to the making and remaking of "race" and the resultant racialized experiences of different groups in the U.S. and globally. Prerequisites: BLST 207 or SOC 207 or BLST 225 or SOC 225 or LALS 225 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as BLST 407. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 409 — Senior Research Practicum Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students with an opportunity to conduct their own sociological research. Over the course of the semester, students will refine a research question, gather and analyze data, and draft an academic paper based on their results. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SOC 201 and SOC 300 ; and Sociology majors in their final year of undergraduate study; and consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in SOC 201 and SOC 300 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SOC 201 and SOC 300 Prereq Codes (parsed): SOC 201, SOC 300 Coreq Codes (parsed): SOC 201, SOC 300

Course: SOC 422 — Chicanas and Latinas: Self and Society Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 Description: The experiences of Chicanas and Latinas through the lens of contemporary sociological research. Topics to be discussed include: community formation and activism, feminisms, sexuality, religion, health, family, immigration, education, work, media, etc. Course Information: Same as LALS 422.

metadata.class_name: Chicanas and Latinas: Self and Society
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 424 — Sociology of Gender Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Variety and change in gender roles; patterns and consequences of gender inequality; gender and sexuality; gender and social institutions such as family, economy. Prerequisites: SOC 224 , or any 100 or 200-level GWS course and an additional 200 or 300-level elective in sociology or gender and women studies; Junior standing or above; or graduate standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GWS 425. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 425 — Race and Ethnicity Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Critical examination of the conceptual frameworks and empirical findings in the study of race and ethnicity. Prerequisites: SOC 225 an additional 200- or 300- level elective in Sociology; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 426 — Topics in Race, Ethnicity, and Gender Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive examination of a specialized topic in race, ethnicity and gender. The specific topic of the course varies depending on the faculty offering it. Prerequisites: SOC 224 ; or SOC 225 ; and junior standing or above and an additional 200 or 300-level elective in sociology; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 times. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Race, Ethnicity, and Gender
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 428 — Asian/Asian American Women in the Global Economy Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the racialization and feminization of a global division of labor and focuses primarily on Asian and Asian American women's participation and incorporation as workers and key actors in the development of the global economy. Prerequisites: At least one GLAS or GWS or SOC course; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as GLAS 428 and GWS 428. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Previously listed as ASAM 428.

metadata.class_name: Asian/Asian American Women in the Global Economy
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 433 — Latin American Migration to the U.S Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Latin American migration to the U.S. International migration theories, family remittances, transnational linkages, dual citizenship, and past and current U.S. immigration policy debates. Prerequisites: One course in LALS or SOC; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LALS 433. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Migration to the U.S
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 440 — Topics in Organizations and Institutions Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive examination of a specialized topic announced when the class is scheduled. Prerequisites: SOC 244 or MGMT 340 , and an additional 200-level sociology elective, and junior standing; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 2 times. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: SOC 441 — Social Stratification Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The nature of systems of differentiation and ranking in societies and their consequences; emphasis on class structure in the United States; prestige, status, power, and social mobility in the United States and other societies. Prerequisites: SOC 241 and an additional 200 or 300-level elective in Sociology; and Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 444 — Race and Gender in Organizations Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines how organizations operate in society, creating racial/gender inequalities and making space for resistance, and how race and gender are constructed and embodied in them. Prerequisites: SOC 244 or MGMT 340. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 445 — Sociology of the Family Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Variety and change in family patterns; family formation and break-up; parents' and childrens' effects on each other; influences of culture and political economy; consequences for other institutions. Prerequisites: SOC 224 , or SOC 245 and an additional 200 or 300-level Sociology elective; and Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 446 — Race, Ethnicity, and Gender in American Religion Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Religious institutions in the U.S. as a crucible for racial, ethnic, and gender identities, group formation, and intergroup relations; major world religions represented in the U.S. Prerequisites: SOC 246 and an additional 200 or 300- level elective in Sociology; and Junior standing or above; or consent of instructor. Course Information: Same as RELS 446. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Race, Ethnicity, and Gender in American Religion
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 447 — Organizations Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Characteristics of business, government, and not-for-profit organizations; approaches used to study organizations; theoretical and empirical analysis of organizational processes. Prerequisites: SOC 241 or MGMT 340 or SOC 244 and an additional 200 or 300-level elective in sociology; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as MGMT 447. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 448 — Sociology of Development Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Historical, economic, political, social, and geographic factors shaping national and international development experiences and outcomes. Prerequisites: 6 hours of upper-division social science courses or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 451 — Medical Sociology Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey of major topics in sociology of health and medicine including social definitions of health and illness, patient practitioner interaction, the organization of health institutions and professions. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 455 — Topics in Medical Sociology Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive examination of a specialized topic announced when the class is scheduled. Prerequisites: SOC 451 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: SOC 465 — Topics in Sociology of Politics Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive examination of a specialized topic announced when the class is scheduled. Prerequisites: 6 hours of upper-division sociology or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 465. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: SOC 471 — Population Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: The measurement and study of major trends and differentials in fertility, mortality, migration, growth, and compositional characteristics of the population of the United States and other nations. Prerequisites: SOC 201 and an additional 200 or 300-level course in sociology; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as EPID 471. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 473 — Cities and Regions Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Characteristics, conditions, and consequences of structure and change of cities and metropolitan regions. Spatial, political economy, cultural perspectives. Census, ecological, historical, comparative data for cities. Prerequisites: SOC 201 and an additional 200 or 300-level course in sociology; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 474 — Latinx Youth: Coming of Age in the U.S Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Discursive and cultural positioning of Latina/o/x youth in the US. Explores how youth shape identity, culture, education, politics, community. Using concept of intersectionality, explores links to gender, class, and sexuality. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. Same as GWS 476 and LALS 476.

metadata.class_name: Latinx Youth: Coming of Age in the U.S
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 476 — Topics in Urban Sociology Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Intensive examination of a specialized topic announced when the class is scheduled. Prerequisites: 6 hours of upper-division sociology or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: SOC 485 — Classical Social Theory Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Survey and analysis of classical European and American social theory. Examination of how theorists such as Marx, Weber, Durkheim, Veblen and Park defined and described society within their own social contexts and how we derive meaning from these theories. Prerequisites: SOC 385 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 487 — Current Social Theory Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Review and evaluation of major currents in sociological theory since the 1940s. Prerequisites: SOC 385 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SOC 490 — Igniting Sociological Futures: Senior Capstone Experience Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 4 Description: Focuses on sociological concepts, competencies and complete a hands-on experience with a community organization while developing a professional portfolio highlighting their accomplishments and preparing them for their professional and educational goals. Prerequisites: SOC 300 and SOC 385 ; and senior standing or above; and one 400-level elective in sociology; and consent of the instructor. Enrollment is restricted to sociology majors in their last year of study. Course Information: Previously listed at SOC 400. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Igniting Sociological Futures: Senior Capstone Experience
metadata.subject: Sociology (SOC)

text: Course: SOC 496 — Independent Study or Research Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 1-9 Description: Extensive readings in specialized areas of sociology or empirical research for advanced undergraduate or graduate students. Prerequisites: 18 hours of sociology, excluding SOC 296 and SOC 299, consent of the instructor, and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated with approval. Students may register in more than one section per term. Approval to repeat course granted by the department. Undergraduate students may repeat course for maximum of 9 hours of credit. Class Schedule Information: This course counts toward the limited number of independent study hours accepted toward the degree and the major.

Course: SOC 499 — Senior Thesis Subject: Sociology (SOC) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual study for students working on a senior thesis under the supervision of a faculty advisor. This course is required for students graduating with highest departmental distinction. Prerequisites: SOC 490 ; and senior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours, with approval of the department. Students may register for more than one section per term. Previously listed as SOC 299.

Course: SPAN 101 — Elementary Spanish I Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 4 Description: First course in the four-semester program where students learn Spanish through real-world tasks. The purpose is to learn Spanish in order to use it beyond the classroom in meaningful and authentic ways and the Novice-mid level of proficiency. Prerequisites: Appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Class is taught in Spanish, at a level appropriate for the course; the main purpose is not grammar learning. Course includes: regular in-classroom interactions, substantial reading and listening tasks for homework, regular class presentations, and one exploratory visit to a Hispanic neighborhood in Chicago. One credit hour takes place online, plus homework.

Course: SPAN 102 — Elementary Spanish II Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 4 Description: Second course in the four-semester program where students learn Spanish through real-world tasks. The purpose is to learn Spanish in order to use it beyond the classroom in meaningful and authentic ways and at the novice-high level of proficiency. Prerequisites: SPAN 101 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Class is taught in Spanish, at a level appropriate for the course; the main purpose is not grammar learning. Course includes: regular in-classroom interactions, substantial reading and listening tasks for homework, regular class presentations, and one exploratory visit to a Hispanic neighborhood in Chicago. One credit hour takes place online, plus homework.

Course: SPAN 103 — Intermediate Spanish I Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 4 Description: Third course in the four-semester program where students learn Spanish through real-world tasks. The purpose is to learn Spanish for use beyond the classroom in meaningful and authentic ways and at the Intermediate-low level of proficiency. Prerequisites: SPAN 102 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Class is taught in Spanish, at a level appropriate for the course; the main purpose is not grammar learning. Course includes: regular in-classroom interactions, substantial reading and listening tasks for homework, regular class presentations, and one exploratory visit to a Hispanic neighborhood in Chicago. One credit hour takes place online, plus homework.

Course: SPAN 104 — Intermediate Spanish II Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 4 Description: Last course in the four-semester program where students learn Spanish through real-world tasks. The purpose is to learn Spanish to use it beyond the classroom in meaningful and authentic ways and at the Intermediate-mid level of proficiency. Prerequisites: SPAN 103 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Class is taught in Spanish, at a level appropriate for the course; the main purpose is not grammar learning. Course includes: six 30-minute face-to-face interactions with native speakers of Spanish from Latin America and Spain via TalkAbroad; regular in-classroom interactions, substantial reading and listening tasks for homework; regular class presentations; and one exploratory visit to a Hispanic neighborhood in Chicago. One credit hour takes place online, plus homework.

Course: SPAN 113 — Spanish for Heritage Speakers I Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to reading and writing for students who already possess basic to intermediate communicative skills in the language. Content focuses on the Latino experience in the U.S. Emphasis on critical language awareness. Prerequisites: Appropriate score on the department placement test or the equivalent AP or IB test score. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class is taught entirely in Spanish. One credit hour takes place online, plus homework. Use of a computer and internet access is required.

Course: SPAN 114 — Spanish for Heritage Speakers II Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 4 Description: Reading and writing for students who already possess advanced communicative skills in the language. Content focuses on the Latino experience in the U.S. Emphasis on critical language awareness. Prerequisites: Appropriate score on the department placement test; or the equivalent AP or IB test score; or successful completion of Spanish 113. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class is taught entirely in Spanish. One credit hour takes place online, plus homework. Use of a computer and internet access is required.

Course: SPAN 192 — Latin American Women Writers in Translation Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to literature by Latin American women from the seventeenth century to the present. Focus on the role literature has played in the negotiation of gender identities in the private and the public spheres. Course Information: Same as GWS 192 , and LALS 192. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Women Writers in Translation
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 196 — Totalitarianism, Writing and Cinema Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: An introduction to French, Spanish, and Italian writing and films dealing with the issue of totalitarianism. Various authors are examined within a broad context of European thinking on totalitarianism. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as FR 196 , and ITAL 196. Taught in English. Two additional hours for viewing films (every two weeks).

Course: SPAN 200 — Spanish Conversation and Basic Writing Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Practice of conversational strategies for developing communicative competence in Spanish. Short essay composition for developing writing competence in Spanish. Review of basic grammatical structures. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 104. Course Information: Not open to fluent Spanish speakers.

Course: SPAN 202 — Spanish Grammar in Practice Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: A review of the grammar of Spanish language. Covers all topics from the structure and components of the nominal phrase to the sentence. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 104 or Grade of C or better in SPAN 114 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test.

Course: SPAN 203 — Extensive Reading and Writing for Non-Native Speakers of Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Develops students' linguistic, rhetorical, organizational, and analytical skills in Spanish composition, as well as reading and critical thinking skills in Spanish. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 104 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 ; and completion of the university writing requirement. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Course Information: Open only to non-native speakers of Spanish. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202

metadata.class_name: Extensive Reading and Writing for Non-Native Speakers of Spanish
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 204 — Extensive Reading and Writing for Heritage Speakers of Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Develops students' linguistic, rhetorical, organizational, and analytical skills in Spanish composition, as well as reading and critical thinking skills in Spanish. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 114 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 ; or consent of the instructor; completion of the university writing requirement. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Course Information: Open only to heritage speakers of Spanish. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202

metadata.class_name: Extensive Reading and Writing for Heritage Speakers of Spanish
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 206 — Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: General introduction to the major areas of linguistic analysis: phonology, syntax, meaning, and variation. Preparation for formal research in the field of linguistics. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202

Course: SPAN 207 — European Cinema Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: An overview of the major developments in European cinema from the post-World II period to the present. Prerequisites: ENGL 160. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Same as GER 207 and MOVI 207.

Course: SPAN 210 — Introduction to the Formal Analysis of Hispanic Texts Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Formal and content analysis of Hispanic essays, short stories and novels, poems, and plays. Application of basic literary concepts through the writing of critical and argumentative analysis. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 202 ; and Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204 and completion of the university writing requirement. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204 and completion of the university writing requirement Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204 and completion of the university writing requirement Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 203, SPAN 204 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 203, SPAN 204

metadata.class_name: Introduction to the Formal Analysis of Hispanic Texts
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 212 — Cultural and Literary Studies in Spain and/or Latin America Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Prepares students to examine problems of cultural and literary analysis from a theoretical perspective. It will provide a broader overview for the more focused topic courses at the 300 level. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and Grade of C or better in SPAN 210. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Cultural and Literary Studies in Spain and/or Latin America
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 220 — Spanish for Business and Law I Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to conversation, composition, and grammar, emphasizing usage specific to the areas of business and law. Familiarizes students with the legal and business culture in the Hispanic world. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 ; and completion of the university writing requirement; or approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Recommended Background: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Grade of C or better in SPAN 204. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202

metadata.class_name: Spanish for Business and Law I
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 221 — Spanish for Health Personnel I Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Develops students’ communicative competence in Spanish in the medical and health field through the introduction of specialized vocabulary and communication skills. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 ; and completion of the university writing requirement; or approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 202 Recommended Background: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SPAN 204. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 202

Course: SPAN 224 — Bilingual/Bicultural Hispanic American Writers Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the phenomenon of the bilingual and bicultural Hispanic American writer. Prerequisites: Completion of the University Writing Requirement. US Society course. Course Information: Taught in English.

Course: SPAN 225 — Spanish and Latin American Culture through Literature and Film Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the Hispanic cultures, both Peninsular and Latin American, as represented in literature and film throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. Prerequisites: Completion of the university writing requirement. Course Information: Same as MOVI 225. Taught in English. Two hours per week to view films. Class Schedule Information: To be properly enrolled, students must register for one Lecture/Discussion and one Lab. World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Spanish and Latin American Culture through Literature and Film
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 226 — Early Modern Spanish and Colonial Latin American Literature and Culture in Translation Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to a variety of Early Modern Peninsular and Colonial Latin American literary texts and other cultural artifacts in translation. Prerequisites: Completion of the university writing requirement. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course. Course Information: Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Early Modern Spanish and Colonial Latin American Literature and Culture in Translation
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 228 — Translation/Interpreting for the Professions I: Medical and Business Spanish-English Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the theory of translation and translations of simple texts in both directions: Spanish/English and English/Spanish. Prerequisites: SPAN 202 and sophmore standing or above; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Translation/Interpreting for the Professions I: Medical and Business Spanish-English
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 230 — Civilization and Culture of Spain Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Historical, social, and cultural aspects of Spanish civilization. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204 Course Information: Taught in Spanish. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 203, SPAN 204 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 203, SPAN 204

Course: SPAN 231 — Civilization and Culture of Latin America Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Historical, social, and cultural aspects of Latin American civilization. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 204 Course Information: Taught in Spanish. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 203, SPAN 204 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 203, SPAN 204

metadata.class_name: Civilization and Culture of Latin America
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 278 — Latin American/Latino Film Studies Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 4 Description: Introduction to the history and major aesthetic movements of Latin American cinema. Course Information: Same as LALS 278 and MOVI 278. Taught in English. Includes a film screening component. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: SPAN 285 — Zombies, Plagues, and Other Pandemics in Literature and Visual Media Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Pandemics and their effects on human beings on a physical, emotional, and societal level, as seen through literature and visual media across nations. Course Information: Same as ITAL 285 and LCSL 285. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Zombies, Plagues, and Other Pandemics in Literature and Visual Media
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 295 — Latino Literary Studies Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Major trends, genres, works, themes, and writers related to Latino history and culture, mainstream and minority U.S., Latin American and third world literatures. Course Information: Same as ENGL 295 and LALS 295. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: SPAN 302 — Exploring Spanish Grammar Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Explores advanced topics in Spanish grammar from a linguistic perspective. Topics range from the noun phrase to complex sentence structure. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 202.

Course: SPAN 303 — Advanced Oral Presentation, Writing, and Analysis Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced instruction in linguistic, rhetorical, organizational, and analytical skills in Spanish composition. Further development of reading and critical thinking skills in Spanish. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 203 or Grade of C or better in SPAN 204 ; and completion of the university writing requirement.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Oral Presentation, Writing, and Analysis
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 304 — Introduction to Spanish Creative Writing for Heritage Speakers Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of writing tools through analysis of Spanish literary texts and through creative writing exercises. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 204 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as LALS 304. This course may not be used to satisfy the prerequisite for ENGL 490 , ENGL 491 , or ENGL 492. Extensive computer use required. This course is intended for heritage students, but may be taken by students demonstrating near-native writing proficiency with the permission of the course instructor. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in SPAN 210.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Spanish Creative Writing for Heritage Speakers
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 320 — Spanish for Business and Law II Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Enhances students’ ability to function effectively in legal and business contexts by building and improving their vocabulary and communication skills for these contexts. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 220 ; and completion of the university writing requirement; and sophomore standing or above. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SPAN 204.

metadata.class_name: Spanish for Business and Law II
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 321 — Spanish for Health Personnel II Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Further develops students’ communicative competence, grammar, and vocabulary in Spanish for the medical and health fields. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 221 ; and sophomore standing or above. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SPAN 203 or Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in SPAN 204.

Course: SPAN 328 — Advanced Translation/Interpreting for the Professions: II Medical, Legal & Business Spanish-English Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: The translation of specialized texts from the source language into the target language. Focus on legal, commercial and health related vocabulary and concepts. Some translation of literary texts may be included to expand students' cultural knowledge. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 220 or Grade of C or better in SPAN 221 or Grade of C or better in SPAN 228 ; and sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Advanced Translation/Interpreting for the Professions: II Medical, Legal & Business Spanish-English
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 360 — Study Abroad Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 0-18 Description: Subjects taken in a variety of areas while studying abroad in Spain, or Central or South America during the student¿s sophomore, junior or senior year of study at UIC. Prerequisites: Approval of the Department. Course Information: May be repeated. Recommended Background: SPAN 104 or SPAN 114.

Course: SPAN 361 — The Structure of Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the formal study of the syntax of Spanish, from the combination of words into phrases to the combination of phrases into sentences. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206 or LING 150 ; and consent of the instructor; and sophomore standing or above.

Course: SPAN 362 — Sounds of Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the phonetic system of Spanish and its variation throughout the Spanish-speaking world via phonetic transcription, acoustic analysis, and phonological analysis of data. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206 or LING 150 ; and consent of the instructor; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as SPAN 205.

Course: SPAN 363 — Spanish in Society Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Investigation of the role of language in society or of society in language with a focus on Spanish and issues of Latinos. Sociolinguistics investigates aspects of language structure and use. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206 or LING 150 ; and consent of the instructor; and sophomore standing or above.

Course: SPAN 364 — Acquisition of Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of the psychological and social aspects of the acquisition of Spanish as a first language, a second language, and in bilingual contexts. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206 ; and sophomore standing or above.

Course: SPAN 365 — Meaning in Language Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to the study of both literal meaning and meaning in context in human language. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206 or LING 150 ; and consent of the instructor; and sophomore standing or above.

Course: SPAN 366 — Current Topics in Spanish Linguistics Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Topics will reflect the general agenda of linguistics. May cover advanced issues in Phonetics or Phonology, Syntax, Semantics or Pragmatics, SLA or HL Instruction. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206 ; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

Course: SPAN 367 — Meaning and Context in Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to linguistic pragmatics, that is, the study of the role of context in interpretation, with a focus on the Spanish-speaking world. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206. Course Information: Taught in Spanish.

Course: SPAN 370 — Writing and Research in the Major Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 1 Description: Perfecting writing and expository skills in English. Required for majors in the department. Prerequisites: Junior or senior standing and approval of the department. Course Information: Same as FR 370 and ITAL 370.

metadata.class_name: Writing and Research in the Major
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 375 — Current Topics in Hispanic Studies Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Study of Hispanic literary and/or cultural production focusing on a specific theme, critical approach, or genre-related issue which currently has special relevance within the discipline. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 210. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours, if topics vary, and with consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212

Course: SPAN 376 — Topics in Politics, the Economy, and Law in Hispanic Culture Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Basic introduction to the syntax and rhetoric of legality, order and hierarchy in Spain and/or Latin America as these elements are manifested in literary and cultural texts. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 210. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours, if topics vary, and with consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212

metadata.class_name: Topics in Politics, the Economy, and Law in Hispanic Culture
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 377 — Topics in Health, the Psyche, and the Human Body in Hispanic Culture Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Topics will address issues regarding the representation of the body, and different notions of illness and health in Hispanic literature, film, and other media. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 210. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours, if topics vary, and with consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212

metadata.class_name: Topics in Health, the Psyche, and the Human Body in Hispanic Culture
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 378 — Topics in Hispanic Cultural and Media Studies Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Studies of transculturation as a guiding principle in the development of Hispanic identities. Exploration of changing definitions of race, nation, immigration, hybridity, and consumption. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 210. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours, if topics vary, and with consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212

metadata.class_name: Topics in Hispanic Cultural and Media Studies
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 379 — Topics in Cultural Difference and the Politics of Translation Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of the ways in which different forms of cultural production participate in the construction and deconstruction of national, regional, class, and gender identities. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 210. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212 Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours, if topics vary and with consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 212. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 212

metadata.class_name: Topics in Cultural Difference and the Politics of Translation
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 380 — Professional Development Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 1 Description: Students will be trained in the preparation of resumes, curriculum vitae, and presentation letters for academic and professional settings and will practice interviewing skills. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 206. Senior standing or completion of at least two 300-400 level SPAN courses (excluding SPAN 320 , 321 , and 360) and approval of the department.

Course: SPAN 399 — Independent Study Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 1-3 Description: Individual reading or research project under the supervision of a faculty member. Prerequisites: SPAN 206 or SPAN 212 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours. Students may register for more than one section per term.

Course: SPAN 400 — History of the Spanish Language Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Origins and development of Spanish; phonological, morphological, syntactic development of the language; foreign influences; origin of dialects. Prerequisites: SPAN 362 or SPAN 401 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SPAN 406 — Spanish Sociolinguistics Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Past and current theoretical and empirical sociolinguistics as applied to the study of variation within Spanish and U.S. Hispanic communities. Prerequisites: SPAN 363 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SPAN 407 — Methods of Literary and Cultural Analysis Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to basic tools and critical vocabulary to conduct advanced work in Hispanic literature. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate horus. Taught in Spanish or English.

metadata.class_name: Methods of Literary and Cultural Analysis
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 408 — Hispanic Dialectology Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Descriptive and historical analysis of the most salient linguistic phenomena of peninsular and American Spanish dialects. Prerequisites: SPAN 362 or SPAN 401; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SPAN 409 — Semantics and Pragmatics in Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the study of meaning in language with a focus on Spanish. Includes formal/compositional semantics and an introduction to pragmatics. Prerequisites: SPAN 365 or SPAN 401; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SPAN 411 — Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Spanish Literature and Culture Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of topics and theoretical approaches to the literature and culture of medieval and early modern Spain. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Spanish Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 414 — Topics in Cervantes' Don Quijote Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examination of current critical and theoretical approaches to Cervantes Don Quijote, including questions of gender, class, historiography, and ideology. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

Course: SPAN 421 — Topics in 18th and 19th Century Spanish Literature and Culture Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of topics and theoretical approaches to Peninsular literature and culture from the Neoclassical period through the Generation of 1898. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in 18th and 19th Century Spanish Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 422 — Topics in 20th and 21st Century Spanish Literature and Culture Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of topics; sociological and historical approaches to the literature and culture from the vanguard movements of the early 20th century through the present day. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in 20th and 21st Century Spanish Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 427 — Studies in Language Policy and Cultural Identity Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the development, articulation, and effects of language policies on identity formation and culture. Focuses on the United States and the Spanish language, although other countries and languages are included. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above. Reading and writing knowledge of Spanish. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Studies in Language Policy and Cultural Identity
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 430 — Topics in Colonial History, Literature and Culture Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics in colonial literature, history and culture intended to introduce students to the main methodologies, paradigms, issues and critical approaches to colonial studies. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the intstructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Colonial History, Literature and Culture
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 431 — Topics in Latin American Letters from the Revolutionary Era to Independence Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Nineteenth-century literary trends from the beginnings of the novel through Romanticism and Realism to Urban naturalism. Prose and poetry. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Latin American Letters from the Revolutionary Era to Independence
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 434 — Topics in Latin American Letters from Modernismo to the Early 1970's Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Emergence of new literary and cultural trends from the beginning of the 20th century to the end of the so-called Latin American Boom. It may include fiction, poetry, film, theater, as well as less traditional genres. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Latin American Letters from Modernismo to the Early 1970's
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 435 — Topics in Contemporary Urban Latin American and Latino Culture, Literature and the Arts Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Study of particular cultural, artistic or literary phenomenon in urban Latin American and Latino culture, literature or the arts. Emphasis on cultural studies and/or literary analysis. Critical writing is an important component of the course. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above for undergraduate students, completion of two 300-level courses in Spanish literature; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Contemporary Urban Latin American and Latino Culture, Literature and the Arts
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 436 — Special Topics in the Teaching of Spanish Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which course is given. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. Taught in English. Some semesters, may be taught in Spanish.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in the Teaching of Spanish
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 440 — Theory and Methods in Teaching Heritage Speakers Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Reviews theories in bilingual development, sociolinguistics, and language teaching in order to understand best practices in and develop coherent materials for teaching heritage language learners. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 363 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 448 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 449 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 363 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 448 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 449 Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Course is taught online and internet/computer access is required. Recommended Background: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 363 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 448 or Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 449. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 363, SPAN 448, SPAN 449 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 363, SPAN 448, SPAN 449

metadata.class_name: Theory and Methods in Teaching Heritage Speakers
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)

text: Course: SPAN 448 — Foundations of Second Language Teaching Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Provides an introduction to second language acquisition research and its implications for communicative language teaching. Emphasis is on creating activities to develop high school students' communicative abilities in speaking and listening. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor and three courses at the 200 and 300 levels. Course Information: Same as FR 448 and GER 448. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English.

Course: SPAN 449 — Teaching Second Language Literacy and Cultural Awareness Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Examines the nature of literacy as a reciprocal relationship between readers, writers, texts and culture. Students learn the practical and theoretical foundations of classroom teaching of second language reading and writing skills. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor and three courses at the 200 and 300 levels. Course Information: Same as FR 449 , and GER 449. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Second Language Literacy and Cultural Awareness
metadata.subject: Spanish (SPAN)
