text: Course: SPAN 451 — Educational Practice with Seminar I Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 6 Description: The first half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, and approval of the department. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: SPAN 452 — Educational Practice with Seminar II Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 6 Description: The second half of a two-segment sequence of practice teaching, including seminar, to meet certification requirements for teaching in grades six through twelve. Prerequisites: Good academic standing in a teacher education program, completion of 100 clock hours of pre-student-teaching field experiences, credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 451 , and approval of the department. Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 451 , and approval of the department Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in SPAN 451 , and approval of the department Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Conference and one Practice. Prereq Codes (parsed): SPAN 451 Coreq Codes (parsed): SPAN 451

Course: SPAN 487 — Computer Assisted Language Learning Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: An introduction to computer assisted language learning (CALL): the use of computer technology in second language reading and research. The effectiveness of CALL technology is assessed based on SLA theory and research studies. Prerequisites: LING 483 or CIE 483 or GER 448 or FR 448 or SPAN 448 or GER 449 or FR 449 or SPAN 449 ; or SPAN 502 or FR 502 or the equivalent; and senior standing or above. Course Information: Same as GER 487 and LING 487. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Taught in English. Extensive computer use required.

Course: SPAN 494 — Special Topics Subject: Spanish (SPAN) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Topics will vary from term to term and may cover such areas as literary theory or culture. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and approval of the department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term. May be taught in English or Spanish.

Course: SPED 201 — Children’s Literature and Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Examination of children’s and young adult literature focused on how disabilities are portrayed and how literature encapsulates societal attitudes, beliefs, and stereotypes contributing to access and equity of children with disabilities in schools. Course Information: Same as ED 201. This is a blended course. Creative Arts course.

Course: SPED 202 — International Perspectives: Inclusive Education and Schooling Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Focuses on international comparative views of how different educational systems include students with disabilities. Course Information: Same as ED 202. Extensive computer use required. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: International Perspectives: Inclusive Education and Schooling
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 410 — Exceptional Learners Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses the psychology of, identification of, and methods of instruction for exceptional learners served under all categories recognized by federal law. Course Information: Field work required. 20 hours of field work is required.

Course: SPED 416 — Methods of Instruction for Exceptional Learners Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: The purpose of this course is to address issues of instruction for individuals with special needs. Topics include effective instructional and accommodative practices and strategies in multiple areas (math, literacy, science, social studies, art). Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and admission to the Bachelor of Arts in Elementary Education program.

metadata.class_name: Methods of Instruction for Exceptional Learners
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 423 — Assessment of Monolingual and LEP Children with Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: To prepare students in use of formal and informal assessments to inform placement, instructional planning, and evaluation of English Language Learners with disabilities. Prerequisites: Restricted to students seeking LBSII or admission as a doctoral student or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Assessment of Monolingual and LEP Children with Disabilities
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 424 — Assessment of Students with Special Needs Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theoretical basis and practical application of standardized and alternative testing of children with learning and behavior difficulties. Prerequisites: SPED 410. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Assessment of Students with Special Needs
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 426 — Curricular/Behavioral Considerations for Learners with Special Needs Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Instructional practices related to academics, classroom management, individualized and group instruction for students with special needs. Prerequisites: SPED 424 or the equivalent or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Curricular/Behavioral Considerations for Learners with Special Needs
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 427 — Instructional and Behavioral Methods for English Language Learners with Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: To prepare students in the use of best practice instruction and the promotion of prosocial behavior within the context of teaching English Language Learners with disabilities. Prerequisites: Open only to Master's degree students; and consent of the instructor and successful completion of SPED 423 or equivalent. Assumes previous instructional planning for students with disabilities and practicum that is part of the certification requirements for the Learning Behavior Specialist I certification; and minimum one year teaching experience or providing direct services to students with disabilities. Recommended Background: Illinois State Board of Education certification: Learning Behavior Specialist I; minimum one year teaching experience.

metadata.class_name: Instructional and Behavioral Methods for English Language Learners with Disabilities
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 430 — Fieldwork Supervision Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 0-6 Description: Students will implement evidence-based behavioral assessments and interventions in community-based settings that provide ABA services to children, adolescents, or adults with disabilities from underrepresented groups in a field based setting. Prerequisites: Acceptance to the Master of Science in Applied Behavior Analysis, Disability, and Diversity in Urban Society program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Practice and one Clinical Practice.

Course: SPED 431 — Applying Evidence-Based Practices in Authentic Settings Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 4 Description: Students will demonstrate competence at implementing behavioral assessments and interventions. Complete a series of performance assessments and will receive individualized feedback until reaching mastery for each assessment and intervention. Prerequisites: Acceptance to the Master of Science in Applied Behavior Analysis, Disability and Diversity in Urban Society program or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Applying Evidence-Based Practices in Authentic Settings
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 432 — Foundations and Contemporary Understanding of Applied Behavior Analysis Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 4 Description: Overview of the science of ABA and its philosophical underpinnings; will be exposed to the concepts and principles underlying the science of ABA, and how the science has informed educational practices in schools, clinics, and community-based settings. Prerequisites: Acceptance to the Master of Science in ABA, Disability and Diversity in Urban Society program or consent of the instructor. Corequisites: SPED 433.

metadata.class_name: Foundations and Contemporary Understanding of Applied Behavior Analysis
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 433 — Ethics in Applied Behavior Analysis Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 4 Description: Will examine the professional and ethical obligations of practicing behavior analysts. Issues related to common ethical dilemmas, scope of competence, behavior analyst’s responsibilities to clients, and the ABA compliance code, will be discussed. Prerequisites: Acceptance to the Master of Science in ABA, Disability and Diversity in Urban Society program or consent of the instructor.

Course: SPED 442 — Language Development and Disorders Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory and research on the acquisition of phonology, syntax, semantics and pragmatics in children with and without disabilities. Models for language assessment and intervention. Prerequisites: SPED 410. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: SPED 444 — Assistive Technology for Literacy, Learning and Participation in Pre-K through High School Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Use of communication systems, computers, adapted equipment and strategies to foster participation and inclusion of students in grades preschool through high school. Course Information: Same as DHD 444.

metadata.class_name: Assistive Technology for Literacy, Learning and Participation in Pre-K through High School
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 448 — Topics in Special Education Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course or workshop on preannounced topic on the education of handicapped children, adolescents, or adults. Prerequisites: SPED 410 and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: SPED 449 — Early Childhood/Early Childhood Special Education: Perspectives, Policies and History Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Perspectives, policies, history, and foundations of Early Childhood Education and Early Childhood Special Education. Emphasis on the effects of changing economic, political, legal, social, and views of human development. Course Information: Same as EPSY 449 and EDPS 449.

metadata.class_name: Early Childhood/Early Childhood Special Education: Perspectives, Policies and History
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 461 — Political and Socio-Cultural Perspectives on Special Education Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Students will examine issues of access and equity through legislation, litigation, and socio-cultural perspectives and be introduced to major theoretical frameworks that influence special education programs. Course Information: Same as ED 461. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Political and Socio-Cultural Perspectives on Special Education
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 462 — Assessment of Individuals with Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: To prepare students in the use of standardized and formative assessment to understand student learning, inform decisions regarding placement, instructional planning, and evaluation of students with disabilities.

Course: SPED 463 — Literacy Instruction for Diverse Learners in School Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Emphasizes the components of designing, implementing, and assessing reading and writing instruction for diverse students at the early childhood/elementary level. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Literacy Instruction for Diverse Learners in School
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 465 — Understanding Students with High Incidence Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Uses major theoretical frameworks of human development to examine the characteristics and development of students with high incidence disabilities, ages 3-21. Course Information: Same as EPSY 465. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Students with High Incidence Disabilities
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 466 — Language Development, Diversity, and Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Theory and research on language development in children with disabilities, in the context of typical development. Models for language assessment and intervention. Course Information: Same as EPSY 466.

Course: SPED 467 — Understanding Students With Low Incidence Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Explores characteristics and development of children and youth with low incidence disabilities, ages 3-21, as well as how schools address their instructional needs. Course Information: Same as EPSY 467.

metadata.class_name: Understanding Students With Low Incidence Disabilities
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 471 — Curricular Adaptations for Learners with Significant Disabilities Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Provides information on the nature and needs of individuals with severe/profound disabilities and the roles of federal, state, and local education agencies play in providing services to this population. Prerequisites: SPED 461 and SPED 465 and SPED 467. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Curricular Adaptations for Learners with Significant Disabilities
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 472 — Academic and Prosocial Interventions Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the principles and concepts of data-based decision making and individualization with an emphasis on addressing the social, emotional, and behavioral needs of students with disabilities. Course Information: Same as ED 472. Field work required.

Course: SPED 473 — Teaching Math and Science with Adaptations Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Provides prospective teachers with assessment strategies and a range of adaptations, modifications, and interventions in math and science for students with disabilities. Prerequisites: SPED 461. Course Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Teaching Math and Science with Adaptations
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 481 — Theoretical Foundations and Issues of Bilingual Special Education Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Theoretical, pedagogical foundations of Bilingual Special Education to provide experienced special educators with research-based knowledge and practices to serve English Language Learners with disabilities. Prerequisites: Restricted to students seeking LBSII or admission as a doctoral student or consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Theoretical Foundations and Issues of Bilingual Special Education
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: SPED 482 — Collaborating with Families, Community, and Professionals Subject: Special Education (SPED) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the dynamics of professional collaboration with families, addressing characteristics, structures, and processes of collaboration for children and youth with and without disabilities. Course Information: Same as EPSY 482. Previously listed as SPED 582. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

metadata.class_name: Collaborating with Families, Community, and Professionals
metadata.subject: Special Education (SPED)

text: Course: STAT 101 — Introduction to Statistics Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 4 Description: Applications of statistics in the real world, displaying and describing data, normal curve, regression, probability, statistical inference, confidence intervals and hypothesis tests. Prerequisites: Grade S in MATH 090 or Grade of C or better in MATH 108 or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Credit is not given for STAT 101 if the student has credit for STAT 130. Credit is not given for STAT 101 to students in any major in the Department of Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science. Extensive computer use required. This course is offered in both a blended and traditional format. If the section is marked "Blended-Online and Classroom," use of a computer and internet access is required. Blended sections require students to do some of their coursework online. A high-speed connection, while not required, is strongly suggested. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture.

Course: STAT 130 — Introduction to Statistics for the Life Sciences Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 4 Description: Basic concepts and methods of statistics with illustrations from different areas of the life sciences; graphical and summary representations, probability, random variables, normal distribution, estimation and tests of hypotheses, t, F and chi-square. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 110 ; or appropriate score on the department placement test. Course Information: Credit is not given for STAT 130 if the student has credit for STAT 101. Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Laboratory-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Statistics for the Life Sciences
metadata.subject: Statistics (STAT)

text: Course: STAT 194 — Special Topics in Statistics Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 1-4 Description: Course content is announced prior to each term in which it is given. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. May be repeated for credit. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: STAT 361 — Elements of Statistical Methods Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 2 Description: Graphical and numerical summaries of data, statistical software package use; introduction to probability, random variables, and sampling distributions; point estimation, confidence intervals, and test of hypotheses. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181. Course Information: This course is restricted to students in the College of Engineering.

Course: STAT 362 — Elements of Statistical Computing Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 2 Description: Statistical computation with the SAS and R software packages; data structure, entry, and manipulation; numerical and graphical summaries; basic statistical methods. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 361 ; or Grade of C or better in IE 342 ; or Grade of C or better in STAT 381. Course Information: This course is restricted to students in the College of Engineering.

Course: STAT 381 — Applied Statistical Methods I Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 Description: Graphical and tabular representation of data; Introduction to probability, random variables, sampling distributions, estimation, confidence intervals, and tests of hypotheses. Includes SAS and SPSSX applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 181.

Course: STAT 382 — Statistical Methods and Computing Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 Description: Statistical computation with the SAS and R software packages: data structure, entry, and manipulation; numerical and graphical summaries; basic statistical methods; select advanced methods. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 381. Students in the BS in Data Science may satisfy the prerequisite with grade of C or better in IE 342 or ECE 341 instead of STAT 381.

Course: STAT 385 — Elementary Statistical Techniques for Machine Learning and Big Data Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 Description: Sampling algorithms; nonparametric tests; data mining: classification, clustering, LASSO, cross-validation, Principle Component Regression; and big data analysis focus on R-package. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 382 ; and consent of the instructor. Students in the BS in Data Science may satisfy the prerequisite with grade of C or better in IDS 462 instead of STAT 382. Course Information: Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Elementary Statistical Techniques for Machine Learning and Big Data
metadata.subject: Statistics (STAT)

text: Course: STAT 401 — Introduction to Probability Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Probability spaces, random variables and their distributions, conditional distribution and stochastic independence, special distributions, sampling distributions, limit theorems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 210 ; or approval of the department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 411 — Statistical Theory Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Estimation, tests of statistical hypotheses, best tests, sufficient statistics, Rao-Cramer inequality, sequential probability ratio tests, the multivariate normal distribution, nonparametric methods. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 401. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 416 — Nonparametric Statistical Methods Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Distribution free tests for location and dispersion problems, one-way and two-way layouts, the independence problem, regression problems involving slopes, detecting broad alternatives, resampling methods. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 381 or STAT 411. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 431 — Introduction to Survey Sampling Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Simple random sampling; sampling proportions; estimation of sample size; stratified random sampling; ratio estimators; regression estimators; systematic and cluster sampling. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 411 or STAT 481. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 451 — Computational Statistics Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Modern computationally-intensive statistical methods including Monte Carlo integration and simulation, optimization and maximum likelihood estimation, EM algorithm, MCMC, sampling and resampling methods, non-parametric density estimation. Prerequisites: STAT 411. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

Course: STAT 461 — Applied Probability Models I Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Computing probabilities and expectations by conditioning, Markov chains, Chapman-Kolmogorov equations, branching processes, Poisson processes and exponential distribution, continuous-time Markov chains, reversibility, uniformization. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 401. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 471 — Linear and Non-Linear Programming Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Linear programming, simplex algorithm, degeneracy, duality theorem sensitivity analysis, convexity, network simplex methods, assignment problems. Constrained and unconstrained minima. Quasi-Newton methods. Ellipsoidal methods of Kachian. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MATH 310. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 473 — Game Theory Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to the basic ideas of game theory. Static and dynamic games; mixed strategies, imperfect information; economic, political and biological applications. Prerequisites: STAT 381 ; or ECON 270 ; or equivalents. Course Information: Same as ECON 473. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 475 — Mathematics and Statistics for Actuarial Sciences I Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Financial mathematics as it pertains to the valuation of deterministic cash flows. Basic concepts and techniques regarding the theory of interest. Prerequisites: MATH 210. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Mathematics and Statistics for Actuarial Sciences I
metadata.subject: Statistics (STAT)

text: Course: STAT 481 — Applied Statistical Methods II Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Testing hypotheses, linear regression, generalized linear models, analysis of variance, factorial design, and nested design. SAS and R applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 381 ; or consent of the instructor. Students in the BS in Data Science may satisfy the prerequisite with C or better in IE 342 or ECE 341 instead of STAT 381. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 485 — Intermediate Statistical Techniques for Machine Learning and Big Data Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Modern techniques for statistical learning including linear models, subset selection, partial least squares; LDA; logistic regression; model selection; sampling theory with applications to big data analysis; applied nonparametric inference. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 385 ; and Grade of C or better in STAT 411 or STAT 481. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Intermediate Statistical Techniques for Machine Learning and Big Data
metadata.subject: Statistics (STAT)

text: Course: STAT 486 — Statistical Consulting Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Consulting methodology, data cleaning, experimental design, linear regression, missing data, categorical data analysis, logistic regression, and stat learning. R and SAS applications. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in STAT 411 or STAT 481. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: STAT 494 — Special Topics in Statistics, Probability and Operations Research Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Course content announced prior to each semester in which it is given. Topics drawn from areas such as distribution theory; Bayesian inference; discrete optimization; applied probability models; resampling techniques; biostatistics; environmental sampling. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Special Topics in Statistics, Probability and Operations Research
metadata.subject: Statistics (STAT)

text: Course: STAT 496 — Independent Study Subject: Statistics (STAT) Credits: 1-4 Description: Reading course supervised by a faculty member. Prerequisites: Approval of the instructor and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: THTR 101 — Theatre History I: Premodern Drama Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Offers an introduction to the history and development of theatre and theatrical literature from the 5th Century BCE (Ancient Greece) to the modern era, with a particular focus on Western theatre traditions. Play attendance required. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 109. Field trips required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

Course: THTR 102 — Introduction to Theatre: A Collaborative Art Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students explore the history and collaborative nature of the theatre experience through readings, lectures, and attendance at two plays. Culminates in an original small group performance. Attendance at Department of Theatre production(s) required. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Theatre: A Collaborative Art
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 103 — History of Chicago Theatre Past and Present Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students learn about the ideas, individuals, and institutions that have made Chicago one of world’s great theatre cities. Involves short readings, review of historical photo and video archives and interviews with leading contemporary Chicago artists. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: History of Chicago Theatre Past and Present
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 105 — Introduction to American Musical Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: A brief history of American musical theatre, its adaptation and alteration of earlier types of theatre, the basic structure of a classic musical, and how song and dance advance storytelling. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee. As UIC does not offer musical theatre productions, the course will require attendance at productions outside the University. At least two are anticipated, one to see/assess a traditional musical comedy and a second to see a new or contemporary example of musical theatre. Creative Arts course, and US Society course.

Course: THTR 111 — Movement I: Body/Self Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques in physical awareness and expression use of dynamics in movement and text. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 210.

Course: THTR 121 — Introduction to Acting I Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students explore basic vocal and physical stage performance techniques through improvisation and exercises. Focuses on developing truthfulness. Actors perform as themselves in given circumstances. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 161.

Course: THTR 122 — Acting II: Adaptations Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques of adapting and interpreting text from fiction, short stories and novels into short dramatic scenes which the students write and act in. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 121 ; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 263.

Course: THTR 140 — Polish Drama in Translation Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Elementary aspects of Polish dramatic theory and close reading of representative scripts selected from various periods. Course Information: Same as POL 140. Taught in English. Creative Arts course, and World Cultures course.

Course: THTR 141 — Acting I: Fundamentals Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students will be guided through a series of exercises that introduce the fundamentals of acting. Through observation, improvisation, and performances, students will learn to live truthfully in imaginary circumstances.

Course: THTR 145 — Acting Fundamentals for Non-majors Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students are guided through a series of exercises that introduce the fundamentals of acting. Through observation, improvisation, and performances, students will learn to live truthfully in imaginary circumstances in exercises and scenes from plays.

Course: THTR 150 — Fundamental of Theatre Technology Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the history and theory of theatre technology, and provides an overview of theatre technology areas of scenic, costume, lighting and sound.

Course: THTR 151 — Costume Technology I: Introduction to Costume Technology Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Fundamentals of costume construction from conception to realization, through the use of sewing machines, pattern making, and historical research with practical projects.

metadata.class_name: Costume Technology I: Introduction to Costume Technology
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 152 — Lighting Technology I: An Introduction to Lighting Tech Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory course introduces students to the basic lighting technologies used in theatre and develops knowledge about theatre electrics, controls and maintenance. Prerequisites: THTR 155 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

metadata.class_name: Lighting Technology I: An Introduction to Lighting Tech
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 153 — Scenic Technology I: An Introduction to Stagecraft for the Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the theory and techniques of stagecraft for theatrical production. Includes materials, tools, and fabrication techniques used in traditional and modern scenic construction. Prerequisites: THTR 150 ; and consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Scenic Technology I: An Introduction to Stagecraft for the Theatre
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 154 — Drawing and Digital Design for the Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Develops drawing and digital literacy. This course uses different types of traditional drawing practices and introduces students to digital media techniques, including Adobe Photoshop Creative Suite. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Drawing and Digital Design for the Theatre
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 155 — Fundamentals of Theatre Design Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the history and theory of theatre design, and provides an overview of the theatre design areas of scenic, costume, lighting, and sound. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

Course: THTR 156 — Lighting Design I: An Introduction to Lighting Design Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces basic interpretive and practical techniques in creating and enhancing 3-dimensional performance environments through lighting. Prerequisites: THTR 150 and THTR 155.

metadata.class_name: Lighting Design I: An Introduction to Lighting Design
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 157 — Drafting for the Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Develops the necessary skills in drafting for both theatre design and theatre technology. Includes hand and computer aided drafting techniques. Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 150 and Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 155 ; and consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 150 and Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 155 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 150 and Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 155 Prereq Codes (parsed): THTR 150, THTR 155 Coreq Codes (parsed): THTR 150, THTR 155

Course: THTR 158 — Costume Design I Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces foundational interpretive and practical techniques in designing stage costumes including conceptualization, rendering, and construction techniques. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 257.

Course: THTR 159 — Fashion and Furniture: History of Cultural Influences from Gothic to Atomic Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the history of fashion and furniture in Europe and North America between the Middle Ages and WWII. Using historical timelines as context, focus is placed on evidence of stylistic influences derived from cultural exchange. Creative Arts course, and Past course.

metadata.class_name: Fashion and Furniture: History of Cultural Influences from Gothic to Atomic
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 162 — Voice I: Voice Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Fundamentals of vocal production including physical and emotional characteristics and their relationship to body, space, action and emotion. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 121. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 260.

Course: THTR 170 — Sound Design: An Introduction to Sound Design for Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory course introduces students to the fundamentals of sound design used in theatre and develops knowledge of the software and hardware used in the industry. Prerequisites: THTR 155 ; and consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Sound Design: An Introduction to Sound Design for Theatre
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 182 — Practicum in Theater: Run Crew Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1 Description: Students will receive hands-on experience in the area of technical theatre by working as run crew in the areas of set, fly, props, lights or costumes for a main stage production. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: THTR 183 — Practicum in Theater: Build Crew Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1 Description: Students will receive hands-on experience in the area of technical theater by working as build crew in the areas of set, fly, props, or costumes for a main stage production. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture, one Laboratory, and one Practice.

Course: THTR 201 — Theatre History II: Modern Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Theatre theories and techniques developed between 1870 and the present, notably those of Ibsen, Appia, Stanislavsky, Meyerhold, Brecht, Artaud, and Grotowski. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 209. Recommended Background: THTR 101 is recommended for theatre majors. Creative Arts course.

Course: THTR 211 — Movement II: Body/Space Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced techniques in the physicalization of performance. Focus on relationship of body to space, time, and partner, kinesthetic response and physical action. Introduction to methods such as viewpoints, capoeira, a.o. and contact improvisation. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 111 and Grade of C or better in THTR 121 ; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 310.

Course: THTR 212 — Movement III: Somatics Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Physical theatre course for the actor. Develops self awareness and body use through Alexander Technique and Bartinieff principles. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 211 and Grade of C or better in THTR 261 and Grade of C or better in THTR 221 and advanced physical performance experience; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 410.

Course: THTR 217 — Movement & Voice I Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory course to build self-awareness of physical and vocal instrument through relaxation, dynamic alignment, concentration, free breath, full release of sound, range of motion, and spatial awareness. Will apply this awareness in performance.
Course: THTR 219 — Dance at Hubbard Street Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1 or 2 Description: Study in specialized areas of dance (ballet, tap, jazz).

Course: THTR 221 — Advanced Acting: American Drama Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students learn techniques of performing classical and modern American drama. Focus on character development and interpreting dramatic action. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 111 and Grade of C or better in THTR 121 and Grade of C or better in THTR 162 ; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 451.

Course: THTR 222 — Advanced Acting: Chekhov Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students will learn techniques of performing scenes from Chekhov's plays and short stories. Focus on Naturalistic theatre, Psychological Realism and craft of transforming into the character. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 221 and Grade of C or better in THTR 211 and Grade of C or better in THTR 261. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 458.

Course: THTR 230 — Script Analysis for Theatrical Production Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Examine and apply fundamental techniques theatre artists use to read, analyze, and organize a play script in preparation for theatrical production. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor.

Course: THTR 240 — Improvisation for the Actor Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students learn contemporary improvisation history and theory; and develop fundamental improvisation knowledge and skills through various short-form, long-form and sketch-based exercises.

Course: THTR 241 — Acting II: Scene Study Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques of interpreting text, character, and dramatic action. Includes attention to alternative dramatic forms and modes of performance. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 141 and Grade of C or better in THTR 217 and Grade of C or better in THTR 230 ; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 262.

Course: THTR 245 — East Asian Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Survey of traditional theatre forms in China, Japan, and Korea, their cultural contexts, and influence on today's theatre. Students may also choose to research theatres of South East Asia. Creative Arts course.

Course: THTR 246 — Acting Fundamentals for Non-majors II Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Building on Acting Fundamentals ( THTR 145 ), students expand knowledge of theatre ideas/vocabulary and develop acting skill through readings, scene work, audition practices, and attendance at theatre productions in Chicago and UIC. Prerequisites: THTR 145 THTR 145 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trips required at a nominal fee.

Course: THTR 250 — Scenic Design I Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduction to techniques in creating 3-dimensional performance environments including conceptualization, research, drafting, rendering, and model building. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 150. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture.

Course: THTR 251 — Costume Technology II: Intermediate Techniques, Pattern Development, and Costume Construction Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Intermediate course reinforces construction techniques and introduces pattern generation through drafting, draping, and fitting methods. Prerequisites: THTR 151 ; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Coursework or experience in clothing construction, design, or production.

metadata.class_name: Costume Technology II: Intermediate Techniques, Pattern Development, and Costume Construction
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 252 — Lighting Technology II: Intermediate Topics in Lighting Technology and Theatrical Lighting Controls Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Intermediate course provides a review of fundamental lighting technologies and introduces advanced theatrical lighting controls used in theatrical production. Prerequisites: THTR 150 and THTR 152 and THTR 157. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

metadata.class_name: Lighting Technology II: Intermediate Topics in Lighting Technology and Theatrical Lighting Controls
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 253 — Scenic Technology II: Intermediate Topics in Stagecraft Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Offers topics on a rotating basis and may include: stage properties, scenic painting, furniture construction, and scenic construction. Prerequisites: THTR 150 and THTR 153 and Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 157 ; and consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 157 Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in THTR 157 Prereq Codes (parsed): THTR 157 Coreq Codes (parsed): THTR 157

metadata.class_name: Scenic Technology II: Intermediate Topics in Stagecraft
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 254 — Stage Management Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Organization and management of personnel and procedures in a theatrical production. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 270.

Course: THTR 255 — Scenic Design II Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced interpretive and practical techniques in creating 3-dimensional performance environments including conceptualization, research, drafting, rendering and model building. Students create a design solution for one of the theatre productions. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 250.

Course: THTR 256 — Lighting Design II: Intermediate Topics in Lighting Design for the Stage Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces intermediate interpretive and practical techniques for creating and enhancing 3-dimensional theatrical performance environments through lighting. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 150 and Grade of C or better in THTR 156 ; and consent of the instructor. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

metadata.class_name: Lighting Design II: Intermediate Topics in Lighting Design for the Stage
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 258 — Costume Design II Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced practical research and rendering techniques in designing stage costumes for use in theatrical productions. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in THTR 257. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: THTR 259 — Makeup Design Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students explore principles of make-up design and application for stage performances, including prosthetics and wigs. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in THTR 150 or grade of B or better in THTR 151. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Laboratory-Discussion and one Lecture-Discussion.

Course: THTR 261 — Voice II: Speech Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: The relationship between speech, sound, and dramatic sense. Detailed work on the principles of speech. Advancement of breath and phonation skills from Voice I. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 111 and Grade of C or better in THTR 162 and Grade of C or better in THTR 122.

Course: THTR 264 — Voice III: Advanced Voice and Speech Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced techniques in the integration of voice, speech, dialects, and other text-related vocal performance skills. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 211 and Grade of C or better in THTR 221 and Grade of C or better in THTR 261. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 462.

metadata.class_name: Voice III: Advanced Voice and Speech
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 271 — Sound Design Topics Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: This intermediate to advanced course focuses on topics in sound design, acoustics, physics and technology. Prerequisites: THTR 150 and THTR 155 and THTR 157 and THTR 170 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Laboratory-Discussion.

Course: THTR 280 — Practicum in Performance Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Rehearsal and performance techniques, including script analysis, characterization, voice, movement, directing, or design. Prerequisites: Approval of the department and completion of a successful audition. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 18 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: THTR 281 — Practicum in Theatre Administration Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1-6 Description: Planning and execution of specific projects in theatre administration and box office; publicity, budget, marketing, house management, and scheduling. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: THTR 282 — Practicum in Costuming Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1-6 Description: Practical experience in all aspects of construction and maintenance, including millinery, mask making, wig making, pattern drafting, and makeup application. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 15 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: THTR 283 — Practicum in Technical Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1-6 Description: Practical experience in various technical areas: scenery construction, set painting, stage lighting, sound, and properties construction. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 15 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: THTR 284 — Seminar on Play in Production Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Research and development for play production using the current University production as an example. Special topics. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

Course: THTR 299 — Individual Topics Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Individual investigation of special problems. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: THTR 311 — Movement IV: Style Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces, explores and applies movement specific to various time periods; including elements of period gesture, dance, and costume. Matches vocal and acting work explored in the same semester. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 212 and Grade of C or better in THTR 222 and Grade of C or better in THTR 264. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 411.

Course: THTR 312 — Movement V: Character Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Specialized instruction in the subjects of commedia, clowning and mask work. Introduction to 16th and 17th century style of Italian street theatre emphasizing stock characters. physical stunts and improvised text. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 311 and Grade of C or better in THTR 361 and Grade of C or better in THTR 321. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 412.

Course: THTR 317 — Movement & Voice II Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introductory work on the actor’s instrument—relaxation, alignment, released and supported sound, spatial dynamics—explored along with emotional access and integration of the instrument and the actor. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 217.

Course: THTR 321 — Advanced Acting: Shakespeare Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students learn techniques of performing monologues and scenes from Shakespeare's plays. Focus on Magical Realism and techniques of performing in verse. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 222 and Grade of C or better in THTR 264 and Grade of C or better in THTR 212 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 452.

Course: THTR 322 — Advanced Acting: Brecht, Beckett, Pinter Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques of performing styles in the theatre of alienation and the theatre of the absurd. Focus on interpreting characters from plays by Brecht, Beckett and Pinter. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 311 and Grade of C or better in THTR 321 and Grade of C or better in THTR 361. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 467.

Course: THTR 331 — Page to Stage: Adaptation of Text for Theatrical Performance Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Explores the history, methods, ethics, and aesthetics of adapting non-dramatic texts including fiction, non-fiction, personal narratives and found texts for theatrical performance. No adaptation experience required. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 231.

metadata.class_name: Page to Stage: Adaptation of Text for Theatrical Performance
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 332 — Performance Ethnography Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students engage performance as a subject and method of study as they investigate the methods and ethics of conducting ethnographic research and creating performance in order to explore how people express, negotiate, and create identity and meaning. Course Information: Same as ANTH 332. Previously listed as THTR 350. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice. Recommended Background: Considerable interest in performance and/or ethnography is important; but no formal performance or ethnography training is required.

Course: THTR 333 — Stage Direction Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Exploration of conceptual planning and implementation skills for the stage director ranging from script interpretation to rehearsal and performance. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 101 and Grade of C or better in THTR 201 and Grade of C or better in THTR 230 ; and Grade of C or better in THTR 121 or Grade of C or better in THTR 141. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 465. Performance projects required.

Course: THTR 341 — Acting III: Classics Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students will learn the history, structures, and elements of classical theatre; explore heightened language; and apply this to performance of Greek drama, Commedia Dell’arte, and the plays of Shakespeare, Moliere, Chekhov or Shaw. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 141 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 241 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 230.

Course: THTR 351 — Costume Technology III: Advanced Techniques in Costume Crafts Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced course introduces students to specialized production techniques in the field of costume crafts, including alternative construction materials and safety procedures for these materials. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in THTR 151 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated.

metadata.class_name: Costume Technology III: Advanced Techniques in Costume Crafts
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 352 — Lighting Technology III: Advanced Lighting Technology and Controls for Production Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced course expands students’ knowledge of lighting technologies, controls and visualization tools used in the entertainment industry. Students will have the opportunity to develop professional relationships. Prerequisites: THTR 150 and THTR 152 and THTR 252. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

metadata.class_name: Lighting Technology III: Advanced Lighting Technology and Controls for Production
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 353 — Scenic Technology III: Advanced Technical Problems Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced course introduces students to theories and techniques in technical direction for theatrical productions and covers topics in scenic construction, material selection, fabrication processes, and applied project management. Prerequisites: THTR 150 and THTR 153 and THTR 157 ; and consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Scenic Technology III: Advanced Technical Problems
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 354 — Stage Management Topics Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Intermediate to advanced course focuses on topics of theatrical production and personnel management. Prerequisites: THTR 150 and THTR 154 ; and consent of the instructor.

Course: THTR 355 — Scenic Design III: Advanced Scenic Design for the Stage Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced course builds upon visual and verbal communication, collaboration skills, using interpretive and practical techniques in conceptualization, creating 3-dimensional scenic design model, research, drafting, model making, paint elevation. Prerequisites: THTR 154 and THTR 155 and THTR 157 and THTR 250 and THTR 255 ; and consent of the instructor.

metadata.class_name: Scenic Design III: Advanced Scenic Design for the Stage
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 356 — Lighting Design III: Advanced Lighting for the Stage Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Advanced course develops advanced visual and verbal design collaboration skills, and expands knowledge of the creative and implementation process. Students create lighting design projects from a music or movement based source material. Prerequisites: THTR 155 and THTR 156 and THTR 256 ; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee.

metadata.class_name: Lighting Design III: Advanced Lighting for the Stage
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 358 — Costume Design III: Advanced Costume Design for the Stage Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Builds upon visual and verbal communication skills and delves further into critical analysis and interpretation of classical and contemporary texts. Students will create full costume designs for two theatrical texts. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in THTR 155 and Grade of B or better in THTR 158 and Grade of B or better in THTR 258 ; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Grade of B or better in THTR 151 and Grade of B or better in THTR 251.

metadata.class_name: Costume Design III: Advanced Costume Design for the Stage
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 361 — Voice IV: Text Styles Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques in various styles of classical and contemporary text, especially heightened language. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 212 or Grade of C or better in THTR 222 or Grade of C or better in THTR 264. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 477.

Course: THTR 362 — Voice V: Dialects Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Techniques in acting through song and performing in a dialect in musicals and/or plays. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 311 and Grade of C or better in THTR 321 and Grade of C or better in THTR 361. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 478.

Course: THTR 383 — Special Projects in Theatrical Design Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1-3 Description: Design for the contemporary stage and other performance spaces. Problems in conceptualization, realization, and execution. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 250 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated. Previously listed as THTR 464.

Course: THTR 384 — Teaching Artist Seminar Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to history of arts in education, and provides hands-on training that prepares them to serve as teaching artists in elementary, high-school, and community settings. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Students must have satisfactorily completed at least one 200-level practice-based course in the Departments of Theatre, Music, or Art.

Course: THTR 385 — Teaching Artist Practicum Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Provides students who have completed the teaching artist seminar course with an opportunity to develop expertise as teaching artists through 6-to10-week internship placements with master teachers at Chicago organizations. Prerequisites: THTR 384 ; and consent of the instructor.

Course: THTR 388 — Special Projects in Performance Training Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Training in varying advanced techniques of performance. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours. Previously listed as THTR 466.

Course: THTR 403 — Topics on Performance Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Explores topics of contemporary performance history, theory or practice. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 463.

Course: THTR 413 — Movement VI: Movement Lab Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Ensemble created physical theatre. Introduction to devised work. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 312 and Grade of C or better in THTR 322 and Grade of C or better in THTR 362.

Course: THTR 421 — Advanced Acting: Ensemble Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Students develop a performance as they learn techniques and models for working within an ensemble. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 312 and Grade of C or better in THTR 322 and Grade of C or better in THTR 362. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated up to 1 time(s). Previously listed as THTR 459.

Course: THTR 422 — Advanced Acting: Audition Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Selection and performing of audition pieces from theatre, film and television. Professional seminars and discussions with actors, directors, agents and casting directors. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 413 and Grade of C or better in THTR 321 and Grade of C or better in THTR 461 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 475.

Course: THTR 431 — Playwriting Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: The development of scripts for stage performance. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as ENGL 495. Previously listed as THTR 423. Recommended Background: For BA Theatre majors: THTR 101 , 201 , and 230.

Course: THTR 435 — Contemporary Performance Techniques Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: The relationship of contemporary theory and performance techniques with attention to both text and non-text based forms. Topics vary. Performance projects required. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 101 and Grade of C or better in THTR 201 and Grade of C or better in THTR 230 ; and Grade of C or better in THTR 121 or Grade of C or better in THTR 141. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 470.

Course: THTR 444 — Drama in Its Cultural Context I Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Drama in its social and cultural context, through the seventeenth century. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Drama in Its Cultural Context I
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 445 — Drama in Its Cultural Context II Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Drama in its social and cultural context, eighteenth to twentieth centuries. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Drama in Its Cultural Context II
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 448 — The Business of Theatre: A Career in the Arts Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Prepares theatre students to navigate an ever-changing professional landscape as focused and well-rounded theatre artists. Students work with a primary instructor and local professionals. Students create a personalized professional plan. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 101 and Grade of C or better in THTR 141 and Grade of C or better in THTR 182 and Grade of C or better in THTR 183 and Grade of C or better in THTR 201 and Grade of C or better in THTR 217 ; and Grade of C or better in THTR 230 ; and senior standing or above; and approval of the department. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in THTR 241 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 317 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 341.

metadata.class_name: The Business of Theatre: A Career in the Arts
metadata.subject: Theatre (THTR)

text: Course: THTR 449 — Capstone: Senior Project Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students in their final year will develop, perform in, direct or author a performance piece that will be presented as their capstone project in front of audience. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 141 and Grade of C or better in THTR 101 and Grade of C or better in THTR 201 and Grade of C or better in THTR 150 and Grade of C or better in THTR 151 and Grade of C or better in THTR 230 ; and THTR 217 and THTR 241 and THTR 317 and THTR 341 and ISA 120; and THTR 431 or THTR 333 or THTR 332 or THTR 231 or THTR 240 or THTR 435 ; and approval of the department.

Course: THTR 450 — Portfolio Production Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Students learn portfolio production and presentation protocols and techniques-both aural and visual-and produce a professional portfolio of their design work. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 141 and Grade of C or better in THTR 101 and Grade of C or better in THTR 201 and Grade of C or better in THTR 230 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 254 ; and Grade of C or better in THTR 150 and Grade of C or better in THTR 155 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 154 and Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in THTR 157 ; and Grade of C or better in AH 111 ; and junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Completion of DPT coursework through the 200-level in one or more specific areas.

Course: THTR 461 — Voice VI: Voice Lab Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 3 Description: Ensemble and individual experiences in various advanced voice and speech techniques. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in THTR 312 and Grade of C or better in THTR 322 and Grade of C or better in THTR 362. Course Information: Previously listed as THTR 479.

Course: THTR 491 — Study Abroad in Theatre Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 0-16 Description: Study abroad within an approved foreign exchange program or departmentsponsored program. Prerequisites: Approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated with approval. Approval to repeat course granted by the department.

Course: THTR 494 — Internship Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1-8 Description: Students work in an approved professional setting. Individual projects developed through conferences with a faculty member and a field supervisor. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above and 12 hours of upper-division courses in theatre, with a 3.00 grade point average in those courses and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours for undergraduate students; or 8 hours for graduate students. Undergraduate credit should be in multiples of 3. Only three hours may be applied toward theatre major requirements.

Course: THTR 498 — Independent Study Subject: Theatre (THTR) Credits: 1-4 Description: Individual investigation of special problems that may be student-initiated or related to faculty research. May also be used for special University-sponsored projects, such as interdisciplinary seminars. Prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing and approval of the department. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term.

Course: UPA 120 — Urban and Public Affairs Seminar I Subject: Urban and Public Affairs (UPA) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces first year students to the College of Urban Planning and Public Affairs. Emphasizes competencies such as public speaking, presentations, dialogue around controversial urban and policy issues, effective teamwork, conflict resolution, communication and proposal writing. Prerequisites: Undergraduate student with fewer than 24 credit hours. No graduation credit given to students enrolled in Graduate College. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Urban and Public Affairs Seminar I
metadata.subject: Urban and Public Affairs (UPA)

text: Course: UPA 121 — Urban and Public Affairs Seminar II Subject: Urban and Public Affairs (UPA) Credits: 1 Description: Introduces first year students to the College of Urban Planning and Public Affairs. Emphasizes competencies such as analysis of controversial urban and policy issues, effective teamwork, project planning and management, and professional communication. Prerequisites: Continuing or entering student with fewer than 24 credit hours. Course Information: Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only.

metadata.class_name: Urban and Public Affairs Seminar II
metadata.subject: Urban and Public Affairs (UPA)

text: Course: UPA 498 — Independent Study in Urban Planning and Public Affairs Subject: Urban and Public Affairs (UPA) Credits: 1-3 Description: Provides an opportunity for students to pursue an independent project that is not availble through the required UPA coursework. Prerequisites: Admission to the BA in Urban and Public Affairs Program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as UPP 498. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours.

metadata.class_name: Independent Study in Urban Planning and Public Affairs
metadata.subject: Urban and Public Affairs (UPA)

text: Course: UPP 220 — Latin American Cities in a Global Context: Environment, Employment, and Housing Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 Description: Global economic trends impacting Latin American cities, with a focus on three urban planning issues: environment, employment and housing. Growing inequality, precarious employment, spatial segregation, and squatter settlements will be explored. Same as LALS 220. Recommended Background: LALS 101.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Cities in a Global Context: Environment, Employment, and Housing
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 302 — Great Cities Internship Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 6 Description: Provides students an opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge and conduct research in metropolitan organizations through field placements and seminars. Prerequisites: Junior or senior standing and grade point average of 3.00, or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as POLS 302. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Practice.

Course: UPP 403 — Just and Sustainable Planning Practices for Great Cities Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduces and explores urban planning practices, with an emphasis on sustainability and social and environmental justice. Addresses real-world sustainable planning problem. Prerequisites: Advanced undergraduate standing or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Just and Sustainable Planning Practices for Great Cities
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 405 — Researching the City Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 0-4 Description: Addresses basic issues of quantitative reasoning in planning and policy, including use of data sources, organizing, sorting, managing, and analyzing data. Emphasizes presenting findings visually and in writing. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ECON 120 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Field work required. Recommended Background: Grade of B or better or concurrent registration in US 202. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation.

Course: UPP 420 — Great Cities: London and Chicago Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 1-8 Description: Comparative investigation of urban, economic, social, and political issues in the two global cities. Includes classes, study, and living in London. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above and selection by the Office of Study Abroad admission committee. Course Information: Field work required.

Course: UPP 452 — The UIC Freshwater Lab Course Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Brings a Humanities lens to the Great Lakes watershed to examine how water interacts with socio-political systems, legal structures, cultural perceptions, and artistic visions. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ENGL 452 and PA 452. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: UPP 453 — Freshwater Lab in Practice: Environmental Research, Projects, and Internships Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Investigates key issues surrounding Great Lakes water governance through a combination of hands-on research and professional development in fields related to environmental policy, planning, writing and communication. Prerequisites: ENGL 160 and ENGL 161. Course Information: Same as ENGL 453 and PA 453. 3 undergraduate hours; 4 graduate hours. This course offers an internship placement opportunity. Depending on placement/start date, students may begin internship work during the second half of the semester or during the summer.

metadata.class_name: Freshwater Lab in Practice: Environmental Research, Projects, and Internships
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 458 — Introduction to Geospatial Analysis and Visualization I Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 2 Description: A basic introduction to the softwares used and rules governing effective communication of geospatial and other data in visual format. Prerequisites: Graduate standing. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester. Credit is not given for UPP 458 if the student has credit in UPP 460.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Geospatial Analysis and Visualization I
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 459 — Introduction to Geospatial Analysis and Visualization II Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 2 Description: In-depth instruction in softwares used and rules governing effective communication of geospatial and other data in visual format. Exploration of design principles for communicating complex information in a variety of formats. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in UPP 458 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Credit is not given for UPP 459 if the student has credit in UPP 460. Extensive computer use required. Meets eight weeks of the semester.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Geospatial Analysis and Visualization II
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 460 — Introduction to Geospatial Analysis and Visualization Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Exploration of geospatial analysis and visualization theory and tools; how to appropriately choose and use tools. Cognition, communication, modeling, cartography, web authoring, 3-D visualization, and aerial and satellite photography. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and approval of the deparment. Priority registration will be given to students admitted to the campus certificate program in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Centrino 2 Duo processor, 2 GB RAM and 100 GB hard drive minimum recommendations.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Geospatial Analysis and Visualization
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 461 — Geographic Information Systems for Planning and Policy Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Applications of Geographic Information Systems to understanding spatial relationships for their importance in planning use and policy making across a variety of disciplines/policy sectors. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Students enrolled in the Geographic Information Systems minor must first complete US 261 and US 361 , in this sequential order. Priority registration will be given to students admitted to a campus certificate program in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization. Course Information: Same as GEOG 469. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Geographic Information Systems for Planning and Policy
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 462 — Intermediate GIS for Planning and Policy Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: To reinforce and expand on topics taught in UPP 461 and introduce more advanced features of GIS and its applications to urban planning and policy. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in UPP 461 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Priority registration will be given to students admitted to the campus Certificate in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Intermediate GIS for Planning and Policy
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 463 — Complexity-based Models for Planning and Policy Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduction to complexity-based models and their possible applications to a range of planning and public policy issues. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and approval of the deparment. Priority registration will be given to students admitted to the campus certificate program in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Experience in object-oriented programming is helpful but not required.
