metadata.class_name: Complexity-based Models for Planning and Policy
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 464 — Advanced Visualization Techniques Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Specialized computational abilities for various planning areas including: database and spreadsheet analyses, spatial information systems, imageries and image editing, 3D modeling and virtual reality, hypermedia or multimedia, and the internet. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and approval of the deparment. Priority registration will be given to students admitted to the campus certificate program in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Extensive computer use required. Centrino 2 Duo with at least 2GB RAM and 110 GB hard drive minimum recommended specifications.

Course: UPP 465 — Topics in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 0-5 Description: Intensive exploration of specialized topics in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in UPP 460 ; or Grade of B or better in UPP 461 ; and appropriate score on the department placement test; and senior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 2 to 5 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours for undergraduate students and 12 hours for graduate students. Students may register in more than one section per term. Extensive computer use required.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Geospatial Analysis and Visualization
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 470 — Cohort Seminar for Urban Developers Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Application of the financial calculator, use of spreadsheets, and other tools commonly used in real estate-based urban development projects. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: UPP 471 — Housing and Community Development for Urban Developers Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Housing policy at federal, state and local levels affecting urban housing markets. Emphasis on assessment of market conditions affecting community development decisions. Prerequisites: UPP 470 or consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Housing and Community Development for Urban Developers
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 472 — Development Finance For Urban Developers Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Key financial principles of real estate development, particularly those related to the financing of affordable housing. How to develop a real estate pro forma. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: UPP 473 — Organizational Essentials for Urban Developers Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Theory and practice of management in public and non-profit settings. Focus on developing communication, leadership and legal skills for each step in development. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

Course: UPP 474 — Community Development Process for Urban Developers Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Developing affordable housing: development team, acquisition strategy, legal issues, construction management and project sustainability, as it pertains to different types of housing developments. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Community Development Process for Urban Developers
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 475 — Sustaining the Housing for Urban Developers Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 or 4 Description: Introduces students to a range of management issues: property management and maintenance, resident relations and services, and financial/ asset management as it relates to sustaining affordable housing. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

metadata.class_name: Sustaining the Housing for Urban Developers
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 492 — Topics in Urban and Public Affairs Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 Description: In depth study of selected issues of urban and public affairs. Prerequisites: Admission to the BA Program in Urban and Public Affairs or consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register for more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Urban and Public Affairs
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 493 — Topics in Urban Planning and Policy Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 1-4 Description: Intensive analysis of selected planning problems or policy issues. Prerequisites: Junior standing or above; and consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Students may register for more than one section per term.

metadata.class_name: Topics in Urban Planning and Policy
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: UPP 494 — Senior Capstone Experience in Urban and Public Affairs I Subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP) Credits: 3 Description: A selection of a capstone topic and introductory research on the topic. Prerequisites: Senior standing or above; Admission to the BA in Urban and Public Affairs Program or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Conference.

metadata.class_name: Senior Capstone Experience in Urban and Public Affairs I
metadata.subject: Urban Planning and Policy (UPP)

text: Course: US 100 — Concepts in Geography Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Geographic concepts drawn from the areas of cultural, urban, economic, global, and regional geography. Course Information: Same as GEOG 100. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Discussion/Recitation and one Lecture. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

Course: US 101 — Introduction to Urban Studies Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: General survey of urban issues and experience using an interdisciplinary approach. Course Information: Previously listed as UPP 101. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. US Society course.

Course: US 130 — Principles of Urban Sustainability Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to fundamental principles, interdisciplinary approaches, historical trends, policies and planning programs that promote sustainability in urban regions. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. US Society course.

Course: US 140 — Introduction to Urban Transportation Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Examines how different layers of transportation systems are planned, operated and managed; effect of time and spatial scales; how systems address mobility and access; long term impacts of policy; effect of transportation technology on urban form. Course Information: Field work required. Individual and Society course.

Course: US 199 — Independent Study in Urban Studies Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 1-3 Description: Study and analysis of topics selected by the student under the guidance of a faculty advisor. Prerequisites: Consent of the instructor. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Students may register in more than one section per term. Previously listed as UPP 199.

Course: US 202 — Social Justice and the City Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Overview of diversity, justice, and equity within an urban framework; cultural shifts and political movements shaping concerns about social justice; theoretical approaches and literature explaining forces and factors underlying these issues. Course Information: Previously listed as UPP 202. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion. US Society course.

Course: US 205 — Cinema and the City Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Explores how diverse societies, cities and urban phenomena are represented in film at different points in history, explores theories of urbanism and individual relationships to cities and urban society and institutions. Course Information: Previously listed as UPP 205. Students are required to view films outside of regular class hours. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. Individual and Society course.

Course: US 208 — Mapping the Urban: Cartography and its Alternatives Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Maps both represent space and influence the spatial imaginary. From traditional cartography to new media, the course will explore the power and possibilities of mapping and counter-mapping as narratives of space, power and social relations. Course Information: Same as GEOG 208. Previously listed as UPP 208. Individual and Society course.

metadata.class_name: Mapping the Urban: Cartography and its Alternatives
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 220 — Latin American Cities in a Global Context: Environment, Employment, and Housing Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Global economic trends impacting Latin American cities, with a focus on three urban planning issues: environment, employment and housing. Growing inequality, precarious employment, spatial segregation, and squatter settlements will be explored. Course Information: Same as LALS 220. Individual and Society course, and World Cultures course.

metadata.class_name: Latin American Cities in a Global Context: Environment, Employment, and Housing
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 230 — Practices for Sustainable Cities Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction to topical issues of sustainable urban development and surveys emerging sustainability practices. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better in US 130. To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation. US Society course.

Course: US 240 — Urban and Community Economics Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Surveys economic perspectives on urban processes, including the location decisions of households and firms, the determinants of urban economic development, and the theory and practice of community economic development. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation.

Course: US 250 — Analyzing the City Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses basic issues of quantitative reasoning in urban studies, including use of data sources, organizing, sorting, managing, and analyzing data. Emphasizes presenting findings visually, in writing, and through social media. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Recommended Background: Grade of B or better or concurrent registration in US 202.

Course: US 261 — Mapping, Data, and Geographic Information Systems Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an introduction to the tools and techniques of mapping, the relationship between data and cartography, and the basic concepts of geographic information systems softwares. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Mapping, Data, and Geographic Information Systems
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 296 — Special Topics in Urban Studies Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Special Topics in Urban Studies. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Credit or concurrent registration in one course at the 200-level Corequisites: Credit or concurrent registration in one course at the 200-level Course Information: Field trip required at a nominal fee. Recommended Background: Nine hours of coursework in Urban Studies or Public Policy, including credit or concurrent registration in one course at the 200-level.

Course: US 301 — Political Economy of Urban Development Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Political and economic approaches to the study of urban life, urban problems and the built environment. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in US 240 ; or Grade of B or better in ECON 120 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as UPA 301. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in on Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation.

Course: US 304 — Visualizing the City: Methods and Tools for Representing the City Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Addresses basics of visualization methods and techniques of representing the physical environment. Prerequisites: Open only to juniors and seniors; and approval of the department or admission to the BA Program in Urban Studies. Course Information: Previously listed as UPA 304. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must register for one Lecture and one Discussion/Recitation.

metadata.class_name: Visualizing the City: Methods and Tools for Representing the City
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 306 — Urban Policy Analysis Methods Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Introduces students to the basics of policy and program evaluation using rational model. Needs analysis, performance evaluation, data collection methods and analysis, discounting valuation problems. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in US 240 ; or Grade of B or better in ECON 120 ; and junior standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as UPA 306.

Course: US 308 — Globalization and Environmental Planning Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: How globalization and climate change are impacting cities. Examines new toolkits, activist movements, and mitigation strategies in urban governance and environmental planning. Considers local political economic contexts and implications for justice. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in US 240 ; or Grade of B or better in ECON 120 ; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Previously listed as UPP 308.

Course: US 309 — Public Budgeting and Financial Management Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Government budgeting, financial, management and the reciprocal relationship between government and the economy. Prerequisites: PPOL 210 and admission to the BA in Public Policy or Urban Studies; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PPOL 309.

Course: US 361 — Introduction to Geographic Information Systems I Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) adds spatial analysis and communication to the critical thinking toolbox. This course, the first in a two semester sequence, introduces students to basic GIS data concepts and map making techniques. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above and Grade of C or better in US 261 or equivalent; or instructor approval. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Students must have access to a PC on which they can install software, and meeting the system requirements detailed on the ESRI website at: http://www.esri.com/software/arcgis/arcgis-for-desktop/system-requirements. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in US 100 or Grade of C or better in GEOG 175.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems I
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 362 — Introduction to Geographic Information Systems II Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) adds spatial analysis and communication to the critical thinking toolbox. This course, the second in a two semester sequence, introduces students to basic GIS data concepts and map making techniques. Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in US 361 ; and sophomore standing or above. Course Information: Extensive computer use required. Students must have access to a PC on which they can install software, and meeting the system requirements detailed on the ESRI website at: http://www.esri.com/software/arcgis/arcgis-for-desktop/system-requirements. Recommended Background: Grade of C or better or concurrent registration in GEOG 100.

metadata.class_name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems II
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 390 — Sustainability Internship Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Provides an intellectual framework for students to apply classroom learning to hands-on project-based internships that advance the overall mission of greater social, economic and environmental sustainability in the campus community. Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in US 130 ; or Grade of C or better in PHYS 116. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PUBH 390. Students will be placed in internships with UIC departments and units for approximately 8 hours per week.

Course: US 490 — International Student Exchange Program Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 0-18 Description: The Student Exchange Program enables the reciprocal exchange of students between UIC and colleges or universities in other countries. There are a variety of programs tailored to meet the needs of CUPPA students. Prerequisites: Completion of the English Composition requirement; and junior standing or above; and approval of the College of Urban Planning and Public Affairs; and approval of the Office of International Affairs. Course Information: May be repeated for a maximum of 36 credit hours per academic year or for a total of 48 hours, all of which must be earned within one calendar year. Determination of the number of credits to be granted is part of the proposal approval process. Previously listed as UPA 490. Field work required.

Course: US 491 — Internship Experience in Public Policy and Urban Studies Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Two hundred twenty-five hours of service learning/practical experience through an internship placement approved by the Urban Studies Program. Prerequisites: Sophomore standing or above; or consent of the instructor. Course Information: Same as PPOL 491. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory grading only. May be repeated. Previously listed as UPA 491. Field work required.

metadata.class_name: Internship Experience in Public Policy and Urban Studies
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 495 — Senior Capstone Experience in Urban Studies Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 3 Description: Students synthesize and draw upon knowledge learned in the program to engage in projects in the urban community. Prerequisites: UPP 405 ; and senior standing or above; or consent of the instructor or admission to the Urban Studies major. Course Information: Previously listed as UPP 495. Field work required. Class Schedule Information: To be properly registered, students must enroll in one Lecture-Discussion and one Conference.

metadata.class_name: Senior Capstone Experience in Urban Studies
metadata.subject: Urban Studies (US)

text: Course: US 498 — Independent Study in Urban Studies Subject: Urban Studies (US) Credits: 1-3 Description: Provides an opportunity for students to pursue an independent project that is not availble through the required US coursework. Prerequisites: Open only to juniors and seniors; or consent of the instructor. Previously listed as UPP 498. Course Information: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.
